Title: Mondo - Zen In The Balance / Zen In America - Tricycle Article
Caption or Other Speaker:
Daido Roshi leads a mondo, discussing the  Spring 1994 Tricycle article "Zen in the Balance", which is an excerpt from Helen Tworkov's book, "Zen in America". 

Contains the text discussed in the Mondo
Extracted Text:
Zen in the Balance: Can It Survive America?
We must ask ourselves if the Americanization of Zen now under way is a necessary cultural
adaptation or a justification for the co-optation of Zen by secular materialists.
By Helen Tworkov | Spring 1994
This essay has been adapted for Tricycle from the afterword that has been added to the forthcoming
edition of Zen in America. Written by Tricycleâ€™s editor, Helen Tworkov, the book follows the
movement of Japanese Zen to the United States through portraits of Robert Aitken, Jakusho
Kwong, Bernard Glassman, Maurine Stuart, and Richard Baker. Zen in America was originally
published in 1988 by North Point Press and was reissued in the spring of 1994 by Kodansha America.
Speaker: John Daido Loori

Title: What Limits Your Freedom?
Extracted Text:
This is from the Transmission of the Light, the 32nd Zen ancestor, Daozhen.

Daozhen said to the Zen master Tsang San, “I beg your compassion. Please give me a way of liberation.” Tsang San said, “Who is binding you?” Daozhen said, “No one is binding me.” Tsang San said, “Then why seek liberation?” At these words, Daozhen was enlightened.

In Kazon's verse: “When mind is empty, pure knowledge has no right or wrong. Here I don’t know what there is to bind or free. Even if you distinguish the elements of body and mind, seeing, hearing, sound, and form are ultimately not another.”

So this collection is sort of presenting the Zen ancestors, beginning with the Buddha and then down to Ejo—Dogen’s, one of Dogen’s successors. And so Daozhen, this is very early in the Chan tradition. So Bodhidharma, Huike, Seng San who wrote the Faith Mind, and Daozhen—the fourth Chinese ancestor. So late 500s, early 600s, very early.

And, you know, all of the teachings that come down to us—the records of different masters and going back to the sutras of the Buddha—you know, with the distance of time and just seeing things in print and kind of getting so accustomed to that, you know, we can know that this comes down to us through people, practitioners in every generation, beginning with the Buddha. But to really think about that, you know, how here we are sitting sesshin, getting ready to do ango. We have our own Buddhist practice, our own meditation practice. We study these teachings. And that’s been happening for all of these centuries. Just people, human beings living in their own time, in their own iteration of samsara, and thinking, “This is it.” Seeking, looking for some sanity, some sense of how to go about it a different way.

I was reading an early, one of the original sutras earlier, Nanda—not Ananda, but Nanda—who was a cowherd, he tended somebody else’s cows. And the Buddha was once with some of his disciples teaching, and Nanda with his cows was sort of on the periphery just listening. And he was so taken by the Buddha’s teaching that once the Buddha finished, he said, “I hear your teachings. I want to enter the way. Please ordain me right now.” And he said, “Cowherd, take your cows and give them back to the owner.” And Nanda said, “They’ll find their own way. They’ll figure it out. They’ll get home.” He said, “No, take them back, give them to their owner, and then come back.” And that’s what he did. He took them back, came back and was ordained, and went on to become one of the Buddha’s realized disciples.

And I thought it was such an interesting... you know, the Buddha said, take care of this, finish this before you begin something. But to think of just wandering around—he was at work, right? Nanda was just at work. He’s just out tending the cows. He didn’t wake up planning to be a monk. He just overheard the Buddha. So you’re just wandering around and you bump into the Buddha. That happened back then.

So Daozhen comes to Tsang San and says, “I beg your compassion. Please give me a way of liberation. I seek enlightenment. I seek release.” And students, practitioners, I think, can be shy about being so forthright, as though it’s presumptuous or arrogant or conceited. But to want to seek freedom from presumption and arrogance and conceit—is that egoistic? It’s easy to feel like it’s unrealistic, out of reach, only for the few. But the Buddha didn’t teach that way. He taught everyone who came to him and asked for the Dharma. So they were asking because they were capable. They had the capacity not just to hear and not just put it into practice, but to realize themselves.

And so walking this Eightfold Path, this path of liberation, of non-attachment, of compassion, loving kindness—every step we take, every day of honest practice is walking that path. And in some way, without measure, we come closer. So we shouldn’t be afraid to aspire, to speak those words. If you feel shy, do it in the privacy of your own home to begin, do it at your altar. “As I enter into this day as a practitioner of the Dharma, may I awaken my mind. May I realize enlightenment.” Get used to that. But of course, that presupposes seeking that, wanting that, wanting to practice, wanting to engage in a path to be liberated.

Daozhen says, but liberated from what? Well, Daozhen says, “I am bound. Please give me a way of liberation. Liberate me from what constricts and confines and makes my life not its full.” And I suppose a person can go through their life and never ask that question, “What is binding me? Who is binding me?” While shining the light upon themselves, but always outwards, right? Because there’s always somebody to blame. There’s always something going on out there that is giving us headaches or worse—something, someone that’s not right, that is wrong, that’s making our lives more difficult.

Maezumi Roshi, as we’re entering into the sort of celebration time, our 45th anniversary—one of the reasons I wanted to focus on Genjokoan is because it was something that Daido Roshi dearly loved. It was something he taught us and brought into our training and teachings, and also because it helps to connect with our lineage. It was important to him. We’re going to use his commentary, and there’s a talk by Maezumi Roshi where he says, “Our life is usually so hectic that we can quite easily lose ourselves. Zazen is a wonderful opportunity to face yourself and closely study yourself. In a way, it’s almost a joke to have to find out who we are or to realize what our life is. Our life, this life, it’s already in realization. It is already manifesting. So what is there to look for? When we look for something, the Buddha calls this delusion. Unfortunately, this is what all of us do in one way or another.”

And then he talks about the koan where there’s a student who says to his teacher, “I want to peck from the inside. Would you please tap from the outside?” When an egg is ready to hatch, the chick inside pecks at the shell, and the mother hen senses it and taps on the outside. When it’s time, just a little tap on the outside breaks the shell, and the chick hatches. If the shell breaks too soon or too late, the chick dies. So the student says, “Please tap from the outside.” Then he asks, “What is the point of this koan?” Roshi says, and he says, “I’m ready. Please let me come out.” And then he asks, “Where’s the shell? Where’s the hindrance that keeps you from coming out? What is binding you?” He says, there’s an expression in Japanese: “Without a rope, people bind themselves.” Roshi says, “You yourself do not think you are completely free. So you practice trying to liberate yourself. But what is binding you? Look around you. Nothing is binding you. And yet something is binding you. ‘I’m ready to come out. Please let me come out.’”

And there is a kind of... Daido Roshi talked about this a lot. Tap, tap, peck, peck. And there's that—it is a kind of a description of something that happens in training, the teacher. But the true power, the door that needs to open, is always in the hands of the student. And so how to liberate this sense of being bound—that’s what we’re doing. We’re trying to liberate ourselves from a delusion, right? Not from an actual constriction, although there is constriction. But what we’re trying to free ourselves from is the sense of that constriction, the sense of our delusion, which is just showing us how powerful our mind is to create a sense of something that, in essence, can’t be found, has no essence, and yet sets us seeking and is at the root of all the human suffering.

And so the Buddha said, “See everything that is impermanent—in your eyes, in the objects that your eyes see, in your consciousness that is seeing. When your eyes touch an object, there’s a moment of contact and there’s a feeling, a sensation. You like what you see, you don’t like what you see, you’re indifferent.” He said, “See that each aspect is impermanent.” Why is that important? The Buddha said, when we see that clearly, we become disenchanted. When we realize there’s nothing there that's permanent, we become disenchanted.

He said, “See everything that is dependently arising—when the ears hear and consciousness knows the sound of what is being heard. And there is contact and there is feeling—liking, not liking, neutral.” The Buddha said, “See that in that, nothing has any self existence. Nothing happens on its own, is separate from seeing, from hearing, from consciousness.” And he presents these teachings and really meditations as paths of liberation. That when we see that, we become disenchanted. When we realize there’s no self-being, no own-being, that we realize that there’s no solidity to anything. So what are we grasping at? What is binding us?

There’s a... in the Therigatha, the collection of poems by nuns at the time of the Buddha, there’s one of the nuns, one of the verses is from Sisu Pacchala, who had a sister Chala, and another sister named Upachala. And the three sisters were all the younger sisters of Sariputra, who was one of the foremost disciples of the Buddha. We chant his name every morning—the Heart Sutra. So this is some family, right? So they all go to the Buddha and ordain. And the footnote on her says their parents were not happy. That’s going to lead them to also want to go ordain, or never want to go anywhere near. So in her poem, she says:

“The nun, filled with virtues, with the ways we know the world, well-controlled, attains the state of peace, sublime and sweet.” 

And then Mara, speaking to her, says, “Yeah, but you know, there are gods in the heavens, and they are creating pleasures unimaginable every day. Turn your mind to those pleasures. Don’t you want those pleasures? You used to enjoy them, and these are so much better.” 

And she says, “Yes, there are still these gods who create their own pleasures.” She says, “But all of them, day after day, life after life, in whatever body they come into being in, they will never get beyond this. They just turn and turn and turn—in birth and death, coming and going, trying to hold on to what they cannot have and ultimately losing. She said, “The whole world is in flames. The whole world is burning. The whole world is blazing. The whole world is shaking. The Buddha taught the Dharma that cannot be shaken. It has no equal and is not known by the untrained. But I have fixed my mind on it. After I heard what the Buddha said, I lived delighting in his teaching. I have seen this with my own eyes. What the Buddha taught is done. What you take, Mara, as pleasures are not for me anymore. The mass of mental darkness that I lived with for so long is split open. Know this, O Mara, you are defeated. You are finished. Defeated.”

As she knows her mind, as she is free of the enchantment of those pleasures. And the Buddha acknowledges in the sutras, he says, “Yes, they are pleasurable.” He doesn’t say, “They’re not.” He says, “No, they are. They are pleasurable and they’re impermanent.” And so that pleasure that we derive from them is pleasurable, right? But we can’t keep it. And so we will continually be disappointed when we invest in them more than they can give, when we seek from them some lasting, deeper, more ultimate sense of satisfaction or fulfillment.

The Dharma that cannot be shaken. Every mind-created idea or belief or philosophy or opinion can so easily be shaken. And then what do we have? You know, it’s the importance of faith in the Buddhist path that is based in, that is tethered, is dependent upon, is relying upon our practice. From within that, faith to verify that which we have faith in. That is a crucial aspect of Buddhist practice.

I remember years ago—it’s a long story, but I knew somebody—the wife of one of the Greenhaven students who also had been incarcerated for a very long time. And she was deeply religious. She was Christian, deeply religious. Her message on her voicemail, her answering machine back then, was a message of faith. It was a huge part of her life. And through various circumstances, her husband, the student at Greenhaven, who had just been released—actually was just to be released, and they had the rest of their lives before them, finally freed. And he died suddenly before he could even leave prison.

And I remember calling her and speaking with her afterwards and asking her how she was doing. And of course, she was in immense grief. And I said, “Is your faith helping you?” And she said, “What faith?” And that’s understandable, right? Her whole world has been shaken and some perhaps understanding that with this faith I will be, I don’t know what, in God’s grace, that if I live a pious life, then my life will be a mirror of that piety, that I will... gone, at least for the moment. I don’t know what happened over time, but for me, it was a really vivid example. I felt heartbroken really for her, because I knew how important, what a pillar that was for her. And I said to her, I said, “Look, I get this, but I really hope that this is going to change, you know, this will come back.” But for me, it was a really kind of... it got my attention because I thought, as strong and deep and righteous as that faith is, in a way, it can be precarious unless it’s bound up, right? It’s dependent upon something that I am doing that begins to, in a sense, not just verify, but in a sense, replace that faith with experience. So in a way, the faith that I have had, in a way transforms into experience, which then encourages me to have more faith. Faith isn’t something that we don’t yet know to be fully true. And so it seems that greed and stinginess, fear, anger, jealousy, indifference, deception are perennial, right? As long as human beings have been speaking about their world, we hear those records, we see that in the records, but also perennial is generosity and patience, kindness, moral clarity, commitment, devotion, respect, humility.

Sisu Pacchala said, “What you take for pleasures are no longer ultimate pleasures. I am no longer seeking through those pleasures.” So it doesn’t mean we cannot partake of those pleasures, but in a sense, as practitioners, partake of them knowingly. And the Buddha said this. He said, “Look, use food for what food is for. Don’t try and turn it into something it’s not. Don’t look for it, from it, to give us something it can’t give us. That will only lead to disappointment.” The mass of mental darkness is split open.

And so in sesshin, we create this very simple kind of bare landscape with the precautions and silence and eyes lowered, and no entertainment other than what you’re coming up with in your own mind. So we’re releasing much of those sort of ephemeral, temporary pleasures to create this bare landscape, this naked landscape, to make it easier for... for what? To see. To make it easier for us to see.

And so first, in order to do that, we use that bare landscape to not agitate the mind, right? So that our mind is not going out, out, out, out, out, and being excited or agitated or upset by what we’re experiencing. There’s just not much going on, so that there can be a great deal to see. And in that, as the Buddha said, we can begin to see more closely in a way that is more... changing. Impermanence, right? I mean, we all know everything is impermanent. That’s not that hard to know. Everything is in a constant state of change. Of course, we forget that all the time. We act as though it’s not true all the time. But the Buddha said, when we really understand impermanence, that will liberate your mind. So he’s talking about understanding impermanence at a deeper level, not just a conceptual understanding.

So Maezumi Roshi asked, “Well, what is binding you? Look around you.” He said, “Nothing is binding you, and yet something is binding you. Nothing is binding you. You are realizing yourself, manifesting yourself as you are. What is wrong with how you are? What is wrong with how you are?” He asks. Then he says, “You just can’t take it.” Take what? Who you are. He said, this is simply because something is obstructing us from seeing this fact, that there is nothing wrong, and we can’t—it’s hard to take that. There has to be something wrong. If there wasn’t something wrong, then why wouldn’t I...? I mean, if there’s nothing wrong, then why wouldn’t I already be enlightened? Why wouldn’t I be at peace? Why wouldn’t I be fully embodying the precepts? It’s just hard to take. He said this obstruction, whatever it is, makes us feel as if we are bound by something. The Buddha calls this delusion. In other words, your mind is not in the right place. Your mind is not in the right place.

Daozhen, right before he dies, said, “All things are liberated. You should keep mindful of this and manifest it in the future. All things are already liberated.” So he clearly went on to see that not only was he not bound, nothing was binding him, but there was nothing being bound in the whole universe. It’s said that after he died, which was just after he said this—he was 72—he was entombed on the mountain where he lived. And the next year, the door of the crypt where he was entombed opened of itself for no reason. And when they looked in, it looked like he was still alive. And so after that, they never shut the door of the tomb. He was posthumously named the Great Physician.

Zen Master Kazon in the commentary says, “The cultivation of emptiness is called the gate of liberation. Why neither sentience nor Buddhahood binds you—what more birth and death could there be to entangle you? This cannot be assessed through body or mind. It cannot be discerned by illusion or enlightenment. Even if you talk about mind or objects or afflictions, enlightenment—all of these are just different names for the self. Therefore, mountains and rivers have no barrier. Subject and object are not different. And because of this, when it’s cold, it chills you thoroughly. When it’s hot, it heats you thoroughly.”

Your sentience, our sentience, our Buddha nature, our Buddha mind does not bind us. Our body, our senses, our experiences, right? Of course, this is hard to take, right? Because it sure as hell seems like something is binding us. When a strong emotion, when something happens and we feel a strong reaction comes forth, then we get caught in—it gets entrenched, intractable. We suffer, we get sick, we act out. And so he says, “Nothing is binding you and something is binding you.” Both are true, and both are truths within Buddhist teachings, which means both are to be examined deeply.

So this means our humanity, our faults, our strengths, our weaknesses, our desires, our non-attachments, our attachments do not bind us. And pain and confusion, sense of constriction, anxiety, fear, and worry—they have a reality, right? Buddhism does not deny that. It does not say you are not experiencing that, that when you are sad, you are not sad. Buddhism doesn’t teach that, but it asks the question, “But what is this sadness? As I am bound by sadness or grief or anger—what is this sadness or grief or anger?” And so to look closely. And so Tsang San says, “Well, who is it that is binding you?” And Daozhen says, “No one is binding.” Maybe he answered that right in the moment, he knew already. Maybe he had to go away for a while and examine and look deeply within himself and ask that question. Maybe he’d never had that question presented to himself, so he really, he wanted to know. And he came back and he said, “No one is binding me.” “Then why seek liberation?” So what did he realize in that moment?

Kazon said, “When you cross this barrier, it’s not a principle of either/or. That is to say, there’s neither bondage nor liberation. There’s not this nor that. Things do not set up names. Things do not set up their own forms. Therefore, deliberate cultivation comes to an end.” In other words, we stop creating worlds within worlds and taking them as existing by themselves. So then the Bodhisattva of Compassion now goes about creating worlds—we’re in one right now—for the purpose, but knowingly, as a skillful means.

“When the mind is empty, pure knowledge has no right or wrong. When mind is empty,” he says, “here, I don’t know what there is to bind or free.” Where is this “here”? When all mental activity comes to rest, when there’s no sense of bondage or release. That’s why the Buddha said, “When you’re sitting, don’t sit and think, ‘I am sitting. I am holding on, I am letting go.’ Don’t keep imposing, injecting a created sense of self into a moment that does not have one and does not need one. Being free of that sense of self—now, what is binding?”

There’s an interesting sutra where the Buddha talks about the six senses, and he likens them to animals. So there’s a snake and an alligator and a bird and a dog and a jackal and a monkey. He’s just drawing from his neighborhood. And he says, so you take a rope, and you tie the rope around each one of these: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, mind. And then you take the ends of those six ropes and you tie them into a knot. So now each of those animals is tethered to each other. And he said, they are going to pull and pull and pull and pull, because each one wants to go to its domain. The alligator wants to go into the water. The bird wants to fly. The monkey wants to go up in the trees. The snake wants to go into the grasses. So they’re all fighting to go to their place where they belong, where they gravitate, where they dwell. And he said, eventually they’ll tire themselves out, and the one that’s most powerful will dominate all the others. Interesting. And pull the others along.

So to think of that—which sense, right, finally wins out, and it tethers all the others coming along. He said, now if you take the same animals, tie them, but now you tie the ends of each of those ropes to just one stake. They pull just like they did before, but they’re not pulling against each other. They’re pulling against the stake, and the stake is holding them equally, and the stake isn’t fighting them back. When they’re tethered to each other, they’re fighting against each other. The stake isn’t fighting anybody. And finally, they get exhausted. And what the living things do when they get exhausted—they lay down and rest. He said, that stake is mindfulness. That’s what holds us. That’s what, in a sense, binds with, in a positive way, us to this moment freely. And the difference between the bondage that Daozhen is talking about is that is not given freely. That is a sense of something that is happening to me, even though I am doing, is born out of a lack of mindfulness.

And so it’s interesting just to use that as a way of thinking about, right, the role of mindfulness and holding, keeping us from just flying away. And that when finally we exhaust ourselves—well, part of sesshin is to get you exhausted. It’s pretty effective, wouldn’t you say? But exhausted in a good way—not worn out, you know, mentally, emotionally, but exhausted of our efforts to continually pull and try and get away from that stake. And so when we’re practicing mindfulness, we move towards it, right? The rope goes slack, but then we get distracted, we get excited, so we pull and it yanks at us. That’s our vow. That’s our intention.

Kazon says, “Even if you distinguish the elements of body and mind, seeing, hearing, sound, and form are not another. Seeing is seeing, hearing is hearing. Each complete within itself, each by itself free. The eyes do not bind. The object does not bind.” And so Kazon says, “You actually have a light called ‘vision of the world.’ You have a sense of taste called ‘blending six flavors.’ Therefore, you emanate this light everywhere and prepare a feast everywhere. As you savor it, you find rich flavor where there’s ultimately no flavor. As you observe it, you find true form where ultimately it’s empty of form. Thus, there are no rules, rulers, or politicians that you need to approach. There’s no physical or mental sitting or reclining that is going to give it to you. It’s all here. The feast is prepared, the table is set.”

And so we open the eyes, we open the ears, the tongue, the nose, skin, mind. And then in the moment where it seems like something, we ask, “Where is the hindrance? What is it that’s binding me?” And realize nothing is wrong with you. You can take it, and your mind is in exactly the right place.

Thank you for listening.

To find out more about ZMM’s programs, retreats, and residency, please visit us online at zmm.org.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Title: Silent Illumination
Caption or Other Speaker: Rebecca Li
Extracted Text:
Good morning. Welcome, everyone. Some of you may know that we just finished Silent Illumination Retreat this morning. And even for those of you who weren't here for the retreat, you may find what I'm about to share, hopefully, a little useful.

Some of you who have been practicing may be wondering how we can take the practice that we've been engaging in—the practice of cultivating moment to moment, clear awareness of body and mind in this space here, a lot of time on the sitting meditation seat—how do we take that into our daily life? After all, we go home; we've got responsibilities at home, in the family, at work, and, of course, various ways of engaging in social, relationship, or other ways we engage in civic life as citizens, members of our community.

And this is when we will find guidance from what we recite often—the Four Great Bodhisattva Vows—helpful. Many of you may remember reciting it at various times, in various situations. In fact, I myself recite it every time before I start my sitting meditation practice. And you might want to try integrating it into your own practice. I also recite it at the end of my meals so that I won't forget. Some of you may remember reciting it here at the monastery.

The Four Great Bodhisattva Vows:
- Sentient beings are numberless. I vow to save them.
- Desires are inexhaustible. I vow to put an end to them.
- The dharmas are boundless. I vow to master them.
- The Buddha Way is unattainable. I vow to attain it.

And you may vaguely remember reciting this. Possibly you think that, well, this doesn't really apply to me. Surely it seems very sort of highfalutin or really advanced. It's maybe for the priest here to do, me, maybe not. And so maybe you're just kind of saying it without really paying much attention to it.

In fact, remembering these Four Great Bodhisattva Vows will be incredibly important for us, to remind us of the path so that we do not stray off in some strange directions. I just read you the translation used here at the monastery. I have been using, reciting on my own, a slightly different translation, and that's what I'll be using. And that translation is a literal translation of the four lines written in Chinese. You might notice some slight differences, but the general idea is the same.

The first vow—most important here in the liturgy book: "Sentient beings are numberless. I vow to save them." The character "save" that's being translated as "save" in the version that I recite myself, we recite as "I vow to deliver innumerable sentient beings." Save, deliver—what is that? Well, the word "deliver" is a literal translation from the character that intends to say, like, we want to bring sentient beings from the shore of suffering to the other shore.

Now, you might be like, "I don't know that has anything to do with me because I am suffering. I really can't help the other people go to the other shore. Right?" Well, actually, we can do it right now. What it really means is that we vow to bring benefits to sentient beings in what we do, how we live. That is very manageable. We can do that.

This is very important to keep in mind because it reminds us what it is that we are here to do—the motivation, right intention we need to cultivate for our practice. Oftentimes, I encounter practitioners who come to the practice, for example, a few years ago, she's a therapist at a college. She wanted to come to practice to endure seven days of leg pain so that she can better help the suffering beings she works with as a therapist at work. She can be more present with them and be able to support them.

Also, I encounter people who find that they're struggling as parents. They feel like they can't really connect with their children and they're not really doing a good job as parents, not able to have a harmonious relationship with their family members. And they want to practice to be able to be better parents. So these are really the motivations that are appropriate for bringing to the practice: "I vow to deliver innumerable sentient beings."

Here we are pointing to the fact that we are practicing in order to be able to bring benefits to sentient beings. Especially, it's easy to kind of forget. When we engage in a lot of meditation practice, after a while we forget what it's about and may kind of think that, "Oh, this is about finding ways to gain meditative experience." After a while, you think, "What am I doing here? I'm trying to achieve this one-minded state. I'm trying to achieve that blissful experience so that I can tell people when they say, 'Hey, what are you doing? You're doing all the meditation retreats and what did you get?'" You want to have something to show for it.

So after a while, if we forget this vow, we may go off in those directions. When we remember this vow—that I am engaging this practice so that I can bring benefits to sentient beings—then we can remember it is not about gaining meditative experience, it is not about some form of collecting meditative experience, some form of spiritual materialism. This will help us stay on the path.

Some of you may be kind of discouraged, put off by the part about "sentient beings are numberless" or "innumerable sentient beings." That feels very impossible—maybe a couple people, but innumerable sentient beings? How is that manageable? How is it possible? Am I just saying things, making vows that there's no hope of fulfilling?

Well, one way to understand "innumerable sentient beings" is to understand it as referring to everyone—everyone we encounter, everyone we have the opportunity to encounter, and also people who are affected by our actions. Then it becomes more manageable for us to consider our action and think about how, in this moment, I can bring benefits to others.

First off, we start with people who are close to us—our loved ones, our family members, our friends. Some of you may think, "Well, how to bring benefit to them?" In our culture, we're encouraged to show that you care about them by going shopping and buying more gifts for them. Oftentimes, that may not be what they need. And we already have what most people truly need and want—our full presence.

This morning in the sharing at the end of the retreat, one of the participants shared this very important insight: realizing that being fully present with someone really is a form of love. If you have been fortunate enough to be on the receiving end of it, you realize when someone is fully present with you, allows you to feel truly seen and heard, you feel loved by that person. And the reason why we notice it is because it's rare. Most people are so distracted, their minds so scattered, they often forget to be fully present with us.

So this is one way we can bring benefit to other sentient beings. This is the reason why we engage in the practice of cultivating moment to moment clear awareness. In the practice of Silent Illumination, we've been engaging in practice being fully present with ourselves, allowing thoughts and feelings to be fully felt and seen and heard. We engage in this practice to be fully present with ourselves so that we know how to be fully present with others, allowing others to feel felt and heard and seen, and thus loved.

Sometimes, when we try to put it into practice, we may notice some habits. Our most common entrenched habit is to take people in our life, especially our loved ones, for granted. In our mind, we think they're just there, almost like a piece of furniture. It's like a couch. "Like my husband—yeah, he's just there." So as a result, because we have fallen into this habit of taking our loved one for granted—they're always there for us—we allow ourselves to get in our mind that, "I'm too busy. I'm too busy. I have all this stuff to do." You have this long to-do list to get to.

At home, when our loved ones come home, we often forget to bother to notice, to pay attention, to be fully present with them. For example, maybe a loved one has been out at school or at work for a day and comes home. If we spend time to be present with them, we may be able to notice, "Hmm, something is bothering him. Did something happen at work?" And we're able to ask about it. Maybe you can't offer any solution for them, but they feel seen and felt and thus loved by us.

Oftentimes it only takes a minute. But in our mind, because we are so habituated to taking people in our life for granted, we tell ourselves, "I'm too busy. By the way, I already know who that is. It's my husband." Ignored, not really seeing him. So this is what we can do in bringing benefit to people in our life.

Actually, this reminds me of someone I spoke with recently in the last couple of months. She told me she's a homemaker and her husband works at home part of the week. And she said, "Well, we spend all this time in the same house, but we rarely talk to each other." And actually, when she travels to visit her mother in another country, that's when they talk a lot more. So this is kind of illustrating how we tend to get into the habit of just getting so busy with our stuff. And, of course, nowadays we sit there and start looking at our phone instead of paying attention to our loved ones right here in front of us.

Again, here I'm not talking about just, like, staring at the people at home and like, "I'm paying you attention here." They're kind of like, "You're being weird, so I need to get going doing my stuff." We're not talking about that, but actually, yeah, pay attention and spend time to be present with them so that you can see and feel what's going on. Because this is a new moment. This is a new moment of this person being here. Even though you may have been married to this person for 50 years, it's a new moment of this person being here.

So in our daily life, as we remember the vow of bringing benefits to sentient beings, then we can notice these habits of taking people for granted and not paying attention, and so we can release it and be here and present with them. It doesn't take much. In this way, we allow our loved one to feel seen and heard and loved.

Related to this, some people may be thinking, "Oh, okay, this is what I'm here to do—to bring benefit to sentient beings." And a lot of you may have been already doing that by trying to be helpful, like wanting to be someone who is helpful to others. Well, I'd like to invite you to use these moments to look into your mind to see if it is a habit. It is a habit that may inadvertently lead us to cause harm to others. Like, really wanting to help others can cause harm to others.

I had this student, she has this habit of wanting to always be helpful, wanting to always be helpful. In fact, for her, "I have to be helpful. If I'm not helpful, something's wrong. I always have to be helpful." That's her habit. One time in a retreat, this habit showed up and she went over to someone who was engaging in her task and started helping her. And this other retreat participant came to me and was very upset about what happened. There was a little bit of a conflict there.

And you wonder, what happened? Well, you know, because in her urge and compulsion of having to be helpful all the time, even when it is not needed, someone has been assigned to do this. And her urge, her compulsion of having to be helpful all the time, trying to help, barging in on another person assigned to do a task, made this person feel that you are saying she is doing a terrible job—"Let me help you." And that's why she got quite upset. She meant well, but what happened was, inadvertently, by succumbing to this urge of having to be helpful all the time, which is a form of self-centered attachment, we inadvertently cause harm.

Afterwards, she talked to me, this retreatant told me, "Yes, that is actually like a form of suffering for her. She always feels that she has to do this and it has to do with her sense of inadequacy and low self-esteem." So when we cultivate moment to moment clear awareness, that allows us to notice that, oh, what's happening is not fulfilling the vow of benefiting sentient beings. Actually, what I'm doing is perpetuating this habit, this habitual reactivity, telling ourselves that I have to, I have to be helpful, be a certain way all the time, whether that is appropriate or needed or not.

So when we are able to notice this urge, "I have to be helpful," and release it, that actually allows us to open our awareness, to see clearly, to see the present moment situation clearly, and actually be able to notice what is actually needed. And when you notice no one is doing it, maybe if I can, I can be the one doing this. Quite different from barging in, doing something that someone else is already doing and making that person feel inadequate, feel that you are telling them that they are doing a terrible job.

In fact, this is something that I learned from my root teacher, Master Sheng Yen. He often would teach us that when something needs to be done, but no one is doing it, "Let me do it. Give that to me. Give that task to me." So what he's pointing to is that oftentimes there are certain aspects, for example, running a monastery or certain aspects of a task that is difficult, very challenging. Oftentimes, no one's doing it because it's very difficult, but more often it's because it does not show results very quickly.

Most of us want to do something and see that we are succeeding quickly. It's like you may just do it, do it, and do it, but you don't really see results, and you may not even see a result before you die. So people don't want to do it. Or it's not something that is popular or not glamorous. It's not going to earn you recognition or fame or status, but it's needed, very much so. And that is what he is pointing to: when there's something that needs to be done and no one's doing it, "Let me do it, let me do it." And also, the things that others are already doing, it's already covered. Then there's not a need for me to also jump on it to add to that. Let me do something—do what is needed, but not currently being done.

Here I want to clarify: it's not about wanting to stand out as someone who's different just for the sake of being different. What I'm talking about is that we cultivate clear awareness of the whole situation, total clear awareness, so that we can recognize what is needed but is not being done, and also the willingness to let go of our desire or attachment to recognition and praise, status that come from what we do, and do what is needed, even though it is difficult and does not show results and earn us recognition.

In our dealing with loved ones in our life, sometimes we may find ourselves falling into a mode of operation because that's what we've been doing all our life without knowing, even though we are engaging in it with good intention. For example, recently I met a practitioner, a very sincere practitioner, naturally very generous, loving. She told me how her mother had a very hard life raising several children on her own, and now she is able to make a good living, and she wants to be able to show her love to her mother by showing her a good time, taking her traveling with her to enjoy life at this time.

And then she said, "But I dread doing that, because in the previous time she took her mother traveling, first, her mother insisted on taking her cousin with her. And the whole time, her mother was only hanging out with her cousin. And apparently, her mother was overheard by the taxi driver badmouthing her with her cousin." And she's like, "I don't know if I can do this anymore."

So, wow. Here is a situation: she wants to show her love, she wants to give her mother a good experience traveling, yet she ends up feeling rejected, very bitter, and very upset to the extent that she's just kind of taking time off from talking to her mother. Like, well, what to do, right? How to use the practice with that?

Here, when we engage in the practice of cultivating clear awareness of what's going on, we may notice—and this is what this practitioner did—notice that what's happening was that she's been attached to her idea of how her action of showing love should look like. "I love my mother. I want to go travel with her, show her a good time by traveling, taking her travel with me," and imagine that we're going to go and have fun and enjoy each other. She had in her mind some other mother—not her mother—some other mother who loves traveling with her daughter.

Meanwhile, she wasn't able to see what her mother actually enjoys, actually wants at her age. Her mother wants to be able to spend time with someone her age, her own cousin, so that they get to do things; they have the same pace, you know, traveling. Recognizing that we have been attached to our assumption, our idea, believing that her mom should want to spend her dream vacation with her, recognizing that, "Oh, actually, that's not what she wants," in the first moment can be a little painful. It's like it shatters your idea, maybe wanting to continue to be the center of your mother's universe. Happens to a lot of adult children. Not anymore. You're not five anymore. They want to have their own life now that you're growing up.

And when cultivating clarity about this, it allows her to see that, "Ah, okay. What do I want? I want to show my love. I want her to be able to have an enjoyable trip. How about I pay for her and her cousin to go to London and I don't need to be there feeling rejected and criticized and also save money for my own share to go to London, because it wasn't enjoyable for me last time?"

So in our good intention of bringing benefits to our loved one, we can practice noticing these ideas we hold in our mind about our loved ones and instead really see who is here so that we can work with the person as they are now, not the person we wish them to be. Recognize we hold our idea of people in our mind and ignore the person who is actually here.

Now, some practitioners make this vow: "I vow to deliver innumerable sentient beings," and these innumerable sentient beings, yes, "I vow to bring benefit to all sentient beings—except me. I have been excluded from the sentient beings somehow, not me." So we're willing to look after others generously, with kindness, but not ourselves.

Oftentimes, that shows up as ways where we perpetuate habits of harshness toward ourselves. Some of you may be able to recognize it in moments when we are feeling really quite exhausted, overwhelmed by all the work we have, and we wouldn't allow ourselves to take a break, just keep pushing on, you know: "I'll just sleep less, skip meals, you know, just push on." But we will, when someone is feeling kind—"Hey, you should go take a break"—but not me. Benefit everyone but ourselves.

Or related to that, the habit of only focusing on what we did not do well and ignoring, dismissing everything we managed to do actually quite well. It's like everything we are able to do—nothing, that's nothing. But this thing, you know, I didn't do well, it's a problem. What's wrong with me? What's wrong with me? Beat ourselves up. I don't know, it doesn't sound familiar to you? It's like some practitioners sit here in meditation: "I feel drowsy." Beat themselves up: "What is wrong with me? Why can't I stop being drowsy?" While the whole time, they didn't give up. They stayed and stayed and stayed and never gave up. Session after session, never gave up. Doing that is incredible. Yet we dismiss that, refuse to recognize that.

So the practice of cultivating total open, clear awareness is about recognizing that. Because if we refuse to recognize what we are able to do—in this case, we didn't give up, we stayed—then what happens is we end up feeling despair, like a failure. And that can compel us to engage in other actions such as, "Oh, I feel like such a failure. I want to avoid other people." And then we kind of just become more and more isolated from others and turn our life into a ball of suffering.

So this is an example of when we allow the habits of harshness on ourselves to be perpetuated, then what happens is we become so consumed by suffering that we deprive the world of our presence. We withdraw ourselves, feeling like such a failure. We deprive the world of our presence, deprive the world of the opportunity to benefit from your full engagement in life.

Every single one of us, when we are fully present, everyone benefits. But when we insist on suffering, we deprive the world from benefiting from us. The world needs every single one of us. So do everyone a favor. Be kind to yourself. Because when you suffer less, you are more available to others. And you're already making the world a better place by suffering less, by giving rise to vexations less.

Some practitioners, when they think about this vow of benefiting sentient beings, one place they go to is like, "Well, what do I do, you know, like, in terms of having a livelihood, right?" And for those of you who are here at the monastery, or sometimes you come to practice and think that, "Oh yeah, but like, you know, I would love to be a priest, but I can't." Or, and naturally, some, some may be called to priesthood or life in a monastery to support and maintain a place of practice like this monastery, to bring benefits to all sentient beings. But that is not the causes and conditions for everybody. And if that is the case for you, then there's no need to generate suffering about it.

We work with the causes and conditions we have in our life. So the key is to identify a livelihood that does not involve unethical behavior and also that will make good use of your experience, your talents, your skill that can bring benefits to others. When we have this vow of bringing benefits to sentient beings, it can help us find that direction. And when we maintain clear awareness of our causes and conditions, then we can find that, "Ah, this is the place where I can start."

Some people, they engage in what we call helping professions, like the therapists I talked to. I have students who are nurses, social workers, and teachers. Of course, there are all kinds of professions that are also needed. I had a student who's a chief operating officer of his company. We have a tendency to think, "Oh, corporate." Well, we definitely can use more practitioners in the corporate world.

He talked about how he uses the practice to work with the board and to ensure that his staff will get properly compensated and not be exploited, using and developing his skill to manage that relationship. So then, in that way, bringing benefits to sentient beings.

Or if your talent is in creating and running a business, we definitely need businesses that provide useful services and products, right? And if you're good at making money, if that's part of your talent, you can make good use of your money to support places like the monastery. Somebody needs to make money. So if that's what you're good at doing, go do it with the intention that you will make use of what you're able to make to benefit sentient beings.

Here again, when we say, "vow to deliver innumerable sentient beings," all sentient beings, meaning whether we are sharing space with them this moment or not. So when we are sharing space with sentient beings in the interaction at work, at home, or in other spaces, when we remember our vow of benefiting sentient beings, then it reminds us—besides staying present—to use our speech, our bodily action to bring benefit to them. It can show as being respectful, being courteous, making people feel cared for, loved, and showing kindness, being gentle, supportive, encouraging. And this is even when we disagree with them.

That is the difficult one, right? Oftentimes, when we find ourselves interacting with people with very different views that we disagree with—for example, we disagree, we have different opinions or ideas on how best to achieve something, or on different ideas on what's the most important priority—we notice in those moments the urge to demonize them or to dismiss them: "They're just stupid," or begin to think that they are these really bad people. Notice this urge to demonize and dismiss people with different views from ours.

This is the time we can practice recognizing, noticing the habits. This is a very, very, very entrenched habit—the habit of identifying with our views as the only right one and thinking that others' views are, whatever word you use to judge them. You think if you're sitting here it's like, "Yes, of course, my view is the only right one." That's the point I'm making. That's a very entrenched habit. Recognize, recognize the habits of feeling that way, this urge to believe it, that compels us to dismiss, demonize the other person who has different views.

This is a moment for us to practice remembering that every moment is the coming together of causes and conditions. We may think that our view is superior because, I guess, because I'm a superior person. When in reality, the views we have are the coming together of all the moments of our experience—people we talk to, people who taught us, the things we read, things we heard, everything, everything. All our experiences, everything we have encountered, our background, all the information we've been exposed to, we encounter, come together as these views. And it is the same for this other person. They have a different background, different experiences, they've been exposed to different information, so they have those views. Which means if you had the exact same causes and conditions as that person, you would have those views.

If you sit here and think, "Nah, I don't think so," then you are forgetting emptiness. Our views are the coming together of causes and conditions. Difficult to remember this one, though. We can practice and practice remembering this.

So when we remember to practice, when we remember to practice to release the habits of aversion when encountering people with different views and opinions, then that allows us—because our aversion is no longer getting in the way—we can actually be here, open our awareness, and allow ourselves to truly listen. Listen instead of, "That's so stupid, that's so stupid," we can't even hear. Actually listen to what they are saying and be able to appreciate where they are coming from. "Oh, I can see, yeah, with your experience, I can see why you would feel that way. I can understand. I can see that." And oftentimes, when people feel heard and seen, all the armor kind of softens. It's like they're ready to fight, then, "Oh, actually, you're not there to attack them." They become less defensive and possibly a little bit more open to what we might have to share. Maybe you won't be able to convert them to your view, but maybe there's a way, there's a possibility in opening to find some common ground. Because, after all, we all want to find ways to do something well for everybody.

So this process makes it a little bit more possible for us to find a way forward to benefit all. If we end up still not being able to find common ground, at least we're able to agree to disagree instead of ending up perpetuating more hatred.

One time a retreatant asked me this question, "What is the point of the practice here?" I hope you have been asking this question: How is it going to make the world a better place? So I thought of this, and I thought of a bowl of jelly beans. So stay with me. Think about the world—the entire world—as a bowl, a giant bowl of jelly beans. So there are red jelly beans and blue jelly beans. Every time we give rise to hatred in our heart, we throw a red jelly bean in the world. Every time we do not give rise to hatred and remember to be kind and listen, we throw a blue jelly bean in the bowl.

Well, maybe we are living in a world with a lot of red jelly beans. And it's up to all of us to turn this bowl of jelly beans every moment into a more red jelly bean, more filled with hatred, or less, fewer red jelly beans. Every moment, every moment we choose to react with hatred, perpetuate hatred or aversion in our mind, that moment, another red jelly bean, another red jelly bean. So you can ask yourself, "Which color jelly beans have I been throwing into the bowl?"

Every single one of us, every moment, we have an opportunity to make the world a better place. Which do we choose? Every moment is a brand new moment to put a different color jelly bean in the world in every interaction we have.

So when we are fully engaged with each moment, that gives us an opportunity to see what's going on. That allows us to notice, "Ah, all the things that are working well." And keep that in mind: "Yeah, okay, this is good." And also maybe notice things that can use some adjustments that will allow us to grow. So it's not about, "Oh, it's all good, you know, just keep doing the same." No, you notice things and then you can adjust and keep growing. And when appropriate or when we are asked—sometimes we ask, "Is there anything that, you know, feedback you have?" If you haven't been paying attention, "Everything's fine, because you notice anything." But if you have been paying attention, then when we are asked, we are more able to perhaps share some constructive feedback that is a way to benefit other sentient beings, because they want to be able to grow, and we are there to support them by providing some constructive feedback.

This is when I remember Master Sheng Yen's quote that I actually use for the signature of my email. I share this with you here, and this is what I use in my daily life: "Wherever we go, whether or not you benefit from being there, let that place benefit from your being there." Let that place benefit from your being there. Usually, in our self-centered way, we think about, "What am I going to get from this? What am I going to get from this?" Drop that habit; let that place benefit from our being there.

I've been talking about interacting with other sentient beings we encounter. Of course, sometimes, you know, there are sentient beings that are not in our presence. We can also think about how our action might affect them. Here in the last few days in the retreat practice—and actually you can do that at home—when we remember to stay in the practice, for example, we will be more likely to remember to open and close the door quietly and not let it slam and kind of startle everyone, because that can affect other people, can get people all shaken up. Little things, little things. But that is, at that moment, you can remember practice and benefit others.

Or not leave a mess for others to clean up. I have this practitioner who talked about how her husband would come home and leave a sock at the bottom of the stairs and then another sock at the top of the stairs. That drives her nuts. And you may think, "Socks, you know, what's the big deal?" It's like, well, when we leave a mess for others to clean up, not only are we making them do the cleaning up, but it makes them feel unloved. That's why it's upsetting.

And I remember many years ago when I was traveling with Master Sheng Yen as his translator. When we were done at the conference, we needed to check out of the hotel. He told us, "You clean up your room in the hotel." At that time, I was like, "Well, we pay for the hotel. Why would we clean? They pay people to come clean the room." But I remember this every time I would do it. And then one time I finally realized, "Oh, it's like if I leave a mess, not only does the person who comes and cleans the room have a lot more work, but it makes them feel unloved. You just treat them as like not a human being, just leave this for them to just clean up after us." So it's a way for us to show that we care about them, even though we may not get the opportunity to meet them in person.

And lastly, I do want to mention this. In our practice, we encounter, like, right here, people who guide us in our practice, support us on the path, like all the residents, the Roshi, and the priests here who devoted their life to supporting others in their practice. One important way to bring benefits to sentient beings is to show appreciation, show love and care to the people who teach and guide us in the practice.

The reason why I want to make this point is oftentimes practitioners make the assumption that, "Well, they're very advanced, you know, they don't really need, they don't really need people to, like, you know, show care about them and they can just take anything, you know." Well, they are human beings and also can use encouragement and love and care.

The reason why I talked about this is many years ago I heard of a story of a very good teacher in a community, and he decided to stop teaching because he got fed up. Got fed up because—I know a little bit about that community—it's not their strong point, appreciating the teacher, showing appreciation. The teacher, it's like they prefer complaining. And so they probably think that, "Oh yeah, you know, you're very advanced, you don't need appreciation." Well, but that's what it ended up. It was a shame because he's a very good teacher, and he got fed up by how he was taken for granted and treated by a sangha that preferred complaining and making demands and not showing appreciation.

So when we remember to show appreciation, finding ways to take care, take care of sangha members, our guides and teachers, what we are doing is to support and keep them feeling encouraged, so that under the nourishment, they can continue to do the work of guiding and supporting other sentient beings on the path. Sometimes we think, "Oh, teachers just, like, they are like these independently existing entities." No, we co-create a teacher. A loving, supportive, appreciative sangha co-creates a loving, supportive teacher.

So I want to leave you with that. Thank you for your attention. Thank you for listening.

To find out more about ZMM's programs, retreats and residency, please visit us online at ZMM.org.

Talk Location: Zen Center of New York City
Title: INDRA’S NET WITH ENTANGLEMENTS
Speaker: Jody Hojin Kimmel

Title: Sarah Taisho Sands - Shuso Hosen Talk
Caption or Other Speaker: Sarah Taisho Sands Shuso Hosen Talk and Encounter
Speaker: Other

Title: Eight Gates Of Zen: Part 4
Extracted Text:
So, good evening. Imagining that most of you don't feel any—any of the anxiety that I'm feeling, but I hope you feel a little bit of excitement.

Our topic of the evening is Buddhist study. She started her mondo on teacher-student relationship and said that that was the edgiest of the eight gates. And afterwards I was like, oh, did I choose the least edgy? But I'm not sure that's true. I chose this topic because I love study. I've learned to love study, and it's become an important part of my ongoing practice. Study is bringing us into direct contact—directly to the Buddha's teachings, to the Dharma treasure.

When the Buddha was dying and his students were bereft and saying, “What are we going to do?” he said a couple of things, but one of the main things that he said was kind of like, “You have the Dharma. Trust that you have what you need. You have the teachings, these precious teachings.” What could be more precious than the outline of the path to liberation, the path out of suffering, to liberate suffering? And really, Buddhist practice and realization is realizing what the Buddha realized and taught.

So, study is one of the eight gates. It’s worth noting that Daido Roshi chose to present the eight gates as gates of training. A gate is a place of entry. In each of the eight gates, what does that mean? How do we enter? What does it mean to enter? What do we have to do in order to enter? How do we find our way in? Some gates of practice are probably more natural places of entry for some of us than others, and that may not always be obvious. Sometimes for an artist, art practice is actually a difficult place to enter. Or for an athlete, it’s like, “I know how to work out, but what is body practice?” And that may be true for many of us with study. Most of us, all of us, have had some experience with study in a different form. Maybe that wasn’t such a place of meeting our life, meeting truth.

So, how do we enter through study? And with each of the gates, I guess part of that question of what is it to enter is: What is it to study the self through this gate? What is it to study the Dharma through this way of practicing, studying? And each of the gates can be an ongoing place of entry, inquiry. And so when we see that one of the gates is no longer open, alive for us, how do we make it alive, bring it alive again?

The Zen school has a particular relationship with study, some history. You’ve probably all heard this famous quote from Bodhidharma that Zen is a special transmission outside of the scriptures, is not reliant on words and letters, is not reliant on the sutras. It’s a direct pointing to the human mind and realization of Buddhahood. As an aside, we always attribute this to Bodhidharma, but apparently this didn’t show up in the records for hundreds of years after his life. But it’s an important way of understanding the Zen school.

So, the emphasis on direct experience and a kind of warning, right, that words and ideas can only point. You can know for yourself your true nature, but you can’t explain it. We talk about the finger pointing at the moon—don’t confuse the finger for the moon. This is important because we can do this. We can get confused. We do get confused. We’re used to being able to figure things out. We’re smart, we’re used to understanding things in our way of understanding things, and we trust that. Particularly until we have some experience of understanding something more directly, knowing something more directly, kind of knowing how to experience, that feels like sometimes it’s like, “No, it must be this way of understanding,” because we don’t know something else.

And so Bodhidharma gives us this important warning. We can be studying the Dharma and not studying the self. Studying the Dharma and not practicing. Talking about practice rather than practicing. Explaining practice to ourselves or explaining the Dharma to ourselves and not actually meeting ourselves, working with ourselves. And so our emphasis on direct experience—we’re the meditation school, that’s the focus. If you think about how we practice, the emphasis on zazen, our intensive retreats, sesshin, there is no reading and writing. That’s very explicit, so that we can be—to help us be with our direct experience. And that’s taken up in other places in different ways. I remember Daido Roshi always used to talk about the first monastery where he trained: the library was locked. You weren’t allowed to study. And so this emphasis on direct experience is important, right? It’s true. The teachings are always pointing us to our own mind, always helping us. Their only purpose is to help us understand our own mind, understand ourselves, to realize what the Buddha realized and taught.

And so I think just to hold these both. I think that there are ways in which Bodhidharma’s—you know, the locked library, I would say, was sort of a misunderstanding of Bodhidharma’s warning. And we can probably look around and see places where there is study happening rather than practice. My sense is that study and practice have always gone together—always both been integral parts of the path.

Last week, I was reading some of the early Zen teachings, Bodhidharma and his immediate successors, and they both—all—left teachings, written teachings, and they all quoted the sutras. They were all quoting the teachings, pointing towards the teachings.

I’ve been thinking a little bit about my own experience of study practice here and how that’s evolved, how I’ve seen that evolve in my time here. I think particularly in seeing how Shugen Roshi, in his time as abbot, has given more attention to study. I feel like I observe in him, in my teacher, how important study is to his practice. I think it always has been, is my sense, and I just—I see it ongoing and so learning from his example.

A few of us talked about the interaction between zazen and study—how texts that might be inaccessible in the middle of a busy day might be accessible and take root as an extension of meditation practice.

And then one more: My partner and I have very similar experiences of intellectualizing instead of studying the self through Buddhist study. Intellect as near enemy of study of Dharma and self.

Last one, Laura says: When I found the right book, study helps zazen feel more alive. My challenge is finding the right books.

Yeah, yeah. Thank you for all that.

So, anything else?

Yes, Madhav’s statement brought it up. Let me go with that. So, curiously, we get good at audiobooks, but it’s an oral tradition, you know, and the fact of—and then I’m reminded, just pulling from a history in philosophy, I mean, Socrates is very anti-text and very much about word-to-word discussion, like, has to be alive. And text to him is like—it’s a dead thing. Like, we’ve reified it, we’ve frozen it. And in our discussion, I was saying the most successful Buddhist study I have is I meet with a friend once a week and we read it together out loud. And that part of that, that makes it alive versus this sort of silent thing into my head. I just throw that out there.

Yeah, yeah. So, coming back to the, like, what makes it Buddhist study? How do we let it be alive? And if you think about, you know, you’re right: originally it was an oral tradition in the Buddha’s time, right? There was a lot of debate and it was all oral, right? And they would like, memorize the Buddha’s teachings. You know, the Tibetan tradition, the debate. And we do a little bit of that—not the debate so much, but, you know, the monastics meet every week to do some study. The seniors meet every month to do some study. And that’s a little—we do things like this, we do things like the ango intensive, where there is some discussion, some back and forth, because that’s a helpful way in, right?

Yeah. Yosh and I talked about how much study is too much study, because there is too much study, I think, but there can also be too little, right? So just about finding a sweet spot where it’s staying alive and you’re not sort of hiding from practice by being a big nerd. This is a quote that I found: “Those who read should only look at books for a while, then hasten to put them away to test them in practice.”

Yeah, that’s—oh, sorry, I got passed the microphone, so I guess it’s my turn. And I wouldn’t have had that if it wasn’t for studying. So I found that to be really useful.

Yeah. And I was going to say this later, but so I also have that experience, right? And so that’s why study can be so important. And then how do we integrate, right? So, like, I’m not looking for a new practice, right? Or new—so how do I, when I look at the Satipatthana Sutta, how do I let that inform my zazen practice? And so I think that can be a little bit of an edge, right? There’s so much out there that’s available, and so how do we use it to deepen our practice rather than kind of scattering us?

Right. Is it my—it’s my turn.

Josh and I spoke about how when we read and we don’t really have much of an oral culture anymore, so when we read and we take in information that way, we sort of reify it a bit. So, it’s like, “Oh, I’ve read that book,” and you might not remember anything about that book, or you might remember one thing, but if you kept revisiting it as you would if you were in an oral tradition, then you get a lot more out of it. You remember a lot more. And it can be more alive because of the repetition. And I think an important part of study for me is not trying to read all the books, just maybe rereading books occasionally, if only passages.

Yeah, yeah, definitely coming back to things over and over again over time. And, you know, so that’s true. Like, I overheard Raku-san, I think, talking about how, you know, we don’t memorize things anymore, but we could, right? Like, it can be helpful to—like, what are the five skandhas, you know, to, like, know. And so, yeah, that’s like a helpful way. It’s still a part of language pedagogy. You have to memorize poems sometimes and things like that. So we could bring that into this.

Rebecca: I’ve found that when I’m at home and I’m just feeling in a funk during the day, if I listen to just even a little bit of a Dharma talk with a teacher that I connect with, just, like, taking in the energy of Dharma can plug me back into myself. And that’s one way that study really helps me.

Yeah. Thank you.

Okay, so I have this broken out a little bit as, like, why do we study, and then how do we study—we’re already touching on that—and then, if there’s time, to talk a little bit about, well, what do we study?

And as I was working on this first section, you know, so, you know, there is studying just to understand the tradition, right? Most of us were not raised Buddhist or raised in the Buddhist culture. It’s like, what is this that we’re taking up? We are part of a tradition, right? And part of a school. So, like, to understand, well, what is that? There is study and kind of testing the teachings so that we can have trust—to trust enough to take the next step, to keep practicing.

There’s a contemporary teacher—I think it was Thanissaro Bhikkhu—who talks about, you know, we don’t need to believe anything. We’re not asked to believe in Buddhism or believe in the Buddhist teachings, right? That’s—the Buddha himself said that very clearly. But Thanissaro Bhikkhu suggests—but it’s really helpful to have conviction in the teachings. It’s a little bit of a different tone to that. We can develop that conviction through our own study, through our own testing of the teachings. That’s what the Buddha said to do. He said, don’t believe what I say because I am the world-honored one, because I am the Buddha. Test it for yourself. In the Kalama Sutta, he goes through this whole list: Don’t believe anything simply because you’ve heard it. Don’t believe in traditions because they’ve been handed down. And then he says, “But after observation and analysis, when you find that anything agrees with reason and is conducive to the good and benefit of one and all, then accept it and live up to it.”

Maybe most importantly, we study because we need help, we need guidance. In the same way that it is so helpful to have a teacher—in some ways necessary to be able to work with a teacher—well, study can offer that. We can meet a teacher on the page, meet a teacher in a talk that we’re listening to. I’ve talked to people who said that. I have a friend who said Joko Beck was her first teacher. She never met Joko Beck, but she read her book so thoroughly and so many times, it was like that was teaching her. There have been times for me where I found a teacher in a book that was like, this is just what I need right now. And for a while that was just what I needed. That teacher was teaching me.

We need instruction, we need guidance, we need help staying on the path, understanding what we’re doing. And there’s study to develop right understanding. So, right understanding or right view is one of the steps of the Eightfold Path. I think this is sort of where study is integral with practice—is not other than practice. Sometimes in some presentations of the Eightfold Path, right understanding comes first. We have to have some understanding in order to practice, in order to take another step along the path. And right understanding comes at the end; it is what we realize ultimately—a traditional understanding of—well, I’ll get to that maybe.

And so there can be in study a kind of back and forth, kind of moving in and out. How do we reach out into the teachings, put ourselves out into the teachings, and how do we let them enter us? Study can also be a place where our conceptual understanding mind meets our non-conceptual mind. Or we can use our conceptual mind through study to kind of get to a non-conceptual understanding. It kind of lays the groundwork. Again, the teachings are always pointing us to our own mind, helping us to understand our own mind. It’s always about helping us to realize.

And so from the time of the Buddha, the teachings are a teacher—someone, a person, speaking from their own experience, trying to guide through sharing their own experience, trying to share their own practice and realization in order to help us understand our own experience. So, the teachings can—I think someone shared this—you know, that the teachings can help us understand what we have already experienced. They can also point us to what we have not yet experienced, but pointing us to what can be realized. And sometimes they can help bring us to an experience, help us to realize something, understand something for ourselves.

And so I think of this sort of back and forth, moving in and out. How do we do that? How does that happen? How do we kind of reach ourselves out and enter the teachings? How do we let them enter us and allow them to turn our mind?

Years ago, Shugen Roshi said something in a talk about how he felt like he was realizing—he was seeing—how practice is simply continuing to clarify for ourselves the Four Noble Truths. And, you know, I think—and this is one of those things that, like, from years ago has always—I just—I heard that and took that in and always remembered that, just that short part of that talk. And I think that he must have been speaking from his own experience in that moment, right? And it also—that is just what the teachings are, right?

So, as I think I just said, so the right understanding, ultimately, sort of the traditional understanding is that we are realizing for ourselves the Four Noble Truths. That is right understanding. That’s sort of the big part of right understanding. And that’s true of all of the teachings—to take them in, study and reflect, take them into our practice, and then they’re in you. And then in your zazen, sometimes you can use them to guide yourself. The teacher’s not always sitting there answering your questions for you, helping you—how do I deal with this?—but you have the teachings with you, and so you can give yourself what you need, give yourself the guidance that you need.

And sometimes, because the teachings are in you, as you are working with your own mind in your own direct practice, in your zazen, something becomes clear—not because you’re sitting with that, trying to understand that teaching, but just because that’s in you and you’re working with your mind. You’re encountering your mind.

Let me just pause here for a sec, see if there are questions or comments, thoughts.

So, I want to speak a little bit more directly to right understanding. To be—that we are cultivating right view, right? So the “right,” which is in a sense correct, right or appropriate, is sometimes translated bringing our view into alignment with this right view. Because we all have a view, or maybe we have many views. We act out of those views. We experience the world through those views.

Something I was reading, this teacher was suggesting—even the simple activity of brushing your teeth is based in a view, in an idea, in a certain kind of understanding. “If I brush my teeth, I won’t get cavities.” Some people say, “If you floss, you’ll live longer,” right? And so that action, since it’s based in that, based in a view, based in an idea—it’s not to say that we’re always acting rationally, but I don’t know, sort of look into that, right? We’re acting based on an idea, and we may or may not be conscious of that. Often we are not. And we may or may not be conscious of where this view came from. Maybe most of the time, a lot of the time, we’re not conscious of that. And sometimes our experience will sort of bear out, will verify our view.

So I was remembering when I graduated from high school and sort of moved out of the house and my mother was no longer making dentist appointments for me—I didn’t go to the dentist for quite a while, and I don’t think I was brushing my teeth enough either. I got a bunch of cavities, and I went to the dentist and they sort of put the fear of God into me, and I started brushing my teeth more. Haven’t had any cavities. Sometimes we verify like that.

But so in cultivating correct right understanding, it’s like we’re cultivating a correct understanding of the Buddha’s teachings rather than our own view. Our own views may be more comforting, based in our own emotions. But look around: what does that lead to? The sort of tangle of views based in our own emotions.

And so right understanding traditionally is understood as understanding the Four Noble Truths—so suffering, its cause, cessation, the skillful activities, practice of the Eightfold Path. It’s understanding of karma, so the law of cause and effect: what we do has an effect. Daido Roshi used to say, “What we do and what happens to us are the same thing.” I find it helpful to understand karma as habit, power of habit. And then I think from the Mahayana point of view, we could add upaya—so understanding skillful and unskillful, what is leading to freedom and what is not, what is more binding—and dependent origination or emptiness: all things are impermanent, changing, have no fixed essence.

And so how is this moving in and moving out? How are we guided by this right understanding? How do we use this right understanding, this correct view?

So I’ll try another pair share—maybe turn to someone different, mix yourselves up a little bit—and see if you can find, share an experience where you used your understanding, your Dharma, your understanding of the teachings, used your right understanding, your right view, to help yourself. To help yourself understand something that was happening in you or to work with something. So maybe you were meeting a difficult state of mind. Maybe you were meeting a strong desire, just as possibilities. And how did you use the teachings? How did the teachings—either to sort of understand what was happening or to work with your mind, to work with yourself?
