Okay, so again, we’ll take about five minutes. So a couple minutes, and then your partner has a couple minutes. And so just see if you can try and find an experience. So again, folks on Zoom, please share in the chat so we can hear from you too.

And can we hear from—sounded like there was a lot to say in that one. Anyone want to share?

So I got to speak to one that is very alive. I just started working with it today. The food here is so good, and there’s so much of it, and I’ve been overeating most meals for about a month, and it leaves me feeling tired and, like, super full and lethargic. It impacts my practice. It impacts my mood. Like, it’s just—in general, I’m like, why am I doing this? And, you know, so I’ve been kind of, like, stalking it a little bit of like, okay, well, what’s going on here? And, you know, looking at the causes of it, it’s like, oh, there’s not that much stimulation here. So this is, like, a little hit, right? You get, like, all this delicious food, so boom. Like, the suffering is—right, the cause of the suffering is kind of—I’m looking at it. It’s like, okay, I’m overeating. And then looking at the reasons why, kind of just going through each of these things. And essentially today I was like, all right, I don’t want to feel this way. I don’t need to be loyal to this piece of suffering. And so I can choose differently. And today was a success. So thank you.

I’m excited to share this one because it’s outside of this tradition a little bit. I—I guess I have to contend with, like, horror of birth and death and violence, like, a lot, because I’m an anxious person. And something that I have found that helps is one day—I’m not gonna even bother sharing what was bringing up the horror. It could just, you know, pick your favorite one—and I ended up meditating on a wrathful deity, actually. Taikyo has—it’s Vajra Varahi. You have a sticker. It’s great. Garland of heads. There’s usually fire, fangs, they’re very scary. But I learned at some point that they’re benevolent. And something about meditating on the wrathful deity—like, long story short, I kind of, like, took the horror that was in my mind that was like, I felt like I had to push it away. I couldn’t understand it. I didn’t want to turn away from it because that seems dishonest. And something about meditating on the deity made me feel like there was a place for it in the cosmology. Like, whatever horrific thing is bothering me about existence, it’s part of the perfection. And something about the very vivid imagery of the wrathful deity and the understanding that this was created to kind of deliver a point. It was created with the intention to be benevolent. I don’t know, it just—it really clicked something for me. And ever since then, it’s not a big part of my practice, but it’s like, it’s somehow comforting to be like, this isn’t something that I have to push away. Like, the horror is kind of baked into the whole thing, the whole life thing.

Okay, thank you. Everyone else, how do you use the teachings?

Yes, there’s a few here. So, Philip: Sharon Osho’s description of empty boats bumping in the mist has lodged in my accessible memory enough for recall when my boat is bumped sometimes.

Mike Kaysey says: We talked about how much we put the teaching of right speech to test at work, where complaining and criticizing others becomes a central way that people sometimes bond with each other. So the precept becomes a knot of difficulty. You want to bond, but not at any price. You want to affirm people’s experience, but not by pressing others down. You want to feel part of something, but you just don’t want it to be a complaining session—although it often is. But we both agreed it comes up all the time, every day, and we try to see it clearly and practice it well.

Thank you.

Yeah. I just want to share—just a few weeks ago, during a Dharma talk, I was stricken by the idea of “not two.” And that’s been really useful to me when interacting with the world at large. With my son, for example, when I get angry at him, you know, and being like, not two—he’s not me either, not one, but not two, he’s not that. And that right away, in a weird, selfish way, gives compassion and calms everything down. Like, someone is swerving around and I’m, like, getting angry and like, oh, not two. That could be you. They probably have reasons, you know, and that—every time I’m able to bring that up, they’re not two. That recenters me and somehow, I don’t know, opens me to the other person and removes the wall—“that’s them and there’s me.” It’s like, no, but not no. You know, if that makes sense.

And why do you say that that’s selfish?

It’s self-serving a bit, I guess in a sense it helps me, you know. It’s like, being angry is not good for you. It’s not nice either. And so being able to use that to not give in to it—well, it’s a bit selfish, I guess.

I mean, being angry isn’t good for your son either.

I totally agree. Yeah, yeah, no, for sure. It’s like, of course, not two.

I use studying the precepts in my life by—well, one of the patterns I learned very young was that I have to lie and steal in order to be okay. I really felt like that was true, and that’s like a really strong feeling in my body. But I really trust and have faith in the precepts, that not stealing and not lying will actually bring me in the direction that I want to go. So I notice in moments when I feel like I’m about to lie, I can pause and feel that my body doesn’t trust that I’ll be okay if I don’t lie. But there is this other faith that I have in the teachings that I can—that can give me the courage in that moment to step in the other direction. And it always feels so much better.

And over time, has that sort of changed your view? So you have this—in a way you have this view that you have to lie or steal to feel okay. Is that changing as the evidence shows you otherwise?

Yes, yes, I noticed that now there’s like a paved path in my own body that tells me that I’ll feel better if I go in the direction of not stealing or lying. And then in the moments when I still slip up, it’s so much more accentuated how bad I feel. And like, it takes many trial and error, but over time I’m learning, like, okay, this really does feel so much better.

Thank you. Anyone else?

Sorry, I forgot, that’s your bad.

What do you think about right view becoming an obstacle when you may have an understanding—a right understanding—of a teaching, you may even have direct experience of that teaching and that reality, but the understanding becomes maybe a box or an expectation or—what do you think about right view becoming an obstacle in creating a fixed reality?

Well, does... Like, do you experience that?

I think that sometimes I can expect reality to be a certain way if I behave a certain way or think a certain way or—and that doesn’t always work out? It doesn’t always work out, but sometimes it does. But—

So then where’s the barrier? Where’s the problem? Like, is it in—like, is your view incorrect or is that—

Well, the view may not be incorrect, but I’m wondering about believing the view as a thing.

I mean, I guess I hear—I think I’m hearing something about expectation. You expect that if you act in a particular way, then things are going to turn out in a particular way. And that’s not always true.

I think I’m more asking about making the Dharma into something.

Well, that is—our job is not to turn the teachings into something, right? So, yes, if you’re experiencing that, then you’re sort of verifying that way that we can get stuck or sort of misuse the teachings, right? They’re not meant to become a belief. The other thing is—this is not directly related to your question, but reminds me of—we also—it’s like we can misunderstand the teachings, right, and sort of misuse the teachings. And so how do we not get fixed, right, and stay open to continual verifying, in a way, right?

Okay. I’ll talk a little bit about how do we study—part of what you were asking at the beginning. Some thoughts about how we study.

When I talk about—during the introductory weekends—I talk a little bit about study as a gate, and I often use the talk announcement. So before we hear a Dharma talk, there’s the encouragement that the talk may be—parts of it at least—may be dark to the mind. We can’t understand it in our usual way of understanding, but it can be radiant to the heart. We can understand it, we can take it in. How do we do that? And so we can kind of bring that same spirit to different ways of encountering the teachings.

So, when we are studying something, how do we allow ourselves to be open? And so that may be helpful. So when we listen to a talk, the guidance is that we sit in a zazen posture. We sit in a formal posture, which is open and receptive. In the tradition, there’s encouragement to not study a Dharma text while you’re lying down or slouching—I’m guilty—but it’s like, there’s a reason for that. Sometimes when I read that, it’s like, that’s kind of expressing, kind of showing, reverence for the Dharma, right? But it’s also because you’re not going to receive it in the same way as if you’re sitting upright.

Do we concentrate, right? So part of the talk instruction is practice just listening. So practice just reading, just taking in what you’re studying—really, that’s in any gate of practice, right? Concentration. Cultivating that.

How do we allow the teachings to be alive? How do we allow them in? There is instruction—you don’t hear so much in Zen—but to read and to reflect and then to verify. And so I think of study as sort of being the reading and reflecting part. What Tysha was saying at the beginning—how do we do that reflecting? Sometimes it might be helpful to have someone else, say, “How do you understand this?” Or, “Can I explain this to you? What I’m taking from this?” How do we do that reflecting? It takes some work sometimes to kind of get into the teachings, right? Sometimes they’re just hard to understand. And how do we find our way in so that there are—this reflecting part is like, how do we make it actually meet our experience, meet our life, so it’s not just an idea?

I think someone talked about coming back to things. So I think there is both ongoing study—I remember once at one point Shugen said to me, “You should always be reading something. You should always be studying something.” And so, sort of just to, like, keep ourselves in contact, right? There’s a reason that we hear a talk every week, right? Over time that, like, sinks into us. Daido Roshi used to—I remember him saying, you know, people would come up and say, “Thank you, that was such a great talk. Thank you, that was so helpful.” And sort of to the side, he would say, “I say the same thing every time.” And that’s not quite true, right? There’s some great talks, but it’s also kind of true. But we need to hear it over and over and over again, right? We hear little bits. Each time it kind of soaks in, and sometimes then we finally hear it.

And there is coming back to things. You know, I come back to, you know, sort of like circle around through the Zen sutras, right? Some of them are, like, difficult to understand. You read the Diamond Sutra—the first time I read the Diamond Sutra, it’s like, what? And the second time, it’s kind of like, what? You know, like, you keep coming back to it. And you’ve been practicing over time, and so you’ve changed, right? And things change. Maybe something enters this time. You understand something a little differently this time. And I find that’s true with all different kinds of teachings. So just to, like, keep coming back to them.

There’s a way—I was thinking about—I see this particularly in the Tibetan teachings, how they kind of seem repetitive. It’s like every time a teacher gives a teaching, they start with this whole kind of lead-in. And it’s like—but that’s helpful to hear it over and over again, to be reminded over and over again.

There is a way of kind of carrying the teachings around with you. And so maybe this is part of reflection, but I remember years ago, one of my early teachers said something—you know, like they had been, like, driving to Boston, and they said, “You know, while I was driving to Boston, I was thinking about that Dogen fascicle, reflecting on that.” And it was like, I don’t do that when I’m driving to Boston. But so, how about that, right? What are we—like, we can do that. And what happens then if we’re, like, just kind of carrying something around, checking in with it, reflecting a bit?

There are other ways of—I think Tycha was also saying this, right? So there is, you know, reading something silently to yourself is one way of encountering the teachings. Reading it out loud to yourself is different, right? I shared recently—I was doing that in a hermitage recently—I was like, “Whoa, this is very different. This is really helpful. I’m meeting this in a different way. It is entering me in a different way.” We chant—sometimes we chant the Heart Sutra every morning. We’ve been chanting some other teachings. That’s a different way of letting them in. There is a tradition of copying sutras, copying teachings, because that’s a different way of letting it in. And so to find different ways, to experiment with different ways, right? If it’s dead for you, do something different.

Andrew: I was just gonna ask, in terms of what we’re studying, about taking up texts that wouldn’t be, like, specifically Buddha Dharma texts. Like, you know, that the Dharma is not limited to that. You know, we can take it up through all kinds of texts. Everything’s pointing in a different way. So, like, I’ve got my Rilke poetry book, you know, and he’s pointing for me at a lot of things that feels grounded in Buddha Dharma. So how do we take up texts from all kinds of sources or study, like, this vast world, you know?

Well, a couple of thoughts. I mean, one, I would sort of question whether everything is pointing in the same direction, right? It’s not. When there are other views that are being expressed that are not the Buddhist teachings, that is not right understanding from the Buddhist point of view, right? And I guess my other—you know, so, which, kind of what I hear you saying about Rilke, you know, so they’re also—like, how about, can you read Rilke through your Buddhist understanding, right? I’ve been hearing some Rumi, right? It’s like, it’s a different tradition, and there are some things that are different, right? And we can, like, understand that and sort of bring it in line with our Buddhist understanding.

Yeah. Getting to your question, definitely. I think, I guess when it feels grounded in Dharma, it’s like even reading something that is, like, wrong understanding is learning about that, or we’re contacting our suffering, understanding that, and turning it and working with that.

Okay. If you are—right, there also is—you know, there have been—there also is—sometimes I’m reading something, I’m like, this isn’t feeding me. And sometimes it’s just a little entertaining, and so that’s why I’m reading it, maybe, but then it’s also like, that’s enough of that, because it’s not feeding me, it’s not helping me, it’s not pointing in the right direction. And I may be also hearing your question: we have to be discerning in what we study. And so if it is grounding, if it is feeding you, to know that, to discern that, and like, okay, turn towards that. And if it’s not, then not.

And I guess I would say that, you know, that’s also true—well, maybe, never mind.

You mentioned a couple times, if you’re reading something and it feels dead, make it alive. What does that mean? Or—you seem to be a rhetorical—how do you make it alive?

How do you make it alive? Yeah. I mean, I’ve offered some examples, right? You know, so you know that experience that I had of, you know, reading texts that I had read many times silently to myself, reading it then out loud, right, was very different. I don’t know that I quite have an answer for you, Ben. I feel like it’s sort of pointing to that. That is part of our, I don’t know—“task” isn’t quite the right word, but, like, in this gate of practice, right? How do we find our way in, right? You know, maybe another—you know, it’s sort of like the coming back to, coming back to a text, you know, is another way. So it’s—so I’m not finding my way in right now, but I’m not going to reject it, right? I’m going to put it down, go on to something else, and I come back to it later, right? But we do have to find our way in, right? I mean, I guess another thought is that there are different kinds of study that are helpful at different times. And so sometimes the Diamond Sutra is not what I need. I need something that’s much more accessible, a more contemporary teacher that has done some work for me in terms of making it more relatable to my life in this time and place, has done some translating from cultures for me. Sometimes what I need is just some inspiration. So, like, to read a biography of a practitioner—sometimes that’s helpful, and sometimes there’s also some teaching in there. But kind of what I need is just the inspiration.

Yoshi: I was just reflecting on Ben’s question and my experience of, like, I think especially earlier in my practice, really struggling with depression and, you know, difficult feelings, and being able to go to a Dharma text and actually find that really, like, named, you know, the misunderstanding of many lifetimes, like, oh my god, there it is, you know, and it’s been going on for all these hundreds of years that somebody else is talking about this confusion that I feel right now. And to me, that’s just—that’s amazing, right? And Hongzhi, you might be like, wander into the circle of wonder. It’s like, I don’t know where that circle of wonder—but I understand where that misunderstanding of many lifetimes is, because I’m in it, you know, in that life is dukkha, and can land there. So I feel like I was able, and I have been able, to really land and study through my own suffering and just finding so many places—Bodhidharma—that have been so helpful for me.

Yeah, yeah, yeah. Thank you. I really relate to that. And also for me, when I first—particularly when I first came to Buddhism or found Buddhism, it was like both that I recognized what I was feeling and—and there’s something you can do about it. I found that.

Dan, maybe last one.

I’ve seen a lot of monastics during study periods with notebooks next to them.

With what?

With notebooks, writing things. Never asked anyone, so I’m curious, is there like a—do you—and I think I’ve seen you with notebooks as well as you’re reading. Like, do you take—do you—are you just taking notes from what the words are? Are you writing reflections? Is there like a common theme or use? Or is it just kind of per person, per moment, what feels useful there?

I can only tell you what I do. I mean, yes, I find it helpful to take notes. That’s something I’ve learned over time. In actually Buddhist study, I was—like, in school I was never a very good note taker, but I find that it helps me to understand it. Also, I go back to it, and sometimes just as reference, but also I go back to it to find what am I going to talk about when I have to give a talk. Because I both write down, sort of take notes to help me understand, and I just take notes of things like, “This was really helpful,” or “This was inspiring,” or “This was—things that just kind of strike me.”

So, we did not get to what do we study, which I was reflecting, we don’t get a lot of guidance in that. Often people say, “What’s the curriculum? What should I read?” And so maybe that’s a topic for a different discussion, different time. We’ll have to wait.

Okay, thank you, everyone.
Speaker: Bear Gokan Bonebakker

Talk Location: Zen Center of New York City
Title: Right Imagination
Extracted Text:
Good morning everyone in Brooklyn, and wow, so nice to see so many new people here each week. When half the zendo goes upstairs for beginning instruction, it's great to have you. And I would so love to hear what this turning was for you—why you turned to this this morning. I don't know. For some reason right now, I don't even know what hour of the day it is. I don't know. Is it this morning? Anyway, welcome.

Yesterday we watched our second video for the ango, which was on Daido Roshi's teaching—my teacher, who started this Mountains and Rivers Order that you are in the midst of receiving the transmission of, by virtue of your being here and receiving beginning instruction in zazen and entering the practice of what the Buddha offered us over 2,500 years ago as a path to be free of suffering and really understand our heart and mind, our whole being.

So, we watched this video on the Mountains and Rivers Sutra, which was a sutra written by a Zen teacher named Eihei Dogen, which you'll probably hear a lot from if you stick around, in 1240. He was born in 1200 and only lived till 1252, so he was 40 years old when he wrote this sutra. And it's an integration of Daido's understanding and imagination and skillful means of using creative expression to convey the teachings of the Buddha, which is part of our lineage—using the creative expression path to sometimes show students the nature of reality through a brushstroke, through flute playing, through some movement.

And so, I began to—it just came up for me—I started to wonder this week about the role of imagination in practice life, in life. We receive all these methods of training, methods for how to arrange our body in the best way so we can set up an architecture, whether on the floor or a bench or a chair, so that energy can move through our system really openly. And we have to actually test that and work with that to make it skillful. We get the instruction, but we're also different, so we have to make that skillful for ourselves.

We learn all these ways, these antidotes to work with our afflictive emotions. When we're experiencing dullness, laziness, forgetfulness, agitation—obstacles, essentially—when we encounter our stinking thinking, how do we work with that? How do we get hooked on that? What's true? What's real and true? How do we set the thought free? Because sometimes that one thought just binds us, and it may not even be true, but we believe it. That's called our conditioning.

We learn about how to increase concentration and how that is made skillful. How do we imagine it to be? How do we imagine that teaching to manifest inside of ourself, in our practice? And it's great that our ancestors passed down so much wisdom, in whatever tradition we come from. Like, we don't have to starve to death to practice. Buddha became an ascetic, and he took in very little food, just really cut off the senses, and basically was starving—almost died. And he said, don't do that. You don't need to do that. Okay, I'll take that off your plate. You don't have to do that.

Also, Bankei got very sick, and he said, just push through your sickness. And he got sicker. And later he said, don't do that. Take care of yourself, you know? Otagaki Rengetsu, in her grief of losing four children and two husbands, saw that she needed a moving meditation. She worked on the potter's wheel, and she showed that that's sometimes skillful—that we don't just be still, that we actually move the energy in a moving meditation.

And so, we've been given these ways that people have imagined the teachings that can come into our body. And so yeah, I wanted to explore imagination as skillful means and to cultivate what is beneficial for ourselves, for others. In turn, imagination and reality are not in opposition. True imagination goes towards reality, shapes and evokes it.

So we need skillful methods to guide us. We need training. Just like you need training in anything you do—a job or something we want to get proficient at—we need to train in it. And yet at the end, that gets left behind. We don't need to continue now in the Eight Gates. So Daido has this training matrix that we work within—you'll learn about that if you like to. And in the glossary, I looked up skillful means, and the word for it is upaya, which means skillful means, and it says: forms that the teaching takes, reflecting their appropriateness to the circumstances in which they appear. Their purpose is to liberate the clinging mind so we can guide ourselves.

So the ango theme for this three-month period that we're working with is the mountain training. We're looking at these areas of training, and it's been a great ango. I hope those of you that are formally in it are enjoying it. For me, it's been a lot of re-meeting my teacher. He died in 2009, and I've been reading his books again, listening to his talks and hearing his voice, and hearing the teachings like anew. It's been great. And he's just changed his form of teaching, which people do. When people pass, they still teach us, they just change their form of teaching and skillful means.

So if we understand the teachings as skillful means, the next question would be: skillful means for what? And as I said, in Buddhist teachings, it's skillfulness for liberating the clinging mind from suffering. So in coming here, we are entering Daido Roshi's skillful means and the skillful means of the Buddha, the whole tradition.

And Daido used to say there aren't really Eight Gates. So there's body practice, art practice, face-to-face teaching, liturgy, moral and ethical teachings, work practice, right action. He just said, we're just one body, one heart, one mind. But we need to be able to focus on these different aspects of ourselves so we can go more deeply into our creative aspects, our moral aspects, our body, developing our skills for arousing and protecting bodhicitta, the heart-mind that wants to be a benefit in this world.

We have to develop and arouse and protect that within ourselves and see where we turn away and turn towards not creating harm, practicing good, actualizing good for others, cultivating and strengthening our aspiration to be of benefit.

And I read this before, but it came back again. So it's a book on contemporary artists practicing Buddha Dharma, and Robert Thurman—Buddhist scholar, he was the first American monastic of the Dalai Lama and he lived right by the monastery, and he was good friends with the monastery—so I pulled this from him. He says:

Say you are a Buddha and you're free of suffering. Okay, there's imagination right there. Say you are a Buddha. You are. Can you imagine? Say you are a Buddha and you're free of suffering and you feel totally great, as happy as a bee, as happy as a clam, at one with the universe. And then you see all these miserable people. What good would it do for you to go and give them a big grin and hug and smother them with joyfulness? They'll probably just get freaked out and paranoid, and they'll say, what does this person want? You know, we've had people do that to us, right? They'll just get... So instead, a Buddha has to develop some strategies, some art, to first open all that person's imagination. First of all, open that person's imagination to the fact that there is a world where we don't have to be miserable all the time. And then they have to develop for them a method of how to move from their paranoid corner of misery into the great ocean of the universe that you, a Buddha, perceive.

He says, in the sense that none of what Buddha expressed was driven by any sort of selfish impulse on the part of the being that was formerly Siddhartha Gautama. Everything he does is a communication of compassion to other beings, creating doorways to open their imaginations and then their whole beings to enlightenment, to nirvana, to peace. So to first present nirvana first as a work of art allows people to perceive it and open up to the possibility they can experience it for themselves. Who would want to seek nirvana if they couldn't imagine there was such a state, to be free from suffering?

So upaya is Buddha's art. As I said, Buddha was probably one of the first great performance artists. So first of all, to open our imagination to the fact there is a world we don't have to be miserable all the time. What generosity. He could have just gone off and said, I got it. Later, folks. Work it out. But he stayed. He taught with upaya, with skillful means, using the most powerful of mechanisms: our consciousness, the imagination. And we need these skillful means, these teachers, these methods to open us.

Yeah, so I was—this led me to—in the temple notes we put in this poem by Issa: "Under the cherry trees there are no strangers." Under the cherry trees there are no strangers. Have you been under the cherry trees with people, or any tree? What is that moment, that experience of being under them? And we're not strangers. There are no strangers.

And it reminded me of this line in Neruda's poem "Keeping Quiet," where he says, "For once on the face of the Earth, let's not speak in any language. Let's stop for one second and not move our arms so much. It would be an exotic moment, without rush, without engines, we would all be together in a sudden strangeness." There it is again, that sudden strangeness. And what is it, that if we don't make space for that—to quiet the mind—it's hard to imagine, because we're taken up by the rush of our life, the busyness.

And the Chinese character for busyness is heart over killing, heart killing. We become entrenched when we get too busy. We begin frozen in our imagination, in our actions. It gets really narrow. And do we ever take time to ask, what are we really here for? In real time, what are we really here for? Even in spiritual communities, sometimes people don't ask, which is weird, right? You think, what are we here for?

If we're truly part of a larger spiritual reality that can offer peace and happiness and empower us to make the world healthier, why wouldn't we enthusiastically embrace every practice that might help us enter into that reality? And to my mind, zazen is that primary practice that helps us discover and align ourselves with our true nature and its purpose, taking time to be open and present to a reality beyond what our tiny minds can grasp. Just in those moments of turning around.

This quote—George Bernard Shaw wrote about the true joy of life is in being devoted to a purpose recognized by ourself as a mighty one. He says, being a force of nature, instead of a feverish selfish little clod of ailments and grievances complaining that the world will not devote itself to making you happy.

And I'm not calling anyone here a little selfish clod of anything. I'm just saying: think about it. Are you too busy to do nothing? Which is, rather than being nothing, might actually mean everything to our happiness.

And this reminded me of an essay I read by Janet Ruffing years ago. She wrote this piece called "The Demon of Busyness." I'm just going to read you a little bit of it. I'd like to read you all of it because it's excellent. But she said many of us suffer from chronic busyness. And by the way, people always tell me they don't want to take up my time because I'm so busy. And I'm like, wait a minute, how do you know? And I don't say, I know what busyness is. I know what busyness feels like. We have to know what it feels like. But I also am full. I like being full. I like to be full of activity. I enjoy activity. Busyness, I can feel when it turns to heart killing; it just has a different feel to it.

So anyway, she says many of us suffer from chronic busyness, a sense of having so many things to do and not having enough time to do it. Ring any bells? We keep plugging on, hurrying to finish this task so we can get to the next one. She said the Demon of Busyness believes that this unending busyness is profoundly destructive to self-intimacy, intimacy with the divine, interrelationships, reflective thought, the fabric of our society, our care for the planet, and our own psychological and physical health.

She also notes that, contrary to the way most people think about it, busyness is not directly related to how many things we have to do. She cites Sister Gina from Plum Village, who explains concretely how it is possible to be active and engaged but not in a hurry. When we walk in a hurried way, we don't rest in every step. Instead, we seem to quickly touch the earth in order to get somewhere. So I practice taking the hurry out of my steps so that I can come to rest in every step—like our kinhin. It is a bit tricky because there's something in me that tells me if you don't hurry, you're going to be late. But I also experience that if I don't hurry up, I will get there much faster because the hurry comes from the worry, and the worry is very heavy and slows me down. If I drop the hurry and the worry, I can move a bit quicker and be in every step and be on time. Did you ever find that? Or maybe it's just too fast? You can try it. It's a very interesting experiment. You can meet this habit energy that says you have to hurry or you will be late. You can move faster, but you don't need to hurry. It's very handy when you're in the airport and a bit late, she says.

So if busyness is not helpful or sustaining, why is it so common? She said her insight is that we become overwhelmed by busyness because of ego and institutional pressures. We lose our mindful connection with our bodies and hearts. We lose our imagination. There is something about the feeling of busyness that is exhilarating. There is an altered state of consciousness I experience when I swing into action and begin working through today's to-do list. A burst of adrenaline carries me from one activity to another, how many things I can get done in the shortest amount of time. Racing against the clock becomes a game, sometimes an unhealthy competition, but nevertheless a game.

While I'm occupied orchestrating this internal race against time, I feel both strong and important. My ego is firmly in control. I am clearly the center of these activities, and this particular state of mind, of course, is illusory. When I am busy being busy, I avoid making time for leisure, for play, for relationships, for reflection. I delight in moving fast, being caught up in the rhythm of an institution, a city, a community that runs me and overwhelms my internal sense of self and my felt responses to internal and external events. I'm actually being captivated by a false consciousness that is largely generated by the culture outside of me. I go on automatic while believing I'm still in charge.

When I am busy, I can believe myself to be incredibly important in the scheme of things. I become independent, indispensable, necessary. My ego becomes reassured that I'm productive, accomplishing something worthwhile and valuable.

There's a book that the monastics are reading called "Making Sense of Mind: Why Yogācāra Buddhism Matters" by Bill Waldron. Yogācāra and Madhyamaka are two of the major schools of Mahayana Buddhism. They're different, but they have complementary perspectives on understanding reality and the path to enlightenment. Madhyamaka emphasizes the wisdom of emptiness, that there's nothing fixed, there's no fixed self or any selfness in anything that's permanent, that stays the same. And we see this in our zazen as we see thoughts come and we relinquish them and just come back to the vastness of the breath—just the breath. So it's right there, and that grows.

Yogācāra, known as the Mind-Only School, speaks of emptiness, but then it focuses on compassion, bringing that into our deeds, how we act, engagement. And so within the teachings of the Yogācāra is the work of Vasubandhu, who spoke of these three natures. Vasubandhu's three natures highlight the imaginary, dependent, and complete realized nature inherent in all aspects of phenomena. You with me? I'm sure you are.

Anyway, the imaginary nature of things is what we think they are, what we imagine them to be. The dependent nature is that they appear to arise from countless conditions. So that's what comes to mind, or all phenomena are momentary arisings that come together from countless conditions. We call it karma or karmic. And the complete realized nature is that they aren't as we imagine them to be—things that can be grasped or pushed away.

The three natures form the backbone of this Yogācāra philosophy. In order for us—skillful means—to see beyond our preconceived notions of ourselves and others, beyond the things that we're convinced are true, and open up a path to personal and communal healing. We don't hold each other fixed—ourselves or others—in something. Buddha encouraged us to use our own creative imagination to open our doors of perception.

And after his realization, when the Buddha was told he should go teach and not tuck away, he went and taught a crowd of thousands on the Prajnaparamita—what we chanted this morning, the Heart Sutra, the emptiness of all the conditions, what we chanted, right? Guess what? It's in the Lotus Sutra. Five or six thousand monks, nuns, and lay people left. They couldn't understand what he was talking about, and they all just got up and walked away. Some scholar called it the Heart Attack Sutra. Some people had heart attacks because Buddha was saying that there's nothing inherently anything, you know?

But yet, in the compassion part, here we are, yet this is here. We have to take care of this reality. But they all left, and Shariputra was there freaking out. What should we do? How are we going to get them back? And he's like, it's okay. It's my mistake. I started in the wrong place. That wasn't skillful. People don't get it. Let me think again. And then he came back and he taught the Four Noble Truths. And he said, hey folks, life suffers. And everybody's like, all ears. I'm in. I get it.

And that there's a cause for that suffering, that causes a thirst that's unsatisfied. Either we have something—we'll put it just kind of simply—we have something, we don't want it, or we don't have it and we want it, and we just circulate. And that's samsara. Never, always dissatisfied. There's this unsatiable thirst. It's called dukkha. And then we can actually—Buddha said—we can put an end to that cycle. We can end it.

And he taught the Fourfold, and he taught the Eightfold Path. And Daido created—dynasty begins with right understanding, and then right thought, right speech. Right could be perfect—right, perfect speech, perfect action. Not like "right" as opposed to "wrong," just complete—complete livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration.

And the second limb of the Eightfold Path, normally translated as right or perfect view, thought, can also be translated, I think, as right imagination. Having the right imagination—in this way, our right view is being able, the ability to go beyond our reactive patterns, beyond socially imposed norms, and envision different possibilities and outcomes which are more skillful and mindful. That's what we're doing. That's skillful means.

So it's an essential part of the Dharma path and teaching to test and direct our experience. What came up for me was—we're an imaginal body, and I realized that term was used a long time ago. Some of you therapists might know Henry Corbin, pre-Jung, who coined this term "imaginal" from his work as an interpreter of Islamic thought, where he describes this imaginal realm as holding images, stories, dream figures, embodied imagery, and movements that come to us beyond dimensions of our rational, intellectual perspective.

So we have all these methods that we are given that are very pointed and particular, and yet we're this imaginal body that actually puts it into our reality to be skillful and beneficial. Similarly, creativity—which is "nedi" in the Pali language—is crucial if we want to liberate ourselves and create a culture of awakening. We have to be creative.

So I guess, like, I've just been feeling like, please don't lose your imagination and your creativity. Don't get so busy. Find some quiet time to let that imaginal body come through.

In an essay by Stephen Batchelor, he explained how the Buddha often compared our development along the dharmic path with the creative labor of craftsmen, musicians, artists, doctors, who apply their desire, their effort, intuitions, and willingness to experiment to their projects. He says, using these skills and qualities, creative laborers begin with the raw materials of their work and transform them so completely into useful and beautiful products that the process is, in a fundamental sense, magical. We take the raw materials of our heart and mind and see them for what they are so that we can transform them into something useful, magical, which we are—like we hear in our may: we exist in muddy water with purity, like a lotus.

Have you ever seen—like a lotus grows out of the muck—that's us, and that muck has all the nutrients we need. So it's the stuff that we want to say, like, if I didn't have that, I'd be fine. If I wasn't like this, it would be okay. But how can we imagine that that darkness, that muck that we sludge through, has the nutrients to make us this whole beautiful being that we are? And once we can imagine that it comes together, we have much more space to hold the parts that we feel like we want to jettison in ourselves and in others. We accord it with the priceless gift of our attention.

He says keen attention becomes an act of deep regard, in which we grow more conscious. I keep Rilke by my bedside, and I was reading the Book of Hours. And of course, when I'm working on a talk, everything's like, I can use it. Like, every poem is like, there it is, there it is. So I just took one. I love this line. He writes:

"I know that nothing has ever been real without my beholding it. All becoming has needed me. My looking ripens things and they come toward me to meet and be met."

I know nothing has ever been real without my beholding it. All becoming has needed me. My ripening, my looking, my attention ripens things and they come toward me to meet and be met. The 10,000 things come forward as this self to be met.

This is why all of Buddha's teachings are considered to be skillful means. They are part of our refuge to protect us from ourselves and our lack of skill.

Daido also cautioned us in believing that we have all the answers as part of skillful means—that we know what is skillful for someone. And maybe you've been in that place where you think, I know what's best for you. Nene. Do we? Maybe. But I don't know. On the deepest level, we can present something, but we got to leave it open. We could say, this has worked for me and many others, but one has to drink it. We can be led. We all know this on some level.

So he said to be cautioned there, that we have the answers for someone else, or even that we know what is skillful. Skillful means can take years to initiate. We just practice it over and over, and then it starts getting skillful in and of itself. It's not skillful means. It takes my looking at it; it ripens it.

He also cautioned us against arrogance in that way, making someone disempowered with skillful means. Because we know Buddhist communities, and many continue to grapple with leaders claiming to be enlightened who say, I'm using skillful means, and taking advantage of their power dynamic. So there's that in history, in our Buddhist history, more recently, in fact. So skillful means isn't skillful on its own.

And Dido said, don't think we get into an attitude where you take your seat and you say, okay, do me. I'm sitting, meditating. So we actually have to—it needs us. Skillful means needs us. When the mind is free of attachment and delusions, its actions are effortlessly creative, boundless in expression, and perfectly tuned to the moment, just like the universe itself.

One of our students wrote a book on the Greek language, and in the beginning, she starts with one word on one page, and it's "ginosko." And it actually—it says, it means to come to know, the recognition of what is true by experience, because nothing can—this is written by, I'm not sure who—because nothing can be skillful means unless it has been associated with the earth. I like that. Nothing can be skillful means unless it's associated with the earth, unless it's occurred within our body; we're the earth.

We need to imagine and visualize and return to our body, heart, mind, to the earth, in and through it to find out what's true.

This one Buddhist teacher says we need to throw the word "visualization" out the window. It is the wrong word, because the word visualization implies something visual. It implies working with visual images, and it also implies working with the eyes. This is incorrect. Instead, we are working with the imagination. When we work with the imagination, we're not just working with imagined sights, but also with imagined sounds, smells, physical awareness, sensations, feelings, emotional feelings, and so on.

To affirm the pervasiveness of emptiness is to discover the fact there is no inherently existing self.

So that's what I got on imagination. I'll end with Daido's words. And also, I love this psychologist/analyst Marion Woodman, who was a Jungian analyst, and her favorite, I guess, phrase was: "If we could allow the pace of our meetings to slow down to the pace of our hearts, we might find genuine understanding." If we could allow the pace of our meetings with whatever we're meeting to slow down to the pace of our hearts, we might find genuine understanding.

And so how does that factor in with zazen? Zazen gives us that opportunity to strengthen that ability to slow down to the pace of our heart when we meet something, so we can understand, get genuine understanding throughout this whole earth.

Daido Roshi says, so please, when you practice anything skillfully, practice your life. Trust yourself completely. Trust the process of sitting. Know that deep within each and every one of us, under those layers of conditioning, there is an enlightened being, alive and well. In order to function, it needs to be discovered. To discover this Buddha is wisdom. To make it function in the world is compassion. It's not great if it's just emptiness. It's got to function. Otherwise it's not useful. We can't even do anything if it's emptiness. And emptiness isn't a thing. We can't even walk across the street. We got to come back in the world.

That wisdom, he says—to make it function in the world—is compassion. And that wisdom and compassion is the life of each one of us. It's the skillful means, the spontaneous creativity of the universe. It's up to you what you do with it.

Thank you. Thanks so much for listening.

For meditation supplies such as cushions, incense, liturgical instruments, Dharma books and more, visit monasterystore.org—support for your spiritual practice at home.
Speaker: Jody Hojin Kimmel

Title: Daio's Shuso Hossen Talk And Encounter
Extracted Text:
Attention. True Dharma Eye Case 65, Guizhong's One Flavor Zen.

The main case: A monastic bid farewell to Guizhong. Guizhong said to him, “Where are you going?” The monastic said, “I'm going to many places to study the five flavor Zen.” Guizhong said, “There is one flavor at my place.” The monastic said, “What is your one flavor Zen?” Guizhong hit him.

Good morning, everybody. Good morning to those of you here and those of you joining from home. Good afternoon, Amy and Ollie and Annie. Thank you for making this life possible. My name is Dayo. It's my pleasure to offer this short talk this afternoon as part of the Shuso service position.

I know that in my training here I found these mornings incredibly helpful. Some of you have already been slated to ask questions afterwards, but I really encourage you, if you're not on that list, to sort of get involved internally. How would you respond? What would you say? What would you ask? These live opportunities for training can really stay with us and feed our practice for years to come.

So with that being said, let's jump in with Guizhong and the departing monastic and let's try and make it about us. Close as many gaps as we can.

So, we go to one of the teachers and we tell them we're leaving. They say, “Well, where are you going?” Say, “Well, I'm off to get the five flavors Zen from a whole bunch of places.” Teacher tells us, “There's only one flavor here.” We ask them what that is. That's pretty simple. So why is a monastic, or anybody—why is anybody getting hit for simply expressing their desire to go get some teachings from some places?

This is from Master Yuanwu: “Ever since ancient times, people with the will for the path have traveled around from region to region seeking instruction from adept wayfarers. They truly did not let their lives in this world go by in vain. Thus they did their best to put their conditioned mind to rest and picked out teachers who genuinely possessed the enlightened eye. When they encountered such teachers, they put down their baggage and stayed for as long as necessary, relying on these adept teachers to help them complete the work.”

Master Dogen took a ship from Japan to China and back again and said, upon returning, “I return empty handed. The eyes are horizontal, the nose is vertical.” Now, that's some serious going around that Dogen got up to, and in one sense came back empty handed. So even the great Dogen traveled.

So if Yuanwu and Dogen's words carry some weight for us, we can move past the idea that going around is the issue. This sangha, our sangha, is from all over. You know, we go all over. Clearly, it's the mind that we do it with that's crucial and really the heart of this encounter.

So let's imagine after we finish today, we go outside in the field and we hear a little voice: “Oh, no. Oh no.” From the field, as we go over, the sky is lamenting, “I need to be more spacious. More spacious. Please help.” What would we try to explain to it? “What? You're the sky. You can't be more spacious or less spacious. How would you even do that? You're the sky.” What if it didn't change? Would we run around to demonstrate to it just how spacious it is? Get in a lawn mower and fly around in our compassion, our love for the sky? Would we resort to attempting to give it a whack, to demonstrate its remarkable spaciousness?

If we fill the sky with Canadian geese, could we diminish the sky's spaciousness? Or if we eradicated every cloud, mountain, tree, could we increase the sky's spaciousness? And then, if the sky came to its senses and went back to being, well, just the sky, would we say that it achieved spaciousness?

This example is me somewhat clumsily adapting a koan among cast. Seijo Daitsuchisho Buddha did zazen for ten kalpas, could not realize the highest truth and so could not become fully emancipated. Why was this? Seijo said, “Your question is a very appropriate one.” The monk would not put that down. They asked again, “Why did he not attain Buddhahood by doing zazen in the meditation hall?” Seijo replied, “Because he did not.”

We say that delusion is going around looking for a head to put on our own. That's how I'm interpreting this monastic's five flavor trip. Get something from each of those schools, something the monk thinks they need. Clearly, everything can be a flavor. We think we need a head to put on top of our own: a promotion at work, a new car. This robe can be a new head, a new flavor. “I'm a practitioner” can be a flavor. If I think I don't have it and I can get it from somewhere, it's another head, another flavor.

The delusion of desire is that me, a discrete, separate object, lacking something, thinks that more value is added to me because I get that thing that is currently outside me, or on the rejection side of delusion, that my value is somehow reduced if that object gets too close.

One of my boyhood heroes, Eric Cantona, said, “When seagulls follow the trawler, it is because they think sardines will be thrown into the sea.” Some of us end up living our whole lives as the sardine or the seagull or the trawler. What if we look beyond the foreground, the objects? Other options are available.

But this delusion process, we might say, is far more insidious than just an object acquiring objects and just occasionally rearranging them. It sometimes kind of seems quite benign, like the worst thing we might be is just a little bit hoarderish. But it's not like I get that thing, put it on a mantelpiece or a dusty attic, or if we're a bit fancy, it's not like I get that thing and put it in some sort of beautifully lit art gallery. It's not that sterile or innocent, because the thing isn't a thing. Whatever it is, whether it's an object or an idea or a part of my life, we have to make it into a thing every minute, every second.

It's like we kind of choose a piece of the water in the ocean and give it an arbitrary boundary. And we're not doing this once or twice a minute. This is multiple times a second. We have to use our mental energy and our life force to bring that object into being in our mind so we can attach it to this object, “me,” which we also have to make, naturally. Nothing is fixed and static.

So after we've made our important thing, given it a value, we have to use our mental energy to attempt to solidify it, either so that we can keep hold of it or to keep tabs on it, make sure it doesn't get too close. No wonder we're exhausted.

Ziyong, a nun from around ninth-century China, said, “The pine tree does not envy the plum. That is the practice.” Well, this process of objectifying, fixing, holding, we might say, is really honest because we're just responding to our fears. We probably all have this. You know, I certainly grew up in an environment where the message was: there is not enough. You're not enough. You have to compete. Individuals compete, groups compete, nations compete. Some people even tell us that's completely natural. It's just human nature. They say, “It's me against the world.” And that is so often reality-defining, scary.

An oft quoted koan is Zhaozhou's oak tree. A monk asked him, “Why did Bodhidharma come from the West?” Zhaozhou answered him, “The oak tree in the front garden.” What? Bodhidharma wasn't competing. He wasn't solving a problem, just an oak tree in the front garden. Was Zhaozhou so far ahead, in so much luxury, that he could afford to give a seemingly absurd answer? What is he pointing to?

I can totally relate to this monk trying to work out Bodhidharma's intention. If I know his motivation, I can sort of like transpose that onto my situation and I'll do the thing that will get me ahead. I might not do it as smoothly as old Bodhidharma, but it'll get me somewhere. And the answer comes back to me: the oak tree in the garden. Sorry.

Mumon's poem in the Gateless Gate for this koan reads:  
Words do not express fact.  
Phrases do not reveal the delicate motion of the mind.  
Those who accept words are lost.  
Those who adhere to phrases are deluded.

Why? Why does adhering to and accepting words and phrases leave me lost and deluded? Why did Guizhong perform such an extraordinary act of striking someone? Because they seemed a bit attached to five flavors of words and phrases. Is the hit extreme?

Responding to our fear, we wind up fixing everything. This is this. That is that. This is how things are to me. Everything gets solidified. You might say we turn the world to stone. Well, this is really quite dangerous. As soon as we look under the hood a little bit, as soon as something comes along that has more value—and it most certainly will, because in our desperation we'll create it—we'll dispose of the less valuable thing. This thing here might be me, you, that group, that nation, those trees, that ocean.

This is a huge part of our “beyond fear of differences” work. Is there merit in finding the courage of not knowing each other, not fixing each other in place, not giving each other a value? Not knowing? The quote “not knowing is most intimate”—we see that over and over again in the teachings. Is it hyperbole to say that not fixing things in place, not knowing ourself, not knowing things, might be a question of life and death?

Hojin Sensei, over and over through the years when I've gone into dokusan room with a problem, has always said to me, and I'm sure to many of us, to simply get curious, take a look. That's pretty powerful. Just take a look. You know that monster under the bed relies on us not looking under the bed. If we get a little bit curious, just poke even half an eyeball down there—wait a second.

We might have all come here because we were, or are to a decent amount, turning it to stone. So what is it when we get curious? This is from the verse:  
The Great Way is vast and all-pervading.  
If you direct yourself toward it, you move away from it.  
So is there just like one Great Way flavor? And we've got to get ourselves at the perfect distance from it, not moving towards, not moving away?

The Great Way moves. We move. Do we have to be like flamingos dancing perfectly in line, perfectly in synchronization? There's us and the Great Way doing this dance forevermore. Daido Roshi's commentary to this koan says, “The principle cannot be grasped within words and ideas.” When we hear the words “one flavor,” we're almost certainly going to create a thing out of this oneness. Maybe we conceive of a homogenous pink-beige mass, probably with a little bit of glitter. It's got to be a little bit special, right? Guizhong hits. It's hard to keep telling our fairy tales when that hit fills the heavens.

So is it just a case of balancing the two sides of each idea? The student says five or many, so Guizhong says one. Is he just trying to get the monastic to see the other side of the coin? And the middle way isn't a halfway point. It's not two and a half flavors. “Think neither good nor evil,” doesn't mean to position ourselves in the just-about-okay middle. It's not sitting on a fence, never doing anything for fear of tipping the scales one way or the other.

We might say the middle way is the absence of falling into this or that, just letting go of measuring by abandoning the scales altogether. Abandoning the scales, the measuring stick, can, in my experience, be incredibly terrifying because it seems like we're giving up the mechanism that we think our entire life rests on—getting that thing I don't have, keeping that other thing that I don't want away.

Kim Euryeop, a Korean nun who just passed away maybe about 50 years ago, said, “The more I threw away, the more I became. My body, my name, even my opinions—those were only shadows pretending to be me.” So when things are getting solid, we've got to find a way to fray the edges of those constructed solids, shake things loose a little.

I've always found nature a pretty willing helper in this when I've needed a bit of shaking loose. Ed Yong—he wrote a book called Immense World about how animals perceive the world. He's got innumerable examples of this. It's very enlightening for this. You know, that we used to think animals were this. Then we discovered they're far more remarkable than we ever gave them credit for.

So for apparently years, and until relatively recently, folks in Europe thought that swallows in the winter, because obviously they disappeared, they thought that swallows burrowed down into the mud in the bottom of ponds. And then a scientist and a team of scientists, they started getting reports of these tagged swallows in Africa.

We'll fast forward a few “oh wow” moments now. It seems obvious, right, that instead of burrowing into the mud under ponds every year, swallows make this remarkable five or six thousand mile migration. They must have some pretty good batteries on their phones to guide them all the way, right? Well, now I can see swallows a little fresher. The edges of that thing I call a swallow don't have to be fixed. I can leave a door, maybe a window, maybe a whole wall open for them. When the edges of mind's facts fray, they start to breathe a little. When they can move, they can be fluid. Then we don't need to worry whether it's a question of one or five, this or that, striving or not striving.

Yuanwu says, “Rootless, but finding life.”

A few years ago, I was watching a documentary. It was about Eliud Kipchoge. He's becoming the first person, at least that we know of, to run a marathon in under two hours. It's a really wonderful watch and it's quite fascinating for me from a practice point of view.

Firstly, Kipchoge just seems like the kind of person you might consider just taking up running, just to spend a bit of time around. He's warm, determined, and sort of a part of him seems to be operating in a field that we can't quite see. And part of the documentary is it shows two different running clubs or training camps. One camp, you know, I'll sort of disparagingly call them the Clipboard and Computers camp. You know, it's very structured. The athletes have their striving measured out for them. “Run at this pace.” The coach tells them, “At age 15, you should be capable of this, 19, this.” You know, it's a little bit unkind, but machines. I thought those guys must be a great big bundle of “I.”

The Kipchoge Club. They just, they just seem to—the whole, I don't know, there's this massive group of people just goes out running. The junior runners are just running with the professionals. Those junior runners just ran when they could keep up, they could. And when they didn't, they didn't. There was no one telling them what was possible, who they should be, how they should measure themselves.

Artists maybe, when they're running so freely, are they striving to run? Are they not striving to run? Now, I think I'm taking a huge artistic license and projecting what I wanted to see. But it did strike me that if you want to run freely, and therefore presumably quickly, it's really helpful to be free as you're doing it.

This is again from Yuanwu: “If you can be free and clear in actual practice for a long time, naturally you will come to meet the source on all sides and become unified and whole right before your eyes. It has always been that if you don't know it in your daily life, where then will you look for it? Better find out.”

And finally, Hojin Sensei turned me onto this quote from: “Just resting is like the great ocean accepting hundreds of streams, all absorbed into one flavor. Freely going ahead is like the great surging tides riding on the wind, all coming onto this shore together. How could they not reach into the genuine source?”

There is a verse about this case. I requested that Kaiku read it.

The Great Way is vast and all pervading.  
If you direct yourself to, you move away from it.  
For the mind unified with the way, all striving ceases.

The Great Way is vast and all pervading.  
If you direct yourself to, you move away from it.  
For the mind unified with the way, all striving ceases.

The Great Way is vast and all pervading.  
If you direct yourself toward it, you move away from it.  
For the mind unified with the way, all striving ceases.

The Great Way is vast and all pervading.  
If you direct yourself toward it, you move away from it.  
For the mind unified with the way, all striving ceases.

The Great Way is vast and all pervading.  
If you dare direct yourself toward it, you move away from it.  
For the mind unified with the way, all striving ceases.

The Great Way is vast and all pervading.  
If you direct yourself to it, you move away from the inexhaustible lion's roar.

How will you use this shep, freely giving life and taking it away? This is a 3-foot long brown snake. A long time ago, it had become a campora flower. On Mount Gudhakutra and on Mount Sharon, it had become a plum blossom. Sometimes it transforms into a dragon and swallows heaven and earth. Sometimes it transforms into a diamond sword with the freedom to kill and give life. Right now, in accord with the order of my teacher, it lies in my hands. I feel like a mosquito trying to bite an iron bull. However, being assigned Chief Disciple, I have to fulfill my duties now.

You dragons and elephants in this Dharma Hall. Confront me in Dharma Encounter. Kaiku, you go first.

Attention. I have always been taken with this idea of striving because, well, striving brought me here. Striving gave me a career. Striving in many ways worked for me. So how and why should I give up striving?

He started by saying, “Taken by the idea of striving, may your life go well. Thank you for your teaching.”

Attention. Give me a wave. Where are you? Hello. My dog's afraid of motorcycles. Sometimes she and I hold her, and sometimes I comfort her and I pet her. And sometimes I shout at her, “Stop it.” I even kicked her once. Is the hit the right action for the monk? Not because it's a hit, but how do you come from the place where it's not the habit?

What is your dog's name? Rosa. Rosa. Could you share a little bit about Rosa, briefly? Say it again? Could you share briefly a little about Rosa? Found her on the street in Mexico. She loops up in a circle when she sleeps. And she thinks that motorcycles are terrible. And sometimes she just—she looks at me. When one passes and I look at her, there's no reaction at all. You just never know.

She sounds quite wonderful. Avalokiteshvara perceives the cries of the world. And so compassion is shown in all its many forms. May your life go well. Thank you for your hand.

Attention. Shuso. What is your one flavor Zen? Approaching the altar: shashu. Departing the altar: gassho. May your life go well. Thanks for your answer.

Attention. In a world with so many different flavors, so to speak, it can seem almost like an infinite number of flavors, especially in just contemporary society. I find myself thinking, how do we engage with that? How do we be in that without getting carried away or without rejecting it completely, completely disengaging from society?

Why do you need to disengage? Why do you need to reject? If you don't want a strawberry ice cream, right? You don't sit at home all afternoon going, “Get away, strawberry ice cream.” May your life go well. Thank you for your teaching.

Attention, Shuso. The world seems to have meter sticks baked into it—like, seems to have meter sticks baked into it, part of everything we do. How do we let go of that in a world that seems to demand it?

What is this world? Teaching, helping. But where does that will come from? Is it just there? How does it get there? Well, society creates rules, things that we need to do. And then you... May your life go well. Thank you for your answer.

Attention. Shuso, when I'm sitting zazen and directing my mind towards not adding anything to what's there, it seems like I'm directing my mind even if I'm not, and my mind is not. And it seems like there needs to be some form of striving or directing or right effort. It's part of the Eightfold Path. I... I'd like to experience or do. I don't know. I want to make right effort. How do I do that when it's not towards something?

Your service position was a server this week, right? Yeah. How did you serve? You. You actually don't need to use any words. Just show this anger. How did you serve? Sorry to confine you. I mean, I thank the people I serve. Sometimes I didn't serve. Sometimes I served. Did a condiment tray of sugar and peanut butter magically appear in front of myself and Shugen Roshi? Yeah, I guess so. A wonderful bodhisattva just served. May your life go well. Thank you for your teaching.

Attention. Shuso, Hojin—you talked of how she encouraged curiosity. When you come with a problem, can you share some of what you've learned so far about bringing yourself to curious? And if you like, cite things you've seen in your teachers and Dharma sisters and brothers.

What is your motivation for asking the question? I actually don't quite understand the question, it's quite long. What is your... When you get beneath the surface of that, what do you want out of this response? What's your motivation?

Learn more about when I'm really upset with negative emotions, how I get to the place of curious. I have some skill at that and want to continue to learn about that.

Okay. So I'm wondering for you this morning, Alexandra, for the benefit of few of you who didn't hear, she said—paraphrasing—Alexandra, resisting is really tempting. We have somehow... This is a point for not the middle way. We somehow have to get that fire going in us that we tip the scales 1% more “I want to wake up” than “I want to go to sleep.” So when I'm in pain, god damn it, I did that again, I hurt my Dharma sister. I can't do that. May your life go well. Thank you for teaching.

Attention. Yep. Coming from tasting five flavors, knowing there's one. I don't... How do you commit to that? How do you step into that? How do you throw off the meter stick when all you—all I think I know is five flavors?

When you're eating mango, mango. You're eating strawberry, strawberry. How many is that? Mango. May your life go well. Thank you for your answer.

Attention. So this—why didn't the monk taste what he'd just eaten? Same old. He's leaving, he's been there, he's been eating, he's asking, “What flavor is this?” Why doesn't he know?

Yeah, that's a good question. Society does it to us. No, I don't know. I don't know how I came by this conditioning. Having spent a little bit of time around people who've walked down this path a few more steps, I can see, wait, what are they doing? What are they being that I'm not, somehow. So I don't know why sometimes or anyone sees or what anyone doesn't see. All I know is that I do want to see. I can't control it. When I put plants in the ground, I just try and give them the best soil possible. I can't control the flowers. May your life go well. Thank you for your answer.

Attention. I've heard you say a couple times, “I want to see and I want to wake up.” Yeah. And to hold that without striving. We have a Buddha on the altar. It's not nothing. How do we strive to not strive? How do you not strive to not strive while not having an empty altar?

This is running as much as I can with the fan and the stick. This is running. If I start commentating, oh, my Lord, I'm going to run through treacle. Just run. Just practice. Don't worry whether you're striving or not striving. May your life go well.

Attention. Shuso, how do I know it's striving or how do I know if I just really care? You know, when I'm a perfectionist and I feel like part of it comes from feeling like, not good enough and, and coming from this culture and the society of scarcity and, and, and just making us feel like, making me feel like I'm constantly lacking. Right. But then in Buddhism, you know, the paramitas are like the perfections. And so sometimes, like, I'm straightening out all the zafus and the zabutons after we sit and, and, and, and I see the perfectionist in me, you know, and is it, am I striving for something? Am I competing here or is there genuine compassion? I just really care. So how do you know the difference?

So you're straightening the cushions. Yes. Then you start having a nice little conversation about it with yourself. And then, and then what's next? I straighten the next cushion. May your life go well. For your answer.

Attention. There's a time for staying. But sometimes the staying is comfortable and it feels good and it's not really working and it's time to leave. There's a time for leaving when it's not working and it's hard and, and you need to do something else. How do you know? How do you know when it's the time?

Another way we might say, why didn't that monastic taste? Why didn't they know? In one sense, it sounds kind of harsh, but I'll make it about me. When I don't know whether to stay or go, when I don't taste, I've kind of got my hands around my own throat now. What can I do at that point? Either I jump or I try and loosen the grip, or someone comes along and gives me a whack. I haven't really answered you there. Let's keep talking about that. I feel like that's a good question. I didn't really meet that. May your life go well. Thank you for your answer.

Attention. So there's a lot of hitting and things in the koans, and we don't do that anymore for the most part. But there's a sense of urgency and a directness that's conveyed. So if you were the teacher, how would you convey that sense of urgency, that directness? And how do you know? What is that hit? What is that hit?

When we let go of it being a hit, what is it? It's contact. It's right now. When we let go of it being a hit. May your life go well.

Attention. Shuso. Congratulations on being a senior monastic. Where are you going? On Skegness Beach, I took a ride on a donkey. May your life go well.

Attention. Attention. Shuso, from the moment I've gotten here, I've wanted to get out. And yet here I am. How has it been for you, Rusty Nail? May your life go well. Thank you for teaching. May your life go well.

Being immature and insufficient in training, I wasn't expecting to be assigned as chief disciple. I feel as if a crime has been committed that fills the heaven. There isn't a place on earth for me to hide. I hope that there's enough water in the Esopus for you to rinse my words out of your ears. Water flows and returns to the sea.

Well done, Shuso. Well done.

To Shuso Daio, this is like a mountain returning home. Cultivating a spring to share, to give you. Planting thousands of flower seeds in the winter greenhouse. Sitting in the brightness of awareness and putting among sympathetic black dope. Days and night passing, your eyes were watching and caring. Your fingers are connecting and responding. Look. Wow. In the opened empty field, born the 10,000 baby spring. Arms and hands dancing, shining, touching our spirits. Sealed window. Knocking, knocking. The monk, go open the windows. First time of the year we were sitting and you say, “Today the zendo's windows are open because spring is here.” But now we find and feel our spring in here. It's because somewhere inside of us opened. And that is not a small thing. Congratulations for you, Shuso.

Oh, what a path you have planted here. Greeting friends old and new. A bright evolution. One season to the next, one year to the next. What ease and brightness you bring in such smiling spring color. Stately red and violet columbine. Subtle toned hellebore. Joyful bursts of purple allium. What generosity you offer the Sangha. Each tiny seed at a time. Who knows what colors will blossom next. Congratulations, Shuso.

Did the mouse really say “olay” as it ran past you? The alliums stand proud while the foxgloves burst into laughter. Your warmth is infectious. We watch as the blue heron takes an eternity to reach the other rock. “Let's remain in this timelessness together,” you say. With you, the world feels vast and boundless. Congratulations.

Su Dayo, a question. How come you planted so many flowers? Rows and beds of flowers. Do you love how they dance in the spring breeze? Do you love how the pollinators arrive hungry with joy? Or do you love us? Love this mountain? It's simply what a flowering heart does. Thank you, Shuso.

Congratulations for Dayo. Just like a fish jumping out of the water, suddenly a net leaping free, spreading out over the entire ocean. A day comes, a heart. Open. Land ho. Best wishes for the day. Love you.

High or low, dirt, digging in the dirt. Shuso, I see your smile. Uplifting children or simply being like a child, leading the wayward, guarding the true. Your staff is barely visible amidst the poppies and foxglove. Completely lost inside that good field protector Arhat. Or maybe just a regular guy gone mad in the springtime with the love of it all. Congratulations for Dayo.

Fierce dancing flames licking the night sky. How did it become so strong? Mystery is the fuel, with a bit of British humor thrown in the mix. Burning, burning ever brighter, warming the bones of the Sangha. Congratulations, Shuso, for Dayo.

Oh, the flowers. Who knew they could show so much Monarda? Modeling vulnerability, the courage of columbine, alliums tall and straight, sincere, the sneezeweed wise beyond its name, echinacea exudes enthusiasm. And when those poppies pop, they will fill the world with love. Congratulations, Shuso.

For Dayo. His heart melds with silent blossoms the same day they scatter in the wind. Mountain walking, mountain tasting loves, mountain training, loving, mountain blooming. How many flavors deepen in this spring drizzle?

It seems that you have a reputation, Dayo. One mountain, one flavor, one great response. How is it? When springtime finally calls, there is someone who gives loving attention to the many blooming flowers. And because of this, this joy just cannot be contained. Congratulations.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Title: Shugen Saturday Sesshin Talk
Extracted Text:
The following Dharma discourse was given by Jeffrey Shugan Arnold at Zen Mountain Monastery. Shugan Roshi is the head of the Mountains and Rivers Order and abbot of the monastery. This talk, like all of our talks, is offered free of charge. If you would like to make a donation or find out more about our various programs, visit us online at zmm.org. Thank you for listening.

This is from the Book of Serenity: Sun Sheng's Golden Fish.

Meeting the strong, be weak; meeting the soft, be hard. If both are hard and meet each other, there will surely be one damaged. But tell me, how do you interchange?

San Sheng asked Xuefeng, “The golden fish that's passed through the net, what does it use for food?” Xuefeng said, “When you come out of the net, I'll tell you.” Sun Sheng said, “The teacher of 1,500 people, yet you don't even know a saying.” Xuefeng said, “My tasks as abbot are many.”

Verse: When first ascending, the tears of waves, clouds and thunder accompany leaping up magnificently. Look at the great function. With a burnt tail he clearly crosses the gate of view. The beautiful fish won't agree to be sunk in a pickle jar. An old, mature person does not startle the crowd. Someone used to facing a great adversary has no fear from the start. Floating, floating, just as light as five ounces. Massive, massive, heavier than even a thousand tons. Sancheng's exalted fame over the four seas—who again was his peer? Xuefeng stands alone. The eight winds blowing do not move him. The ship is coming into harbor.

I always have this sense image of On Go as a ship setting, sailing the beginning and now 45 years on Mount Tremper. In Buddhist geologic terms, we're barely through the birth canal. But in terms of life here on Mount Tremper, it is something I hope there will be a 90th, 100th anniversary—think about that hundredth anniversary. We'll have to come back and shake some bones, see what's going on.

I remember watching “The Rock Grow,” that very special, very simple, very early video that Daido Roshi did for the 10th anniversary. And in that he was talking about the future. People were always trying to get him to say what was going to be happening in 15 years, 20 years. He said, “I don't know, I'm not a prophet.” But he talked about the Eight Gates, and he said, “Look, if they continue to be useful, then I hope that, you know, the teachers in the future will continue to use them. If they're not, then they should let them go.” And I remember really being struck by that because those coming into formation, being brought out in the book—that book that was really important at that time—was kind of represented something, you know, a kind of coming together of the articulation of this training that he was developing with us together and talking about the lay and monastic paths.
