He used to talk about that a lot in the beginning, how he wanted them both to have full integrity and be different. He didn't want them to be blurry. And then he would say, “Well, you know, if we don't need this anymore, then we should let it go, you know, and use what's needed at that time.” It reminded me of Egyoku, who was a long, long time student of Maezumi Roshi’s and a teacher—she was the abbot of Los Angeles for some time. She told the story that in the early years, she was fretting over ZCLA and their finances. It was early years and they didn't have much, and she went to him and said, “Roshi, I don't know how we're going to do this.” He said, “It's okay, it's okay. If we have to let go of the center, we let it go. The sangha will still practice.” I was struck by that too—you know, putting so much effort into developing, finding, establishing, growing a center, and him, leading that sangha, saying very freely, “If we can't do this here, we'll let it go. It's not in the building.”

These mountains and rivers of the present are the actualization of the word of the ancient Buddhas. Each abiding in its own dharma state completely fulfills its virtues. I think that those are some of the most beautiful words spoken.

Mountain training. Dogen speaks of mountain training. To deeply study the word of the ancient Buddhas. And to study the word is to study the body and mind of the Buddha's ancestors—to make them our own body and mind. It's intimate, it's personal. That's why we have to get in close. To study the self within this body and mind, to study the perceived self in others. What is it? Is it to free ourselves? Simple words: to free ourselves. To free ourselves from the net that shows up in all kinds of ways. And the problem with that net is when we find ourselves entangled in it, it's not enough to just be tangled—we throw it onto others. We kind of can't not do that; we kind of can't not have an influence. And we influence each other with ourselves. And if that self is caught and deluded and angry or greedy, then that's the net we toss out. If it's clear and kind and compassionate, then that's the net.

Meeting the strong, be weak; meeting the soft, be hard. Of course, strong and weak can mean all kinds of things. There's social conditioning, gender conditioning, historical narratives about what is strong, what is weak, what is soft, what is hard. And we absorb it, and then we bring that into practice. And so to really understand and begin to experience what is real strength, what is true weakness—he's saying, when meeting the strong, be weak. We tend to think of weakness as a fault, as something we want to avoid. He's saying, no, employ weakness. So what is that? Meeting the soft—to be hard, to be pliant, to develop pliancy, suppleness. To think of that as a trait, as a quality, as a virtue, something that we're trying to develop.

That's why we have to keep meeting so many different situations, circumstances, as practitioners—a pliant mind and body—so that we can meet the needs of ourselves, of others. You know, I think about what is the allure, what is the seduction of a dictator? You know, somebody who knows all the answers, somebody who's going to take care of you, right? Make it all right. I don't have to think, I don't take responsibility. I just follow. But it has no fixed form. And so we have to practice letting go of the sense of a fixed form in anything in training, which can seem kind of odd since there is attention to detail—the way we hold a bell, the way we strike a bell, the way we unfold our bowls, the way we have meal, the way we enter the zendo. It can seem a lot about adhering to a form. That's not what it's about. It's finding pliancy, spaciousness, flexibility, freedom in a form. Right? If we're not walking in this way, we'll be walking some other way—to be conscious, intentional.

I think of wind. Huineng, having received the robe and bowl, was met by Monk Ming, who wanted to take it back. He was angry, he was righteous. Who is this nobody who had taken the Fifth Ancestor's robe? And Huineng just placed it on the rock and said, “This was given in faith. You can't take it by force. Take it. I leave it to you.” Meeting the hard, be soft. Or was it Monk Ming who was actually soft? Who was in a state of a kind of weakness? And in Huineng's pliancy, he met something impenetrable, such that he couldn't lift the robe.

I think of Deshan coming down in his ripe old age, who had been a very strong, fierce teacher, coming down for oryoki. And the tenzo says, “Where are you going, old man? Drum hasn't sounded. It's not time yet.” And Deshan just turns around and goes back. Very simple. But the student working on that koan has to enter into that mind. What's happening right there? What is that mind?

If both are hard and they meet each other, there will surely be one damaged. How to interchange, how to weave, how to move amidst and intermingle? I think zazen is the epicenter of where we discover these things. You know, I was meeting with One Continuous Thread, some of the folks who met last night, and one of the things I was talking about was that in zazen, like in life, we’ve got to deal with things—situations, people, circumstances, work. We have to. Things arise, we often have to respond, a response is needed. Zazen is like the place where you don't have to do that, you don't have to fix it. You're not there to manage, we're not here to control it, we're not here to make it right, to correct it. All of those things. The one place, the one time—if it's ever going to happen before we're dead and it's too late—is zazen. Because you don't need to do that. In fact, you're specifically being asked and given permission to not do that. Just meet. Just meet.

If it's too hard, it breaks; too soft, there's no vitality. Shawn yesterday talked about the gate, the eight gates. What is a gate? Those of us who've entered into formal training, you know it's not just about putting on a robe or doing tangaryo or these other important things. Entering into training, entering the mountain gate. We were talking the other day about how nice it would be if we had a more traditional front gate, which is usually a very significant piece of architecture. It's big, you have to walk through it. And there are deities, guardian deities, fierce deities—you have to walk through them. You have to pass through that gauntlet. They're there to protect, they're there to burn off the unnecessary, they're there to turn away those who are not actually sincere. We'd have to do some serious reconfiguring out there to make that work. So we have two little puppies, but don't mess with them. They're small, but they're mighty.

San Sheng was a student of a successor of Linji—the Linji lineage—and Deshan was a student of Xuefeng, so these were very different lineages, 9th century. And one day, a student asked Xuefeng, “What is it if my fundamentally correct eye sometimes goes astray because of my teacher?” Xuefeng says, “You haven't yet met Bodhidharma.” And the student says, “Well, where is my eye?” Xuefeng says, “You're not going to get it from your teacher.” Thank goodness. Thank goodness. But don't over-rely on that. Don't over-rely on others. He's saying, don't over-rely on your teacher. In other words, in entering the training, implicit in this is you are trusted to find out. You are being trusted to find out, not only because there is no other way, but actually being trusted, which means you have the capacity. You don't entrust somebody with something they're not capable of doing. That's not kind.

Another student, another time, asked Xuefeng, “What is it when one is solitary and independent?” And Xuefeng said, “Still sick, not yet healed, not yet fully alive. Don't over-rely on oneself.” So here's Anxian as Xuefeng with this golden fish. It's often used as an image of an enlightened being that swims upstream like salmon and leaps over waterfalls to get to the place of its searching. And so this golden fish that has passed through the net, what does it use for food?

There are several koans that talk about what is it before enlightenment—Qimen, I think, said, “Lotus flower.” What about after, “Lotus leaves”? We want to know, right? What is it before? But we're most interested in what is it after. How is it after I pass through this net? Tell me that story. The net of greed and anger, pride, jealousy—you name it. You have your own list. But now what do you use for food? What is passing through? What is the path? What is a gate? A gate of entry. A gate is something that can block our passage if it's locked, if it won't open, if we don't know the key, the code, the combination—it won't let us pass. And so it's a fitting image, right? Because it often seems that we cannot pass. We cannot pass through. There's something we're not able to pass through.

We practice. The mind is distracted, distracted. It starts to calm. It calms, and then there's a moment—many moments—where there's nothing arising, but there still seems to be something there, something in between, a veil, a screen, something that seems to be obstructing, but you can't see anything. How do you pass through that? How do you let go there? And so Buddhism speaks about a path passing through a thicket of brambles. If you've ever walked through the woods, the nice thing about being on a trail is the trail is cut for you, right? It is cut through the brambles, so you don't have to deal with them, you just walk. But a true path isn't like that. It's sort of like somebody cuts a trail as they're walking the path, but as soon as they pass through, it all grows back in, right? So when you encounter it, you have to do the same thing. And if you've ever walked through a tangle of rhododendron, for instance—it's called the hiker's nightmare—it’s almost impossible.

There's a river of samsara, right, that we have to cross over. Paramita, prajna-paramita—crossing over to the other shore. So these images, these metaphors, this sense of traveling, of moving from somewhere to somewhere else, which is accurate and inaccurate at the same time.

And so normally for many, we're motivated by what the Buddha spoke of in the First Noble Truth: dukkha. Right? It's coming in loud and clear, almost enough to get our attention. And so that's a great motivator. It's a strong motivator because it hurts, it's painful, it's exhausting, it's confusing—it's all of that stuff. And so we can either ignore it, deny it, numb ourselves, or distract ourselves. And Lord knows there are ample opportunities for that. But for some, it just keeps getting through all that. That doesn't work anymore. And so that can be a very good motivator.

What happens often, in a sense naturally—you might even say necessarily—is that as practice continues, a lot of those brambles, those thickets, those obstacles begin to resolve, drop away. They don't show up, they don't appear in the same way. They're not so strong. You don't get so hooked. Pliancy, freedom.

And what often happens, I've seen, is that students sometimes will get lost there because that sort of very long-standing, familiar motivation is not the same, right? The fire may still be there, burning your ass a little bit, but it's not this raging fire. And so oftentimes I see students really kind of wander. They're not quite sure what is motivating their practice now. And in a way, it's a place where some people can see what really are they looking for, what are they motivating. Sometimes that's enough, that's sufficient—their life is better, demonstrably. That's a good thing. They're living better lives, they're kinder people, they're happier, they're more contented, things are working, and maybe that's really sufficient. But for others, it's not—there's still something that has not been addressed, that is not yet clear.

It's sort of like, you know, working very diligently to get to that door—you know, not everybody read Narnia. I didn't, but I kind of figured it out. Yeah. I wasn't reliant upon you having read Narnia. Oh. I really felt like I took that personally. I really felt, I felt like I was the only one who hadn't read it. I'm so sorry. But it's like working to get to this door, you know, that has seemed far away, impossible, maybe never. And then there it is, and you open this door and it's just, you stand there, it's like, “Oh, this is good.” And then you just sit down and have a barbecue. It's like, no—step forward. The way is open now, more clear.

So having passed through the net, what does the fish now use for food? And Xuefeng says, “When you come out, then I'll tell you.” The footnote says only say 30% for the time being. Why? Why only 30%? The Buddha made a point over and over again about how he wasn't tight-fisted, which meant he had taught what there was for him to teach. He didn't hold anything back. He didn't conceal, he didn't harbor, he didn't—he gave it all away. So why only 30%?

Xuefeng says, “I'll tell you later,” saying too little. The precept on not being withholding really refers to the Dharma—not being withholding, not being stingy with the Dharma. It doesn't mean go out and convert people, doesn't mean tell everybody everything you think you know. Don't be a big-mouth Buddha person. It means when somebody's asking, when somebody wants to know, and you have something that you can offer, you have experience, you're meditating. So why only 30%? Saying too little can not meet the needs of the person. Saying too much can ruin their meal. Very important, very important principle. Say too much—Daido Roshi used to say it robs something essential from the student. It is not trusting them. 

How can we learn to use our minds deeply, well, if we haven't learned how to think? Now, that might seem strange, because in a sense, we are taught, in a way, how to think, but maybe not. Actually, we're taught a lot about what to think, what should we think about, but are we taught how to think? That's just sort of taken for granted—you have a mind, you have thoughts, you know how to think. We know how to have thoughts. But do we know how to think, how to use this power? So we have to learn how to think. Well, how do we do that? Well, first we have to shut up—I say that respectfully. We have to give it up a bit, learn how not to think for a moment and realize, oh, we have that capacity. You have that capacity. It's a natural capacity. And then from that place, we begin to discover how to think.

How can we meet adversity if we haven't experienced adversity, if we haven't met difficulties and discovered their inner workings? And not just anywhere, everywhere, randomly, at a loss, but met adversities within the context of practice, the way, the path—training in a way to meet adversities that are very simple, ordinary. Nobody's trying to make your life difficult here. Actually, the whole point is to make it easier. But it's rigorous, right? And so we meet these small, little bitty adversities. They don't always feel that way, right? Admittedly. But in the landscape of the world, they're workable. And within that, within this, can we trust them? You're not the only one getting up before four o'clock. You're not the only one sitting silent. You're not the only one facing your—the mind, right? And so can we trust those adversities and within this context, practice them?

I remember Open Sozan many years ago, and a person who'd been practicing for quite a number of years said that every sesshin they always experienced pain—there's always, you know, very obstructing, very difficult. And this sesshin they decided they would really try and practice what the teachings say, really use it to really concentrate their mind, go into the pain. And then they spoke about how transformative that was, which was wonderful. And meanwhile, I'm thinking, just now, just now you're doing that. Bravo. And maybe earlier—we each have to come at the time we're ready.

How can we meet pain and suffering in others if we haven't met our own? How can we really cultivate compassion, alleviating suffering, if we haven't met and alleviated our own?

Xuefeng says, “When you come out of the net, I'll tell you.” Is he holding back? Is he withholding from Sun Sheng? Is he going right into Sun Sheng's belly and meeting him there?

The commentary says, Sun Sheng, imposing this question, undeniably set out a bowl of glue in a forest of thorns—a place to get stuck. Xuefeng at first is 30 steps away, watching you, looking in yourself, and drawing out yourself. It's a very interesting image he creates. Xuefeng is 30 steps away, watching you as you ask this question, looking in yourself, trying to draw out yourself. And so he says, “Wait till you come out of the net, and then I'll tell you.” Strange.

It's just like a national champion of chess, playing first, looking several moves ahead before they make their move. You know, it's presented as very strategic, like very calculated. I don't think it's like that. It's much more natural, spontaneous, immediate.

And San Sheng says, “The teacher of 1,500 people, and you don't even know a saying. You can't respond. You can't offer a teaching.” The commentary says, San Sheng, seeing that at this stage victory and defeat are not distinguished, goes by a different road—sees that this is not about victory and defeat. This is not about who knows and who does not know. And that's one of the beautiful things about the koan—it presents what sounds like a very ordinary conversation. Xuefeng knows, San Sheng doesn't. San Sheng's in the net, he doesn't really understand. When he comes out, Xuefeng will tell him, right? That's the obvious point—except it's not. They're having the same words, but they're having a different conversation. They're meeting each other. Sun Sheng, seeing this, goes a different way. And so he says, “You're the teacher of 1,500 people. You don't even know what to say.” Using the tooth and nail of the cave of Dharma, the commentary says, Sun Sheng captured him alive. And so Xuefeng, honest and sincere, just said, “My tasks as abbot are many.” Is he just complaining? Is he weary of this conversation, just wanted to be over? Are they meeting?

What is passing through the net? It's a path, right? So there has to be a sense of movement, progression, traveling, going through different landscapes, right? It's not static, it's not stuck, it's moving. In fact, the Doshinji code says there needs to be progress, which is very interesting. You might not have seen that little phrase in the Doshinji code, right? What does that mean? What would a person, a practitioner here in sesshin, in residency, practicing regularly, have to do to not move anywhere along the path? Think about it—what would they have to do? They would have to be not practicing in a very deliberate and demonstrative way, of course. There are many times where we feel like we're not moving, we're stuck, we're not developing, we're not getting what we want, we're not experiencing what we should be—all of that. But to actually not make progress doesn't mean not changing, because not changing is not a possibility.

And so that's why that part of the Doshinji code is ever invoked: “This is not working for you because you have made no progress whatsoever.” I don't think so. Okay, we will not name names here. Just plant the seed of doubt—who could that be?

What is Zen? What is training? What is selflessness? What is true compassion? Sit, train, practice for three years, five years, thirty years. Then I'll tell you. Ryokan said, “When you know my poems are not poetry, then we can have a discussion about poetry.” Does that mean—it seems to imply—does that mean that we just sort of live in confusion for three years, five years, twenty years, thirty years, and then the doors open? Of course not. Is that what you've seen?

I've told this story about once when I went into dokusan during a sesshin in a moment of some frustration, and I was complaining about, “I don't think I'm getting anywhere, nothing is changing, blah blah blah, complain, complain, complain, nothing is working.” And Daido Roshi looked at me and just went…rang the bell. “That must be hard. Must be hard being you.” Which of course just got me really pissed off, right? I wanted to go right back in and argue for all the ways and things, all the ways things have changed.

What is this path? I was thinking about when Gmon and I drive down to North Carolina to see my family. We leave the Catskills, we follow the mountains—Pennsylvania, Maryland, Virginia, Tennessee, North Carolina. Go through all these landscapes—villages, towns, cities—changing landscapes, weather patterns. We're moving, we're traveling. And at each point along the way, every point along the way is complete. It's a place, people live there. It's got history, right? It is complete with everything that life needs. At every point along the way, it abides within its own state. And we are moving closer to what? Well, if we're going to the property where my family lives in North Carolina, then the analogy fails, right? Because you do—there is no property of enlightenment. But if my destination is returning home, my first home, my birth home, my origin—where is that exactly? How will I know when I get there? Is it the hospital where I was born? Is it the house I grew up in? Is it where my heart beats the loudest? There are sights and smells, sounds—when we roll across the border into North Carolina, I have a little ritual: I put in the Allman Brothers and I turn it up loud. Oh yeah.

A student asked Changsha, “Where are you coming from?” Changsha said, “From wandering in the mountains.” The student says, “Where did you go?” Changsha said, “Well, first I went pursuing fragrant grasses and then I came back along the falling flowers.” And the student said, “How very much like the sense of springtime.” Where did he get to? Did he arrive there? How do we hold this? It's not a duality—that's the short answer. We can say it's not a place, it's not a thing. We get that. We still want that. We want to know when we've arrived. It's not a duality. It is not something apart from something else.

Daido Roshi used to say, “All the way to heaven is heaven itself.” And then he would say, “I'm going to take you there, even if I have to carry you on my back.” He was kidding about that part. All the way is the way. And maybe that's why it takes three years, five years, ten years, twenty years to really know that. It's not an idea—we can have faith in it, it can encourage us, it can point us in the right direction, it can help us reorient when we get fixated on things. It can be useful in all kinds of ways, knowing that. But really knowing that, I think, must take time. It's just too baked in that it has to be otherwise.

When first ascending—the tears of waves, clouds and thunder accompany. The footnote says, regrets that heaven hasn't come yet. Thank goodness. Thank goodness. Why? So that we can learn how to walk, to swim, to leap, to fly.

Every living thing faces great odds in this life. You know, if you read about any life form, whether it's a tree or a flower or an insect or a mammal or a fish—in terms of propagation, in terms of a new generation and those new life forms actually succeeding into life—the odds are not in their favor. Very few make it. We've improved that a bit. But we still face dangers and risks—like the danger of caring, the risk of loving, the danger of committing yourself to something and saying, “Yes, I am going to do this, I am doing this.” And of course, the risk of what? Failure, thought, story.

Leaping up magnificently. Look at the great function so that we can discover our great function. The beautiful fish won't agree to be sunk in a pickle jar. In a sense, that's what we're expressing when we say, “I am not—I do not choose to live in samsara passively anymore,” right? I am committed to another way. I am not going to live in a pickle jar.

An old, mature person does not startle the crowd. This is in the training. A mature person, a person who's grown in time, has experienced a lifetime of practice. They've lost their shine. They're not startled. They've seen a few things, they've been through a few things. They've learned how to face adversity. They've learned to understand what is actual adversity—where is it? That's why Daido Roshi used to say, “This is not for sprinters; it's for long-distance runners.”

I remember there was a guy who called many years ago when I was at the office downstairs—I was registrar, I think he was from Oklahoma—and he said, “I've sold my farm, I'm packing everything up in a truck, and I'm coming out.” I said, “For what?” “To be there and do it until it's done.” I said, “Hang on, do not do that. Do not do that. Stop, wait. We need to have a conversation.” He said, “I'm coming.” And honest to God, he showed up on the doorstep days later. And do you know how long he stayed here? Not even a day, not even overnight, right? Because the moment he came in, I said, “Okay, so this is what it means.” He was like, “What?”

Floating. Floating. As light as five ounces. Easy, easy. Massive. Massive. Heavier than a thousand tons. Difficult. When light, mean it honestly. When heavy, mean it honestly—mean it simply, nakedly. Before the net, inside the net, beyond the net. What is the use of the net? What do you use for food? What do you use for food?

This afternoon, tomorrow we'll be doing Shuso Hossen, and, you know, we'll say something about that a little bit later. But, you know, it's important to understand because it's high ceremony, right? It's lots of drama. It's not that—it is not a performance. Please know that, that if the shuso has done his job, their job, when they say those words, they're real. They're real. Even though the words are offered and said by each chief disciple, they should be real. And this is how—one of the ways in which—this living, living dharma is passed down. It doesn't just happen within the student. It doesn't just happen between the student and teacher. It happens everywhere. And so tomorrow is a big everywhere that everybody is a part of and everybody makes happen. So please just appreciate that, that it's, you know, during Open Sozan and, you know, oftentimes, well-wishing people—I get it, people who love the chief disciple—say, “Have fun,” and I just cringe, right? I mean, I think I understand what they're saying, but it's like, it's not—make it a misery—but it is about life and death. It is about a house on fire. Is there joy in that? Absolutely. And there will be joy. But let it come from that natural, authentic place of doing something that is true and doing it in a way that is true.

So let's really, you know, think of all of this—three months of training, in a sense, your whole life of practice up to this point. And that we just stay here. That's what this week is about. You just stay here. It's not over. Tomorrow is an eon away. Let this moment be that eon.

Thank you for listening. To find out more about ZMM’s programs, retreats and residency, please visit us online at zmm.org.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Title: Entering The Gate Of Wonder
Extracted Text:
Good afternoon, everybody.

I was thinking earlier this week about what would be something I would enjoy talking about and would also feel suitable for the occasion, perhaps thematically appropriate, worthy of this august body. So knowing that words can never reach it, I thought it might be interesting to take up gates.

So we have the eight gates that we've been studying this ongo, and I was reflecting on that and thinking about gates. We talk about the sense gates, gates of entry, the gateless gate. And then I started thinking about Narnia and that experience that I had as a kid of being read The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe aloud to me and being right there. When is it, Edmund, who opens the wardrobe? Lucy. Thank you. When Lucy opens the wardrobe and this other world is revealed.

And we were a little ways into sesshin, so I was kind of feeling like, yeah, totally. For those of us who were here on Wednesday, Roshi opened his talk by saying something like, okay, so we're in.

So first, just to give this a solid scriptural foundation, a short passage from the Lankavatara Sutra:

Thinking about beings in future ages, Mahamati asked the Buddha, "Bhagavan, please tell us about the practices of realization whereby bodhisattvas become great practitioners."

The Buddha answered, "Mahamati, there are four practices, the mastery of which enables bodhisattvas to become great practitioners. And which four? Becoming adept at distinguishing the perceptions of one's own mind; perceiving the non-existence of external existence; avoiding views of arising, duration and cessation; and delighting in the personal realization of Buddha knowledge. These are the four practices, the mastery of which enables bodhisattvas to become great practitioners."

So I would like to consider this first practice today: becoming adept at distinguishing the perceptions of one's own mind.

We say, "Gate gate paragate parasamgate bodhi svaha," the mantra, the great mantra, the vivid mantra at the end of the Heart Sutra, the unsurpassable mantra. And it translates roughly to: gone, gone, gone beyond, gone way beyond, to the other shore, svaha.

And one scholar I was looking at said, you know, the key word in this mantra is "bodhi," which means awakening. And all the other words are modifying bodhi. "Gate" means gone, and "paragate" is apparently a stock Sanskrit expression that was used by the Jains and Buddhists to refer to arhats. So "gate" meaning gone, and "paragate" referring to arhats. And I guess the word "para" meaning the bank of a river on the opposite shore to the one which you're presently standing on. So it's got both meanings in one. The arhat, I guess, is named after that other shore, the one who's crossed to the other side of the river.

And "parasamgate," "sam" is an intensive, which means completely or thoroughly or altogether. So, completely gone to the other shore. And then "svaha" is from Vedic Sanskrit and is said to be the name of the wife of Agni, the fire god. And it was used at the end of recitations that accompanied burnt offerings as part of a Vedic sacrifice ritual and meant sort of like "amen." So, not translated so much as a performative word.

And Allen Ginsberg translates the whole thing: "Gone, gone, totally gone, totally gone. Over the top awakened mind. Svaha."

So, ah, okay, so it's story time. So get your graham crackers and apple juice, all of you at home.

This is the story of Enid in Zendoland.

One unseasonably cloudy and cool spring day, Enid sat slumped on a park bench, holding her head in her hands and feeling especially discouraged about her life in particular, and about being a person in general. The problems were myriad. She was stressed out about work, had just had a falling out with her best friend, her new jeans did not fit her right, and her neighbor's apartment was infested with bedbugs. People hurried through the park on their way to who knows what, some pointless job or doomed online date. And other than the pigeons pecking at the scattered crumbs of her lunch, no one seemed to even notice her despair. Honestly, when you added the inevitable sickness, old age, and death to the picture, there just didn't seem to be much point to anything here in the human realm.

Enid sighed heavily.

Just then, a glossy black crow touched down, edging the pigeons out. It seemed to turn a shining black eye right toward her. "Grr. You're late. You're late. It's time to go through the gate." She could have sworn she heard it say.

Great. I'm losing my mind on top of everything, she thought, when she heard another sound.

"Psst. Psst."

Enid looked around. There were just some random passersby, their attention glued to their phones.

"Psst. Over here."

Enid turned and looked behind her. Peering out from behind a gnarled tree trunk a few yards away were a pair of dark, sparkling eyes belonging to a bald head. Enid squinted. An old woman dressed all in black, holding a tall staff and standing beside a rusty wrought iron gate. She looked distinctly out of place. Medieval, almost. A witch. Enid's heart started beating fast.

The old woman beckoned. "Well, come on then. We're running a bit late and it's time for zazen. If we don't hurry, the zendo will close. Through the gate with you," the old woman said. She had a pleasant enough smile, though the top of one of her front teeth protruded noticeably.

"What? What are you... What are you talking about? Late for z... zenza? I don't even know. Are you a witch?" Enid blurted out suspiciously, furrowing her eyebrow, which met like a snake across her forehead for a moment.

"What's a witch?" the old woman said.

Enid hesitated, biting her lip. This could be tricky. Some possible responses flitted through her mind, but they all seemed a bit offensive. "Someone who casts spells, I guess," Enid said finally.

"Oh no, then," said the old woman confidently. "I'm someone who breaks them." And with that, her eyes locked with Enid's for a moment, and Enid felt a rush of aliveness she hadn't felt in a very long time. Then, nodding briskly, the old woman gave Enid a firm little shove through the gate.

After a swirl of light and a tunnel of sound, Enid found herself outside an imposing stone structure at the foot of an ethereal green mountain. The old woman was there beside her, staff still in hand. A blue-gray cat with yellow eyes came running toward them, and Enid knelt down to pet her.

"That's Ling Zhao," the old woman said.

"Nice to meet you, Ling Zhao." Enid stroked behind the cat's ears, velvet and soft.

Then another voice croaked, "It's about time. We've been expecting you."

Enid looked up to see an even older woman, also bald, also draped in dark flowing robes, poking her head out of a heavy wooden door. She had shaggy eyebrows, wore thick horn-rimmed glasses, and her ancient face was a maze of wrinkles and furrows.

"Where am I?" Enid wondered.

As if she could read her mind, the old woman with the staff said, "Enid. Welcome to Zendoland." A shiver went through Enid's body.

"I'm Zhen Shen, and this is my dharma sister."

"Dharma elder," Dharma Elder Zhenxian, said Zenzo.

The wrinkled woman in glasses nodded curtly. Enid stared.

"Wait. Who... Who are you?" she asked.

"If you're not witches, then I suppose you could say we are..."

"Monks," Zhen Shen replied.

"Better: nuns," Zenzo croaked.

"Priests?" Zhen Shen suggested.

"Buddha Ancestors," Zenzo said.

"True people of no rank," Zhen Shen finished.

Zenzo nodded. This seemed to settle the matter. Enid blinked a few times.

With that, Zenzo and Zhen Shen disappeared behind the wooden door, and with some trepidation and some excitement, Enid followed. After all, she thought, I have nothing to lose.

The first thing that she noticed was the smell. Oh, so familiar, but she couldn't quite place it. It was immediately calming, lightly smoky, a little spicy and sweet, like the smell of a damp autumn forest mixed with her grandmother's closet.

The next thing she noticed was that it was dark and very quiet, and although Enid could hardly see, she could feel that there were more than three of them in the space. As her eyes adjusted, she saw she was at the threshold of a great hall filled with people. At least they seemed to be people, but they weren't like any people she had seen before. They were sitting perfectly still. No one was moving, not at all. Certainly no one was talking. No one was looking around or checking their phone. Everyone was just sitting there, upright, awake, still, and silent.

Enid had never seen anything like it.

"What are they doing?" she whispered.

Zhen Shen considered this for a moment. Then she grinned, her top tooth snagging her lip slightly. "Nothing."

Zenzo grunted in assent. "That is, if they can help it." She chuckled knowingly.

Enid's brow furrowed. "Nothing?" Enid asked, growing curiouser and curiouser. It sure seemed different from when Enid did nothing. All those nights crashed out on the couch, staring into space, rising periodically to fetch a snack from the kitchen, maybe a Twinkie or one of those good creamy yogurts. This was different. So intent. She'd never seen a single person so completely do nothing, let alone a whole room full of people just sitting there doing nothing. The notion was startling. All that busyness, all that running around with work and promotions and shopping and dating. And here, everyone just sitting so still.

She felt her eyes start to well up. A tremble went through her. She looked over at Zhen Shen, who was watching her closely.

"What do you mean by doing nothing?" Enid asked.

"Think. Non-thinking," Zenzo grunted. "Purify, cure, grind down, or brush away all the tendencies you have fabricated into apparent habits."

"Uh, okay," Enid said.

"Traps and snares can never reach it," Zenzo croaked.

Enid furrowed her brows, the black snake appearing for another instant.

"They're practicing," Zhen Shen interjected. "They're practicing being aware of the breath, each breath as present as they can be. And they are watching their minds."

"Watching what?" Enid had spent countless hours watching all sorts of things. She had a big-screen TV and subscriptions to Netflix and Hulu and Disney. There was no shortage of things to watch. But she had never, ever, ever considered watching her own mind.

"Why would they do that or not do that?" Enid asked.

Zhen Shen turned to Zenzo, who was stroking her chin, which Enid noted was dotted with several wiry white whiskers.

"Suffering," Zenzo snorted.

"Suffering?" Enid asked.

"End of suffering," Zenzo clarified.

Enid looked back at the people in the hall, sitting so still. They were watching their minds to end suffering. It felt like the strangest thing she had ever encountered. And at the very same time it made a certain kind of sense. A certain deep kind of sense. She was more than intrigued.

"How does it work?" Enid asked.

Zenzo peered over her thick glasses. Her eyes were milky with cataracts, but Enid got the feeling that she could see her perfectly clearly in some other way.

"Mind. Mind creates the suffering. So much struggle. Big tortures and small terrors. All of it. Mind, thoughts, emotions. And where are these thoughts? What are they?" Zenzo paused, as though waiting for an answer, but Enid had nothing to say. What were thoughts? She wondered. She had never—well, she had never thought about it. What were they? Where were they? In her head, she guessed, but somehow that seemed too obvious.

Zhen Shen picked up the thread, adding, "We're like fish who never ask what is water. We swim in an ocean of thought and emotion. So much struggle, so much suffering. But we may not have asked. We may not have noticed this ocean of thought. We just have our struggles. We believe that's how it is. That's the spell. To break it, we watch the mind. We settle the mind. We get to know the mind, to know its tricks, to know its power."

"So like making thoughts go away?" Enid said.

Zenzo and Zhen Shen exchanged glances. This was always the tricky part.

"Sweep as you may, you'll never empty the mind," Zenzo muttered now, her gnarled hand smoothing the white stubble of her head.

"But, but, but... You said thoughts are making the suffering."

Zenzo shook her head, "Becoming adept at distinguishing the perceptions of one's own mind," said Zhen Shen. "It's different from getting rid of thoughts. Distinguishing them, getting to know them, recognizing them. Seeing what is a thought. And where does it come from?"

"Nothing there, actually," Zenzo chimed in. "No problem at all actually. Sitting still, watching it all, little by little, we can see. Takes time. Lots of time. Habits are deep. Karma is strong. But it can be done."

Zhen Shen nodded. "So much stronger than we think. But if we can deeply see again and again and recognize that thoughts aren't real in any lasting way, then it's like waking up from a dream or..."

Enid interrupted, "Like breaking a spell."

Zhen Shen nodded. "Yes," she said. "Like breaking a spell."

"I want to do it!" Enid shouted. "I want to break the spell."

Zenzo's eyes seemed to flash behind her glasses, as though sizing Enid up with some other sense beyond vision.

"Difficult, difficult, difficult. To go beyond concepts is like covering a tree with sesame seeds."

"I can do difficult things," Enid countered.

Suddenly, Zenzo seemed to tower over her. "Who are you?" she barked.

"I'm Enid," Enid said.

"Thought," Zenzo barked.

Enid glanced around. "Okay. I'm a project manager."

"More thoughts. Concepts," Zenzo responded.

Enid tried again. "Well, I'm a mildly depressed woman who—"

"Stories. Thoughts. Concepts. Stories," Zenzo interrupted.

"I... I'm... You're making me anxious," Enid blurted.

"Thought," Zenzo growled.

"I don't get it. What am I supposed... supposed to say?"

"Thought. Stop. Stop. You're freaking me out."

"Thought, Thought, Thought. Who are you?" Zenzo snarled.

Enid cried out, taking her head in her hands.

Suddenly it was very quiet. Suddenly the room felt very big. Enid could feel the space around her, soft and velvety. So much space all the way through. She raised her eyes. As if for the first time, she noticed the sunlight coming in through the windows. As if for the first time, she heard the sound of the robins outside. They seemed to go right through her.

"What just happened?"

"Upaya," Zhen Shen offered, smiling and exposing her snaggletooth. "Skillful means."

Enid took a breath.

"We have to see that thoughts and concepts are empty. We have to see that thoughts and concepts are empty. Perceptions are empty. Perceptions seem different from thoughts, more objective. But if you look closely, they're mixed in and tangled up with thoughts. We believe we are our thoughts. We believe we are our concepts. But it is like being under a spell," Zhen Shen explained. "And it's extremely subtle."

"For a moment," Enid said, "for a moment, it was like I was as light as a feather."

Zhen Shen smiled. "Yes, for a moment. You see," she said, "when we train the mind, we learn to see our thoughts as thoughts. Seeing them this way, we don't have to get rid of them. We just need to recognize them. Things do exist, after all. You are here. You do exist. The question is just how so. We watch our minds to see how things exist. And in this way we end suffering. We wake up from the dream. We break the spell."

Enid nodded. It was a lot to take in, but still she felt she had touched something true.

The blue-gray cat with the yellow eyes emerged from around a corner, waving her tail in the air.

"It's a beautiful cat," Enid said. "It reminds me of my kitty at home."

"Thought," Zenzo whispered. This time gently.

Enid dropped the idea of her kitty from home. She looked at the blue-gray cat. Suddenly its sleek blue-gray fur was right there, vivid, pulsing alive.

"Hmm. So am I not supposed to think?"

"Of course you can think," said Zenzo.

"Thinking is amazing," Zhen Shen proffered. "It's our most potent power. It's just that we don't know how to use it. We don't even know that we are using it, and so we're used by it. It's like the most powerful empress in the universe had taken you captive instead of you wielding that power yourself for good. So you see, in the zendo, we take our seats and we train not to get rid of thought, not to stop thinking, but to settle the mind. Yes, thinking can slow down quite a bit sometimes, and that's helpful. So that we can recognize the thoughts. So that we can have a break from all that thinking. So that we can pierce the veil, go beyond, enter the gateless gate. All the while we're becoming familiar with how our thoughts create the world. And then maybe you can see where this is going. Then we can use them for good."

"It takes time," Zenzo chimed in. "One thought follows the next, and before you know it, away you go, back to suffering. Difficult, difficult, difficult," Zenzo murmured.

Zhen Shen made a soft hum. "Easy, easy, easy. You don't have to do anything. You don't have to create. Don't try to get rid of it. Don't try to make it stay. Just let it roll."

Enid wasn't sure.

At that moment, the blue-gray cat leapt up onto the windowsill, knocking over the vase of grasses.

"Ling Zhao always gets the last word."

"Well, all this is really just the tip of the iceberg," Zhen Shen said after a pause.

"What do you mean?" Enid said.

"This dharma is infinitely subtle and incomparably profound," Zhen Shen said knowingly. "It's boundless and impossible to attain. But for those who want to know, training gives a way to travel ever deeper into the mystery of who we really are."

"Okay," said Enid. "I want to do it. I want to train."

"Then you'll be here for breakfast tomorrow? We're having cake," snorted Zenzo.

"Cake?" Enid brightened.

"It's not really cake," Zhen Shen corrected. "It's sweet bread."

Behind her glasses, Zenzo rolled her eyes and snorted. "Oh, it's cake all right. Cake for breakfast every morning. Good Zendoland fare."

Enid smiled. "Well, whether we call it cake or sweet bread doesn't really matter, right? I mean, no one's eating concepts for breakfast. And anyway, it sounds delicious."

Zenzo and Zhen Shen exchanged a pleased glance.

"You caught a live one, dear sister," mumbled Zenzo.

"Nothing better," said Zhen Shen.

Cake for breakfast then, Enid thought as she crossed the threshold to the zendo, tiptoed to take her place among the rows.

If we get caught in thought, if it feels like one of those sort of, I don't know, bound up moments where it feels like—I know I'm thinking, I know I'm thinking, I know I'm thinking, but like, how do I get out of this?

I remember once, many years ago in dokusan at the temple, Shugen Roshi said something to me like, "Well, it's all just working with energy." And I was kind of like, wait, what? And he sort of backed that up and obviously that stayed with me.

When we can feel that like, I'm caught, I'm caught, I'm caught in thought, there's an energetic tension that's in our body-mind. You don't have to get rid of anything and aggression will only be a temporary measure if it even works at all.

So it's like what Gokan was saying yesterday about relaxation. It's like, can we find, you know, there's the tension that we can feel in our body. If you can find that, excellent, that's a great place to enter in, to try and just bring your awareness to it and let that begin to soften. And then thought is creating an energetic tension in our body-mind. And that's subtle, that's subtle. But finding that, finding that and then again, same, just like with the muscle tension, letting your awareness rest with that and just being still with that. Don't try to make it stay, don't try to make it go, just let it roll.

The more we can refine that, the more the self-liberative aspect of thought can become part of our own upaya. So first we have to recognize thought for thought.

May our practice and effort here be for the benefit of all beings.

Thank you for listening.

To find out more about ZMM's programs, retreats and residency, please visit us online at zmm.org.
Speaker: Danica Shoan Ankele

Title: Relaxing Completely
Extracted Text:
The following Dharma talk was given by BER Gokhan Bonnebaker at Zen Mountain Monastery. Gokhan Osho is a Dharma holder and priest in the Mountains and Rivers Order. This talk, like all of our talks, is offered freely. If you would like to make a donation or find out more about our various programs, visit us online at zmm.org. Thanks for listening.

I have just a few things to say this afternoon. This is a short talk. I hope that for each one of you there's something helpful.

A couple of weeks ago, during the Ongo intensive, Shugen Roshi gave us some writing prompts, some art practice prompts, and one of them was to have some words with Yama. Yama is the Lord of Death, who I think only comes when it's time. Part of what I said to him is, "Wait, not yet. I like being alive." I said, "I will not worry anymore. I will not complain or criticize. I will not be dissatisfied. I will only trust and love, only appreciate."

I found it a helpful exercise, helpful to reflect: How are we using our mind, our life, our lives, our energies? It can be an ongoing reflection, a practice of reflecting and remembering. Death will come for me as it comes for everyone. The when, the where, the how—I do not know. But death will come. I'm going to die. Those I love are going to die. I'll be separated from all that I care about. So in this time that I have, I vow. I vow.

I find that there is ongoing reflection—can be ongoing reflection—maybe of the precepts, other vows that we've taken, these remembrances. And then sometimes we actually hear it. Sometimes we're ready to change, to make a vow and act on that vow. There have been times when I have experienced that, and a vow has changed my life. And sometimes this reflection may be kind of about the big picture. How would you like to use your life? What would you like to do? And there's also the kind of more hard-to-see interior: How do I want to use my mind? In a way, that's where our life is happening.

So I said these things to Yama: worry, complaint, criticizing, being dissatisfied—because I know them, familiar energies that arise in my body-mind. I work with them. I have worked with them. I was remembering when I was first in residence, realizing that every time I sat down, I would sort of groan, and that I was kind of going through my day doing things like that, and realizing I was creating something—that I was basically complaining throughout the day. And so I changed that. I was 24 at the time. Now, sometimes I sit down and I do kind of groan a little bit. But these energies that arise in my body-mind—my relationship with them has changed over time. They arise differently.

In studying them, I know that they keep me separate, that they are obscurations, as we say, that they are habitual, that I'm creating something. They're negative; they are suffering. And so doing this exercise a couple weeks ago, having these words with Yama, felt like maybe I'm ready to let something go here.

I've been reading the Surangama Sutra, which is a Mahayana sutra, which I kind of just found. I think maybe there haven't been translations so available. And I'm also reading some commentary that goes along with it. And there's much more language about purifying the mind than I'm kind of used to—purifying the mind of obscurations, kleshas, desires and aversions, reactivity, conflict, suffering; purifying the mind of what obscures the mind. Ultimately, there's nothing to purify, but there are all these things that prevent us from knowing that, from knowing our true mind.

Also, in the Surangama Sutra, to the extent that I understand it—I'm finding it difficult—there's a lot of the Buddha telling Ananda that things are illusion. The Buddha asks Ananda questions. Ananda is an excellent student, an example of a student in the sutra. And Ananda responds to the Buddha as best he can with some seemingly very good answers, seemingly based in the teachings, in the Buddha's own teachings. And then, over and over again, the Buddha points out, shows how, "No, Ananda, basically, everything you're saying is based on an assumption. Everything is an illusion." He goes through mind, all of our perceptions, organs of perception—over and over, saying, "No, that is an illusion."

I was feeling earlier, it's kind of a mystery. It's kind of mysterious how this self arises, that comes into being, kind of coalesces around something. This mystery of all these things that arise in our experience that we react to, we get upset with, we want to possess. When we look closely—what is there? We can't find anything. There is nothing to find, no thing to find. And yet we respond, we react, we get upset. What's happening? And, you know, a lot of the time it doesn't seem like a mystery. We're just upset. There is just this barrier that we're struggling with. But with some space, some familiarity, some looking: what's happening? What's happening?

Looking a little bit at complaining, being dissatisfied, and wondering, why do I like this? Why do I do this? I do like it in a way, a little kind of twisted-up pain, pleasure—certainly familiar. Maybe this is part of why samsara is so hard to kind of see our way out of. There's a lot of time that we may not see that we're suffering because it seems like we're getting—seems like we're getting what we want, or we're just caught up in trying to get what we want. But even when we have a sense that we're suffering, even when we know that we're suffering, it's hard to get out, it's hard to kind of change, because we like it somehow.

And I was thinking—I'm not sure how to say this—because in a way it is just that: things. It's difficult to see that things are an illusion, to see that they are created and conditioned, our experience. And kind of the other side of that is that when our mind does clear and open, when we have some experience of letting go, of seeing more clearly—you know, often it comes like towards the end of sesshin or somewhere in sesshin—and it's like we had to do a lot of work to get there, to see that, to let go, just to let go, let things open. But kind of to not be fooled by that—it's not that we are creating something with all of that work, all of this work that we're doing. We're just practicing letting go. Seeing and letting go, releasing, allowing our habitual, our familiar, our sometimes hard-to-see mind states—just letting them settle, loosen, allowing our natural mind to be less obscured, unobscured. Can we trust that? I think we know that we're returning to ourselves, not making something. But it's important to see that.

I was talking recently with a student who really struggles with difficult mind states, confusing mind states, and they were telling me that they had been here for a while, and when they went home for like an hour, it all cleared. It all cleared. And I asked them, "Well, what did you learn from that?" And they said they could see—they said that all of those things that are usually so confusing, I create them. So important to see that.

Yesterday, when Shugen talked about how over time, in just seeing things arise and pass away and getting to know ourselves and learning to work with ourselves and letting go, that then there's not so much surprise—which I understood to mean not seeing new things in ourselves, new barriers, struggles—and I was just kind of thinking, like, is that true for me? And the thing that, you know, where the surprise is, is how the same things still come up. Just last night, this morning, I was, like, starting to get caught up. And it's not a surprise in the sense that, no, I know this. I see what's happening. I know how to work with this, how to make space, loosen, how to find my seat again, return to myself. But I still get surprised that it happens.

In our men's group last week, I think it was, we were talking about insecurity and comparing and sort of feelings around that. And I was saying, you know, this is what I have worked with for my whole life. And that there have been times in my practice over the years where I felt like, yeah, now I think I'm done with that. I think I really, like, let it go. I finally kind of pulled it out by the roots because it had changed so much. I can't remember now, sort of in my body-mind, how it was. But it keeps surprising me. It kind of slips in under the door. And so I don't say that anymore. That's what I was saying.

This is not a perfect analogy, but I was thinking that it was kind of like—those of you who knew Uconn—he used to like to hide behind doors and jump out and scare. I assume he did this to other people, but he certainly did it to me. And, you know, a lot of the time, I would jump, right? But then it would just be Uconn there, laughing and so pleased that he had scared me.

A while back, Shugen Roshi, in a talk, said something about that we can think of zazen as relaxing completely. I've been kind of carrying that around with me, wondering, kind of checking it out. I don't think I've ever heard him say that before: "Zazen is relaxing completely." And so I've been kind of like, is that always true? Is this what it means to practice in accord—in accord with the Dharma? To practice no conflict, no opposition. Relaxing completely. To practice not creating—relaxing completely. What is this relaxing?

I've been trying this as I go through my day. Walking to the office building: relaxing. When I'm chanting: relaxing. Working on this talk: relaxing. And in that feeling, finding what is not relaxed. Where is that tension? What is that? Finding what I think wants to be relaxed. It wants me to relax. It helps it to relax, allow it to relax. But this not-yet-relaxed comes in different forms.

Sometimes it's kind of apparent, obvious, like it's tightness or irritation. Or sometimes, walking to the office, I'll realize, why am I in a hurry? Why am I moving so quickly? There's some tension there. Relaxing, coming back into my body. And sometimes it's very different. Pretty much every time when I'm working on a talk, I get to a point where it feels like I've said this before. I always say the same thing. I can't say this to the sangha. But really, it's this heaviness in my body, and I know this very well. Didn't actually get that much this week. But how do I relax that? Where's the grasping in that? There must be grasping. Somewhere in that mind state, I can feel the suffering. Where is the grasping, the creating? How am I creating conflict?

Zazen is relaxing completely. Is that true for all forms of zazen? If you're working with the breath, what is it to do your practice, to do your practice wholeheartedly and relax completely? If you're working with a koan, what would it be to do that practice wholeheartedly, relax completely? If you're doing shikantaza, are you relaxing completely? Is that the not-doing of shikantaza? This, not-this.

Relaxing completely reminded me of this passage from Daoxin—it's the fourth Zen ancestor—which I read a little while ago. He's asked a question. The question is, "How can we illuminate and purify our minds?" So he's being asked, what do I do in my meditation?

Daoxin says: "It is not by reciting the Buddha name, not by restricting mind, not by observing mind, not by calculating thought, not by contemplation, not by the practice of observation, not by scattering and confusion. Just let it roll along, don't make it go, and don't let it stay. In solitude and peace, mind of itself is illuminated and pure. If we can observe it truly, mind is instantly illuminated and pure. Mind is like a clear mirror. If we can observe it truly for a year, it will be even more clear and pure. If for three years or five years, even more clear and pure."

Just let it roll along, don't make it go, don't make it stay. Is this relaxing completely? What is he saying? I think we can hear, know, trust that when we have an idea of what our mind should be like in meditation, and we're trying to make our mind match that idea, it doesn't work. That's not the way to illuminate and purify the mind. When we're trying to control the mind, control our thoughts, it doesn't work. That's not the way to illuminate and purify the mind.

In my experience, it is certainly around concentration, ideas of what concentration should be like, that I get stuck, tight. This is where we can block things out, bypass, trying not to be disturbed by our thoughts and feelings, fighting with our thoughts and emotions and feelings, trying to make things quiet. We do need to learn to be concentrated, to concentrate, whatever our practice is. But it's not from controlling. What is it you're trying to control?

Because our habits are body and mind. We experience them body and mind, feel them in the body. The familiarity is in the body and the mind. Familiarity with our kleshas, our difficult mental states or complaining—it's in the body-mind. That familiarity in the body, I think, is part of what makes it hard to see that it is just to see it for what it is.

And so something I've experimented with, that I work with, is bringing something different into my body-mind. In a way, I think this is true of all of the practices that we do. Our practices are just of coming close, of being intimate so that we experience that in our body-mind. What is that? How is that? Allow that to be familiar. Distraction may be familiar. We have to—how do we let that go? And let that be not what we default to.

This is also how I experience metta practices. To be able to offer someone peace, I have to feel peace in my own body-mind, know peace in my own body-mind. And I've found that kind of magical—to bring into my body love, acceptance, peace, loving attention; allow that to permeate, become familiar for me. And so that then I can offer that, change my relationship by offering that.

And I think this is true also in learning to relax. Relax body-mind, to get familiar with relaxed body-mind—relaxed and open and awake. Allowing space for ourselves to be ourselves completely. Not trying to make anything, not trying to control.

Daoxin says: "Mind of itself is illuminated and pure. If we can observe it truly, mind is instantly illuminated and pure. If we can observe it truly for a year, it will be even more clear and pure. If for three years or five years, even more clear and pure." Letting it sink in—for a year, for three years, for five years—becoming convinced. Mind of itself is illuminated and pure. We do not make it more pure.

I wanted to end with a story about Dongshan, one of our important ancestors. The story is that the gods wanted to see Dongshan, but they couldn't because he was so empty of ego attachment that he was invisible to the gods. They would go looking for him and they would pass through him or enter into him. But they couldn't see him. And they were very curious about this person who had become so empty. So they played a little trick on him. One day, when Dongshan went out for a walk, they went into the kitchen, the monastery kitchen, and took some handfuls of food. And they took them out and they threw them on the path.

When Dongshan came back, he saw this food just strewn across the path. You shouldn't treat food like that. It's disrespectful. It is alive. It is not good practice in a Zen monastery. When Dongshan saw this food strewn across the path, he got upset. He was a little offended. He couldn't believe that some of his disciples, one of his disciples, would have been so careless. And for a moment, the gods could see him. He wasn't empty anymore. Something had crystallized around his reaction. A cloud appeared in the emptiness of his being, and the gods could see him. And then it dissipated, and they couldn't see him anymore. His reaction disappeared. He knew how to return from his reaction.

I like that story. A Zen story. Just a person who's purified his mind and still has reactions.

So, we're right in the middle of sesshin. Allow yourself to be fully in sesshin. Can't see the beginning, can't see the end. We should know how fortunate we are and use this time well.

Thank you for listening. To find out more about ZMM's programs, retreats, and residency, please visit us online at zmm.org.
Speaker: Bear Gokan Bonebakker

Title: Possibilities
Extracted Text:
The following Dharma discourse was given by Jeffrey Shugan Arnold at Zen Mountain Monastery. Shugan Roshi is the head of the Mountains and Rivers Order and abbot of the monastery. This talk, like all of our talks, is offered free of charge. If you would like to make a donation or find out more about our various programs, visit us online at zmm.org. Thank you for listening.

This is from the record of Layman Pang. One day the layman was sitting in his thatched cottage.

“Difficult, difficult, difficult,” he suddenly said, “like trying to scatter ten measures of sesame seed all over a tree.”
“Easy, easy, easy,” returned Mrs. Pang, “just like touching your feet to the ground when you get out of bed.”
“Neither difficult nor easy,” said Ling Zhao. “On the hundred grass tips, the ancestors.”

So, we’re in it now. There is something that comes closer, becomes more possible with sustained practice. That’s why intensives such as this are important in most of the practice-based schools of Buddhism. When we have the opportunity to immerse ourselves, and with just slight voyages off the cushion, but to stay close.

Difficult, difficult, difficult, the layman said. There’s something to be said for being told this in advance. And the teachings do not apologize, do not conceal the fact that it is a long path and there will be many challenges along the way. And I think there’s something very refreshing in that true speech. 

At the same time, sometimes being told something will be difficult can set up something in the mind, something that is expectant. When I was in college, I was in the school orchestra. Our regular conductor was not a great conductor; he was very wishy-washy about everything. When we were getting ready for a performance, he would get up there and say, “Well, you know, this is kind of a hard piece, you know, but let’s just give it our shot, you know.” And that’s what he got.

And then once a year we had a guest conductor who was another teacher at the school, was excellent, but he was a choral conductor. So just once a year he would conduct the orchestra and he would get up and just say, “Okay, we’re doing this.” And that’s what he got—a different orchestra, a different group of musicians, same people ascending the mountain, training.

So yeah, it becomes pretty clear pretty early that it’s not going to be a cakewalk, that whatever great plans we have made are just going to have to be put away, and that’s okay. You know, the challenge really is when our expectations meet reality. Can we yield? Can we yield to reality and turn towards that and give up all of our easy dreams?

So we meet our habits, our tendencies, our memories, our reactivity, our regrets, our insecurities. We see our attachments are strong—stronger than we thought. And we keep seeing that. They seem to keep being stronger than we thought. Faith seems to come and go. Our energy rises and falls. And there’s a kind of maturing, a kind of seasoning that happens when you sit in one place and watch yourself go through all of those changes.

Because we’re just so used to just change, change, change the condition, change the environment, change what I’m looking at, change what I’m doing. And when you’re just sitting here on this cushion in your world, just keep showing up and showing you, showing each of us. And you don’t go away. You don’t fly away.

It’s hard to recognize in the beginning. Maybe a good analogy is like when we’re young, you know, kids growing up, going through stuff, you know, and we just see it as this—just what’s happening right now. This heartbreak, this triumph, this contest, this whatever. We don’t see it within this large view that each of those experiences is teaching us something, presenting us with something. We’re learning about life. We’re learning how to be a person, how to live. But we don’t have that big picture, right? 

We realize how labile everything is. In a sense, the things we’ve been relying on for so long are just really not reliable. Not for what we actually want, not what we’re seeking.

So, you know, there’s the Vimalakirti Sutra, which is this sort of large and perfect embodiment of a fully realized being—free in every situation, having realized every dharma—and a layperson. But it’s fictional, right? Vimalakirti was not ever a historical person. But Layman Pang was. He studied with different teachers, 8th century Shitou, Mazu. There’s somewhat known about him. He had a family. He also had a son who I think was an artist—doesn’t usually get included because he was off doing his own thing. You gotta have one of those, right?

But the family, and particularly Layman Pang and Ling Zhao, they seemed to be particularly close. But they were all practitioners. And according to the records, they were all realized. So that’s a nice family to be born into.

And it’s said that he—I’ve never seen what he did in his life to make his livelihood—but at a certain point, when he got really involved in the Dharma, he thought, “This is just a hotbed of attachments.” So he put all of his stuff in a boat and took it out in the lake and sunk it because he didn’t want anybody else to have it either. No comment on how the family felt about that, but it’s a done deal. And then he spent a lot of time wandering. Towards the end of his life, he lived in a cave for a while. And there are different records of his teachings. And this is one of them.

Difficult, difficult, difficult. Like trying to spread bushels of sesame seed all over a tree. So he’s making it clear—it’s difficult, what we’re trying to do. The habits of a lifetime, lifetimes, deeply embedded and in a sense, to a certain extent, instinctual, right? When something’s painful, get away. When something’s pleasurable, go towards it. Hold on to what you don’t want to lose. When somebody makes you angry, get angry back. If there’s a problem out there that’s causing you distress, see if you can change it, conquer it, get away from it. When you’re experiencing difficulty, do something to change that. When you don’t feel good, when you don’t like what you’re feeling, add meaning to it. It means something. What does it mean?

And so whether it’s a person or a family or a community or a nation or a world, samsara finds its way into wherever we are. So an old teacher said, is there anyone who can find a true path home? A true path? In Buddhism, a path means something very particular. It’s not just, well, everybody’s on a path. Some of them work, some of them don’t. No, that’s not how it’s seen in Buddhism. It’s very intentional. It’s based in what is true. And it’s a path. It’s not just a random road going somewhere. It’s a path that is Eightfold and noble, right? You are given provisions. We are given provisions, guides. And then, as the Buddha said, he could only point. And then we have to find our way. We have to find our way.

Like when Huike came to Bodhidharma, “My mind is not at peace. Please set it at peace.” He wanted nothing more in the world than that. And Bodhidharma said, “Bring it to me, this mind that is in turmoil, that is tormenting you, that brought you to this very place, bring that very mind to me.” That should not be hard. And then he left it to Huike to find that mind.

But of course, the difficulties don’t begin when we enter practice. If they did, we probably wouldn’t be here. But they often seem to increase. They seem to get worse somehow, or more, or bigger. And actually, that’s a good sign. It’s a sign that we’re looking, we’re paying attention, we’re not turning away—not too much.

We can think that because we, you know, in the dual world, we think everything works like a machine, and so walking a path means every foot takes you one step further, one step closer to your goal. And you can track your distance, right? Get an odometer, get a map. You can track exactly where you are and you know how far you are from the beginning and how far you are from the end. And there is a beginning and there is an end. Not this one.

And so we can think in that way of thinking that every step is not only going to get us closer, but it’s going to get easier, right? Because it’s a path of liberation. We should be liberating ourselves, right? Would anyone disagree? 

And so, but then when we go through these, we see these moments of burst, right? Everything’s fine. Then everything’s fine. And then we think, okay, you know, in the beginning, I can handle that. But then at a certain point, we think, okay, I’ve done that. No more of that. Now I’m just smooth sailing. And hearing that, we can think, okay, so it’s not really working, right? The same stuff keeps happening.

No, not really. It’s not the same, because the stuff of it is not in the...it’s in my mind. What do I see? How do I respond? How do I understand this? That’s not the same. And so those outbursts keep happening, but they’re not the same. And yet, they still require attention. Sometimes they throw us back a bit. 

And so we establish intention, raise our aspiration, keep going, don’t be afraid. It’s easy to get lost. That doesn’t take a lot of skill, right? In fact, you probably have. You probably will. Everybody gets lost for a moment, for a day, for months, sometimes for years, sometimes forever. There are those who are lost and do not find their way back—not in this lifetime. They’re not looking.

And so how to walk a path takes skill. That’s what we’re developing: skill. It’s not just learning how to meditate and making sure you get to the cushion sufficiently, or chanting the sutra, or reading some texts. It’s a whole thing going on. And we have to learn how to do that, just like the child has to learn how to be a human being, how to be in the world.

I was listening recently to an educator. An interviewer was talking to them about—in this section about AI—and she said, you know, children need to learn how to do. They need to do things that are difficult. They have to learn things that are hard to learn. And they have to go through that struggle of trying to learn something that’s not easy, right? It may not even seem relevant or important. I mean, I’m sure we’ve all had experiences when we were in school, like, what’s the point? This doesn’t interest me. This is no good for me. I don’t care about this. I’m never going to use this. 

And that may be true about the subject, but that’s also looking in a very, very narrow way. But that when we have to learn or stay with something, engage something and really try, that’s difficult. We’re learning a whole lot more than just whatever the subject is.

And she was talking about when AI came into the schools, that the teachers were like, “Okay, we have to have anti-plagiarism tools.” And the kids immediately learned how to hack that, get around it. And so she was saying, we’re never gonna beat the kids on this in terms of creating something that they can’t get around.

And I was thinking, right, so maybe that’s not the point. The point is, how do you teach a child to not want to get around it? How do we teach, how do we learn to want to learn, even if the subject isn’t easy? And the person that she was interviewing was saying, “You know, I was that kid. I thought school was boring. I didn’t like it. I struggled with it.” But then they had some encounters that inspired them, and they really got very interested in one thing. And he really studied this one thing, and his whole relationship with learning began to change. And then he said, and then he went back to some of those other subjects that he’d hated and thought were stupid and irrelevant. And he realized he could study those now. He had learned something that transcended just the subject itself.

Practice is a lot like that. And so we need to free ourselves from the idea that because something is difficult or painful, it’s bad, and if it’s easy or pleasurable, it’s good.

I’ve been rereading Righteous Mind by Jonathan Haidt. And he was talking about how in all these experiments that they’ve done about just how people make decisions and sort of the relationship between the emotional aspect, you know, or the feeling that guides us versus the intellect, which rationalizes, and that people basically believe that if I’m feeling good about something, that must mean I like it, and if I don’t feel good about something, that must mean I don’t like it. So clearly, as practitioners, we have to get beyond that or else we’ll never practice.

They did an experiment where somebody was on the street asking passersby a series of questions that had a moral component to it and asking them for their opinion to sort of make a moral judgment. And they were standing next to a trash can, and with some of the people, the trash can was just empty. They’d ask the question, people would respond, make a moral judgment, and then pass it on. And other people, before the person came up, the interviewer would spray what they called fart spray into the trash can, right? So the person comes up and the air is, like, filled with this fart spray. And they found that people still made moral judgments, but they were much harsher, right? And so how a person is feeling affects their judgment, their sort of reaction, their mood, their temperament, their attitude.

In the Prajnaparamita Sutra, Subhuti and Shariputra are having a little chat one day about the Dharma. Shariputra says, “Venerable Subhuti, the Supreme Enlightenment is hard to come by. Hard, difficult, difficult, difficult. Why? In the same way that it has not occurred to space, ‘I shall know enlightenment.’ Space doesn’t think, ‘I shall know enlightenment.’ Just so, it doesn’t occur to the bodhisattva, ‘I shall know enlightenment.’ Why? Because the same as space are all dharmas. And it is after they have firmly believed in all dharmas as the same as space, that the bodhisattva knows full enlightenment.”

So when the bodhisattva understands, has faith in that all things are empty, nothing is fixed. They can’t get it. It’s not a thing, right? They can’t just set a goal and move towards that. It’s not a treasure hunt, right? There’s a treasure there, and it’s hidden somewhere. But if you get to it, you’ll find that treasure and you’ll have it, like that mani jewel in the claw of the dragon.

He said, once the bodhisattva understands that, then they realize how difficult this is going to be—because it’s not a thing. “If on the part of the bodhisattva, who has firmly believed that all dharmas are the same as space, the Supreme Enlightenment were easy to win, not hard to come by, then bodhisattvas, countless as the sands of the Ganges, would not turn away from enlightenment and would easily attain it.” 

So in this way, it’s difficult, difficult, difficult because its very nature. If it were just, you know, an answer—a question is asked, you have to figure out the question, the answer, like an exam, a test. It’s the ultimate test, right? But you just have to figure out the answer, use your mind. Then we would do that. But it’s not that. Because all dharmas are the same as space.

Of course, we don’t experience them that way. We experience them as having weight, as having solidity. This emotion, this memory, this sensation, this action, this person, this mood—it feels so real. Not just in the sense that I’m experiencing something, but in a sense that it is something that is happening to me. And that’s why the bodhisattva does not think, “I will know enlightenment.” That’s—we have to give that up. It is something that I will know, I will attain. It is not like that. Taizan Roshi used to often say, “It is not like something.”

But then Mrs. Pang says, “Easy, easy, easy. Like touching your feet on the ground when you get out of bed.” The Supreme Way is not difficult if only you do not pick and choose. Just like your feet touching the ground when you get out of bed. You don’t have to think about it, plan, prepare. You’re already home and there’s no step that’s going to bring you closer. Easy, easy, easy.

The obstacles are not as they appear. When something arises, it’s something. It has qualities and characteristics. That’s how we can recognize it. It’s got meaning. It’s got a story.
