We have a story about it. We have a relationship with it. This isn’t the first time. Even if we haven’t seen this one, we’ve seen a lot of other ones that are like this one. So we throw them all into the same box. We know it. And in that moment of knowing, it feels good. Or in that moment of knowing, this doesn’t feel good at all. I like this. I don’t like this. This is good. This is not good.

And so there seems to be a whole lot going on in that object. That’s where the qualities and characteristics are. I was fine until it arose, and now look what’s happening. So the evidence seems to be that that object has got something going on that’s doing something to me. I want more of it. I don’t want any of it. So, deal with the object. Get it, possess it, get rid of it.

And so the radical faith of practice is realize there’s something there—not what we think, but what we really need to do is turn around, turn it around. It’s not about the object. It’s this mind, it’s this moment, it’s this response, it’s this clinging, it’s this rejecting. It’s this body, it’s this emotion. In that way, the object is just, in a way, a friend, right? Helping to show the self arise so that we can see, stop and see. Easy, easy, easy.

In the same way that if we want to be a compassionate person and live a compassionate life, the way that happens is by being compassionate and living compassionately. You know, it’s not like we can do some sort of, you know, stuff over here, and then one day we’re just going to be compassionate, right? We actually have to be bringing forth being, that very thing, practicing that. And so that’s what we do. That’s why we need to be practicing compassion.

In our zazen, there’s virtually almost no element of the Dharma in which morality, good and bad, in our way of seeing it, isn’t present, isn’t needing our attention. And in the same way, if we want to live a life that is, you know, awake and aware and mindful, then we have to be mindful. If we want to live an enlightened life, then we have to be an enlightened being.

Well, now, hang on. That seems a lot harder. How can we be an enlightened being on the path of enlightenment when we’re not enlightened? By bringing forth the mind, the qualities, the aspiration, the virtues of an enlightened being—the precepts, the paramitas, the practice. And so when we meet the moment in love and hate and grasping and rejecting and our opinions and, you know, our habits—well, that’s not quite it. When those things just arise impulsively without asking, and we respond, right? With awareness, with compassion, with mindfulness. Those are enlightened qualities.

And if the burden is light, then you carry it lightly. If it’s heavy, you carry it heavily. Don’t complain. Don’t complain. Don’t compare. Oh, now, wait a minute. Don’t speculate. Don’t strategize. Four tough asks, right? Because we love these things.

You know, somebody was asking about—it’s easy, easier, you know, to let go of things that are painful, come back to their practice. But when it’s pleasurable, it’s hard to let go of that because you’re getting pleasure right now. It’s happening, you’re enjoying this, it’s good, feels good, you must like it, it must be good. It’s hard to let go of that consciously and return to a practice that may not be those things, yet it’s not bringing forth all those wonderful descriptions: radiant, luminous, blissful, equanimous, liberated. It’s just the breath, right? So you’re going to let go—wow, come back to the breath, right? That’s not what we would normally do. We would normally stay with the good thing, the fun thing, the “I like” thing.

And so that’s where being able to practice what in that moment is difficult. It can sound very trivial, but in that moment, it can be hard.

Towards the end of the Ox Herding Pictures depiction of the journey, the ox self transcended, the poem says:

“Astride the ox I reach home, I’m serene.
The bull too can rest now, the dawn has come.
In blissful repose within my thatched dwelling,
I’ve abandoned the whip and ropes.”

All of those practices, those efforts, those struggles have eased.

There’s nothing we meet that really is new. I mean, that’s not entirely true—we do experience new things in meditation. But in terms of the habitual mind, the conditioned mind, the karmic mind—I mean, come on, really. I don’t—maybe now and then, doesn’t really matter. But the point is, we get so surprised. You know, we fall into a habit. We’ve fallen into it a thousand times, ten thousand times, right here in sesshin. And yet—poof—it’s like, what? Swept away.

So if you can let go, let go. If you can’t let go, if you won’t let go, know that you won’t let go. Know that you’re not letting go. Just know that. Don’t write a thesis on it. Just know that. If your faith is strong, practice with a strong faith. If it’s dim, practice with a dim faith. There’s no situation—as long as you have your mind—in which practice cannot occur. And it will be different. It will be different.

We need those differences. We need to go through all of those different conditions and situations in order to develop, in order to learn how to live in this world which is continually throwing stuff at us, near and far. And to study without investment—great aspiration, but not invested. Hold no opinion and recognize that all of this that’s arising is just arising. It’s just a moment, it’s not you. It’s not permanent. Don’t take it lightly, as Dogen says, but don’t add weight to it. It’s not the self, it’s just an event. We’re not only event planners, we’re event makers. We’re making events all the time. But if we see it as just an event, and it’s gone...

In the Prajnaparamita, it is said, the Buddha has said that it’s hard to come up to the supreme enlightenment. And that is said over and over again in this sutra. How difficult it is, how deep it is. So he’s just acknowledging that. But then Subhuti—and, of course, Subhuti and Shariputra are both very, you know, prominent disciples of the Buddha—Subhuti says, “As I, however, understand the meaning of the Buddha’s teaching, and as I think it out for myself, easy to win is the supreme enlightenment. Easy, easy, easy. Why? No one fully knows. By no one is anything fully known. And there is nothing that should be fully known. For the Buddha, all dharmas are empty. And when all dharmas are empty, that dharma does not exist which would fully know, or by which one would fully know, or which one would fully know. They cannot be grasped. For all dharmas are empty. And because of this, easy to win is the great enlightenment.”

Because they are empty. It’s exactly what Subhuti was saying or Shariputra was saying. They’re just looking at it from a different perspective, that’s all. Same reality, same teaching, same truth. Because it’s empty, it is difficult. It is difficult to take this grasping mind, this object-seeking mind, this self-seeking other on this path, which needs to have a beginning and an end. It’s difficult. But because it cannot be grasped, then what is it that I’m attaching to? Why is it that this emotion has such an influence on me, has such power over me, if it has no power of its own?

I was listening to a teacher talk about—he was using his—it was Alan Wallace, and he was using his cell phone, and he picked it up and he looked at it and said, “There’s a dent on the back. Oh, it was so beautiful. It was perfect. It was brand new and it’s got a dent in it. How did that happen? Now it’s dented, it’s broken. It’s not the same. I can’t enjoy it, because it still works, but every time I pick it up, I just see that dent. I can’t see anything else.” And he went on for a while—very simple, trivial example, maybe not so trivial. And then he said, “If the power was in the dent, and that’s what was making me miserable, then I could turn it on you. You’d all be miserable.” Because it’s easy, it’s empty. Because it’s empty, it’s easy.

And then Ling Zhao has the last word: “Neither difficult nor easy. On the hundred grass tips, the ancestors.” Meaning, on the tip of a grass, on the tip of every blade of grass, the truth of this Dharma. Well, what is that? Neither easy nor difficult.

We can think of the instruction or the teaching about not having an opinion, not grasping, rejecting, not naming—all these foundational, reactive, deeply habitual things that we do. I remember sitting—I remember I was working on this dairy farm in upstate many years ago. I was sitting one morning before I went in to work the cows, and I was noticing my impulse, my impulsive mind, to name everything, to identify everything that came up, you know? And I remember thinking, I guess that’s going to always be there, you know? I mean, I couldn’t imagine that my mind wouldn’t do that at some point, because it was just so consistent, so reliable, right? And then that started to change, right? Started to drop away, started to get softer, started not to be so reflexive.

And so when we don’t engage in those simple actions that actually have very deep roots—naming, opinion, judging, grasping, rejecting—all of those things are strengthening our suffering, strengthening the very things that we’re trying to free ourselves of. And so when we relax those, and when we relax the sense that you are doing something, you are holding on, you are rejecting, you have an opinion, you are comparing, you are meditating, your concentration is getting stronger, your mind is distracted—none of that is necessary in order to practice, in order to see, be alert and practice well.

And the more—or the less—that that self is brought forward: I am, I am, I am, I am. The less the self is brought forward, long before it’s realized, that self is becoming quiet. And that’s the essence of an enlightened being. And so we are bringing forth enlightened mind when we allow that self-consciousness, that self-witnessing, that self-naming. And when it does arise, don’t make a big deal about it. Doesn’t mean anything. It doesn’t have any power. It’s not a problem. So when you just meet it as like as one of many sensations, it arises, it’s gone, it arises, it’s gone.

Later in the sutra, a couple pages later, Subhuti says, “Well, how then should a bodhisattva practice? How should we go forth?” And the Buddha makes it very clear—it’s very simple. If you want to know full enlightenment, behave towards beings with an even mind. With an even mind. Don’t produce an uneven mind, a mind that is dull, apathetic, asleep. And don’t produce a mind that is agitated, volatile. Bring forth a thought of benefit towards all beings. In other words, generate intentions, desires, thoughts, citta, to be of benefit towards others—a thought that is free from aversion. Treat each person as though they were your mother, your father, your brother, your sister, your friend, your child, your relative, your neighbor, people you depend upon, people you care about. Become a person who abstains from taking life, from stealing, from clouding your mind, and so on. In other words, practice in accord with the precepts.

Practice is a Buddha practice. The paramitas. Give, give—it doesn’t matter what you give, it doesn’t have to be something. When we want to bring forth thoughts of benefit, we want to be giving. Then we cultivate a mind and a heart that has that kind of generosity, magnanimity, patience, vigor, concentration. Develop the practices—your mindfulness.

The Buddha says, practice the great friendliness and the great compassion, the four immeasurables. In other words, engage in the practices that have come down to us, that have been transmitted. Understand the Four Noble Truths, understand dukkha, relinquish attachments, realize the nature of your mind and follow the path. And do all of this, the Buddha says, without taking a basis in anything, without turning any of this into something fixed, solid, graspable, something to gain, something to lose, something that has its own power. 

In other words, practice as an enlightened being, within faith, within understanding, and in time, through direct experience, that there is nothing that is eternal except that which is never born. There is nothing that we can actually grasp in our mind other than our mind. There is no obstacle that we’re experiencing that is actually external to ourselves and doing something to us. There is adversity. There are difficult situations, absolutely. Buddhism has never denied that. The world is filled with them and filled with people making them, and sometimes we’re that person.

The path is not about living in a fantasy world. But it’s said, whatever those conditions are, whatever the moment is, whatever this day is, you have a mind and a path that is fundamentally, in and of itself, free, unbound. But we have to train. We have to train that mind, develop it, bring it forth, make it, make it happy.

One day, Layman Pang and Ling Zhao were out selling bamboo baskets. They were coming down off a bridge and he stumbled and fell. When she saw it, she ran and threw herself down next to him. And her father said, “What are you doing?” And she said, “I saw Papa fall to the ground, so I’m helping.” And he said, “Ah, thank goodness no one was looking.”

Thank you for listening. To find out more about ZMM’s programs, retreats, and residency, please visit us online at zmm.org.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Title: Feeding Your Demons
Caption or Other Speaker: Lopon Karla
Extracted Text:
Good morning, everyone. It's so great to be here. I felt warmly welcomed, at home, well taken care of, which is really kind of good for me because I'm the kind of person that, oh, I can do it. Oh, I'll do it. Oh, I can do it. And it's really nice to be able to receive. So I want to thank everyone here for really supporting me in being able to share this teaching.

As you know, I am a senior teacher associated with Tara Mandala Retreat Center in Pagosa Springs. I practice Vajrayana, Tibetan Buddhism. And I'm going to take a moment now to raise bodhicitta, to raise the intention that this talk—you can hold your hands in prayer, or as we do, a one-pointed mudra, middle fingers out, rest of the fingers folded down like an arrow, the arrow of our focus. But either way is acceptable.

I want to begin by acknowledging the indigenous folk of this land—the Mohawk Confederacy, the Iroquois Confederacy. May their wisdom be present with us today. I also invoke and call in my ancestors, the ancestors of those who are present today, those who have helped us, because without them, we would not be here. And I honor and acknowledge and aspire that their wisdom will be present. I invoke all of the wisdom beings of all of the traditions represented here. May their wisdom be present. I acknowledge and honor all of the Dharma protectors, the Dharmapala and the local protectors. May they continue to protect us as we walk our path. And connecting to my heart, I raise a heartfelt motivation that this talk will be a benefit to ourselves, to all beings everywhere, without one exception. Thank you.

This weekend I had the opportunity to share the Feeding Your Demons practice, which really is ancient wisdom for resolving inner conflict. Numbers of us learned the practice. Feeding Your Demons was developed by Lama Tsultrim Allione to help her students transform and address the underlying issues, conflicts, habitual behaviors that often get in the way. They get in the way of our everyday life. They get in the way and sometimes create obstacles for our even being able to practice, to deepen our practice.

And FYD, as we call it, Feeding Your Demons, is a westernized version of the Tibetan Buddhist Chöd practice. Chöd was developed in Tibet by an 11th-century Tibetan woman. This is highly unusual because most of the practices that come from Tibet have been developed or initiated by men. And for a while, women couldn't even be educated to read and write—just how it was. But Machig was born into a family that was pretty well off, and her parents were practitioners. Both her mother and father recognized at her birth that this was a special being. As in many Tibetan stories, she had certain marks. She had, like, a very, very tiny—looked like a third eye here. Her fingers were webbed. She could read, and she learned to read very early. She would read the Prajnaparamita Sutra, which, of course, at one point was 8,000 lines, at another point was 25,000 lines. So, wealthy people would hire her to come and read the sutra, primarily because there would be a generation of merit. And the more you could read a full sutra, the more merit could be generated, the more benefit could be gleaned.

She would read within her community and was known for this. Of course, as many of us—you know, sometimes you read something and you think you get it. You think you know it. Particularly with Dharma, right? It's like, oh, nature of mind. All right, I get that. And I know I don't. I can't even explain it to somebody, right? So it's this way of, like, oh. And at one point she was asked, do you really know what it means? And she recognized, no. So she went on, and she studied further. She became a nun, practicing.

When she talks about demons, what are these things called demons? What they are not are Hollywood projections. What they are not really is something outside of ourselves. What Machig says in her teachings is: what we call demons are not materially existing individuals with huge, dark forms, frightening and terrifying anyone who sees them. A demon really refers to anything that hinders liberation—usually anything in us that hinders liberation.

We can often think, you know, it's so easy to other, right? It's like, it's your problem. No, that's not my—if you would only—if you would only be kind to—if you would only listen to me—because you're the issue. No, you're not the issue. I'm the issue, and it's my issue. So Chöd and Feeding Your Demons really help us look at that in a healthy, transformative way.

Demons are our fears, our negative self-talk, our illnesses, our perseverating thoughts. Down the rabbit hole I go—what are they doing? Things happen to us in life, but they operate to block us. They operate to create obstacles for feeling free.

In ancient times, Chöd practitioners would travel from village to village and perform the Chöd ritual to heal humans and to heal animals. And yet they did not become ill. Some of this is because the traditional Chöd practice is designed to help practitioners cut through ego clinging, cut through ego fixation, cut through the concepts. We hold that this vehicle I'm traveling in is the real deal. If we hold the view in Buddhism, this is not the real deal. This is an illusion. Emptiness, luminosity is the absolute. But again, we're in 3D reality, so it makes it a little difficult to lean into that all the time. Hence, we practice. We keep diving deeper and deeper and deeper.

So Chöd practitioners, in some ways, as they practice, there would be nothing for an illness to hold onto. The word Chöd means to sever. So the whole process is to continue to cut through the fear—the fear of what might be here, the fear of failure, the fear of this energy that might be lurking behind me. It doesn't exist in and of itself. Chöd is a practice that keeps reminding us about that.

Sometimes in the West, we often think that anything that's negative needs to be defeated. We should conquer it. People say, you need to conquer your fears, crush them, cut them out, destroy them. And in some ways, that is problematic. It's problematic because often we can't stuff them in a drawer enough so that they don't come out, right? Maybe we do conquer them for a moment, but then there's a little bit that peeks out from the side. So we're taught to fight, we're taught to conquer.

The teachings of Machig shift that in terms of shifting the paradigm. Machig's teachings offer us another option. They do show us that when you offer anything exactly what it needs, it relaxes. So in the West, we say, oh my gosh, if you feed a negative feeling, it's just going to grow. Well, maybe you're not feeding it the right diet. Because in actuality, if you offer something to someone that they truly need, at the core of their being, whatever tensions they might be walking with, whatever aggressions they might manifest, that just relaxes because it fits, because it integrates, because what was two parts becomes whole. Machig again—her gift to us: feed, not fight.

In terms of this idea, where did she come up with this? Right? I mean, she grew up in a world where people were warriors, where people were fighting, even practicing the Dharma. So we know that she could read Prajnaparamita Sutra, she became a nun, she studied with many lamas. And there was a moment—some of you have heard this—where she was receiving a very secret initiation. And in this initiation, as the lama was reading the text, Machig levitates from her cushion. And actually she does a little, what they call a dakini dance, where she moves: left foot raised, right foot waves, left foot raised, dancing between Samsara and Nirvana. And then she floats through the wall of the gompa.

Now, some of you are like, well, that's a pretty fantastic trick. But in ancient Tibet, people could do these kinds of things. They manifested the siddhis so often. But we could say that she was so deep in meditation that she was tapping in to absolute reality. She floats out and lands in a tree. This tree is located by this lake. The lake is ruled by a very fierce, angry, frightening Naga, this water spirit. People would walk far away. They wouldn't walk near this. He was so terrifying.

She lands in his tree in meditative equipoise. And of course, he's like, well, who the heck is this? What? How dare she? And he rises up and comes at her to attack her. And she remains in meditative equipoise, communicating: take what you need, do what you will. He's like, well, maybe she really doesn't know who I am. So he conjures up his minions. So we have big Nagas, little Nagas coming at her, right? She remains in meditative equipoise, communicating: take what you need. No fear, no doubt, just in the true nature.

In the moment when he attacks her the second time, he is transformed and commits himself to protecting the Dharma and protecting Dharma practitioners. And in Tibet, there are numbers of stories about these demons, these manifestations of beings that are doing harm to many, many people. And they're pretty arrogant in the idea that I am the baddest, I am the biggest, I am the meanest, and nobody can stop me. Nobody, not over here, not over there, nobody can stop me. And they have pride in how many people they have harmed.

Well, there's a story about a protector, Mahakala, who was really creating so much negative karma that Tara and Avalokiteshvara come together and really have a conversation. Could you please stop? And he's like—laughs—you can't make me stop. What do they do? Do they annihilate him? Absolutely not. What they do is they offer him compassion and, in fact, flood his heart with compassion to the point where he suddenly experiences regret for all of his transgressions and then dedicates his life to protecting practitioners and the Dharma.

So we have a lot of themes of this transformation of something that might be experienced as negative into something that becomes a support, that becomes an ally. Feeding Your Demons operates in that way.

I'm going to ask you to just for a moment think about a time when you were really thirsty—I mean really thirsty—to the point that all you could focus on was getting a cool drink to quench your thirst. And maybe you had tasks to do. Maybe you were writing a Dharma talk, maybe you were ready to practice. But how could you do that? Because all you needed was a drink of water. So you can feel the tension. You can feel the—I have to have it. Can I get it? And then what happens when you take that first sip? The first sip goes in your mouth. You feel the cool water on your tongue. You feel the water going down your throat. And sometimes what happens is your body begins to relax. That's what happens in the Feeding Your Demons process—the inner tension, our conflicts, through that process, get transformed. And we can be more at ease, more open, maybe even feeling a little bit of liberation, a little bit of expansiveness, freedom, opening.

And so this ancient practice, Chöd, is the root of Feeding Your Demons, that we get to look at what blocks us. We feed it what it really needs through a process that combines Buddhist practice and Western psychology. And we discover an ally. Sometimes whatever issue or demon we're working with is directly connected to the ally. We can see the relationship. Sometimes we don't. But often in our life, having an ally is so useful. It's like when we find the right teacher for ourselves, right? The right teacher for me—in some instances, I can just relax a little bit again. That fit.

Feeding Your Demons encourages us to integrate the parts of ourselves that we have cast off, that we've turned our back on, that we've denied. And what do they want? They want some attention. They want some love. They need some compassion. Or how else will we integrate that? And so Feeding Your Demons really helps us relax the inner tension that we experience when we live in dualism, like hopes and fears. I hope I'll be able to get home safely. I'm afraid I might be in an accident. I hope—think about how often you may be living between hope and fear. I hope that I'll be able to sit through meditation still and drop in. I'm afraid I'm not going to. I'm afraid my discursive thoughts are going to take over. I mean, all of those ways in which we're like in between and the tension. Feeding Your Demons helps us relax that.

There are many benefits of this practice to support us on the path, but also to help us in our life. So we know relaxing that inner tension, and as I said, on a psychological level, can foster this integration of the parts of ourselves that we are rejecting, which might be functioning as obstacles. Self-doubt—I have that one big time. You know, no matter how many times I've done something, oh my gosh, is the teaching going to be good enough? Am I going to cover everything that needs to be covered? You know? Oh, no, you can't do—quiet. Well, I can't just quiet it. What would be great is if I said, what is it you truly need? How would you feel if you get what you truly need? An answer may be I'd feel secure. Okay. In a Feeding Your Demons practice, I would offer security, and I don't have to worry about what that might look like. So psychologically, we can actually have integration.

On a spiritual level, Feeding Your Demons does help us remove obstacles to our practice. It can definitely foster a deepening of our meditation practices. It can help us manifest a form of fierce compassion in the world. And boy, do we need fierce compassion right now—the compassion that holds the line, the compassion that goes into any area. There was a time that I used to think that Green Tara was just soft, you know, compassion is sweet compassion. There she sits, looking so lovely. Until I recognized that Tara will go anywhere where beings are suffering—into the bellies of the world. I was like, wow, that takes some courage. It's like, oh no, there's strength here. There's power in compassion. So Feeding Your Demons can help us manifest that right now for the benefit of others.

When we step on the Buddhist path, being a Buddhist requires courage. It requires a steadfastness. It requires the ability to look at suffering. No, don't turn away. Look. Look at it. Witness it. And then maybe you can offer something that could shift it, that could lessen it. Because we are practicing for the benefit of ourselves and the benefit of all sentient beings. That's a big task. I mean, I think about, you know, in my practice and often in my practices, it says, "I single-handedly..." It's like, whoa, I don't know if I can do that. And I said, yes, I do that every time I practice. So this interconnection and this interrelatedness—again, Feeding Your Demons allows us to transform something that is an obstacle into something that is a support—from demon to ally. And the allies actually are our own innate wisdom, our own inner knowing. How wonderful that we can access that.

Feeding Your Demons reminds us that we have the capacity to be our own allies. It helps us move away from obscurations, drop the veil of ignorance, and just rest in our true nature—our true nature, luminous, shining in the ten directions, connected to everything and everyone. One taste, as we say. So again, feed, not fight. Paying attention and caring for the parts of us that we discarded. Nobody likes to be discarded. We don't like to be rejected. And think about, well, why might I be doing that to myself? Why is that happening in my psyche? Maybe I could just be with what is for a little bit, look at it, and then ask or see what it truly needs.

We can think of Feeding Your Demons practice as transforming obstacles into opportunities. And sometimes I'm like, oh, come on. An obstacle into an opportunity? That feels like a reach. I'm kind of tired. Come on, opportunities to practice. It's like, uh huh. Well, sometimes my practice doesn't feel like an opportunity. No, to be transparent, it's like, all right, I have to. And yet, often—actually, always—there's benefit, right? But we get to remove those. It's like sweeping—sweep out the dust and then you can see the floor, how clear it is.

Feeding Your Demons practice helps us enhance our bodhicitta. It helps us in terms of walking the bodhisattva path. Bodhicitta—awakened mind, right, awakened heart-mind. That space where we hold our compassion. And in these chaotic, troubling times, we want to be able to really call in our bodhicitta. We want to actually even maybe manifest radical bodhicitta. Take it out, take the aspiration for all beings to not be in suffering, take it out into the world, which many of us, many of us do, right? But we need fierce compassion now. We need to look, we sometimes need to say, something's wrong here. This can't—this should not happen.

So the Feeding Your Demons practice can clear out what might get in the way of our walking with our aspirational bodhicitta into the bodhicitta of action. Feeding Your Demons cuts through spiritual bypass. No spiritual bypass here. There's no time for denial. And we all know you can't meet anger and aggression with anger and aggression. And yet, how long have humans been doing that? Machig offers another option.

Each time we practice, we meet ourselves. It can be really beneficial to access some of what we refer to as skillful means—the technology, our practices that help us to reach in or touch into the wisdom that is available, to the wisdom that's right here, wherever here is. When we practice, we often do meet what Machig would refer to as maras—these demons, these obstacles. And we also experience wisdom when we truly face our inner shadow, maras or demons. When we stare directly into the face of what haunts us, when we do not look away, resist or aggress, we can see clearly—that pristine clarity. It's like turning on the light: Dharma in a dark room, samsara—all is dissolved in Dharma, into the ground of being.

There's no need to be afraid. There's no need to run to a protected space. When we embrace our shadow, when we embrace the ego clinging, self clinging, we can lose the distinctions between others and ourselves. We then have the opportunity to create a new relationship with others and with phenomena. At that moment of recognition, we are better able to rest in equanimity.

Machig Labdrön and Lama Tsultrim Allione have gifted us the powerful and immediate methods to identify and transform these obstacles, these things that plague us, these things that block our freedom and liberation. Feeding Your Demons provides a method for meeting the muck of our inner lives and transforming that into the lotus we truly are. Through Feeding Your Demons and transforming what blocks us into what supports our liberation—and this quote comes directly from the Chöd practice—we are victorious in all directions so that whomever we meet will be benefited.

Thank you. Thank you for listening.

To find out more about ZMM's programs, retreats, and residency, please visit us online at zmm.org.

Title: Awakening To Forms, See The Mind
Extracted Text:
The following Dharma discourse was given by Jeffrey Shugan Arnold at Zen Mountain Monastery. Shugan Roshi is the head of the Mountains and Rivers Order and abbot of the monastery. This talk, like all of our talks, is offered free of charge. If you would like to make a donation or find out more about our various programs, visit us online at zmm.org. Thank you for listening.

This is from the Book of Serenity, Mu and Yunmen's Sound and Form pointer:

Not cutting off sound and form is falling. Wherever you are, searching by way of sound and looking by way of form, you don't see Buddha. Isn't there anyone who can take to the road and return home?

Yunmen one day said to the assembly, “Hearing sound, awaken to the Way. Seeing form, understand the mind. The Bodhisattva Avalokiteshvara brings money to buy a sesame cake. When she lowers her hand, it turns out to be a jelly donut.”

Hongzhi’s verse:
Going out the gate, making the horse leap,
Sweeping away the comets,
The smoke and dust of 10,000 countries is spontaneously clear.
The 12 media are free of useless images and echoes.
Pure light emanates in a billion worlds.

So, we're completing our ongoing intensive this morning and I don't know how to describe what it was in my mind. It was many things, so I'll let it be that. But I wanted to talk a little bit about art practice this morning—one of our areas of training—drawing from the particular relationship with the arts in the Zen tradition.

In Buddhism, most of the arts have a function as a meditation, as an aspect of meditation, as something that is brought into meditation. There’s also the aspect of how something is created: that it is created within a mind, within a mind of Buddha, within a mind of meditation. So process and result are merged in the Zen tradition. Zen masters—Hakuin, others—who are poets, painters, painter-priests, offered pieces of creative expression, poetry, paintings, and so on, as teachings.

And then Daido Roshi, in his own path as a photographer—he talked about when he first met someone, Nakagawa Roshi and then Eido Roshi, in Daibosatsu, and was interested but was wary of Buddhism, of Zen, of religion. But he offered to spend time there, photographing, because he was a photographer and offered those photographs. He wasn’t ready to enter the gate. He wasn’t ready to begin practicing, but he, I guess, was trying to find a way in and then eventually, of course, did and brought that gate of training into our practice here from the very beginning.

And because he was a photographer, he kept shooting his whole life; it was just what he did. When video cameras came out, I remember he rented the first video camera. We couldn’t afford it. We didn’t have money, and they were very expensive. So I remember he rented one from Sears and started making films and exploring, continuing his photographic artistry through videos, which he was very excited about. He created a little sort of studio at the Abbey’s studio where he would put those together. Particularly in his later life, his relationship with the arts and the way that came into his teaching became more and more, I think, prominent and present. He spoke very, very often about the arts and our practice and his own relationship with creativity.

So, not cutting off sound and form is falling wherever you are. Searching by way of sound and form and looking, you don’t see the Buddha. That is drawing from the Diamond Sutra, where the Buddha said, “If you see me in form, if you hear me, recognize me by sound, by my voice, you don’t see the Buddha, you’re not seeing Buddha.”

So what does it mean to see Buddha? Does an enlightened being not see, not hear? How do we inhabit this dharma body? We talked about that in various ways during the weekend. How do we, as a sentient being—right? We can think of our senses as the places in which we get caught. In fact, the senses are often spoken of as thieves. It’s where we get stolen away from ourselves by going out into our senses and getting confused.

In the poem where it says, “the 12 media are free of useless images and echoes,” the 12 media are your senses: eyes, ears, nose, tongue, body or skin, and mind, and then the objects in the respective fields of those sense organs. The poem is saying, as Hongzhi says, they are free of useless images and echoes. We might think that means in a state of samadhi where there is no seeing, no hearing. And that’s true, but it’s talking about at all times being free, not being deceived.

How do we inhabit this dharma body, this true person of no rank? The eyes and ears are clear. Nagarjuna might say, “Well, we do see something with the eyes. There is something in front of you. We do hear something with the ears.” But what is the nature of that which we see? That’s the question the Buddha Dharma is asking. What is the nature of that which we hear? Are we hearing in a way that is true, that is reliable?

We talked over the last couple of days about teachings about how, because of dependent origination, because we get lost in things, we project our ideas, our views, our karmic history, our experiences, our wants, our likes and dislikes in through our senses, through our mind, through our consciousness, into our perceptions. Those perceptions are intrinsically then unreliable, unstable—one, because they’re impermanent, but also because we’re projecting ourselves onto it. So what are we actually seeing?

And we can think of that as, you know, so what if what you’re looking at is a bowl of fruit or a tree or something—that may not matter to you, but you’re still relating to it, it’s still in your world. But what about when that object is a person—someone you love, a stranger, someone who’s acting in a way that you don’t like, you don’t agree with, somebody who doesn’t look like you? We see the consequences of that. That’s the long, troubled story of humanity, still trying to work that out. So what is the nature of that which we see?

The Buddha said, that is what we call the world: what I see, what I hear, what I perceive. If we take the sounds and forms as the true person, the Buddha said, you cannot see me—which is another way of saying, you will not see yourself.

We talked yesterday about that fundamental sense of distance, isolation, alienation, loneliness, estrangement. Why does that seem to occur within human beings, wherever we are? Why does that seem to show up in various ways in our various religious traditions, a recognition that in some way we have lost something, become distant from something, and need to find our way back? Is there anyone who can take to the road and return home?

Well, that then begs the question: what is home? Is it here? Is it up in heaven? Is it somewhere else? Is it in this time? Is it another time?

We were looking at some of the writings of Evelyn Underhill in her book on mysticism. So I want to just read a little bit. She said, “The conscious self sits, so to speak, at the end of a telegraph wire.” That is, our senses. Information comes in. She said it seems to most people to be the one channel of communication with the hypothetical external world. So she’s already suggesting that what we take as the fixed, solid, inarguable world might be up for question.

The receiving instrument registers certain messages. The receiver, she said, does not know—and as long as she remains dependent on that instrument, can never know—the object, the reality at the other end of the wire by which those messages are sent.

So when the Buddha considered not teaching because what he was going to teach, what he wanted to try and point to, could not be pointed to, could not be experienced with the senses. But then, when we take that for the world and when we assume that that which I’m experiencing is what everybody’s experiencing—my world is the world—we don’t think of it in terms of an individual, personalized world. That’s the fundamental bias of the self: my assumption that my experiences, which—if I don’t recognize—are the result of a lifetime of karma and thoughts and experiences and beliefs and so on, if I’m not aware of that, then it just seems like I open my eyes and I just see what is objectively there. “It’s just not there. It’s just that, surely you’re seeing the wrong thing.” So when we’re in disagreement, “What’s wrong with you?”

She says, “The sphere of our possible intellectual knowledge is strictly conditioned by the limits of our own personality. On this basis, not the ends of the earth, but the external termini of our own sensory nature—nerves are the termini, the endpoint of our explorations. That’s it. That’s all we need to know. And to know oneself is really just to know your universe. We don’t need to examine ourselves.”

It’s one of the things that I see coming up with practitioners sometimes who are in relationship with partners or family members who may not have a relationship with looking for a road by which to return home. They may not have something in their lives which is somehow inward-turning. There are people in my life who are like that. And so then, to such a person, it cannot make sense. Like, “Why do you need to do this? Why do you need to go and sit and look inward? Why don’t we, I mean, just live? Why do you need to take this time away from me, from us, to do something that I don’t get, you know, I don’t understand. Isn’t this enough? Aren’t I enough?” See how that can be challenging, threatening. Right?

That’s oftentimes what I’ll ask: Does your partner have any kind of relationship with something in which they reflect, they examine, they have some access to a world that’s not just out there?

And so then she talks about those few people, she says, who realize acutely and persist that there is, she says, a type of personality which does not realize this limitation—or I would say at some point doesn’t accept it, doubts it. “There has to be something more and cannot be content with the sham realities that furnish the universe of normal people. It is necessary, it seems, to the comfort of persons of this type—seekers—to form for themselves some image of something or nothing which is at the end of these lines of communication or perception, some conception of being, some theory of knowledge, something.” How do you even speak of it? She says they are “tormented by the unknowable. An ache for first principles demands some background to the shadow show of things. Insofar as people possess this temperament, they hunger for reality and must satisfy that hunger as best they can, staving off starvation.”

A real thirst, a good thirst that the Buddha realized can be quenched. It’s not the thirst of the hungry ghost that is unquenchable because of its very nature, but this is to be quenched. That’s why experiencing that ache, as she speaks of it, that discomfort—you know, were there any moments in your practice, if you’ve been practicing long enough, as it were, for me, where I thought, “Why can’t I just, like, shut up about all this?” Right? “Forget about it, go back, go on, be happy. It’s enough.” Always in difficult moments, right? Tormented by the unknowable.

The 19th century Otaka Kaki Rengetsu, Zen nun, teacher, poet, said:
“Heart drifting like white clouds from beginning to end.
A thing of mystery is this heart, and mystery contains.”

I think this can contain the sense of something that is not easily knowable—not knowable in the old way, but is something we can encounter. There is a road home, and at the same time it can possess the quality of, “you will never know this.” That’s not its function, that’s not what’s needed. There’s something else here.

Daido Roshi used to talk a lot about the sort of connection between the creative process and dharma practice, where we are focused on something, we’re engaging in something, we’re encountering something that isn’t just an intellectual process. There’s something else going on in this realm—it’s creative expression. There’s a medium, right? We’re using something, our body’s involved, and something is trying to be communicated. Something is trying to be encountered.

And in our practice, the emphasis is always: let it be true. So when you see your mind going towards, “Do I like this? Do I not like this? Does this actually look like a... What will other people think? This doesn’t make sense.” When it starts to get intellectual, you come back, come back, come back, come back.

Think of the haiku: a simple three-line verse that originates out of a direct experience of something simple, going out on a spring day and then trying to convey the sense of that—not describing. So if it’s something to convey the sense of spring, you can’t use the word spring, right? How do you convey the sense so that somebody reading that haiku smells the air, the spring air, feels the cool breeze? It’s conveying the experience, right? And so then we have to be intimate with that experience and then let it be manifest.

He used to talk about the muse. He talked about when he went out west once—I forget the name of the area, but it was on the coast, the west coast. There are some of the photographs downstairs from that trip that he took. He said he got so intoxicated by these visual images and the photography, and he was just getting so that he thought he was going to faint. So he actually went inward, inland—not inward, and sat down. And just, he said, was overtaken by the muse. He was so excited and just filled.

Evelyn Underhill said that mysticism, the mystic path, is the art of union with reality—a road to take us home to here. To here.

So what is creative expression? I remember somebody many years ago talking about asking Daido, because he was a truck driver, and he said, “Could driving my truck be my art practice?” And Daido said, “No.” He said, “But there’s a creative element to it.” He said, “Save it.” He said, “No, whatever that is, fine, but try something new. Try something else here.” When I first was here, because I was a musician and I had my instrument, every ango I would try and take up my flute. It was a natural thing to do, make that my art practice. But it was so hard. I just kept reverting to my training, reverting to what I knew as a classical musician, which had a very particular way. It was very hard for me to be new, to be a beginner, to be a student. So I stopped doing that, and I just started working with a brush and paper, which I hadn’t done since I was in grade school. I had no investment in it. I had no history. I didn’t need to be good at it. It was great. And for the first time, I felt like, okay, I think I’m starting to get some sense of what my teacher’s talking about. And then I was able to come back to the flute. Geimon and I used to do things together where she would do movement and I would improvise, basically. And then I could come back to it having sort of gained a little bit of understanding through a different medium in which I didn’t have a personal investment. That’s what I had a hard time letting go of with the flute.

And so we can think about creative expression as communicating, sharing, something that arises when we are in contact, both within and without, and something that is to be shared. And so, what is that? When the self is bound within grasping, what might the creative expression then be? What might it be when that grasping is being released? It’s not so strong, but the self is still very much present. So of course there is grasping, but it’s softening. And then what is it when grasping and selflessness is realized or let go of in that moment of creation? It’s compassion.

Somebody asked yesterday, because we were talking about prayer, and somebody asked if zazen could be prayerful. And I said, “That’s a wonderful question. Let’s just leave that as a question. Don’t rush to an answer. Don’t try and come up with an answer. Explore. Will it have compassion within it? Selfless thoughts, words, and actions to not create harm?”

Ryokan, the priest-poet, wrote:
“The rain has stopped, the clouds have drifted away and the weather’s clear again.
If your heart is pure, then all things in your world are pure.
Abandon this fleeting world, abandon yourself.
Then the moon and flowers will guide you along the way.”

When the heart, the mind become clear, fresh, new, the world is clear, fresh, and new. It’s still samsara; there’s still much, much trouble going on. But we perceive it differently because the world is mind.

I was thinking of many years ago when I was first living in the city. It was late 70s, early 80s, performance art was happening. And I would go to different performances, often in basements and dark and, you know, scary places. And I remember being in a performance with a couple. It was a very small room. We were in chairs. They were right in front of us. We could almost touch them. There was a television with Richard Nixon giving a speech. And the two people were doing something—I couldn’t really understand what was going on. But they had a tape recorder with another speech going on that was on the end of a rope. And they started—he started swinging it over his head. And then he started letting out the rope. So it was getting closer and closer. And then they started throwing bananas. And I thought, “This is bullshit. This is just bullshit.” And afterwards, you know, some people were really agitated. And I was watching the performers and I thought, “Oh, that’s the point. That’s what you were going for. You just wanted to piss everybody off. Well done.”

And Daido Roshi used to talk about the responsibility, you know, just because I created it, just because it’s something—like, there’s a responsibility. Just like what I think, just like what I say, just like what I do, I have a responsibility. It doesn’t mean it always has to be nice and pretty and beautiful. It doesn’t mean that we have to avoid any disagreement or conflict at all or strong emotion. But to take responsibility for it, to not wantonly inflict it upon each other as though there’s something noble or artistic—there’s a responsibility.

When Geimon was a dancer (my partner), and she was—I'm biased, but I thought she was an extraordinary dancer, it’s how I first met her—was when she was on stage and had a real talent. If you’re listening to this, I hope this is okay. She was very gifted, and I could see that. I think other people could see that. And when she left dance, there were a lot of people who were not happy about that and were like, “How can you walk away from this?” And she and I used to talk about, you know, if somebody has a gift, do they have a responsibility to use that gift? Do you have to be an artist? Do you have to dance? Do you have to be—if you’re a prodigy on the violin, do you have to play the violin? Like, are you somehow bound by that, to use it in that particular way? It could do a lot of good. It could bring a lot of joy, it could inspire. It’s like, if you have something that could be really helpful, do you have to use it in that way? Are there other ways you could use it?

So, hearing sound, awaken to the Way; seeing form, understand the mind. Then Yunmen says, and this is basic practice: by entering into the sound, entering into the form, the only way to enter is to leave the self behind, let it relax. Of course, it’s not a thing; you’re not leaving anything anywhere. You’re just not invoking it, not producing it, not self-creating. And so, then what is it?

And so there are many, many koans that do that. A student asked Master Zhaozhou, “What is the true dharma?” And Zhaozhou said, “That oak tree in the garden.” And the student said, “Master, don’t point to something in the phenomenal, conditioned, impermanent, samsaric world to reveal something that is unconditioned and free.” And he said, “I don’t point to something of the samsaric world that is conditioned and impermanent.” And the student says, “Well, then, what is the true dharma?” And Zhaozhou said, “The oak tree in the garden.”

What did Zhaozhou see? What did the monk see? They were both seeing a tree. The monk only saw a tree. He was only seeing his mind’s image of something.

And so then Bodhisattva Avalokiteshvara brings money to buy a sesame cake. But when she lowers her hand, it’s a jelly donut. It’s classic Yunmen, right? You can imagine studying with this teacher, right? Because so many of his teachings are like this. I remember when I came to this koan, I thought, “Oh, what?” Because it’s not logical. Obviously, it’s not logical. And so what does it mean to enter into this?

Hear the cries of the world. She goes into the market to buy a sesame cake to alleviate all suffering. But when she lowers her hand, it’s a jelly donut. Doesn’t she know what’s going on? Isn’t she in control? Does she know the difference between a sesame cake and a jelly donut? Going beyond sound and form, there is a tree. What is the nature of that tree? What else is it?

When we sit down on the cushion, you’re a person. You come from such and such. You’ve done this and that. You live here. You have these possessions, these memories. That’s the bark, the branches—what else? What are you not? When you leave that behind, what remains? The Buddha said, now you can see Buddha. Now you are seeing Buddha.

Rumi wrote:
“Dissolver of sugar, dissolve me.
If this is the time, do it gently, with a touch of a hand or a look.
Every morning I wait at dawn. That’s when it happened before.
Or do it suddenly, like an execution.
How else could I get ready for death?
You breathe without a body. Like a spark.
You grieve. And I begin to feel lighter.
You keep me away with your arm.
But your keeping away just pulls me in.
I will not be kept away no more. Enough.”

And so we practice within sound and form to free ourselves of sound and form. The Buddha said, one of the entanglements is in rites and rituals, sounds and forms. I spoke during the weekend about why it was so important to Daido Roshi that liturgy is part of our training, so we’re not just ringing bells, doing prostrations without understanding, so that we can just ring a bell, just bow, see Buddha, return home.

And then in our practice, to bring that out. Because the moment you touch the brush to the paper, you make a sound, you make a movement, you utter a word, that’s your mind. And of course, the deal is everyone’s seeing it. Okay, let’s lay that bare.

I was thinking with Mother’s Day, I was thinking of my mother, Nels, and I was thinking of many things because she was many things. But she was a teacher in my high school, and for a while, and she taught the troubled kids, the troubled youth. They all sent them to my mom, the school sent them to my mom. She was supposed to get them right, you know, and she pretty quickly realized, you know, I don’t think everybody has to go to school all the time. She just tried to find out, what do you love? What do you care about? What turns you on? And she just tried to move them in that direction.

But she was telling us one night at dinner, my family, she said she got so tired of these kids cussing. They were always cussing—each other, at her. And one day she said, “Enough. I am so bored with this. You just use the same old language. So, look, we’re just going to get it all out. Write them on the board, and then you can’t use these words ever again. If you want to be nasty, you have to come up with different kinds of words.” So they—and of course, she said they got so into this, right? She said she was a little worried about what she had unleashed, right? She said they were coming up with words she’d never even heard of. So the whole board’s filled, and of course, there’s lots of sounds going on. And so the principal walks in. She’s already got a reputation in the school. And so the kids are like... And my mom’s looking at him and the board and him, and as she starts to open up, he goes, “I don’t even want to hear it.” And he just walked out. Yeah, she was pretty cool.

If zazen is a time to be released from the need to control, to manage, to fix—I mean, if we can really get that, is that not a relief? Is that not a relief? You don’t have to do that. In fact, if you do that, it’s going to get harder. That doesn’t keep us from trying, because that’s our habit. But ultimately, we have to understand, if there’s one moment, one time in the day when you trust enough to give that up within—that doesn’t mean just do whatever within your meditation. And so it means within that form, within the discipline, within the correctness of true meditation, there is letting go of control. There is a letting go of managing, of trying to fix.

So then we can think of our practice as also a time to be released from the need to be right, to be approved, to be skillful, to be creative. You know, it’s been said many times that, you know, when we’re young, as children, everybody’s an artist. And then at a certain point, that just stops.

I had an art teacher in grade school, Mrs. Lawson. Mrs. Lawson. She was a country woman, and she was the art teacher. And she would mostly sit at the table and just direct. And I remember bringing her a painting I’d done. She says, “Let me see what you’ve done, honey.” And I put it down. She said, “Well, now, isn’t that nice?” And then she picked up a pen or some crayons. She said, “What if I did this?” And then she redid the whole thing. I swear to God. And then she gave it back to me. She said, “Now, isn’t that nice? Isn’t that better? Don’t you like that?” Now, lesson learned. I get it.

So that comes up for a lot of people in our practice. “No, I don’t do that. I’m not creative. I can’t do that. I’m not good at that.” Okay, this is the time when you don’t have to be good. How about that? That’s what I did for myself when I started doing painting. I had to be good at the flute—I mean, for God’s sake—but painting, I didn’t have to be good. I had an excuse, right? I don’t know anything about it. It was a relief. It’s freeing. And then can we come back to something that we maybe have skill in, training at, history with?

She goes to buy a sesame cake. Lowering her hand, it’s a jelly donut. Things take shape. Sounds have certain qualities, but they are not fixed. We do not need to fix them. And that does not deny, it doesn’t distort—it actually frees us from the distortion. When we apply that to the world or we allow the world to be what it is, it’s vibrant, alive, dancing, it’s got ki—energy, aliveness. When we do that with each other, we’ve got buddhas, sentient beings, dignity, respect. We’ve got compassion, you might say. We have prayer manifested.

Going out the gate, making the horse leap, sweeping away the comets—these images, these phrases that are about being on the road, returning home, departing, letting go, shoving off, dropping the rope, untying the knot so that the smoke and dust of 10,000 countries can finally be seen to be clear. And sometimes that spontaneous clear is a ravaged mountain or a war zone or an angry face, a hatred made manifest. And it’s painful and it’s destructive. It is destroying. And within that, there is something that is beyond right and wrong and completely understands, can now understand the destructiveness without forsaking the person, without responding to hatred with hatred, without responding to dislike with dislike.

I’m thinking of one of our senior students who was in a, I think, a Gay Pride march many years ago. And the march got stuck, you know, as it does sometimes. Everybody’s just standing still. And she was standing—there were some other people, and there were some people in the crowd who were just hateful, screaming, yelling hateful things, and they were just stuck there. And she said, without really knowing what she was doing or thinking, she just went over and started doing prostrations. That’s love. That’s loving your enemy. Who knows what happens in such a moment, right? What does that person filled with hatred do with that? What do they do with that? I don’t know. But a message is being sent and something is being received. It’s worth considering.

So I’ll end with a poem:
Full bright, luminous moon fills the woods and shadows,
But it’s the barest sliver, fine curve of moon that I love the most.
Though it contains the whole, only this thin beauty is revealed.

The Buddha once said, if we could see the world as he saw it, we would never take a bite of food before feeding everyone else—which is exactly what we do in oryoki. If we could see the world as the Buddha sees it, then loving-kindness, compassion, all these wonderful virtues would be spontaneously clear.

That’s the great heartbreak of the Bodhisattva, and perhaps of most religious traditions, is just the simple fact: it doesn’t have to be like this. We don’t have to actually do this. We don’t have to build successive and sophisticated realms of hell and inflict them on each other. We just really do not have to do that. And it’s really not that difficult. And yet we have to find a road that takes us home.

And so, road travelers, let us travel well. Thank you for listening.

To find out more about ZMM’s programs, retreats, and residency, please visit us online at zmm.org.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Title: Being One With: Fusatsu
Extracted Text:
Fusatsu is the Japanese translation of Upavasatha, which is an ancient traditional practice started in the time of the Buddha, where the Sangha would come together twice a month. This still happens in some Sanghas, Theravada Sanghas, and a member of the Sangha would recite the precepts which the Buddha taught from the very beginning and which in his time were particularly important for lay students, as well as the monastic rules, the Vinaya, which are much more of a set of rules, much more extensive.

As the Precepts and the Vinaya are recited, members of the Sangha who have strayed from their vows have an opportunity to step forward, to speak about how they have strayed. In some cases they're given some act of penance. In many cases, just the act of speaking—bringing forth—is their repentance. This is a way for practitioners to bring themselves back into alignment with their vows, with how they are endeavoring to live their lives, back into accord with themselves.

Fusatsu is a practice, a way to bring ourselves back into alignment. We do stray, get caught up, confused. We return to acting out of habit, fear, desire. And we can use help remembering—remembering what is most true, what is important, remembering how it is that we want to live. What is the direction of our lives? What do we want the direction of our lives to be? What do we want to be cultivating, bringing forth, giving energy to?

We translate Fusatsu as a renewal of vows ceremony. And I've always wondered why the Precepts are not included in Fusatsu, these most important vows that some of us have taken formally. In my mind, I kind of consider them to be implied. Whenever we do the Gatha of Atonement, there's an opportunity to reflect. I take it as an opportunity to reflect on my practice, particularly of the Precepts—to reflect on how I have strayed, maybe how I have caused harm, hurt. How can I bring myself back into alignment with my vows? Often by doing differently next time.

Fusatsu is a practice of reflection and repentance. Fusatsu is sometimes translated as repentance ceremony. Repentance means recognizing where we've gone astray and includes a resolve to change, to act differently in the future. Fusatsu is a way to remember, to remind ourselves, to bring ourselves back into alignment with ourselves and to give verbal, physical expression to this.

Fusatsu is a way of remembering our vows, whether we have taken formal vows or not, and can help us to remember the importance of vows. Our vows can guide us, but we have to keep them alive, we have to take care of them, stay in contact with them.

So Fusatsu begins with this Gatha of Atonement. Daido Roshi used to talk about atonement as at-one-ment—when we turn towards, when we take responsibility, there is the potential for turning, karma resolving. And so we say, "All evil karma ever committed by me since of old..." And "evil" is a strong word; I get a little caught there sometimes. Other translations that might be helpful: unskillful actions, misdeeds, harmful actions, harmful karma.

We atone because we understand cause and effect. We understand that our actions do have effects, that we can cause harm, we can cause pain. We do, we have, on account of our beginningless greed, anger, and ignorance born of our body, mouth, and thought. The harmful karma we create is the result of our greed, our anger, our ignorance. It is from our actions, our speech, our thoughts that arise out of these confused states—a self-concerned state, a not-seeing state, maybe a not-paying-attention, not-caring state.

So the Gatha of Atonement is calling our attention to this as well. This is part of this teaching, practice, part of taking responsibility, part of our reflection. How do I create, what do I create, and what mind states do I create? And we atone.

Daido Roshi, in speaking about harmful karma, says when you take responsibility for it, you make it your own. And when you make it your own, then there is something that you can do about it. If you do not take responsibility for it, you are powerless to change. It is someone else's fault, something else is to blame, you are the victim. Taking responsibility empowers us to free ourselves of the endless cycle of cause and effect. This radical teaching of taking responsibility—it's what makes all transformation possible, what makes practice possible, what happens when we turn towards rather than turning away, when we look here, rather than turning outside, when we don't blame or put our discomfort outside, trusting there is a way here.

The Gatha of Atonement is a regular part of my personal liturgy. And sometimes there's something in particular that I want to take responsibility for, so that it can be resolved in me. And I say this: may this be resolved in me. And sometimes it's something that's mine, and sometimes it's something that's bigger than me, but I know runs through me. May this be resolved in me.

It is by taking responsibility that we can resolve. We can forgive, we can let go. And this part is important—the letting go, the forgiving, forgiving ourselves, forgiving others. Forgiving doesn't mean to condone harmful things that have been done. It's to not carry anger, resentment. And this practice of reflection, atonement—and atonement is not meant to lead us to shame or guilt, to beating ourselves up. These are not bringing us into accord. Returning to alignment.

Regret may be helpful. The pain of regret can be what tells us, brings our attention to what we've done. It's a sign that we care. Atonement, at-one-ment, is a practice to bring ourselves back into alignment, back into alignment with the direction that we choose for our lives.

We recite the names of the Buddhas—the past seven Buddhas, legendary Buddhas from the past eon, and from this fortunate eon. We live in the fortunate eon. As Roshi said earlier, we chant these names in our lineage, these enlightened beings, without beginning, going back eons. And then this human being, Shakyamuni, the Buddha of our time.

And we say "Namu." I've always understood "Namu" to mean "being one with." And it does. But it also means reverence, adoration, homage. And then we chant the names of the great bodhisattvas of this tradition, these beings who are manifestations of our own enlightened qualities. Namu, being one with Manjushri Bodhisattva, the embodiment of wisdom. Namu, homage to Samantabhadra Bodhisattva, embodiment of enlightened activity. Namu, adoration for Avalokiteshvara Bodhisattva, the great Compassionate One, your great, wise, compassionate heart. Maitreya is the Buddha to come, the next Buddha, the Buddha of the future. And there will be Buddhas, great teachers, enlightening beings after Maitreya, endless for eons to come.

Namu—being one with, turning towards, turning into. What does it mean to become one with? Namu, being one with these qualities that are our qualities, not outside of ourselves, that may come forth when we are clear in our mind, not confused, and that we may not be fully in touch with, that may be outside of our experience. How do we learn to trust that they are our qualities, our heart, our mind? These beautiful, wise, human qualities and aspirations are ours—to give homage to these qualities of being. Where are they?

We recite the Four Bodhisattva Vows. These vows that we recite frequently, every night here—reminders we can forget. We can stop hearing, chanting them so frequently, lose touch with what they are reminding us of. What is the direction of our lives?

Sentient beings are numberless. I vow to save them. Most simply, for me, this has always been a reminder that I'm not alone, this great truth that we are not alone. We all suffer and want to be free of suffering, want to be happy and at ease, and we are bound up together.

Related desires are inexhaustible. I vow to put an end to them, to lessen them, to not be controlled by them—by desire or by aversion. To not let desires dictate our actions, not let our fear and aversion drive the direction of our lives. A reminder—don't forget, this is where we can go astray, where we cause suffering. Desires themselves are not bad, but don't be confused. Don't get confused. Be wise, pay attention.

The Dharmas are boundless. I vow to master them. There is a practice, there is a path. We are offered these many ways to practice, these many places to enter. May I practice them, see for myself how they are a place to enter.

The Buddha Way is unattainable. I vow to attain. It's kind of our underlying vow, direction. There are five monastic vows, and the fifth is to accomplish the Buddha's way. And for me, that has always held the other vows, what is most important.

And we will end Fusatsu with taking refuge. Refuge in the three treasures. You'll see, we don't say that we're taking refuge, but that's my understanding of this part of the Fusatsu. Taking refuge means to rely upon completely, wholeheartedly. What do we rely upon? What do we put our faith in? What do we turn to when we need help? What do we turn to when we're acting out of habit, when we're not paying attention? What do we turn to when we're confused? What is it to take refuge in the Buddha, in the Dharma, in the Sangha? To turn towards consciously, wholeheartedly, and listen as we chant.

We say, being one with the Buddha. Being one with—again, Namu. Namu, reverence for the Buddha. Raise the mind of enlightenment. It is not outside, it is not elsewhere. Being one with the Dharma. Namu, reverence for the teachings; wisdom that is not apart from us. Being one with the Sangha. Namu, reverence for the Sangha; may harmony pervade. Namu, being one with—it is not outside. May we remember.

Thank you for listening.

To find out more about ZMM's programs, retreats, and residency, please visit us online at zmm.org.
Speaker: Bear Gokan Bonebakker

Title: Buddhist Studies And Language
Extracted Text:
The following Dharma discourse was given by Jeffrey Shugan Arnold at Zen Mountain Monastery. Shugan Roshi is the Head of the Mountains and Rivers Order and Abbot of the Monastery. This talk, like all of our talks, is offered free of charge. If you would like to make a donation or find out more about our various programs, visit us online at zmm.org. Thank you for listening.

This is from the Book of Serenity, Four Sections of the Enlightenment Scripture.

A Pointer:

The presently forming public case is just based on the immediate present. The fundamental family style does not aim beyond the fundamental. If you forcibly set up divisions and foolishly expend effort, it’s all drawing eyebrows for chaos. Putting a handle on a bowl, how can you become peaceful?

The Main Case:

The Scripture of Perfect Enlightenment says: At all times, do not produce delusive thoughts. Also, don’t try to stop and annihilate deluded states of mind in realms of false conception. Don’t add knowledge and don’t find reality in no knowledge. 

Holmzhi: Magnificent, clearly outstanding, serene, at ease. Clamor pierces the head. Quiet is where to tread. Underfoot the thread breaks and I am free. The spot of mud on the nose is gone. You don’t have to chop, don’t budge on a thousand-year-old scrap of paper. Medicine is compounded.

So I wanted to speak a little bit this morning about the gate of Buddhist study. Gokanoshu gave a nice mondo on that earlier this week. 

As most of you know, Bodhidharma is attributed with having said that Zen is a special transmission outside the scriptures, with no reliance on words and letters, a direct pointing to the human mind and the realization of Buddha or Enlightenment. Daido Roshi, about that, says many people have interpreted this to mean that there should be no Buddhist study in Zen. But the principle of no dependence on words and letters should not be taken to mean abandoning the use of language, but rather to mean mastering its use. To not be a victim of it, to use it for what it is, to not try and use it for what it is not, to understand its realms of capacity, of influence, ability, power, we might say, and to recognize the limits of language. 

That’s why we’re sitting in a Dharma hall and not a classroom. The presently forming public case is just based on the immediate present. So the koan is translated as a public case. It is public in the sense that it’s open to all, it holds no secrets, and yet it is not immediately revealed because it’s speaking, you might say, to a part of our consciousness, a part of our mind, to the part of yourself which already knows, which is clear, without conflict, outside of scriptures—no reliance. Learning how to master the use of language rather than being a victim of it.

So when the pointer says, if we forcibly set up divisions and foolishly expend effort, it’s drawing eyebrows for chaos. So there’s chaos and somebody is drawing eyebrows, right? In the midst of chaos, to find one’s ground, what’s real. Daido Roshi used to say, if everybody around you is running and screaming, maybe there’s something you don’t know. That’s pointing to the other side. Sometimes if we impose a sense of calm, you know, we may not be noticing what’s happening around us.

Buddhism has much to say, certainly in the Zen tradition, pointing words, warning words, in a sense, cautionary words, around the use of language. Why? We can become so familiar with those teachings in Zen because we encounter them all the time and we see our own distracted thoughts. We might just sort of accept all of that on face value. So we can think of the realm of words and ideas, concepts, just in terms of basic distraction. When our mind is distracted, it’s distracted. Within language, we’re thinking.

But at a deeper level, there are concepts, beliefs, views. That’s why attachments are so hard to let go of. It’s not just an exercise of relaxing a muscle that is grasping. There is that kind of aspect of it. But what makes them so tenacious is the view underneath, the belief in them, the identity in them.

Bill Waldron, in his book on the Yogacara school, looked at this from the point of view of the early Yogacara teachings. He’s talking about Asanga, who is the originator of the Yogacara school, which is one of the principal schools of Mahayana Buddhism, bent Buddhist tradition, Zen tradition. This is around 4th century AD, very early. Asanga talked about the unconscious influence of language on our cognitive process—how we think, what we think, how we understand—and then explains that is owing to the special powers, this is Asanga’s words, of the predisposition or imprints of speech, that conscious awareness arises in regard to expressions of the self, of things, of our actions, that language has a special power, and within it there is a predisposition, right? An imprint that the speech is both arising from and is strengthening.

So it’s something that we are both creating and something that is, in a sense, turning back and reinforcing something within ourselves. He said cognitive awareness takes on the form of humans and gods, eyes and visible forms, comings and goings, due to the imprints of conventional expressions. In this way, he said, imprints from everyday speech, everyday language that we use every day, that imprint—that is, imprinting is influence, is changing. Our mind divides the world up into discrete objects and categories, subtly conditioning our conscious experience.

So think of just the noun, the use of the part of speech that is a noun. So something is a cup, a piece of paper, a person, right? It takes on the quality of being a thing, something that exists in and of itself, by itself. And so it’s a reification, a solidification, a kind of isolation of something unto itself. That noun conveys no sense of connection or interdependence, of mutual dependency. It just is. When we name it, then we know it, we identify it, and then we take those nouns and we put them into categories.

He said, the shape of the perceptions we experience, the categories of the things we see and touch, are subtly influenced by the expressions and figures of speech to which we habituate. So how we say things—the turning of a phrase, right? Think about phrases that are repeated over and over and over and over, right? This is just something that we do in our ordinary life. It’s also something that politicians have discovered: if they just keep saying the same thing over and over, it gets to the point where it doesn’t matter to some whether it’s true or not—it becomes true. It’s both coming from an imprinted mind, and its very purpose is to imprint the mind, to influence.

But then he goes on to say, languages, of course, are not private. They’re social and intersubjective. Their categories are shared among their respective speakers. So we think of language that brings us together. We can think of language that separates us and divides.

The Buddha was very clear about this—talked about divisive language, harsh language, numbing language. He called it idle speech, false language, just language, speech that’s not true. But language can also bring us together in hatred, right? In fear, in blame. It can also bring us together in kindness and compassion, in taking responsibility.

So as Daido Roshi said, it’s not a matter of not using it—it’s not misusing it, it’s mastering it, knowing what it is and using it well. And so then he goes on to say that Asanga talks about how this deepest level of our consciousness, the alaya, for those of you who understand, that includes both shared and individual aspects, and that this transition from individual to shared forms of unconscious cognitive processes is intriguing, but he says, be careful then we don’t think of that shared aspect as a kind of collective, right? Sometimes people say, is there like a collective mind, a collective consciousness? Buddhism does not teach that because the Buddha did not find that. Where is that? So a shared understanding or a shared language is shared, but it’s not a collective, as though it exists somewhere, as though it’s an entity.
