And then he went on to say that this basic process of what he called a linguistification of human experience underlies the complex interrelationships among sensory forms of awareness, mental awareness of non-sensory objects such as thoughts or ideas, and the ensnaring web of conceptual proliferation. So just think about how when you think about something—maybe you read something in the news, or you’re just sitting here minding your own business on the cushion, and something arises and your mind recognizes it, grabs onto it and then proliferates, right? It starts having babies. Quickly it proliferates and that becomes, becomes. It’s coming from an imprint, it’s coming from our karmic mind, it’s coming from our view, it’s coming from the habits we’ve established. We’re not choosing the specific thoughts that we’re proliferating. They just seem to happen. And that is what can lend them a sense of, well, they must be true. That must be my intuition, or it must be the fact, or it must be what’s real. We don’t necessarily see that it’s just habitual—the ensnaring web of conceptual proliferation entangling us in webs upon webs of our own devising.

And that’s what we need to see, that our mind is actively involved, and that the habit nature of that is that it can do that seemingly without our participation, our willful participation. But that happens because the willfulness has already happened way early, where it was conscious, where we were making choices, where we were deciding about certain things.

And then he says, the most consequential of these recursive and self-referential processes has to be our ingrained sense of self, the conceit that I am, I am this, I am that. And of course, here he’s bringing forth the Buddha’s words. And so he says, in short, our sense of self-identity, which is so karmically potent, it is the seed of every form of suffering we see in the world. There can be no suffering without a self. There can be no creation of suffering in any form without a self, so to say. That it’s karmically potent is way understating matters. He says this is not just some simple referent of language. It is a byproduct of the recursivity entailed by language.

So, you know, he’s a scholar, so he’s speaking, you know, in kind of scholarly language, but trying to make it accessible to us and explaining, how does our mind work? Why are thoughts so proliferating? Why do we get so caught? Why are they so seductive—even when we may know that they’re false, still they grab us? Why are they so difficult to let go of even when we want to? And so Buddhism has been studying this for a long, long time. Why? To liberate ourselves. So, to liberate the self.

What Bill is basically saying is we can’t separate that from our language. It’s not just a matter of getting to a place where there’s no thought. The imprint is still there. The underlying views are still there. And that’s just a moment of calm or reprieve, right? Until the mind begins to move again, and then we’re caught again in that view.

And so this sutra, some scholars think that it originated in India—a Mahayana Sutra, clearly Mahayana Sutra. It was translated to Chinese. Other scholars think it might have originated in China around the 700s. It’s early, particularly influential in Asian Buddhism, in the Zen tradition, Chan tradition. And so in that it says: At all times, do not produce delusive thoughts. Okay, we get that. See the thought and let it go. And then it also goes on to say: Don’t try to stop and annihilate deluded states of mind. Hang on. What? In realms of false conception, don’t add knowledge, don’t add more, and don’t find reality in no knowledge. Don’t think that if I just free myself of any thought, of any view, that I am now liberated.

So then what are we to do? The Buddha was very clear about the caution around concepts. Anālayo Bhikkhu talks about this—when I have too many papers, you know, we’re in trouble. He says, in talking about the Satipatthana and talking about mindfulness, he says, concepts are intrinsically related to cognition. That’s very easy enough to understand, since the ability to recognize and understand relies on a subtle level of mental verbalization and thereby on the use of concepts in order to understand something. Right? That’s what the Skandhas are doing. They’re perceiving something, and then they’re placing it within a kind of order. Right? What is it? What kind of thing is it? What is it like? What does it do? Is it helpful? Is it hurtful? Is it good? Is it bad? Do I want it? Do I not want it? And that’s all, of course, involving language.

He said, according to the Buddhist survey of wrong views—views that are not skillful, not true—misinterpretations of reality can often be based on meditative experience, not just theoretical speculation. So he’s saying that if we just rely on meditation, right? I’m not interested in studying about the Dharma, I want to realize it, that our meditative experience itself can lead us in the wrong direction. Of course, we can also go in the wrong direction by just relying on ideas and concepts about Buddhism without meditating. They work together. Meditation grounds our study in actual experience, lived experience.

You read something, it may intrigue you, you may have faith in it, but is it true? Is it true? How do you know? Well, the Buddha said it was true. So if I say, well, that’s good enough for me—it may be good enough for me, but it’s not good enough for Buddhadharma. It’s not good enough if I want to liberate myself because it’s not my experience. And so the Buddha said, bring it into your experience. He actually said this. Listen to the teaching. Bring it into your experience. Find out. Verify.

So he says, to prevent such misinterpretations, a firm acquaintance with the teachings is an important factor for proper progress along the meditative path. For the Buddha, the mere absence of concepts does not constitute the final goal of meditation practice. If that was true, this talk could not be happening. We cannot receive the teachings. Concepts are not the problem, he says. The problem is how they are used. That’s what Daido Roshi was saying. A realized being still employs concepts, but without being bound by them. They use them knowingly, without being confused.

And he goes on to talk about how a purely theoretical approach to result in awakening, the Buddha said, is not possible because, again, it’s just living basically within our conceptual mind. It’s not in our actual embodied experience.

So think about, you know, in the Buddha’s time, where the only teachings that could happen, that could be found, were spoken—nothing was being written down. So you had to actually sit in the presence of the Buddha and listen, or you had to sit in the presence of one of his teachers, his disciples, and listen. Or you could have a conversation with another practitioner about the Dharma, but that was the only way it would happen. And then think about what we have now, right? Talk about proliferation. And of course, there are many good aspects to that, and there are other aspects that aren’t actually very helpful.

And so, to be a practitioner means to be discerning, right? Just like with anything, don’t just assume that everything that’s on the internet is true or reliable. What is true speech? The Buddha spoke in the Eightfold Path of right speech. It’s speech that is in accord with what is true, accord with Dharma, in a sense. It’s reliable speech. You can rely on it. You can trust it. But that’s based on what is true, what is being true. True to what? It always comes back to you. It comes back to the person, to the mind, the unfettered mind, the unconditioned mind, the unbiased mind, the mind that is brought forth and strengthened and clarified and cultivated, that is always there in completeness, but is clouded, veiled, shrouded.

And so Dharma practice helps us to not only disperse the clouds, but in that dispersal, we begin to make contact with a felt sense of something that is true.

So oftentimes, when we come together to practice, we hear the teachings, we practice together. We’re having a—I mean, just this morning, it’s like a banquet, a Dharma banquet of sounds and sights and smells and touches, right? That’s all happening together and is happening on your own seat in a way that only you can know.

I remember before I lived here, I was living about an hour away, and I was coming almost every Sunday, and I would leave and I would go home and just feel so filled, invigorated and inspired and just full. And I would think, how did that happen? You know, we did a service, we sat, I was trying to add up the parts, you know, this plus this, plus this. It didn’t add up. And I realized there’s something going on that is not the sum of the parts. It’s more than that. And that’s why practicing together, since the time of the Buddha, has always been so important. There is something that happens, something that touches us, that we are touching, that we feel.

And I spoke about this recently—that subtle sense of your own inner life, your own spiritual life, whatever you want to call it, whatever names you give to it, that aliveness, that desire for aliveness, that sense of what is true, that yearning for what is true—it’s so real. In moments, it seems tangible, and yet it can easily seem to go away, to become dim, to become distant, particularly when we become sort of caught up in our proliferating mind. And so I think of the Dharma as a spring that you have to keep going to drink from—just keep drinking from it, drinking from it.

The enlightenment scripture, the passage in which this comes from in the Perfect Enlightenment Scripture, says the Buddha is speaking to the Sangha, says, “O virtuous ones, all hindrances are themselves the nature of ultimate enlightenment.” Everything that we think is obstructing us, everything that we think is in the way—words and ideas, concepts, language—are ultimately our enlightened nature, are ultimately in and of themselves complete, are ultimately in and of themselves peaceful.

And so, in a very real sense, your distraction, your distractedness, if you practice it well, helps you build your mindfulness, strengthen your mindfulness. Your attachments, when you practice them, help you strengthen and cultivate and live more within non-attachment. Your lethargy, if you engage it—your dullness, your sleepiness—it’s a tough teacher, right? It’s a tough one, right? But it can teach you a tremendous amount about the energy, the natural flow of energy, the ki, the natural and always available alertness that exists within each of us. Your agitation can help you to discover a profound sense of relaxation. Your doubt can help you to discover the true nature of faith. Your expectations can help you to understand the difference between an expectation, which is very unhelpful and causes a lot of problems, but it can help us to understand that there’s that and aspiration—big difference. How anger, our anger, can help us to really understand the nature of compassion.

It’s not theoretical, right? We don’t practice in a test tube, right? These concepts are just concepts until they’re alive within us. Now, anger is not a word. I’ve talked about how I would sit there and my teacher would talk about, you know, going into the dragon’s cave, wrestling with the dragon—you know, stuff’s going to come up. He called it the bilge—you know, the stuff that’s… It’s like, you know, when your toilet backs up, you know, it’s like, ugh. And he says, but that’s how you become free—is by engaging it, understanding it, turning towards it. And I would think, yes, that’s what I am here for, that’s what I want. And when it was happening, that was not what I wanted. It was not what I came here for. It’s like I wanted what he was talking about, not this. And I actually thought that. I never thought, okay, this is what he was talking about. I didn’t think that. It took a while.

But if these obstructions can help us, then why aren’t we all being helped all the time? Because we have to learn how to practice them. There were lots of moments where I’d be in the middle of something and I would want to practice it. And I would think, I don’t know what that means. I don’t know what it means to practice this. And almost always when I reflect back, I was looking for something that was complicated. There was somewhere else I was looking for some sort of advanced, sophisticated teaching that I hadn’t received yet. I was just missing the simple reality of the moment—what is my mind? What is this? Do I even see it? What am I creating in my mind about this?

Master Dogen said, in a classical on reading a sutra, he said, “The practice and realization of unsurpassable complete enlightenment is brought forth sometimes by a teacher, sometimes by a teacher. A sutra, a teacher is a Buddha ancestor of the entire self. A sutra is a sutra of the entire self. We say this because you yourself are the self of all Buddha ancestors and the self of all sutras.”

So not only can we have insight by working with a teacher, but by entering into a sutra, teaching that the sutra is a sutra of the entire self. What does that—what is he pointing at?

When we do liturgy, when you’re chanting a sutra, to chant it with the whole body and mind—it’s language, those words have meaning. So part of it is understanding: What do these words mean? So that when you’re chanting it, the full experience of that sutra, that teaching, the words, the meaning, Buddhist meaning, the sound, your voice merging with the Sangha, all of that is present within you in a deep state of awareness, of alertness. And in that, something happens where you’re not just chanting words, where it’s not the Buddha’s words, it’s not you chanting something—the sutra becomes the entire self.

In the Prajna Paramita Sutra, there’s a section where Subhuti, who is a disciple of the Buddha, said that he was born after the image of the Buddha, right? What does that mean? And he goes on to say, “The Buddha’s suchness is Subhuti’s suchness. The Buddha’s enlightenment is my enlightenment. The Buddha’s mind is my mind.” Now step into Subhuti’s place: You are born in the image of the Buddha. The Buddha’s mind is your mind. The Buddha’s realization is your realization.

Dogen goes on to say, “Although it is called the self, it is not bound by you or I. Thus, there is a remembering, a chanting, a copying, a receiving and maintaining of a sutra. All of these are the practice realization of Buddha ancestors.” So he’s talking about traditional ways of studying sutras: chanting, remembering, memorizing, copying, receiving, maintaining—ultimately to be the sutra itself. That’s the essence of liturgy. To enter into it so wholly, so completely, that there’s a moment where those words are no longer the words of the Buddha—they’re your words, they’re expressing your experience.

Dogen said, “These mountains and rivers of the present are the actualization of the word, the sutra of all, of the ancient Buddhas, each abiding in its own dharma state.” Isn’t he saying the same thing? The mountain itself, Dogen is saying, is a sutra. It’s teaching. It’s teaching the dharma. It’s manifesting the dharma. How is that? To meet that dharma teaching, you have to enter into the mountain. You have to meet the mountain as the mountain. The mountain has to meet you as yourself.

Well, how can you do that if you’re here and the mountain is over there? If you are the self, if it is about you and I, if I am bound to that, I can look at the mountain. I could climb it, I could write a poem about it, but I can’t meet it. I can’t meet it in intimacy. I can’t meet myself. I can’t meet you.

Once, Master Yunju saw a student reading a sutra in her room, and he poked his head through the window and said, “What sutra is that that you’re reading?” And she said, “It’s the Vimalakirti Sutra.” And Yunju said, “I’m not asking you about the Vimalakirti Sutra. I’m asking, what sutra are you reading?” And at that, she gained insight. I’m not asking you about a book, about words on a page. I’m asking you, what is that sutra?

Everything in Dharma is coming down to this. To even say it’s personal is okay in the beginning, but it’s too limited. It too easily becomes just another form of being bound by you and I.

Master Yunmen said, “All the world is medicine. Where do you find yourself?” That’s such an important teaching in Buddhism. And, you know, it’s not just Buddhism. You know, just take whatever’s happening and, you know, find the good in it. Turn it into something positive. That’s good advice. But this is not that. You are already the sutra. You and the mountain are already indivisible. Your basic nature is the same. The nature between you and that person who really irritates you—same nature, same essence.

You know, when I read about how human beings—and I don’t know, lobsters or worms or, you know, some other creature, you know—have 97% of the same DNA, it’s like, what? How can that be? It’s kind of like that, except it’s 100%. The essence is 100% the same. Right? That’s what we call Buddha nature. That’s what we call our basic nature of emptiness. And the beauty of that is that it manifests in 100,000 million billion forms, which is the abundance of life.

But we just get confused and caught up and greedy and angry. There’s something that is not right within ourselves, and we don’t know what to do with it. We don’t know what to do with it. And so the easiest thing seems to be externalizing. Turn it out. Not me. It must be you. I was going to say it’s very childlike, but I want to—I don’t want to sell children short here. It’s unexamined. It’s unexamined.

And it, when it gains energy, when you give it power, it becomes dangerous. And I don’t mean metaphorically—literally. And the danger goes in all directions.

I’ve always thought it’s interesting that the more we grasp and cling to the self—because I don’t know what to do with what I’m experiencing here—and in my grasping, in my rejection, in my avoidance, in my lack of examination and in my externalizing of that, acting out of that, not only do I cause you infinite harm, but I’m killing myself and I don’t know it. And that’s the pickle of delusion, right? Is we can just keep accommodating and viewing and actually experiencing that destruction, self-destruction, as something that is good or positive or necessary.

Dogen said, “When intimate language encounters an intimate person, the Buddha eye sees the unseen. Intimate action is not known by the self, but the intimate self alone knows it.” And so, again, coming back to Buddhist study, you may be wondering, what is the connection here? Because we think of Buddhist study as study. It is studying the sutras, studying the teachings of ancient masters, past and present. It’s listening, hearing the Dharma, and then reflecting on it and then bringing it into our practice.

So it has many of the elements of study, of having learned how to study. What does this word mean? How to study in a contemplative way, in a way that is not just gaining knowledge, but is constantly being referenced back. I mean, even when I’m reading a scholarly work that is more historical or more about, you know, it’s not talking about meditation per se, you know, I find that important and valuable just for understanding how did we get here? But also, I’m always looking at it in terms of how does that relate to practice, how did that feed into the development of Buddhist teachings and practices and traditions over the centuries that have come down to here. I’m always interested in how can that be helpful, not just as another piece of knowledge, but in terms of lives, my life.

And of course, study sometimes gets a little too top-heavy, you know, so sometimes a person relies so much on study that they are intellectualizing their meditation practice. You know, they can’t let go of the concepts. And so students sometimes will come in and say, you know, I think I need to, like, have…take a fast, do a fast on study for a while, you know, or cut back a little bit. It’s like, okay, fine, you’re seeing something good. Respond to that, you know, maybe that will help you for now. You know, other people come in and say, I’m not—I don’t study. It’s difficult, it’s confusing. It’s because it’s talking about something complicated, like you. Right? We shouldn’t expect it to be just immediately accessible. It’s not like a Big Mac, you know, you have to chew on it, you have to work on it. I mean, for goodness sake, we’re willing to do that with our zazen. You know, if you expect this to be easy and you can’t let go of that, you’re not going to, that’s not going to happen. We’re willing to do that with zazen. It’s the same in a way. It’s more difficult because it is dealing with concepts—difficult concepts because the consciousness is deep. It’s profound. I mean, just language—just language. And so we should be patient and keep coming back, work at it, let it develop, see the connection, let it nourish your practice. Know the difference between intellectual, conceptual understanding and direct understanding. Know the difference. That’s part of our work.

Magnificent, clearly outstanding, serene, at ease. Clamor—he’s describing you, what this koan is pointing to. Not holding on to thoughts, not rejecting thoughts, not dwelling in conceptual ideas and thinking that that’s all there is, not abandoning concepts and ideas. What is the middle way, this most profound enlightenment of the Buddha? A middle way. It’s not balance. Balance is good, but that’s not what he’s talking about. Not dwelling in any extreme.

Clamor pierces the head. Quiet is where to tread. Underfoot, the thread breaks and I am free—cutting that thread that tethers us, binds us. The spot of mud on the nose is gone. You don’t have to chop—this points to… There were two people in the woods cutting, doing, cutting down trees for lumber. And one of them had a spot on his nose. And it was, here, I’ll take that off. And he swung the axe, took it right off. He says, no, you don’t have to do that. That mud, it’s not a problem. It’s not what you think. On a thousand-year-old scrap of paper, on a thousand-year-old scrap of paper, medicine is compounded. He’s talking about the sutra.

I’ll finish up with a few words from the Perfection of Wisdom Sutra. It’s a large text. When I handed this to Roxanne this morning, I said, it’s heavy Dharma this morning. He goes, it’s always heavy.

This is Subhuti speaking to the Buddha:

He says, “Deep, O Lord, is this perfection of wisdom. She is not to be developed by anyone, nor should anything be developed, nor should one develop anywhere. Why? Because in this deep perfection of wisdom, one does not get at the full reality of the Dharma. You can’t get to it. It’s not a place you cannot get to, which would develop or which would you develop or through which you would develop. Rather, a development of space is this development of the perfection of wisdom.”

How do you develop space? You can’t touch it, you can’t grasp it. It’s like that.

He says, “A development of the Dharma is a development of what is not, a development of not taking hold, a development which is really an undevelopment. That is this development of the perfection of wisdom.”

It’s actually a very good description of zazen. Ultimately, with all of the effort that you bring, you are bringing yourself to a state of not developing, not creating, not proliferating, not doing. If enlightenment could be something that you could create, you could find, you could get to, we’d all be there. We’re good at that. That’s why we have to employ extraordinary measures, which are also very, very ordinary. It’s just your mind. It’s your natural mind.

When the Buddha was dying, his last words were, “Take heed, be heedful, apply yourself.” And so, those of you who have joined us for the weekend, I really hope that this was helpful to you in some way, to bring some energy into your seeking, into your practice. If you have a practice, if you want to develop a practice, I hope you have some sense of how to do that. You know how to get here now. We have a seat for you whenever you want to come. But whatever it is that brought you here, that fire, that ember, take care of that. 

From “thus have I heard” to “be ever heedful,” the sutras have always been intimate words for the intimate person to see the unseen. May we bring that to fruit in our own lives. The world is counting on this.

Thank you for listening.

To find out more about ZMM’s programs, retreats, and residency, please visit us online at zmm.org.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Title: Eight Gates Of Zen: Part 3
Extracted Text:
Good evening, everybody.

So let's just start by sitting for a moment and kind of centering in, getting in touch with why we're here. And I'd like to just offer a little bit around that, so as you settle yourself—and those of you at home also—to just recognize this really precious opportunity to be together as Sangha, to have encountered the Dharma and have conditions in which we can practice and realize the Dharma, and to feel into our own aspiration in a personal and real way, to know for ourselves our true connection, our true connection to each other, to this earth, to this cosmos, to all the creatures and beings. 

An aspiration to not only know for ourselves this true connection, but that everyone—that everyone—might know this true connection, and an aspiration to live in accord and out of this recognition, and that everyone might live in accord with this recognition. One great body, releasing our clinging and grasping, moving beyond our self-centered inclinations, expanding beyond our own suffering and touching the true abundance of reality. So let's take up this time together tonight in that spirit. Thank you.

So this mondo is on the teacher-student relationship. And before I get into it, actually, let me just mention for those who may not be aware: there's a program that SHAC is offering on Saturday morning that I think is such a valuable offering. It's an online program, so those of us here at the monastery won't be participating unless—maybe unless you decide to ask if you can participate. But it's called Engaged Response Part One, Holding the Fire. And so it's really coming out of: How do we use our practice at this particular time to meet the moment in the burning world? And they've put a lot of thought and effort into thinking about how to frame an experience that would be meaningful for folks and supportive and helpful. And it is. It'll start with some words from Shugen Roshi, who will kind of lay a nice dharma foundation. And then people will have a chance to speak together in breakout groups. There's some pre-work, so if you're going to go, you need to do a little homework. So check out the website. I think Kian's going to put the link in the chat, and I hope that if it's something that you're needing right now, you'll be able to join them for that.

Okay, so the teacher-student relationship. Our theme this ango: on the eight gates and training in the eight gates, this is the gate we're going to take up tonight. I was talking with someone earlier this week, and they sort of wondered aloud if maybe I had been assigned this topic. And I chose—I chose it. I chose this topic. I thought it would be helpful for me, and hopefully helpful for you too.

Just to state what I think is obvious to most, if not everyone: I have a lot more experience as a student, and I'm just beginning to have some sense of what it means to teach. And not being in the role of a transmitted teacher yet in that way or having students, I'm really going to be leaning on my experience as a student. And it turns out as I do begin to do a little bit of teaching, that that is totally the experience that I am always drawing upon.

So I was thinking about how this gate is like, I think, maybe the edgiest gate. And I was thinking about practicing the edge. When I think about that phrase, which is a phrase that Daido Roshi used to invoke a lot—practice your edge—it's like, oh, what is that edge? And I was imagining walking along a cliff edge at sunset, and it's craggy, and there's waves breaking beneath, and there's gorgeous, gorgeous land all around. And how it's so powerful and so beautiful and so full of possibility, and then also not without its peril.

So I wanted to start—I thought we should go to the heart of the matter. And I wanted to do just a very brief five-minute, two-and-a-half-minutes-each, pair share. The question that I would like to ask you, at least to get started with—you won't plumb the depths of it—typically when we think about showing up in front of a teacher, we know what we're there to learn. If I'm going to a French cooking class, I know I'm there to learn French cooking. If I'm going to a foreign language class, I know I'm there to learn Spanish or Japanese or whatever it may be.

When you show up in front of a Dharma teacher, what is it that you are there to learn in your own words? No wrong answers. Please, amongst yourselves, find a partner, and just briefly, how would you say it? Try not to rely on Buddhist jargon, but just authenticity, authentic and fresh. What are you there to learn? And folks at home, we're going to put you very briefly also in a pair with someone, so stay tuned.

So I would love to hear what it is you think you're going to learn. Or, said another way—yeah, why? Why study with a teacher? And folks at home, if you would like to put a few words or a phrase into chat from your pair share, it would be nice to have some of those in circulation too for the folks who are on Zoom. But here in the room, what came up for people?

Thank you, Blue. It's a wonderful quality. There you go. Oh, geez. Thank you.

So I guess I question the question, like, what are you going to learn? Since SJ and I were thinking, when we meet a teacher, we aren't learning, okay. But I, like, you're like this—some lengths to, like, work with a teacher. So if it doesn't fall into the framework of learn for you, like what? Like why? You're right. It is about relationship. It's a going—I didn't talk to SJ about this, but it seems to be it's about going deeper than psychology and therapy and just talk.

It is, yeah. Like SJ was saying, it's sort of a mirror—encountering a mirror of who you are at that moment.

Okay. Okay. Going deeper. Good. A mirror of who you are. All right. All right. What else we got? Shoka.

Hello. Hello. We didn't actually talk about this, but when you posed the question that you just posed, I was immediately—came to mind—Hogan's encounter. And this idea of deceiving yourself. And so a big part of why I work with a teacher is to understand how I might be deceiving myself, how not to deceive myself, how not to deceive others.

Okay. And why is that important? And in what way do you mean deceive?

It's something about honesty and something about reality. Interpreting reality in a genuine way, not seeing what a person wants to see, what I want to see. I don't know. Not making up stories. Huh? Like seeing reality as it is.

Yeah. Yes. That's a better way to say that.

So when I approached the idea of having a teacher, I was already interested in the Dharma and living my life according to the Dharma. But it felt like a very big, complicated endeavor. And so I wanted a teacher to show me that I was on the path and that I'm living a life according to the Dharma.

So I wanted to start this way because how we show up in front of the teacher, I mean, is, like, going to affect what we're able to receive. And I think what we heard in the folks who were willing to share is that the thing that we're looking for, the learning that we want, is not an ordinary kind of learning, right? It's not information, it's not knowledge-based. It's not really even skill-based. I mean, people didn't go to that so much actually, in terms of like how to meditate or something like this. But that depth, that mirroring of our being, the true part of our nature, that vast, boundless heart—what we're talking about, in a sense, is learning how to transform consciousness, our consciousness.

And when we talk about the role of the teacher in Buddhist tradition and the role of the student, we talk about this transmission—mind to mind transmission. Daido Roshi would always say, "Nothing goes from A to B." And so again, the scenario is that we actually—we already have the Buddha mind. And so we're not getting and we're not learning and we're not taking something from outside and putting it here. And yet something does need to shift. There is some kind of learning, but what is it? What's its nature? How does it work?

And also helpful, I think, to recognize this because on the road, right, in a relationship, we're going to bring so much of our karmic relational baggage into the picture. And so if we can be clear, like, okay, why am I in this relationship? Or why am I exploring this relationship and see that clearly, then when we get blindsided by all the other stuff that's going to come up along the way—such as wanting approval, seeking love, seeking someone to make our problems better, actually looking for therapy, healing our karma, or just plain old advice on how to live, what should I do? So we may have moments of that. There's nothing wrong with that. That's part of a natural Dharma path. But to be clear for ourselves, like, that's not the heart of the matter. And our teacher, our Zen teacher, may actually not be the best person to fulfill that need or that want for us in our life.

Transformation of consciousness. If we're talking about the deluded consciousness, right, where we have this mistaken sense of ourself, where we believe our thoughts for reality, we look through our views and we think that we're just seeing the world. We don't recognize our view for our view. Our judgments and opinions appear to us to just be reflections of what is. So it's extremely difficult to see through this delusion on our own, and yet we're extremely attached to it. And if we're inviting someone into our life and actually seeking out and asking them, help me disrupt this delusion, then we should be prepared for it to be uncomfortable.

And so this is why I'm saying the teacher-student relationship is so edgy, because we're coming at it from, like, you know, a full heart, like really, you know, for the most part, I think, pure, good intention. And then we're going to end up meeting disruption, the upending of our sense of self to some degree, the chipping away of things that we've put in place to protect us.

And so how does this actually unfold? You know, this piece about just recognizing conceptual mind, I feel like that has been such a—in my relationship with Shugen Roshi—that having him, like, again and again and again over years be like, "That's an idea, that's a concept, that's an idea, that's a concept." And, and, like, how much it takes to really start to see the depth, at least for me, to see the depth of that conditioned karmic mind for what it is.

So as we go a little bit further, I wanted to kind of think in terms of two aspects to several different pieces of the student-teacher relationship. So I wanted to talk a little bit about upaya. What's the skillful means? If this is the project—I mean, that's such a horrible way of putting it—if this is the aspiration, if this is what we're endeavoring, is this kind of awakening of our Buddha mind, our unconditioned natural mind, then how?

So within a tradition, that's one of the beautiful things about being in a lineage and in a tradition: there's upaya, there's skillful means, there's ways of working that have been handed down. So I wanted to talk about that a little bit. I wanted to talk about within that the role of the teacher and the student. Why is that a thing? To talk a little bit about Dokusan and face-to-face teaching and training in that way, and to talk about commitment and the importance of commitment and a relationship that takes place over time.

And with each of these things, what I want us to do is to look at: How is it upaya? How is it skillful means? And what's the shadow side of that? What's the edgy piece? Where's the peril?

Okay, so this will be made much richer and much more beneficial to all of us gathered if you are willing to participate and make yourself vulnerable in terms of being authentic. That's what I mean by vulnerable: in terms of just being real. Because we've all studied, whether we're formal students, and some of us have been training as students for many years, or whether we're here at this monastery for a period of time and in that way have shown up as a student or are exploring that process, we can all speak from our own experience. So everyone knows or can know our own experience. And in that way, we have something to offer.

Okay, so before I go on, I want to shift in a moment and talk about the role of the teacher and the role of the student. But just before I go on, any questions at this point? Or, I don't know, anything that's emerging? I shall proceed.

Okay. All right. So in Zen, we do talk about the three trainings, right? The precepts—sila, meditation—samadhi, concentration, and prajna—wisdom. And so the teacher-student relationship is kind of holding all of those, right? As students, we do so much just on our own. We do so much with each other in Sangha. And then there's this other piece that's the teacher—the teacher-student piece.

And so this notion of having a teacher, it goes way back, right? And within Buddhism, it's interesting to note that the Buddha himself—I was speaking with Gokan as I was getting ready for this, and he brought up—I can't exactly remember the question that I asked, but he brought up, there's a sutra where it's after the Buddha's enlightenment, and he's decided, okay, he will teach the Dharma. And he's thought through in his mind, like, who would he teach? And he thinks of his two teachers that really were so important for him. And he learns that each of them has died, a couple of those recent teachers. And so he realizes, like, oh, well, he could teach the group of mendicants that he was training with. And so he goes back to see them, and when they see him and greet him by saying "friend" and using his clan name. And he says, "Do not call me friend and do not use my clan name." And it's kind of this, like, startling moment where it's like, what's up with this guy? And it's also upaya. Something's happening there, right? Something's happening there, as he sort of says, like, wait, no, it's not like that. I'm no longer—I'm no longer best identified by those words. And I'm no longer—if you think of me as your friend, then I'm not fulfilling the role that I came here to fulfill. I mean, that's my sort of attempt to interpret that response.

So we have that. And then within Zen, there's also this way that, like, the Zen teacher—like, we really appreciate and recognize the Zen teacher as, like, an ordinary person. And there's a lot of the way that the forms of Zen reinforce that, right? Shugen Roshi has meals with us, and Hojun Sensei and Hogan Sensei too. They eat with the Sangha. They sit in the zendo with the Sangha. They're there at the caretaking meeting. And they get an assignment too, from the work supervisor. So on the one hand, it's like, okay, well, they're ordinary beings. I don't think that we're confused about thinking that there's something other than a human being. And if we are confused about that, if we're paying attention, sooner or later we're going to see like, oh, they're just people.

And at the same time, well, when they sit in the zendo with us, they sit at the front of the zendo. Right. They definitely have special seats. When they get a work assignment, it's not exactly cleaning the bathrooms, right? Abbot's duties or teachers' duties. And, and, and you know, when they're eating with us, we are pretty informal about that. But, like, you know, the gisha comes and takes their dishes away, and maybe if you're talking to them, they'll take your dishes too. So it's, it's pretty low-key, but there's a—there's a gesture there. There's a gesture.

And so there is this aspect of we're empowering the teacher. They get a little something special. So how is that upaya and how is that edgy? I want to hear from you.

Thanks, Visay. Well, I suppose if you were a teacher and you also had to occupy the role of friend, you might be reluctant to say something that your student friend wouldn't want to hear. Might be actually harder. I think it would definitely be harder to offer what was needed if you were—yeah—close in that way.

So that's the totally—the skill, the edge is that sometimes, for me anyway, it has been that when Shugen Roshi is playing the long game with me, as it were, and being skillful, it can feel not great. And it took—I mean, just speaking from current circumstances, it took me maybe years actually to see that some of the things that felt really crappy at the time were like, oh, now, now it's actually—I see. But, but at the time it was like, yeah, like being on the edge of a, you know, a can that had been opened badly, like a, you know, rough and sharp and not fun.

Yeah, yeah. And so that—that in order to stay in there, right, during this period of time where it's rough and sharp and not fun, like what—what have you needed to bring forward as a student?

Trust, perseverance, capacity to be uncomfortable, yeah, and a little bit of wisdom to know when it's like, when I need to seek help elsewhere, which is also thankfully possible.

Yeah, yeah, yeah. It's so rich, right? Along the journey of, like, working with the teacher to transform our mind, to wake up, we're gonna move through—it's not like the transformation is like—it's not like this, just see it this way. It's like you're going through all of that, right? Like that having to trust yourself and trust the teacher and persevere in the long haul—that is your consciousness transforming.

Meiju, so the edge for me, one of the edges has, I think, always been, like, this question of, is it actually upaya? I remember with Daido, a lot, like, he would express his anger or irritation, and Jeffrey and I would, like—it was like an ongoing debate. It was like, he'd be like, that was skillful means. And I'd be like, no, he lost his temper. And I think I've also had experiences where I felt some of the things and ways that I have learned the most, like, from Shugen, I'm not sure actually where skillful means—I feel like my, you know, like, I worked with them. So that's one part of the edge.

And I think the other part of the edge is just for me and my personality and my karma and my relational karma is just that piece of trust. And knowing that actually there is a lot of skillfulness. And sometimes I can see in the moment that that's what's happening. Sometimes, like Fuyu was saying, I can see later. But yeah, that piece of trusting myself too, and sometimes not being sure which is which. Yeah. But knowing that I can learn something anyway, I feel like that is so, like, what makes that possible—the sort of, like, is it upaya? Is it not? Did someone just, like, you know, do that intentionally? Or are they just acting, you know, in a way that's unskillful and then but you somehow using it—what makes that possible?

I mean, I think that that is, you know, kind of goes back to your first question of, like, why am I here? What do I want? What's most important to me, like, who do I—it—like, I want to be somebody who makes use of whatever this is.

It's so real. It's so real. It's like those moments that feel like, wait, this is not supposed to happen. Like, this is—like, this is not how it's supposed to go. It's like knowing why you're there and using that is so potent. Again, like, that's the transformation. Thank you. Yeah.

Kyosha, right behind you.

I feel like one of the vulnerabilities is this kind of, as a student, putting oneself in harm's way with a teacher. Not so much that the teacher's intention is somehow to cause injury, but that one is not in control of what that is going to happen once one gets over what I see as this kind of comradely skepticism, where we don't see the teacher as anything different than ourselves and are kind of skeptical that they even have anything worth bothering about—like, why we should get ourselves into a place of thinking, or are we just groveling and acting out a role and all these things that eventually come to a place of, well, I need something anyway. Does this person—and then can I reach out? And I don't know what I'll find.

And I think what you're pointing to is something I've thought about too, which is like, if we empower them in the role of teacher, then something becomes possible that's not possible if they're just our friend.

Yes.

Right. I mean, I remember being in the kitchen as the cook many moons ago, and Shugen doing caretaking in the kitchen. And he at that time had teaching responsibilities. And I was like, okay, I'm gonna watch how this guy cuts onions, because maybe there's like, you know, maybe there's something I'll see there that will show me what this is, like, he's got it. Okay. He just seems like an ordinary person. Like, let me study. And that—like, what that did for me, you know. And, you know, spoiler alert, he just cut the onions mindfully. Mindfully. I did observe that.

And also, going back to what Fuyu was saying in the beginning, if we empower the teacher, then they can be a model. Then, as Meiju was alluding to, the edge of that is like, what if they're not modeling well? Really important all the way along the student-teacher journey is we are the owners of our own power. There's actually no part of this teacher-student relationship in which we should be giving our power away. We're being introduced to it. We're being guided in how to discover and refine it. But we should feel empowered as a being all the way along.

And sometimes we may not. We're looking for something, we want a certain experience, we're not getting the approval we want, we're not getting the kind of contact we want—whatever it is, it's unsatisfying. But we should study those moments and see, like, are we giving our power away? Are we thinking that someone else is going to make us feel better? Because that's the edgy part.

There's a great article that I wanted to just allude to in this place. And it has to do with—it's an article called "Student and a Zen Perspective." And some of you may have seen it. It's by Nikoli Jikyo Roshi, who is a Dharma heir to Maezumi Roshi, later than Daido Roshi. She received transmission from him in 1995. But this article, and I asked Kian to put the link in the chat for folks at home, it's, I think, really excellent. She's basically trying to illuminate for people, here's some of the common pitfalls. And she uses the language of therapy to talk about transference and countertransference. I think it's a fairly straightforward, fairly brief, condensed piece of writing. And if you're a Zen student, you'll totally relate to it. So I think it's worth looking at.

But she talks about—she names some unrealistic expectations that we might have for a teacher. And I just thought that they were so good, I wanted to share them: wanting to be understood and supported all the time, wanting the teacher to be omniscient. I remember saying this actually in a mondo years ago. I was like, wait, I thought you would know how I felt. No, we have to say. Wanting the teacher to fix you and wanting to be special most of the time. So relatable. So relatable.

So one more shadow piece from when we empower a teacher and put the teacher in the teacher's seat, kind of raise them up in that way, is that they get confused and they think they're more powerful or that they are outside the rules. And we have seen this happen, certainly in the Western Dharma and also in our Sangha, and the harm that that causes. So important to name that, that piece, that edgy piece, too.

All right, so we've put the teacher in the teacher's role. We've sort of empowered them. There they are. And now training, training, face-to-face teaching: this kind of hallmark of the Zen school goes way back—the private meeting with the teacher. Certainly these kinds of teacher-student, one-on-one encounters are so kind of held up in the koan tradition. Dogen writes about it in his writing. And even outside the Zen tradition, meditative traditions often will emphasize this one-on-one relationship and opportunity to meet with the teacher.

So I think, you know, to some degree, I think probably all of us have experienced face-to-face teaching in some form. And some, to some degree, I think it's kind of obvious why this is upaya. We're working with our own conditioning, and so being met just as an individual with whatever's arising for us can be really skillful. And, you know, that's part of why we don't talk about face-to-face teaching, that the general guideline is you don't talk about it outside of face-to-face teaching because it was offered for you, coming from your position with your energetic experience that you brought forward. And when you repeat it to your friend, what gets lost there? What sort of leaks out or could be misunderstood? Or how do we make a story out of a live moment, a live encounter?

And at the same time, important to say that it's not, that it's secret, right? And for sure, one of the lessons from power breaches that I think we're learning more and more is the difference between private and secret, right? It's not secret.

So the tricky part of dokusan or face-to-face teaching is that we have to show up, and we have to show up in a real enough way that we can be met and really worked with. And that can be hard for various reasons. But the teacher has to get to know the student, and, you know, a teacher-student relationship can really develop and deepen over time over all of those opportunities.

So that sense, I think a lot of us probably have worked with, of wanting to like put your best face forward, you know, to show up and sort of, like, be thought well of, be taken seriously, you know, say something intelligent. Like, we kind of got to get through that point until we're willing to really look like an idiot and just be completely with whatever is coming up. But willing—Daido Roshi used to say, "You've got to be willing to show your pimples." What does think of that?

So with dokusan, what's the upaya and what's the edge, what's the shadow? And think of your own, you know, your own experience. I'm saying dokusan, but I mean, you know, face-to-face teaching.

Yeah, Olivia, great.

Or, like, I can kind of try to give my teacher a picture of my mind or my heart. And maybe not—yeah, like, is that—I think I tend to make my own rules, sort of like, it's like, okay, I don't need to make it a question. I can just say what I am. Or like, you know, but is there—yeah. Is it still important, I guess, to practice that question, making it a question or like—yeah, I don't know. I mean, that's one thing. But yeah, I resonate with what Baike was saying.

I appreciate what you're saying. And I don't have a clear, like, stance on that. In some ways, I think if we're open, like, if you're—if we're kind of—if we're coming in and saying what's on our mind and heart and we're doing it in a way that's, like, listening or that's—a question comes up.

Yeah, actually, that does happen. Yeah, it just comes up naturally.

Like, it comes up naturally or, like, we're, you know, saying all of the things around the question and the teacher maybe is listening and can see the question there. So I think that's fine. You know, sometimes I feel like people, particularly in the beginning, get a little fixated on, like, the question, and then it becomes like, you know, "My question is..." and because of the pressure of feeling that you have to ask a question, you're not actually touching the heart of what's live for you. So I would say better to err on the side of being in true contact. And I also think that when we can ask a question that's a pointed, framed question, we get that kind of response, right? Like in all of those koans, the student isn't like, "Oh, I was feeling this kind of weird, queasy feeling." They have a question, right? "Why did Bodhidharma come from the West?" So then we get that kind of response. And that can be very helpful.

I was just thinking, a question comes up after the dokusan, as it ends. And then, yes, next time I'll ask.

Yeah, yeah, like, you know, you're like—I mean, it's just nice when it comes up organically like that.

Yeah. Thank you. Thank you, Kokuan. And then we'll shift. Oh, Miro, please.

I was just gonna say about, like, questions—I get in my own way, maybe whenever I think of a straightforward question, I can, like, Zen my way out of it, you know? And I can think of some Zen response. And I'm just like, I'm not gonna ask that because, you know, if I can kind of dharma combat myself, I don't need Shugen to do that for me.

I love that. I love that. And, like, how many times have you, like, asked the question that you're like, I know what they're gonna say, and it's, like, totally not that.

I usually don't ask.

Yeah, well, you might want to experiment with that.

Yeah.

Yeah, Kokuan.

Yes, you should. One thing I think is helpful, I noticed that a lot of times teacher will throw, like, a change-up. Like, sometimes they're abrupt and that's it, I'm out of here. Other times, more conversational. Other times pushing me. So a lot of times I'm kind of thrown off guard, which I think is helpful. Remember one time, Daido Roshi—I was listening to Myotai Sensei, she was giving a talk and she was talking about the Amazon on fire. And I went in and I gotta do something, you know, and he just kind of, like, turned into—we just had a conversation and, like, I walked out. I was like, how's that—yeah, why are you turning into cover? What was that all about? And it wasn't until later on, I think I understood what he was pointing to, like, what he was trying to say. So a lot of times, when I go into dokusan, I don't know what to expect. Sometimes what they offer is not what I expect, but it makes me think about what were they trying to point to. And a lot of times it'll dawn on me later on, sometimes years later. And so a lot of times these stay with me. I don't really understand at first, and not always, but sometimes they're like, ah, I think I know what he's pointing to. So thank you.

Yeah. That's a really—that sort of shake up—I mean, that's part of what's made possible, right, in that one-on-one conversation is—the teacher is, you know, ideally, is knowing the student, having a sense of how their mind works, like knowing, having a sense of, like, what is—like, who is this Kokuan? Who does he think he is, right? And then how do you, how do you interrupt that?

Taisho.

Yeah. There's a—it's actually a dedication and it—I came across it early and it's always stayed with me. I don't remember her last name—Obai's partner, Kate Larson. Yeah. So in her book Uncaged, she dedicates it to Daido, "who had—to Daido, who had the patience to listen until I had nothing else left to say." Beautiful. Just that sense of when you, when you in it for the long haul, there's this shedding of words. That wasn't it. That was pretentious. That was fake. That was a put on. That's me. And you just keep—it just, you just keep shedding it because you know, ultimately you're trying to point to something that's beyond words, right? And you keep avoiding that, you know, and Shugen's constantly challenging you by saying, "Those are just words, those are just ideas. Show me. Don't tell me. Show me, show me." And sometimes you go in to say, "I got nothing, I got nothing," you know, and that's—and at that point, you're really right on that edge. And sometimes he can just shoo you over.

Yeah, yeah. Thanks, generous.

I want to shift. And just before we close, touch in on—what the heck. It must be like moisturizer. There was some on him earlier. We're in an infestation.

All right. I wanted to touch on commitment. Okay. And I think, again, pretty much everyone here knows either from direct experience or has a sense of that. There's quite a process here. There's a difference between showing up for teachings as we might on a provisional basis, either for retreat or sesshin or even for a long-term residency that's not yet a long, long-term teacher-student commitment. But there is a process here. That's one of the ways that training was established here—of making a commitment to a particular teacher for a lifetime, possibly. Yeah. And so I wanted to make sure that we touch on this. Like, what's the upaya of that? Why? And then also, what's the edge or the shadow there?

So I think that the upaya is that we're all in it always and it doesn't end. So commitment is seeing that, but the edge is we're always changing. So how do I make a commitment to something if I don't know who I'm going to be in the next moment or what the circumstances are going to be? So who or what am I committing to?

Yeah, the upaya is kind of like, in committing, it's like it invites the teacher to push you or to—that even if you feel uncomfortable, you're still committed. So, you know, it's not like there's kind of like a thing, well, if you make me feel too uncomfortable, then I'm gonna go up and leave, you know? Yeah. So it allows for more development. I feel like, in that way, that's really important.

I think that that's kind of the key—the key piece that I feel like I really see is that permission, right? So having gone through a process, having sort of asked in all of these different ways, like, "Will you teach me? Can this person teach me?" You know, Tangaryo, Guardian Council, all of those different gates of entry, there's a sense of like, okay, this person is serious. And so when it becomes a matter of things the teacher may say or do that will be uncomfortable or enraging even, that we're not going—like, the teacher won't do that, right? I mean, ideally, I think it would not be skillful for a teacher to be too strong with someone who hasn't made—who's not ready for that, right? Because then you're going to turn the person away from the Dharma, which is considered a really big deal in a bad way.

So there are certain things that won't happen in a teacher-student relationship unless there's a commitment made. And the student is really giving the teacher permission to work with them in that way.

What about the shadow? The shadow or the edge of commitment?

I think the edge is when the relationship gets unhealthy. And sometimes it is better to leave a teacher.

Yeah. Yeah. We can be so committed that we are stuck. We're trapped. And again, that's where we have to be, as students, we have to be connected to our own power, our own authority, so that if it's unhealthy, if it's no longer—maybe it's simpler than that, maybe it's just no longer a priority in our life—it's time then to dissolve that commitment, to step away.

Other shadows?

Robert.

And then, and then...

I think there can be periods of time where you just, maybe you don't feel like you're making any progress. You don't feel like it's going anywhere. And that can, that can be hard. But when you've made this commitment and you know, you're hoping for something to change or to shift and it's not happening.

Yeah. I mean, that's edgy. And it's also like, it's so beautiful in a way when we are held by a commitment, right? Because there—it will for sure—there will for sure be times where we feel like we're not sort of—we're, we're, we're, we're—again, Daido Roshi used to talk about like plateauing, you know, or we're not getting anywhere, we're just kind of spinning our wheels or it feels dead or dry. I mean, how many of us would have left practice if we took that as a cue of like, okay, game over, you know? For sure. Yeah. So the commitment allows that, you know, like a committed relationship—when it gets difficult or when it's boring, if the commitment is deep enough, you hang in there. And then things, things can turn.

I don't know if this falls into the realm of shadow, but something that I've struggled with over my period of time trying to find a teacher has been like not being able or feeling like I can't commit because of, like, location or, like, constraints. And that's just been—that's—I can't quite figure that out. I would, I'd be interested, like, and I guess, you know, maybe it's location, maybe it's, like, time zone things, maybe it's time commitment things. Yeah, that's just been something I've struggled with. Kind of similar to relationships of, like, feeling constrained on my mobility in my life.

Yeah, yeah, that's a real thing. That's a real thing because it is important to be able to show up. And also I think sometimes when those outer things are presenting, we should look and see, like, is there an inner piece that we're sort of projecting or reflecting outer. Is there a different kind of hesitation that we haven't gotten in touch with? Because a lot of those things can be worked with. Maybe not in our idealized version of a teacher or a teacher-student relationship, but in a real-world way. And that the urgency of our own bodhicitta has its own power. And there's a lot of ways, you know, I think of times where, thinking of Shugen Roshi and knowing that I had a teacher, even though I wasn't seeing him, I was far away, I wasn't in contact—that relationship was bigger than that and was still functioning.

Thanks. Yeah. So we're just about at time.

The one other thing I wanted to say that I've found to be an edge or maybe a shadow of the long-term commitment is we can, you know, form a relational dynamic because it's happening over so many years that gets a little bit solidified. And so to be aware of that, right, the way that I show up with my teacher—like, I think for myself, just speaking personally, I started training in Zen when I was quite young, 21. And so that youthful quality I had, you know, for many years, sitting in front of a teacher who was so much older, Daido Roshi, who's so much older than me, and feeling like the young acolyte, you know, and it's been, like, part of my own maturation to recognize how I still will bring that energy forward with Shugen, even though I'm 52, you know, and having to recognize that and be like, wait a second, wait a second. I've gotten solidified in this relationship and I'm, I'm doing it, I'm doing it. And so how do I, how do I shed that, you know?

Yeah, okay.

You know, thinking about, like, what—what is it that gives the teacher-student relationship its power? There's, like, so much power there. And it's not just, you know, it's not the power that we give to the teacher or the power that we have ourselves. It's the power of the Way. It's the power of the Dharma. And that metaphor of, you know, when we talk about, like, the Buddha meeting the Buddha or the, you know, the hen and the chick inside the shell, and the hen peck, peck, peck, peck on the outside and the chick on the inside, and then the shell breaking open. That mutual faith and trust, that aliveness.

I always used to wonder in sesshin, I would, like, you know, be going into face-to-face each day, and I could see like, oh, the teacher is—they're settling into their samadhi too. Like, they're definitely, like, the teacher at the end of sesshin is definitely in a deep place. And I'd be like, how does that work? Because I'm out there sitting my ass off. But they're, like, in the dokusan room responding to people kind of instantly. And, like, now that I've had the opportunity to taste what it is to be in that space, like, it's so—like, there's something else that's happening as people come in, in their zazen, with their minds settling, and it's like that energy is not contained in a body and it is transmitted.

So, yeah, the Way, encountering the Way.

One last thing: disappointment has to happen. It's part of the path. It has to happen. It doesn't mean that something's wrong. And also, we should know what the difference is between the disappointment of maturation, of letting our fantasies fall away, and the disappointment of having a boundary crossed or harm done.

So the Buddha taught the four reliances: to rely on the teaching, not the person; to rely on the meaning, not the words; to rely on the definitive meaning, not the provisional meaning; to rely on wisdom, not consciousness.

So may our evening here illuminate not only our own delusion and our own suffering. May it soothe not only our own fear and bring the joy of truth not only to our own lives, but may it extend expansively outward, unbounded, illuminating, soothing, bringing joy to all beings everywhere.

Rogetsu, can you lead us in the Four Vows?
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Title: Eight Gates Of Zen: Part 2
Extracted Text:
Good evening, everybody. Hello to all of you in your place. So, tonight we're continuing the study of the Gate of Zazen. A few weeks ago we looked at shikantaza, and tonight we're going to look at the koan. I had to really think a lot about this—there's so much that could be taken up around the koan, so I had to make some hard choices.

Maybe a good place to start is to just remember, or note, that a really essential aspect of Buddhist meditation, or one of the distinguishing aspects of Buddhist meditation, is that it involves the development of concentration, beginning with mindfulness and insight, or direct understanding, non-discriminating consciousness, awareness, and insight. Almost all, I'm going to guess, most forms of meditation incorporate some aspect of the calming that is part of Buddhist meditation—shamatha in the early tradition—calming the mind, developing concentration, samadhi, one of the three wheels of training that the Buddha laid out: the sila (the precepts, the moral teachings), concentration (samadhi), and insight (vipassana).

And so then the question is—it's clear enough, I think, how meditation is addressing the calming aspect. That's what everybody is introduced to when we give instruction in meditation in the beginning. That's pretty much what practicing the breath is: it's a concentration practice, it's developing the ability to bring one's mind to one place—the breath—and then practicing everything that comes along with that, that makes that challenging or difficult or unsteady, which is a whole world of thought and mind and emotion and dukkha, really. I mean, that's a lot of what we're contending with or meeting in the early years—and years can mean many years—where those things are primary. They're the primary things that are in front of us, which is oftentimes the very things that brought us to practice.

And for the most part, they're pretty easy to see. They're obvious, because we feel the discomfort and the suffering when we're experiencing it. And so learning how to meet ourselves or our mind, our thoughts, our emotions, our karma in a way that is cultivating compassion and calming the mind and the body—same.

What is less easy, perhaps, in a way, to make clear, is that—how then? Because that's something each of us can do, right? You focus on the breath, there's something very tangible about that. You see things arise, there's something very tangible about that. We see it, it's an object; emotion, it's not an object so much, but it's a visceral, physical experience. So there's something that's happening and we can address it. We can turn our attention to it, and in various ways that we learn, we can practice non-attachment.

The aspect of insight, by its very nature, is different because its very nature is to see that which is non-conceptual, to see that which is not something. Because anything that we gain insight into that is within the realm of conditioned existence is still dukkha, is still impermanent. It is coming and going.

And so all the ways in which we practice—thoughts and emotions and sensations and pain and so on—in the beginning, we're in a sense pretty much practicing them as though they are objects, they are things. They are things that are arriving on your doorstep, they're pushing at you, they're causing you some sort of experience and reaction. And so we practice them in a certain sense as though they're objects. You see a thought, you let it go, right? The language itself suggests that there is something to this object—like that you can both hold onto and you can let go. And there is a truth to that, because that's our actual experience. And there is a non-truth to that, because it's not an object. And ultimately, that's what we need to see. And that's what insight meditation is about. That's why that's so important, because it's seeing beyond the appearance—the sort of object-like nature of the thing—so that we're not just developing our capacity to do that forever, but never ultimately freeing ourselves, because we still see it, experience it, understand it, believe in it as something that has its own existence.

And so that's why the Buddha said that developing samadhi is really important in a whole host of ways and has a kind of transformative experience. Because when you're in a state of concentration, you feel different, right? You experience yourself, your mind, your body differently; you respond to things differently. You know, I mentioned that's why Daido Roshi stopped giving dokusan on the first day of sesshin, because everybody was just act—cranky, you know, and in a bad mood, right? Because they were getting settled in, but weren't yet. And so they were, you know, just a lot of blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, and they would bring that into dokusan. And he realized if he just waits a day, right? Then when they come in, a lot of that stuff's still there, but they're not as deeply sort of in it. We have continued that tradition, by the way. It's a fine tradition.

So what are those practices that help us to examine and see into the nature of the self? Because that's the fundamental thing. If self-clinging—the views of a sense of self, a separate self, autonomous—is the fundamental delusion, then we basically project that into everything else. So in the same way we see ourselves as something distinct and separate, we see everything else as distinct and separate from us. And so the insight aspect of meditation is to see into what's often spoken of as the two emptinesses: the emptiness of self and the emptiness of phenomena.

Let me just address this up front. So the question—sometimes it raises, whoa—why and when is a student assigned to work in a different way? We all start with the breath. And you know, of course, if somebody's practicing on their own, they'll choose whatever they do. But in training, when we're working with a teacher, we do that generally together with the teacher. The teacher guides us, which doesn't mean that the student can't present or speak about something—a form of practice they might feel very drawn to. So if a student feels drawn from breath practice to shikantaza, or feels a real affinity towards koan study, even if they haven't done it yet, that's important to know, right? Because that means there's an attraction there, there's an energy that's moving in that direction already. There's an interest. And so that's not absolutely necessary, but it can be very helpful.

Sometimes a student, you know, is impatient in working with the breath. It's like, "Okay, I've done that. Now what?" You know, and they sort of see these practices as, you know, sort of underclass, high class, extreme—you know, that they're ranked in the sense of, you know, low, medium, and high. And they're really not like that. They're really not that different, actually. I mean, each of these practices is fundamentally the same. They're just slightly different ways of working with your mind and awareness. And so when a student is impatient, that's not so good, right? Because then whatever that impatience is, they'll just bring that into the new practice, because that next practice is not going to make them practice differently. They're going to be the same person; they're going to be the same meditator. And so if we haven't really developed some foundation and stability with the breath, then we will have that lack of stability when we take up a different practice, which means we'll flounder in that different practice that is, in a way, could be seen as demanding a little bit more of us.

So the teachers generally are waiting to see the signs within the student and just for how their practice is developing, in terms of both their stability, their concentration, but also how they're working with their things—how much is coming up for them, how much of their karma, their history, things that they have been carrying around, how sort of prominent are those in their sitting, how are they practicing those? Because again, all of that will just carry on into whatever different form of practice is. So the practice itself is like a magic trick, you know, it's not like a magic key that unlocks the door. And also that these various practices are in a certain sense complete within themselves.

And also as we move on, you know, in a way what you're developing if you stick around long enough is you're broadening your capacity to draw on different practices. So a student who's practiced for a while and has various ways of practicing the breath, they've done shikantaza, maybe they've done some koan work. So they're learning how to work, how to practice zazen in different ways, how to work with their mind. And each of those practices is going to help them develop in different ways, some different ways. And that can be extremely helpful. And that, I should say, is going along with other meditation practices, like metta practices, the four immeasurables. Sometimes a mantra practice might be given to a student. Sometimes visualization practices are given to students. So there are different ways—these are all just different ways, basically, of addressing the fundamental matter.

So I wanted to draw on a few—so this question of insight in the earlier traditions, if you read Theravada teachings, particularly commentaries, and in certain schools of Tibetan Buddhism, you'll come across either analytic meditation, insight meditation. And so that question—when you see the word analytic, it sounds like, well, what are we sitting there and thinking about, meditation? That's not what it means. It means analysis in the sense of a penetrating examination of something that is striving towards being non-conceptual. So it's not sitting and thinking and contemplating, trying to figure something out—that's what we are trying to free ourselves of—but rather it's examining, or you might say analyzing, something to try and see into it in a way that is more true and clear, and in that way is freeing.

And so this is a text on Satipatthana by Analayo, and I just want to read a couple passages. So he just talks about the development of the self—independent, permanent entity—and that that basically inflates a sense of self-importance, centering ourselves in our lives amongst others, and that that sense of self needs to constantly be gratified, right? It's always hungry, it's wanting what it wants, right? We pursue desires, and it doesn't want what it doesn't want. And so it's this constant ongoing sort of feeding situation.

The Buddha spoke about delusion in terms of those as sort of having the sense of "this is mine," which is my possessiveness; "I am this," which is conceit. And in Buddhism, what that means is just having a sense of self. I mean, you can think of it as being conceited, but it more specifically is just having that sense of self. And "this is myself." So, "this is mine," "I am this," "this is myself." You see those three, those phrases used a lot in the early teachings that are pointing to different ways that we're relating to the self—this is myself, or all the views that I have about myself and then the world.

And so he goes on to say, a practical approach to this, this study of the self, is to keep inquiring into the notion "I am," right? So we have that—once I recognize that sense of "I am," that I have a sense of self, I see that self-awareness coming up, I recognize this sense of me, then we can begin to inquire into it. That sense of "I am" or "mine," a sense of possession—of "this is mine," it belongs to me. And he says, once this notion of an agent or an owner behind the experience has been clearly recognized, we see through that, then the above non-identification strategy can be implemented, which is, "this is not mine, I am not this, this is not myself."

So you could think of—I remember Robert Thurman was here years ago and he said, zazen practice is constantly disidentify, disidentify, disidentify, disidentify, which really means not grasping first. But more than that, it means sort of actively not identifying in moments when we are.

And so there are practices, beginning with the Buddha, and fundamentally, one of the fundamental practices is to bring that inquiry into the aggregates—the skandhas. So you think about, we chant the Heart Sutra every day, right? The prajna paramita, "Gate Gate..." doing deep prajna paramita, deep wisdom, samadhi, inquiring, meditation, clearly saw, inquired into, and clearly saw emptiness of the five conditions—the five skandhas. The skandhas are what the Buddha said: they're you, they're the person, they're how we create a sense, through a kind of a process, of this sense of "this is mine, I am this, this is myself."

And so the meditation is to actually direct your concentration into each of those skandhas—form, sensation. Your mind comes in, you come into contact with something that has a feeling. It might be a sensation in your leg, it might be a feeling arising within you, it might be tension around your eyes. And then there's a perception—we translate it as conception—where you're identifying it. And then there's mental formations—discrimination in our translation—which is what you're going to do next, the karma that you begin to create around that, your response. And then consciousness—being aware.

And so in this, you're inquiring, examining each of those skandhas in turn to see, to locate possessiveness, conceit, a sense of self and views. In other words, you're trying to see—because if those five aggregates are how we constitute a sense of self, okay, so let's examine each of those and see if we can find that self present within them. And then the Buddha went on to, in a somewhat elaborate way, to talk about different ways we can impute or invest a sense of self into the skandhas or the skandhas into the self. So there are about 20 different ways of analyzing the skandhas in this way. We're not going to go into that.

So I just wanted to mention that because it's one of the very early practices of consciously, deliberately taking up an inquiry, an examination through meditation, to try and turn one's attention to this sense of self that we all have. And it seems true.

Okay, so let me talk a little bit about the koans. I thought it was kind of interesting in Daido Roshi's book that has a lot of collections of different talks by different people. It's really—I haven't looked at it in a long time. I was really appreciating it. There's a lot of really nice talks and articles in here. And there's a letter from Hakuin to a student.
