Hakuin, of course, was a later 17th, 18th century Japanese master, very important in the Japanese Zen tradition, and was kind of a reviver, you might say, of the koan tradition, which had become, he felt, rather morbid and was dying. And so he put a lot of energy into that. And there's quite a lot of writing by Hakuin—it's rare to have that much direct writing, autobiographical information and letters that he wrote to students from any of these teachers. So there are a couple of several different books out on that.

But he writes—he's writing to somebody that he knew, a woman who was a lay practitioner, and he was writing about the one hand koan. So let me just get—let me just skip, I'll come back to that, what that was. But—so one of the first koans that he developed is, "What is the sound of one hand clapping?" You've probably all heard—it's been, like, popularized, right? It's used in—so he brings that up in the middle of this very long letter, which is, I don't know, like 20 pages. It's very long. He said he stayed up all night writing it. And so when he gets to the subject of the one hand, he says, this is the instruction:

"The sound of one hand is not a sound you hear with the ear. If at all times throughout the day you struggle with the sound of one hand without mixing in any intellectualization and staying aloof of the five senses, without bringing into play any words of logic or explanation, if you pursue it to the end, be that where it may be, then suddenly you break through to the source of your wandering in this realm of birth and death."

That's it. Twenty pages of writing to this student about practice, about zazen. He has this somewhat lengthy section on the one hand, but three lines, instruction. So what does that mean? It means the student has to find their way. And that's one of the challenges. It's not that different than shikantaza. There's not that much to say. I'm surprised we spent two hours talking about it. I was just going to be for an hour and a half because I thought, well, probably that'll probably be more than we need.

And that is, in somewhat—maybe more than somewhat—to some degree, part characteristic of the Zen tradition, which is careful about saying too much about practice itself and about many things dharma, because of the tendency to latch onto that. It's like, "Oh, I just do this. That's all I need to do." And so, in a sense, you're given enough to arrive at your seat and turn your attention to that particular form of practice, but not so much that you sort of have it all mapped out in front of you. You're the map. You have to find your way.

And in essence, what we are told is, in a sense, what can be said. Everything else, in a certain sense, can be helpful. And there are teachings and teachers who will say a lot more. But that still doesn't prevent one from having to find your own way. And that's just something that's the way it needs to be, because each person is entering into a realm, in a certain sense, for the first time with a particular—in this case, a practice that you're given as your, in a sense, your vehicle, and, you know, motivated by your bodhicitta. And then you face your mind and you bring that, what you understand about that practice to that mind in all of the ways that it's going to present itself to you. And you learn. We learn how to make that, or discover that form of practice, to be deep and broad and powerful and multifaceted and flexible and dynamic.

So, the koan—in the breath practice, there's an object that we turn our attention to. Shikantaza—there is no object; we talked about that. In the koan, there's an object again, to speak of it that way. So for Hakuin, it was, "What is the sound of one hand?" And he says, you know, the sounds of two hands clapping, but what is the sound of one hand?

So remember that what the meditation inquiry, or insight meditation, is endeavoring to help us do is to go beyond trying to figure this out ourselves. Because we all come into practice with a deep trust in our thinking mind, right? It's how we've gotten most—so many—of our things done. And so this is just another problem. We're going to figure it out—and we won't, but that won't keep us from trying.

And so the practice, the insight meditations, are specific in the student's need to be alert to every time their mind starts to try and grasp onto this or to understand this with thought, or to explain it to themselves or figure it out or do what we've done in many other situations. The koan does that in a very unique way by, in many cases, giving you something that doesn't make sense, right? It doesn't conceptually, you know, make it easy to figure that out, right? Because it's not—we know what this is. But, you know, so, like, everybody will do that once in dokusan, right? Because what am I trying to do? Well, I'm trying to—I'm relying on what I know. I'm relying on what I think it must be. So the leap is to sit deeply with that koan in the mind and not think about it.

And of course, koans in that way are very dangerous because we're bringing language into our mind. And what is language for but to think about? And so that's why it's important to, you know, teachers—we will generally wait until a student has developed enough concentration that they can bring that koan in and not just tumble around with it. It's still going to be a challenge, but—and so—and that as they're entering into that koan more and more and losing their sense of not only conceptualizing, but distance, subject and object, right? So the sense of "I am inquiring into this koan," it's really no different than you and the breath, you and awareness in shikantaza, letting that sense of subject and object begin to drop away because you're not creating it. "This is mine, I am this, this is myself"—that is all subject and object, and it's all an activity of the mind. So what is it when the mind stops moving, stops creating the sense of I in this? And so the calling is to, by going into the question, into the inquiry, to lose, let go of that subject-making, object-making mind, because there's no distance anymore.

It's the basic principle behind when your leg hurts and you bring all of your attention to the pain, and you let that distance between you, the subject, and the pain, the object—"I am feeling this pain"—when that begins to dissolve, your actual experience of the pain changes. Now, logically, that doesn't make sense, right? Your leg hasn't moved. If pain is just a fixed thing, you're not creating it, right? Then why would—by not doing anything, by not creating a sense of subject and object—would the actual experience of the pain begin to transform? That should raise questions. So it's a very similar kind of principle in working with the koan, but here it's with a question.

So there are dangers with every form of meditation practice. There are dangers in the sense of places to get caught. And so, of course, one danger with koan introspection is just intellectualizing it. I mean, that's the easiest thing to do. There is something—there's something sort of intrinsically difficult about dharma practice, right? Because we have a lifelong habit of self and grasping and views. And to a large degree, we don't even know that. We don't even know that. And so a lot of practice is actually just bringing things up into our view so we can actually see what's—but then there's still the very strong grasping and belief and clinging.

What is very challenging about the koan training is it gives you a question that is to be resolved. And it is to be resolved not by getting an answer, but by entering into the reality that that koan is presenting you with. And in that moment, moment of intimacy—Dogen says "intimate communication," right?—when their subject and object drop away, then the koan is realized. In other words, the dharma of what that koan is pointing to becomes one's own body and mind.

So, sort of intrinsic and ongoing danger of koan training is that the student intellectualizes. You know, there were many times, well enough in my own training, where I'd be studying with my teacher and moving along in koans, and Daido would at some point say, "Shugen, you're getting intellectual again. You're getting intellectual again." So it was like an ongoing vigilance, really, to check that, to be alert to that. And what I've seen in koan training—my own and others'—is that almost inevitably when a student, in the beginning, yes, it's to be expected. But even as a student goes on, when they get stuck on a koan, almost inevitably they'll start turning to their mind, their thinking mind, because they're frustrated, right? It's not yielding, they're not finding access, but they can always come up with something with thought, right? Every time. And so it's just something to be alert to.

So, intellectualizing is a danger, just having a mind that's thinking, you know, a mind that is not settled, that the koan—by taking the koan in, because it's language—can activate thought. And so that's part of what the student's learning how to do: hold that within stillness, within a state of concentration. And that's an ongoing practice, of course.

I mean, you know, some of this is obvious that is going to be sort of at risk, which is seeing the koan as a goal that is to be achieved, right? We all know how that goes. So here's something I want. It's presented to me in the form of a—I just need to get that thing. And then I'll have insight, I'll experience liberation, I'll be enlightened. So I need just to get that thing, right? And so it is not a thing. It cannot be gotten. But every student will fall into that because it's what we know. How else would we go about it? You know, so that's a real danger that the student's just going to have to work with, right? Which means recognize when they have turned it into an object that they are seeking to grasp. How will they know? Because they're getting discouraged, they're getting frustrated, they're getting pissed off. They don't like the koan, they don't like the teacher, they may not like the person sitting next to them. It can get big, right? And what's really happening is something is not clear. To me, that's really all that's happening. Something is not clear. I want to be clear, and something is not clear. But rather than just recognizing that, I do what we tend to do, which is externalize it, right? Because it's much easier to blame, right? The koan's bullshit.

I remember a student who was working on Mu, who left after a year of residency and was still working—was very frustrated—and as he was leaving, told me, "You know, I figured out Mu." I said, "Oh, what'd you figure out?" He goes, "It's a scam. It's bullshit. There's no koan. There's nothing to see. It's just a way that teachers have enticed students to sit and keep sitting." I said, "Oh, okay."

So, to be caught in a goal grasping, to believe that the koan has its own power—that if I work with a koan, if I have insight, if the teacher passes me on that koan, which basically means that they have recognized that the insight of the student that they've had with this koan is showing them what the dharma point of that koan is about—and that insight may be shallow, it may be deeper, but the danger is that the student thinks because of that, it has done something to me, that because of that, I have been given something, in a sense, and they don't understand that. It's that, you know, there are all depths of understanding and insight. That's why it's ongoing. And it's also, you know, what do I—how do I experience it? How do I relate to it? How do I live it? The koan doesn't do any of that for you. It doesn't make you a better person. It doesn't make you live in accordance with the precepts. It doesn't make you more compassionate. Right. So there's a danger in thinking that it has a kind of power. "If I see this, I will never think, speak, or act from delusion again. I'll instantly be compassionate. I'll never cling to the self again. I'll be free." I mean, if you read Wumen's commentary in the Gateless Gate to Mu, it sounds like you see that koan, you're done. Right. For most people, that's not true.

I think it's fairly predictable, even when warned, that the student will see the koan as a test of their worthiness: of a Zen student, of a koan student, of your understanding, and most fundamentally, just a person—whether you are worthy as a person. So that every time a student goes into dokusan and they don't see the koan, that's a failure, right? "I am failing. What am I doing wrong? What is wrong with me? What is wrong with my practice?" That's why we can at some point turn it against the koan, right? Turn it against the teacher. And so that's really a big one. That's a big one. And particularly if a student—I mean, if a student that I know, a student has struggles more than your average bear with insecurity, self-doubt, you know, if I, you know, ask them to begin doing koan study or they ask to do koan study, I usually give them a fairly hefty warning. I say, look, this is what's going to happen. You're going to get to a point where you think you're not seeing something. I mean, I just lay it all out there, knowing this is not really going to help because you're going to forget we ever had this conversation, because I did. And even if you remember it, you'll think, "Yeah, but that's not what's happening here. What's happening here is really, I am failing. I am not good. I am not a good student."

But for all of those same reasons that I just spelled out, koan training can be incredibly powerful. If you are defeated by yourself in any of these ways, then the koan is not helping, right? But if in the face of possible defeat, you rally and you start shifting, you know, rather than just keep hammering on the same nail, hoping for different results, you actually realize, "Oh, maybe I have to do something different." You know, I remember—I mean, so many moments for me, but that sense of failure, of failure, of failure, of failure, you know, "What is wrong with me? Why can't I get this right? You know, I must really be disappointing my teacher." You know, all of this, it was completely making it all up. None of it was actually true, but it seemed very true to me. And there was a certain point when I realized—you know, I came out—the worst was when I went into dokusan before I had even talked, and I was rejected. You know, I didn't see the koan, so I have no right to even open my mouth, you know, it was just like—it was like it didn't even matter, you know, up to a certain point, how much, you know, how long I'd been practicing and stuff, it was just like, okay, it's like this happening for the first time.

And there was a point at which I thought, what is really happening here? What is happening is there's a point, dharma point, a point about myself, about reality, that this koan is trying to help me see, and I am not seeing it. That's what's happening. And once I framed it to myself in that way, and I thought, oh, but that's why you're here. That's why you came. That's what you want to do. So the koan is helping me to do that thing that I actually want to do, and that really helped shift it for me. So then, rather than seeing it as my enemy, you know, that was confirming my inadequacy, I saw it as my ally, you know, this is how I am helping myself.

There's a lot about—I'll say a little bit more, and then we'll take some questions. But there's a lot of—I wanted to read this. This is J.C. Cleary. Christopher Cleary is a brother of Thomas—they're both translators of many, many texts. And this is an old book. But he talks about a lot of the misconceptions around koans that I don't hear so much, but I think they're probably still out there. So I thought I'd read about some of this. And he talks about the whole idea that Zen and koan study is anti-intellectual, anti-rational, it's irrational, right? And he says, you know, the people are just projecting their own ideas onto that. You know, the Zen—I mean, a lot in the earlier, there was a lot of thinking that Zen was iconoclastic, you know, that we burn the Buddhas, you know, we don't bow, you know, it's—you don't need all that stuff. And so people were very surprised when they came and saw an altar and we did prostrations, and it was disciplined. And so that sort of anti-intellectual idea.

And then he goes on to say that reason in Buddhism is—he said, the problem with reason, according to the Buddhist masters, is that it's trapped in a limited and arbitrary conditioned view of the world. Our ability to think and reason is incredibly important. It's incredibly important, and it's important in dharma practice. But we're trying to release it from the ways in which it's been trapped and limited and conditioned by ourselves in our world. So that's all the stuff that comes up when we're sitting is all of that. And when we do koan training, that's what comes into the koan. That's what we're wrestling with, you know, before we even get to the koan, really.

He said, reason becomes entangled with our biases, our desires and aversions. It's limited by the categories we have conditioned and believe in, sort of absolute realities. So he says, Buddhist analysis, insight, examination, inquiry, focuses on what he calls the psychological conditioning that shapes perception. And think of psychological as just the totality of your mind. Don't think of it as just in terms of psychology, but sure—the totality of your mind that shapes perception, creates common sense, reason, and makes it seem objectively true. So the self seems to be an objective truth. I see myself, I am aware of myself. There is a subject, myself, and an object—or subject, my awareness, and an object, myself. So I can create that dualistic split, the fundamental split within my very person.

And so then, when you think about how the Buddha said, okay, so turns out that examination towards that very self that you believe in and that is constructed through these various steps we call the skandhas. He says, Buddhist adepts, experimentally—and I would say experientially—discover, verify, and he says, map out, I would say, gain understanding—a form of perception that goes beyond the confines of conditioned, common sense reason. And I think by common sense, think of just relative understanding, things everybody believes.

He says, so the task of Zen and other forms of Buddhist teaching is not to abolish or destroy the intellectual faculty, but to free it from its conditioning, to purify it, and to allow it to function in an accurate, dispassionate way. In other words, to make it even more powerful, most powerful. So part of this process involves breaking the moment-to-moment tyranny of the conditioned intellect, showing the contradictions and absurdities to which this leads.

And then he goes on to say that misconceptions are that koans are just paradoxes, that they present paradoxes and that are issues to stay alive. The idea of a paradox is just an idea—when conceptually we think about this or that, we can create a sense of paradox. But in reality, there are no paradoxes. He says they shouldn't be understood as mere exercises or egocentric contests for intellectual supremacy. Sometimes, I mean, a common thing is people think of them as, you know, sort of performative. You have to come in and do something zany, do something not irrational, you know, turn a cartwheel, you know, there's a koan of Nansen kills the cat.

Monks of the Eastern and Western hall were arguing about the cat, and Nanquan came in and said, "Look, if you can say a true word, I won't kill the cat." Nobody could speak. So he killed the cat. That night, Zhaozhou comes back. He was away. Nanquan told him what had happened, and Zhaozhou put his sandals on his head and walked away. So that's a very good example of what—and so you can think, "Well, just do something silly, right? Do something crazy." When people—when I hear people talk about or read teachers who speak about the koans in that way, it always confuses me because I think, if you really believe that's what it's about, is that helping you? Like, do you think that's why these have continued to be passed down all these years? It's just to come to that idea? That doesn't change anything. How could one be satisfied with that?

But Daido Roshi told the story of once in Maezumi Roshi—they were doing dharma encounter, and everybody was lining up just like we did on Sunday. And there was a new student who stood there, and he took off his shoes and put them on his head. And Tetsugan or somebody leaned over and Daido said, "Get that guy out of here." They're not battles of wit. They're not puzzles or riddles. He said, the real answer to the answer, quote unquote, to the koan, is not a sentence or gesture in response to the teacher's question, but the change in the student's state of mind and body. And that's really the key—through the practice of the koan, it's bringing about a shift in the mind and body state of the practitioner, which is what allows them to encounter the point, the dharma teaching of that koan. And that, by teaching, I just mean, you know, I realized reality.

Okay, so just a couple more things so we can open this up. Then I'll kind of be done with my introduction. So one of the things that traditional koans, particularly as they developed in, well, in China, is the sense of doubt, spiritual doubt. You know, bodhicitta, the aspiration to liberate oneself and others, could be thought of as just a great aspiration. But in a sense, it's just a very profound question: How do I liberate myself? What is not liberated? What needs to be liberated? What do I turn my attention to? What is it that is binding me?

And so the koans recognize, you might say—and this is sort of speaking from the side—that sense of urgency, of question, of wanting to understand something is one of the most powerful forces in the human realm, right? And all too often it's directed towards—well, very often it's just directed towards other things: making money, you know, doing something, you know, with oneself, which can have value, of course, but in dharma practice, it's directly being directed towards liberation. And so the koan basically holds that sense of urgency, that sense of what Daido Roshi used to call the spiritual imperative, what is chanted every night in the evening gatha, that is trying to, right, arouse that sense of urgency, of immediacy, of impermanence, right? So that we don't become complacent.

So, but what do you do with that? What do you do with that energy? So in the koan training, you channel it into the koan. So in koan training, there is—in the koan lineages which came to be in Japan—raised, recognized primarily as the Rinzai or Linji and the Soto or Caodong. So in each lineage there will be some different course of koan training, you could say. So there's always a first koan, which is really fundamental because it's a complete wilderness. The student has never really done this before. And the essence of that koan is to see into their self-nature, the reality body, to realize the self is empty, and to have that first direct encounter.

And so the first koan is always very particular. So the koan Mu, the koan "sound of one hand," the sound of "what is your original—the face you had before your parents were born"—those are three of probably the most commonly used. Mu is probably the most commonly used of all. But because they, you know, they don't really—although we can intellectualize them, that's not going to take you very far. So they don't give you a lot of meat to chew on and get caught up in. And they're very succinct, they're very direct, and they are directed directly towards oneself.

And in the development of koan in China, Dahui, who was a great proponent of koans and helped to establish a lot about how koan practice went, he talked about what he called the huatou. So if you think about the mu koan—so, student asks Zhaozhou, "Does a dog have Buddha nature?" The obvious answer is, yes, everything has Buddha nature. And Zhaozhou says, "Mu," no. So that's the dialogue, right? The huatou is "What is Mu?" So what Dahui said is that with the koans, to distill them down to their essence, their sort of pivotal seed phrase or word or question, so that that's what the student is holding in their mind. And they're not getting caught up in a lot of, you know, verbiage. And so that element is part of—very often students need to do that, particularly with more advanced koans. It can be quite complex and there's a lot of language, and they need to really discover what is the question that's being asked. Because a lot of koans don't ask questions. They just present you with something, but they don't actually explicitly ask a question. So the student has to see what is being asked here? Like, what am I inquiring? And then once that koan is seen, then there are subsequent koans that are similar—not similar, but they're called miscellaneous koans. And they are to help clarify what Mu helped a student to initially discover. And there were originally 200. In our training, when I did them, they were 200. At a certain point, Daido Roshi winnowed them down to 100. He wanted to make less, but have people take longer and work with them more deeply.

So one of those is, "How do you stop suffering?" So that would be an easy question to sit and contemplate. You can come up with a hundred different ways to stop suffering. And all of them, probably most of them would be good—and good if you did them—but they have nothing to do with the koan, because the koan is always taking you to the fundamental, right, which, in a sense, is not what you can practice. That's not something you can practice. It's more the ground of things. And so then in that koan, the student has to keep letting go of any thought they have about how to stop suffering.

From the Diamond Sutra, there are a number of koans: "It is not a world," the Buddha said, "and for this reason, it is called the world." So there is an example of taking a sutra, a line from a sutra, and presenting it as a koan. So for the koan students, it's a really wonderful opportunity to learn how they can work with all kinds of different texts and bring them to that kind of intensity. There are koans directly from the Heart Sutra: "Form is emptiness, emptiness is form." There are koans that deal with language: "With your throat, mouth, and lips closed, how will you speak?" There are koans that deal with obvious dualities: the koan of—it's like a person hanging from a tree. You're hanging by your mouth from a branch. You can't touch the branch with your hands. You can't wrap your legs around the trunk. You're just dangling. And somebody comes and says and asks you an essential question that their life depends upon. If you answer, you fall to your death. If you don't answer, to save yourself, then you forsake that person. What will you do?

So there are koans that make it very real, right? Who are you going to choose? Is there another way? It's not magical thinking, right? It's not Disney. It's not being a superhero. It's letting go of a dualistic way of thinking, right, and entering to it directly.

There are koans that will clearly bring up sort of karmic tangles. Fayan, one day, as he was getting ready to give teisho, pointed to the blinds where the sun was streaming, and two monks got up and rolled the blinds up—exactly the same. And Fayan said, "This one has it." No, he actually didn't point to them, he said, "One has it and one doesn't." What do you think everybody in that zendo was thinking, was wondering, right? What do you think those two monks were thinking? So it's like throwing gas on a fire, right? You want to be the one that has it, right? You want to have it. You don't want to not have it. And so there are koans that just go right for the jugular in that way.

So let me just finish, and then we'll take a little break and then come back and just open this up. But I wanted to read from a couple passages of Dogen to just show how he brings in this sense of inquiry without ever saying anything about a koan. So he's talking about koan Mu. He said, "Does a dog have Buddha nature?" Zhaozhou said, "No." And then Dogen says, "Can you gauge this word no, Muji? Can you contain it? There is no place at all to grasp its no's. Please try letting it go. Let it go and just look. What about your body and mind? What about your conduct? What about life and death? What about the dharma of the Buddha, the dharma of the world? What about, after all, the mountains, rivers, and great earth, the people, beasts, houses, and dwellings? If you keep looking and looking, the two attributes of motion and rest will naturally become perfectly clear, no longer arising. Yet when these attributes do not arise, this does not mean that you have become rigidly fixed. There are many people who fail to realize this and are confused about it. Do not stop, press on." So he's presenting all of these questions. Is that just, you know, to fill a page? He's presenting different ways of inquiring, of examining.

In another fascicle on the King of Samadhis, he says, "Know that the world of sitting practice is far different from other worlds. Clarify this for yourself, and then activate aspiration, practice, enlightenment, and nirvana. Now study the world. At the very moment of sitting, is it vertical or is it horizontal? At the very moment of sitting, what is sitting? Is it an acrobat's graceful somersault or the rapid darting of a fish? Is it thinking or is it not thinking? Is it doing or is it not doing? Is it sitting within sitting? Is it sitting within your body and mind? Is it sitting, letting go of sitting within sitting or letting go of sitting within body and mind?" It's very—I don't know if he was drawing directly from those practices the Buddha laid out in terms of how we impute the self into the skandhas, skandhas into the self, but it's very evocative of that.

And then he says, "Investigate this in every way possible. Sit in the body's meditation posture. Sit in the mind's meditation posture. Sit in the meditation posture of letting go of body and mind." And so Dogen, of course, is the great proponent of shikantaza that we think of as objectless, goalless, non-directed meditation. And that is how we generally teach shikantaza. But no form of practice is fixed or rigid or monolithic, right? And that the question, in a sense, with shikantaza is how is that inquiry brought in? How does that inquiry exist within shikantaza?

Okay, so I hope I've not said too much to dull your mind. So let's take a break, freshen your mind, and then we'll come back, see if there are questions or comments that people would like to ask.

---

During the shikantaza mando, you referred to this expression, "Don't make a Buddha and don't interfere with the making of the Buddha." That's Dogen. Sorry, that's Dogen. And how does one apply that to koan study?

Well, the koan is the point of one's attention. And so if a person is sitting with a koan and trying to make a Buddha, they're not sitting with a koan. So, I mean, that's the tension, right, that the koan presents to the student: you're presented with a question or something that needs to be resolved. So it's really not different than shikantaza. I mean, there is something that is to be resolved, right? It's just not given that direction and that sort of focal point and the question, although that's why I think it's important to recognize how, you know, these questions that Dogen is asking, you know, these more explicit forms of analytic meditation that exist within different traditions—it's, I don't know, I mean, I'm sure in the Zen tradition, as Buddhism was coming to China, that those practices were coming, you know, they were reading about those practices. Well, you know, it seems to have evolved in a way that those weren't sort of carried along, you know, with the teachings that developed in Zen in terms of applying those specific practices. That's why I think it's interesting when they show up without, you know, calling them anything—Dogen just embeds those questions in the context of a teaching.

But the tension is that there is something that the student—I want to resolve. I want to be clear about this. I want to know my true self. But how do I hold that? How do I practice that without turning it into an object that I'm going to grasp? You know, because in a way, that's all I know. That's what I've done in my life. And so the way I discover that is by grasping, suffering, letting go. Grasping, suffering, letting go, until I find: how can I hold that deep desire, that deep wanting, that deep caring, but without the clinging? So that's what makes it difficult, is that we have to go through those many times, those many experiences of falling into the very thing that we're trying to free ourselves of. And when we do that, it's not abstract, you know, it's not neutral. It's painful. You know, there is struggle, and it's the same struggle that we're trying to free ourselves of through practice. It's the struggle that brings us to practice. But now it sort of gets focused in zazen on the koan, and that's where it can get all tangled up.

---

See if I can phrase this in a succinct way. You mentioned, like, the ways in which a koan is answered. Seems like it's an embodied piece of wisdom that's unique to the person who experiences it and in the moment that they display to the teacher. I'm curious if it's—is it a momentary experience, or is it something that's lasting and shifting, like it changes the person internally? Which my guess is yes. But is it something that's able to be summoned up? You know, essentially, the answer to the koan, summoned up by the person?

Yeah, yeah. No, because then it's willful, you know, then it's, "I am bringing something forth," which means I have to have something I'm bringing forth, and there is a subject and object distance. No, that's why it's challenging. I mean, if we could be—if it could be realized willfully, everybody would be enlightened, right? So that's the challenge, is it takes effort and wholeheartedness, but without self-clinging. And most of us just don't know what that experience could be like. I mean, sometimes people even argue, "I can't—there is no love without attachment." It's like, no, actually real love is without attachment. But we just tend to get attached when we love, and so we conflate them as the same thing. That if there's something that is very important to me that I am seeking, then it is a goal. How else will I achieve it if I don't establish it as a goal that I am trying to seek?

And so going back to that passage that Sogen was pointing to, Dogen says, "Be it known that for studying the way, the established means of investigation is the pursuit of the way in seated meditation." So he's holding up meditation as really essential. And the essential point that marks this investigation, this sort of is the foundation by which we are investigating, is the understanding that there is a practice of a Buddha—that's you—that does not seek to make a Buddha, which is exactly what you want to do. You want to make a Buddha, right? And he's saying the essential point of the investigation that we're undertaking in zazen is that you are a Buddha and you are and want to realize that, but you must not seek to make a Buddha. He said, "The practice of a Buddha not making a Buddha is the realization of the koan." In a sense, that's when it's real. That when, like, what is your original face, the face you had before your parents were born? So it's not this face, it's your fundamental face, it's your fundamental nature. So when the student holds that question so deeply that they enter into the—in a sense they become—the original face, which is not something of their own doing, but rather by letting go so deeply of any doing such that all that's left is the original face, then in that moment of intimacy, it's realized. And that moment itself is the, you know, sort of a puzzle because how can you realize that which is not something, and it can only be realized when there is a merging or dissolution of subject and object. But for something to be realized, somebody has to realize it, right? And so that's where a student can experience—and this, this is in any practice—can have an experience of some direct encounter with their self-nature, and it's not a realization yet because it's not actually apparent to them. It is a cognized, and so that may come at some other time. Sometimes in koan training, in dokusan, if a student is really inside of the koan, they may be presenting it—this is particularly true of the first koan, because they have no basis, no history to know that—sometimes they're presenting the koan, the teacher may be asking them questions to probe into their understanding, and the student is answering the questions before they've even realized they've realized it. In other words, the koan itself is speaking. They're speaking directly from that place, and it's not yet apparent in their mind. In other words, in a sense, they haven't seen, but in that moment, they see as it's being, in a sense, unveiled. And so there's this sort of liminal place, right, that's not a place. And that's why it can't be done. You know, we can't make it happen. We can't make it come about. But what we can do is make the conditions for that ripe. And that's really what all the practice is about. Doesn't matter—I mean, that starts right away with the breath. You're making yourself ripe to be a true human being.

---

Kusay asks, "Do koans help to dissolve, dismiss, or deeply see the stories that get in the way of living in the moment?"

I think so, because in order to get close to, I mean, the koan, to the breath, to an awareness, we have to recognize when we're telling a story, when we're identifying the self with something or something with the self, because that will stop us. That will just hold us right there. And so whatever our practice is, those aspects of the self, of our karma, that come up that are very strong, have to be both recognized and practiced, which means to not be rejected, but also to not be grasped and become entangled in. And so in that way, a beginning practitioner can practice that. I mean, that is what we give instruction in, is practicing just that. And in that way, we're beginning to free ourselves of that impulse to deny or to claim. We're discovering a middle path, right, that is freeing ourselves in that moment of either of those entanglements.

And as I said earlier, we can do that, and that's profound and good, and the sense of that thing that I am not rejecting or clinging to, still in my awareness, my experience is a thing. I still experience it as something that is happening to me, that is coming and is exerting a force on me and has some kind of force in and of itself. So that basic delusion can still be intact. And that's again, why the introspective or insightful nature of zazen is so important.

---

Follows that up with, "Seeing the koan—does it happen suddenly?"

Yeah, usually. I mean, sudden is just a word, you know, that sort of tracks time. But there is a moment—I mean, just think about in any moment in your life when there's—when I was in college, I took an upper-level geometry course, and one of the early days, and I was studying here already, and the teacher one day talked about working on a theorem, you know, working on a proof. And he was getting really worked up. And he says, you know, it starts to consume you and you don't go home, you stop taking baths, you forget to eat. And I was like, oh man, he's like doing koan training. It's like consuming, you know, in other words, I have to know. Of course, he was talking as a mathematician and having that kind of passion. And then what he said, and then there's a moment where something shifts. You can't predict it, you can't make it happen. But suddenly something that was not seen is seen. It's like there's a crack or there's an opening and it becomes clear.

And so we have those moments. Creative work, in science—I mean, it can happen in all kinds of endeavors. And it's usually the result of a very concentrated period of time in which there's a lot of very focused energy that can often be very difficult because something is not clear, something is not resolved. So we have to learn how to hold that uncomfortable experience. And then sometimes it comes right out of that, but often it comes out of a moment—a subsequent moment—where you just forget about it. In other words, the mind relaxes. I remember once when I was doan or jisha and I was working on a koan and I went in to see him and I didn't pass it. And I was frustrated and discouraged. I went back to my seat and then dokusan was over. So I went in and he was doing his bows. And as I went over to do my bows, standing bows with him, it became clear to me at that moment—I was not working on it anymore. You know, and so sometimes it happens in that moment of release because we've released, it's like we've relaxed and are no longer focusing on it. So, but, you know, there's no predictable nature.

And just to keep saying that, you know, so much of what we can say about the koans is true about any form of meditation. So it's really important not to see the koan as some, you know, thing that is, you know, and sort of elevate it to a special place. The Buddha didn't do koans, right? Most Buddhists don't do koans. It's just a way of—it's a skillful means that evolved in a particular way in the Zen tradition, within some Zen traditions, because, you know, it can—because of it, for different reasons, I guess. And partly, you know, I do emphasize them in my teaching. And so that can convey a sense of that if you're not actively working on the koans, then, you know, something's missing. It's not—not at all.

---

So you said that everyone has Buddha nature, and then also that you mentioned something about delusion. So is it the case that a Buddha can have delusions, that the Buddha—what? That a Buddha can have delusions or be deluded?

Well, it depends on how you understand Buddha. So in Buddhism, there is one perfectly enlightened being—a Buddha—in sort of an eon or some vast period of time. And so Shakyamuni was the Buddha of our time, 2,500 years ago. And that before Shakyamuni, there have been Buddhas going back, because there's no beginning of time in Buddhism. And so the Buddha was just the enlightened being of our time, and that his realization was complete in the sense that he saw all that there was to see. So that's the sort of the essential meaning of Buddha. So in that, the Buddha is a Buddha because he's free, there is no more delusion, right? There's no more deluded thoughts or speech or action, that even the capacity or the sort of sources of that have been realized, have been liberated.

Particularly in the Mahayana tradition, we use Buddha more liberally, right? Drawing from Buddha nature. So because we have the nature of Buddha, we have—our mind is fundamentally an enlightened mind. Our minds are not different from the Buddha's mind. We speak in that way of being a Buddha, which doesn't mean I am a realized being, but it means I have the same nature, right? Which both means I have it already—it's already present within me—and it also means I have the potential to realize that. It has both of those meanings.

---

This is from Kiho. "I think Shindo wanted to ask a question, but go ahead while she's getting the mic. Okay, from Kiho, can you please speak about how working with the Faith Mind poem relates to koan practice and also a bit about the origin/intention behind using this as a form of practice that is different from shikantaza and formal koan study?"

Yeah, that's a good question. I'm glad you asked that, because I wanted to mention that. So years ago, Daido Roshi, after years of teaching and teaching many shikantaza students, talked about—he talked with me and I think Mihotai at that time about how, you know, about how the depth and breadth of the power of shikantaza. And because of its nature, one of the characteristics is the student is not engaging with dharma teaching in their meditation, right? It's objectless. And one of the things that does happen in koan training is you're working with language, but you're also working with dharma teachings. Because a lot of the koans, like those teachings from the Diamond Sutra, that koan that I did recently, that was drawing from the Diamond Sutra, that, you know, that "because of all of my misdeeds of the past, you know, the scorn and revilement that I'm experiencing in the present moment, by virtue of that experience, I am thus liberated." So—and I talked in that talk about how, you know, you could look at that from the point of view of understanding karma, how karma works, and how the consequences of my past actions will bear fruit in some misfortune, some, you know, negative experience that I'm having in the present. And that becomes the moment when I can shift that karma by how I respond to it. And I said, but as a koan, that same phrase is not asking for those explanations. It assumes the student already knows that, because you're a practitioner. It's asking, what is the fundamental basis? What is the nature of karma? How do you fundamentally free yourself, not just by practicing the precepts and not getting into trouble, but actually in a more liberative sense? And so the koans help the student develop their dharma understanding in that way, both directly but also in literature.

And the other valuable part of it is that you're articulate. You have to express yourself in relationship to the dharma. So the student is coming in—there are a lot of koans, particularly early on, that don't require any language. It's embodied, right? You're presenting the living experience of that koan in a way that doesn't need language. But at a certain point, the student needs to begin to bring in language and learn how to, as we say, speak, express their understanding in live words. Which means, don't explain it, don't describe it, but convey it so that when you speak it, I'm experiencing that—you're not explaining it to me, but you're giving me the direct experience of that. And the student, that is more challenging. So the student has to develop their ability to articulate, which means it's going to get clearer.

So what Daido Roshi did was he began having students working with the Faith Mind in the beginning. I mean, he also worked with the Genjo Koan and Mountains and Rivers Sutra. But the Faith Mind is particularly well suited because it works in couplets or single lines, so you're not holding too much. And rather than a koan, where you're taking it and focusing on it directly, the student holds that line in their mind at the beginning of sitting. And just—the image I have is you're dropping a teabag into hot water and it infuses, right? And so you're holding that line in your mind, just letting it infuse in your body. You're not thinking about it, you're not trying to figure anything out. You're just letting it fill your consciousness, planting that seed. And then you let go and you just do your sitting. You're not bringing it up, you're not trying to think about it. If the lines do arise, you treat them like any other thoughts. So you're not really shifting how you do shikantaza, except at the very beginning. It's like an oblique way of gaining an understanding rather than looking directly. You know, on a very dark night, if you look at stars and you want to look at a particularly faint star, if you look straight on, sometimes you can't see it. But if you look off to the side, there—is it the rods or the cones on the side that pick up faint—and then you can see it. It's sort of like that. It's like you don't look at it directly, but you sort of plant the seed.

And in that way, through sitting, could be through contemplating off the cushion, and then in dokusan, you know, I ask the student, well, how do you understand this? It gives me an opportunity to see where their understanding is. It allows me—it gives me a chance for the teachers to ask questions. There have been many times where the student will bring something up and I'll give them one of the koans to sit with it that is directly related to what they're—because they're already sort of encountering something. It's like, okay, why don't you work on it in this way? So in that way it can move in different directions. But fundamentally, it's not the same because you're not intentionally directing your attention to it and trying to resolve it in that way that the koan student is. So it's a little more indirect, and that the, you know, the face-to-face is very dependent upon the student. So for some people, it's just, you know, they're discussing it, they're sort of explaining how they understand it, because that's where they're at. For some students, they may be able to work with it at a little bit more direct level, deeper level, so it can evolve. So that's a long answer to a short question.

---

Shindo: Well, that kind of answered my question. And so I'm not sure if I still have one. But I was curious about—in koan practice, as I understand it, you know, there's—well, the word kensho, right? Like a moment of seeing clearly into self-nature. And I was wondering about in other forms of practice, it's not kind of taken up in the same way. There's no kind of, I don't know, clarifying of that or testing of it or affirming or denying, right? Like it's, in my understanding, it seems more spacious or—

Yeah. Well, think of Dogen, you know, when he was in China with Rujing, he was just sitting. I was thinking about this because I was reading recently, rereading something, and it was saying that Rujing, they used to sit until about 11. And then it said at—I think it was either 1 or 1:30 or 2:30, they washed their face, which I think meant they were getting up. And so if you think you got it rough waking up at 4:30, just telling you. And at one point there's a—Dogen speaks about how some of the monks came to him and said, "Teacher, like, we're dying here. Come on, you know, can we wake up a little bit later?" And he said, "If we wake up later, you'll still be sleeping." He said, "It won't help." But they were all sitting, and Dogen was sitting, and Rujing was walking around—I think he had a sandal and was slapping people because they were falling asleep. And he said something about, you know, dropping off body and mind. And that seemed to have precipitated Dogen's realization. I don't know, you know, exactly what happened, but I can imagine that in that moment he was dropped off body and mind. And in that moment when his teacher said that, it was like he realized it, right? Because he then got up and he went to his teacher's room. And that was the koan I presented recently. So it just happens with shikantaza by its nature, generally in a more subtle way, whereas the koan tends to be more direct, because that's its nature.

But the thing about the koan that's important to understand is—I talked a little bit about the dangers. And, you know, it takes time. And so, you know, I was at a sesshin many, many years ago where there were two people in that sesshin who saw Mu. One had been sitting with Mu for about six months, and the other person had been sitting with it for 20 years. And that person was very mature, very successful, was clergy—like, they had all these credentials that you think would make them an easy shot. And it didn't matter. It didn't matter whether it took six months or 20 years. And that's sort of the spirit that the student has to take. And we live in a very patient culture in a very impatient time. And students can get very impatient with the conversation quickly.

Daido Roshi told a story of when Maezumi Roshi was here of one of his students, Daido's students—Teshu perhaps—who was working on Mu and went in to see Maezumi Roshi, Daido Roshi's teacher, and said he was working on Mu. And something like, Maezumi said, "How long have you been working on it?" And Teshu said something like, I don't know, a year or two years. And he just rang them out and said, "I don't even want to talk to you."

---

So Roshi, could you speak about capping phrases and if they have any legitimate role in our tradition?

So one of, and this is something that developed in the koan training in literature was the use of poetry and the use of what's called a capping phrase. So if you think of all the poems that are written for each of these koan collections that we draw from, those are verses that are basically encapsulating a capping phrase for a point or various points of the koan. So it's a poetic way of expressing live and through the beauty and wonder of poetry, which generally isn't definitive. It's not descriptive and explanatory. And so the classical koans provide those verses which the students in our lineage have to present as koans. But students in their training can be asked periodically to present the koan as they understand it and now present it as a capping phrase, present it in poetic form. And that can be much harder, right, because they're trying to draw—they have to go back into that experience and try. And how would they express something that is, in essence, inexpressible? And in a way that conveys that sense of aliveness. And so, again, it's a way of clarifying and being able to articulate in a live way. That's why poetry has been such an important part of the Buddhist tradition.

But we are not using capping phrases in our training—not in the way that it was developed in Japan, which was intensely academic. I mean, student, you read Victor Hori's book, I mean, this—hours and hours and hours and hours pouring over. And, you know, so, no, we don't do that. And I think that's appropriate, you know, for us, you know, as—I mean, I even didn't have that training, so hard to speak of that way.

---

But you sort of touched on this already, but—and maybe you don't have more to say on it—but if you do this, you know, Daido Roshi used to speak about kind of the affinity that people would have for shikantaza or for koan study. And do you find that to be—like, he would sort of sketch, you know, kind of sketch a profile of, here's your shikantaza student, and here's your koan student. And I just wondered if you find that to be true or helpful.

I don't know. You know, I don't know that I—I don't think I really use that. I mean, you know, I heard that, and I reflected on that a lot when he was teaching. And I—I don't know that I—you know, he would often talk about shikantaza is good for people who really have a deep faith in dharma, practice, in zazen, don't necessarily have a very strong, you know, sort of inquiring impulse or mind. And I think certainly there's a validity there, you know, in terms of sort of an affinity. He would say that sometimes people who are very intellectual, tend to really engage things intellectually, koan can be very good for them because—because it'll make them crazy. It'll help them to try and release that impulse, that way of experiencing things and turning towards things.

So it's also—it's such an evolving thing that—particularly with the first koan, because it's, you know, it's such new terrain. And if it, you know, these questions don't necessarily resonate with the student in a way—they don't make sense. Like, I know what I'm feeling, I know what I sort of am yearning for, but how does this question—it doesn't seem to speak to that, right? And so what the student has to do, and that's part of its function, actually, is because otherwise I might just get embroiled in how I feel and what I'm thinking and everything I've thought about. So in a way, it's more flavorless. And so then the student has to, in essence, bring it to life. And they do that by sort of recognizing that this koan is asking what you're asking, is wanting you to know, what you want to know is speaking to that yearning, but just not in a language that you understand yet. And so can I bring that sense of urgency or that imperative or that yearning into, with some faith, into that work and breathe life into it?

Yeah. You know what? I guess what I've seen is—I mean, with some students, it seems a little easier to get a sense of what might work best for them. And others, sometimes they think, "Oh, I think this would really suit that person." And it doesn't necessarily. And also, I think it's good over the course of time to have some experience with these different practices. For instance, for koan students, I think it's good sometimes between collections, I'll have a certain person just do shikantaza for a while, not do koan. Certainly if a koan student is going through a lot, something's going on in their life, there's a lot of turning or turmoil, I'll almost always encourage them to not do the koan and just do the breath or shikantaza, so that they're not using the koan to kind of push aside something that they really need to be allowing to arise. So in that way, there could be some fluidity.

For a person who's really done a more concentrated practice for a long time, to sit shikantaza can be quite a shift in terms of feeling, experiencing the mind more spacious, more open. When they go back to a more directed practice, can they retain some of that spaciousness so that their concentration is too tight, too narrow? Can the koan work help bring some incisiveness, even a sense of inquiry, a subtle sense of inquiry into the shikantaza? So I think there's real value in developing some fluidity.

---

Yeah, Kien, maybe we'll finish off here. You spoke about some of the traps of koan study. Could you speak about traps of shikantaza or pitfalls of it?

Dullness, complacency, just meandering, you know, because there's—and that dullness can be in a quietude, you know, that was Dahui's criticism of the School of Silent Illumination, you know, is that it was just, you know, people were just sitting there like dead things. And without that element of introspection, of inquiry, that's really, I think, what he was concerned about. And so a person can easily sort of drift into that because it's comfortable, feels good, you know, but it's not—it's impermanent because it's based on the meditation in that moment. And it's also not leading to a more fundamental shift. I mean, this is what the Buddha said, you know, that he said that the sila and samadhi and prajna, these three essential elements of training. And he said that samadhi, as important as it is, does not fundamentally free us, right? Because the view, the fundamental identity view, can still be intact. And so to see that that identity is empty, that the skandhas are empty, is ultimately—because then the very notion of clinging, you know, becomes, you know, illusory. So I think those are sort of the main elements—that just dullness and kind of, you know, just getting lost, because there's nothing to gauge your awareness against, right? Which is sort of the value of the object. And a person can be quiet and even quietly drifting and not be fully aware of their state of mind because it feels good. So it's a little easier to get lost. And then, of course, if the mind is active, then the person can just sit there and just think.

So I think it's a good practice at all times, in all days, for all kinds of people. In particular, it's a good practice for somebody who's been practicing for a while and is in a place to do that, and if they're not having a lot of contact with a teacher or any contact, because it's a good practice to maintain on one's own. Whereas, koans, I don't think you can really—I don't see how that can work. You have to really work with a teacher, because how can I guide myself in something that I don't understand? And I can't understand it. I can't understand it because I haven't experienced it. And so I think that the likelihood that I will get tangled up in ideas and false sort of insights is inevitable. And so that's why, you know, that's one factor. It's not determinative, because there are some students who live far away and do fine with the koans, but in general, it's good to have contact.

---

I was just curious about these—like, each koan is different, there's a different dharma point that you're talking about, but it's making contact with ground. So what, like, what is different, I guess, about each?

Well, there, you know, I mean, what do we need—where do we need to be liberated? What do we need to be liberated from? Well, we need to be liberated everywhere and in every situation. We need to be liberated in our thoughts, words, and actions. We need to be liberated in this body. We need to be liberated between ourselves in terms of relating to a world in which there are lots of things, in which there are situations—in other words, everything that a human life encompasses. And so it's not that the koans are, you know, line by line item dealing with every single part of your life. But, you know, I talked a little bit about, you know, language, karma, fundamental teachings, life and death.

There are koans that deal directly with life and death. There are koans that deal with biases—not necessarily the way we would think of them today—but, you know, prejudices, you might say, usually related to the self. So they're—and they deal with phenomena. You know, there are a lot of koans that—a monk asked Master Zhaozhou, "What is the meaning of Bodhidharma's coming from the West? What is the fundamental truth of Buddhadharma?" And Zhaozhou said, "An oak tree." "That oak tree in the garden." And the student says, "Master, don't speak to something that is of a conditioned nature," right? Because that's dukkha, to present the fundamental reality. And Zhaozhou said, "I don't point to the conditioned." And the student says, "Well, then, what is the fundamental reality?" And Zhaozhou said, "Oak tree in the garden." And so there, the student is working with, well, what is the nature of phenomenon? An object in the external world, right? If that's empty, how do I realize that? Because I can't experience a tree the way I can experience myself, but I can experience the tree in the way that I experience tree at all, which is in my mind. And if I'm entangled with that object, it's not on the tree, it's in my mind. So if I can liberate that object, that phenomenon in my mind, and realize that it's empty, my perception of it is empty, then I realize that that object is empty, because that's the only way I know it. And then there are other ways that are more through inference of analyzing an object like a tree and realizing that the notion of some unified object that we call a tree doesn't exist anywhere in that object.

---

Okay, okay, I think that's enough. So the next mando will be—is that you? I think so. Okay. And what are you doing it on? The Teacher-Student Relationship. Sean will be doing a mando next on Teacher-Student Relationship. So let's all be sure to show up for that. Bring your friends.

Okay. So thank you for coming. Are you chanting now? Okay, so Raigetsu will lead us in the four vows.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Talk Location: Zen Center of New York City
Title: In Darkness It Is Most Bright
Caption or Other Speaker: Suzanne Taikyo Gilman
Extracted Text:
Good morning.

Silent and serene, forgetting words, bright clarity appears before you. When you reflect it, you become vast. When you embody it, you are spiritually uplifted, spiritually solitary and shining. Inner illumination restores wonder: dew in the moonlight, a river of stars, snow-covered pines, clouds enveloping the peak. In darkness, it is most bright; while hidden, all the more manifest.

I was here at the temple this week while the sesshin is happening at the monastery—the Apple Blossom Sesshin. And then the week before, I was in hermitage. So I was living in a little cabin on the mountain for a week by myself, solitary, close to the land. Spring waking up. It started the week really cold—snowflakes on my glove. End of the week, it was T-shirt weather. It was crazy.

And I worked with this poem from Hongzhi during the week: "Guidepost of Silent Illumination." And it's from the collection *Cultivating the Empty Field*, translated by Taigen Leighton. Beautiful book.

So, I'm a little nervous talking about practice because it's so personal. We get the instructions for zazen—some of you got them for the first time today—and then you're on your own on the cushion. And we're on our own to face our habits, patterns, things we want to get rid of. And we courageously face our minds—maybe past mistakes, regrets—and we let go. That's the instruction.

So I really struggled for many years with what letting go actually meant. It didn't really make anything go away. That's kind of the puzzle, the challenge. But it changes things. It changes our perspective in a radical way. So I want to explore this a little bit more, and I want to bring in and honor that this is Earth Day week also, to try and bring in the Earth. I mean, it's everywhere around us, just popping out. But—so I want to talk about a perspective shift that's somewhat unique to human beings in our time. And it's not unlike the perspective shift that happens deep in stillness and in solitary practice, and that's traveling outside of Earth's orbit.

That experience—which I've not had personally. But even before going to the moon, American astronauts began to prepare by going on high altitude orbits of the Earth. So, in the late '60s, there were people who were selected for their mental stability. These are not people given to reveries. They really wanted people to stay within their rational and mission-based mindsets. So, I'm going to read a little bit from an article I found from *BBC Sky at Night*.

So, on the Apollo 9, which was testing lunar lander modules in Earth's orbit, one of the pilots, Russell Schweickart, finally had the chance to gaze out the window. He looked first for the friendly images, like his home city, which was Houston. He said, you identify with that, it's an attachment. Gradually, with each passage around the world, his attachment widened, and Schweickart found himself identifying with North Africa. By the end of the mission, his sense of connection had come to encompass the whole Earth. And somehow you recognize, he said, that you're a piece of this total life.

So these very rational people were starting to expand their sense of connection after seeing an overview, connecting with home as being vast, enormous, bigger than you could conceptualize, and like a sudden shift. So this ability to identify with the whole, rather than just the sum of the parts, is called the "overview effect." This is actually a kind of a thing.

So to me, it felt like what was being described was awe and reverence, that there was a renewed sense. These astronauts coming over, like the edge of a kind of—when they finally traveled to the moon, over the moonscape, which is very rocky and empty and dark, and it looks like all life is absent. To see this fragile blue thing kind of rising—it's called "Earthrise." And we've all probably seen that photo. It's kind of iconic: the moon's surface, and then this bright Earth. Stunning.

Hongzhi said, "Silent and serene, forgetting words. Bright clarity appears before you." So when we sit, particularly with a consistent, ongoing personal practice, it is a perspective shift that starts to happen.

First, as I mentioned this morning to you in beginning instruction, we're just encountering the noise of our minds, which is pretty noisy. There's a lot going on there. And then as that quiets down, we can encounter our kind of deeper reveries—maybe they're vexations, disappointments, epiphanies, sudden insight that might happen, euphoria, states of bliss. And it is vast. Over time, recognizing that this is endless, this mind, and there's much yet to be known. I think that's one of the perspective shifts that I find most interesting. To me, there's much yet to be known.

So when Hongzhi says "bright clarity appears before you," he is pointing to an experience. Okay, not a thing. It's an experience. And I was kind of trying to describe this to somebody—it's kind of like seeing where a thought had been. Just seeing kind of the possibilities, that it was there and then it's not. And also seeing the capacity, maybe the tendency, the urge to kind of add more thoughts and think about it or congratulate myself, you know, there's like, "That was so cool. Wow, how do I do that again?"

So, "forgetting words," he said. There's an emphasis in Zen, which we received from Bodhidharma, Bodhidharma's teachings, to not rely on words and letters. That Zen is a special transmission outside of the scriptures, a direct pointing to the human mind. So before there are words, what's there? And this can be also a special kind of frustration, because words are how I communicate—communicate with myself, with you. Letting go of words. What is that?

Whoever's doing—yeah, if you could just shut off your phone, that would be really helpful. Thanks. Unless that's, of course, an insulin monitor. Leave it on, please.

So some of these words, like, there was this redbud tree blooming on Fourth Avenue when I went by last night. If you see it, it's stunning. And it's a flower, right? There's a flower blooming—you know, a flower. Where does that come from? There's words, but the experience of really being with it, that's something else. But the words, oh my gosh, they're so delicious. Like, a flower is a thing, right? It's also coming, you know, a process. It's like flowering. So something coming into being. It's also, you need a flower in order to get a fruit, right? That happens on the apple trees. If all the causes and conditions are right, you get some fruit. That fruit's got its own seeds, more flowers. So there's a proliferation that can happen.

So for a tree, under the right conditions, we get fruit. For zazen practice, under the right conditions, we let go of the words. We come back to the experience: bright and serene. Bright clarity appears before you. When you reflect it, you become vast.

The mind is said to be like a mirror that perfectly reflects everything that comes before it without getting involved in it. So that perfect reflection, in a sense, is seeing the thought in the mind, not adding to it. There's nothing in that mirror but the arising of reality—the thing, the thing outside, the thing in your mind. But it's all clear. It doesn't need to fixate. And it's a process. And that helped me to think about it that way. And over time, with practice and diligence and a bit of resolve, I began to see that and to be more relaxed in it, to not hold my thoughts so tight.

So when there are no obstructions present in the mind, when we don't immediately step back or get whisked into the next thought, there's a moment you might have experienced where your mind becomes very gentle and pliable, resilient and vast. When you reflect it, you are vast. When you embody it, you are spiritually uplifted.

So embodiment is one of the things that we talked about in zazen instructions. How do you put your mind into your body? You know, we use the breath, focus on the breath. We say we put our mind in the hara. Put your mind in your body. That's not fixed either. That's an experience. And it's one we can return to again and again.

You know, dancers, martial artists, probably you know this because you practice it, right? You got to put your mind in your body so that your body is moving, you know, as one entity—probably musicians too. So embodied practice is really what it's all about in zazen.

So each time we return to the cushion, we're starting up again. We're getting grounded in that breath, settling the body. We're on the earth, bringing about those conditions for that clarity and that ease to come about.

It's very important not to be perfectionist about this either, because we are a dynamic being coming into being all the time. And so really accepting what is present really means accepting what's present, even if it's a very tight, distracted, can't-settle-down mind. That's just what's present right now.

So he says, "When you embody it, you are spiritually uplifted." And I think that's probably the best description of why really landing in your body can make things easy. Even a new, mysterious ache in your knee or some connection your mind just made that really makes you uncomfortable. Working with kind of holding that what's-arising feeling, even if it's difficult, does help to develop what's called concentration. And we can feel that aliveness as the result of embodying what's happening—the fullness of breath, the fullness of your heart.

In fact, I have noticed that when I really land with stillness, there's actually—there's a relaxing into the fullness of heart that actually is kind of like a heartache. It's actually kind of full. And I've been studying this and trying to understand. I feel like it's because I'm becoming more vulnerable in some ways, that really being in my heart is that opening up the heart, feeling more tender, more vulnerable, and more capable really, of walking a bodhisattva path. And this is also kind of that tipping point where that stillness can start to happen, developing some concentration, trust—trust in the body, and stillness, and stillness in practice.

It also has a name: samatha, I think it's pronounced as. Sometimes translated as cessation. When thoughts gradually slow down and are not being grasped at, they're said to cease. And I want to admit that that actually sounds pretty scary and definitely not what I came to practice for. I did not come to practice to cease. Cessation just sounded very like, "No, that's not really what I want or what I think this is about."

So I'm going to step into this text. It's a core Mahayana text called the *Awakening of Faith*. It's attributed to a fellow named Asvaghosha. And I like it because it's somewhat pithy and I keep coming back to it. It's a somewhat technical version of some of the more elaborate Mahayana sutras, like the *Avatamsaka Sutra* or the *Lotus Sutra*, and it reads—with a few notes from me:

What is called cessation means to put a stop to all the characteristics of the world of sense objects and of the mind, because it means to follow the samatha, or tranquility method of meditation—that is, stillness.

And then the corollary part: What is called clear observation—clear, bright clarity—means to perceive distinctly the characteristics of the causally conditioned phenomenon (that's our world, the world of samsara, causally conditioned), because it means to follow the discerning method of meditation—that is, insight. Insight into the nature of emptiness. And emptiness is one of the three marks of existence: emptiness, no self, and nirvana, as Thich Nhat Hanh likes to call it—samsara, nirvana, the world.

So I could read that again:

What is called cessation means to put a stop to all the characteristics of the world of sense objects and the mind because it means to follow the tranquility method of meditation—stillness.

What's called clear observation means to perceive distinctly the characteristics of the causally conditioned phenomenon—that is, the world in which we live—because it means to follow the discerning method of meditation.

And these two are linked: stillness and activity of insight. They're not the same, but they're linked. They're one. And as we follow the breath and develop that stillness, we're developing some concentration and that develops our confidence—I think the confidence that we can turn towards stillness. And as I was saying, landing in your heart, it's a truer expression of that heart, a fuller expression.

And stillness and clear observation are inseparable from wisdom and compassion that arise in our heart. They are spontaneous and effortless, free of the tangles that the thinking mind can create. Clearly being aware of everything—that's how Zen master Sheng Yen translates "bodhi" or Buddha mind. He said, when the mind stills to the point where thoughts cease to arise, then body, mind, and universe disappear. This is bodhi. Bodhi is being clearly aware of everything. And that's the kind of awareness that we have in our zazen. Just see it. Not like going after it or not thinking about it—just clearly, just aware.

And that's the same bodhi—Buddha of bodhisattva, the being of bodhi, the person of bodhi—which we chant in the Heart Sutra. And so the bodhisattva lives prajna paramita, with no hindrance in the mind. No hindrance, therefore no fear.

Our minds gain that confidence so we can be bright and clear. Hongzhi says, "Spiritually solitary and shining. Inner illumination restores wonder. Dew in the moonlight, a river of stars, snow-covered pines, clouds enveloping the peak."

So what happens when we can rest in zazen? Really rest deeply and feel, really feel deeply. This is the illumination. That is our capacity to really see what's right in front of us. To see that flower, to see that redbud tree, to see the garbage that needs to be swept up from the yard. It's not contrived. It's a genuine seeing. And it can even be as mundane as a cup of coffee and a croissant or somebody offering you a chair, or a public figure standing up against an onslaught of harmful actions—that can be very true, you can feel that. And I feel wonder and awe when I see courage. I feel reverence for the capabilities of an open heart—really feeds my practice.

In darkness, it is most bright; while hidden, all the more manifest. When those who've had the experience of seeing Earthrise over the barren horizon of the moon—the delicacy and brilliant contrast of this bright, turning Earth against the vast expanse of the dark universe—they are seeing, in a sense, all that we are. That bright awareness within a vast mind of changing circumstances.

We will all die someday, which seems inconceivable to this bright awareness. And most of the time, we are woefully unconcerned about its fragility and uncertainty. So, quoting again from this article: Earthrise had a profound effect on Michael Collins as he looked at home—he was one of the early astronauts to land on the moon. In wonderment, suddenly aware of how its uniqueness is stamped on every atom of my body, is what he said. But the effect was short lived. He said, "I looked away for a moment and then it was gone. I couldn't find it again without searching closely." Kind of makes sense, right? You have to renew that.

But I don't think it's a stretch to say that we have to renew our stillness so that we can see our bright awareness in this vast space, and so we can touch that inner illumination, that sense of wonder.

So if we fast forward 50 years from that first spacewalk on the moon—and now we have the International Space Station, we have SpaceX, we have any number of plans to go mine the moon and other ways of developing elite colonies and so on. So in this BBC article, Joe Allen is quoted. He's a shuttle pilot for the International Space Station. And he said, "With all the arguments pro and con for going to the moon, no one suggested we should do it to look at the Earth. But that may in fact be the most important reason."

So Hongzhi said, "When wonder exists in serenity, all achievement is forgotten in illumination. What is this wonder? Alertly seeing through confusion is the way of silent illumination and the origin of subtle radiance."
