So during my hermitage, I was a little worried about this talk because I had just found out I was coming down right before the hermitage. So I was trying not to focus on it too much. But I had a dream that I was in a big study hall—maybe it was the temple, I don't know—and I was starting to feel okay, I was calming down a little bit, and then suddenly Hojin Sensei was at the far end and was like, "We need the dedication! We need it now!" I was like, "Oh, the dedication!"

So, to this glorious Earth, our generous Mother, and all of which we receive in thanks, we dedicate all of our efforts to the benefit of all beings. Thank you so much for listening.

For meditation supplies such as cushions, incense, liturgical instruments, Dharma books, and more, visit monasterystore.org—support for your spiritual practice at home.

Talk Location: Zen Center of New York City
Title: A Question Of Practic
Extracted Text:
Good afternoon, everyone. Hope you're having a good day.

We kind of move into a different kind of time, don't we? It's not like chronological anymore when you get into Zazenkai. So this spring Ango, we have the theme of mountain training—the Eight Gates of Zen. And I didn’t really know what I wanted to talk about this week, so sometimes I just go to the library and I just look at the shelves and just see what jumps out at me. I picked up this book that I loved reading before called *Buddha* by Karen Armstrong. And so I just started leafing through it. It’s nice and yellow. And, yeah, I just was like, oh, there’s something interesting in here where she’s talking about, does it work? Like, does your practice work? Whatever you’re engaged in, how do you know if it works?

And she said, in any practice... she said that was like the Buddha’s—at the heart of the Buddha’s quest. And his realization was like testing things, practices. He went through a number of them. And does this work in terms of—for him, it was, is this settling his question about why we suffer? That was what he was after. Like, why is there suffering? Who's suffering? What is suffering? Why do we keep suffering?

So I thought I would take a look at that question a little bit more: does this work? It’s a good one to ask ourselves on occasion. And how do we know? And how do we receive answers? Are we looking for a sentence—“This works because…”—and we’re getting analytical? Or what is it? What else is operating?

You know, Daido Roshi gave us these Eight Gates, which is his recasting, in a way, of the Eightfold Path of the Buddha. But he says, these are gates we enter, but there are actually no gates. There aren’t gates. It’s just one body, one mind. And we look at these aspects of ourself that we develop as a person: our creative beingness, our intellect, our body, our relationships, our morality. And so we have these particular areas of focus where we can experience the richness of our life through them and see how they're all interrelated. And it’s all what we call our life. It’s just our life.

And how many gates do we enter here today through this Zazenkai? Probably all of them. We touch on all of them: student-teacher relationship, liturgy, moral and ethical teachings, creative expression, the miracle of aliveness of the body, the study of the Dharma, right action. And often students come—and I did myself—wondering to my teachers, is this working? And they would say, you tell me. You tell me, where do you find yourself?

So why are we in the Sendo? Why are you in the Sendo? Why am I in the Sendo? I think it’s important to keep looking at and re-feeling into, and not look for linear answers, but allow for something we don’t know about, something larger to open, that we wonder about. And I think it’s good to keep checking, because we can get lost in that initial impulse. It can become muddy. Some of us start and we’re suffering greatly, and then that shifts a bit after we start practicing. And then why do we continue? So what is that? The essence of why we turned in the first place? Sometimes it gets lost in form. We lose that connection. We get lost in form, or we’re dependent on something external that’s holding us.

And sometimes we start practicing for one reason, and we may still be clinging to that old way through habit, just like we cling to relationships in the past or to jobs after things have passed their time and they no longer fulfill what they used to fulfill. So we have to keep checking in again on that spark, because everything keeps shifting and changing. So to ask from time to time, why am I doing this?—could be helpful.

And it’s important to remember that we’re here by choice. Nobody put us in a straitjacket and said, you’re coming to Zazenkai today. We weren’t airlifted in. We came by choice, right? You knew it was going to be sunny today. So it’s important to recognize we’re here by ourselves. That’s good to recognize. And we begin practice by a choice. Even though we might seem like we had no choice, we made a choice that we had no choice. We’re not here because of our parents—not really—or our heritage, because of institutions. Or maybe you are. Is that working?

And we always begin in a kind of an inquiry, right? I wonder what it’s like if I go to a Sunday service. I wonder what it’s like at this temple. Why am I going? Somebody introduced me. That’s why I went. Really? Is that what was happening? Maybe we’re just curious. Sometimes, for some of us, the fruits of our inquiry will be of no interest. And if they do interest us, then we’ll start to explore. We’ll start to explore and to see what the exploration brings up.

So in a sense, we’re all on an expedition together. And Shugen used to always refer to Ango as like, this big ship goes out when we start Ango. And I always saw, like, this big expedition. We were all going out on this ship together. And then if that exploration is sustained, we kind of make a commitment. Uh oh, commitment—the “C” word. But that’s necessary in a deep exploration.

You know, I think it was Kornfield. He wrote that book *Path with a Heart*. On the back it says *Path without a Heart*—there was a misprint. It was interesting. And he wrote something like, you know, we can dig a lot of holes, but eventually we have to dig a deep hole, otherwise we just get a lot of holes.

So I picked up this book by Karen Armstrong. It’s really clear. I love her style of writing, a lot of clarity. But she does—she brings out this question of does it work? And how that finally led to Buddha’s realization, experience. And so I want to read a few sentences from it.

She says, “A person’s theology was a matter of total indifference to the Buddha. To accept a doctrine on somebody else’s authority was, in his eyes, an unskillful state which could not lead to enlightenment, because it was an abdication of personal responsibility. He saw no virtue to submitting to an official creed. Faith meant trust that nirvana, or peace, existed, and a determination to prove it to oneself—that I could be at peace, and to prove that to myself. The Buddha always insisted that his disciples test everything he taught them against their own experience, and take nothing on hearsay. A religious idea could all too easily become a mental idol—one more thing to cling to—when the purpose of the Dharma was to help people to let go. Even his own teachings must be jettisoned once they have done their job.”

There’s that koan that says, “If you see the Buddha, kill the Buddha,” which is referring to that, you know, don’t put a head on top of the one that you have. Yours is fine.

So he keeps making the point over: does it work? Not do I believe it? Am I doing it right? Am I better than—does it work for me? Does this work for me? That’s all Shakyamuni Buddha is interested in. And maybe what we should be interested in: does it work? And the pragmatic basis of our exploration is, does it work?

So explorers knew that if they saw something, they had to continue their exploration. When we get a glimpse of something we’ve never seen before, how do we then in practice know to continue? We know it’s necessary to continue, perhaps, because when we see something with our ears or hear with our eyes and we have an insight, when we realize something we have never realized or seen before is brought to light, and we realize by being aware.

Awareness is the tool of our attention. I think attention and awareness are interchangeable, and that makes us uniquely human—that we can be aware.

There’s an old Zen story, and it came up three times this week, so I thought I should say it. Three times I heard this story by other people and I read it. A student asked Master Ichu, “Please write me something of great wisdom.” Master Ichu picked up a brush and wrote one word: “Attention.” The student said, “Is that all?” The master wrote, “Attention. Attention.” The student became irritable. “That doesn’t seem very profound or subtle to me.” In response, Master Ichu wrote simply, “Attention, Attention, Attention.” In frustration, the student demanded, “What does the word attention mean?” And Master Ichu replied, “Attention means attention.”

And like this student, we might find this is really disappointing, that that’s the answer we get—so dry and uninteresting. Attention. What’s the most important, the greatest wisdom? Attention. “But isn’t there something else?” “Attention.” It’s like—I thought of Mae West, where she sings, “Is that all there is? Is that all there is? Let’s keep on dancing.”

Yet without attention, there really isn’t practice. We have to see. We have to get insight into what’s happening. So we have to have attention, not tension. Attention and awareness is the makeup of our present experience. It’s what’s going on now. What’s going on now? What are you aware of? Might we know? That’s how our practice is working.

What I was thinking of was, many students will come—and I’ve done this with my teacher—and I’ll go through, like, “My mind is so busy, and I snapped at this person, and I can’t believe how angry I got. And I don’t know if this is working.” And I remember Daido Roshi saying, “Oh, that’s a lot that you’ve seen, that you’re attentive to what’s not working. How many people see that?” See, that’s what’s actually happening with us. And we just brush that off like it’s just nothing. We can’t do anything unless we see something like that; otherwise it just goes on autopilot. But when we see it and we feel like something is happening with that, then we can shift, we can look into it further.

Like, if we’re confused, seeing confusion with awareness. We can see that if we’re confused, then there must be something that’s not confused because we see we’re confused. That’s wisdom. But we brush that aside. So we say, “I’m confused. Something hasn’t come through yet.” We have to be patient. It just means we don’t see something yet. But what we do see is confusion. That’s attentive. I know you’re all like, what the heck? Experiential awareness. That’s how we prove it to ourselves.

Am I able to see this person or this situation in a broader way? Am I able to sit with confusion arising? Am I able to move through this crisis with more calmness? Am I able to look at the news and the things that are happening and stay present? Am I able to open more to owning the dark side, the more shadowy sides of myself as it arises in zazen or in my life—my compulsions, my cravings, needs, my bad feelings? Can I be there? Can I be attentive to that, just seeing it arise? Am I present to this now? Is there letting, non-grasping? Is my universe expanding or shrinking? Am I able to face suffering? Is this happening to some measure or not?

Are you who you were a couple years ago? Think of something that really, like, bothered you. It may still, but sometimes there are certain things that was unbearable a couple years ago, and now we’re like, what was that? What was that? What happened? How come it’s different now? Is it working? And does it work?

I don’t think we can go to the mind for our answers—not all of them. And I remember this quote that I’ve remembered for years—I’ve loved it—which is: To go to the mind to find the answer to the question, “Does Zen work?” is like asking a corrupt police department to investigate itself. Can’t be done.

So we have to go to something else besides the mind. Sometimes because it’s corrupt, it doesn’t always give us the correct answer, but only not-mind does. Sometimes our not-knowing does—this inner sense, our inner connection knows if it works. Yeah.

So we have to expand that not-knowing or uncertainty of what’s happening. And there’s a lot of fear around uncertainty. So much, because uncertainty is the loss of what’s comfortable, familiar, the known. The self that we call “I” is made up of mostly knowns. So this is taking us to unknowns. It’s mostly made up of fixed points of certainty. That’s why I continually try to prop myself up: I’m okay. Tell me I’m okay. Tell me I’m doing okay. Tell me I’m right, you’re wrong, so I can be right. Clinging to identities, titles, possessions, people, religions, ideals—all propping this up to something that’s fixed, settled, dependable. At least I can depend upon it.

And Zazenkai or sesshin, at the deepest level, is an advance by choice into that not-known. By choice, we’re sitting into not being certain, into unknown. But all the knowns come up: I’m this, they’re that. We cycle through all the knowns, and we just want to release it. The experience of no road ahead, no fixed point, no dependable map, no destined end, no result. It’s hard. I just sit there sometimes, and I feel my mind just go into that—like it’s like a Pac-Man: What about—? I’m like, settle down, settle down. You’re right here. You don’t have to go over there.

The practice of all-day sitting is the constant choice of returning to the experience of not-known, not-fixed. Instead of running to the familiar, it’s the experience of not, not. So we have to expand that not-mind.

Somebody wrote a book once called *It’s Figureoutable*. I thought that was really a funny title. I didn’t go into it. But we’re constantly trying to figure out most everything, constantly try to grasp at our mind, use outer sources as a yardstick. So not-mind is zazen: unknown, unfixed. It’s not the Buddha, it’s not the Dharma, it’s not the teacher, it’s not this Dharma talk, it’s not the Sangha. It’s not anything at all. It’s our individual practice of not-mind, of not-known, and our commitment to seeing this as urgent, as the most important thing.

We need teaching for sure, but we do confuse the finger that’s pointing to the moon. But we need to find out about the path, the teachings that remove confusion. That’s necessary. We need to be analytical sometimes for sure. These aren’t absolutes. We need the Sangha. We need these practices to keep going, to keep us from falling into delusion, to ignorance. But I don’t know—ultimately, they may be secondary. It’s just zazen, just sitting, where we can combust our lives. And we do our best to bring the body along.

But our deepest, most honest self knows what we must do, that we can identify a coasting zazen and then re-enter a deep, committed, on-the-edge—wherever we are—zazen. And we know, not knowing, we’re aware. Then we can really answer, does this work? And with great care, keep letting go of the ideas, the ideations, the projections, what we want to look like. That’s mind.

So it must arise out of our self, our body. And when it does, we will know, and we won’t have to believe.

So I’ll close with another piece from her book where she says:

“The Dharma is essentially a method, and it stands or falls not by its metaphysicality or acuity or its scientific accuracy, but by the extent to which it works. The truths claim to bring suffering to an end, but not because people subscribe to a salvific creed or to certain beliefs. Rather, because they enter the Buddha’s way of life. Over the centuries, people have indeed found that this path has brought them a measure of peace and insight. They have realized that by reaching beyond themselves to a reality that transcends their rational understanding, one becomes fully human. For the Buddha, that was a fact. For him, it worked.”

What if we simply stayed with any moment of recognition? We wake up from a thought and there’s just this recognition of our present situation, just where we are. We just come out of the thought and we just recognize just this unknown sitting here. What if we rest with that? What if we allow our confusion to trigger wisdom, to allow anything that we encounter be an invitation to wisdom?

Does that work for you?

Thanks so much for listening.

Speaker: Jody Hojin Kimmel

Talk Location: Zen Center of New York City
Title: Mountain Light: On Zen Study
Extracted Text:
The following Dharma discourse was given by Jeffrey Shugen Arnold at the Zen Center of New York City. Shugen Roshi is the head of the Mountains and Rivers Order and Abbot of Zen Mountain Monastery. This talk, like all of our talks, is offered free of charge. If you would like to make a donation or find out more about our various programs, visit us online at zmm.org or ZCNYC. Thanks for listening.

This is from the Blue Cliff Record: Huang Po's Gobblers of Dregs.

The pointer: The great capacity of Buddhist ancestors is completely within their control. The lifeline of humans and gods is entirely subject to their direction. With a casual word or phrase, they astound the crowd and stir the masses. With one device, one object, they smash chains and knock off fetters. Meeting transcendental potential, they bring up transcendental matters. But tell me, who has ever come on like this? Are there any who know where they are? At the test? I cite this. Look.

One day, Huang Po, instructing the Sangha, said, “All of you people are drunk, gobblers of dregs. If you go on traveling around this way, where will you have today? Do you know that there are no teachers of Chan in all of China?” At that time, a student came forward and said, “Then what about all those in various places who order followers and lead communities?” Huang Po said, “I don't say there's no Chan, it's just that there are no teachers.”

Verse: His cold and severe, solitary mien does not take pride in itself. Solemnly dwelling in the sea of the world, he distinguishes dragons and snakes. Ta Chung, the Son of Heaven, has been lightly handled three times. He personally felt those claws and fangs at work.

Good morning. As many of you know, this ango, our theme is the Eight Gates. And when I was thinking about this ango, our 45th anniversary, I thought about Daido Roshi and his establishing of the monastery. And very early on, Sangha practicing here in the city, originally in Manhattan, and building a community of practitioners and developing what he called the Eight Gates, was really drawing from traditional practices in Zen and largely in Buddhism.

And I really appreciate that he brought them out in the way of making these sort of establishes in a very conscious way as sort of the vehicle by which we take up Buddha Dharma. That both brings them into our consciousness, sort of holds them up for us to see and helps us. And really, I think an important part of his intention was that we would examine them, that we would not just do what people had done before, but we would do that with some measure of faith. But we would also be examining this particular form of practice. Why is this important? What is the doorway that this opens, so that in that way, they become alive, right?

In order for the Dharma to be alive in every generation, it's not in a book, it's not in a sutra, it's not even in a building or temple, but it's in people. And so I wanted to this morning speak a little bit about the gate of training that he called Zen study, which is studying with a teacher.

In the Uttara Tantra Sutra, which is a Mahayana Sutra, Buddha Nature Sutra, it says: “The perfect Buddha Kaya”—and kaya means body, vehicle—so, Buddha body—“the perfect Buddha Kaya is all-embracing. Suchness cannot be differentiated, and all beings have the disposition; thus, they always have Buddha nature. The Buddha has said that all beings have Buddha nature, since Buddha wisdom is always present within the assembly of beings, since this undefiled nature is free from duality, and since the disposition to Buddhahood has been named after its fruit.”

So it's expressing what the Buddha realizes in his enlightenment: that we all have Buddha nature, which is this fundamentally enlightened mind. And all the qualities of a Buddha, of an enlightened being—great compassion, generosity, patience, selflessness, wisdom—it's all-embracing. It's all throughout the body and mind. It's all throughout every single person. Suchness, which is the perfect manifestation of your original nature, which is always present, never absent, which is ultimately what we are practicing to realize, cannot be differentiated. It's not of the discriminating mind. It's not high or low. It's not in the world of gain and loss. It can't be possessed or purchased or lost. And every being has the disposition.

What disposition? Buddhism teaches that because all of us naturally, instinctively turn away from what is painful and move towards what is pleasant and affirming, that we have the disposition to move towards enlightenment—an ultimate kind of pleasure, you could say, an ultimate freedom from every form of displeasure and pain and confusion. Well, then why aren't we all living like that? Right? It's a basic question.

In a sense, every tradition—I don't know about every tradition, but it seems like the great world religions all possess some sense that we have lost our way from something. Cast out of the garden, separated from God, alienated from nature, blind to our Buddha nature. And so in that sense, every tradition has some sense of returning, right? We're trying to find our way back to something. And what Buddha realized in enlightenment is you can't find your way back because you've never actually been apart from it. Thus, everyone has Buddha nature because Buddhism is always present within you. Your basic nature is free of duality and you have the disposition.

And yet we struggle with our attachments. We get deceived by our false views and the false views of others. And as practitioners, this is our practice: to see this, to begin to see this. Right. To come into practice means we have to have some sense of that. Nobody comes here because you're having such an incredible and amazing life and time and are utterly undisturbed by the world. In a sense, we come here because there is the awareness that there is a problem. But moreover, you are acting in response to that. You are not just defeated or not just deciding, “Well, that's just the way it is. Nothing to be done.” We seek.

And so when we begin practicing, we turn towards that very thing that we're trying to, in a sense, escape from, and see it more closely, more clearly. In a way, it becomes more painful. But is it? Is it more painful when you're actually engaged in a path that understands and is guiding you and you're the guide and that can help us to also understand and how difficult that is, right?

And Buddhism doesn't mince words about that. Buddhism lays it out: this is a difficult path. Not because it is difficult. Sometimes people say, “Why did you make it so difficult?” We're what's difficult. Human beings are complicated, deluded, attachment—attaching minds is what's difficult. The Dharma, it's not difficult. And that can help us. This is one of the ways we cultivate compassion, is when we see this in ourselves as we are practicing to free ourselves. And then we look out and see all the people who don't have the opportunity or the inclination or don't give a shit about trying to actually bring benefit into the world, do something good, liberate themselves, liberate others. Then we understand the challenge of samsara.

And what the Buddha realized was that we all have a sense of our self, right? I am here talking to you, and I can talk to you. And in a moment, in different moments, I can be self-aware that I am doing that, right? When I was performing music, there were often moments where I'd be performing and I would just be in the music. And then another moment where I would step outside and be aware that I was performing, and things would start to come apart. And so I had to come back, come back inside. And so we can have that sense. You can have the sense that you are sitting here listening, and in one moment you're just listening, another moment, you're aware that you're listening.

So we have self-awareness. That's just part of the way our mind functions, our brain works. But Buddhism says that where that becomes problematic is when we impute into that a sense that because I am self-aware, there must be someone that is there at the center of that awareness. It's me, it's myself, it's the self. And the Buddha said that the delusion can be sort of come down to just the sense that this is me and this is mine—what I possess, what belongs to me, what is me, my identity. And the Buddha said that is the source of all of the madness that we see in the world, small and large. There is no pain and suffering without a self that arises and acts out of that sense of self and creates harm. There can be no harm without that. There can be no dukkha, there can be no suffering. And so that's what practice brings our attention to—to free ourselves of that. Not the sense of it, that's not the problem. It's the attachment to it, the imputing into that a kind of reality that it doesn't actually exist.

Bakubodi said that we all have a sense of self, but it's kind of vague and amorphous. You know, it's not like you can't, if you were to go looking for it, you couldn't actually find it. But because there's a kind of anxiety, because it's not quite clear, we have to fill it with content, fill it up, right? And so we go looking for things to fill that sense of self up. Like, who am I? What do I think? What do I do? What do I own? My content. And then, of course, if you have content, you need to protect it. You don't want somebody to take it, and you might want it to be better than the next one, and you can always add more. And so this self is like trying to make a fabric whole.

And the Buddha said, you will never succeed—not at creating a self, we all actually succeed at that—or creating a false sense of self. But we will never succeed in fulfilling our disposition. We'll never actually find true happiness, true fulfillment, true contentment. We'll get moments of it, yeah, moments. That's what keeps us going in samsara, those little sweet moments of happiness, of joy, of pleasure, of meaning. But then they go—gone, gone, gone, gone. And so we have to keep going back to the trough to feed, to find. The Buddha said that will never end. It will never end until we introduce something that shifts, interrupts, breaks the cycle, which is often the beginning of the search.

But if everybody has the Buddha nature, has Buddha nature—in other words, you have whatever you're seeking—the Buddha said, you already have that. That doesn't mean you have a sufficient place to live and food on the table, and you know, all of that, but you have, in a spiritual sense, what you are ultimately seeking in order to feel, to experience your life as a Buddha.

And so then, what's the role of a teacher? Dogen quotes an old master who said, “If you want to attain the matter of suchness, your original face, your original perfection, your completeness, your Buddha nature, you must be a person of suchness. If you want to attain this, you have to be a person of suchness.” You already are a person of suchness, so why worry about it then? Dogen says, in other words, those who think that they would like to attain the matter of suchness, to realize themselves, to free themselves, must themselves be such a person. In other words, you can't get it from somewhere else. It's not a thing. The good news is you're not absent of that which you seek. You are already that, have that which you are seeking. So don't worry about it.

Are we done? Not quite. We doubt, we're not so sure. Maybe everybody else, but I don't think me. We're insecure. Every attachment has insecurity. Why else would we attach?

So Huang Po was a really well-known teacher. He was a teacher of Linji, a very important teacher within the Zen tradition, Chan tradition of China. And so one day he says, “All of you people are gobblers of dregs.” We're all just looking for the sediment at the bottom, right? Meanwhile, there's all this exquisite wine or apple cider or whatever tickles your fancy, but we're gobblers of dregs. He said, “If you go on traveling around like this, where will you ever find today? Where will you have today?” He says, “Don't you know that there are no teachers of Chan in all of China?” And this is at the height of Chan: monasteries, teachers, sanghas in all quarters. And so a monk steps forward and says, “Well, wait a minute, what about all those teachers who are teaching in all these various places and leading communities?” And Huang Po said, “I didn't say there's no Chan, I just said there are no Zen teachers.”

Now remember that the nature of the koan is always pointing at the fundamental thing. And so we can look at this and say, well, you know, I get it. Like, you know, I have Buddha nature. You can't give that to me. So I have to realize that within myself. True. Is my life changed by knowing that? No. So that makes it clear that that's not what this koan is pointing to. Just coming to an ordinary, even if true, understanding that doesn’t really change anything fundamentally is not the point of the koan. Koan is about changing something at the fundamental, in a sense, meeting that disposition, meeting your seeking mind, and helping you to leap free into your suchness.

Huang Po, in saying this, at the very moment he's saying this, is a Zen teacher leading a community, right? Nurturing disciples, leading a Sangha. That's true. But again, if we only look at it that way, then nothing changes for us. If the students at that time only saw it that way, then they would never free themselves.

When I was thinking about this morning, working on the talk, I was remembering that when Daido Roshi, when we were doing a lot of wilderness retreats and he was basically leading, he was our guide. He would, as we were developing skills and going out and doing all kinds of things, he would say, “Look, it's important to trust your guide, but you should be prepared to get lost and be able to find your way.” In other words, don't rely on the guide in such a way that if you somehow did get lost, you'd be bereft of capacity. Don't abdicate responsibility, he would say, because otherwise we're not learning something. We're just following somebody.

And so in the pointer where it says “meeting the transcendental potential,” Huang Po is clear on this, on his own transcendental potential, and he sees all of that potential in everyone he meets. But he wants his students to be clear on it. He wants them to realize their transcendental potential, their Buddha nature.

I was also, as I was reflecting on this pointer this morning, “the great capacity of Buddhas and ancestors is completely within their control.” He's really praising Huang Po in this case. “The lifeline of humans and gods is entirely subject to their direction. With a casual word or phrase, he astounds the crowd and stirs the masses, smashes chains, and knocks off fetters.”

And Buddhism in all traditions, particularly in the Mahayana tradition, has a lot of this language which is very poetic. It's very creative, it's very aspirational, right? I mean, you know, if you said, “Look, you may or may not find some morsel of happiness, I'm not sure. Don't get your hopes up,” you know, so it's aspirational. It's aiming high. As Dogen says, aim high because you're a Buddha.

And so we have to learn. How do you do that? How do I have that? How do I have that measure of trust in myself and the Dharma, but not turn that into a fixed notion, an idea, an expectation, right, to which I am always failing? An aspiration isn't like that. It has no end. It's spacious. I'm not forming a fixed idea in my mind of it. When where it's aspirational, very different. But so we have to—how do you hold that and not turn it into something solidified, which then leads to discouragement and frustration?

But another aspect I was thinking of, this pointing is that can it seem to suggest that as a bodhisattva, for practitioners and enlightened being, you're in complete control of everything? Right? It seems to suggest that. That's not what it's saying. Part of the living with and in samsara is meeting squarely and honestly all that we are not in control of. I mean, just sit down and have no thought for 30 minutes. I mean, come on, you can practice that, but you are not in control of your mind, nor do you want to try and practice in that way. Otherwise you'll just become like a tight vise and you will still have thoughts.

And so I think it's really important in that sense of aspiration. We chant our vows to alleviate all suffering, and then we wake up every day in a world in which suffering abounds. And I cannot stop it. I cannot just smash those chains and knock off those fetters everywhere I see them. I can't do that. I don't have that power. And so it's important that we not misunderstand the teachings. But at the same time, they're really pointing at what I can do within myself. Can I deal with my own chains and fetters? In doing that, can I learn a great deal about your chains and fetters—you being everyone, anyone? Can I understand how we tie ourselves up into knots, create a very clear logic within our delusion that makes our very harm-creating actions, our very selfish actions, logical? Can it help us to understand how we can shut down our humanity within ourselves, become dead to that at the same time that we might be becoming wildly successful in the world? And so that when I inflict that deadness upon others, it doesn't matter, I don't feel it, I don't care. It helps us to understand that.

It doesn't, in a way, take the pain away. It's, in a way, even more heartbreaking. Because part of what we're realizing as we practice is it doesn't have to be like that—and not in some utopic fantasy world, but now, in this lifetime, in this human body and mind, we are practicing to realize suchness.

Who gives us the audacity? Who gave you the audacity to think you could do that? It's kind of audacious, right? You need some audacity to do this. But what's the basis of that? You have Buddha nature. You have the disposition that such that on some level, I'm guessing that when you encounter the dharma, even if you're here for the first time, something spoke to you. If it didn't, why would you be here? You know, whenever I—like at the monastery, when a young person comes to do a retreat, you know, they might be still a teenager and they're with their parent and I'm introducing them, I say, “Did you want to come to be here?” Right. Because that's important. Like, you should want to be here, right? Because we have Buddha nature. That's how Buddhism sees it. And it's a truth. It's just a basic truth. It's not because you did something special. Everyone has it.

And so going back to just how do we hear these teachings? Because otherwise, I was saying to somebody this morning, when my teacher would say, “You are responsible.” He would say, “You are responsible for the whole catastrophe.” And I would think, “Oh, my God, I just don't know. How can that be?” Because I heard it as, my responsibility is to make all of this right. And so I thought, “I'm just failing.” That isn't what he was saying. Of course that wasn't what he was saying. Well, what was he saying? What am I responsible for?

There's a koan where Huike, the second Chinese ancestor, came to Bodhidharma and said, “My mind is not at peace.” He was in an inner torment. He was in turmoil. He was seeking. He wanted to be free of that. And he had the sense that it was possible. So he came to this teacher, and he said, “Please, set my mind at peace.” He believed that his teacher could maybe do that for him, give him something that would bring that about. And Bodhidharma said, “Okay, that mind that is in turmoil, bring it to me. I'll set it at peace for you. Bring it to me.” And Huike went and searched and searched and searched. He wanted nothing more than to be able to bring that mind to Bodhidharma. He was feeling it. He was experiencing, seemed to be something. And he came back and he said, “I've searched and I've searched, I cannot find it.” And his teacher said, “There, I've set it at rest for you.”

From an ordinary point of view, in terms of studying with a teacher, I can think, well, there's something I don't have, otherwise I would not see the world, be in this body and mind in this way. The teacher seems to have it. Can you give it to me? Right. So that's sort of a—most students would never admit to that, right? But secretly, secretly, you know, we haven't given up. Teacher's going to save us. So we find out that, okay, that's just not true. That's not going to happen. But then we can look at it as, well, I have Buddha nature, so what do I need a teacher for? I'm going to have to do this for myself. True. There's nothing a teacher can give me. Kind of true. Just meditate. The Buddha did that. Sometimes people say he didn't have a teacher. He certainly did have teachers. He had teachers, he studied with them. But he also sort of came to the point that they came to and realized, “I'm not yet liberated.” They seemed to be satisfied with something that he was not yet. Thank you for that.

I remember many times, particularly in the early years, especially in the early years, where I'd be struggling with something and I would think, you know, I should take this in to my teacher. And I thought, but, you know, I have to resolve this. So I wouldn't bring it up to my teacher. It was true that I needed to resolve this, but I wasn't even giving my teacher a chance to help me. I wasn't understanding something. And after a while, I thought, “Why isn't he helping me?” And then I thought, “Oh.”

And so what is the situation? We begin to recognize what the Buddha called dukkha. Everything, everything has the capacity to lead to discontent, disappointment, dissatisfaction because of our attachments. Ultimately, because there is some sense of a self lacking something, needing something, something outside. We seek. We hear the teachings. We learn how to do meditation. For those of you who learned how to do meditation this morning, congratulations.

When we first learn meditation, if we, I would say, become a serious practitioner, there's really no way we can understand at that moment what has just been communicated, because it's just information. We're learning how to meditate. Meditate. It's sort of out there in the ethos, in the ether, right? People meditate, they're meditating. In Buddhism, meditation is very specific. It has very particular understandings of what constitutes meditation in Buddhism. Why are we doing this? How do we do it? It's not something just in the abstract. It's integral to the whole purpose of the path of Buddhadharma, which is to liberate the body and mind of self and other. And so if we keep practicing, we will begin to understand bit by bit what we encountered in that first moment.

It's sort of like when you're born, you know, you start walking, you know, toddler, you fall, you hang on to stuff. You know, a toddler's not thinking about, “Oh, my God, the implications of this.” They're just trying to stay upright, right? Because it's crazy. Like, who stands on two legs, right? We have no sense of the possibility of this, right? How do we meet all that we experience? How do we meet it? That's the key. If we meet it in the same way we've met everything in our life, then the same thing keeps happening. The Buddha said there's an impulse to shut it down. No. And there are a hundred different ways of saying no, or just grab on and ride with it. There are 10,000 different ways of holding on. He said, there's a middle way. There's a middle way that avoids both of those extremes. It's not an idea, it's not an answer, a question you're just going to answer and then you've got it. It's not a formula. It's a living thing.

The teacher is a mirror to mirror the student back to themselves. Because it's, you know, we're just so used to ourselves. You've been living in your body and mind since the beginning. It's very difficult to see ourselves with any kind of objectivity. We're too invested. And so part of what the teacher does is they mirror. They just mirror back.

I remember years ago, there was a student at the monastery who had a lot of anger. And, you know, there were reasons she had a lot of anger. And one night she went into dokusan—it was just the residents, it was just us in the zendo—and suddenly we hear, “I'm angry. I'm so angry. I'm really angry.” It went on and on. And then there was a pause. And then her teacher responded, “Me too.” Ding, ding, ding, ding, ding, ding, ding. That was it. And I thought, did she see? Did she see what he was offering to her?

It's important that the teacher doesn't need anything from the student. What does that mean? If the teacher needs something from the student, they're already in trouble. The teacher naturally wants the student to be free. As a teacher in our lineage, we take vows to teach, to offer any kind of medicine to anybody. And if it's a Dharma student, then it's the Dharma.

That's one of the reasons the Guardian Council has been set up. Daido Roshi spoke about this years ago. He said, the teacher, if somebody comes and asks for the teaching, the teacher has a vow to say yes. But sometimes the student may not be ready for that commitment, or they may not be looking in the right place. This medicine may not be the medicine they need.

And so he said, the Guardian Council needs to be set up. He said, because I can't say no. But sometimes that person may need to be redirected to something that will actually be helpful to them. This may not be that thing for them, or it may not be time yet. They may need some more study or some more experience or something. And so part of the role of the Guardian Council is to be able to be that, right? It's interesting. It's important. The student can come and go. They can practice or not practice. But the teacher doesn't turn away from the student. That's their commitment. Their vow is to do all that they can to bring wisdom to help the student discover their own wisdom, to help the student realize their own great compassion. They can't do that for the student.

The Buddha was very clear. He said, I can offer these teachings, basically report from within my own experience of what I have seen to be true and what I learned through my own path. I can offer that to you. And so he said, a teacher should be not tight-fisted, which means, don't hold that back, be generous. But he said, having offered that, now you must go. And isn't that what we do for those of you who came here this morning? You come in, so nice to see you. Thank you for coming. We give you beginning instruction and then we take you, you're shown your seat. Now it's you. You take that seat. You're the Buddha. You're the one who has the disposition. You're the one who brought yourself here. And because it's something we can only do ourselves, how wonderful that we do that together.

A student can bring all kinds of questions to a teacher: relationships, family, work, the world. And the teacher is a teacher of the Dharma. They're not a job coach, a relationship coach, a therapist. Some teachers are therapists and are therapists and teachers to their students. There's mixed views on that, just so you know. Personally, I don't think that's a great idea. But the teacher will respond to whatever the student brings, in my experience and from my own perspective from within the Dharma.

I remember years ago, a student had just received jukai. It was a student who was a physician and worked in a pediatric ICU. Very soon after that, they called Daido Roshi in the middle of the night and said, “Look, I've got this child here. They're basically brain dead. They have no possibility. The parents want me to remove the life support system. I just took a vow to affirm life and not kill. What do I do?” And Daido Roshi said, “You received the precepts. They're yours. I can't answer this question for you. You're the one; take that responsibility.” And so the teacher is trying to bring the student to the Dharma so they themselves can see how to bring that into this relationship, this work situation, this family, this world.

The Dharma does not give you answers. It doesn't say, “Okay, in this particular crisis that we're in right now, go to page 25. Follow the rules.” Right? There's no cookbook, or you're the cookbook. That's the deal. The Dharma helps us understand the nature of the self and how things work at the deepest level. And helps us to open our heart so that the pain that we experience in the world is painful. And also that we develop this very deep and essential capacity to unbind so that we can allow that pain to come in, but not take it on. It'll kill you, right? It'll overwhelm you. And for every honest practitioner, there are moments of overwhelm. There are moments where you just feel overwhelmed. That's honest. That's honest. But that's just a moment. Recognize that. Don't set up house there.

The teacher will disappoint you. Just telling you up front. What does that mean? Because the student will have some expectations. Some of them are quite reasonable. There's a role that the student has. There's a role that the teacher has. We should respectively know what those are. The student has a responsibility in training. The teacher has a responsibility. The teacher has a greater responsibility. I think of it as a sacred trust. But the teacher will not fulfill your dreams and all of your expectations. But they should never betray your trust. If they do, that can be repaired. But the teacher has to be supremely committed to that, right? Because trust broken is harder to be regained. And so that's why I think of it as a sacred trust. It has to have resilience and strength and stability, but also to understand in a way, it can be fragile.

In the commentary, it says, “The essence of this school that has come down from ancient times is sometimes holding on, sometimes letting go, sometimes killing, sometimes giving life, sometimes releasing, sometimes gathering up, sometimes being gentle, sometimes being fierce, sometimes affirming, sometimes negating, not fixed. Skillful means.” Means skillful for this person in this moment. Towards what end? Relinquishing attachments, illuminating false views.

I remember Daido Roshi one time telling me that a student had come in to dokusan and said, “I really want you to push me, take me to the limit, take me to my edge. I really want to free myself.” And so he did, and they crumbled. And I said, “So what? So what about that?” He says, “Well, they're showing me.” He says, “They say they want something, but then they're showing me what their capacity is at this moment, what they're actually ready for, or what their actual level of trust is.” He said, “That's more important than their words.” He said, “In a sense, I have to teach to that. I can't ignore that.” And so, in a sense, the teacher is always trying to meet the present capacity of the student. And then more.

It's like when my mother was teaching me to swim, and we got in the water and she said, “Okay, I've got a peanut butter and jelly sandwich right here. It's waiting for you. You gotta come get it, right? You gotta come get it.” And I would swim and I'd swim. And then she started stepping back. I was like, wait a minute. But then she would stop and she'd catch me, right? Stretching, expanding, extending, so that I could see that my limit was not this, it was larger.

All of this is so that we can see for ourselves what the Buddha realized. You have the disposition, your very nature is non-dual, is already free, is already peaceful, and there are a few things that we have to attend to. Suzuki Roshi said, “You're perfect and complete and could use a little work.” But when we do that work, to speak of it that way, from that understanding of faith in Buddha nature, then what we see that is holding us back is not your nemesis, it's not your enemy, it's not a failure.

Bodhidharma said, “When you meet adversity, don't be surprised.” It makes sense. When we really understand karma, the nature of the mind, then when we experience those things within ourselves, it makes sense. I understand this. I understand why this is arising and why it's so strong, right? And it helps to not take it so personally, right? It's not you. It's just an emotion. It's not you. It's just a thought. It's not you. It's just a memory. It's not you. But it is your responsibility, because there it is. And you can strengthen that and act on it. And that's not going to go so well. Or there is shift.

So the teacher can only point. The student has to step forward. Dogen says, if we don't step forward, we can't encounter the Dharma. But stepping forward just happens in this moment, and then this moment, and then this moment. Years ago, we were on a camping trip, and a student was telling us a story of being at a talk by the Dalai Lama. And he was talking about the suffering and the work, and he just got overwhelmed and started sobbing. And she was like, “Even the Dalai Lama.” And then she stopped talking. And I said, “Well, wait a minute. But what happened?” It was like that was the end of the story. I said, “No, what happened next?” And she said—and I wasn't there, but I knew—and she said, “He paused, and then he kept on going with the talk.” I said, “Exactly. He stepped forward.” Yes, he was free enough to be able to be overwhelmed by that pain and suffering because it was not outside, but he was also free enough to not take it on. It's not him, but it is his responsibility.

I'll end with a poem:

Sitting by the river, crying out for a drink.  
This thirst is older than time.  
This water has never been absent.  
Let's go down together to the river's edge  
and discover the realm beyond wanting.  
Don't you know you were born as a water dragon,  
already satisfied in the season beyond knowing?

Thank you for your practice. Thank you for being here this morning. Thanks so much for listening.

For meditation supplies such as cushions, incense, liturgical instruments, Dharma books, and more, visit monasterystore.org—support for your spiritual practice at home.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Talk Location: Zen Center of New York City
Title: Fusatsu: Remembering Sacredness, The Three Pure Precepts
Extracted Text:
Good morning again. I must say that the chanting feels really strong. Thich Nhat Hanh used to say, the future Buddha is the Sangha. It's not one singular person, but it's a collective. The Maitreya Buddha is the Buddha of the future. It's what all of us are doing. So I could feel that this morning. I got a little chills and a little teary right now. So strong in this renewal of vow ceremony—both our own and together as a collective—the harmful karma that we've created, harmful actions.

And I also want to bring in some aspect of the question of what is sacred, our sacred life, what is sacredness? Treating things with respect, treating ourselves with respect, and creating sacred space, is what we're doing—a respectful space together.

This ceremony, primarily Fusatsu renewal of vows, sometimes translated as continuous, good, wholesome practice, rather than ceasing from unwholesome action, is what we're renewing. It gives us a chance to atone, to be at one, not separate from any, whatever kinds of harmful karma or separation we have created. Created by me. If you haven't noticed, Zen liturgy is very direct. We don't look over there. It's created by me since of old. And to recommit to practicing good, actualizing good for others, being guided by the precepts—the moral and ethical teachings—to live in harmony with our nature.

And these precepts aren't fixed. They're seen from different perspectives, but from a Mahayana perspective, they're very open and in accord with time. What time is it? What's our place in what's happening? What's our position? What's the circumstance? So at one moment something might be the right thing to do, and in the next moment, totally wrong. So we have to be in accord with what the circumstances are. And it's all to save life, to be of benefit.

But we also need to recognize that as human beings, there's always some harm that is being created all the time, just because we have to live, we have to eat, we have to have shelter, and we have to have food and clothing. And this is all, in some ways, harming something so that we can have life. But this has to be kept, of course, in balance.

So this ceremony goes back to the time of the Buddha. I'm not going to go into that too much. He would gather his community on the full moon and everyone would look at the precepts and say out loud to each other where one transgressed, where we broke a precept. Can you imagine, if we all went around today and the precepts that we have—the ten, we have sixteen in our tradition, in the Zen tradition—and each, every religion has sort of these moral and ethical guidelines which can seem very similar.

But Buddhism is based on non-self, it's non-theistic. So there's nothing—how might we be guided when there's no external person or thing that demands us to be a certain way? There's no God who is judging. That's all based on our own human experience. And from a Buddhist perspective, actions are both good—in a relative world, both good and bad have consequences. And these consequences shape our future experience in a concept known as karma. And they also go backwards so they can affect what has happened. It's all happening now. There's only now, there's only this moment. But how we understand the past affects what we will act in the future. Only now, because we're in this moving, unfixed momentariness of our life. That's what our life is. We have this body and it's changing and it's just seeing into the aggregates, into the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, mind, that they're all not fixed.

So our sixteen precepts begin with three refuges in the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha. And then there's the three pure precepts: not creating evil or harm, practicing good, and actualizing good for others. And then the ten grave precepts is how to do that: To be affirming of life, not kill life. To be giving, to not steal. This is how it's phrased in our tradition. Honor the body, do not misuse sexuality. Manifest truth, do not lie. Proceed clearly, do not cloud the mind. See the perfection, don't speak of others' errors and faults. Realize self and other as one, don't elevate yourself and blame others. Give generously, don't be withholding. Actualize harmony, do not be angry. And experience the intimacy of things, don't defile the three treasures.

So all of the precepts are about living the life of a Buddha—not about how to be good and live by the precepts, but rather to help us and challenge us in a way to examine who we are as killers, who we are as stealers, as misusers of sexuality, as liars, as addicts of intoxicants, as blamers, misers, angry people, abusers of the three treasures. So if we look deep enough, we can see we are not separate, that we have all of that potential within us. And if you have the Buddhist perspective of karma, you might say we've done this hundreds of thousands of times before. In some way, we know this, we know this.

So Buddha realized there is non-self, and the precepts are based on this non-self as the basis, as the fundamental—that there's that emptiness of all the conditions and that he said the word karma simply means intentional action, this relationship between what we choose to do and then what we make of ourselves, how we shape ourselves and are shaped by ourselves, through action, moment to moment, by this coming together as this. Right now, there's all these causes and conditions that form each of us. But it's moving, it's not fixed. But I manifest as Hojin, as a blessing, and here we are. And this is not fixed. It's constantly in a process of movement, and it's a very... and all of that is born of my body, from my consciousness, from my body, my mouth, my thoughts. So it's a very open system.

And then this future setup of our karma will be either skillful or unskillful—what we will inherit further downstream in the flow of our consciousness. And we can't always see that. So this principle of cause and effect is the centerpiece of the Buddha's teaching. And many teachers say, just understand cause and effect, just understand karma. So there's a lot that we can look at here.

This is a ceremony. And I want to just say again what Maezumi Roshi, Daido's teacher, speaks about on what ceremonial action is. He says this word "ceremony," karamonia, is related to cura, meaning cure—the act of healing or being healed. In other words, ceremony is an act that cures or heals or by which something is healed. In having a ceremony or in doing ceremonial action, we must ask what is healed by what? What is healed by what?

He says the definition of ceremony also includes the word law, the laws of life. From morning until night, our life is continuous ritual, governed by rules, regulations, and laws. Behaving informally, can we follow the laws or regulations that are essential to living a healthy life? He says the word heal means be healthy, be whole and sound, make our life healthy. Is ceremonial. So in renewal of vows, we're making our life wholesome and healthy again by freshening the direction we want to live in. That's healing, that's ceremony.

And we have these rituals, these things we're doing. And he says, don't think ritual's that far away. We're constantly—our lives are full of ritual, as I said. Some people say, oh, there's too much ritual in Zen. But when we look at it, it's happening all the time. From the moment we get up and put our feet on the floor and take our shower and make our coffee and brush our teeth and wash our face and eat, going about these simple things in an orderly way, that's ritual.

So when we do this with others, as the Buddha did, we build sacred trust in community because others help us see our blind spots. We can't do it alone, right? We know that others help us see our blind spots. They inform us in one way or another what our actions are doing and how they're landing.

So I wanted to look at today, the first pure precept, a little deeper: not creating evil, not creating harm. And in some ways, I could say, period, end of suffering, don't do it, don't make more harm. We're already acknowledging we do and we have, but don't create harm.

So in a sense, I think these precepts are the highest art practice—to be conscious of our actions, what we're creating, we need to acknowledge we're always creating harm just by living in this sacred body on the sacred planet with sacred beings. So how do we respect life? When Buddha developed his teaching on karma, it was not by speculating, but he was carefully observing his own life, exactly how things worked in his own life. And it's true today, that's how you learn about it. We observe what's happening in our life each.

The clarity on karma comes from each of us studying, inspecting with focus and clarity exactly how things go for us. How's this going? Where is it landing? Daido Roshi used to say, what you do and what happens to you are the same thing. And for some of us, this karma has lasted a lifetime. Since we've heard it, what you do and what happens to you are the same thing.

So the principle of karma has two parts: the karma of cause and the karma of effect or the result. So the cause, as Buddha says, is a way of acting and to bring to consciousness the acts that we create that are unresolved. So the acts that we do that leave a kind of hangover, the feeling that we're doing something that's not kosher. We're doing something and we could feel it. It's got a hangover. It's not quite kosher. It's continuing to be resolved.

So he says we're like a weather system—it will produce increasing cloudiness of similarly unresolved situations. And he uses the word that haunts. Haunts this particular relationship and others until we deal with it. So if we feel that weather system, that not so kosher, something still resolving in our relationship, according to the teachings we have since beginningless beginning a mass of unresolved karma. That doesn't sound like good news. But if we're getting conscious, then we can be at one with it and resolve it. That's the thing, you know, jealousy—I've had that affliction since I can remember nursery school. And I don't know how long it's been going. And I still feel it and it haunts me. I feel it, really get to like, what is it? What do I not feel like I have enough of right now that I'm jealous, that I can't be happy and someone else is happy? Not everywhere, but things. There's a certain unresolved hangover that I feel. Some of us, it's being prideful or stingy, whatever. You know, you have to look at what happens that you see repeating. That's a kind of a hangover and it just doesn't feel right. And that's good news. Actually, this is all good news. That's why we're practicing. That's why it's called practice. Because we want to bring out of the darkness of ignorance our consciousness.

And we see this at a large scale right now. You know, the fear of darkness. Darkness is where wisdom is, actually. We're afraid of darkness and they send you earth. A lot about that helps us to see that that's where so many nutrients are unfinished. Created by cause remains in the body. And we experience this as tension. When something's unresolved, we get tense about it. Don't you? Like when I feel this jealousy arrive, I know my jaw gets really tight. I can't hear things well. I'm absorbed by this feeling. And so I don't even hear people talking to me when it's inactivated. I can't even hear what the person's saying in a lot of cases. So these are good clues that something's happening.

So we feel it in our body in the form of unacknowledged feelings, emotions, sensations that we might hold at bay. And we get really tense, finding ourselves resisting our bodies. And then there's this log jam of incomplete experience in our body. I see head shaking. Yep, know that one. The log jam. It just gets really tight.

We have ways that we can breathe and see what's happening. It's like, oh, there you are, there you are. Coming into consciousness out of the dark doesn't feel great, can be discomforting. We may want to run, we may want to perpetuate it because it also can bring a feeling that feels momentarily good. Like anger can feel super good for a moment and then the haunt comes—That was not so kosher. That was not so good.

How do we find the wisdom? Intention, not inattention. Intention to not make harm to ourself and others when we're in that. Because that's when it happens. Usually in that unawareness of what we're experiencing, that's where we create more harm. That's what I notice, at any rate.

So we have our zazen, which allows us to take time to learn, to slow down, see what's appearing. You know, there's a mantra in somatic experience that says slow down to go fast, slow down to experience, to go fast. But we just want to go fast. We don't want this there. Get out, get rid of it. And then to not personally identify and hold space. It's not you, it's not you. This is the karma moving through. There's sensations telling us, practicing good kindness, allowing space, allowing them to be seen, allowing what needs to be seen, seen, metabolized, released when ready, connect with our grounded body, our open heart and our clear mind.

So when we atone—at one with—doesn't mean something just drops off and "ah, I'm at one with it." We have to keep going back again and doing more of this process of allowing it to be seen, metabolized and released. That's how that at-one-ment continues.

I love the work of Marion Woodman, a lot of you—she's a Jungian analyst and she has this quote that I've always loved that says, "If we could allow the pace of our meetings to slow down to the pace of our hearts, we might find genuine understanding." Whether that's meeting each other or situation or ourself. If we could allow the pace of our meeting, whatever we're experiencing, to slow down to the pace of our heart, catch up to it, we might find genuine understanding.

And then there's the karma of effect. That's good. As Buddha put it, beings are owners of their actions, heirs of their actions; they originate from their actions, are bound to their actions, have their actions as refuge. It is an action that distinguishes beings as inferior and superior. Contemplate the entire bank of unresolved karma that accompanies us in each moment, recognizing that all this actually is the result of previous actions.

The Buddha realized the absolute nature of things, human and non-human, is without this fixed characteristic. And because we have human consciousness, we think because we have intention in there, not but an intention. Once we see what's emerging, we make decisions, we perceive good and bad, we perceive pain and pleasure for the most part, that everything we do has an effect. So everything that we do, Buddha realized, has a moral quotient for ourselves and others. And he said to begin practicing means to begin by ceasing from evil, from harming.

Dogen wrote in an essay on not creating harm. Now stay with it. This is Dogen. He's going to somersault us a bit. If we don't do harm or make harm, it doesn't exist on its own. Okay? If we don't do harm or make harm, it doesn't exist on its own. It takes someone or something to create it.

So when the precepts were often referred to as standards for monastic bodhisattvas. And a Bodhisattva is a great practitioner walking on the path toward Buddhahood. All of you, all of us, myself, walking on the path to Buddhahood to be of benefit to all beings. And we won't check out until we do that. Every one of them comes through. Every one of them as well as us. Sentient beings are numberless. I vow to save them. It's continuous.

And Asanga, who was a 4th century teacher, founder of the Mind Only or Yogacara school, made it clear that a lay Bodhisattva path—so your lay practitioners, I'm a monastic—is an essential element of the Mahayana and that got passed to the Zen tradition. And these three pure precepts were written out as embracing and sustaining standards of conduct, morality: Do not create evil, embracing and sustaining good qualities, practicing good, embracing and sustaining living beings, actualizing good for others.

And lay and monastic bodhisattvas embrace not so much what form our life takes, but our embracing and sustaining the standards of conduct of our particular life role. Letting go of our self-centeredness, which often brings harm to others. So we're encouraged to appreciate the embracing aspect, to experience harmony with our actions, embracing our conduct. We're encouraged to do that. Embrace it, not push it away. Get rid of it. Where are we going to put it? It's like we put our trash out on the curb. But where's it going? It's not like we get rid of it. It's going somewhere. It has another place it's going, right? She works there on the receiving end.

So there's a little book by Buddha I have on the Dhammapada I travel with. And in there it said, "Refrain from harm, do all good, purify the mind. This is the teaching of all Buddhas. Mind precedes all mental states. Mind is their chief, they are all mind-wrought."

So Dogen transmitted this precept of embrace and sustain standards of conduct. And he wrote an essay, "Refrain from All Harm." And he tells the story of this Chinese Zen teacher named Bird's Nest, who was called this because he lived up in a tree and he was called Bird's Nest.

So the story goes, there was a statesman and a poet who was the student of Bird's Nest. And one time the statesman stood below the tree and called up to him and said, "Looks pretty precarious and dangerous up there." And Bird's Nest said down to him, "Looks pretty precarious and dangerous down there." Indeed it is precarious and dangerous to actually go about in the world outside of trees, because it's so easy to get into, cause harm and forget about doing good.

Once a statesman asked, "What is the great meaning of Buddhist teachings?" That was always a question in ancient China by a lot of practitioners. And his teacher replied, "So what's the great meaning of Buddhist teaching?" And the teacher replied, "Refrain from harm, do all good." And the statesman said, "Though this is so, even a three-year-old child can say that." And the teacher said, "A three-year-old child may be able to say it, but an eighty-year-old person cannot practice it." And the statesman bowed in thanks to that response.

And Dogen comments on this story saying, "Since the family of Buddhas arises from conditions, thus conditions arise from the family of Buddhas. It is not that harm does not exist, it's just that it is not done." And in this writing called "Shawaku Makusa," the characters mean "do not do all harm." But it can also read as Dogen says, "All harm is not done. Harm is not empty, it is not done. Harm is not form, it is not done. Harm is not not done, it is just not done." I know you'll have to take that little strip home, but these are the Dharma's not easy, right? We have to stretch a bit. It's not to twist us up and say, oh, this is just hogwash. You know, we have to sit with it. We have to work with these words to see the great reality that's being shown to us. Seeing it is not substantial and not denying what is. Here. We need both legs—that something is not substantial, and yet here it is. Here's the situation. This is what's arising. Just this. Otherwise it's one-sided.

Dogen says ceasing from evil is the abiding place of all Buddhas. This abiding place is the state of non-duality, of not knowing and non-separation. The Sixth Ancestor defines zazen as the state of mind in which there is no separation between subject and object, no space between you and me, or all the space up and down, right and wrong, being open to all the way of our lives and not having an answer. The flowering of zazen is doing good for others. Dogen says this is to transcend the profane and to be beyond the holy. This is to liberate oneself and others.

I love that the word Buddha is related to the English word "bud." A flower's awakening or opening. We could say the "budd away." The "budd away" is unattainable. The blossoming, the fruitful practice field where we can practice all of it. Budding, fruitful, blossoming. How do we lead ourselves? That's the question. To lead ourselves, to lead the people. Let harmony pervade everywhere. We can do this. This is how we heal and bloom the living as we are, serving within the intimate web of our collective beingness.

And I'd like to, since we have a short amount of time—this was an essay that somebody passed to me this week called "You'd Sacredness" by Jaya John.

The Ancient: Your sacredness. Your sacredness.  
The Ancient One spoke with a depth of prayer.  
Something immeasurably divine, sacred and miraculous is happening now.  
You are happening. You are alive.  
Life comes down to two questions: What do you consider sacred? And how do you treat your sacred things?  
You are a sacred land. This means everything.  
People cannot treat you however they wish, nor can you treat yourself according to any impulse or mood.  
You are a place where ancestors rest and ceremonies are performed.  
You are sacred. Water, fire, sky, earth.  
The first act in a beautiful life is to recognize the truth of who you are.  
You are Sacredness.  
As long as you stay in this truth, you may have your beautiful life.  
This world will often act to persuade you otherwise.  
It will whisper and shout that you are not sacred, that you are less than, that your entire life is soulless.  
You are a salmon swimming upstream against a degrading current that wants your soul.  
You were born to swim upstream to spawn beauty in your life and feed generations their own chance to live, always upstream against a current.  
This can be hard. It can be the sweetest journey.  
Our great misunderstanding is that we believe some things are meant to be done soullessly and other things soulfully.  
Gradually, more and more we live soullessly, believing it to be an easier way.  
Nothing is meant to be lived soullessly.  
It all has the Buddha nature.  
Ease has nothing to do with it.  
You are a soulful thing.  
Live soulfully.  
Live the way of the Buddha.

Thanks so much for listening.

For meditation supplies such as cushions, incense, liturgical instruments, dharma books, and more, visit monasterystore.org. Support for your spiritual practice at home.
Speaker: Jody Hojin Kimmel

Title: Dharma Encounter: Teacher-Student Relationship
Extracted Text:
The following Dharma encounter with Geoffrey Shugen Arnold, Roshi, took place at Zen Mountain Monastery at the conclusion of a week-long meditation session. As you'll hear, Dharma Encounters begin with the introduction of a topic related to Zen practice and training. Students then volunteer to present their understanding of the topic or a question for the Dharma Encounter teacher to reflect on. The presence of fellow students means that anyone in attendance can benefit from the exchange. We hope you enjoy.

Good morning, everybody. So this morning is Dharma Encounter as we are concluding our April session. For those unfamiliar, this is one of the teaching methods in our tradition, along with teisho, the mando, face-to-face teaching, and everyday interactions. In the history of Buddhism, going back to the Buddha and in many practice-based traditions, there are meetings between a teacher and a student in which a question is raised, a point is made. Sometimes it's instructional, sometimes it's guiding, sometimes it's what we call in our tradition direct pointing, which is not so much about information, but really trying to shift a student's state of mind, open a door, to reveal something about their own self-nature. And so Dharma Encounter is meeting each other in that field.

What I wanted to focus on today was to continue a little bit with what I took up yesterday in the teisho, which is the training relationship—speaking of it that way—between the student and teacher. Everybody who encounters Buddhism learns pretty quickly that an essential teaching, particularly in Mahayana Buddhism, is that everyone is endowed with Buddha Nature, which means from the beginning you have what you seek in an ultimate sense. If what we're looking for is an ultimate experience of peace, fulfillment, a resolution of all that is not resolved in the deepest sense, then the Buddha realized that we all have that within us. We're not going to find that outside.

Within many of the traditions of Buddhism, there is the role of the teacher, beginning with the Buddha. So what is that, given that the student is already in full possession of an enlightened mind? So that's what I wanted to look at a little bit.

Now, drawing on yesterday's teachings from Master Dogen: Dogen taught that Shakyamuni Buddha saw Mahakasyapa, his disciple, in person, and Mahakasyapa saw the Venerable Ananda, his successor, in person. And Ananda bowed formally to Mahakasyapa's Buddha face. This is face-to-face transmission. Dogen says an ancestor, a teacher or a disciple, cannot be a Buddha or an ancestor—or I would say a student—without having face-to-face transmission. It's like pouring water into the ocean and spreading it endlessly, or like transmitting the lamp and allowing it to shine forever. The disciple sees the teacher, the teacher sees the disciple. They meet each other, they see each other. As Dogen said, in person.

There are many ways we can think of and talk about being a student, of the way we come in, having been students, most of us, in school for many years, which means you go to a classroom, typically there's a teacher who has certain information, has gained certain knowledge, has certain understanding. They impart that in various ways. The student is there to receive that, to learn, to integrate it. And so we come in with years of history embodied within us about being a student. And of course, we're going to carry much of that in. Some of that's going to be helpful, some of it may not be.

So what I wanted to look at is some of the basic tensions, what I often think of as tensions—important, necessary tensions. Within practice, we often think of tension as a negative thing, stress-related, causing pain and discomfort. This is different. It can cause discomfort and stress, for that matter, but in a healthy way, in a way of working towards something, another resolution, really. So while I think of it often in terms of tensions, we can also look at it in terms of dualities.

So here are a few to reflect on. Having Buddha Nature, we each, as students, need to trust ourselves in a deep way. Daido Roshi used to say that over and over again: trust yourself, profoundly trust in yourself. We also need to trust the teacher if we're going to study with the teacher. Otherwise, obviously, it doesn't make sense to do that. Sometimes those are in alignment. What if they're not? What is trust in the teacher and trust in oneself? To rely on your own understanding, because you're developing understanding, you're here. We're here to develop understanding—direct understanding, transformational understanding, the understanding of awakened mind. And so to rely on understanding, at the same time to question our understanding, to be able to doubt our understanding.

The tension between speaking too much, speaking too little—what does that mean? What might that mean in the context of being a student, particularly in the Zen tradition? There's a lot of emphasis on relying too much on the intellect, the conceptual, trying to figure things out, make everything line up, bring the Dharma into conformity with a linear, rational way of seeing things based on what we already know. And so there's a lot of encouragement to free ourselves of that. But at the same time, on the other side, we can ignore the intellect and conceptual in being a student.

It's common at moments, sometimes often, to be insecure, to doubt oneself, to doubt one's understanding, doubt one's capacity. And so there's building confidence. But on the other side of that is being arrogant, being confident in an unrealistic way, being confident in a way that's not actually confidence, but it's just self-grasping.

It's very common in being a student to want to seek the approval of the teacher. If that relationship doesn't matter to us, it's not a healthy relationship. But that can become a kind of seeking of approval that is not healthy. But on the other side of that is not seeking approval in a way that's not healthy. Wanting to be special, wanting to be seen, wanting to be the best, a shining star. On the other side of that is wanting not to be seen, wanting not to be heard, wanting to be challenged, not wanting to be challenged.
