In gaining confidence, which is a really essential part of the practice and training, there's gaining confidence, which can become arrogance, and then there's humility. In a sense, as we gain confidence, continuing to have and develop humility becomes even more important and more real. There's following the example of the teacher—just natural. It's important, it's one of the ways we learn. I spoke about that yesterday. But not imitating.

And so in a way, we can think of these as tensions or dualities. And in that sense, they're not questions that we just seek an answer to and then the tension goes away. They're lived experiences. The Buddha said our impulse is to swing between extremes. One of the fundamental extremes in Buddhism is annihilism—misunderstanding, emptiness, nothing is, nothing exists. And on the other hand is eternalism—everything is just a material object that exists unto itself. But there are many ways we can look at the Middle Way: rejecting and grasping, too loose, too tight. And those extremes and the freedom from those extremes, actually liberating ourselves within the Middle Way, is a lived thing. It's not a formula that we have to find the correct answer to.

And so, how do you live those tensions, those dynamics in the path of being a student of the Way? How do we seek the teachings without abdicating responsibility, as Dogen says, wholeheartedly, unreservedly, relying upon the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha? How do we do that without turning away from ourselves? How to have faith in the Buddha Nature, in Buddha Nature, in being a person of suchness, while accepting our own delusion, accepting other people's, having faith in other people's Buddha Nature, while accepting their delusion and attachments?

In the case that I took up yesterday, Master Keizan said—he talked about in terms of purity, and I spoke about that. But I want to frame this in terms of selflessness. He said, those who are really selfless do not even establish selflessness. And so their vessel, their Buddha body as a vessel of the Dharma, is not established either. This is why the path of teacher and apprentice, or teacher and student, merge. This is how they merge: that those on the path of selflessness do not even establish selflessness. He said, when you enter into the Way, then you can be called a teacher. You can also be called a student. Therefore, the student climbs over the head of the teacher, and the teacher descends to the feet of the disciple. At this point, there is no duality, no discrimination. The term Buddha, body, vessel, student, teacher, no longer really applies. The disappearance of this represents the realization of the path.

And so, in that way, he's really laying out in a very deep, ultimate sense, the path of the student of the Way. And so that's what I wanted to look at. What is student in Buddha Dharma? What is that? We use that term often and freely. We have a path for entering into formal training as a training student. It was a very clear and deliberate process and path. But anyone who practices the Dharma can consider themselves a student of the Dharma. What is student and what is teacher? What is teacher? It's really important that in our training that we are clarifying this and not just assuming, making assumptions, or taking for granted. Because I am here, I'm a student. Because I have a gray robe, I'm a student. Because I go to dokusan and ask a question, I'm a student. There's some truth to those things, but they're really more on the surface, and the student has some very particular responsibilities. The responsibilities of being a student. The teacher, of course, has very particular responsibilities that are essential to being in that role. So what is student? What is teacher? That's what I wanted to look at today.

So Daio will come first. And part of this is good in and of itself and as training. But also that next month, at the end of the May session, Daio will be giving a short talk on a Case Koan and then inviting all of you dragons and elephants to engage him in Dharma Encounter, as I am doing today. So this is both training for that. It's for you dragons and elephants to sharpen your claws and tusks.

So Daio will go first and do three bows. And I'd like to open this up to any of you who are doing the ango, and also, it would be good to have some of you who have spent years in training and have experience in that role as a student, have really engaged that at a deep level and over time. And also some of you who are doing the ango, who are much newer to that, who are newer in being a student, or maybe not even students yet, or training, formal training. And if any of you who just got up, did last month's Dharma Encounter, maybe yield to somebody who hasn't done it yet, this ango.

---

**Student:** Shusanji, one of the aspects of my service position that I've been aware of is speaking more. And so my words... your words, to make a dichotomy. So considering what I'm going to say and not thinking it to death, the dichotomy of teacher and student—say yesterday, you talked about, whose vessel is it? Is it my vessel? Is it your vessel? Are they my words? Are they your words? Are they the words of a koan I just read in a book? I'm just noticing that that's not... that's not completely fluent in me. I'm... I'm setting things up.

**Teacher:** By whose authority do you sit in this role as chief disciple? Anything more? Anything more? Who would you leave out? Who have you left out? The one wearing the robe, the one who is clarifying what is underneath this robe. Whether we feel ready or not, capable or not, we have to step forward under our own authority. May your life go well. Thank you for your teaching.

---

**Student:** So, Shusanji, very soon after I became your student, I came into the room and I said something like, "I don't think I know what to do with this relationship," or something like, "I don't know how to use this relationship to the best." And you kind of sat up and you said, "This is not a relationship. When you come in here, it's just you." And I had no idea what you were talking about, and it kind of hurt at the time. And I feel like, you know, all these years later, maybe I maybe a little bit understand what you meant, but I would like to know, because I still don't feel like I really know how to use this in the best way. If I ask you again, how would you answer me?

**Teacher:** Now, let me ask it this way. Let me answer this. Recognizing that you don't know how to fully use this, how does that sit inside of you? That's how. That's how it resolves. When yesterday I said, there needs to be discomfort or else it's not alive. But I can speak of it in terms of tensions. I could speak of it in terms of discomforts, different aspects of a lack of comfort, of dis-ease. And that's... you know, we're so conditioned to many unhealthy ways in which there's tension and discomfort. But here, it's really vital.

You know, I mentioned that all the years I went into dokusan, and in the very last times I ever saw my teacher in dokusan, you know, I never went in casually. You know, I was always a little bit... you know, and in the beginning, it was a lot of fear, a lot of anxiety, a lot of the things I was just mentioning, a lot of myself, a lot of my ego. And as those things changed, you know, in a sense, what remained was your question: How do I really use this, right? Have I really... am I doing that? Have I really, you know... and not use him, you know, it can sound like that. It's not that. Use what he was offering by sitting in that seat and ringing that bell and inviting me in. And so what I said, I stand by that, and I'll leave you with that.

But at the same time, you know, there is another side to that. You know, relationship—I always pause a little bit in using that in terms of this, because relationship is kind of like love. Relationship has so much meaning, you know, I am in relationship with... but there is that. And the danger of not seeing that is that the teacher has a very important role and responsibility, which means we are in relationship, right? So to say it's all you, there's a truth to that. That's what I was pointing to. But I am part of this, the teacher is part of this, right? It's not just the student. That's what makes it alive. May your life go well. Thank you for your teaching.

---

**Student:** Shusanji, so as a student, I try to show up authentically. What does that mean for me? What that means is I'm so aware that I hold myself back and I have a tension that kind of has, in my mind, defined me. And so being authentic and showing up for me is to be able to not be holding it back with that old barrier of my story about myself. And when I'm... and it's been my struggle. So how can you be authentic in the midst of that story, in facing your teacher?

**Teacher:** Well, I don't know how. I try to do it, but as I'm with you, it feels like it unfolds. It happens sometimes. In terms of what you bring to that for me is, I see your enthusiasm, and that kind of allows me to open up more. I don't know if... I don't know how to do it. Like, I don't know how to say, "Oh, how do I access that?" But I think it's just like by relaxing. Because I do believe that I have a certain kind of wisdom that I bring. And I also feel that I don't allow it to show. And I want it to show.

**Teacher:** So do I. I mentioned this morning, I think, that when I began sitting in that seat and students came in, that I began to learn so much about being a student. And there was so much that I reflected on about in terms of my own training as a student. And I remember one of the first times somebody came in, they sat down and they said, "I am so nervous." And I thought, "Oh my God, you can say that!" I never said that. Right? Because I grew up in the school of... as the students in the prison would say, "You don't show your sweat." Right? Where I grew up, that's weakness. Right? So I never just said, "I am so nervous," but I was so nervous.

So in that way, how to be authentic in that moment was so simple. That's what that student was showing me. And for me, it was so far away.

And one of the things of being here is you can show it all and feel like it's okay. Because I had spent my whole life trying to cover it. Everything was trying to like, "Oh, look how strong I could look," or "look how unnervous I am."

**Teacher:** Because if you had shown it the way you feel able to do here, what would have happened or what did happen that held you back or taught you that you couldn't?

**Student:** You know, it was my whole, my whole, like my entire life was like that until I really came here and I could sit here and say like, "I'm not okay." I don't know what that story was, but it was a hard, hard-wired one. And I put all of my energy into not letting anybody see how scared I was. But I think it was that because no one ever responded.

**Teacher:** Yeah. Yeah, you know. You know, that's... I mean, isn't that what we have to do to be, to be a student? We have to be willing to say, "I don't know, I don't understand, I can't do this by myself." We have to be willing to say that. When a student comes in and does shoken for the first time, there's a formal way of doing nine bows, but the way they actually say that has to be their own words, right? They have to say it in their own words. They have to say, "Please teach me." How important is that? Why is that important? I'm asking.

**Student:** Yeah. No, I'm asking. Yeah. Yeah. So I'll give you a minute.

**Student:** Yeah, you're asking and... yeah, I'm trying to answer. Sorry. Because that... well, the real please, which is please, Shugen, do teach me is getting to that authentic... yeah... place.

**Teacher:** Yeah. So please do teach me. May your life go well. Thank you for your teaching.

---

**Teacher:** You know, I think of those gates of entry, beginning with the introductors retreat. Each of those is teaching us something about being a student of the Way. Just understanding the path that we're entering into. Meeting with the guardian council, being asked those questions. Why now? Why beneath that now? Why beneath that now? Why beneath that, when you don't want to do this? Why? We don't really have that many opportunities or encounters where we're asked in that way to get clear about something that we're often not really clear about. To have a simple cup of tea and offer a gift, to do a full day of tankaryo.

Oftentimes with students after they've entered, I'll say, reflect on each of those. What were each of those showing you? Because they keep... they're showing each student, each of us, something important—not just for that process of entry, but along the way. And like asking, right? We need to keep asking. Teachers need to keep asking to be taught, to receive the teachings. I think the most important thing to be a teacher is first to be a student—still, always.

---

**Student:** Shusanji. Sorry, this is... my feet are cramped. Well, I'll just have to deal with it. So I was thinking back when I got into this, I had no idea what I was getting into.

**Teacher:** Isn't that a good thing?

**Student:** It's wonderful. I still don't know.

**Teacher:** And so how do you hold that up alongside what you do know?

**Student:** I just take one step after another.

**Teacher:** What do you do with what you do know?

**Student:** How may I help you?

**Teacher:** How does that... how can that transform into not being a student? "I know how to help you." What about that which you know? How can that cease to be something that you actually know?

**Student:** What am I doing here? I don't know. I... I don't have anything to offer. Self-doubt.

**Teacher:** But what's another way—can you repeat it? Can you repeat it? What's another way in which that which you know truly moves you away from being a student?

**Student:** I know, right? When it becomes something...

**Teacher:** Yeah, when you become something. You know, I've been talking about the Prajnaparamita Sutra. It's so unrelenting. You know, the Buddha said, the Bodhisattva does not think, "I am practicing. I am gaining insight. I am letting go. I am serving, I am giving." How wonderful.

**Student:** Indeed.

**Teacher:** Indeed. So, okay. May your life go well. Thank you for your teaching.

---

**Teacher:** I remember years ago, there was a student—a very good student, fine, excellent person, really sincere student—who left training. And my sense of it was that there was an ambition that was impatient and it wanted more, sooner. And I remember talking to Daido Roshi about that. And I said, "Well, you know, the path is about building confidence. Building confidence in one's own ability, one's capacity, one's understanding. So why does that happen to everybody, right? Why doesn't every student get to a point where there's, like, you know, whether it's ambition or just, you know, 'I got what I came for.'" And he said, "Well, part of the role of the teacher is to try and keep showing the student that there's more. Showing the student what isn't yet clear."

---

**Student:** So, Shusanji. Sho-san-shi. Yes, 'san' is Dharma encounter. 'Shi' is teacher. So I guess being a student is trying to meet the teacher.

**Teacher:** Say more. What does that mean to you?

**Student:** Like Dogen talked about, in person. I didn't hear your Dharma talk, but... yeah, while still dripping with birth water, speak from that place. What is student?

**Student:** Yeah. It's taking a lot of sense, being very courageous.

**Teacher:** And why is that important? Why is that needed?

**Student:** Because all of life is meeting the teacher. All of life is trying to meet the student.

**Teacher:** Why is courage important?

**Student:** Disruption.

**Teacher:** No. May your life go well. Thank you for your teaching.

**Teacher:** It sounds nice when we're talking about it. When it's happening, it's not that.

---

**Student:** Shusanji, as I prepare to enter formal training, I am someone still in the womb, knocking, pecking.

**Teacher:** Okay.

**Student:** I am so afraid of so many things. I spent years meditating and not telling anyone that I was doing it, trying to hide that I was doing it. If someone found out, I would minimize it, you know, brush it off.

**Teacher:** Why?

**Student:** Vulnerability. It's admitting that I don't know, that I feel like something is missing, that something is not satisfying, that I'm not put together, and that I'm trying to see if there's something else, that, if anything, can change.

**Teacher:** And what does it mean to be vulnerable?

**Student:** It means to shed everything that isn't true about myself. And that sounds very big. Just in one moment, one moment of vulnerability. What does that mean? Rather than thinking of shedding everything—to be here in this seat, to do the thing that makes me shake, that has me shaking for the last 15 minutes online, nonstop.

**Teacher:** You know, Brené Brown said that when she talked about vulnerability, said that we all move towards it when we see it in somebody, right? It really is compelling. It opens our heart. So we really are attracted to it. But we don't want to be vulnerable. Why? What is the fear? What is the expectation behind being vulnerable?

**Student:** For me, it's rejection.

**Teacher:** Exactly. Exactly. And I have to think that that is—or I do think, I just wonder if that is—a really ancient, primordial fear. Rejection from your people, your tribe, right? Which meant to be cast out, which was death. And then on a deep, deep level in our genes is that concern.

But how can you transform that into something that helps you?

**Student:** That vulnerability is the sign of my humanity. It's the connection that we all share, that it's something that's in everyone. It means that we're all humans and that we're born to be in community, born to be with each other. And that fear is universal. People just respond to it differently. Like when a person is arrogant, why? What is the need for that? What is that serving, right?

**Teacher:** And so to... the fear of being rejected by others is strong. But what's even stronger? What rejection is even stronger than that?

**Student:** What rejection is even stronger is more significant—the rejection of what's real inside me. Rejecting yourself.

**Teacher:** We can have the love and affirmation and support of everyone, and it won't mean very much at all. Truly, it will not mean very much at all if we have... if we are not in full embrace, in person, with ourselves. You don't have to look very far to see testimonies to that. That's why that is never enough. Right? So we'll see you on the other side. Thank you for your teaching.

---

**Student:** So, Shusanji, I actually was reflecting on Daido's entreaty to trust yourself. And it always used to make me a little nutty when he would say that. Because, you know, I, like the rest of us, have led a life, and I've made a lot of mistakes. I've made mistakes, I've hurt people. And so I thought, how do I trust, since there were impulses that I followed which resulted in damage? How could I trust myself? And then on top of that, well, wait a minute. So how...

**Teacher:** How what? How to trust yourself? How to trust yourself in the recognition that you have done untrustworthy things?

**Student:** In this context, I guess I don't even know there's a...

**Teacher:** Wait a minute. I don't buy that. I really, absolutely, simply do not buy that. Prove me wrong. Prove me right.

**Student:** Well, those reflections were reflections on the past, and the past is past.

**Teacher:** But we're talking about you trusting yourself now, right? Because the trust of now is now.

**Student:** But does that mean you're... you're beyond... you're beyond the point of being able to make a mistake and hurt somebody?

**Teacher:** Certainly not.

**Teacher:** Okay, so how do you trust yourself knowing that?

**Student:** Something about awareness.

**Teacher:** Okay.

**Student:** An understanding of action, of choice.

**Teacher:** Whose?

**Student:** Mine.

**Teacher:** Yes. And through—I want to say the filter, although that sounds technical—of the teaching. The teachings of the Dharma.

**Teacher:** That's all good. But you're still on the couch.

**Student:** What couch?

**Teacher:** The couch that you're sitting on. There's awareness, right? There's understanding that there's cause and effect. There's understanding. What do you need to do with that understanding?

**Student:** Act upon it.

**Teacher:** Sounds good. Live it. Live it.

So how do we trust? You know, I often say, how do we walk on the path of enlightening—verb, enlightening—while still deluded? How do we walk on a path of cultivated, great, boundless compassion while still not always compassionate? Right. Knowingly.

I've told somebody during the session about the subject of trust. My brother, my beloved brother—I love you, brother, wherever you are. When I was younger, he had a rep in our family for being late, right? He was late. He was always late. And he would just be up doing crazy stuff, meeting somebody, going... you know, he was a very interesting young person. But we were sitting there waiting for him. And so at a certain point, we decided and we said, "We're not going to wait for you anymore. So we're going to meet here, and then we're going to go there. And if you're not there, we're going, and you can try and find us."

So how did we trust? How did I trust my brother knowingly? I love him. I trust you, but not to be on time. Right. So we can trust knowingly, which incorporates those things that are not wholly trustworthy. Does that make sense? We're not blind. We're not blind to the ways in which... I'm not blind to the ways in which I can be selfish, lazy, you know, hurtful, misspeaking. Right? But if I don't trust myself, I can't do this. I wouldn't even be here, and neither would you. That's why I'm not buying it. So stop buying it. Get out of here. May your life go well.

**Student:** That's what I've been waiting for. Here I am. I've never done this before. I've never felt this before.

**Teacher:** That's a beautiful thing. Can you appreciate that?

**Student:** I'm trying.

**Teacher:** Yeah. Yeah. There's confidence in that. That there's something here. In that. From where I'm not clear, I can move forward. Don't ever doubt that.

You know, one of the things that's important to understand is the subtlety of this. You know, if we don't go to work, if we don't wash our dishes, if we don't bathe, the consequences are obvious. If we don't attend to this, the consequences are there. But they're not always so obvious. Until they are. When they become obvious, there's really no choice. Because the choice has been made, right? The alternative is no longer viable. There is no alternative. There is no alternative, no.

But there is for you and for many of us, right? I mean, in a sense, we always need to understand we are making this choice, right? But the subtlety... I mean, that's why whenever I talk to a student who's struggling, flailing, wandering, I say, just come to sesshin, right? We'll talk about it then. And it may be that by the end of this sesshin, they've decided to withdraw. Fine. But they've done that from within, not from sitting at home with a distant memory that is just now a memory. It's a thought, it's an idea. It's not in their body anymore. Get it back into your body and then see. And that's how fragile it can be, right? That's why this is so important. We have to keep coming back and drinking from that spring. Particularly because in our lives, in a world of chaos and so many things to do, right, that can be lost. You know, practice can be like what happens when you've washed your dishes, you've finished with work, and you've done everything else, right? So if it's not important, the things that are important, we do.

And so feeling that, right? That sense, and tending to that. Like a baby. Dogen said, it's like a baby. It's infinite. It's in your arms, right? If you don't feed it, it'll whimper, it'll cry for a while, and then it'll get quiet. May your life go well. Thank you for your teaching.

---

**Student:** Shusanji, it's taken many years, but you know, I'm really just starting to appreciate how my insecurity and my lack of vulnerability are holding me back as a student, as a practitioner. All the ways that I feel safe, stuck, and that I just can't show myself and feel like I keep shoving things down and cutting them off. And, you know, for a while, I can make that work. And then over time, it's like, this is just killing me on the inside.

**Teacher:** Yeah. Have you known you've been practicing for some years? Have you known that that's what you were doing with practice?

**Student:** Yeah, part of me always knew, but things felt like they were going okay and working out and, you know, wasn't causing any trouble. So as long as everyone else was fine, I could just keep this on the inside.

**Teacher:** And so what's different? Why should it be any different?

**Student:** Well, because as I keep turning the light around, looking at myself, it's just... I guess I just see in the ways how being inauthentic is holding myself back from really engaging practice. Like basically hitting a wall that I finally hit and seeing I can't do this anymore.

**Teacher:** You know, we were talking about this earlier in the week. Kasho brought it up in a way, a person brings it up every time they speak about something that is authentic, which is the ways in which we are conditioned, socialized—we might even say indoctrinated—not just to certain views and so on, but to a belief about who we are, fundamentally about who we can be, who we can't be, what's allowed and what's not allowed.

You know, I've talked about when I was young, growing up as a boy in Georgia, you know, the rules, the unspoken rules that were present, right? And how did you know they were present? Because if you stepped over a line, the response was immediate and swift. And very oftentimes, it was from my own friends. We did it to each other, right? We walk in a tightrope, right? We were all dying inside, right? And we kept each other on that tightrope, right? And so what had to happen for that mode of being to lead to some shift? I just had to get exhausted, just give up and surrender.

It is exhausting. You know, I was reading an article by—I think it was Naomi Klein, I think—and she was talking about the current administration and a lot of people who are in great power now. And the image of the Lone Ranger, the cowboy, right? Going off into the sunset, riding alone, doing it their own way, right? And the toxicity, the foolishness, the delusion, the danger, the unreality of that. It's so incredibly precarious, right? Everything is a threat in the veil of being impenetrable, impervious, confident, in control. It's not just killing you or me. It's killing everyone.

And so what can you do, monk of the way? Show up, offer myself, get uncomfortable, risk being judged and rejected for, at the expense of being honest with myself. Like that should come first. And provide an example. Without knowing, don't know that you are. The moment that you think that you are, come back home. May your life go well. Thank you for your teaching.

---

**Student:** So, Shusanji, when I came into residency earlier this year, I thought I would stay for much longer than I turned out to be staying for. And when I first told some of my friends that I was thinking about leaving—leaving here or...

**Teacher:** Yes, leaving here.

**Student:** They tried to convince me otherwise and I kind of—bah, nonsense, I have good reasons.

**Teacher:** You mean that was your response?

**Student:** Yes. Yeah, I can justify anything. But now that it's time, there's always doubts. Living a life of delusion. Sometimes you're so deep in shit, you can't see the...

**Teacher:** Yeah. So how can I trust that I'm not leaving... Daido Roshi talked about the person who's up to their eyeballs in shit, saying, "Everything's fine, I'm good." I'm not saying that that's you. I just brought that up in my memory. You know, the dual mind, the divided mind, wants absolute certainty. That's what it does. That's why living by dogma, living in extremes, seems safe. You know, just have a story and stick with it. Then you don't have to think, you don't have to be alert, you don't have to negotiate, you don't have to be alive. But there's no life. That's what you get.

And so, in making decisions, it's not always completely clear. When a person is in discernment to be in ordination, that's about as big a decision as a person can make, is going to make in their life, right? And so that they move towards that to develop confidence and a kind of certainty within themselves. But that doesn't mean it's 100%, nor does it mean it needs to be.

But how can you leave now, depart with some doubt, and do that without dividing yourself?

**Student:** Well, I just... I trust that I'm aware of this doubt, that I'm aware of practicing it, paying attention, keeping my eyes open, and that that's not changing.

**Teacher:** When you leave, leave. If you stay, stay. May your life go well. Thank you for your teaching.

---

**Student:** Shusanji, when you're talking about student, teacher, and what that's like, I guess the best way comes to my mind is a metaphor you used dealing with like a stringed instrument. And over these years, I feel that, like, I've tuned myself to you.

**Teacher:** What does that mean?

**Student:** I'm not sure I like that.

**Teacher:** Well...

**Student:** Well, everything has a resonant frequency, right? Like, and I've tried to match yours. You talk about tension, like the tension in the string.

**Teacher:** Okay, so how is that not imitation? How is that not turning away from the self? What if I go off the rails and you've attuned yourself to me?

**Student:** Yeah. Wow. I never thought of that.

**Teacher:** Think about it. It's not... I got nothing planned. But we should never think that anyone, anyone lives in a golden cage, right? Unable to stumble. And so reflect on that. Dogen, you know, that's why this is so important, right? Because there are too many stories of that kind of relationship. That kind of reliance, which starts out—can start out—very healthy and wonderful and innocent and beautiful, but then becomes something else. And particularly if the teacher's not holding the responsibility well, or is just drunk on their own power, their own desires, or they put that above the student.

One of the things about teaching that I feel is the teacher wants the student to free themselves more than anything. But they shouldn't want anything from the student. If you come, come. If you go, go. That's why every student has brought themselves here. Every one of you have brought yourself here. I mean, don't think of that in just a mechanical way. It's so important, right? Each of us is choosing this. You're practicing under your own authority. Don't give that away. That's part of the... you know. But don't get drunk on that. Don't misunderstand what that is, right? So that then we can really study.

You know, I've told the story about when I went in my teacher once and I sat down and I said, "I'm not you." And he just looked at me. And I said, "The point of this is not for me to become you." Like, I... finally, there was a point where I realized in a certain way—I wouldn't have admitted to that ever—but that in certain ways, that's what I was doing, what I thought I was supposed to be doing. And then I realized, no, that's not what I'm supposed to... that's not what he wants me to be doing. And he's my teacher, and I bow to him and ask him for the teaching. May your life go well. Thank you for your teaching.

---

**Student:** Shusanji, just reflecting back on all of the moments that brought me here to this moment. Our auspicious meeting in Chelsea and so many, you know, projects and desires and ideas.

**Teacher:** And what about some of those very tough moments that were happening right here? And you're here now.

**Student:** So they have dissolved in time. They have been passed through and...

**Teacher:** But what did they teach you about student, about teacher?

**Student:** That, you know, all of these manifestations that we experience with our human bodies...

**Teacher:** Who are we talking about?

**Student:** I'm talking about me and you.

**Teacher:** Okay.

**Student:** And, you know, our lives here, there's so much mystery and so much that we don't know. And that requires trust and faith as it, you know, as we pass through and as it dissolves and we find, you know, we're returning to the center that we share.

**Teacher:** And so much of that mystery is worked out in the grit, in the grit. That's the real thing. May your life go well. Thank you for your teaching.

---

**Student:** Shusanji, so I'm good at following the rules, paying my dues, being a good girl, saying the right things. And I think I... someone's talking about what? Being authentic, sincere. It's really important for me to do that in really my heart of hearts and not just to pay my dues and put the books on the shelf properly.

**Teacher:** That's right. That is so important. And I'm going to venture to say that I think everyone here would like that. And it's a challenge. It's a tension, let's say. Because part of the way we train is meticulous effort, paying attention, right? There's somebody during all of this week who had a pair of shoes. And every time I walked down to the hallway, right? So I just observed. And then I would pick them up and I'd put them on the shelf, come out.

Right. It's not about following the rule. What is it about then? It's about picking up the shoes, feeling the suede of the shoes, putting them on the shelf, putting your hands back, shashu, walking out the door, down the steps, step by step, knowing your mind. Knowing your mind. And caring. Caring, yeah.

And how do we show that? Because caring is just a feeling until we let it be, we display it. And in that, everything receives that care. So it's really important for us to get that that point of all of this is not just to line up like good soldiers, right? But to be examining. That's why it's important to just take up this basic question: What does it mean to study, to be a student? And so to know that at this relatively early stage in your training is excellent. May your life go well. Thank you for your teaching.

---

**Student:** Shosanji, being a student for me, I have not always been a good soldier. Sometimes we've disagreed. I trust you. You earn that in many ways. One is my trust in what you have dedicated your life to. You have a lot of skill and wisdom and heart. And I've seen you reflect and change your mind. I can't do this by myself. I want to live a good life. I want to be of service. I don't always know how to do that. I make lots of mistakes, but I try to learn from them.

So being a student, you know, during sesshin, I was reflecting on time. You were talking about sort of back in the day stuff. And I was like, I've been a jukai student for 20 years, and I didn't come quick to jukai. When I finally asked, Daido was like, "It's about time." I've grown a lot. I've grown so much in this practice, in ways that I feel good about. I know that I came in on my knees, suffering, struggling, pissed off. And I'm still pissed off sometimes. But I know better ways to deal with it. And I know how to sit down, find some space, not jump into the decision, but give myself a chance to reflect. I learned this here. Learned this from you. I learned this from Dai En. Learned from Ho Kyo.

**Teacher:** You say you can't do this by yourself. I can't do this by myself. There have been times where my mind has changed because you were not being a good soldier. Trust is earned all around in all directions. When it's injured, it can be repaired. It can be earned back. You know, as you well know, misstepping is an essential part of the path. And the question is, what happens next?

You know, Daido Roshi—and I like this, my concluding words this morning—he used to speak about, as I've said so much, about trusting yourself. Trust yourself, he would say. Trust yourself. He had a deep karmic insecurity within himself that started very early—the loss of his father. There were reasons. And then he responded to that; we all respond to it in different ways. And the way that that came out, you know, he was a very confident, very forceful teacher. You know that, right? And he loved the Dharma, and he gave his life to this tirelessly. And that karmic underlying thread was still there.

I remember when he told me he was shy, and I said, "What are you talking about?" He said, "I'm actually very shy." And then I began to watch him differently. And I realized, oh my God, it's true. He was very uncomfortable, right? When he would sit down at a table with a meal, if somebody didn't engage him, he would just sit there and eat, you know. Sound familiar to any of you? And when I would sit next to him—sometimes I would put myself next to him because I know he would be uncomfortable—and I would ask him a question, and then he would respond, and then it would get going. And part of that was my love for him, and part of it was I was uncomfortable with his discomfort.

And so part of training... Tetsugen Roshi said, while he was still Tetsugen before Bernie, that as a student trains more and more with a teacher, they become closer and closer to that teacher's hopeful wisdom, but their humanity. And he said, a lot of students don't want that. They don't want that. They want to be able to hold that person up in that way, right? And so what do we do with that humanity, right?

And so when I saw that insecurity in Daido Roshi, you know, and the way sometimes that came out towards others, and I said to him once, in a moment, I said, "You say trust every... you trust yourself, you trust yourself, but do you trust us? Do you trust us?" That was hard for him sometimes. And he had to, and he did. And both of those were true.

I need you. Thank you for being there. And I need you. May your life go well. Thank you for your teaching. May our lives go well. Thank you for listening.

To find out more about ZMM's programs, retreats and residency, please visit us online at zmm.org.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Title: Is It Mine, Or Yours?
Extracted Text:
The following Dharma discourse was given by Jeffrey Shugan Arnold at Zen Mountain Monastery. Shugan Roshi is the head of the Mountains and Rivers Order and abbot of the monastery. This talk, like all of our talks, is offered free of charge. If you would like to make a donation or find out more about our various programs, visit us online at zmm.org. Thank you for listening.

And this is from the Transmission of Light: Vasumitra. Vasumitra placed a wine vessel in front of Machaka, bowed, and stood there. Machaka asked him, “Is this my vessel or yours?” As Vasumitra thought it over, Machaka said, “If you consider it my vessel, yet it is your inherent nature. Then again, if it is your vessel, you should receive my teaching.” Hearing this, Vasumitra understood the uncreated fundamental nature.

Kazan’s verse: “If the frosty dawn’s bell rings as it’s struck, you never need an empty bowl. Here, this vessel, is it mine or yours?”

This collection was done by Keizan, who’s a few generations after Dogen. And it’s kind of unusual within the koan literature because it’s said to be the enlightenment experiences of all of the ancestors, beginning with the Buddha and ending with Ejo, Dogen’s—one of Dogen’s principal heirs. In the early—particularly the Indian—teachers, because there was such a paucity of information in the old tradition in India, keeping history was not evidently something that was really done or valued. And so a lot of this material that is drawn—the biographical material—as Daido Roshi used to say, this is a very esoteric collection of koans. There’s a lot of magic and supernatural stuff going on. And even the historical validity of each of these teachers in a direct line from the Buddha to Ejo and then on down to us here is in question.

But in the establishment of the lineage in Zen, as Chan was developing in China, that was very important for a number of different reasons. And so the lineage was formed. And whether each of these teachers is historically both accurate in terms of them being that person and—or whether they were actually in that line of lineage—is not really for us so important. What we do know is that the Dharma has been transmitted all the way since the time of the Buddha, through peoples in each generation, and through that very important relationship between the student and the teacher.

This vessel, is it mine or yours? Does it belong to the teacher or to the student?

Teachings sometimes talk about being a vessel of the Dharma. Oftentimes that means the teacher recognizes that a student may have the capacity—not only to realize themselves, but to become a Dharma holder, a lineage holder, a teacher. In a larger sense, being a vessel of the Dharma is each of you having found your way to the Dharma, having sought that out, having done some good things in your life such that that was possible. And practicing means that vessel is alive and well.

In the Uttaratantra Shastra, which is a teaching on Buddha Nature, it says, “The perfect Buddha-kaya, kaya’s vessel, vehicle, the perfect Buddha-kaya, is all-embracing. Suchness cannot be differentiated, and all beings have the disposition. Thus, they always have Buddha Nature. The Buddha has said that all beings have Buddha Nature. Why? Since Buddha wisdom is always present within the assembly of beings, since this undefiled nature is free from duality, and since the disposition to Buddhahood has been named after its fruit, it’s all-embracing. It reaches everywhere. Nothing is forsaken.” Because that nature which we all possess has no boundary inside or outside. It can’t be inclusive or exclusive. It can’t accept or reject. It cannot be differentiated because it is one nature, like the great ocean, like the boundless sky, and sentient beings have the disposition.

How do we know that? Here you are. And yet, as I said the other day, a few things need to be taken care of.

So Vasumitra was the successor of Machaka. This is very early—this is the eighth ancestor from the Buddha. When he meets him, it’s said that Vasumitra, when he was young, had a wine vessel that he carried everywhere. And so when he met Machaka, he had the wine vessel, and he said, “Do you know what I have in my hand?” Does Vasumitra know what he has in his hand?

When we enter the path, do we know what the vessel is that we are bringing into this journey? Is it my body? Is it my mind? Is it my feelings? Is it my memories and beliefs? My personality? We inhabit, can inhabit, all that we take as ourselves so carelessly, and yet when we die, we sure don’t want to lose it. It’s the seed of our dis-ease, and yet we cherish it. We want to be free within it, yet we can put up a good fight to let go.

Keizan said, “Even if you understand that mind is the way and body is Buddha, this is still a defiled vessel. And being a defiled vessel, it is inappropriate for the Pure.” Pure here means—it doesn’t mean being, you know, a saint or sanctimonious; it means free, awake, clear. He says, “You may understand that it encompasses all of time. And you may know that it is forever complete,” which is all true, “but this is still a defiled vessel. What past or present are you talking about? What beginning or end are you talking about? Views like this are inappropriate for the Pure.”

In other words, as we become more clear, we understand that beginning and end, past and present and future, right and wrong, are what the Buddha called convenient designations—ways to refer to things that we experience in the world and that we can speak about, right? And so we are given a name, so that when we want to call out to someone, we can say—we don’t have to say, “You, third from the right.” But then we mistake the name. We mistake the nouns, the words, for creating or being a definite thing, self-existing. And so he says, this view is not appropriate for the Pure, for one who has seen through that. And then we can use those words, use those terms. We can tell stories. We can tell our own stories and not be fooled, not be deceived by them into thinking, “That’s who I am. That’s who I was. This is the absolute truth.”

You know, more and more, as I have—I was thinking of, as I was getting ready for this earlier, of wanting to talk about student, teacher, and sort of, you know, raising bodhicitta. The beginnings of that stirring that happens within each seeker of the Way, each seeker of the Dharma. And I remember, I was in my room, which I shared with my brother—my beloved older brother, about a year older. And we were doing homework. And I don’t know what precipitated it, but we just started talking, and he started talking, and he was just sharing things he had been thinking about and sort of ways he had been seeing things. And I remember just feeling like scales were just falling, and that I was like—he was like—I just felt like he was opening up a world that was really just beginning to think about things, rather than just, you know, being a teenager and that.

You know, it’s like being a teenager, being in my life, thinking about things, like, “It’s happening, it’s now, I’m involved in it. What is it?” And so it was like that beginning, you know? I mean, there had been stirrings and mostly just feelings of, like, you know, discontent. But that was the first moment where I felt like, really, he was sort of quite unwittingly and innocently introducing me to thinking, examining.

I remember years later, we were—I was in LA visiting him on my way back from New Zealand, where he used to live. He used to live in Los Angeles. And we were out walking and I was telling him this story. And it was like, you know, like, “Oh my God, man, you, like, did this for me. And it’s like, I love you.” And he was like, “I have no idea what you’re talking about.” And it didn’t matter, you know? And it was like, how often has somebody done something for us and they have no idea? We might not even know in that moment the impact of what happened. But later, as we were—I mean, I think of teachers who were so important to me and who I would be fighting with and resisting, you know, but they cared. And they were in there, like, holding my feet to the fire about something related to my schoolwork, and I was resisting, but they got to me, right? They didn’t know that.

So that’s why it’s always important to just practice, give. What is our aspiration? Why is that so important in Buddhist practice? Why is there so much emphasis on raising bodhicitta? Is it just to remind us that our practice shouldn’t be just for ourselves, but should also be for others? But bodhicitta is not just, you know, an intention to realize ourself, an intention to help others. Where does that come from? What is causing that to be aroused? That’s aspiration. That’s the seat of bodhicitta.

That’s why when somebody wants to enter into formal training, Daido Roshi years ago realized it’s important to, in a sense, slow things down and create what he called barrier gates, right? To stop and to be asked questions, to reflect, to try and get clear. You don’t have to do this, right? Why do you want to do this? What are you seeking? What is motivating you? What do you think this is? So that when we enter, our eyes are at least half open.

In the Prajnaparamita Sutra, it talks about being pure, not being pure. Shariputra asks the Buddha, “Undefiled, O Lord, is purity. Being undefiled is purity.” There’s an interesting way that the sutra sometimes works, where there’s kind of a calling and responding, a singing and singing back that goes back and forth. And so Shariputra sings out, “Undefiled, O Lord, is purity.” And the Buddha responds, “Because of the absolute absence of all defilement.” Shariputra says, “Through the non-defilement—of what? Of what is there purity?” And the Buddha says, “The purity results from the fact that form, sensations, perceptions, mental formations, consciousness, are in their essence, original nature, free from defilement. Thus there’s purity, free from defilement, free from anything that constricts, confines, limits. That’s our nature.”

So Daido Roshi, in this setting up of the gates, established what he called Zen study, or as a way of talking about studying with a teacher. That part of what a lineage means is that every teacher has a teacher. And that doesn’t end when the teacher dies. I still have a teacher, right? When we form a relationship with somebody, particularly one that’s significant, that doesn’t end if and when the person’s life ends—it just changes its shape, changes its form. And so what is the teacher meeting the student, the student meeting the teacher?

Dogen, in his fascicle on face-to-face transmission, says, “Shakyamuni Buddha saw Mahakashyapa in person. Mahakashyapa saw the Venerable Ananda in person. And Ananda bowed formally to Mahakashyapa’s Buddha face. This is face-to-face transmission. Ananda maintained this face-to-face transmission, closely guided Shanavasa, his disciple, and transmitted face-to-face. When Shanavasa respectfully saw Venerable Ananda, he received face-to-face transmission—just face-to-face.”

So when we talk about face-to-face teaching, right, we are sitting face-to-face. But Dogen is looking at this in a very deep way, in an important way. It’s not just that we happen to be in the same room facing each other. There’s something happening. Shakyamuni Buddha saw Mahakashyapa in person. He could have never known what that means. Now, right—post-COVID, Zoom—of course he means it in a very particular way. He doesn’t just mean that we’re actually sitting in the same room. Thank you for that. But he’s saying he saw Mahakashyapa in person. Buddha saw Mahakashyapa. Buddha saw Mahapajapati in person, in person. The teacher sees the student in person. The student trains so that they might see the teacher in person, that they might see themselves in person. The Buddha saw Ubiri in person, Patachara in person.

You know that story that Hojun Sensei told yesterday—that’s so compelling, so overwhelming to think of such a cascade of tragedy. What more could there be? How could you not lose your mind? And when the Buddha met her, clearly he was not afraid. He was not overwhelmed with her grief. He was not intimidated by her grief. He clearly was not deceived into thinking that his job was to fix her. He said, “Patachara, come to your senses. It’s time. It’s time.” He knew the reality of grief. He knew its cause. He knew its potential for cessation, and he knew the path. He just presented that to her in a way that got through.

In the gates, in this chapter on Zen study, Daido Roshi talks about how we create a sense of self, and that self becomes our barrier and says, “The ego shell is the barrier and we must become it and realize itself.” In other words, we can’t keep separating ourselves from the barrier, which is what we do when we grab onto it. What we do when we reject certain aspects of ourself, we just make it stronger. To realize the barrier is the self is to realize the self. The barrier then becomes you. You become the barrier and there’s nothing else. Or realize—we just really, we just realize that there’s nothing really there. This is the self teaching the self. This is the self realizing the self.

And then he says, “Isn’t this what Dogen is talking about in the Mountains and Rivers Sutra?” He says, “Since ancient times, wise ones and sages have lived by the water.” Sometimes this teacher is referred to as being somebody who fishes and fishes for a student, throws out a hook and tries to catch a student. When they live by the water, they catch fish, or they catch humans, or they catch the Way. These are all traditional water styles. And going further, they must be catching the self, catching the hook, being caught by the hook, being caught by the Way.

In ancient times, when Chuang Tzu suddenly left Huishan and went to live on the river, he caught the sage of the flower and river who was living by the river. Isn’t this catching fish? Isn’t it catching humans, catching water? Is it not catching oneself?

And then he goes on to say, “My teacher meeting me is my teacher meeting himself. It is me meeting myself. Isn’t this the Buddha meeting the Buddha? Isn’t this my teaching? You meeting myself, you meeting yourself, and the Buddha seeing himself.” We say that to realize oneself is to be intimate with oneself. To be intimate with oneself is Buddha realizing Buddha. This action verifies and actualizes the enlightenment of all the Buddhas in the ten directions. That’s what is meant by face-to-face transmission and that it’s experiential, right? It’s not information, it’s not knowledge.

I told the story that Daido Roshi told, when he was at the temple years ago—probably before the temple, I don’t remember—but he was doing a retreat. Everybody was sitting in a circle and somebody was asking about transmission and said, “Well, you know, but it’s like when you tell somebody something, that message, and then that message is told to the next person, next person. It breaks down, you know, like the telephone game. You tell somebody something that by the time it comes back, it’s almost unrecognizable.” And he said, “No, it’s not like that.” And they said, “What’s it like?” And he slapped the person next to him and he said, “Pass that around.” So everybody slapped each person. When it came back to him, he said, “Yeah, it’s intact.” If it were only that easy.

But what is the toll? What is being sacrificed when we do not meet? When we do not meet the teacher, we do not meet ourselves. Can we prevent the teacher from seeing ourselves? I remember years ago, I had a new student. This was very early in my teaching, and he had just done tankan. And I don’t know if it was actually during shoken, when he was asking for the teachings or the first interview after that—I don’t remember. But it was a normal interview—you know, talked a little bit about practice. And then afterwards he sent a letter and he said, “I quit.” He said, “There’s no way that this can ever work, that you can ever actually be my teacher, unless we spend—basically the implication—we have to spend lots and lots of times hanging out together, talking to each other. You have to know my story. I have to tell my story. That’s obviously not going to happen. In a few minutes, I’m out.” Okay? He was right that none of that stuff was going to happen, or not in the way he thought. But what is lost when we do not meet?

Is there a difference between meeting our teacher, meeting ourselves, and meeting a spring day, meeting a task, meeting a prostration, meeting a Buddha? That’s what we call dukkha—not meeting. We call it samsara. We call it pain and confusion. We call it “Time swiftly passes by and opportunities are lost.”

You know, one of the things I love about living in the Northeast—I mean, we had seasons in the South, but they were, you know, more subtle—is that they’re more vivid, right? Each season is its own living creation. And so each season, you know, I sort of mark the firsts, like with spring: the first night when I’m walking back to the abbacy and I hear the spring peepers—that first night; the first day—last Sunday—the windows are open in the zendo, the first tick—I’ve already had mine; the first flowers, the first crocus, the first daffodil. Isn’t it wholly appropriate—it would make me believe in God—that the daffodil, one of the first flowers, is such an incredibly happy flower? I mean, is there a happier flower than a daffodil? You never see it, like, sad. The first spring rain, the birds returning, all of those firsts. And yet, do we meet them? Do they get under our skin? Do we see what’s happening?

Dogen said, “Thus the authentic ancestors of all generations have continued face-to-face transmission—disciple seeing teacher, teacher seeing disciple. An ancestor, a teacher or a disciple cannot be a Buddha or an ancestor without having face-to-face transmission. It’s like pouring water into the ocean and spreading it endlessly, or like transmitting the lamp and allowing it to shine forever. In thousands of millions of transmissions, the trunk and branches are one. Breaking an eggshell by pecking from the inside and outside at once.” Referring to the image of a hen pecking at the egg—peck, peck, peck—and the egg inside—duck, duck, tuck, peck, peck, peck, duck, tuck, tuck—and finally it cracks open and a new life has come.

And so this, he says, is face-to-face transmission and that this is how we are here now. And we can think of this in terms of formal transmission. But what he’s talking about is that, but it’s also every moment in which the Dharma is being conveyed, being received, being experienced. Sometimes we know that that’s happening, oftentimes we don’t—not in the moment; we don’t know. That becomes clear later. Disciple seeing the teacher, teacher seeing disciple.

We don’t use that term so much—a disciple. It’s a nice term. It means a follower, a student, a believer, an adherent—so not all of those really fully apply. A follower of the way. I don’t think of it so much as following a teacher. It’s not so much based in belief. I was thinking, is it kind of like being an apprentice? You know, in the age-old tradition, you know, apprentice studying with a master craftsman, somebody who has great skill—seamstress. The definition of an apprentice is a person who’s learning a trade from a skilled employer, having agreed to work for a fixed period at low wages. Well, they got that right.

And I was thinking of when I was a music student, oftentimes when I was working on a piece, I would play, then my teacher would say, “Wait.” And then he would play it. He’d say, “Now you play it.” Then I would play. He’d say, “No, listen, listen.” And then he would play it again—calling and answering, calling and answering. So there’s following example, there’s a modeling, but when I played, it was me playing. He wasn’t saying, “Imitate me,” he was saying, “Listen to the music.” He was the vehicle by which the music was coming. He said, “Listen to the music and let the music come out. Let it come from you, let it come from me, and let it be true to the music.”

I was thinking also, when I was studying composition, so traditionally, one of the ways you learn is you learn to write in the style—in the style of Bach, style of Mozart. So you study their writings and you write in the style, but you’re not trying to imitate them. How could you? But you’re writing in the style of. It’s very similar. It has to come from one’s heart. It’s not imitating, but it’s also trying to stay true to the style. And I thought, isn’t that very similar to what we’re doing? We’re trying to stay true to the Dharma because that’s the path that we can rely on, that we take refuge in, but it has to come from within.

When we study with a teacher, we’re following examples. I definitely followed the example of my teacher, and I learned from all of his positive qualities, and I also learned from some of his difficult qualities, right? And every teacher teaches in terms of, you know, the ways in which the Dharma manifests well and also through their imperfections. I remember saying to a new student recently, “I will disappoint you.” And they looked at me like—I said, “No, really, not because I intend to, but because that is going to happen.” We all have expectations. We all have certain ideals, idealizations. It’s actually an important part of it.

And so to follow a teacher is to follow the path, to follow the Buddha Dharma so that we can begin to meet. Isn’t that what’s happening in zazen? Face-to-face, your face meeting your face. And so in practicing, we enter into the mindstream of the Buddha, of these ancestors. In every koan, we’re entering into the mindstream of these teachers. In studying with a teacher, we’re studying, we’re entering into their mindstream, and the teacher is entering into the mindstream of the students.

In the very early years, when Daido Roshi was establishing and teaching and setting things up, and as he said, just doing it like it’s going to happen, like it is happening, we were entering into his—not only his mindstream, but his vision, what he was trying to do, what he wanted to do, what he was trying to create. I didn’t know. We didn’t know. He called it a monastery. Okay, right. He talked about these various forms of training. Okay, right. So, you know, I learned how to do these different things, but I didn’t really know. I didn’t have his mind. I didn’t experience his training. And at every step along the way. And I think an important part of why he set up the gates was he wanted there to be examination and discernment. Don’t just do this stuff. We don’t just bow because the—we do just bow when the bell rings. Just bow. And we don’t just bow when the bell rings, right? In other words, what are we doing? Not analyzing it to death, thinking it to death, parsing it out and dissecting it and pinning it to a board, but bringing it to life. What is it in here?

So in a sense, I am the apprentice. I am following the examples of my teachers. They did prostrations. Okay, I do a prostration. I don’t really know what that is. My body seems to be able to follow that fairly well. That’s part of it. But am I meeting the prostration? When we’re involved in any practice that feels somewhat empty—that’s the gap. Whether it’s actively through resistance, whether it’s because we want to try and figure it out and we don’t, we can’t, or whether it’s just because we haven’t yet met it. And I imagine many, if not most of you, have had an experience where you had an experience of some simple aspect of practice that got in, that entered in, and you experienced something you feel. I’m not talking about enlightenment. I’m just talking about something was touched, something true, a string was plucked, and it was in tune. That’s the transmission happening.

Is this my vessel or your vessel? As Vasumitra was thinking that—it is neither I nor—it’s not mine or it’s not yours. Machaka said, “If you think it’s my vessel, but you have Buddha Nature, so it wasn’t Machaka’s vessel. But then again, if it’s your vessel, why are you here?” He said, “Then you should receive my teaching.” Therefore, it wasn’t Vasumitra’s vessel either. It’s not my vessel. It’s not your vessel. So the vessel itself is not a vessel. This is why the vessel disappears.

This is what is happening in training, that the student and teacher, facing each other, sitting apart, one guiding the other, begins to merge. The mind is known, right? It’s like, how can the teacher know a student’s experience? They’re not experiencing their experience. They need to have had certain experiences to be clear about that and then to be able to see when that is being expressed through the body, through the words, through the eyes, through actions, through what is said, through what is not said—until the vessel is no longer a vessel.

This is why patience is so important, you know, and maybe we should really—I think we should actually really factor in, when we think about, why is this difficult, why does it take so long, blah, blah, blah. You know, we’ve all had that, perhaps are having that particular conversation. Maybe we should throw into that pot the fact that we live in a culture which in some ways is so anti-training, right? It’s anti-patience. No patience for patience. It’s transactional. You better be getting something for your money, right? And that we absorb that, right? We grow up in that—if we grew up in this country—and the aggrandizement, the enshrining of the self, the enshrining of the ego, right? And so that’s got to be playing a role.

I was thinking about how we’ve talked recently on a couple occasions about how in the early days when the dokusan line was called “running,” right—helter-skelter, leaping over people, and there was, you know, there were some problems, right? People who weren’t so fast always ended up at the end of the line. Sometimes people got bumped a little. Some people’s enthusiasm became aggression, you know, or just like, “me first,” you know, crowding somebody out. And so we started to temper that a little bit, and I think that was appropriate. And something was lost.

You know, I got to tell you, when I sit here and I hear the daisan line called and I see some people getting up, and it’s like, you think you’re going to live forever. Are you going to a chat? Are you going to have a cup of coffee? Is your head on fire? You don’t have to knock somebody down. But part of what that was doing was instilling, bringing—it was either just expressing what was already there or was helping to bring forth a sense of urgency.

I remember doing—I think when Shohan talked recently, or maybe it was in Yermondo, about when the Buddha came upon the ascetics and they referred to him as “friend,” and he said he had to reorient him. Our relationship has changed. He was saying, all right. And then I remember doing dokusan—I think it was during an introductory retreat—and some young or maybe a new resident came in and sat down and goes, “What’s up?” I was like, “Where to begin?”

Oh, the blessed bell speaks volumes, raises questions. It’s not a chat. It’s not a discussion. I never went to dokusan—even the very last time, when I thought, this is probably the last time I’m going to see my teacher in this room after all of these years—I never went in casual. I was always sitting at the edge of my seat, always ready, always with some degree of question, “How can I use this? How can I meet this to be a student?” You know, that question of the question.

And I want to think about that a little bit in terms of how we introduce or talk about dokusan or daisan—interview—in terms of—because sometimes when I’m talking to people, they seem to have the sense that they need a question, or the question, you know, it’s like there’s the right question and you better get to it. Sometimes people will come in and say, “You know, I don’t really have anything important to say,” and then they’ll ask something which is actually very important. Sometimes setting it up that way can create a sense of, you know, an idea of something. It comes from within.

As Dharma practitioners, we’re studying the Way, which means self, other, karma, impermanence, death, conflict, fear, joy, impatience—everything, phenomena and that. To want to know, to want to understand, to want to meet, to want to live this life and not just have passed through it, to not want to miss this opportunity that I have been given, that you have been given—that is the fire on top of the head. When you have a fire in your head, you’re not going to put it off till tomorrow, right? That’s not even a question. You’re not going to think, “You know, I was really on my way to something. This is most inconvenient.” It takes—it assumes its place. And that’s a really essential part of practice, is making contact with what is important.

And there are many things in our lives that are important—our families, the people we love, the work that we do, our blessed earth, our time, power and misuse of power. There are many things that are important. Is there anything that unifies all of them? Is there anything that runs through all of them? Is there an undercurrent? Is there something that permeates them? Not in terms of an ultimate solution, but in terms of you, me, living in this world with all of these important matters. Is it just a matter of going from one thing to the next and completing tasks? Is there something I want to know? Is there something you want to know? Is there something, a way you want to be in this life, a sense of it?

I was just reading earlier in this Prajnaparamita Sutra, there’s a passage where Shariputra asks the Buddha, “If someone encounters the Dharma in this lifetime and really is drawn to it, has an affinity and begins to practice, does that mean that in a previous lifetime, in the teaching of rebirth, in a previous lifetime, that something happened, something particular happened?” The Buddha said, “Oh, yes. It means that in a previous lifetime they encountered the Dharma. And they didn’t just encounter it, but they examined it.” He makes this very clear point. “And they examined it,” he says, “with Maitreya, with the Buddha of the future, with the teacher. And then they counter-examined. They didn’t just ask a question and got their answers and said, ‘Okay, thanks.’ They counter-examined.” In other words, they continued to examine, they continued to want to know, they continued to question, right? What? That’s what lies in the heart of that student. That is what we can speak of as the great matter of—she spoke of the spiritual imperative, but those are words.

Is there any person who doesn’t on some level know that they’re going to die? Knowing that they’re going to die, how can that not bring up the question on some level of, what is this? What is this then, right? Something about recognizing mortality brings that finite lifespan into question, as it should. And then what? And then what? What do we do with that? It’s in a way an inconvenient truth, right? It’s an inconvenient—it’s uncomfortable. It doesn’t have a ready-made answer, right? Nobody’s standing outside the door ready to resolve this for you. We actually have to leave home, like the Buddha did. We have to leave, we have to be discontented and not only abide by that, but actually increase it.

The teachings say, you cannot actually do this without adversity—which might seem like a bold statement. From the Buddhist perspective, it’s just truth, it’s just fact. It’s not an opinion. The nature of human beings is that we need to understand what we’re in the midst of in order to begin to wonder, to want to know, to see. And that that urge is inherent within human beings—maybe it exists in other creatures. Maybe they work it out in their own way. Maybe it’s worked out from the beginning and it just doesn’t arise. But it sure as hell isn’t like that for us. And that’s a good thing, because then we can seek, we can encounter, we can practice.

Dogen said, “It is like pouring water into the ocean and spreading it endlessly, or like transmitting the lamp and allowing it to shine forever. In thousands of millions of transmissions, the trunk and branches are one.” They’re one.

We can think about different moments in our lives that might have been important, influential, like I described with my brother. That might have been shifting moments—something changed suddenly. We were actually turned towards the Dharma. Like in the Lotus Sutra. The child who leaves home and is a vagabond and is becoming more and more destitute, right? All the while left a home of riches. And the Lotus Sutra simply says, “One day they turned back in the direction of their home.” And that is one of my most favorite lines in all of the sutras. It’s so unassuming, it doesn’t explain, there are no fireworks. But in that, one day, they just turned in the direction of home. That is full, like pouring water into the ocean.

This is why the Buddha in the Prajnaparamita Sutra said, “I have so much gratitude to wisdom.” Think of that. We think of realizing it, practicing accord with it, having faith in it. But the Buddha in the sutra says, “I am so grateful for wisdom, because it is by virtue of wisdom that everything that has happened here is happening here, has come forth.” So how do we express our gratitude? I think you know.

Thank you for listening. To find out more about ZMM’s programs, retreats, and residency, please visit us online at zmm.org.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Title: Skillful Means In The Forms Of Practice
Extracted Text:
Upaya—Skillful means—forms that the teachings take, reflecting their appropriateness to the circumstances in which they appear. It's from the Agates glossary: Upaya, skillful means, forms that the teachings take, reflecting their appropriateness to the circumstances in which they appear.

I was thinking about Upaya this week. Skillful means: how we discover what is skillful and what is unskillful in moving our awakened nature into beneficial action. How are we a beneficial creation out of this uncreated moment to moment?

So our Ango theme is Mountain Training, the Eight Gates of Zen. I feel like I've been meeting Daido Roshi a lot this Ango—studying the eight Gates, listening to his talks, rereading his books—and how the teacher keeps teaching even though their form has changed. Still, his skillful means are very active. And if, maybe, we understand skillful means as the teachings—skillful means for what? In the Buddha Dharma, it's for liberating the clinging mind from suffering. And the Eight Gates of Zen is entering the skillful means of Daido Roshi's expression. He would say there's actually no gates—no gates, just one body, one mind, one life, one heart, one realization. But we look into these areas of focus to develop our skills, arousing and protecting bodhicitta, to see where we turn away and can turn towards not making harm, practicing good, cultivating good for others, strengthening our aspiration to be of benefit to ourselves, to others. Liberating the clinging mind.

And don't we see it in all the skillful means offered? I mean, just—how many of you ring a bell? Where do you find yourself being a server, an usher? What arises as you're doing your service position? One of our students wrote a book about the Greek language, and she began with this word, ginosko, which means to come to know, the recognition of what is true by experience.

I was reading this book on contemporary artists who practice the Buddha Dharma, and I really enjoyed this essay by Robert Thurman. He takes us back to the time of the Buddha where he started to realize this need for skillful means. Say you are—he says—say you are a Buddha and you're free of suffering and you feel totally great, as happy as a bee, happy as a clam, at one with the universe. And then you see all these miserable people. What good would it do for you to go and give them a big grin and a hug or smother them with joyfulness? They'll just get freaked out and paranoid and say, "What does that person want?" So instead, a Buddha has to develop some strategies, some art, to first of all open that person's imagination to the fact that there is a world where they don't have to be miserable all the time. And then they have to help them with a method of how to move from their paranoid corner of misery into the great ocean of bliss of the universe that you, a Buddha, perceive.

Now, as you know, the Buddha began then—so he says, in a sense, none of what Buddha expressed was driven by any sort of selfish impulse on the part of the being that was formerly Siddhartha Gautama. Everything he does is a communication of compassion to other beings, creating doorways to open up their imaginations and their whole beings to enlightenment, to Nirvana, to peace. So to first present Nirvana as a work of art allows people to perceive it and opens up the possibility that they can experience it for themselves. Who would want to seek Nirvana or peace if they couldn't imagine there was such a state of freedom from suffering?

So the Buddha's first talk was on the Prajna Paramita. And if you remember, it was written in the Lotus Sutra that he talked about the emptiness of everything—the no-thingness. And 5,000 monks, nuns, and lay people left. One scholar called it the Heart Attack Sutra. Some people even had heart attacks because it was just going. They couldn't bear to have it be so laid bare that nothing was fixed or permanent in such a way. And Shariputra saw everyone leaving and said to the Buddha, "What should we do? How should we get everybody back here?" And Buddha said, "Let them go, let them go." And then he looked again and he said, "Let me start with the Four Noble Truths. Hey, everybody, life suffers." Boom. We're all there. And that suffering is from dukkha, from thirst, from dissatisfaction, from not having what we want or having something and we want to get rid of it, to spinning in that. And then he said, the good news is we can put an end to that suffering. And he laid out the Eightfold Path of right views or perfect views, right determination, right speech, right ethics, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration.

In the Avatamsaka Sutra, it says, "Mind is like an artist, able to paint the worlds. The five clusters are all born thence. There's nothing it doesn't make. As is the mind, so is the Buddha; as is the Buddha, so are living beings. Know that Buddha and mind are in essence inexhaustible. If people know the actions of mind create all worlds, they will see the Buddha and understand the Buddha's true nature."

So we know of all the many unskillful, unexamined desires, strong attachments and tendencies we're starting to know or become familiar with in ourselves that cause trouble, stress, create harm for ourselves, for others. And we definitely need to learn skills guiding our alertness and our goodwill. And this is why all of the Buddhist teachings are considered to be skillful means, because they're part of our refuge, as I spoke of before, to protect ourselves from our own lack of skill. How generous. How generous. He could have just gone off happy as a clam.

As we continue on our Bodhisattva path to Buddhahood, Daido cautioned us against believing that we have all the answers, that we know what is actually skillful for someone else, even as we're learning what's skillful for us. He railed against arrogance, making someone disempowered in the name of skillful means. And we know Buddhist communities continue to grapple with leaders considered to be enlightened, using skillful means and taking advantage of their power dynamic. So that's been there throughout history, and we can be grateful to the Buddha and the ancestors for sharing with us what they worked through and taught.

You don't have to starve yourself and be an ascetic to realize your true nature. The Buddha said, don't do that. You don't have to do that. You can nourish. You need this body. It's your vehicle. Bankei says you don't have to push so hard to make yourself sick and then keep going and make yourself sicker. Don't let your Zen sickness be interfering.

Rengetsu showed us it was skillful to have a moving meditation when deeply grief-stricken, that the skillful way is to be absolutely, irredeemably heartbroken and not try and hold it together. She said, we can do that. It's exhausting and everyone can feel it, so we're not doing anyone a favor. She skillfully showed how to know that grief moves and not to solidify in stories about it.

So, skillful means—does it take something to make it skillful? Is it art practice, body practice, liturgy, face-to-face teaching? Is that skillful means in and of itself, or does it need us, our energy, our wisdom, our power to ignite it, to make it skillful? So we have a schedule. We get up at 3:50. Is that skillful for you? You knew that before you came here. You weren't straightjacketed into sesshin, so why fight it? You wanted this on some level—you knew it wasn't going to change. So what do you sit there?
