Why do we have to get up at 3:50? It's like ridiculous. So what does it take to make it skillful? Why is it happening? Why did you choose it? There's many things like that. We can go on and on.

Daido always used to say, you know, don't have this attitude like—just because you take your seat of zazen, you don't just throw, you know, sit there and lower your eyes and say, "Okay, do me. Anything happening yet?" He said, forget about it. In order for it to function, it needs to be discovered, engaged, applied, tested, and developed. And this is not just once. We're constantly having to work this like a piece of clay, molding it into a form. What's skillful? What do we keep? What's not helpful?

When the mind is free of attachment and delusion, its actions are effortlessly creative, perfectly tuned to the moment, just like the universe itself.

I was thinking of Shugen Roshi spoke about Yubiri and how the Buddha, after she had this grief and Buddha opened her up, you know, "Come to your senses." I was thinking of Patacara and the skill that the Buddha used with her. And there are lots of stories throughout the literature—we all know this. It's all skillful means. Every koan is skillful means, getting us to realize.

So, Patacara—her story was: she was a mother, had a child, and she was going to have a second child. And the custom is to go to your parents' house. So she was on the way to the home and a storm came up and she was very close to giving birth. In fact, it was time. Along with the storm, her water broke. So her husband went to get some branches to build a shelter and he was bitten by a poisonous snake and died. But she didn't know it because she crawled into a hollow tree and gave birth. It was only the next day that she searched for him and found him and saw that he had died.

So she decided to continue on to her parents' house. But she had to cross this river that was overflowing, and so she was going to take one child at a time to cross. So she took her newborn infant across and laid it in the bushes. And then she went to get the next child on the other shore when she saw a hawk come and pick up her child and carry it off. And as she screamed, the other child thought that was the cue to come and stepped into the water and was taken away. So that's a husband and two children within a few days.

And she continued on to her parents' house and met someone on the way from that village. And they said, "In that storm last night there was a fire. And I'm sorry, your whole family was taken in that fire." Needless to say, can you imagine her state of mind? And she just kept wandering, wandering after that, just not even taking care of herself, just wandering, wandering.

Unbeknownst to her, she came upon the Jeta Grove where the Buddha was teaching. And his disciples found her very frightening and appalling, a pariah. And the Buddha saw her, and they said, "Let her be." And he rose and he followed, and he placed himself in her path. And when they met, he said, "Sister, it is time to recover your presence of mind. Come to your senses." At that moment, it was like an electric shock for her. She was ready, and she came to her senses. And she realized she had nothing on. She took a cloak and covered her body. And she asked the Buddha to help her.

It's easy to say that maybe the Buddha did something, gave her something. Perhaps she heard not simply the words of Shakyamuni Buddha, but she heard that timeless Buddha voice which calls to each of us to wake up, to recover our presence of mind. What happens when we recognize no one can help us to come home? We have all the means because we've never left. When we unreservedly trust into the truth of that boundless mind itself.

I would say she emptied herself of her games, her illusion, so completely she could hear what was done. She was cleaned out. She found trust beyond any knowing and measure, direct to the heart. Patacara was freed. And then, after listening to her tragic story, Buddha told her, throughout many lives, she had shed more tears for the loss of loved ones than there was water in the oceans. I feel like that was a real critical part of the story that he said, that that was so skillful—that she was recognized, that she was met in her suffering. The Buddha reminded her, "At your death, even if they had all been living, your family could only look on in helpless despair. Only the Dharma can help you." And hearing this, she decided to ordain and was taken into the nuns' community, which welcomed her. And she became a teacher. And she used what she had been through as her skillful means in her teachings. Recognition of what is true by experience.

As is this fusatsu, a renewal of our vows—primarily to have the opportunity to atone, be at one, be not separate from our harmful karma, our intentional actions, separation we have created from beginningless beginning. And to recommit, to be guided by the precepts. So this ceremony, too, goes back to the time of the Buddha. How generous—we can atone for our harmful actions. And Buddha created this ceremony. What a way to spend a Friday night. "All harmful karma ever created by me since of old on account of my beginningless greed, anger and ignorance, born of my body, mouth and thought—now I'm at one with it all."

Maezumi Roshi says—he talks about ceremonial action. And he said the Latin word for ceremony is "caramonia," which is related to "cura," meaning cure, the act of healing or being healed. In other words, he says, ceremony is an act that cures or heals, or by which something is healed. And then he throws in his little, "We must ask, what is healed by what?"

As I was working on this, I was thinking of Daido's skillful means, of how we can connect with Avalokiteshvara Bodhisattva—Namu being one with Avalokiteshvara Bodhisattva. And he initiated an art practice to connect with Avalokiteshvara. Each of us had to study: what are the qualities of that Bodhisattva and find them within ourselves and then create something. And then he had us do this creative audience one day. So we got in groups of five. He loved to do this creative audience. And somebody brought this little sculpture they did. So we all did the process. He took us through relaxing every muscle from the head down to the toe, just becoming aware of each part of your body and relaxing it. And then taking a flash look, closing your eyes and seeing what the after-image was like. And then going into the art a little bit more.

And so we were all doing this sculpture and then we give our responses. And some people are saying, like, "I started to get a headache and my throat was really tight." And the next person saying, "I felt like I was being pressed and I couldn't move and I felt heat in my cheeks." And, like, everyone in the circle was sort of... And the person that made it was visibly getting quite angry. This is—this is their Avalokiteshvara, and we're all saying, "I feel tight. I feel like I'm choking. I can't move, move." And so he finally stands up and he says, "You people are nuts," and he tears out of there.

And so we start processing what happened. We were just doing it. It wasn't about him. We were just... And then in a few minutes, he returned and he says, "You know what? I was working on that up in the cabin and there was no heat, and it was 7 o'clock in the morning. And all I did while I worked was curse the monastery, curse art practice, wonder why I'm here as I'm sculpting this." That's what we got. That's what we got.

And Daido used to say, we're always creating something. The question is—what? How aware are we of our actions and what we are expressing? He also shared one time he got in a big fight in his company because they were—he was in a chemical company and they were pouring stuff out into the river. And he got in a big fight with everyone in the office and he stormed out. And he was coming home, and he had his camera as usual, and he saw some graffiti on these rocks. So he parked the car and he's fuming. He said he's driving along and he's just going over the whole thing and he's angry with everyone and going over the whole situation. And then he starts photographing this graffiti on the rocks. And he realizes he's lightening up and he's getting a little lighter. And he felt pretty pleased with himself and how the day ended and developed these images and had them on slides.

He said he had a date that night. He thought, that's what I'll do. I'll make dinner and I'll show these pictures I created. And so he does that. And as they're sitting there, he looks over at her and there's tears running down her face. And so he finishes and she says, "That was horrible. That was really painful." He thought this was the best thing he did, you know, and he realized—he said that was the first time he realized, as he says, "An unexamined mind is a dangerous one." That he didn't know he was working out what happened at the office. And that's what she was getting.

So we need to take care of our creations. Shugen Roshi gave a talk and I heard this thing—he said, "Don't put the handle of creation in someone else's hands. Create good karmic roots." Karma simply means intentional action. Simply. There's a lot on karma—this relationship between what we choose to do and then what we make of ourselves, how we shape ourselves and how we're shaped by ourselves through actions, moment to moment, by intention. Born of my—born of your body, mouth and thought. It's very direct. We can't look around. It says, "born of my"—nobody else's creation.

When Buddha was teaching his son Rahula, he said—this is like, can you imagine your dad sitting you down and saying this? I was trying to imagine that—"Look at your actions before you act. Look at your intentions. If you think that what you're going to do or say or think is harmful, unskillful, you've got to tell yourself, 'No, don't do that.' If you don't foresee any harm, then you can do it. If while you're doing it, you see that some harm is happening that you didn't anticipate, you stop. Otherwise, you keep on doing it. Then when you're done, you reflect on the long-term consequences of your actions. If you see that there was any unforeseen harm, then you resolve not to repeat it, not to repeat that mistake again. If you don't see that there is any harm, then you can take joy in the fact that you're training the mind well and you haven't harmed anybody at all."

So what qualities do we personally need to be developing? What qualities need to be abandoned? This is part of what the Buddha called the customs of the noble ones, that we learn how to delight—he said, "in abandoning whatever we have to abandon and to delight"—interesting, he uses that word—"to delight in developing whatever needs to be developed." Can we delight in abandoning what we need to abandon and delight in developing what we need to develop? We take delight in development in wisdom, and we support each other in such a way. This is said to be how we purify our actions and where we have to begin.

And I'll close with Daido Roshi's words:

So please, when you practice, practice skillfully, practice your life. Trust yourself completely. Trust the process of sitting. Know that deep within each and every one of us, under layers of conditioning, there is an enlightened being, alive and well. In order to function, it needs to be discovered. To discover this Buddha is wisdom. To make it function in the world is compassion. That wisdom and compassion is the life of each one of us. It's up to you what you do with it.

Thanks so much for listening.

For meditation supplies such as cushions, incense, liturgical instruments, dharma books and more, visit monasterystore.org—support for your spiritual practice at home.
Speaker: Jody Hojin Kimmel

Title: Practicing With Intention
Extracted Text:
Good afternoon.

On the Great Road of Buddha ancestors, there is always unsurpassable practice, continuous and sustained. It forms the circle of the Way and it is never cut off. Between aspiration, practice, enlightenment, and nirvana, there is not a moment's gap. Continuous practice is the circle of the Way. This being so, continuous practice is unstained, not forced by you or others. The power of this continuous practice confirms you as well as others. It means your practice affects the entire earth, the entire sky, in the ten directions. Although not noticed by others or by you, it is so.

This is the opening of Dogen's fascicle on Gyōji, on continuous practice or sustained practice—or another way to think about it is intentional practice.

An intriguing aspect of dukkha is that it promotes a raw honesty if we allow ourselves to deeply feel it beyond our insistence on ending or avoiding our suffering. I know when I feel the most acute pain, the most suffering, it deeply concentrates me and centers me in a way that I might not easily access under more comfortable and favorable conditions. When we thoroughly acknowledge our dissatisfaction and alienation in a given situation, we can be profoundly and painfully willing to let go of our habitual reactions to what makes us uncomfortable or fearful.

Interestingly, although we may recognize that our ways of avoidance do not ultimately help us, it is not easy, as we all know, to let them go, to let go of our safety net. The way that we habitually hide from ourselves perhaps is the entrance to a loving and generous compassion—to ourselves and others—to let go. This is the ongoing continuous practice.

On the Great Road of Buddha ancestors, there is always unsurpassable continuous practice, continuous and sustained. This is the invitation to practice that is before us.

In doing sesshin practice or other long sittings, other long forms of continuous practice, we travel on this great road of Buddha ancestors where, just as they did, we encounter our own minds with our foolishnesses, our obsessions, and in one manner or another, our self-limited and defined places we tend to live out of, sometimes not even visible to us. It's so habitual, just the water we swim in, except that it gets reflected back to us in how we live our life—sometimes just as a subtle undercurrent of disease and dissatisfaction, sometimes as obvious pain.

Those who have traveled the great road of Buddha ancestors have encountered precisely what we are encountering in our practice. They have practiced in a continuous and sustained way precisely as we practice to the best of our ability. We practice now on that great road so that we can be the ancestors for those who follow us on the road.

We can encounter our mind in action and study it, becoming aware of our thought processes with a clarity that's much more difficult to appreciate without practicing together. So practicing together offers us an encouragement with each other as we offer that encouragement to each other, and allows us to see again in a way that would be difficult for us to see just sitting in a lonely apartment or house, perhaps a cave, without an immediate sangha.

When I say together, it is not just those of us in this great room or those of us sitting at home, but we are practicing with all of those who have ever practiced in the timeless past and the timeless future. It's not that we are just connected. We are on this road together, all of us, past, present and future.

And yet at times we may feel helpless and lost, and at other times the path before us opens up and we see light. We see the freedom and open space which we know has always been there, but can be obscured and hard to find our way when we try and grasp it, reach for it. Yet Dogen says that on this road, we are all practicing the road of our Buddha ancestors. There is always unsurpassable practice. The practice you are doing is unsurpassable practice, always continuous and sustained. Always consider that our practice is always there, continuous and sustained.

Can we consider that this road that you and I are on is our practice—to journey with faith and trust in the Three Treasures? The Three Treasures as your own treasures, as your own journey within this vast great realm of this practice.

If, as Master Dogen points out, the road is always present, always before us, how does it become our road? Yours, mine? Intentionally and specifically designed, if you will, for your life. How does it fit? Because it fits so perfectly for you, it's essential to see what helps you in this practice and in your life, to really discern what is helpful and what is not helpful in our actions, in how we think about things.

I just always recall Shugen Roshi being asked a question and saying, "Is that a helpful question to ask?" Are we stuck someplace in our mind that we're kind of drilling into—a question that doesn't help us spend our time and energy, or are there helpful questions?

There's a thin line between "I cannot face this at this time," which needs to be honored, and doing your best to go into what we are facing at this time. When we do this with an intention, a clear intention, a practice becomes intentional. The intention clarifies our lives and it arises in our faith of what we've already encountered before as our own experience. And that may not be so easy to put in a box and define so we can grasp it in a thought. It's deeper than that, it's more subtle than that, more profound than that. And perhaps outside of this practice we're not very well trained to attune to that.

I was reading an article that suggested that we live in this society which is designed to take the most precious thing that you have as a human being, your attention, your awareness, and put it out there. And the article compared it to gluttony. That as we go through our life and are exposed, if you will—expose ourselves, if you will—to what is out there, it's just like an endless feast that we keep stuffing ourselves with, with our attention to things outside us that pull us away from any sense of clarity and a noetic sense of true honesty and self-integrity.

And in a way, our society is designed that way. Our politics is designed that way. Our entertainment. It's almost amusing when you open a web page—so you're looking for information, let's say—and there's a pop-up right on the edge. But you can't quite read the information that you're looking for. So you exit out, and there's another pop-up. And it's designed, and that pop-up may be based on other information from you being on the web. So it's alluring.

I was looking for water faucets—not the kind you can get—a specific kind of water faucet for where I live, and you can't get it at Lowe's or—you have to do a deep search and endlessly there's pop-ups. Here's another set of water faucets for you, brought to you by Amazon or whatever. It just keeps happening. And I look at Aho, my wife, and she says, "Forget that, we're not interested in that crap. You know, we're looking for—this isn't helpful," but in its own way it can be seducing.

When we practice with intention, deliberately, the path opens before us and it's wide and spacious. It's really simple because we understand that we can direct our lives now in a way that makes sense to us, that fits and has always been present as a trustworthy foundation. And your life changes when that happens. When you're on this path and you realize you can turn everything towards the path and you can trust that. And the results may or may not feel good in any given time, because we live in a relative world, and yet that too is trustworthy. And we could turn that to the path. And in doing so, we're moving towards a fundamental and vast responsibility, a responsibility for our lives. We can now own our life. And so all these other influencers and influences that are sneaking into our life are disempowered because we can recognize them as not helpful—or perhaps helpful.

And in walking on this path and in stepping into the responsibility for our life, it extends from my life to yours and your life to mine, because we deeply affect each other. And it's not just you or just me. We're entwined on this path. We are all walking the path together.

To study and practice the Buddha's way is to study and practice one's whole life. Within one's whole life is all of you. So although we're sitting here right now, at this moment, our whole life is contained in this moment. Our whole life has brought us here. And not only that, our whole life in the future is contained in this moment with all of the infinite possibilities.

Monday morning I went for a walk down Mill Road with a student and we walked together. I invited him to walk with me. And as we walked—I've been walking up and down that road for decades—and so many things have happened. I can recall a wild party that happened at that house, a Sangha party that I'm not going to share the details with. But some of you may recall a wild party or two from ancient days, or the people who've been there—some sick, some dying, some younger—or many other stories that we were sharing.

The Half-Secret garden, which if you go into, is an art garden and a place to sit. Suzanne—and I was wondering, is it still being taken care of? Yes, it is. And after I got back, I suddenly realized a remembrance from when I was the age of that student. And Roshi Kapleau, my first teacher in Rochester, New York, invited me to go for a walk. So I was the age of that student at that time.

Now then, and now—Richard Kapleau is an agent—at that time we went for a walk and he was very amused at me because I was young and vigorous and strong and worried about him as we kind of took a course through the streets of Rochester. Did he know where he was going? Or will he trip and fall? And it was a long walk, and he's seeing all this, can see it. And at one point he kind of says, "Come on, we're going to go over here." And we come to a strip, a median strip in a street between two sets of private homes. And he says, "There, look," and there's a stone. And on the stone is engraved, "Here lies Zen." And he looks at me and he's quite amused, and he says, "It's a dog. Someone buried their dog, and the dog was named Zen." Oh, Roshi.

And here in this walk on Mill Road, forty years later, the same thing's happening—exactly the same thing in its own way. And that's the perspective that this practice brings us as we walk this road together. And on this road, we realize most personally that there are no barriers to one's life and no barriers to our realization. We walk the road. This is the great road of Buddha's ancestors. Many practitioners from many cultures and different times have pointed out the road and walked it so that we can walk it as well. They have done so for you and for me. It forms the circle of the Way and is never cut off. How could it be cut off?

Walking on this road, we begin to realize that our lives are thoroughly interwoven with this path. And nothing in our life—absolutely nothing—exists apart from it when we walk that road, when we make the road our life. The distinction between formal practice, practice here, and living our ordinary, everyday life entwine and become a continuous journey. And we're exploring that. We're exploring: is there a difference? Is there not a difference? Although we may feel this connection to this road more intimately in these particular circumstances and sometimes more than others, yet also, perhaps you've had the experience that not in the circumstances, but at home or work, we suddenly became completely intimate with the road, with what's going on and you, or with you and others, which really is the same thing.

Think about our mind of zazen. It's really the same as our life, seeing here the habitual patterns that we repeat regularly. And we can see how these patterns can be so tender and painful. And in seeing it, an option opens to respond in a new and fresh way. And we can study this and see this no matter where we are. It's easier, quote-unquote. Although, isn't it interesting how often we arrive here? And what do we run into? Ourselves. We throw up confusion, tiredness, sleepiness, too much energy, not enough energy, the food isn't right, my legs fall asleep. And yet everything is being offered to us. And everything is also being offered to us outside this room.

So as we study ourselves and our minds, be it here or elsewhere, and see opportunities before us to practice and to live in a new way, a different way, a fresh way, we know the old way and where that leads, and so do we wish to go in another direction. And this is the wonder and power of practice. Even if you say no and come up with a rationalization that no, I don't—knowing that there's suffering in your life or difficulty or barriers—even if we say no, if we continue to practice, there'll be more opportunities, more opportunities to kind of open the space. Even a little is a lot sometimes.

And so it's ours to choose which way to go. No one else but you can choose. That is the wonder and power of this practice—that you choose, which also can be scary. I mean, me, I want someone to rescue me. I want someone else—I'll call it the practice—to rescue me. But the practice is not going to rescue you. There's only one person who can rescue you from your suffering: Umuah, that's it. Usually, I say Umuah—as Miss Piggy would say. Do we know who Miss Piggy is?

So we can zone out to neutral thoughts, safe thoughts, or dullness that we're cultivating in the name of safety. And yet, on this road of ceaseless practice, there will come, as you continue to walk, points at which we're not so caught up in pursuing or avoiding pleasant thoughts or unpleasant ways of thinking. That point will come, does come, repeatedly. And so as we sit, we begin to see the possibilities through ongoing practice and explore the possibilities of letting go of our familiar harm that we're so habituated to. And this is the path of ceaseless practice. This is the point. It's not a matter that I was lost before, but now I'm on this wonderful road. It's all road. And we are increasingly willing to encourage our journey on this road as our own. We can see that it has always been there before us.

This is the mind of zazen. Dogen says it is that sustained effort that forms the circle of the Way and ensures it is never cut off. So Dogen speaks of this as a circle. It's a circle simply because it does not travel from point A to point B. We're here. We're always here. Where are we going? The circle is full. Nothing is outside it. Practice is the circle. You are the circle. We're not going anywhere in the sense of moving between these different places. We're in this vast circle of an unending practice, as our life, with nothing excluded, no event, no occurrence is apart from this. Your arms and heart are wide open, large enough to hold it all. You are large enough to hold it all. Mu is a circle. Breath is the circle. Shikantaza, just sitting, is a circle. Each step along the way is a circle.

From this perspective, you cannot get lost. No matter what happens, you can't get lost. Imagine living out of that confidence that no matter what happens, you can't get lost. You were trying so hard to be safe before, but you've actually always been safe without the trying so hard. Straight ahead, each breath, each thought, each no-thought, straight ahead, runs away as you step. Yet who is taking that step? Who is that one? Are you someone or something else while taking that step, while taking this breath? Are you adding a head on top of your head?

As we walk in the circle, we're always returning home, leaving home with each step and returning home with the same step. Between aspiration, practice, enlightenment, and nirvana, there is not a moment's gap. Continuous practice is the circle of the Way.

Right here in this statement of Dogen is the Buddha's original proclamation: I and all beings are once awake, have always been awake, whole and complete from the beginning. Though this is so, it has to be made our own. It has to be realized. And realization is not a thing. It's not, "Oh, now I'm realized. End of story." We're doing it now. On your cushion, on your seat, you're realizing the Way.

Ordinarily, we approach practice from some sense of lack, from our suffering and others' suffering, to a sense that perhaps we're missing a life as we live. So we take our practice, perhaps we encounter the aha moment and get turned on by this practice. "This is the Way I've been looking for. Great, here it is." Just go. So out of our aspiration to address what we are trying to address, we start, we practice. We cultivate the understanding and the clarity. We cultivate the insight into our being. And as we continue, our life reflects this practice as compassion, as wisdom, small bites. But as we go on, it grows, it gets larger.

So this narrative is okay as far as it goes. But as we deepen, we begin to see and realize that this is too small a frame to hold what our practice truly rests on. In a subtle way, it's too self-referential.

When Dogen says, "Between aspiration, practice, enlightenment, and nirvana, there is not a moment's gap," what is he showing us? Not a moment's gap, no gaps. What is he pointing at? All the steps of our practice realization are present from the very beginning. They're all there. They've always been there. You don't have to go anyplace. It's always right here.

Early on, we may not see it this way yet. Aspiration and practice, enlightenment and nirvana are present from the very beginning. That's what the Buddha saw. That's what so many people have seen. And right now, now, as you practice, that is true for you as well, and me.

And that takes us to the question, because it has to be realized: Will you have the profound faith to practice wholeheartedly, to give it all that you can give it? Will you trust yourself enough to give it your all—not as some measurement of your effort that's important, but instead as just doing your very best without getting caught up in success or failure, just doing your very best to take up your practice, to investigate your practice, to go deeply within it? And when it is not wholehearted, to practice that. So isn't that wonderful? You practice wholeheartedly. And sometimes you realize, "It's not quite my best." You practice that. What does that mean, to practice that? Does it mean to rev up the motor? Does it mean to let go of the motor? What does it mean for each of us? It means a particular way of practicing that is yours, uniquely yours, that you have to see into.

So this is not an accomplishment, it's a cultivation of what is already there. So the practice is not lodged in our measurement of success and failure. It rests in the poco a poco study of our emotions and customary responses to our activities, to our relationships. And from this study we can come forth with an open heart under all sorts of different circumstances, some of which we never thought we could, and we can. And this is practice-realization. This is it. And it originates and rests in the cultivation of the vastness of silence in zazen. It rests in what you are doing here and continues in the moment-to-moment, non-stop flow of our breath and of our lives, of the moment-to-moment breath, just the breath and our whole life as a single thing.

So Dogen says, "Continuous practice is the circle of the Way. This being so, continuous practice is undivided and not forced by you or others. This being so, continuous practice is unstained." You can't fuck it up. You get it? If you give yourself to it as best you can, it's yours, it becomes yours, it becomes whole because it's always been whole. This being so, continuous practice is undivided and not forced by you or others.

What does undivided mean? Unstained, without division, without discriminations, not forced by you or others. It's whole.

Roshi Norman Fischer, highly regarded contemporary and teacher, makes a cogent comment about this, about continuous practice, and it really struck me, and it really pointed at the heart of this practice for us. He says, "Continuous practice, though I am now talking about it and you are now listening to me and thinking about these things, cannot be identified with a concept of continuous practice. It would then become a standard, a measuring stick, which would inevitably become imposed upon you, and you would impose it upon yourself if someone else didn't impose it upon you. So it's not a thing." His words are very wise words—to not mistake the words, the descriptions, the thought, for what it truly is. It's so much bigger than the words and so much more specific to you than the words and ideas of it.

We inevitably judge ourselves and measure our efforts and miss the very point we're examining. It reminds me that emptiness is empty of emptiness. There's no thing called emptiness. We talk about it all the time, but there's no thing called emptiness. There's no thing called continuous practice. There's no place where it sits. Conceptually, if we think about this, it's just an endless loop realized. It just is what it is. There's nothing to say about it. Although I'm talking about it and you're thinking about it. There we go, right?

The power of this continuous practice confirms you as well as others. That's Dogen. So how does this continuous practice confirm you? It's the practice of responsibility for our whole life. Our practice, our realization, arises out of, again, our whole life. And it extends from my life to yours and your life to mine. Present, right here, right now, you and I, continuous practice.

And so Dogen says, "It means your practice affects," because it affects you and I together. Your practice affects the entire earth, the entire sky in the ten directions. Although not noticed by others or by you, this is just how it is. What you do in zazen—think about this—what you do in zazen affects the entire earth, the entire sky in the ten directions, every place. What you do arising from zazen within the moments of our ordinary life, affects the entire earth, the entire sky in the ten directions. You can see that as a heavy, heavy weight, or you can see it as one whole way to live.

We cannot measure the effects of our practice. The Buddha could not. He didn't envision us sitting here today. Yet we are here because of his practice, the ancient ancestors could not. And yet, here we are. And so it always comes down to it. What will you do with this? It's yours.

Thanks so much for listening.

For meditation supplies such as cushions, incense, liturgical instruments, Dharma books and more, visit monasterystore.org—support for your spiritual practice at home.
Speaker: Ron Hogen Green

Title: Understanding Selfless Wisdom
Extracted Text:
This is from the Perfection of Wisdom Sutra.

Shāriputra spoke: The Perfection of Wisdom gives light. O Lord, she is worthy of homage. I pay homage to the Perfection of Wisdom. She is unstained. She removes the darkness from everyone in the triple world. She does her utmost to bring about the forsaking of the blinding darkness caused by the defilements and by false views. She makes us seek the safety of all the Dharmas which act as wings to enlightenment. She brings light so that all fear, terror and distress may be forsaken. She shows the path to beings so that they may acquire the five organs of vision. To beings who have strayed onto the wrong road, she brings about the knowledge of all modes through the avoidance of the two extremes, on account of the forsaking of all the defilements together with their residues.

The Perfection of Wisdom is the mother of the Bodhisattvas, the great beings. On account of her generation of the Buddhadharmas, she's neither produced nor stopped. On account of the emptiness of own marks, she liberates from birth and death because she is unmoved, neither unmoved nor destroyed. She protects the unprotected. On account of her being the donor of all Dharmas, she brings about the ten powers of a Buddha because she cannot be crushed. She sets in motion the wheel of dharma with its three revolutions and its twelve aspects, on account of its neither being turned forward nor backward. The Perfection of Wisdom shows forth the own being of all Dharmas on account of the emptiness of the nonexistence of own being.

This is one of the pieces of teachings that we've included in our liturgy that we do once a week instead of the Heart Sutra. And when we chant this, it really is the Heart Sutra. This is a slightly different version than what we have in the liturgy book, but this is drawn from the Perfection of Wisdom Sutra, one of them.

The Perfection of Wisdom is a body of Buddhist teachings. Edward Conze, who translated this, said it's one of the most important, profound bodies of religious teachings in all humanity. He might be a little biased. It appears in the form of the Diamond Sutra—which is a little more extended—and then different versions, described by how many lines: 8,000, 10,000, 15,000, 25,000, 100,000. The sutras are very consistent, I would say unrelenting, in their emphatic teaching over and over and over again that all things lack any substantial, abiding, independent existence; that all things are empty of own being, existing from their own side independently. On every page, that's being expressed in different ways, of course.

In studying that, as I am now, again, the recurrence of that teaching over and over and over again in different ways has an effect. In a sense, we need to hear it again and again and again because it's startling, it's radical in its affront to our ordinary way of seeing things. At the same time, it is the most natural, simple human expression of existence.

And so, the Perfection of Wisdom is the wisdom of the paramitas, the principles and practice of the bodhisattvas—dāna, effort, vigor, patience, the precepts, meditation. It's the perfection of wisdom that allows each of those other practices to be embodiments of wisdom. When giving is endowed with wisdom, is illuminated, is enlightened by wisdom, then it becomes dāna pāramitā. When patience is realized as selflessness, then it is manifested as patience pāramitā, and so on.

The embodiment of the Perfection of Wisdom, prajñāpāramitā, as the mother of all Buddhas, goes back into antiquity. She sits on the right hand of the Buddha here. It's interesting that even in this passage, which is a very famous passage because it's such a beautiful, just expression of veneration for prajñāpāramitā, it runs the risk of doing exactly what the sutra is constantly saying not to do, which is to turn it into something—"she." She is worthy of homage. She is the one who gives light. She is… So, it seems to very much be talking about something, someone who is prajñāpāramitā, who is endowed with all of these qualities, who will protect you, and so on.

And so, in studying this, in having this in our mind, we have to continually remember that this is just upāya. It's a way of speaking about something that has no form, is embodied nowhere. But it's hard to turn towards empty space, right? And so empty space is given a form as prajñāpāramitā, the mother of all Buddhas, so that then we can relate to this form—because that's what we do, because we have one, the world is filled with them. And so it's like there's a need to bring it into some form. And what form would help us the most as a way of inspiring and providing an example and giving us a sense of faith that the embodiment of prajñāpāramitā is something that we can strive for, we can have faith in our own capacity to realize that? Well, why don't we put it into a human form? I mean, you could put it into any form. In fact, it does take every form. But in terms of upāya, putting it into a human form brings it a little closer to home.

The mother of all Buddhas—the Tathāgata-garbha, the womb. Tathāgata is another name for the Buddha; garbha is "womb," the womb of all Buddhas. From prajñāpāramitā, all life ushers forth: all practice, all teachings, all realization.

What is prajñāpāramitā? We chant it every day. Avalokiteśvara, doing deep prajñāpāramitā, deep within this perfect wisdom, clearly saw emptiness of all the five conditions—the skandhas. The Buddha said the skandhas are not only what constitutes the person, but what constitutes the world. The Buddha said, "The skandhas are the world. The world is the skandhas." And so they describe these different aspects: form, which you can take as your body; sensations, when your senses come into contact with something within their respective fields—sight, sound, taste, touch, feel, smell—there's a feeling, there's a sensation. Feeling here doesn't mean, you know, how I feel about something, but it means the sensation that arises in that moment of contact.

Perception: we perceive it. The mind instantly, immediately wants to know, "What is this?"—to identify it, to name it, to place it.

Mental formations: our karma, the kleshas, our habits, our underlying tendencies usher forth in response to that perception, to try and not just put it into a place, but then to put it into a self. I'm not just interested in what this is, but I want to know, what is it in relationship to me? Because when the self arises, the self places itself at the center of the universe. And so it then needs to know what is everything that is the world that comes into the senses in relationship to this self, so that I can act on it, turn away, come towards, grab, project, love, hate.

And then consciousness: awareness of all of this—so "clearly saw emptiness of all the five conditions, thus completely relieving misfortune and pain." So the Buddha said that when we realize that each of those skandhas are empty of own being, that the form is not, that the self is not in this body, that when I have come into contact and I have a sensation, I don't exist somewhere within that sensation—it's just a sensation; that when I perceive that and name it, that the self is not in that perception, and so on. And when we really understand that, experience that—the emptiness of those skandhas, which are the self—what we're realizing is that the self is empty. Therefore, what is there to be caught in? And by what is there to get entangled by? What is there to be attached to? What is there to defend? What is there to build up?

Form is emptiness. Emptiness is form. Sensation, conception, discrimination, awareness—that's what that's saying. And prajñāpāramitā, the real nature of all things, is true in everything at all times. It's true before we encounter the Dharma. It's true in our first moments of zazen. It's true in every moment in which we're struggling. It's true in our realization. It's true at the moment of birth. It's true in our dying. It's true in our death. It's just the nature of things, the reality of things.

And yet, as we chant, when we do not see the way—when we do not see prajñāpāramitā, we don't see it, even as we walk on it, even as we're immersed within it.

In the same sutra, Shāriputra asked the Buddha, "Well, how is the perfection of giving, for example, dāna pāramitā, fulfilled by a bodhisattva? What is the perfection of giving?" And the Buddha said, "The perfection of giving: when gifts, giver, and receiver are not taken as a basis, are not misunderstood to be something that exists with its own being, as something separate, distinct, apart." The perfection of morality is realized through not transgressing into either offense or non-offense. In other words, we practice not offending, not transgressing against the precepts—we practice that. But ultimately, what the Buddha says is prajñāpāramitā is when we realize that, because nothing exists in and of itself, there is no absolute right and wrong that exists by itself, just in the universe floating around.

The perfection of patience: through imperturbability. (Imperturbability! Got it.) The perfection of patience, through being imperturbable. Think about when we first start practicing zazen—we're sort of in the opposite zone, right? The slightest thing knocks us off, knocks us off, knocks us off. Distracts, distracts, distracts, distracts. We get caught, we get caught, we get caught. And so, it's developing that profound stability that isn't a matter of holding on tightly, it's a matter of just not getting tossed. A hook is thrown and it doesn't land; there's no biting.

The perfection of vigor: through indefatigability of body and mind. When we practice and we struggle with energy, of course there can be different reasons for that. But ultimately, in the mind, in the body, there's the life force, which is the strongest force that exists within us. It's always there. And yet we can get very tired, weary, dull. We experience that—tend to experience that quite a bit in the early stages of practice, right? And it's easy to look at the schedule, or waking up early, or this or that as the cause. And the schedule is demanding. But what's really ultimately the source of that is our attachments, all of our, in a sense, misuse or not well-used functioning of our body and mind.

Prajñāpāramitā is not perceiving anything as existing on its own, as being separate, fundamentally as being opposed to something else in any absolute sense. It's the transcendence of all duality—realizing dualities are something that we create in the mind. They only exist, right? Something only exists in relationship to its opposite. Nāgārjuna said, "This stick is long only in relationship to a shorter stick. If you introduce a longer stick, then this stick is shorter, but nothing has changed." But if we don't understand that—and, of course, we can get that, that's why it's a simple example—but when we act as though that's not true and that things are endowed with an absolute sense of value, of quality, of characteristic, then that's what we grab onto, that's what we are rejecting or holding onto.

The perfection of wisdom gives light, Shāriputra says. And so this ancient—and I don't know if it's universally universal—but this employment of light and darkness: the sun, the bright light of day, and a moonless night. I have to think that there's something both primordial and very ancient about that. I mean, think about the time before electricity, right? When the sun went down, it just got dark, and everything was dark. So think about being in darkness—absolute darkness.

Years and years ago, when I was going to school in Kentucky, I went to Mammoth Cave, which is this huge underground network of caves, on a tour. We were walking and they had it lit, and it was with a group. At a certain point they had seats and we all sat down, and they talked about when spelunkers got lost in the cave, and that when they were rescued, what they usually talked about was most unsettling was not the absence of light, but the silence. That was what started to make them mad. And so the tour guide said, "So let's try and experience that. We're going to turn off all the lights and then let's just spend a period of time in absolute..." So you can really experience how absolute that silence is—just a little taste of what they were talking about.

So they turned out the lights, and it was black; you couldn't see anything. And I think the silence lasted for maybe five seconds. I swear, couldn't—couldn't happen, couldn't let that happen, even though everything was fine, nobody's in danger, we all know what we're doing, you've been asked. It's just too uncomfortable, too unsettling.

So, perfection of wisdom is giving light—it illuminates. And of course, remember what we're talking about here is Buddha wisdom, the wisdom that exists within each of us, our natural mind. That's what we're practicing to realize. Even though ultimately, by its nature, it's non-conceptual—that's why we can't think it into being. But when we think about any point of view, any mental state, any attachment, anything that obscures, confuses, increases our delusion, and so on, we're bringing forth, in a sense, a kind of darkness, a kind of veil.

On the other hand, when we're practicing—so every moment of letting go, of having the willingness to actually examine this mind, of developing understanding of the teachings, developing right view—even though all of that can be happening within subject and object, a self and an experience, in a sense, we're moving towards prajñāpāramitā. We're moving towards that bright light of wisdom in which things are not obscured.

And so in that way, any degree, in any way, that we diminish or relieve ourselves, or illuminate that which was hidden, that which was dark, and bring some degree of illumination to it, we're moving towards and living, experiencing ourselves more in accord with prajñā. So that's why it's so important in practice for the mind to be alert, awake, aware—because it's within those natural qualities of mind that we are more in alignment, more in accord with the very natural nature of prajñāpāramitā, which is awake. That's why that term is used so frequently: to be awakened, to be awake, to be wakeful—which is clearly not just not being asleep in the normal sense of the word, but it's to lift that veil.

Prajñāpāramitā is worthy of homage, to show respect for. And so what does that mean? When we're venerating or paying homage to prajñāpāramitā, what are we bowing to? Your mind, your wisdom, your Buddha nature. And so, in a sense, when we look at it the other way—when we're, you know, deluding ourselves, when we're not having faith in Buddha nature, when we're being self-critical, being judgmental of others—in that sense, we're not paying homage, right? We're in a sense not respecting that which deserves respect in ourselves and others.

I thought of the precept of perceiving clearly—not clouding the mind, the mind's natural radiance, the mind's natural clarity, which is what we're trying to bring forth so that we can realize prajñāpāramitā. And so, to give homage, to respect your bright, aware Buddha mind. In that way, we can think of zazen as a very profound and simple practice of self-respect—paying homage to yourself, to your mind, which we show the greatest respect to by letting go of our clinging, by freeing ourself of self-clinging.

Prajñāpāramitā is unstained. There's nothing apart from it. Nothing stands outside of it. It can't be corrupted or defiled. So, at our time, when it seems like every single thing is up for sale, everything has been reduced to a transaction—"If I'm going to give something, what do I get back?"—prajñāpāramitā does not even know that particular game. Unstained, not because it fulfills some idea of purity, but because there's nothing apart from it.

And so when we see stains, what appears stains within ourself—this thought, this emotion, this action, this quality—to bring to mind that your basic mind is unstained, right? As Suzuki Roshi said, "You're perfect, complete." That's prajñāpāramitā. And you could use just a little bit of work. Okay, a little bit of work. But to do that from within that understanding, that faith in being unstained—it removes the darkness from everyone in the triple world, brings forth that light, right?

Think about that ancient fear of night, of not having light. Those of us who live here—if you've ever been coming up and down the hill in the morning or at night, on one of those nights where it was pitch black, you couldn't see your hand, and then your flashlight goes out. I've had that happen. I had that happen once on the path coming over from the enbusu. And I was trying to feel the path with my feet, but I had shoes on, so I couldn't really feel it. So I got down on my hands and knees and walked like a dog, right? It worked, right? Because I could feel. So I could feel when I was on the path, and then I could feel when I started to wander. So imagine being—not on a path—in darkness.

So prajñāpāramitā removes the darkness and removes it in such a way that the batteries don't run out on that one. It rather illuminates what has appeared to be dark. It illuminates what appears to be dark.

It makes us seek the safety of all the dharmas. And there again, this language is so interesting, given the emphasis of the sutra that it is not something. Don't turn it into something. Don't take a stand on it. Don't solidify it—I mean, that's said over and over and over again here. It makes you seek the safety of all dharmas. So, how do we understand that it doesn't make you do something?

When we raise bodhicitta, when we begin to see more what's really going on, when we see how we are actively creating our unhappiness, our fear, our anguish, our anxiety, our tiredness—and when something just seems to appear without asking—how quickly we can begin to solidify that, turn that into something.

Think about during this week so far. You're sitting, everything's fine, and your meditation is whatever it is, and you just start to feel a little bit of a mood—a little bit of a mood, maybe a little tired, maybe a little cranky. You know, you just don't feel great. You're not in trouble, nothing's wrong, but you just feel a little... And then we feel that because it's in your body, right? And we can turn towards that. It's like, "What is that? Oh, I don't feel, you know, don't feel so great. My meditation isn't going so good," and we can start to think about, you know, "What's going on? What's wrong? Something's wrong. When I don't feel good, something is wrong, being wrong. Something needs to change. Something needs to be fixed here. What does it mean that I feel this way? Why do I feel this little tinge of mood coming on? What's happening? Is my zazen not good? Is this session not good? Is this dharma not good? Did I make a mistake? Do I not belong here?"

The mind can move so fast and create a world that, if we pay attention, we will see ourselves building it brick by brick by brick. But if we don't see it, then it just has power. Even if we do, it can still have some power. We can still feel it and feel in the grips of that.

So prajñāpāramitā makes us seek the safety of all dharmas when we realize, "This has no meaning. I have a body. Something is happening. I don't understand. Maybe I don't need to understand. Maybe it's not about that. Maybe it's just a sensation. I'm calling it a mood because perception needs to name it. It's just a sensation. If I just let it be that and I don't add meaning, then it has no meaning. It's just a particular quality of sensation." And that's such a really vital part of practice, is to develop that, strengthen that capacity. It changes things. It changes us. It changes our response. It doesn't change the thing itself. The thing itself is fine.

That's—as I was saying earlier, maybe that was yesterday—that's why sustained, extended periods of sitting are so important, so that we can just sit down and just—the world just comes and comes and goes and goes. And you're just seeing it, seeing the world turn as the world turns. For those of you old enough, there was a very famous soap opera years ago. They were onto something there.

It brings those who have strayed on the wrong road. It brings us back, or it calls to us. I think I spoke about this on the first evening—to one who is ready, to one for whom there is a certain degree of ripeness. Things have been stirring, things are moving, there's change, something is going on. We may not be aware of it. Oftentimes we're not—not really. And then we come into contact with something that is true: a teaching, the Dharma. We hear about meditation. We see someone, maybe a practitioner, and it gets our attention. It gets our attention. We notice it. Prajñāpāramitā brings those who have strayed onto the wrong road.

It is the mother of all Buddhas: the source of life, of strength, of ground and sky, freedom and discipline, of gentleness and fierceness, of an ancient knowing, of common sense, of selflessness, of compassion. In the sutra, there's a passage where it talks about how do we relate to the mother of all Buddhas? And they said, it's like if a mother had one child, three children, ten children, a thousand children, ten thousand children, a hundred thousand children, and all of those children loved their mother and felt so loving of their mother that they wanted to make sure that the mother was safe and strong and taken care of. We are the children. We have prajñāpāramitā. We are the child of the mother of all Buddhas. We are the mother of all Buddhas calling forth to the children.

I remember years ago when I was working on this, I had a memory of many, many, many, many years ago. There was a group of young people, teenagers, who came. They were living in a residence, and they were troubled youth. And they came to get some instruction—meditation, spend the morning here, and then we had lunch. And I was talking to this young fellow, and he was talking about, you know, his father had cast him out and he was living with his mother. And he said he was a hell being. He just caused trouble every day all over the place. And he said—and then his mother told him he had to leave. And he was incredulous. He was—even just telling me this, he was crying. And I said, "But you said that you were causing so much trouble." He goes, "I know, but she's my mother." And somehow he thought that he could do anything, right, that that bond was so unconditional. It's not. It's not. And nor is this one. Prajñāpāramitā will never have you leave home. She only knows how to call in. But we can be that unruly child. We can just be an inattentive child. We can not take care.

There's a story in the Therīgāthā of one of the nuns of the Buddha, Uppalavannā. She was born wealthy, went into the harem of King Kosala, who was patron of the Buddhas, and they had a daughter, Jīvanti. And they both loved this daughter so much that Kosala made Uppalavannā a queen. But then Jīvanti died young, and Uppalavannā was so overwhelmed with grief that every day she would go out to the cemetery and just grieve and grieve and grieve. And one day the Buddha came to her and said,

"Mother, you cry in the forest, 'Oh, Jīvanti, my daughter.' Come to your senses now. 84,000 daughters, all named Jīvanti, have been burned in this charnel ground. For which one of them do you grieve?"

And that can sound like a very stark, perhaps even uncaring thing. But think about that. Put yourself in the place of this grieving parent who can't leave, every day goes to the place where she has buried her daughter. And so this has been going—it isn't the first day, it's not the second day, it's been going on and on and on. And he says, "Now, now you have grieved. Come to your senses. Not only your daughter is here, but 84,000 innumerable daughters, all of them loved, all of them lost."

And she became a nun. And when she realized prajñāpāramitā, she wrote a verse. She said, "Pulling out, completely out, the arrow that was so hard to see embedded in my heart, that I nourished every day, the Buddha expelled this from me, overcome with grief, the grief over my daughter. Today, with that arrow removed, I am free from hunger. I am unbound. Therefore, I go to the Buddha, the Dharma, the Sangha, for refuge."

I would take issue with her saying—respectfully, Uppalavannā, if you don't mind—with her saying, "The Buddha expelled this grief from me." I can well imagine that it felt like that. But only she could do that. Only she could do that. And maybe the Buddha came at just the right moment. He didn't come on the first day, he didn't come on the second day. She needed to grieve. She needed not only to grieve, but to get to that place, as she said, where she was nourishing that grief in her heart, tending to it, actively holding on to that. Because we can think to let go of that grief is to forsake that which we love, to somehow turn away from it, to forget. We should never confuse that.

Prajñāpāramitā protects the unprotected. When we fall into those two basic impulses—we want to avoid something, deny something, reject something that we don't like—it seems like that protects us, right? We're getting distance between, we're saying no to that. It seems like it protects us. When we hold on to something that we want, it seems like we're protecting that from being lost. But if we look—we don't even have to look that closely—we will see that that's not true. It is not. Protecting us actually makes us very vulnerable. It makes us vulnerable to that which we want to reject and to that which we would hold on to, which means it makes it very difficult, if not impossible, to actually experience the truth, the reality, the real form of that which we are rejecting and that which we want to hold on to.

Then Shāriputra says, "How should one stand in relation to the perfection of wisdom? How do I do that?" The Buddha said, "Relate to the perfection of wisdom as to the teacher. So should one stand in the perfection of wisdom as you would to your teacher, as one should pay homage to the teacher. And here it's the Buddha, so also to the perfection of wisdom. And why? For just this perfection of wisdom is the Buddha, is the teacher. The teacher is not one thing and the perfection of wisdom another. Just the teacher is the perfection of wisdom. Just the perfection of wisdom is the teacher—one body."

And so when we bow to the Buddha—the Buddha on the altar, when we bow to the Buddha sitting across from us in the zendo, when we bow to that true reality of all things that is sitting in our bowl which we're getting ready to eat, when we bow to our seat—all containers possess, manifest the perfection of wisdom, the true reality of all things. When we understand that, then it's perfectly natural to pay homage, to respect, to take care of.

And I'll end with this passage:

The Buddha's asked, "How should we come to this perfection of wisdom? How do we realize it? How do we practice it? How do we realize it?" And the Buddha said, "To the extent that you do not approach anything, do not grasp at anything, do not try to hold on to anything, do not forsake anything, do not settle down in anything, to that extent you accomplish perfection of wisdom. To the extent that you do not procure, obtain any dharma, do not set it free or acquire it—because it is not something to set free or acquire—it is thus that one does not procure all dharmas, does not set them free, does not acquire them."

And isn't that precisely what we practice, the path of non-attachment? Right? It's a simple phrase. It's a simple thing to say. It's a simple thing to seem to understand. "Oh, again, don't attach." True. But this is making clear—don't attach to what? To anything. To not attaching to prajñāpāramitā.

And it can seem overwhelming, it's like, "Okay, I have to be on such guard duty 24 hours a day, never sleeping, right? So as soon as an attachment comes, I can shoot it down." No, we don't have to do that. We just have to be alert and aware and awake and see, because attachments are not something that exist in space. It's, "This moment I am clinging." It's, "This moment I am clinging." It's, "This moment I am clinging." That's the moment when we practice non-attachment, when we're establishing something, making something, turning something that is like a whisper, a wisp, a cloud, a shadow, a mirage—all of these images that are used in the teachings: a magician's trick, a magical display, all of these ways of describing something that's ephemeral, passing, and isn't what it appears to be.

And so if we meet it in that very understanding—something is there, what it appears to be is what's having an effect on me, that's what I'm getting entangled in. But if I can be mindful and pause for a moment and just remind myself: it is not that. What is it? Let's see. Let me see. Let me allow it to reveal itself to me by not getting entangled.

And so in our practice, we are at once very grounded in just practicing: sitting, a breath, walking, a meal, laying down to sleep, having a cup of tea. And in every moment that we're practicing, we are immersed in this most profound—not just teaching, but wisdom—which is the nature of all things now.

So if we can really appreciate that, have faith in that, it can put a whole much larger, deeper, broader understanding of what we're in the midst of. Right? So it's not just—we're not just involved in a kind of mechanistic, you know, exercise. It's much more alive.

Thank you for listening. To find out more about ZMM's programs, retreats, and residency, please visit us online at zmm.org.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Title: The Sacred Activity Of Work
Extracted Text:
Lehman Pong taught: My daily activities are not unusual. I'm just naturally in harmony with them, grasping nothing, discarding nothing. In every place there's no hindrance, no conflict. Who assigns the ranks of vermilion and purple? The hills and mountains—last speck of dust is extinguished. My supernatural power and marvelous activity: drawing water and carrying firewood.

Good morning. I wanted to talk this morning a little bit about work practice, what we call work practice, Right Livelihood, and the Eightfold Path as part of our theme of the Eight Gates.

And by the way, I wanted to mention that when the Shuso, or the chief disciple, is not here, their seat should still remain.

Okay, so the sacred activity of work. What is work? It's a big, fat word. When I looked in the dictionary, some definitions: labor, toil, slog, drudgery, the sweat of one's brow, grind, sweat, donkey work, spade work, elbow grease—just gives you a little bit of a flavor.

So we can think of work as a necessary thing that we have to do. Meaning if we didn't have to do it, that would be so much better. In fact, maybe that's what there are people who strive to do, is to not have to work. Work hard, get wealthy, retire early, die.

We can think of work as a way to earn money to support ourselves. It certainly is that. And we can think of that just so we can buy stuff, enjoy life, retire, die. Work can be status, power, identity, society's rank—work. What work is valued, what work isn't, who's at the top, who's at the bottom? And so in that, when society, or when there is a conferring of status, it's hard not to be fooled by that. So that if you do something that is high value, then you must be of high value. If you're not, then you're not. And the way that goes in industrial countries is if you have to work by the sweat of your brow, that's at the bottom.

We did a—Daido Roshi led a retreat years ago on precepts for people who work. And it was like one of the questions was, in terms of what kind of work do you take a shower at the beginning of the day or at the end of the day? Do you drink Starbucks, Dunkin' Donuts? Coffee, that is. And we grow up in that. We're taught that, and we tend to take it on.

It's been interesting, as the Sangha is developing, evolving, and getting older, that students speak about when they retire. You know, sincere practitioners really examining the nature of the self and identity and the ways we can accumulate and take on attachments. And I've talked to students who've really been surprised at recognizing how much they identified with their work when they weren't doing that anymore.

Before work, I was this person. I did this thing. I was seen in this way. This was not only how the world saw me, but evidently how I saw myself.

We can also think of work as service, as a giving, as dana, as practice, as study, as meditation. We can think of work as oryoki. What is the right amount? The right amount of work, of time, of money, of effort?

I remember years ago when I was at the temple talking to somebody who had been coming to the temple for a while. They were European. I don't remember what country they were from. And they were over here for a while working with an American company in New York City. And I said, is it different? He said, you people are crazy. He said, you work all the time. Don't you do anything else? He said, it's important, but it's not that important.

We can see work as relationships—to the work itself, to people, to what is it that's being created, what is its benefit? We can think of work as a spiritual power to study the self. Mindfulness training, going beyond.

Buddhism says that we move, as practitioners, we move within a Buddha field. And that field is—in the Vimalakirti Sutra, it speaks of that in various ways, but it's basically your field of influence. Then in many ways, our work can provide us with a field of a particular kind of influence. If you're a teacher in a classroom, if you're a person in an office, if you are a physician, if you are a nurse, if you are a construction worker, if you're a plumber, if you work in retail—we're coming into contact with people, hopefully. And in that, we have some field of influence, direct influence, both in terms of what we're doing in our work, what we're creating, what we're providing, but also in terms of our interactions with people.

In Jinzi Fukan by Dogen, spiritual power. Dogen says, the spiritual powers that are thus are the tea and meals of the Buddha family. No Buddhas up to the present have neglected or grown tired of them.

And Zen has a particular relationship in history with work. Because traditionally, in the early tradition of the monastic practice, time of the Buddha, monks weren't allowed to work. Monks and nuns, their work was being a monk and a nun doing Dharma practice. And so they begged for their food. Everything they needed had to be provided by the lay Sangha.

So from the very beginning, there was this very important and essential relationship between the monastic and the lay communities. And they were reciprocal, so that the monastic community was provided with support and food and clothing and so on. And they in turn provided teachings to the lay community.

In the Zen tradition, the monasteries—so in order to do that, you have to live in places where people live, right? If you're going to go begging for your food, you have to be where they are. Zen monasteries in China began to develop, establish themselves in remote areas. Look at Eiheiji, that Dogen developed in Japan. I mean, at that time it was way out. So they had to rely—they still relied on donations, but they also tended to be more self-supporting.

Every living thing works. We can think of it that way. If we think of work as activity in which something is happening—every living thing gives and receives, gives from itself and receives. It's receiving, right, in order to have life, and then it gives some of that. The sun, you would think, is working. It's providing us with light and warmth. Every living thing is supported by the environment in which it lives and then offers support in turn. And in the non-human world, that usually works in a very nice way.

When I was studying mathematics, I thought one of the nice things about mathematics is you never have to write papers, you know, if you don't want to write papers. And in one of my courses I had to write a paper. And so I wrote about a particular form of mathematics that helped to explain and sort of demonstrate mathematically the relationship between predator and prey and how different conditions, different environmental conditions would affect that. And this was all presented mathematically. I have forgotten all of that. I couldn't, wouldn't understand it if I saw it now.

I mean, look at spring, for goodness sake. It's happening everywhere. Every living thing goes its own way of being in the world. Think of a tree, right, that from the very beginning, all the way through its life and all the way through its death, it is giving, it is providing, it never ceases to give. And in that sense it works. But it doesn't know work, it doesn't think of work, it's not going to work, it just is. That's its way of being in the world.

In the human world, it's a little different. We can think of it as karma. We act and we create consequences. We can think of work that way. I do something, and it has some effect.

Kanzeon, at one with the Buddha. At one with the Buddha in cause and effect, Morning mind is Kanzeon. Evening mind is Kanzeon, the great Bodhisattva of compassion related to Buddha in cause and effect. We should examine that. What does that line say? How is the Bodhisattva of compassion related to the Buddha? Wisdom and cause and effect. Compassion at one with wisdom in cause and effect. Morning mind is compassion, wisdom, one thing. Evening mind is wisdom, compassion, one thing.

The Buddha taught right livelihood, right? That there are some livelihoods the Buddha said, that are just not, not right. Why? Because they create or they encourage not living rightly: weapons, selling intoxicants. And so he was pointing at, you know, that what we do has consequence, so we should reflect on that.

And work is grounding, right? We're doing something. We are somewhere. We're located somewhere. We're touching things, and it's grounding, right? During sesshin, it's really important when we spend so much of the day sitting in silence, so much of the day turning inward, that there's this period of time in the morning where we both take care of everything that we need to take care of so that we can actually do sesshin all together. And also so that we can ground ourselves if we need to encourage that.

It brings us into direct contact—body, mind, breath, energy, things, as well as beliefs, history, associations. And in that way, work is a bed of deep habits, deep habits that started early, possibly even before we worked. We were children. We were seeing our parents go to work. We were seeing other adults go to work. We were listening to them talk about work. How did they think about it? What did they say about it? How did they like it? Was that a positive experience? Was it positive teaching?

I remember when I first started working, I was—I mean, I, you know, I mowed lawns, I babysat. I had a paper route when I was really young. But when I was, I don't know, twelve maybe, I went out and got a paycheck job, you know, working in the back of a laundromat, washing dishes in a restaurant. And I remember my mom saying, "Oh, honey, you don't have to—don't—you don't need to work yet. You're going to work, spend your whole life working. You don't need to do that yet. You know, just be a kid." She would say, just go out to do kid things. But I wanted to work. First, I needed—I wanted to have a little bit of spending money. And I couldn't really ask for that from my parents. And so I wanted to, but then I realized I kind of liked work, that it was a good experience, and it was completely on my own. They didn't help me. They didn't interview, you know, they didn't—I'm pretty sure they knew where I was working, but they weren't, like, watching it real close. I was really—so I was at a very young age. It was like, you know, I'm doing this, I'm the one who has to be responsible, which is incredible. It's really invaluable for me.

The Buddha said, around work, he said, follow the teachings on wholesome and unwholesome actions in your work. Let those be your guide. The precepts—how are they being manifested or not in your work? And of course, many people work in situations in which that can get complicated, right? There can be a lot of good, and there could be stuff that's not so good on any different kind of level. And a lot of students, really, honestly, in a very valid way, work with that, struggle with that, try and find their way into that, through that.

He also said that as we're earning income, accruing some wealth, that we should do that properly. We should support ourselves, our family, we should give some to the community, give some to the Sangha, he said, and also put a little away.

It's very interesting, the Buddha who had these teachings on work for the lay Sangha, but he said, don't use wealth as an end in and of itself. That's not right livelihood, just earning to earn, making money to have money. Use it, direct yourself, direct it.

And so we can think in that way of work as being grounded in trying to create no harm. And oftentimes that's not possible. So can I do something that creates the least amount of harm? Are there ways to mitigate that harm? Are there ways to sort of offset, pay back for that harm that I might be creating?

The Buddha said—he said we should gradually increase wealth without squeezing others, just as bees collect honey without harming the flowers. It's a very nice metaphor, right?

We can think of work as a way of keeping our house in order, which is actually part of Buddhist practice. Keep your house in order. Because the Buddha said poverty is a cause of pain. He said, when we're poor, one runs into debt. And this situation can very easily lead us into a state of decline in various ways: mentally, physically, spiritually, right? Then when we're anxious, it's very difficult to practice on an ongoing basis and settle and develop our mindfulness and deepen our concentration if what we're anxious about is that our house is not being well taken care of.

And I think I was thinking this morning, one of the interesting things about work is that in a way, perhaps all work brings in some level of tension, of anxiety or even fear. And I was thinking this is—probably goes all the way back to the beginning of time. And not just for human beings. I mean, in what other ways other creatures do or don't experience fear. But, you know, lives depend on it, right? So even as human beings, if you're going out hunting, are you going to eat, right? If you're gathering, are there things to gather and eat? In other words, it's not a trivial thing. And so within that, there can be anxiety, tension. And for us, there is. Our lives are supported by this. So it matters, right? So what we do is, you know, can have a lot of these different qualities of spiritual practice and thinking about what we're creating. But also, on a very basic level, it's like we're supporting ourselves. We're providing for our necessary needs. And so there can be an anxiety, because if that is dependent upon that work and in that dependency, right, there can be tension.

In the early years when I first came here, I grew up in a house in which, for various reasons, we didn't have a lot of money and we had a lot of debt. And so I grew up in that kind of environment. And in other ways, it was a wonderful, loving house and family. But there was that. And so when I first came into residency or soon thereafter, I was—I was put in charge of bookkeeping. And I was like, I don't know anything about bookkeeping. I've hardly ever had any money, right? And they're like, but you studied mathematics. I said, it doesn't—it's not the same. And it wasn't. So I had to learn. But that wasn't the hard part. The hard part was feeling responsible for the financial body of this place at a time when there was never enough. And it was like, just order me to go to hell, please. That would be better. So I had to deal with this ongoing tension, this ongoing anxiety that wasn't just about taking care of my house. That was hard.

It's interesting, in physics, work has a very particular meaning. Work equals force times direction. So if you have a box—I was listening to some guy, he said, if you have a box and you're pushing it, so there's a certain amount of force going into pushing that box, and it moves in the line of you're pushing, and the work is that force times direction. But what if you're pushing from an angle? The box is here, and I want it to go that way, but I'm pushing down here. Then the direction is diminished, right? The force is—I mean, the force is diminished because it's not all going in the line of direction.
