And so if we think of that in terms of practice, in terms of mind, you know, we talk a lot about intention and raising aspiration, but that intention is a kind of force. But then what direction are we applying it in? And are we applying it wholly in that direction? When we try and help a student clarify, when they want to become a student, why do you want to do this? It's to try and see, or somebody wants to do jukai. You know, is it really—is the intention really what jukai is, or is it for other reasons? Yes, I really want to take these vows, I want to be a bodhisattva, and I also want to raise my status a little bit, right? I want to maybe seem a little bit more important, you know, so that's a—that's not a direct application of intention, right? It's not all moving in the same direction, which means the force, the work is going to be diminished. It's just a different way of looking at it.

So spiritual power equals effort times intention. The mind merging with the body equals the cause versus aspiration. We take up work as a way to study. That's why it's so important that we do the caretaking practice, right? So that we don't just assign jobs and go to work, but we stop and we do this liturgy. That's very clear. We chant the sutra of compassion. We don't chant, you know, the sutra of drudgery and toil, right? To bring our attention, to make it very clear, what am I doing? I am being assigned a task. Thank you very much for giving me that opportunity to serve, to give. But what is underlying that? Is it just to make lunch? Is it just to tend the garden? Is it just to clean a bathroom? Make it larger.

Dogen says, make it the 3,000 acts of the morning and the 800 acts of the evening. Don't exclude anything.

And so in thinking about work, let's think of it as all activity, right? Not just if you're paid for it or if you're unpaid, if it's physical or mental. If you're retired, we're still doing something. You still wake up each day. What do you do? And so if we think of work as whenever, wherever I come into contact with myself, with activity, with things, with others, to think of that as a sacred activity, a sacred work, right? So we can kind of reclaim it from just being what happens nine to five or whatever hours you clock in and clock out.

When I was younger and worked on a couple different farms, Egg Lane Farm in Georgia and a dairy farm up near Utica, you know, I learned so much working on these farms with these farmers where work and life was completely integrated. They didn't wake up and say, I'm going to work. They just woke up and their day was before them, and there was much to do. But always, particularly in this farm I worked on upstate, always, people would come by, neighbors. And Freeman, the man I was working with primarily, who ran the farm, he would stop and he'd go over and they'd sit on the fence for a while and they'd talk and have a very leisurely conversation. Often he would be telling them about my latest mistake, what I had last done that was like, you know—which when it happened, he got furious about, but then became food for entertainment and good stories. It helped sort of me lick my wounds and think, I'm actually providing you with a lot of good stuff here.

But watching just their relationship with work, and they never called it that. There wasn't that kind of consciousness. The way they worked with their animals, the way they worked with machinery and powerful—I mean, I was young, I was pretty fit, and I had to hustle to keep up with them.

Wendell Berry says, when the scale is right and the work answers the calling of the workers, what is needed, then such work as they would rather be doing anything else in the world, then the work comes to be motivated by love, and that changes everything. Love always changes things.

He says, when work is done for love—of the place where it is done, of the materials, the artistry and the product of the work, of the people it is done with and for—then the sign or evidence of it will be beauty. It's beautiful. Both the work and its result will be beautiful. Ugliness in work or in its results is a sign of something gone badly wrong. Something's not right here.

In my early years, when farming here was smaller—he's talking about rural Kentucky in scale and far more discipline of the eyes and hands than it is now—an adjective often applied to work was "pretty." A farmer would mow a field, cultivate a row, crop, and then look, stand back, and say, "Oh, that's pretty work." That word can give pleasure—is one of the happiest things we can know of our life in the world.

I would say, amen to that. When I think about the things that I learned, particularly younger, so important because I was young, you know, I was learning. I didn't have all this experience. I was learning from the people around me who were always adults, older than me, and people from all different walks of life. In the back of a laundromat, in the back of a kitchen, I was working with people who oftentimes lived hard lives. And they taught me lots of things just through conversation. I was a kid—paying attention, taking responsibility, being accountable, showing up, being patient, persevering.

When I worked in that restaurant, I'd come in after school and there would always be a huge pot from the morning breakfast of grits. Now, if you've ever made grits and then just let them sit afterwards in the pot, you know what I'm talking about. It takes the consistency of concrete. And I never—I didn't know enough, so I never just put it on to soak, right, which would have made it very light work. I didn't know how to do that right, so I would scrape and scrape and scrape. That was my—that was my beginning work each day. So perseverance, openness, honesty, being honest in our work.

That job on the farm, he asked me if I knew how to drive a tractor. And I came to that farm on my bicycle. I didn't even have a license, and I had long hair, and I was from the South. So he was looking at me like, I don't know. He said, "You know how to drive a tractor?" And I thought, that's probably important. So I said, "Yes, I do." And I thought, how hard could it be? The first day, he tells me, he doesn't just tell me, go get the tractor. He says, "Get the tractor, back up, hook it up to the manure spreader, and then bring it around." So I jump on the tractor, and he's there with a neighbor, and they're just talking, and they're just watching me. And I'm watching them watch me. And I'm like, okay, this is the moment. Figure it out. Figure it out. I can't figure it out. And he comes over, he says, "I thought you knew how to drive a tractor." I'm nineteen maybe. And I said, "Yeah, that was a long time ago. I forgot a few things." He just shook his head. Yeah, he enjoyed that.

Daido Roshi talks about, you know, in very practical ways. And that's part of the power of work. It's practical, right? He said there's preparation, and this is the whole—a whole body and mind thing. Work is a whole body and mind thing. It's not just, you know, being mindful. That's not enough. There's much more going on. So he says we should prepare. And then there's doing the work itself, and then there's completing the work, cleaning up and leaving no traces.

I was thinking of this building. I think of it often because it's such a marvelous building in and of itself and a testimony to the love of work. The people who built this building could not but have loved what they were doing. You see it, it's all over. And Siobhan, who's been helping us create this narrative of early Sangha members who helped to make this place happen, he's also done some research on the building. I just want to read a little bit.

The Arts and Crafts style of architecture that this building was designed in has its roots in Europe, 19th century. And it says in this idiom, the Arts and Crafts inspired building was a simple, functional and beautiful structure with all parts carefully integrated so that it would be a factor in the growth and happiness of the people who lived in it. So it was built very consciously in such a way that it would help encourage, strengthen the growth and happiness of the people who lived in it. In plan, the spaces flowed easily into one another in order to maximize socialization and to ease the burdens of maintenance. Well, I don't know about that. The Arts and Crafts aesthetic required the use of natural materials—wood, stucco, stone, plaster—with the quality of craftsmanship of great importance. How is it done? In addition to the importance of materials and craftsmanship, the building should be sited in a location that harmonized with its landscape.

We struck gold, all of those things coming together years ago when we needed to. Originally, for many years, this floor had a subfloor of pine, which was a subfloor, but they never finished it. They never put on a finished floor. And it had lots of peaks and valleys, significant peaks and valleys. And so it was time to put a floor on. And I was—and I didn't know about this kind of thing, so I was getting quotes from these different contractors. And I would listen to them, how they—their plan for leveling the floor in a way that would, you know, have some stability for years. And there were some of them that I just thought, that's just not going to work.

And there was one guy who came in and he talked and he, you know, talked. He wanted to go downstairs and look downstairs. None of the other people wanted to do that. And then we were back up here and we were at that back entrance and I'm talking to him about the project and the plan and I realized he's not listening to me. And what he's doing is he's looking at that pillar right as you walk in that's got these cross hatchings, and he's just looking at it and he's just touching it. And I said, you're the one. I did. I mean, both because his plan I thought seemed brilliant, but also I thought because you already love this place, you already recognize the love that was put into this and you want to add something to that.

Daido Roshi says our ordinary tasks can be wonderful opportunities to practice. When students reach a certain maturity in their zazen, their work, their life, all they do helps them develop an equivalent clarity and integrity. Work emerges as an active function of zazen.

Dogen said about Lehman Pang's poem that when he said "spiritual power and wondrous function, carrying water, carrying firewood," he said, you should thoroughly investigate this teaching. Carrying water means conveying water. There is your own work, your own intention, and there is others' work, teaching others, and they bring about conveying water. What we do is our own work. What we do becomes others' work.

One way of looking at what we're in the midst of right now and all throughout all samsaric generations is when other people's work is not done out of love, then their efforts and the consequences of their efforts becomes everybody else's work. And oftentimes burden, oftentimes what is given is ugliness. Because people are not loving their work. There is no sense of artistry, of care, craftsmanship, of the importance of doing something and doing it well. Not in an uptight way, not in a perfectionistic way, but just for the love of it. Because it feels good. It feels good in the body and mind.

When I was working in a restaurant years ago, when I was in college, I was being asked to do way more than was reasonable, but that was the job. So I took it on. And I realized every movement I made has to count. In other words, I can't do any superfluous movements because there's too much. And what I realized was over time, as I was just trying to actually survive and get what needed to be done done, that it was kind of moving, flowing. I discovered it was kind of became a kind of elegance in the work and my movements. It wasn't what I was shooting for in the beginning, but it was like it was kind of coming out of that. And I remember beginning to recognize and thinking, oh, we can think of work in our liturgy, in service positions that many of you do in oryoki, and in those forms of practice, I think we do see and can experience a sense of dignity. It is dignified and again, not in a, you know, I don't know, stupid kind of way, contrived kind of way, but just a natural dignity of being that arises from doing something in such a way that is whole, that is complete, and that the thing itself is good, that's important, that the thing itself is good, because we can give ourselves wholly and completely to something that isn't good.

One way of thinking about it is that it's really cultivating in a sense—I think what we might strive for, aspire to, is that in our work we begin to really understand and experience what Buddhism teaches as ordinary mind, everyday mind, which in a way is the coming together, the culmination of everything that we're trying to do in practice. It is the essence of prajna paramita.

I remember when I worked on the koan, Nanquan and Joshu, and every ordinary mind is the way. And I worked on that koan and I worked on it, worked on, and eventually Daido Roshi passed me through it. And I realized, I haven't really seen this. I've had some insight, but I haven't really seen this. I had a sense that I was engaging something that was very deep, very big. And I imagined that I would spend the rest of my life really plumbing the depths of that. And I think I was right in that reckoning because it's still ongoing.

Dogen says, ordinary mind means to maintain ordinary mind in this world, in any world. Yesterday goes forth from this moment and today comes forth from this place. While going, the boundless sky goes. And while coming, the entire earth comes. This is everyday mind. I think of this as the perfection of work. If work was another paramita—work paramita—coming together, bringing together all the other paramitas, bringing together all of the precepts, all of what we do in practice. That's why it's really, honestly, one of, if not the most challenging aspects of practice to fully integrate, to fully harmonize, to fully embody, right? That's why it's so important that we practice it every day. Not just because every day we need to take care of things, but how do we take care of them?

Dogen says, ordinary mind opens the gate of the inner chamber because thousands of gates and myriads of doors open and close all at once. This is ordinary mind. This boundless sky and entire earth are like unrecognized words, a voice from the deep. The practice is doing that. It's opening that door, the boundless sky, entire earth, unrecognized worth.

When some of you have come here and have talked about, you came here maybe the first time and felt in some way that might have been hard to understand or explain, but the words that you used to explain that was that you had come home. I know that feeling. It's like encountering something and speaking unrecognized words. A voice from the deep that isn't in this place, but somehow the space is evoking that, bringing that forward.

Words are all-inclusive. Mind is all-inclusive. Things are all-inclusive. Sacred activity, when it's all-inclusive, is sacred. And what is sacred is beautiful. And what is beautiful serves, gives.

Is that why flowers are so beautiful? Is that why we're so moved by the creatures of the earth, by a spring breeze, by an open sky? Is that why they're so beautiful to us, so that we are moved by them? Are they providing us examples of that artistry, that depth, that inner chamber? I think so. And all of that without intention, right? It's not that it was all put there for us, but can we receive it as though it's being given to us?

And I really appreciate Daido Roshi for caring so much about that and really wanting to instill that, teach that, and make that an important part of what we did and our own tradition, which values that, recognizes that, has liturgy around that. The regard for a grain of rice, for how a meal is prepared, for how things are done, right? Because things that are done are just not things done. But it's my mind and body made manifestations. It's my love, it's my caring about myself, about this, about you.

Thank you for listening.

To find out more about ZMM's programs, retreats, and residency, please visit us online at zmm.org.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Title: Practice Instructions
Extracted Text:
The following Dharma talk was given by Ber Gokan Bonnbaker at Zen Mountain Monastery. Gokan Osho is a Dharma holder and priest in the Mountains and Rivers Order. This talk, like all of our talks, is offered freely. If you would like to make a donation or find out more about our various programs, visit us online at zmm.org. Thanks for listening.

Good morning.

This is from Master Hongzhi, who was a 12th-century Chinese master:

> Fully appreciate the emptiness of all dharmas,  
> Then all minds are free and all dusts evaporate in the original brilliance shining everywhere, transforming according to circumstances.  
> Meet all beings as your ancestors; subtly illuminate all conditions, magnanimous beyond all duality, clear and desireless.  
> The wind in the pines and the moon in the water are content in their elements without minds interacting.  
> Wind and pines or moon and water do not impede one another.  
> Essentially you exist inside emptiness and have the capacity to respond outwardly without being annoyed.  
> Like spring blossoming, like a mirror reflecting forms amid all the noise, spontaneously emerge transcendent.

He says, fully appreciate all dharmas, the emptiness of all dharmas. Then all minds are free and all dusts evaporate in the original brilliance. Fully appreciate all dharmas, then all minds are free. Whose minds is he talking about? Your mind and my mind? The mind of all dharmas. What does that mean? He says, then all minds are free and all dusts evaporate.

These dusts are the six dusts—the objects of our senses—which are called dusts sometimes in Buddhism because, in our attachment to them, to the objects of our senses, we get clouded, confused. Our mind, our original mind, is clouded, covered over. When they evaporate, he says, there is the original brilliance shining everywhere.

So what are these dusts, actually? How is it that they evaporate? Fully appreciate the emptiness of all dharmas.

Maezumi Roshi was Daido Roshi’s teacher, so one of our great grandfathers in the Dharma, would say, “Let us appreciate.” It was kind of one of his refrains, this very simple line: Let us appreciate. I find I return to that, to his teaching, this simple teaching. What is he pointing to? Let us appreciate. Just remembering.

There are a couple of early, in my practice, a couple of interactions that I remember. One, I was in a group of students meeting with a famous teacher and some of us had the opportunity to ask a question. One of my friends asked, “When I see something beautiful, how can I see it? How can I see it more fully? How can I appreciate it?” And another interaction was with Myotai Sensei, who was one of my early teachers here in daisan. I don't remember what the daisan was about, but I remember at some point she said, “For instance, if you would like to appreciate the gray of your robe…”

And these questions, I was kind of like, what are you talking about? My friend who asked the question about seeing beauty, I was like, what does that have to do with resolving my suffering? I don't understand. How is that a Dharma question? I think I couldn't see—how I couldn't see that my vision was clouded, my experience, I’d numbed. And yet I heard these questions. They stayed with me. They have stayed with me.

I think that at that time, I somehow also knew in me that I was divided, I was clouded, distracted, not able to see the world around me, and that that was part of my suffering. I knew I was suffering. This is part of the trap of samsara. It seems that a little bit of distance, a little bit of distraction, a little bit of numbing is protecting, protects. Maybe we do get a little bit of pleasure, comfort, but really we're distancing ourselves from ourselves, from our life, and that is suffering.

Let us appreciate. Maezumi Roshi says, how do we come closer? Coming closer, we can appreciate. Coming closer, there is a radiance. Coming closer, we come closer to ourselves.

Hongzhi again:  
> Fully appreciate the emptiness of all Dharmas. Then all minds are free and all dusts evaporate in the original brilliance shining everywhere, transforming according to circumstances. Meet all beings as your ancestors; subtly illuminate all conditions, magnanimous beyond all duality, clear and desireless. The wind in the pines and the moon in the water are content in their elements without minds interacting. Wind and pines or moon and water do not impede one another. Essentially, you exist inside emptiness and have the capacity to respond outwardly without being annoyed. Like spring blossoming, like a mirror reflecting forms amid all the noise, spontaneously emerge transcendent.

I chose this passage, these practice instructions from Hongzhi, because I wanted to speak about reverence and devotion. Last week, when I found out that I would be giving the talk, I was just kind of feeling around in myself—what would I like to explore, to offer, to talk about? And that's what I found. If I'm passing, paying attention, if I'm just practicing, well, this is always a live place. This is—maybe this is where practice is happening.

And when I read that passage, it was also, oh, and it is spring and we are celebrating Buddha's birthday. I also had the question, is this kind of speaking to the moment? I sometimes feel a question: is there an avoiding? I hear that from others in practice, and turning inwards? I don't think so. I think maybe that's not quite the question. This is exactly what we need more than ever. And we need other things.

In this ango, we're studying the eight gates of training, Daido Roshi’s offering practice. We can understand the eight gates—each of the eight gates, take them as practices of coming closer, different ways to come closer. Each gate is a practice of cultivating reverence, devotion, learning to appreciate, learning to appreciate more fully.

Hongzhi is giving us practice, instruction, guidance. The practice is to appreciate all dharmas, he says, to fully appreciate as they are. What has to happen for us to come closer? What's happening when we come closer? There is letting go. We have to let go of something, move through something, loosen what it is that divides, holds us separate. What is that? What needs loosening?

Hongzhi says, wind and pines, or moon and water do not impede one another. How would they impede one another? How do we impede one another in our relationship? They are in relationship, but so close.

When I read Hongzhi's practice instructions—there's a whole series of them, several dozen—always they include turning inwards. There he's speaking about zazen: to turn in deeply, cultivating stillness, cultivating the empty field. He says to be intimate, and always in each of them, I think there's also at least a line about turning out. Turn inwards and then turn out, in intimacy and not knowing. Is there also kind of turning in and turning out at the same time? When we really come close, is turning in—what is turning out? When we meet, truly meet a dharma, a thing, we meet ourselves.

Of the eight gates, zazen, in a sense, is the most direct. I think it's helpful to remember that it is one of the eight gates. It is a gate of practice, certainly a practice of coming close. Can we think of zazen as a devotional practice? Cultivating reverence in zazen?

In thinking about zazen and some of the other gates of practice, it's always felt to me like what we learn in zazen—the coming close, the learning that we can be quiet, the learning that we can concentrate our mind, we can be present with one thing, present with ourselves—that that informs the other gates of practice. But we also learn in other areas of practice. I think for some of us, there are kind of natural places of entry: art practice, body practice, work practice. We also learn to give ourselves over. We learn to enter caretaking practice, work practice, this practice of coming close in work, in our human activity of work.

Recently, Shugen was introducing caretaking at the beginning of retreat, and she said very simply, you know, each of us will be given something to take care of. What happens when we're given something to take care of? What happens when we take care of something? It changes our relationship with it. There are so many things that need taken care of—to take care, there is a letting go, there's a giving of ourselves.

I feel like we don't say this so much anymore, but there used to be—we used to talk more about leaving no traces. Maybe there are still signs in the bathroom that say, “Leave no traces.” I just don't see them anymore. Kind of an emphasis on leaving something finished, so that you're leaving it, letting it go, and leaving it complete, in a sense. Why? What does it do? Does it create when you do that?

I was thinking about the ushers straightening the zendo. So there are a couple of people, a couple of residents who are assigned as ushers, and they both hand out the books. But then when we all leave the zendo, their instruction, their service is to straighten the zendo. And, you know, when we leave the zendo, usually we're all pretty good about straightening our own seat, putting the cushion back in the middle. You could turn around and look at the zendo and say, yeah, it's good, it's straight. But the usher's instructions are to come back and to straighten each cushion, to smooth each zabuton, plump up each zafu, put it back in the middle of the zabuton. When I learned to be usher, I was told if there was an obvious seam on the zabuton, to put the seam towards the back. If there was a label or a name tag, to put the label towards the back. If the zabutons have a label or a stain, to turn it over.

And the ushers straighten all the seats in the zendo, and then they go and check the Buddha Hall, straighten the Buddha Hall. Sometimes they know the Buddha Hall hasn't been used since the last time they were in there. Why? What happens? Do we take care of things for others, for the next person to come along and see, appreciate, feel that? You do feel something when the zendo is well taken care of, or anything is well taken care of. Do we do it for ourselves, that the ushers have this practice opportunity, an opportunity to come close, to study a dharma, to study these dharmas, appreciate them? Do we take care for the things that we're taking care of so that they can flourish in their own way?

What happens in caretaking when we hold ourselves back? Some of the things that I, just walking around, will notice, I will see something and I'll say, “Oh, that's someone else's job. Someone else will take care of that.” Or “I don't have time.” I come in kind of in a hurry. Or “I'll get it next time I walk by, pick it up.” What happens when we don't walk by? We pick up a piece of trash and carry it to the trash can next time we get to a trash can, straighten the umbrella that someone left to dry.

Hongzhi's friend Dahui would say, all of these are first-class times to make efforts to arouse and alert yourself and awaken—awaken opportunities to come out of ourselves, to come close.

Liturgy is the gate of practice which maybe is most obvious that we are cultivating reverence, devotion—a place where we actually talk about that. When I introduce this much of introduction in liturgy and beginning instruction, people who are new here, I talk about reverence. When we bow, we're expressing reverence, cultivating that virtue. But how is it that liturgy is a practice of coming closer, of appreciating always, kind of in every practice? That is the practice, right?

So when we're chanting, it is a meditation practice to just chant, to be wholehearted, to be complete. That is the instruction for officiants: simply don't be doing anything else. The first time I heard that, Shugen was talking to a group of us, and I may have been the only senior there, so the only person who was actually officiating. And I remember he was talking about liturgy and he said this, and then he just kind of paused and looked at me. Then he went back to talking.

What are we cultivating reverence for in liturgy? When we're bowing to the altar. You could say we put a Buddha on the altar so that we can bow to the Buddha, bow to awakened nature. And for me, in liturgy, it's always, whether I'm doing it by myself or doing it in sangha, it's always, sort of in a simple way, just remembering that I'm not alone. Liturgy, we can offer the world to the world. We can affirm the wholeness of things.

I wanted to say a little bit about Buddha's birthday. You know, when we come to Buddha's birthday, I will always—this is, I think, the only sort of holiday that we celebrate, sort of Buddhist holiday that we celebrate. You know, everything else, we just do zazen or we do sesshin, right? That's like how we celebrate, which is great, right? And I don't know, this one feels different.

So just a little bit. I just looked some stuff up. There are some stories about the Buddha's birth, and so one of them is that when he was born, he was born sort of as a child, fully grown, and that he took seven steps on lotus blossoms that appeared for him to step on, and he pointed to heaven and earth. So that the baby Buddha that we bathe, that's why he is in that pose. Those figures were made by Kaijin, who was a monastic here for many years. For some years, I don't know how long, it was sort of in her—monks don't really retire—but sort of in her retirement, there was less and less that she could do that felt productive, and that was a struggle for her. And for a while, what she found is that she really enjoyed making these ceramic figures. And I think she made a lot of Jizos, and there are a few of them around here and there, you see them still. She died quite a while ago now.

So the Buddha is said in some stories to have pointed to heaven and earth, pointed up and down, and said, “Between heaven and earth, I alone am the honored one.” Another story says that when the Buddha was born, there were fountains of water that rained down from the heavens. One was warm and one was cool, to bathe the baby Buddha and his mother who had just given birth to him, Queen Maya.

I looked at just what a couple of contemporary Asian teachers say about this ceremony. One said that bathing the Buddha is an opportunity, that we're purifying our own body, speech, and thought. This teacher says in doing that, we might experience reverence or joy. Another teacher said the ritual of bathing the Buddha has a humanistic meaning. It not only expresses the reverence of Buddhists for the Buddha on the occasion of his birthday, but also gives everyone a chance to introspect themselves so that they may reduce bad seeds, increase good seeds, open their minds, raise the seeds of enlightenment, make life more meaningful, and bring happiness to all sentient beings in this universe.

So maybe that's what we were doing this morning.

In art practice—the gate of art practice—which for me has not been a natural place of entry. But I feel like what I have learned in art practice is kind of exactly this: appreciating that it's when I take time to do art practice and just sit with one thing, as we're doing this ango for our assignment—sit in the woods somewhere or walk in the woods and just listen and just look, kind of allow myself to be open and wondering—that when I can allow that, then something sometimes happens, if I stay long enough.

This ango I'm writing. So it's like, sometimes, like, well, if I just keep writing long enough and listening and looking and holding myself open, then sometimes something opens. Sometimes something comes out in my writing. Sometimes the expression helps, it seems, helps me to come closer. Sometimes something comes out and sometimes not much.

I saw this in one of Hojin Sensei’s retreat descriptions recently. She said, “Our path into expression, which will be informed by the silence and stillness of zazen, to help loosen the woven web of knowing that constricts our heart and mind and that often pressures us to yield to a certain result.”

All of these practices, we could say, are ways to loosen our woven web of knowing—this woven web which constricts our heart and mind and pressures us to yield to a certain result. How do we loosen this woven web of knowing?

Master Dogen said, “When you reflect on your life activities, are they intimate with zazen or remote from it?” When you reflect on your life activities, are they intimate? How do you know if they are intimate or not? This isn't a question that's like a value judgment—it could be hard for a lot of us to avoid that—but it is a place of study: is this skillful? Am I coming closer? Is this intimate or not? Or is it unskillful? Am I moving further away? Am I holding myself apart?

The skillful or unskillful, I think, can be a really helpful kind of guiding question. Awareness. If it is coming closer, how is that? If it is not closer, how is that? Can we feel that? When it is dividing and distancing, how does that feel—body and mind—to pay attention to that? Can we tell the difference? Because then we can choose. Then we can move closer, move into—into our lives.

Hongzhi says,

> Essentially, you exist inside emptiness and have the capacity to respond outwardly without being annoyed. Like spring blossoming, like a mirror reflecting forms, amid all the noise, spontaneously emerge transcendent.

We do have the capacity to respond without being annoyed, without resistance, without any discord. And we get annoyed. I appreciated what Daio said yesterday: just like, sometimes it's just grumpy. I felt like this line kind of brings us back. This is not just pretty poetry, right? Yeah, we get annoyed. For me, I feel like these days, a lot of the time it's just a little bit. It's just a little bit of tightening, a little bit like I do have an opinion, I do feel a little resistance. But we do have the capacity to respond without being annoyed.

And he says that we can do this amid all the noise. Amidst all the noise—there is a lot of noise, but what is the noise? I think it's kind of the same question as at the beginning: what are these dusts?

And emerging transcendent—again, not to be kind of intimidated by the language. That is no other place than—no other person than—yourself.

I read this recently from Shishin Roshi, who was one of Daido Roshi’s Dharma brothers. He says,

> Because we have not developed confidence and trust in ourselves, we continue to look for a flash of insight or sign outside of ourselves. Rather than shedding the skin of our old habit-ridden selves and entering the unknown. In this unknown realm, we cannot rely on any of our old tricks for maintaining separation, which is the actual cause of our confusion.

I just thought it was helpful in the way he says that it's because we've not developed confidence and trust. We are developing, can be, should be—in coming closer, developing confidence and trust in ourselves. Seeing it is not outside, is not anywhere else. We don't need to look, wait for something from the outside. Come close, look here, enter here, learn to trust.

So I'll end with Hongzhi one more time:

> Fully appreciate the emptiness of all dharmas, then all minds are free and all dusts evaporate in the original brilliance shining everywhere, transforming according to circumstances. Meet all beings as your ancestors; subtly illuminate all conditions, magnanimous beyond all duality, clear and desireless. The wind in the pines and the moon in the water are content in their elements without minds interacting. Wind and pines or moon and water do not impede one another.  
> Essentially, you exist inside emptiness and have the capacity to respond outwardly without being annoyed. Like spring blossoming, like a mirror reflecting forms amid all the noise, spontaneously emerge transcendent.

Thank you for listening. To find out more about ZMM's programs, retreats, and residency, please visit us online at zmm.org.
Speaker: Bear Gokan Bonebakker

Title: Not Clinging To Anything
Extracted Text:
The following Dharma discourse was given by Jeffrey Shugen Arnold at Zen Mountain Monastery. Shugen Roshi is the head of the Mountains and Rivers Order and abbot of the monastery. This talk, like all of our talks, is offered free of charge. If you would like to make a donation or find out more about our various programs, visit us online at zmm.org. Thank you for listening.

This is from the Entangling Vines Koan Collection.

Once, at the time of the Buddha, seven wise women were taking a walk through a charnel ground. The eldest pointed to a corpse and asked the others, "The corpse is here, but where is the person going?" One of the younger women replied, "What's this? What's this?" The other women all saw clearly and attained enlightenment.

This is a collection that comes from the Linji School. Not much is known about its compilation, but a lot of the koans come from the other classical collections: Miscellaneous Koans, Blue Cliff Record, and Book of Serenity. And there's just the case here; there’s no verse, no commentary, no pointer. Just: "The corpse is here. Where's the person going?"

We end each evening remembering that life and death are of supreme importance. When a student enters the zendo for the first time as a student, they say, "I come here realizing the question of life and death is a vital matter." Why does Buddhism so emphasize this?

One of the things I appreciated when I first encountered the Dharma was how it spoke of, and seemed to turn towards, things that we would rather not turn towards—how it acknowledged what we'd rather deny. There was something very refreshing, very affirming in that: fearless to face what we would like to avoid. If you're lost in the woods, the first thing that we need to do is acknowledge, "I'm lost." If we're sick with an illness, we need to acknowledge, "I'm sick," so we can take the next step.

Where's the person gone? Spring brings life to the mountain. Summer is rich and verdant. Fall gives us a dazzling display. Winter is cold and quiet. These cycles—earth cycles, cycles of creatures, cycles of life—birth and death, coming and going. It's an ancient cycle. It's eternal, it's universal, it's inescapable.

Why do we fear this? The Buddha wanted to know why. These essential realities are true for every living thing. But as human beings, why do we fear this? And fearing, what do we then put our trust in? What do we turn towards? What do we rely upon?

Well, there are different ways that Buddhism speaks of that, but if we think of it in terms of desires, there's the desire for just sensory experience, sensory pleasures. Right? The thing about pleasure is, it's pleasurable. Things that feel good, feel good, right? It seems built in, right? It seems to have a purpose. Things that are not good don't feel good. And so there's a sort of evolutionary, biological intelligence to that—you know, don't go towards the things that are not good for you; go towards the things that are. But then, we get that all mixed up. So much so that when we enter the training, in Buddhist practice, the teachings are there to actually help us understand what actually is good. What actually should I be moving towards? What is skillful? Something we don't always know.

And then there are the desires for existence—just to be. And, the Buddha teaches, there's the desire for non-existence. And I've seen that present in different ways, whether it's the desire for non-existence in this moment—because existing, being, this mind, these patterns, these attachments, I would just like to be done with them—or, at its sort of extreme, could be the desire to cease to live altogether.

A baby is born; a human being is brought into this world, human consciousness. That is a toddler, adolescent, youth, young adult, middle-aged, old person. And there's a sense that there's somebody in that person that is that person, that maintains themselves, that person all the way through. You know, when you think about yourself as a child, you might think, "Who was that stranger? They had my name. But why’d they have my name? They weren't me." We don't think like that. We think, "That was me when I was young, this is me now. When I'm older, I'll be me—older." But what about when I die? What happens to me then? Where does "me" go?

There was a practice in old times, in the Buddha's time, of practicing within a charnel ground, where people who had died would just be laid out. There are, in fact, very detailed—more detailed than you might want—meditations to meditate on a corpse as it is actually decomposing. And the Buddha is very explicit with this: different stages that the corpse goes through as it basically is disassembling. The teaching or the practice of that was both to recognize—because he said we kind of get fooled by the packaging, right? Which is kind of nice. It is nice, right? But we think that's all it is. And so it's sort of like, okay, well, take off the package, and what is it? Well, it's, you know, kind of gooey and smelly and all kinds of stuff—and to sort of disenchant us, our attachments, not just with the body, but with the body as "me," and my clinging to the body as me.

Because, you know what? It's going to get older, and that body's going to change, it's going to get sick, it's going to change even more, it's going to die. Now it really changes. And so that attachment to the body itself is primordial, ancient as we can imagine. And so these practices were to sort of address that directly. Those didn't travel so well when Buddhism left India. Asian practitioners didn't seem as enamored of that practice as in the Buddha's time.

Non-attachment to the self—this sense of self. So there's someone, if you think of it, that is listening right now to this talk, right? There's a sense that there's someone in your body who is listening, hearing, reflecting, reacting. There is someone who is sitting on your cushion. There's someone who will afterwards chant and bow, and then that someone will go downstairs and have lunch, and so on—all through our lives. And the Buddha said, yeah, it does seem like that. It sure does. It seems like that to everybody. And so we take it as a kind of inarguable, you know, something that doesn't even need to be argued—it just seems self-evident to the self.

You know, if you look up "self" in the dictionary, in a Western dictionary, it's got a very, very long passage section. There are many things that are associated with the self—many things where the self is the prefix of something more. It's at the center of things, and it's understandable, it is our actual experience. I'm looking out at you. Well, you're not me. I'm looking out at you. And there's a distinct experience that someone's doing that—I'm doing that—and that you're looking back at me. So there must be something going on on both ends.

And what the Buddha realized is that that sense of self is just that—it's just a sense of something. You're sitting and you become aware of yourself sitting. That's a sense of something arising. It's like a sensation, it's a perception. And the Buddha said that's all it is—it's a perception. It is something our mind does, it's something we experience in the mind, and we impute into that a sense of a reality, a permanence, an essence, something that exists in and of itself. It keeps showing up—how could it not? And the Buddha said, as soon as that arises, then you have everything. Everything that we see now in the human world, you have, because there's a boundary.

And that sort of essential priority of that self is not just to live and survive, but to be—to be and to establish itself in beingness. And then, having the self, being this person in this boundary, what do I do with all of you? What do I do about that? Particularly if you infringe. Particularly if you do something or say something that seems to threaten me. Right? You offer some helpful criticism, right? Something is hurt, right?

Evelyn Underhill, in the book that we recently studied on mysticism, she says, "What is it about human nature that when we experience something that is hurtful, that event comes and goes, it's gone in an instant, but the self continues to be hurt? Something is hurt and continues to be hurt long after the cause of that injury is gone." That's the self—a sense of self.

So the Buddha realized that it's empty—it doesn't exist like that. It exists in the way we experience it, as a perception that comes and goes, but it doesn't exist as anything more than that. And so that's why Buddhism, there's a lot of teachings and practices of turning towards, facing, remembering—remembering what we want to forget. Time swiftly passes by, opportunity is lost.

I remember being a child, a young person, and waking up every morning to hear my father, who was a heavy smoker, hacking, hacking, coughing, coughing, coughing—all of it out. And at one point, I remember I was a teenager. I was laying in bed listening to that morning ritual and thinking, "He thinks he's going to live forever." I hadn't encountered Buddhism before, but it just seemed like—I mean, I didn't understand addiction, I didn't understand how addictive cigarettes were. I just thought, he's making a choice. And why would he choose that unless he thought he was going to live forever?

And so there are meditations of visualizing yourself, your person, on your deathbed, dying, to just hold that in your mind. What happens now in your dying process—just to visualize that you're not there to fix anything. It's just a mental image. But we create mental images all the time that seem very real to us. We react to them, we talk to them, we act out of them. So now you're employing that—but deliberately, mindfully, and for a good purpose—to face that inevitability that we would rather not, and to try and make it real in our mind, and then to take it a step further and visualize yourself as that corpse, lifeless.

And if you've ever been with someone who is in the dying process, very close to death, unconscious, not responding, not reacting, not giving any of the signs of life other than breathing, which is becoming increasingly erratic, and then that moment when life seems to have departed, and the dramatic shift of that—even when the person is unconscious and is completely still, unmoving, unresponsive—the very palpable change when it seems as though something has left—what is that? So Buddhism understands that it's consciousness. And it's not you, it's consciousness. It is the continuity that has been going on forever and, in different lives, has been assuming different forms and continues because it has no end. But it's not the self, it's not the person.

So here, when the elder says, "The corpse is here, but where has the person gone? Where is that person? Where is that self?" And another nun says, "What's this? What's this?" And they're all enlightened. So the student of that koan has to enter into that. "What's this?" It's not intellectual, it's not conceptual, it's not an idea. "What's this?"

The Buddha said, we impute a sense of self into this body. "This is who I am. I am. I exist. I am this. This is mine." And then I extend that to my possessions, my relationships, whatever I want to belong to me. To ask, "Where has the person gone?" can already imply that there's a person. They've gone somewhere. Let's go find them, right? Are they a ghost? Are they in heaven? Or are they in Buddha heaven? Are they in Buddha hell? Buddhism has hells. They're like pretty juicy hells, really. Buddhism lacks no imagination. In the hell realm, there are multiple hells, all kinds, for all kinds of lives. You don't want to go there. Even the best one, you don't want to go there. I'm telling you.

There was a poem that Maezumi Roshi liked very much. I think it was sort of taken as his death poem. Something—I'm paraphrasing, I couldn't find it, I don't remember it completely—but something like, "After I die, you can call, but I won't answer. I won't have gone anywhere." And yet we do take care of this body, this Buddha body, because it's your vehicle, it's your vessel. Take care of it, right? It's the body you practice in, you meditate in, you love in, you work in, you do good for the world in. But what about those attachments we have to it— that attachment to self? And of course, our culture, society, you know, companies, businesses want us to be attached to the body. It's good for sales, right? So we glorify youth. We disparage aging.

But you know, the funny thing about aging—I heard somebody say, "Nobody wants to get older, but it's the club you actually want to be a member of," right? Nobody wants to be excluded from that club. But where's the person? Where did the person go?

So some people resolve that, or try and resolve it, by wanting to live forever, right? That's probably been going on for as long as—maybe forever. Wanting to live beyond. It's okay, I'm going to die, but I can keep living, right? Somewhere, somehow. Or just not wanting to let go of this life.

A very important experience I had when I was a teenager was I had an uncle who was, you know, had some good qualities, in many ways was not a very nice person. He lived kind of harshly. And he was dying. He was dying of cancer and he was dying. Everybody knew it. He was in the hospital. He was in his deathbed. He was not having it. "Don't talk to me about death. I'm not dying." He was not having it, and he would not die all the way to his death. And that was a very powerful experience for me. It's like, oh, that's a way to go. And the aftermath of that was because he didn't accept his dying, he did not do certain things to take care of people who had given him a better life, like his wife. He would not do certain things, so she suffered quite unnecessarily after he died because of his clinging. Self-clinging. That's the nature of karma. Where is the person?

Dogen says the great way of all Buddhas, thoroughly practiced, is emancipation and realization—liberation through realization. Then he says, "Emancipation means that in life you are emancipated from life, and in death, you are emancipated from death." Well, everybody lives and everybody dies. So what is he talking about? He says there is detachment from life and death and entering into life and death. This is the complete practice of the Way. There is letting go of life and death and vitalizing life and death. This is the thorough practice of the Way.

And so we can speak of emancipation as to be free of all of the various forms of our greed and our anger, our pride and jealousy—all the things that bind us, the kleshas that we act out of and cause all kinds of trouble, our false views, our confusion, our indifference.

Indifference is non-attachment—not attaching. It's not grasping, it's being free of anxiety, free of trying to control. It's not clinging to inner experience, it's not clinging to outer experience. It's not clinging to this self, it's not clinging to others' selves. Detachment doesn't mean distant, it doesn't mean cold. It's immediate. It's right here. It's just not clinging.

And he said, and so there is vitalization—that when we let go, there's vitalization. Attachment has a dampening quality. It dampens, right, because our attachments are constricting. It's like trying to stuff something alive into a box, to domesticate it, control it, to know it, to have it, right? And so it loses its vitality. It becomes dim, it becomes distant. It's our holding on that causes things. When we let go, there is no box. It becomes vibrant. It doesn't become vibrant—we just experience it in its vibrancy.

And so he said, from within life and death, we are liberated from life and death. It's the only way. We think we'll be liberated from death by never dying. I mean, think about it. If you had the choice to live forever, would you take it? Think about that. Would life be sweeter, more precious? Would you use it better? If you knew that there were an endless, infinite number of tomorrows, what the hell does today matter, right? You've got forever tomorrows.

This is a complete practice, Dogen says, which means it requires a complete person. I mean, think about when we're fearful in our lives, when we have anxiety. And I think, I will propose, that if we really pay attention carefully, we'll see that there is a very subtle, sometimes not so subtle, deep underlying anxiety of existence, because we know it doesn't last forever. We already know that, and we respond to that in a whole host of ways, many of them not so helpful.

So think: if we acknowledge the fear of death, of life, then it's hard to enjoy life, right? Because we're fearful. It's hard to experience it because it seems to get in the way. It's hard to be free because we're not. And then, of course, it's going to be hard to face death. How can we face death if we haven't really engaged and understood life? And then what if we're afraid of death? It's going to be hard to live, right? It's going to be hard to grow old. It's going to be hard to experience illness. It's going to be hard to be with others as they are getting sick and growing old and dying. It's going to be difficult to be joyful in life because there's this specter that has not been examined, not been attended to, that basically is not understood. That's what the Buddha said. We fear it because we don't understand it.

I mean, one way of thinking about death is, you know, it's a pretty august group that has preceded you. Right? Some notables there. Not the first time.

There's another koan from this collection in which a poet went to see Master Huang. And Huaitang said, you know, the passage in which Confucius says, "My friends, do you think I'm just hiding things from you? In fact, I'm hiding nothing from you." And then the Zen master said, "It's just like this in the great matter of Zen. Do you understand?" And the poet said, "I don't. I don't understand what you're talking about." 

So later, they were out walking in the mountains where the air was filled with the scent of locust blossoms. And Huaitang said, "Do you smell the fragrance of those blossoms?" And the poet says, "Yes, I do." And Huaitang said, "You see, I'm hiding nothing from you." Later, the poet came to visit again. And Huaitang said, "I'll die and you'll die, and we'll end up burnt into two heaps of ashes. At that time, where will we meet? Where will we meet?" And the poet didn't understand. And it is said that later on he was on a trek and he woke up from a nap, and as he woke up, he saw it, he realized it. Where will we meet again?

We so easily fall in. You know, Buddhism acknowledges—the Buddha recognized—the deepest, most persistent belief that we have is in me and you, in the self. He said, you know, all of the different things that we disentangle ourselves from and free ourselves from and realize as empty, and even realizing that the self is empty, directly experiencing that and experiencing that again and again, it will continue to arise.

I remember reading an old but contemporary master who said, "I have seen that the self is empty, but every time I stub my toe, ow, I hurt."

How could Huaitang hide the scent of the blossoms? They're there for everyone. Everything is like this. When the mind becomes more clear and settled, the world appears more vital, more alive, more immediate, unhidden, undulled. Here, here, here.

Dogen says, "Realization is life. Life is realization. At the time of realization, there is nothing but life, totally actualized, made actual. Nothing but death, totally actualized."

I remember when my dad was coming close to the end of his life. He had cancer and it was not a good prognosis. He knew he was going to die of it. And we met one time and he was very anxious, very frightened. He was afraid of how he was going to die. He was afraid of being in a lot of pain, and he was feeling very vulnerable. He said, "I don't know how to do this." He said, "I've never done this before." I said, "I know. And I think if you can be here now with this, and then you keep doing that—just be here, right?" Because he had been an alcoholic for much of his life, so his habit was to not be here. It was to dull himself, to turn away, to deny that. And so I said, "If you can just be here and then keep doing that, I think at the time of your death, you'll know what to do." I wasn't going to give him instruction in zazen. I didn't want to offer him a teaching of the Buddha. The Buddhist teachings have complete integrity. And you don't need to use any language, of course, to be here.

Because we have such a habitual impulse to not be here, we have to train ourselves. That's why we've been talking about mind training during the weekend. I can recognize I need to be here. I'm keep going away, I'm turning away, I'm fearful. I don't want to experience this. I need to be able to be more mindful. But I don't—I can't—because I haven't developed that. I can have moments, but they're fleeting, and then the fear takes over. So I need to develop the capacity to actually do that. That's what training and practice are.

Dogen says such activity makes life holy life. It's a complete practice. Dogen says for a complete person, it makes life holy life. Nothing is missing, nothing has been dimmed, it's not dull. And it makes death, holy death.

You know, practitioners, students that I've talked to who are approaching their death and sometimes are experiencing pain or medication, and they want to be alive into their dying. I've had students who said, "I don't want to miss this, I don't want to dull this. I want to be present. I want to be able to experience, to practice into this."

"I'm hiding nothing from you," Huaitang said. To be a complete person, to practice with your complete mind, to not divide, to not separate, to not be. The Buddha said, "When you're sitting, don't think, I am sitting, I am meditating, I am concentrating, I am letting go," right? Because that's just re-establishing, reaffirming, strengthening the sense that there is a self and that there needs to be.

Because we could think, well, how the hell is all this happening if there's not a self? How could I have done all of this in my life without a self? You just did all of that without a self. We are doing this right now. Without a self. The self is the illusion of something that isn't what we think it is. It isn't as it appears.

And so the teachings say, yes, there is something that appears—it seems like a sense of self. So let’s just agree on that. Now, what is the nature of its existence? How does it exist? Because without investigation, it seems to exist in the way we think: it's solid, it's fixed, it's permanent, it's got a soul, it's me. So then it makes sense for me to attach to it because it's me. But the Buddha said because of that, we have dukkha, we have samsara, we have human beings—intelligent human beings who have Buddha nature, who have fundamentally enlightened mind—acting like monsters, creating evil, actual evil in the world, cruelty, hatred, and not accidentally: consciously, strategically. That's the pain of the Bodhisattva, is to actually see that more and more clearly—the foolishness of how we can be. And yet we have this incredible intelligence, this fundamentally compassionate heart, this capacity to free ourselves, to be a Buddha.

Huineng said that there's fundamentally no difference between being an ordinary being—an unenlightened, deluded being—and being an enlightened being. When an ordinary being believes in a sense of self and attaches and strengthens all of those binding emotions and views that cause a lot of trouble for self and other, they start out as a Buddha—they're an enlightened being—but they look out and they see the world is just filled with ordinary human beings, right? Expendable. A lot of them are just in the way. When an ordinary being sees—frees themselves of that grasping, of those false views, of those attachments—then they look out and they just see a world of Buddhas, and too many acting unknowingly.

And so Avalokiteshvara hears the cries of the world, hears the suffering. She's that courageous. But you know, it's not even courage for her. She just hears. She doesn't wake up and think, "Okay, I'm going to be courageous today." She just wakes up and hears and sees and she responds. But as we, on the path of enlightening ourselves, have the heart of Kannon Bodhisattva but are not quite fully actualized, sometimes we have to wake up and say, "Okay, be brave, have courage, have faith. Don't give up. Everything is possible. Nothing is set, nothing is fixed, nothing is permanent." Even in the worst actors, they're suffering. They may know it, they may not. They may care, they may not. They're causing harm. Yes. That needs to change. Yes. What can I do? Yes.

And so we have to vitalize ourselves again and again and again. We have to start over again and again and again, right?

There's a—you know, the dualistic mind is like, you know, sort of—when I was a kid, teenager, I had friends. There was a big lake in Georgia we used to go to. I had a friend whose family had a boat. So, you know, sometimes we would ski, you know, sometimes we'd tie an inner tube. But why do all of that when you could just hold onto the rope and have the boat drag you through the water? Particularly after you've had a couple beers, right? So we would do that. So it would just drag us through the water, right? You know, and you're just drinking all this water. But then at a certain point—so it's hard, right, because you're being dragged through the water, and the boat's speeding up and they're all laughing—but at a certain point, you start planing and you're just skimming across the water, right, like a dolphin.

Why did I think of that? There was a connection that I have lost. Maybe it has something to do with starting out, you know, slog—having to slog our way through for a while until it gets easier. But, you know, samsara kind of stays the same, but it doesn't. You know, it's kind of like the path itself.

I remember sitting in this zendo more than once in a misery—in a misery at the bottom of a well. Dark, alone, waiting to be saved. Nobody was coming to save me. And thinking, oh, this is so hard. I don't know if I can do this. I don't know if I can do this. And then I would reflect—it happened a couple times—where I would start thinking about, you know, like, what if I just give it up? You know, go back, go back—to what exactly? Was that easier? And every time I thought that, I thought, no, that was hard. That was hard because there was no path. I was just at the bottom of a well. And that was just it—having a path. It's not the same misery. It kind of feels the same, but it's not.

And so to think of ourselves, our own practice that way, to think of the world that way. You know, Buddhism—one of the interesting things is for all of its fearless facing of life and death and suffering, of all the things we'd like to avoid, in a way is extremely—I don't know if optimistic is the right word, but really sees human beings as fundamentally on a path towards enlightenment. Every human being. Why? Because we have a fundamental aversion for what is destructive of life. And we have a basic affinity for what is life-affirming. And so through successive lifetimes, there's a sense that we are inexorably moving towards the ultimate affirmation of life, which is enlightenment—the total actualization of life and death, the complete embodiment of a liberated being—and that everyone comes along, no one is left out. I mean, it doesn't get any better than that.

And it takes time. Because it takes time. It takes time within this lifetime. And so that's something that practitioners have to essentially grapple with, right? Because we're not used to that. Like, we'll engage something that's difficult, but there's a very specific goal there. You're basically promised. It's not like that. What you're promised is you have Buddha nature, you have the capacity to do this. And the rest, in a very real sense, is up to you. But, you know, take some traveling partners with you—it makes for a very different journey.

And so Buddhism is so perfectly turning towards life, which is now—I said on Friday night, it's the only show in town, right? And it also has this long view, right? Because if we just reduce everything to this moment, then everything rides on this moment. You can't fail, you can't misstep, you can't do anything. But if there is an ongoing succession of moments, then when you fall, it's okay. Here's another moment. Stand. When you get lost, it's okay. Next moment, find your way back. When you give up on yourself, next moment, find your faith.

Dogen said, it's like riding in a boat. You raise the sails and you steer. Although you maneuver the sail and the pole, the boat gives you the ride. So take care of that boat. But it's just a boat. And without the boat, you can't ride. But you ride in the boat, and your riding makes the boat what it is. The boat isn't a thing that you got; it's something we create every day. It's like the boat of this monastery, right? This is a monastery. But where is monastery? Is it in this hall? Is it in the dining room? We create this every day. We're creating it in this moment. It's the boat, and your riding makes it what it is.

So he says, investigate such a moment. Examine that—the implications of that. What is actually going on? What is this boat? What is this ride? How am I steering it? At just such a moment, there is nothing but the world of the boat. The sky, the water, the shore, are all the boat's world. Your world, our world, which is not the same as a world that is not the boat's. There is no other world. Thus, you make life what it is, and you make birth your birth. You make life your life.

And that isn't just a matter of, you know, thinking positively. It isn't that with your mind, you're literally creating everything, and if you stop thinking, everything is going to disappear into a void. It's not that. It's that the world is what we experience it to be. And if our experiencing of a moment, of every moment, is cloudy, is bound, is fearful, is angry, that's the ride we're getting.

But to shift the direction of that boat has to be honest. It has to be genuine. You can't just say, "Okay, I'm going to be happy and not sad. I'm not going to be angry anymore." Try that, right? You will not succeed. And not because you're not trying, not because you're not a good person—because it's not sufficient.

We make life what it is. We make birth what it is. And isn’t that what’s so painful—is when we see people who are in a position to create such a good ride for themselves and others, run it into the shoals. It hurts. It should hurt, right? But to carry that hurt, to bind ourselves to that, becomes paralyzing.

And so, as practitioners, as you lose your skin, as you increase the capacity to feel, to experience, to engage in dukkha and suffering, as we are bringing forth compassion, loving-kindness, sympathetic joy, equanimity, we have to let go. We have to let go, right? Otherwise, we'll just go numb again. And so that really works together, right? So in a sense, as we move more into our lives, the stuff of practice becomes more important. Whether we're doing it through the Buddha way or another way, to not cling is an essential path. Buddhism doesn't own that. It's not proprietary. It belongs to everyone. So shall we take advantage of that and spread a little around when you get the opportunity?

Thank you for listening.

To find out more about ZMM's programs, retreats, and residency, please visit us online at zmm.org.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Title: Planting The Fields
Extracted Text:
The following Dharma discourse was given by Jeffrey Shugen Arnold at Zen Mountain Monastery. Shugen Roshi is the head of the Mountains and Rivers Order and abbot of the monastery. This talk, like all of our talks, is offered free of charge. If you would like to make a donation or find out more about our various programs, visit us online at zmm.org. Thank you for listening.

This is from the Book of Serenity, Dijiang: Planting the Fields.

The pointer: Scholars plow with the pen, orators plow with the tongue. We patch-robe mendicants lazily watch a white ox on open ground, not paying attention to the rootless auspicious grass. How to pass the days?

The main case: Dijiang asked Zhishan, "Where do you come from?" Zhishan said, "From the South." Dijiang said, "How is Buddhism in the South these days?" Zhishan said, "There's extensive discussion." Dijiang said, "How can that compare to me here, planting the fields and making rice to eat?" Zhishan said, "What can you do about the world?" Dijiang said, "What do you call the world?"

Hongzheng's poem: Source and explanation variously are all made up. Passing to ear from mouth, it comes apart. Planting fields, making rice—ordinary household matters—only those who have investigated to the full would know. Having investigated to the full, you clearly know there's nothing to seek. Zhifeng, after all, didn't care to be enfeoffed as a marquis. Forgetting his state, he returned, same as fish and birds, washing his feet in the Kung Lang, the hazy waters of autumn.

So, for those of you who have been here for the weekend, this is an example of the koan, which is an important and perhaps extraordinary aspect of Zen practice and a body of literature, of religious and spiritual literature, that has the express purpose of being practiced—of being an aspect of meditation—which is really true of virtually everything in Buddhism.

When you think of Buddhist artwork, for the most part those pieces of art are intended to be used in meditation. And so the koan—they have these classical formats: there's a pointer, there's a main case (which is the koan itself, where the student sits with as a meditation), and there's the verse. Each koan is pointing to some fundamental aspect of the student. It's a way to very directly and ultimately non-conceptually, free of the intellect, free of ideas, to have a direct encounter with one's self, with nature, the nature of things, the nature of the world.

Buddhism traces its history to Bodhidharma, the Indian monk who came to China and who is said to have presented Zen as a special transmission outside the scriptures, that doesn't rely on words and letters. It's a direct pointing to the human mind and the realization of Buddhahood or enlightenment.

And so what about all these words and letters? What about these sutras that are so abundant within Buddhism and certainly in the Zen tradition? I mean, here's a bunch right here, and I'm adding to it. So what about all of this?

How is Buddhism in the South? Dijiang asks his student Zhishan, who has come to be a student. "There's extensive discussion." And extensive discussion tends to lead to more discussion. Meanwhile, time is swiftly passing by when there's no real affinity with those teachings, or they're just words. They might be intriguing, they might be interesting, they might provide interesting conversation, but that might be it.

But for somebody within whom something is stirring, those words—the teachings that a person encounters—can ignite a fire or fan the flames of a fire that's begun to burn. They're not just words. Hopefully, ultimately, and maybe even in the immediate, the student is not primarily interested in a discussion.

Dijiang lived in the 9th and early 10th century China, was a student of Zhuangshi, and Zhishan was one of his students.

The pointer says, "Scholars plow with the pen, orators with the tongue." People use different things to do different things. Patch-robed mendicants just lazily watch a white ox on open ground. The white ox is the self. So the monastics study themselves lazily, in a relaxed way, are watching the self—studying this self on open ground. Let it be open, not constricted. There's no need to confine this ox. It comes into practice confined, right? We don't want to confine it further, but we do need to pay attention or it's going to wander off into the woods, into the weeds. It'll get lost.

So when Zhishan came to Dijiang, Dijiang asked him, "Where do you come from?" And the footnote to that says, "Can you say he doesn't already know where he comes from?" That is, Dijiang is not really asking him where did he sleep last night, or from where did he travel. Where are you coming from right now? Are you coming from yesterday? Are you coming from tomorrow? Are you coming from confusion? Do you remember the question I just asked you? Where is the you that seems to come and go right now?

Zhishan said, "From the South." He's a monastic. He's been in monasteries, training in the South of China. Dijiang said, "How is it going down there? How's Buddhism these days in the South?" And Zhishan said, "There's extensive discussion."

We could talk about Buddha Dharma all day and night and nothing would change. We all enter practice with our thinking minds, right? Having spent so much of our life with that thinking mind and our thoughts, we trust them, we might love them. We will find them hard to let go of. But if the person is ready, then something is stirring. There's already some understanding about those thoughts, this mind, about how far it can take you, where it can take you, where is it that you want to go? And that's where, when we encounter the teachings for the first time—you know, it's said that when the student is ready, the teacher appears. In a certain sense, the teacher's always there. The teacher's always ready, just waiting for the student to appear. And sometimes that begins with encountering a teaching, some words, and feeling something stir. It's like meeting some ancient part of yourself. And then in that moment, it's like an awareness—like there's already something that you know, something that's being, like a string on an instrument that's being plucked, and the string next to it resonates, vibrates in tune.

Sometimes it's as though a person hears those words for the first time, and it's like you've been waiting your whole life to hear those words. Somebody understands.

When I was young, my girlfriend was a little older than me and she had a car. I don't know how I got her to do this, but I talked her into going to different churches on Sunday. And because I was not a church-going lad, after a while, for a long while—you know, I was a teenager, so I knew pretty much everything—I thought, "Religion is bullshit, you know, that has nothing for me." But then I thought, well, you know, there are a whole lot of people who would disagree. So I thought, what's going on in there? So I'd get her to—we'd go to different churches in Atlanta. There wasn't a lot to choose from, frankly. But we'd go and I would just listen and watch and think, is there something going on here? Right? Is there something that I don't—I'm an outsider, I don't understand really what this is. But I was just listening. I was just hearing. I was trying to sense, is there something alive? 

And then when I first encountered Buddhism, it was like, "Oh, yes."

There's a story that Zhishan was traveling with two of his monastic brothers, Fayan and Wudang. And they came to Dijiang's monastery. It was snowing and cold, and they got sort of cloistered there for a while because they couldn't travel. So the first night, they were huddled around the charcoal burner trying to get warm, and they were ignoring Dijiang, which is not polite, and they were just having their own conversation.

So Dijiang sort of shimmied up and said, "I wonder if I could ask you monks something, a question." They said, "Sure, if there's something you want to ask, we'd be happy to help out." And Dijiang said, "Are the mountains, rivers, and earth identical or separate from you elders?" And Zhishan said, "Separate." And then Zhishan said, "Identical, identical." And Dijiang held up two fingers and then he walked away.

And Fayan said, "What do you think he was getting at, holding up two fingers?" And Zhishan said, "He just did that arbitrarily." And Fayan said, "I don't know. Don't be so quick to insult him." The next day, they took off to leave. And Fayan, who went on to be an important teacher in his own right, said, "You brothers go ahead. I'm going to stay behind and see if Dijiang has something to offer. If I don't find that, then I'll come and find you." They all came back. They all ended up coming back. And Zhishan went on to become a successor.

Are they separate or the same? There's extensive discussion going on down South.

So there's a question, in a sense, in Buddhist practice: what is the role of your thinking mind? Of course, you know, our thoughts, our distracted thoughts, our kind of habitual thinking, our obsessive thinking, you know, those are cloud-making, right? They really obscure the natural clarity of our mind. They make it very difficult to develop mindfulness and concentration. So we have to work with that mind, with those distractions. That's pretty clear and obvious, and I think every meditator understands that.

But at a deeper level, what is the role of the more powerful aspect of our mind, which has the ability to reason, to think, to think critically, to engage something and try and understand it? What is the role of that? Does it have a role?

And one teacher said, you might wonder how logic and reasoning can cause us to realize what is beyond concepts. How can that which is based in concepts help us to go beyond concepts? And how could such an intellectual approach take us beyond our intellect? Usually, we think of this as meditation's role, right? To let go of all of that and move beyond.

But there are schools of Buddhism and lineages and teachers who believe that the role of reasoning is important, emphasized. And I should say that there are differences of opinion around this, right? There are teachers and very important, powerful, respected lineages and teachers that feel that it has a very minimal role. But in here, this teacher is saying, because it's difficult to realize the true nature of reality and attain liberation without first developing certainty in emptiness, then reasoning is important. Reasoning is emphasized.

And I would say not just certainty—that is, having faith in something that we don't know yet, we haven't experienced. And so there are teachings that try and cultivate, through reasoning, a faith in emptiness. And I would also say what's important is, in that process, to understand what does that even mean? What does emptiness even mean? Because it's just a word in English. And if, when we hear that word, and as I think almost probably all of us did—I certainly did—I started imagining different ways: what is emptiness? It's a big black hole. It's outer space. It's a tunnel you fall into and never come out of. You know, it's like, what is emptiness? And it's none of those things.

So to actually develop a good understanding of it, having an opinion that things are empty, or a general understanding of emptiness, isn't really going to do much good. Emptiness doesn't appear to our senses, right? We can't touch it. And so we don't ordinarily think about it because it's not something we encounter in our senses.
