Since it is one of the most profound and unfamiliar topics, we need explanations and study to come to terms with it.

We already believe there are so many reasons that things exist. That's where we start. Of course things exist. And each of these reasons need to be examined so that we can develop confidence that maybe that way of seeing things ain't necessarily so.

And so in practice, particularly in our tradition and with Bodhidharma's teachings on being outside scriptures, there's a tendency to think meditating, being free of all thoughts, being free of all rational thinking, is better—right? Is better than having thoughts, than thinking, than having rational, conceptual thoughts. So we rank them. But ultimately they have to be unified, or we have to realize them as unified. If we're going to be active, integrated, living bodhisattvas on an enlightening path, we're not going to leave our thinking mind behind.

So to actually really understand it and not put it in rank. Of course, in the beginning, we're so default to the thinking mind that we do need to be sort of dedicated to freeing ourselves of that and developing this more stable mind, but not to judge it in the ways that we tend to do. Do not judge by any standards, we chanted this morning.

And so we tend to, in this way and other ways, make assumptions about what practice is, about what we should be doing, about what is right and wrong, what is good and bad. And a lot of times we're just making that stuff up based on what we already know, based on the way we've lived our lives, what we already think is true and what is not true.

Of course, we have to use standards in many aspects of our life. We have to guide ourselves in zazen. So in a sense, the standard that we guide ourselves with are the teachings: am I practicing according to the Dharma, if I want to be practicing Buddha Dharma? But we can forget or lose sight of the fact that those standards are created. They don't exist in any absolute sense. That's why Buddhism really speaks in terms of what is skillful, what is helpful, rather than what is absolute truth or absolute non-truth. Because those standards by which we judge things become part of our identity, our attachments.

So the angry mind, the greedy mind, the greedy heart uses the standards that arise out of such a mind, out of such a heart, to see the world, to experience things, to see other people, to relate. And anger and greed and pride and jealousy—the kleshas—will always create more separation and will ultimately always be used against someone, something. Those kleshas, by themselves, in and of themselves, in a sense motivated by those very strong, deeply embedded emotions, lead us to create ranks and hierarchies and elevate and degrade and exclude and include, and ultimately to create a whole—as the Buddha said—a whole mass of suffering.

I was listening to a historian recently, and she said, you know, in every society, in every culture, there's the question of who has the power. Is it the church? Is it a government? Is it a dictator? And of course, in our country, what was established a long time ago is it's supposed to be the people. That's where the power lies—it's the people.

She said that the nature of power is when somebody has it, they want more. Frederick Douglass said, "Power does not yield in and of itself." Right? We don't want to give it up. And so then the question becomes, for a Buddhist: for whose benefit is that power being wielded? To what end? What is it being used for?

You could say that in Buddhist practice, you're developing what is sometimes referred to as a spiritual power, right? And it is a kind of power. When your mind settles, there's a kind of power. You feel it. When your body comes into alignment, there's a power. You might think of it as energy. You might think of it as a loss of tension. We might sort of describe it to ourselves in different ways, but it's a kind of power that's being brought forth, that exists within us. For whose benefit is that power? To what end?

This historian was talking about Trump responding to these tariffs for which the world and the stock market and economy is, you know, tanking. And he sent out a note saying, "This is a great time to get rich, richer than ever before. Only the weak will fail." And there we have it. Kind of sums it up. Who wants the power and for what reason and for whose benefit?

And so hundreds, thousands—hundreds of thousands of people gathered yesterday, many of you. Thank you for your service on all of our behalf, to try and get things clear. There's extensive discussion. It's exhausting.

The Buddha said, one of the four forms of speech which is not right speech is idle chatter. Oh, my Lord, did he ever—could he have ever guessed how much idle chatter was possible to be endured? It is not neutral. We know that. Even when the words themselves are clearly not neutral, just the noise itself is not neutral. It has an effect to exhaust, to tire, to numb.

Zhishan says, "There's extensive discussion." Dijiang says, "Well, how can that compare to me here planting the fields and making rice to eat?" How can that compare? Is he just talking about ranks? "What I'm doing is much better than having discussion." Well, that would seem obvious, but in a koan it's never what seems obvious. Because if it's obvious, everybody would get that. And what difference has that made? None. And so we always have to look deeper.

How can that compare? There's a moment in which there is no comparison. The subject and object fall away. This moment is not standing in relationship to another. Think about when you're bored. You know, what is boredom? You're sitting and you're bored, right? Where's your mind? Where's your breath? In that moment, are you actually sitting? Because boredom can only happen when this moment stands in comparison to some other possible moment that's a whole bunch better. When there is just this moment, how could there be boredom?

How can that compare to me here planting the fields and making rice to eat? He's talking about a way of being, about a way of planting a field, planting rice.

I was reading this article about this company that's one of many who's building robots, and they were touting the humanoid form and teaching it to do, like, household things like washing dishes, sweeping a floor, those things so that you never have to do them again. Oh, my God, I've been waiting. How far can we go to degrade and minimize and belittle the ordinary things of living? Well, clearly, so that we—because we have better things to do. Like TikTok. Right? It's frightening because it's so seductive. I won't have to do that anymore. I won't have to wash any dishes. I won't have to clean my bathroom.

Has that person ever actually cleaned their dishes? Have they ever actually cleaned a bathroom? That's what you're given the opportunity to do here when you come here, is to actually clean a bathroom in a way that cannot compare. Not because it's the brightest, cleanest bathroom ever and you have won, but because there's nothing outside of that. There's no before, there's no after.

And so he says, "Well, what can you do about the world?" And he says, "What do you call the world?"

I've been reading Ed Yong's book, An Immense World, and he talks about—I'll only read a little bit of this—but he talks about the very beginning: "Imagine an elephant in a room, and in that room there's a real elephant." He says, "It's not the elephant in the room. No, it's an actual elephant. It's an elephant. There's a mouse, there's a robin, there's an owl, there's a bat, there's a rattlesnake, there's a spider, there's a mosquito, there's a bumblebee. And there's a woman. Let's call her Rebecca," he says. They're all in this room.

He says, "The elephant raises his trunk like a periscope. The rattlesnake flicks out its tongue. The mosquito cuts through the air with its antenna. All three are smelling. All of them are in the act of smelling what there is to smell in that room. The elephant sniffs. Nothing of note. The rattlesnake detects the trail of the mouse and gets ready to strike. The mosquito smells the alluring carbon dioxide on Rebecca's breath and the aroma of her skin."

And he goes on to talk about how each of these creatures, these living beings in this room, are in the same room at the same time, having very different experiences. What do you call the world?

He says Rebecca has the clearest eyesight of everybody in the room—until the lights go out. Plunged into darkness, she's in trouble, but some of the other creatures are now ready to go.

He says these seven creatures share the same physical space, but experience it in wildly and wondrously different ways. The same is true for the billions of other animal species on the planet and the countless individuals within those species. Earth teems in sights and textures, sounds and vibrations, smells and tastes, electric and magnetic fields. But every animal can only tap into a small fraction of reality's fullness or completeness. Each is enclosed within its own unique sensory bubble, perceiving but a tiny sliver of an immense world.

And that's really important, I think, as practitioners, for us to bear in mind, because the teachings also often talk about that we're going to experience reality as it is, as though there is an objective reality out there that we can experience without our senses and that we will experience that same objective reality—like the elephant and the bat and the robin and the mosquito.

Buddhism is concerned with the human world. And so we have to practice with this human form using our human senses. And in fact, realization, enlightenment—even though the thing itself of enlightenment, what is realized, is beyond concept—it's not realization until it comes into cognition. Until it comes into cognition, there's no realization. There's nothing that has been realized. And so in that sense, what is ineffable, what is beyond any sense organ, has to, in some strange way that words can't really describe, come into a sense of something kind of interesting.

Our world appears to us as the world. And historically, when other creatures have an experience—like when we test intelligence of animals, we test them according to what we think intelligence is. And if they can't do those, perform those functions, then we think, okay, this animal doesn't have any intelligence. If you set the standards of the test, you are sure to rank high, right? If you're deciding what counts, isn't that kind of like the reference field of the self? The self decides, sets the standards for what matters, what doesn't, who's in, who's out, what's smart, what's not, who's worthy, who's not.

He says there's a word for this. It's called "umwelt." It's the field in which we have sensory awareness. And I was thinking, you know, a person who lives by anger, lives by greed, who is thrilled, whose umwelt is "richer than ever, and only the weak will fail"—if they were in the same room as an enlightened being, a bodhisattva, could that person appreciate, have any sensory experience of the bodhisattva's world? They certainly have the capacity because we all have the same nature. But is their umwelt so different that they actually can't experience that, that the suffering of that other person is outside their umwelt? Their senses are not tuned or not practiced or not alive to experience.

And remember, one of the sense organs is the mind, which means thought, which means belief, views. So the mind is sensing things through our thoughts and creating logic and reason and worlds and ideologies. And so in that way, of course, a person whose life, whose mind, whose umwelt is very limited, is going to replicate that by creating a very confined and constricted and limited life and world. And all of those creatures—two-legged and more—who are not recognized as having intelligence or having the qualities that the standards within this other umwelt have established, they don't matter, they don't count. When the umwelt of a country is defined by race or gender or wealth or power, then even an elephant could deceive itself into believing that its world is the world.

So I wanted to—I've been drawing a little bit from this book by Wendell Berry that I've been reading. I finally finished it, so I can't promise this will be the last time I draw from it. But he speaks to this in a way that I found useful. He's actually talking about Albert Schweitzer, the Christian missionary, musician, physician, philosopher, and about—he was sort of talking about the material progress, technological, industrial progress, and ethical progress.

He says it became obvious that there was never a possibility that ethical progress would or could ever develop in union or in parallel with material progress. Material progress was never going to wait for ethics to catch up. I think that's just a very true and succinct way of describing—it's just right. Can't hold back progress. And progress means something very—it's a very particular umwelt, right? Ethics, you know, if you can squeeze it in. But that's not really what's important here.

And so Schweitzer came to a realization of what he called "reverence for life," which he described. He said a person is ethical only when life as such is sacred to them, and that of plants and animals, and when they devote themselves helpfully to all life that is in need of help. That is reverence for life. It's large. It includes everything, right?

So when we think about, you know, what is good for humanity, what do we need to do to take care of the human species—all of the things that are important—but as though we're alone, as though if we can just make it good for humans, then everything else will be okay.

He talks about people who have revered—this is Wendell Berry—who have revered life and those who still revere it, and that there have been people forever, since the beginning, and there are still many who revere life. I would say, venture to guess, there are a few in this room. It's hard to practice Buddha Dharma for long and not to begin to experience life in a different way and begin to touch something that we might even timidly, shyly, even reluctantly begin to think of as sacred. I was very timid about that. I was like, "I don't know about that. I don't know." That was sort of a loaded word for me. But there was a point at which it was just undeniable—there's something going on here. There's something going on here.

And he says to those for whom life begins to be understood as reverent, he says it has appeared to them to be a great miracle. That's why there's reverence. Unaccountable on the terms of available knowledge—can't explain it. He says that is because life—life itself—is not a substance. It's not a thing. That's why it's a miracle. That's why it is of reverence. He says air and light are oak and iron in comparison to life itself. And he says because of this, because it's not a thing, because it's not a substance, he says life itself has never been isolated or captured or confined. You can't buy it. It's not a piece of real estate. You can only give it value in your heart, right? There's no stock on Wall Street.

He says we can see how generous and abounding is the commonwealth of life in comparison to that merely of humans or humanity, and how fairly—we could almost say how democratically—it is portioned out among the creatures: a mouse, a horse, a butterfly, a fly, a microbe. They all have their own portion of life.

He says his life is not isolatable, is not isolatable or empirically knowable. This is just another way of saying it's not reducible. It can't be reduced. It can't be reduced to money, to a house, to a job, to a position, a role. It's not isolatable. It cannot be made into anything that it's not. It's not a thing. It's not something that we can have only for ourselves or something we can compete for or take away from others and so have more for ourselves. Our life can be made more abundant, as Jesus said, but not by any quantifiable amount. Wendell Berry is a Christian. We cannot have life for ourselves alone, but only in common with other living creatures.

We were talking earlier in the week how you—you can't have morality by yourself. Doesn't make sense. You can't have language by yourself. We can only have it together. Doesn't exist as an isolatable thing. And in that way, it's not quantifiable, right? How much morality did you have today? Right. Can you gain a little of that moral weight? It's not like that. But we know it when it's present; we see it when it's not. But that's not morality. It's what we do with our morality or our lack of it.

He says we and our kind must live, if we are to live for very long. In order to live for very long, we need to obey absolutely nature's requirements to keep all of her places healthful and whole. And to waste nothing, we need to use sparingly, carefully, kindly, and gratefully all that we must use.

Buddhism has been practicing this way for centuries: to take care of what we have, to have just enough. When we take our formal meals, oryoki, it means the right amount. And here specifically, we're talking about food, but it's in relationship to my hunger. What is the right amount? What is the necessary amount? The amount that is reverential of life? What is the amount that is obeying nature's laws? Because they don't change, right? We can't bend them.

And we can say that we have to live according to our own natural laws. We call that Dharma. But the thing is, as human beings, we don't have to. And when we don't, those laws don't bend, right? We can defy impermanence, but impermanence is a natural law. It's not debatable, right? We can try to defy death, but that's just magical thinking, right? We can think that attachment is the same as love, but it's not. These are basic truths, basic laws.

When we live, when we obey them, live in accord with them, we flourish, life flourishes, life has reverence. When we don't, we desecrate what is sacred. As we are not whole in ourselves when divided from other humans, Wendell Berry says, so we are not whole as humans when divided from all other creatures. So we are not whole as creatures when divided from the earth, from a home country, and the landmarks and the reminders of a home country, from those places of sacredness that we each have. And if we do not have them, they're there.

This is a place that is sacred for many of us. Why? Is it the architecture? Is it the building? The architecture is quite marvelous, right? If we were in a warehouse, it wouldn't be quite the same. But sacredness ultimately is not in the space—it, in a sense, draws. If there is natural beauty in the space, it draws that out, magnifies it. But what makes this space sacred, I believe, is what has been happening in this space for 45 years and in a sense, by extension, for 2,500 years.

And so then, as we—those of us who practice here—something starts to happen. There's a kind of a bonding, a binding, a kinship, something alive, a reverence that goes in both directions, a kind of nourishment. Sometimes people speak of it as coming home. These are not quantifiable things. You can feel it, but you can't possess it. Nobody's given it to you, but you are definitely part of it.

He says we are now down to one significant choice. We can take our stand either on the side of life or on the side of death. Now, of course, Buddhism sees these as non-dual, because they are. So another way of saying this is we can either live in a way that is in accord with the nature of things, or we can live in a way that is not in accord with the nature of things. This will never be presented to us as one large and final choice, but only as a succession of small choices, continuing to the 7th and 700th generation.

I think that's an extremely important point, right? Because when we see the world in a state—I mean, don't you just want the final solution, right? The ultimate fix that's just going to, like, fix it. And what Berry is saying is what we understand as practitioners: you don't get to the top of the mountain in a leap. You have to walk one simple, small, seemingly insignificant step at a time. And in the same way, to be a practitioner means we have to make choices each day—to sit, to practice, to be mindful, to care, to take responsibility, to examine. And we have to keep making those choices. But we can do that because they're just today's choices. You don't have to make one choice forever. Nobody has. Nobody can do that. It's just now, it's like every time you're sitting in a moment, your mind wanders, you make a choice, right? And then you just do that again. You do that. And the more we do that, the easier it begins to be to make that choice until it's not really a choice anymore, it's just your life. And that life has reverence.

And I think that's really important in terms of, like, yesterday's rally. That was happening all across the country. It was happening in other countries. Did it work, right? Did it work? Has everything changed? No, everything has not changed. Has something changed? Yes, because what happened today or yesterday created karma. Because you had hundreds of thousands of people with minds, with intentions, coming together, sharing something and expressing it in some sense, I would venture to say, of things moving frighteningly out of accord and trying to bring it back into accord. Let's actually obey the laws that we live within—of nature, of the earth, of Buddha nature, of a civil society.

And so as a practitioner, to ask "Did it work?" is not the right question. That's not a helpful question. It's rather, is this a good use of my time? Is this a good action? Is this an intentionally good action? What do I want to do with this? Not what is the consequence of it? Because that will stop us.

So I'll let Wendell have the last word. He says, "If we worked for the world's life in good faith, with sufficient love and knowing how our work would become good—" I have to read that again. "If we worked for the world's life in good faith, with sufficient love and knowing how our work would become good, our work itself would be good. Because we're working for the life of the world, and we're doing that within good faith—we could say good understanding, clear views—and we're doing it with sufficient love, compassion, concern. Sufficient. He doesn't say total, complete, absolute—sufficient."

And he says, "In this way, it would become beautiful, it would make us happy. And not with the future happiness of political promising, it would make us happy as soon as we began to do it."

Maybe those who are coming to practice for the first time have had a sense of something, even when it's difficult, that in those first moments, it is the beginning of something that is good, even if you don't yet know why or what or how.

Thank you for listening. To find out more about ZMM's programs, retreats, and residency, please visit us online at zmm.org.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Talk Location: Zen Center of New York City
Title: Opening To Liturgy
Extracted Text:
The following Dharma talk was given by Jody Hojin Kimmel at the Zen Center of New York City. Hojin Sensei is the Abbot of the Zen Center and head priest at Zen Mountain Monastery. This talk, like all of our talks, is offered free of charge. If you would like to make a donation or find out more about our various programs, visit us online at zmm.org/zcnyc. Thanks for listening.

This is from Bodhidharma's Bloodstream Sermon:

Buddha means awareness, the awareness of body and mind that prevents evil from arising in either. To invoke means to call to mind, to call constantly to mind the rules of discipline, and to follow them with all your might. This is what's meant by invoking. Invoking has to do with thought and not language. If you use a trap to catch a fish, once you succeed, you forget the trap. And if you use language to find meaning, once you find it, you can forget the language.

To invoke the Buddha's name, you have to understand the Dharma of invoking. If it's not present in your mind, your mouth chants an empty name. As long as you're troubled by the three poisons—which are greed, anger, and ignorance—or by thoughts of yourself, your deluded mind will keep you from seeing the Buddha, and you'll only waste your effort. Chanting and invoking are worlds apart. Chanting is done with the mouth. Invoking is done with the mind. And because invoking comes from the mind, it's called the door to awareness. Chanting is centered in the mouth and appears as sound. If you cling to appearances while searching for meaning, you won't find a thing. Thus, sages of the past cultivated introspection, not speech.

So, I've been thinking a lot about liturgy, and I wanted to give a talk on liturgy. And so I started to work on that, and I realized I can't. I can't talk about liturgy because it's experiential, for sure. And it's hard to teach this invocation of our mind, where we are in our mind. So, I'm going to do my best to speak about liturgy.

We had a precepts retreat yesterday, and the word "opening" came up. And that really struck me, this word opening—opening this door to awareness, being opened, being uncovered, unfolding. Seems like the right season to talk about opening. After all, that's sort of the force that's happening. Things are opening.

What is it to be open? What is it to be open to liturgy and be opened by liturgy? And so this is one of the eight gates that Daido set up—this gate of liturgy, which he calls, in his chapter in the Eight Gates, "Making visible the invisible." If that's not a koan for us, what is? Making visible the invisible.

Liturgy for me today—and I hope maybe you'll feel it—is really helpful in this time, in this present time, since it is perceived and subtly answered that our thought, what we do with our mind, has a lot of reverberations and a sense. Like what we chanted this morning is, we're all doing good speech together. We're creating a ritual of good speech and putting that out there, letting that reverberate.

Kaz Tanahashi did a book on Zen chanting. And he wrote, "A Zen chant is like a compass that sets us in the direction of the awakened life. It is the dynamic audible counterpart to the silent practice of zazen. And it is a powerful expression of the fact that practice happens in community."

So, Daido says in this—he has this book called The Eight Gates of Zen, for those that are new. That's our training matrix, ways that we train based on the Eightfold Path of the Buddha. And he starts off—I'll just say a little bit about his words:

"Just as in the arts of painting, poetry, music and dance, so in Zen liturgy, we manifest that which is known to us intuitively and subconsciously in the form of a visible, tangible reality. In this way, liturgy tends to make palpable the common experience of a group. There is, however, very little explanation of liturgy generally available. It is rare to see a substantive work on the subject in Buddhism or in any other major religion, because it is experiential."

It's a very direct experience. And I know in my first encounters with Zen liturgy, my brain was crackling. I mean, even to read, "it's the common experience of a group," I'm like, what does common mean now? What is experience and what's a group? I don't know. It puts everything into question. I can't take for granted that I understand any of these simple words, anything, as well as to presume anything about this mysterious, non-self espoused in Buddha Dharma.

So there's a whole different cast on words. I remember when I first came to the monastery, just like some of you this morning, right into liturgy, the morning service, and the person greeted me at the front door. They said, "Welcome." And they said, "We're going to start with morning service. There's going to be some chanting and bowing. You okay with that?" And I was like, I don't know, what does that mean? Like, what kind of bow? Like, bowing? I don't know. Sure, I can bow. Full prostrations. I was like, okay, yeah, okay. So, yeah, I'm okay with that.

And so the bell starts, and it's like the whole community just started, like, moving around like we do. Some people were sitting, and then everyone knew, like, it was time to stand up and take this place. And I don't know, it was very earthy. It was like we were all just—and everyone was barefoot. Like, that really was so exciting to me that we took our shoes off and we're just, like, raw, touching the earth. I used to make latkes with my grandmother. She used to say, "Take your shoes off. It's going to taste better." And the food tastes better. So I was remembering that. I was like, oh, okay, this is going to taste really good. We're barefoot, no hats. You know, everything just sort of in.

And I felt like, oh, there's this, like... there's like, a ritual taking place here. Like, there's incense happening and instruments, and some people had robes. I didn't. And people had positions, and they seemed to know what to do. And I was just really like, wow, this thing's just going along really nicely with precision and with care. And something spoke really powerfully to my heart and mind in those moments, which I can't articulate, but maybe you feel it, too. It just starts to, like, move in us, right? That's the liturgy happening, the ritual and how we appreciate ritual.

And this felt celebratory, and it also felt kind of sublime. And everyone was silent. Some people were looking down. And so I was kind of peeking because I didn't know what was going on, and I didn't know about lowering my eyes. That was something to really trust. And then I received a sutra book. And then there's these words, like a Heart Sutra. And I was like, a Heart Sutra? What could that be? A Heart Sutra? And then I heard, "Form is emptiness and emptiness is form." And so the chant's going along, and I'm still on that phrase and seeing, like, did anybody hear that? Like, what is that?

And then the Identity of Relative and Absolute. Like, what is that truth? What is truth? Like, this is the truth, not a lie. And I'm like, what's the truth and not a lie? And do I agree with that? And all kinds of stuff, sound syllables, just like, "No mo san..." And I was just like, okay, I'm here to do it. I'm going to do it. So I just tried to keep opening and opening.

And I remember, I'm bowing. It's not like I—I don't know if I had bowed before. It was different in the religion I was brought up in, but I didn't know where everyone went. Like, everyone dropped down to the floor. And I was really nervous about that because suddenly you can't see anything. So I was again peeking out the side. And then it's like raising the Bodhi mind. It's like the Buddha's on—you're holding the Buddha on the palm of your hands and you raise the Buddha by your ears, you're raising your Bodhi mind. That's what I found out later. And putting your hands down. So I did that too. I did everything.

And there was this feeling of like just open and just surrender, doing the best I could, trying to stay in curiosity and wonder. And you know, a lot of us come into Zen with our backgrounds in religion and Zen is said to be non-theistic. So it doesn't take up whether or not there exists a God as being relevant to seeing the nature of oneself, one's nature. But a lot of us have a lot of discomfort with bowing. And nothing's external in Zen liturgy. So it's all an expression of identity. So when we have a Buddha on the altar, we're identifying with our own wakefulness and these are just reminders of who we are. So it's identity.

But there's a lot of—many people have discomfort. And even with rituals, like, I like the sitting part, like the talk, but I don't like the liturgy. In fact, my teacher, Daido Roshi, used to sneak out when he was in training in ZCLA. He would leave when liturgy started. And so we have these people that watch the zendo and they would see him going. He had this pattern of like, liturgy started and out he went. And he said he would go to the diner and get a sandwich and then come back when the teacher was going to talk. And so Tetsugen and his Dharma brothers would get ready and Maezumi would say, "Let him go." His teacher would say, "Let him go. I see it. Let him go."

And he did this for a while and he was just watching him. And then somewhere along that line, his son became ill, had a brain tumor, three-year-old son. And Daido went in to his teacher and he said, "Well, would it be okay if the Sangha chanted for your son on the healing list?" And there was Daido, like, oh boy, you know, liturgy. And he was, at that point, he was just open. Maezumi went right for it. And from that point on, he was so moved by liturgy and what it was doing for him and the Sangha, the community, like putting all this energy towards his son that was ill, that it became very—one of the most important practices for Daido. So that's why it is a lot of what we do here.

And, you know, sometimes we have discomfort with ritual, but all throughout our day, if you look at it, your day—isn't there ritual? I mean, you get up, you put your feet on the floor, you maybe go and make something to drink, or you go to the bathroom. That's your ritual. And then you have a certain drink. And then maybe you take a shower. And then maybe you sit, maybe you will sit, maybe you dance. I don't know. And all through the day, there's order that we make in things we do. That's ritual, right? But somehow we come here and it's like there's too much ritual.

So this is where it involves staying open. Because we can't base things on what we might assume or what we've been brought up to. At least if we can be open, we can say, oh, that's coming up. Let me ask a few more questions. Be curious. Is this what I did years ago that really turned me off? And da, da, da.

And so Maezumi Roshi, I wanted to share with you—he writes a chapter in his book on "Let Us Appreciate" on ceremonial action. He says it's interesting to reflect on how many of the most basic routines of our lives are conducted in an orderly way within a particular form. When our actions are conducted in this way, they become ceremony. What is ceremony? And then he says in Latin, ceremony is "ceremonia," which is related to "cura," which means cure, the act of healing or of being healed. In other words, ceremony is an act that cures or heals or by which something is healed. In having a ceremony or in doing ceremonial action, we must ask what is healed by what?

You know, sometimes when people are ill, I say, there is one who is not ill taking care of the ill person even as we're sick. And I remember that myself as I'm laying down, tucked in the covers, drinking water, doing what I have to do. There is one who is not ill, taking care.

The word "heal" means to be healthy, to be whole and sound, to make our life healthy is ceremonial. In order to live a healthy life, we live ceremonially every day, regardless of our culture, country, or race. From morning to night, we live our lives through rituals, don't we? We get up, we wash our face, we brush our teeth. And Dogen has a lot of fascicles—Master Dogen—on these very rituals we do; we brush our teeth and eat, go about our simple routines in an orderly way. Work can be an act of ceremony. Wouldn't that be nice? Like, if you think of your work as like, I'm going to a ceremony, and you go in the office, you say hello to everyone. That's part of the ceremony. It's part of the ritual. "How you doing today?" "Oh, really? What's up?" So you can think now of your entire day as being in liturgy, in ceremony. It's nice.

The definition of ceremony also includes the word "law," the laws of life. From morning until night, our life is a continuous ritual governed by rules, regulations, and laws. Behaving informally, we follow the laws or regulations. What are the laws and regulations that are essential to living a healthy life? What do we follow? What do we abide by? It's interesting, he says, who do you think creates the casual, disorderly way of life? I do. The ego does.

Ceremony can be understood as a form of discipline by which we avoid self-centeredness, which causes us difficulties. And there's much more if you want to go to his book on Let Us Appreciate.

So Daido speaks about making visible the invisible. Give you a chance to let your brain crackle with that for a moment. And in his book he says—this is from "Celebrating Everyday Life"—what does it mean to make visible something which is invisible? He says, essentially it means to bring that something into the awareness of the six consciousnesses, which we chanted this morning: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind. And in addition, the five awarenesses: hearing, seeing, tasting, smelling, and touching. And then the five organs, that is your nose, tongue, and body.

And so he says Buddhism identifies mind itself as an organ that perceives. The organ of perception and the object it perceives, together with consciousness, produce what we call reality. So you need an organ of perception, an object of perception, and consciousness. If any of those are not there, there's no reality. So a thing becomes real—what we call real—when the organ of perception, its object, and consciousness come together. My eye, the object that it sees, and consciousness combine to form a tangible reality.

He says when you consider mind as one of the organs of perception, the concept of reality expands beyond the boundaries usually accepted in the West. He says the object of mind is thought. Mind, thought, and consciousness thus create a reality. Making visible means we are able to perceive through the organs of perception that something is there, though invisible. What is it that is invisible? What is the common experience of the Buddhist community that is restated in our liturgy?

So just before we start a talk, if you remember what we just did, the big keisaku started over here, got our attention, vibrated—bong, bong. We're all silent, hands are going to gassho, which is an expression of unifying one reality. And then we chant this gatha on opening the sutra:

"The Dharma, incomparably profound and infinitely subtle, is rarely encountered even in millions of ages. Now we see it, we hear it, we receive and we maintain it. May we completely realize the Tathagata's true meaning."

I think one of the most important words is "now." Now, this present moment. We see it, we hear it, we receive and we maintain it, making visible the invisible. The past is gone, future hasn't happened yet. Neither of those is reality. Only in this moment, right? This is it. Right now is what we have. This strange and wondrous now that just slipped—and there's now, and just went, and now and now and now and now and now and now. Because we can't grasp it. Because it doesn't have a length, it doesn't have substance. If that ain't wondrous, I don't know what is.

So this is a gatha, which is a short poem or a verse—gatha on opening the sutra. So, opening. What is opening for you? What is opening for you? Most of us want to be open. We definitely want to have openings. People come and tell me, "I want an opening," but it's happening all the time. Maybe it's allow access, not playing at the entrance.

We brought this up in the precept. Somebody said opening is to be impacted by surrendering, accepting. What exactly is being opened in this sutra? What is the sutra? So, to see the Dharma, we need to let go of our limited ways of measuring things. It's just not... We see it, we hear it, we receive and uphold its power boundlessness openly.

And Buddha woke up out of the sleep of what he thought he was, into the reality of what each of us really is now. The origin of this sutra—there's a lot of... I didn't spend a whole lot of time, but it is in the Lotus Sutra and chapter on Expedient Means, skillful means. But it's said it has origins in China. They found something very similar in about 500 to 700 CE, but the counts vary. Anyways.

Our true nature is vast open space. That's our true nature—boundless. We hear it, so we may feel some things pushing against, which might be our beliefs, our strong-held beliefs, our positions, which we can inquire about. So what might I need to open before we start? You know, we say these talks tend to be dark to the mind but radiant to the heart. So there's a little hint. These talks tend to be dark to the mind but radiant to the heart. And they require a different kind of listening. Maybe that's part of the meaning of opening and opening the sutra.

The sutra is the scriptures. It's also said to be the words of the Buddha. The Tathagata is another name for Buddha. But sutra, like there's "suture" when we get stitched up, is exactly what it is. It says, "interwoven of strings in vertical and horizontal." That's sutra—interwoven strings of vertical and horizontal. Isn't that what our human life is? Could we be the sutra? Could you be the sutra? Is that the sutra we're opening? Is this a verse on how to open ourselves to the dharma, to everything interwoven up and down because we're not fixed?

So it's a fast-moving system of momentariness being woven up and down. Constant flow, a dynamic, moving, vast network. A tapestry of threads merging into a constant flow. Looks like this. Looks like this. This kinhin is called a walking sutra. That's what we are. We're all stitched together. Walking, walking, sutra—interwoven steps like stitches.

One teacher wrote, we have to see that clearly, then taste it, to see the real picture of our life—a huge network of interwoven time and space. Even though we see the momentariness or instant that we exist day to day, it consists of a huge network of interwoven time and space. An instant has this kind of vast structure. So if we have clinging or grasping to our own prejudice, if we grasp at our desire at the expense of everything and anyone else we know, it's really... How's that going? It's difficult to open our life. It's a sticky network. And so we can feel that. We can feel it's like a spider web. You know, there's certain things that will get stuck. So we have to practice to open ourself to see the real picture of our life.

And zazen is that, of course. That's where we can practice very directly to open ourselves. Thought arises, we don't judge it. Or maybe we do. We see that we don't have to. We let it go, we open to it. And we open to coming back to our breath, surrendering, allowing access to those fast-moving networks of interwoven time and space.

Now we open our eyes, ears, nose, tongue, body, mind, and see what's true. And that truth that we see is called the Dharma. Whatever comes to us that we see to be tested and real and true is the Dharma. And Daido used to give us a warning, if you remember. He says, if any teacher tells you, "I have the truth," he said, "Run for your life. Run for your life." We need to find out what is real and true and test it in our life. That is opening the sutra.

If, as we open this sutra, the huge network of interweaving time and space, if we do that, we find it is incomparably profound and infinitely subtle, sometimes called "penetrating Dharma." So Dharma is a very full Buddhist term. I'm not going to go into Dharma, but just kind of give you these three principles that are, I think, important for now. It's the principle of existence, this Dharma—all phenomena, visible or invisible—and the teachings of the Buddha, mainly compassion that extends everywhere, is the Dharma.

And all of this is at a state—as a category, a state of always functioning at super speed, constantly supporting, helping, and nurturing all beings. If you come to see this state of being, realizing this is true is Dharma. It's said that we will be completely, constantly supported and helped and nurtured. We will feel that.

It's said, the inside needs to be like a hollow, like a reed. You know, sometimes teachers used to speak of kinhin as a hollow reed. Walking, like when we walk kinhin, walk like you're a hollow reed. So we say, you know, let go of counting. And it's the same as zazen. We're just walking. So when thoughts come up, we're not hollow anymore. We're filling ourselves up. You know, should I do this? I can't wait till we go to lunch. Da, da, da, whatever. And we let that go, and we walk like we're hollow. A hollow reed. I like that. It's helpful. Nothing to grasp.

This, too, is a meaning of dharma. Constantly supporting, upholding, helping, nurturing all beings. And the inside is hollow. Not unfeeling, just empty of grasping—that kind of hollow.

The Dharma, incomparably profound, very profound. Some translations say "penetrating," but originally it says "profound" or "profundity." Deep, unfathomable. This is one of the characteristics of the Zen arts—sublime profundity. And I think of it—I always think of it as when I have a pot with a certain glaze, or I've seen pots with certain glazes, and you look in and you can't tell where the bottom is. You just can't tell the bottom. And it has its form, but you can't see the bottom. You can't see the depth of it. I think of it like that kind of profundity. We cannot touch it, but we can be there. If we can open ourself, open our heart, we can see it and be present exactly in peace and harmony. Right there. This now—it's what's speaking of—is profound, infinitely subtle, wondrously inconceivable. We can't pin it down what it is, but it's working with us. If we can open to it—that's when we fill ourselves with all the things we fill ourselves with—but if we can open, open to it.

Katagiri Roshi continues: "Meeting it objectively, we cannot know what it is. We can't explain it. Speaking subjectively, we can experience it exactly, we can know. Yet it is with us. Difficult to say what it is objectively is called subtle. Very subtle, infinitely subtle. Our mind cannot pin down what it is. And we can experience it and know it is always with us."

So Dharma is supreme, incomparably profound, unmatchable, beyond comparison, and subtle, very subtle. Because we can experience it, we can teach it to people, we can transmit it. This is our responsibility. Each of us, whatever Dharma you realize, we let move on. Whatever goodness it brings, we have to transmit this Dharma. And it's rarely encountered, even in millions of ages. Some say kalpas.

What's a kalpa? Now we see it, hear it, receive and maintain it. We rarely meet with, even in hundreds of millions of kalpas of ages. So aren't we the lucky ones? We don't understand how rare it is. I don't. I hear that a lot, but I really—it's beginning to get to me like, wow, it is rare. I mean, 9.5 billion people on the planet, the Dharma to be encountered—it doesn't have to be through Buddhism—ages. Kalpa, that's an expression of time. That's boundless, eternal. Let's just say it's a... when somebody—when you write "long time." Very rare for us to be born as human beings. Very rare for us to have the opportunity to meet and listen to Buddhist teachings and practice zazen together.

So those of you that showed up today, I'd love to meet each one of you and say, what was it that you turn to the Dharma? This opportunity to express ourselves as we are. And then maybe we make contact, that it's important to have our spiritual life. We do make contact and to take care of it. And then that spurs us on to pay attention in zazen, which I feel is happening more and more, more and more.

Even those of you—I mean, some of us have sat before. I realized when I was a newcomer, there were a lot of newcomers. Some of us have meditated before in various ways, but it's rare, and we may not get this opportunity again for millions of ages. And now we see it, we hear it, we receive, we accept, and we open to be impacted and maintain it.

And so there's this spiral of practice. We practice it, we realize it, we actualize it, we manifest it, we practice it, we realize it, we actualize it, we manifest it, and that continues endlessly. That's an enlightened life. Buddhism does go for the long view. And when we see the real picture now, that affects the past and it affects our actions going into the future in this now. So it's all one reality. So whatever happened in the past can actually be worked with now and affect that past and how it moves forward. That's how we change things, change karma, work with our karma, our actions, what we make of ourselves through our actions.

"May we completely realize the Tathagata's true meaning." That's the last line. May we completely realize the Buddha's true meaning, really taste the truth of it, of what the Buddha was saying about our nature, our Buddha nature, being perfect and complete, lacking absolutely nothing—all beings, all things. In that way, never fail to cover the ground upon which they walk.

If practice does have a goal, it's to see the reality of each being—like that included. Putting this one on your cushion doesn't mean we don't have stuff to work on. So don't get confused about perfection. Wondrous and difficult to grasp and not different from the ceremony of our everyday life, day to day.

This is what it is to meet the Dharma, to see it, to hear it, receive and maintain it. And then when we experience that, we can't help but want to understand it more deeply. We keep wanting to deepen ourselves and the Dharma, to realize the Buddha's true meaning once we taste it. That's why Trungpa says, if you start on this path, be careful, because you won't be able to turn back, because now you know something, and it's harder to go against what you know to be true that you've seen and realized. It's hard to turn back. We can try. It's really hard.

So some people, they say, "I left practice," and then they come back, and I'm like, no, you didn't. Not at all. You know, yeah, maybe you didn't show up here, and I haven't seen you for 20 years. But here you are. You haven't left. You never did. You couldn't. Sorry. It's too late. First day you walked in—too late.

So this verse is saying something so vivid and directly about our life. Stay open and let it be this unknowable mystery that it is.

Maezumi Roshi's words: "When we carefully understand our lives, every bit of life becomes ceremonial action, an open, orderly, ordinary life. And we should take care in this way. This is liturgy. This is ceremony. Do you see?"

And in closing, I'll just share a prayer by—make sure I—by somebody named Dana Faulds. She's a practitioner, I think in—yeah, she's a practitioner. She writes—like, I like her writing because she writes about Dharma, and that can get kind of syrupy sometimes, but I think hers is okay. You'll see. I like it.

I pray to stay open today.
Open to the unrestrained energy of now.
Open to mystery and power.
Open to whatever comes.
Open to routine and surprises.
Open to moving past my first reactions.
Open to my imperfections and the divine spark that underlies them.
Open to the wonder and the everyday grace of life unfolding as it does.
Open to events and circumstances that I like and that I don't like.
Open to fatigue and the overflowing energy.
Open to listen and to speak.
Open to love in all the ways it manifests.
Open to give and to receive.
Open to the seasons, changing priorities, rearranging, nothing staying the same for very long.
Open to letting beliefs dissolve into the etherium.
Open to the direct experience of truth.
Open to forgetting and remembering.
Open to life and open to death.
Open to seeing old patterns and letting them go.
Open to fear and to courage, ease, difficulty.
I pray to stay open.

Thank you for listening.

To find out more about the Zen Center of New York City's programs, retreats, and residency, please visit our website at zmm.org/zcnyc.
Speaker: Jody Hojin Kimmel

Talk Location: Zen Center of New York City
Title: Cooking Our Supreme Meal
Extracted Text:
Good morning, everyone, and welcome to those of you who are here for the first time. Wonderful again to see such a nice fill.

This is from Dogen Zenji, who is a 12th-century Zen master who wrote "Instructions for the Cook," the monastery cook—Tenzo Kyokun, Instructions for the Cook. So we're going to cook the supreme meal today.

"Never change your attitude according to the materials. If you do, it is like varying your truth when speaking with different people. Then you are not a practitioner of the Way. When you prepare food, do not see with ordinary eyes and do not think with ordinary mind. Take up a blade of grass and construct a treasure king's land. Enter a particle of dust and turn the great Dharma wheel. Taking up a green vegetable, turn it into a 16-foot golden body of Buddha. Take a 16-foot golden body of Buddha and turn it into a green vegetable. Handle even a single leaf of green in such a way that it manifests the body of Buddha. Then this in turn allows the Buddha to manifest through the leaf. This is a power which you cannot grasp with your rational mind. It operates freely according to the situation in a most natural way. This is a miraculous transformation, a work of Buddha that benefits sentient beings."

So, cooking our life, making our supreme meal together.

Yesterday we had a video here called "Watching the Rock Grow," which I was very inspired by seeing—my teacher, my first teacher, Daido Roshi. The film was made in 1990 and it was about how the monastery was founded and how he set up a training center. What ingredients he had to put in his pot and build this incredible meal of training and practice of the Buddhadharma on this hemisphere—fairly new to Zen. Zen was fairly new to this country, and all these teachers came and were forming centers. So it was the very formative years. It was the year I arrived at the monastery, 1990.

And how he had so many flavors to deal with—bitter, sweet, sour, delicate, strongly scented, weakly scented. And he created these eight areas of training to study this self. One of Daido's teachings, which I'm sure he heard from Dogen and also felt very deeply, was this: engaging and training fully in our everyday activities with mindfulness, dedication, attention to the smallest detail is the enlightened way—it is enlightened in itself. That kind of practice. Take a green vegetable, turn it into a 16-foot golden body of Buddha.

He just loved the teachings of Master Dogen. When I came to Zen Mountain Monastery in 1990, I was there for only a week, and I was made the monastery cook for a year—which I felt very comfortable doing. I loved to cook. And, you know, I came from a clay background, so I was used to working with large amounts of material, and people were part of those ingredients.

When I had one of my first dokusans with Daido Roshi, he said, “I want you to read this fascicle by Dogen Zenji called Instructions for the Cook. It's in a book called Refining Your Life by Uchiyama Roshi.” If you saw the video, I should show it again, but he had a big gap in his teeth—he’s very toothy—and he smiled at me with his big toothy grin. And he said, “We'll get you to see how to take a lettuce leaf and handle it in such a way that it manifests the body of the Buddha.” And I'm like, brand new, wet behind the ears. I was like, “Yeah, sure, okay, right, sure, okay, whatever that means.” And I believe that he assigned it to every cook, and we still do.

One former cook said to me, “It's not reading that book that's difficult. It's actually doing it, what it says.”

So what is it showing us? I'll just pull out parts today about how we prepare this life. What are the ingredients we're finding that we have—our happiness, our depression, our grumpiness, people, things. How does that all become part of the ingredients? Those ingredients have no fixed position. They're ingredients—how can they work for us as we're making this supreme meal together and individually, our life, moment to moment, with all that's presented to us, working in this relative world as well, of this and that, of discrimination.

Uchiyama wrote, “In the world of discrimination, there are valuable things, worthless things, new things, shabby things, beautiful things, ugly things, attractive things, disgusting things. When this is the only way we see, eventually there will come a time when our life circumstances on balance seem bleak and dismal. On the other hand, if we handle the most mundane items with care and appreciation, our whole system of valuation is turned on its head.”

I really like that—our whole system of valuation is turned on its head when we just don't stay in these discriminations of “this is valuable, this isn't; this is worthy, this isn't; this is new, this is shabby; this is beautiful, this is ugly.” And we handle with care every part of our cooking.

I came across this term as I was studying called “nyoho practice,” which I didn't know about in all these years. It says nyoho practice is looking for opportunities to act in accord with the Dharma in the midst of our daily lives in very practical, physical ways. We view no act as too mundane or insignificant to perform with care. Now, we always say, before you leave the zendo, straighten your cushion, bring your cushion up to its fullest and put it back, because that has an effect. When you come back in, if you see an all-mashed cushion, like someone just got off, it feels different than when it's in its upright position, centered on the mat, the mat's nice and neat. These things have an effect.

We view no act as too mundane or insignificant to perform with care—closing a door, anything, stepping into a subway. And no object or being we encounter is beneath our respect or attention. No object or being we encounter is beneath our respect or attention.

So just to hold that for a moment as a practice—it's saying nyoho practice is something we practice. And as we do it in that way, our whole valuation would turn on its head.

So Dogen has this teaching, which we're working with this ango—all-inclusive study, encountering everywhere. So whatever we're meeting, we're doing this primarily through art practice, but our lives, cooking our lives, whatever we meet. You know, we hear that a lot—“that's our teacher.” But in a sense, yes, that's what it's saying—that everything we meet can teach us something if we have that kind of openness, as it said, that openness of mind.

So he's inviting us to be alchemists. Yeah, alchemists, shape shifters, transform our lives with all of our ingredients into awakening.

So most important, when we function as the Zen cook of our life, we leave out the attachment to ourself. That's one of the ingredients that Dogen speaks of. When we function as the cook of our life, leave that attachment of self, like anger, like the three poisons. Like, anger is considered a poison. When it's self-centered, self-motivated, it can be a poison.

If we take out our attachment in anger to the self—anger, the same emotion, the same energy—can be the fierce energy, very fierce energy of determination or care. So, you know, I think anger gets a bad rap, like “don't have anger.” It's a very powerful force. It's just a word, but used in the right way where we're not attached to ourself, it could be a very positive force. And it could also mean we care so much.

Take out the self-centered aspect of greed—that becomes a desire to help. We just don't want it for ourselves. And we drop the self-orientation from ignorance, and that becomes a state of the knowing, of unknowing, that allows us new things to arise.

So Dogen wrote this fascicle in 1236, just to give you a context. He finished it in 1237. He was 37 years old. Okay, who's 37 here? This is like his—I don't know how many he's written already since he was—he was born in 1200 and he started writing these fascicles when he was 25 or 26. Can you believe it? It's kind of like Martin Luther King and his writings—started so young. Something was coming through so powerfully.

And it said that he had a reputation for being a strict teacher, so the number of his followers and disciples was rapidly increasing. I found that interesting too—he was known as a strict teacher and things increased, like people came to him for something, some kind of guidelines, or it offered something, his strictness of holding to the Buddha Dharma. It helped people focus and see what was real and true—that's what I imagine.

And of course, just as the Buddha said, you get more people together, you need more protection, more guidelines, more ways of practicing together that everyone understands. This is what we do here. This is how we comport ourselves—regulations, they're called—so we can all practice together with as few difficulties as possible. But we're people, so things will come up within communities and we work with them.

So these are guidelines for the kitchen, and that's how they were born—because things were happening in the kitchen. And so Dogen used to say, “Dharma is food and food is Dharma.” And usually that position in the kitchen was given to a Roshi or a senior monastic. But such is the case—I just arrived and I was the cook. So we just took whoever has a way-seeking mind, which is all of us here, so you could be the cook. Okay. And sometimes you didn't know how to cook—those were... We all had to go through that with someone. Broccoli, broccoli, broccoli, broccoli, broccoli, broccoli, broccoli. Then something else might come in—it's great. It's a great position to nourish the community.

And Dogen, on the back of Uchiyama's book, he said Dogen had three secrets for enlightenment, to generate these attitudes of mind which we can all use today:

A joyful mind—Kishin.
Parental and nurturing mind—Roshin.
Magnanimous mind—Daishin.

So living with a joyful heart, cultivating this joyful mind. A caring with the deep concerns of a parent—a parental mind. And performing all activities with compassion.

I was just thinking of Yukon—he's one of my Dharma brothers who died last year in February. Those that knew him, he was quite funny and always like a trickster in a way, always joking around and getting—he had this way with people. And I used to tell him, I used to say, “Parental mind, Yukon.” When I wanted him to shape up, I'd say, “I want to see your parental mind.” He'd snap to, like, “Oh yes, parental mind. Take care of things. Don't just keep joking around. Take care.” And that was part of it. But do it in such a way that he was taking care, nurturing.

Dogen puts it like this: “The aspects of these attitudes are to see that working for the benefit of others benefits oneself. To understand that through making every effort for the prosperity of the community, one revitalizes their own character.”

So I'll just say a little bit about this joyful spirit mind. Ed Brown—Ed Epsey Brown, who also was from San Francisco Zen Center, started this restaurant, Greens, and Tassajara Cookbook—that's Ed Brown, if you have that one. That was a great cookbook. So he would teach these different mind spirits. He said, “Joyful—consider this carefully: All of the myriad circumstances which brought you to the front door of this temple today to engage zazen, you made this opportunity, you walked onto the path and to encounter this Dharma. As we just chanted, the Dharma is rarely encountered even in millions of ages. What a rare gift that you gave yourself today, that you are encountering the Dharma. It may not seem that way, but hey, all of Brooklyn isn't here today, so it is pretty rare. But you are. And we can be grateful and spirited by this movement of raising the Bodhi mind.”

Every moment we have lived, every choice we have made up until this moment—if one decision was changed, we can't say our path would be the same, could we? One decision might be different. We made all these decisions, every choice up to this point, which you may not have seen as a choice, but that's the way it lined up, brought us to here, this moment.

And one aspect of joyful mind that Daido Roshi always emphasized—or should I say roared, which we heard in the film yesterday—was, “Put your entire being into your activity. Just give it your whole body and mind. Don't hold anything back.” Like a plant, when the sun's shining, they just, like, turn towards it. You don't see a few petals, like, “No, not today.” They just go right to it, right? He says, “With that kind of turning, do what you're doing, what you're doing. Completely.”

We see that's no small thing. I mean, get up and do kinhin—to really just walk, do you see? Like, we go off in our head and we're not just walking, we're thinking about this and that and hamburger and whatever. But to just walk, we have to really be meticulous in our effort, understand why what we're doing. And most of us have had this experience of a joyful mind, direct experience, wholeheartedly engaged in activity. I'm sure of it. I'm sure of it.

And we know other things happen. We have annoyed, angry, not wanting—what is this moment mind? The world becomes narrow, necessarily completely filled as that. Like when we're annoyed, that's it, that's the whole world, right? All our thoughts. Sometimes we forget we're actually aware of that, sometimes we're not. But if we're aware of it, we're aware we're annoyed, we're aware we're angry. That's good. That's good. It's all-inclusive. It's not going to a particular state because all of those aspects of our enlightened nature—annoyance, anger—so there's wisdom there. There's wisdom in all those experiences, or what we call, you know, anger, depression—there's wisdom there. And that, if we can see that, if we can care about that attitude, is what Dogen's saying. Just care about the attitude we're in, meet it with awareness. Then we have the possibility to see what's happening in that state and relax a bit and meet this more directly with our senses—not with our stories, just senses.

And right there, we can find a bit of joyful mind in that awareness. Do you know that? I'm sure maybe you know that. And especially when we could say it to someone who we're with and we're really annoyed or angry, and we could say, “Like right now, I'm really annoyed and angry,” it kind of takes the lid off the pot. We're not going to blow.

Dogen says, “If this is not yet clear to you, it is because your thoughts run around like a wild horse and your feelings jump about like a monkey in the forest.” You might have heard zazen in the beginning called us working with our monkey mind. It's like a monkey that's swinging in the jungle, and we grab a thought and we swing, and we grab another thought and we swing and we swing and we swing—and the less we interrupt, we just keep swinging from, Daido used to say, from cradle to death, we keep swinging on vines.

So when the monkey and the horse step back and reflect upon themselves, freedom from all discrimination is realized naturally. This is the way to turn things while being turned by things.

There was a film made about Ed Brown, I don't know if any of you have seen it, called "How to Cook Your Life," a documentary by Doris Dörrie, who did "Cherry Blossoms" and a bunch of other—"Enlightenment Guaranteed," yeah, Doris Dörrie. So she did this very raw footage of Ed Brown talking about being a cook. And it's very raw, and Ed's there talking to his students, and he's telling his students that he is a human being. And he says he's like all human beings: “I get irritable, I get fed up and I get frustrated.” And this is not sweetened in the film—she's just, you know, he's saying it to his students.

At one point in the film, he becomes really annoyed with his students because they don't know how much salt is required in a bread recipe, and he just goes ballistic. And he did a retreat at the monastery when I was the cook in 1990, and I witnessed him do that. And yet I felt something different—like, it could be taken to feel like that's really excessive what he's doing right now, and his fed-upness. But I really thought he was demonstrating clearly, knowingly, an important part about how our lives are discovered in details.

Because he knew what he was experiencing. And he just brought it out, this awareness of fed-upness and anger. And he just folded it in. He folded it into the tomato sauce, you know. I used to say to Daido, “I don't think I can cook today—like, I'm having a moment of, like, I'm upset, I'm, you know, disappointed. And I said, I don't think I should cook because people are going to, like, eat and they're going to feel, like, disappointed, and they're going to get my upset.” He said, “No,” he said, “alchemize it, transform it. Like, when you're actually cooking, is that what you feel?” And I said, “No, I'm so excited, like, it feels great. I'm in there cutting the carrot.” He says, “Exactly. Just take all of those ingredients, put it in the pot and it'll change. But when you try and keep something out, that's not going to work.” It's a good teaching.

Dogen points out, we only have the moment-to-moment details to sincerely care for. That's it. All in the details. We've heard that our life is details and that's what we sincerely care for—all of that, all of it, moment to moment.

He says, “Prepare the meals of your life day and night in this way, without wasting time. If there is sincerity in your cooking and associated activities, whatever you do will be an act of nourishing the sacred body.” If there is sincerity in our actions, in our cooking and with our activities, whatever we do will be an act of nourishing the sacred body of all beings, of everything. But then, you know, those poisons—it becomes very self-centered, and what are we seeing? Not everybody's getting this wonderful meal that we have the potential for.

He says this is also the way of ease and joy for the Great Assembly. Uchiyama says it's called life that is lived fully and completely—nothing held back—the supreme meal.

And there's another story of Dogen, you may have heard, where he meets the cook on the boat going to China. So Dogen was going to China to see if he could find authentic Zen training because he wasn't feeling it in Japan. And, by the way, there was a potter on that ship, I learned. So when I was in clay, and the Chinese had developed glazes before the Japanese had developed—they were using mostly raw firing—and on the ship was a potter named Shigematsu, who, in this book I was reading on pottery, spoke about this guy named Dogen he met who was going for Zen teachings, and there was a cook there, and they were all having this conversation. So when I got to the monastery and Daido said, “Master Dogen,” I just went like, “The guy on the boat!” But I didn't follow him then. I went for the other guy. I wanted the secret glazes from China.

But Dogen was so impressed with this cook on the boat that he visited him at his monastery. And when he got there, he was drying mushrooms out in the courtyard, and it said the stones on the courtyard were so hot that they burned one's feet. Ever go out, like, when the patio is so hot, it's just like burning your feet? So that's how hot it was. And this old man, who was 70—I don't like to say that now, like, “really old, 70,” nae nae—but he had a cane, an arched back.

Dogen asked him, “Why don't you have an attendant dry the mushrooms for you?” And the Tenzo answered, “Others are not me.” Dogen asked, “The sun is hot. Why do it now?” And the Tenzo answered, “What time should I wait for? I have taken this position in my old age. This is the fulfillment of many years of practice. How can I delegate the responsibility to others?”

Dogen writes, “I again asked the Tenzo, ‘Honorable Tenzo, why don't you concentrate on zazen practice and on the study of the ancient master's words, rather than troubling yourself by holding the position of Tenzo and just working? Is there anything good about it?’” And the Tenzo did what you just did—laughed aloud and replied, “Good man from a foreign country, you do not understand practice or know the meaning of the words of ancient masters.” Hearing him respond in this way, I suddenly felt ashamed and surprised. So I asked him, “What are words? What is practice?” And the Tenzo said, “If you penetrate this question, how can you fail to become a person of understanding?”

Very Zenny, huh? You ask a question, and you get a question right back—the boomerang. Any good teacher will throw you a boomerang as a student. You throw it out, and it just goes right back. So that's a good way to test a teacher—if the boomerang comes back, “What?”

So Dogen withdrew with a deep appreciation of the Tenzo's practice and the manifestation of Buddha Dharma. “What should I wait for?”

So part of training is knowing what it's time for. As you see, we have a Zen clock, right? We start—boom, boom, boom, boom—9:25 Dencho starts. We say, “Arrive at 9:15. Give yourself some time to settle in.” Jikido lights the candle at a certain time. It's always our practice, no one else's. So we're always learning what it's time for. When do we take the soup off the stove so it doesn't burn? There's a time for things. We have to pay attention to what it's time for, as in our care.

When is it time to speak to someone in an important way? I always look at that with my teacher. I see—when do I talk to Shugen about this? Not now. But I could feel when there's a receptivity happening, and it's the time for it. Otherwise, I might get burned in a certain way. I don't mean in a bad way—he doesn't do that—but it's not the right time. I do it to myself, actually.

So, you know, Daido lived in the parsonage, which was where the Jizo House is—there's another building there now—but he lived right on campus, so he saw everything. It was a little house, tiny little structure, but his living room was all windows around, so he could see from his living room right into our zendo, the monastery zendo. And so one day we had this phone that he would call, and we called it the Bat Phone because he could call us directly. And when we heard that ring, we knew it was Daido calling—we should answer the Bat Phone.

So it was in the morning, I was attendant up front, and the Bat Phone rang. And so I run down, I get it. He said, “The jikido's late.” I said, “What?” He said, “I could see from my living room, they lit the candle late. It's your responsibility to know what it's time for and tell them.” I was like, “Whoa, wow. Why the demand? Who was that for? Who was that for? And then how did I transmit that to the person?” And I looked at my watch and I was like, “Damn, he's right.” And I knew it was a little over, but I was, you know, okay, you know, but it was a little over. And it was repetitive, too. It wasn't the first time. And this time he saw it.

So what is it time for in the kitchen? Of course, you know, Daido and Dogen taught all of life is zazen. So zazen needs to come off our cushion into our life. And zazen is paying attention, right? Staying present. And of course, in the kitchen, knives are sharp, potatoes and mushrooms are very slippery to cut when they get wet, vegetables rot, things can burn—all these details and caring and a timing, and there's joy to be in accord with the Dharma in time, in the midst of our daily lives.

And often, when people go to a retreat at the monastery, the kitchen is one of the places they'll end up, you know, because we get a simple task for caretaking—caretaking, that's the name of it—cutting a vegetable, simple, deceivingly simple. Sometimes just doing these physical tasks, and we get this chance to practice wholeheartedly just on this one thing.

Once I gave someone—I needed all these onions, and I gave them a whole bunch of onions to cut, big bowlful, in fact. And I just watched them, I was so inspired. They did it all, they were bawling and wet and just, you know, and they did it like there was nothing else to worry about, like that was their entire—they totally did it. I was so inspired. And it was like onions, you know, and I could see their joy in doing it, like they weren't bothered by what an onion does. It was remarkable. They were just naturally engaging.

And then this parental mind—this mind of treating all things as being sacred, with respect, affectionate, caring for what we're handling. How deep is a love like that? It's parental mind. Taking up a green vegetable and turning it into a 16-foot golden body. Taking a 16-foot golden body and turning it into a green vegetable. With a nurturing mind, a parental mind, we can make all things, all activities alive and vibrant.

So to really strive to treat things like that in all our affairs, particularly with people, with each other—that parental mind, with good care and deep respect, no matter what the ingredients are before you. Not so easy.

I always love this part. It says, “Take special care lest a mouse accidentally falls into the pot. Under no circumstances allow anyone who happens to be drifting through the kitchen to poke their fingers around or look into the pot.” We know that happens a lot, especially at the monastery—we're always hungry. So we'd always used to—and we had the kitchen, it was a big passageway, and so people would submit, “Ooh, cookies!” And you know, you're the cook and you're like, “All right, take one,” you know, but you got 50 people walking through—there goes your cookies. So it's a good rule, a good regulation.

I don't think Dogen was talking about some cosmic magical power. He's saying, with respect to anything, act in a way where we're seeing with loving eyes, handling things as sacred, and something happens—we feel it. It's not rational. We feel it.

There was a woman that came to a Zen training weekend, and then she sent a little video of her husband vacuuming. She sent him for a gift, and when he went home, he was vacuuming, and he never did it before. So she took this video and she said, “I don't know what you people did, but I love it.” And suddenly, like, just in, like, he started to see, like, with loving eyes, I suppose, and care, like he cared if the place was clean. But she never saw him vacuum. So she goes, “I don't know what you did, but that was him,” right? He just turned it on himself, turned it.

So where do we draw the line of any activity being less than sacred? Like when you're parking your car, do you line it up straight? And do you notice, like, if I leave room, then this guy can get out or someone else can park there? That awareness, that parental mind. Putting your shoes on the shoe rack straight, not, like, on the floor, like all different directions—he says, “Sounds pretty simple.” To let it register. And Uchiyama says, “And see how it feels, handling everything with equal care.” This also includes being prudent and aware what is needed.

Dogen says, “See the pot as your own head and the water as your lifeblood.”

And then this magnanimous mind, he says—big mind, it's sometimes called—he offers this advice to the Tenzo: “Like a mountain, stable and impartial, exemplifying the ocean. It is tolerant and views everything from the broadest perspective. Although drawn by the voices of spring, do not allow your heart to fall. With this attitude, we engage in activities fair-minded, impartial, not swayed by our judgments, good or bad. Your attitude towards things should not be contingent upon their quality.
