A person who is influenced by the quality of the thing, or who changes their speech or manner according to the appearance or position of the people they meet, is not a person working in the Way.”

So what is this impartiality, this non-discriminating mind? Dogen goes on to say, “Nurturing mind makes things sacred and worthy of respect. Magnanimous mind makes all things equally sacred and valuable. Where the mind is stable and imperturbable. While the mind may whip the waves of the ocean surface, magnanimous mind lets us remain a full, vast body down to the depths.”

And just because magnanimous mind makes things equal, equally sacred and valuable, doesn't mean we ignore the differences—the differences between people, between things. The mind is broad and impartial enough to include and encompass differences rather than pretending they're not there.

That's important. Yes, we have to discriminate stones from lentils—I don't want to eat stones; we've got to know what a stone is, and it's not a lentil. But are we taking stones from lentils or are we taking lentils from stones?

Dogen expresses this when he describes cleaning up the kitchen: “Put those things that naturally go in a high place onto a high place, and those that would be most stable on a low place onto a low place. Clean the chopsticks, ladles and all the other utensils. Handle them with equal care and awareness, putting everything back where it naturally belongs. Keep your mind on your work and do not throw things around carelessly.” But that's so fun sometimes. Don't get too rigid. I mean, you gotta, like, fling things around sometimes—I do. With a little music too, you know. Anyway, I think you get the point. It's not about rigidity, but it's just the respect and the care. And some things want to be flung sometimes. Can we kindly, lovingly make differences part of our life practice?

He says, “Do not arouse disdainful mind when you prepare a broth of wild grasses. Do not arouse joyful mind when you prepare a fine cream soup.” I was just thinking of you. I'll tell you why. “When there is no discrimination, how can there be distaste? Thus, do not be careless when you work with poor materials and sustain your efforts when you have excellent materials. Never change your attitude according to the materials. If you do, it's like you're varying your truth when speaking to different people.”

Our habit tendency is not to use ingredients we might think might ruin the meal. Sometimes those are the best. The thing we think might ruin it might be the best. We want to throw them away, maybe hide them in the back of the refrigerator, on the back shelf, out of sight, behind everything else. But Dogen instructs us, take the ingredients we think are going to ruin our meal and figure out how to use them that they improve it.

So just look at the world situation too—what we think is going to be ruined and is being ruined—and figure out how to use it so it can improve. Apply it to any situation.

I know some of you know I was making a bean soup and Yukon was with me in the kitchen. We were like Mutt and Jeff, you know. But I found—and we were cleaning out the refrigerator, and you know, you build a soup as you're cleaning, and you got a little piece of this and you cut it up—and we came across a half of banana. And I'm talking about a pot of soup. So I said, “Peel it and put it in the soup.” He says, “I'm not putting that in the soup.” I said, “It's a bean soup. Bananas go with beans. Like, put it in the soup.” We got in such a fight over, like, a little piece of banana that even when he was sick and dying, he made a joke and he says, “I can't believe you put that banana in his soup”—till his last breath.

So how about it in regards to a person—times we might seem that we can't find a way to use somebody's particular qualities which may seem toxic and harmful to what we're trying to do. We may make a clear decision not to use their particular ingredients in the meal—we can make that decision, and we don't ignore or deny the ingredient. But we can still make a choice without denying it, acknowledge it, remain aware of it. We may even appreciate it in another context, but we decide at that moment we won't be using it. And then to refrain from saying that about someone's life—“I don't want to be like that, I'll leave it out on the table.” It's still going to be there whether we like it or not, so why deny the flavor?

So cultivating bigness that doesn't judge, like we sit a period of zazen and we might say, “Oh, that was really a good period of zazen.” Then we have another one—“Oh, I couldn't even get to two in that period. It was terrible, useless. I sat this morning, I just saw my mind was busy, busy.” You saw that? Do you see? That's awareness. That's precious. Don't judge the ingredient, just see it for what it is.

Dogen ends his instructions with these words: “If anything should be revered, it is enlightenment. If any time should be honored, it is the time of enlightenment. When you long for enlightenment and follow the way, even taking sand and offering to the Buddha is beneficial. Drawing a figure of Buddha and paying homage also has an effect. How much more so if you act in harmony with the minds and actions of your ancient predecessors, how can you fail to bring forth their virtue and practice? After all, enlightenment's job is compassionate activity. Zazen is compassionate activity.”

How is it then, when we act, when no act is viewed as too mundane or insignificant to meet someone or perform with care, that no object or being we encounter is beneath us in terms of being worth our respect and attention? Because everything matters. Everything's connected.

So let's keep cooking our supreme meal together. Thank you for being here, for listening.

Thank you for listening. To find out more about the Zen Center of New York City's programs, retreats and residency, please visit our website at zmm.org and zcnyc.
Speaker: Jody Hojin Kimmel

Talk Location: Zen Center of New York City
Title: The Creative Life Force
Extracted Text:
Behind people, you can pull yourself into the middle more if you would like to. Just get up and slide your zabuton. Yes, I'm talking to you. Yeah. So we can see each other. Yeah, it's fine. You can use that whole area there.

Good morning and thanks for springing forward. We're still doing that, yeah. So today I wanted to... We're in Ango, which is a 90-day training intensive. For those of you that are new, it goes back to the time of the Buddha. It's a time where we really increase our contact with the Dharma. And we're studying the Eight Gates of Zen, which is a training matrix based on the Eightfold Path of the Buddha that my first teacher, Daido Roshi, set up as a way of training students in the Buddhadharma. When he created that, it was fairly new to this country. There weren't many resources—there was no internet, not many books. So he put together this way that we could train. If you're reading it, you might see some things are outdated or different now, so it's just interesting to look at.

One of the gates of training is art practice, and the residents are reading for... We chose for our academic study that we do once a week here to read together "The Zen of Creativity," written by Daido Roshi. So I don't know, this talk is something about the creative spirit—that we are creative beings, that we're constantly creating. It's not just making things like paintings or sculptures, though that's a part of creation and a valuable part and brings immense joy and goodness to us. But what are we creating? What do we stop creating?

We're a part of a vast web of interconnectedness, and we keep hearing this in the training from the Avatamsaka Sutra, the diamond net of Indra—that we're all intimately connected. That's how vast we are. And this web isn't all tangled up. Some people think of like a fishing net, all wound up. No, it's a vast, functioning, pulsating creativity. And so, yeah, we are always creating, always communicating. Part of what practice is about is becoming conscious and aware of what we are doing and what is our intention. What's that emerging from? As a practitioner of peace, as a bodhisattva, we want to practice good, create good.

And we do. See, in one moment—from the moment you woke up till breakfast—we can be in any realm, we can create any realm. We can be in hell in a moment, we can be in heaven, we can be an animal, we can be a hungry spirit. So we're training to bring the whole being into awareness, to recognize our creations.

He starts off: Creativity is our birthright. It's an integral part of being human, as basic as walking, talking and thinking. Throughout our evolution as a species, it has sparked innovations in science, beauty in the arts, and revelation in religion. Every human life contains its seeds and is constantly manifesting it. Whether we're building a sandcastle, preparing Sunday dinner, painting a canvas, walking through the woods, programming a computer, interacting in the subway—the creative process, like a spiritual journey, is intuitive, nonlinear and experiential. It points us towards our essential nature, which is a reflection of the boundless creativity of the universe.

Zen Buddhism, and particularly the Zen arts, are a rich source of teachings to help us understand and help us cultivate our creativity. And as we know, Buddhism traces its history back to Shakyamuni Buddha, who lived over 2,500 years ago in India. The Buddha spoke upon his own enlightenment and saw that each and every being, as well as the great earth itself, is perfect and complete, lacking nothing. He pointed out that our idea of a separate, limited self is a painful delusion. That's that interconnectedness, right? So everything we think, do with our mind, with our body, with our actions—body, speech—has an effect. Sometimes we don't think about that with our thoughts—"No, no, they're in me. That doesn't go anywhere." Hmm. Wonder.

He says the self is empty of any intrinsic characteristics. So what kind of expression comes out of that realization? All the Buddhist teachings are skillful means to help people discover these truths for themselves.

Then in the 6th century, there was a monk named Bodhidharma. Some of you might see him—he's often depicted kind of growly and grumpy in these paintings of him. He doesn't have eyelashes because it's said to stay awake, he pulled them out and then threw them to the ground and they became the first tea plants. I don't know how true that is—that's in the legend—but he is considered to be the first ancestor in the Chinese lineage of Zen. He came from India to China. So this is 6th century CE. He defined Zen by four points. He said: Zen is a special transmission outside the scriptures. So it's not anything we read or find in books. It doesn't rely on words and letters. It's a direct pointing to the human mind and the realization of enlightenment.

So the Zen arts are a form of that direct pointing. What is this direct experience, direct pointing? D. T. Suzuki said, "Experiencing reality directly without relying on concepts, beliefs or external interpretations. A state of immediate, unmediated awareness." Direct. Smells good. That's even extra, right? It's cold. That's extra. Just very direct.

We've all had these unexpected, unsuspected moments of just simple presence where our heart and mind just relax for a moment. There's a gap in our continuous thinking about things and doing things to things, but there's a gap where we relax and there's a simple presence with things. And there's a direct experience that happens a lot in nature—before we say, "Oh, how beautiful," but when we just encounter it, it's like right before anything, before the mind moves—maybe for a moment—and we just dissolve for a moment with a boundless heart and mind. Could even happen with a person, where that seemingly separate, solid, static sense of self turns into kind of a healthy emptiness for a moment. Just a healthy emptiness not filled within ourself.

In this regard, I was thinking about one of the first practice instructions on Zazen I heard from Daido Roshi, where he said, stop attaching—I mean, stop creating as a creative. He said, "Stop creating by attaching." It was interesting because this week, Kien, one of the monastics, sent—Daido had this rant that he did during an introduction to Zen training about zazen. It's 23 seconds, and Kien found it and sent it to me. So I'm going to read you Daido's little rant that he did—and some of you might be going, "Uh-huh, I remember that, it's the same thing every time."

"The first and most fundamental of the eight gates of training is zazen. And some of you just received instructions in this. Don't confuse zazen with meditation. Don't confuse it with mindfulness or mindlessness or focusing the mind or quieting the mind, or concentration. Zazen is not meditation. Zazen is a way of using your mind, a way of living your life, and it's a way of doing those things with other people. And at the same time, there is no rulebook to go by. You have to go deep into yourself to find the foundations of it."

Zazen brings us home constantly to the moment—to stop creating and directly experience. But that's the first step of what zazen is about. It does not take place on the cushion. Ultimately, it must manifest in everything that we do. It is our very life itself. And step by step, as our practice deepens and we travel through the stages of training, that zazen evolves into a whole way of living your life and using your mind.

So in Zazen, the goal isn't to stop the thoughts that arise or create a blank mind, but rather to observe—see without judgment or attachment—returning to the present moment with the breath as an anchor and using counting, sometimes breaths, to lead the way so we know where to return and we can just see what's happening. We're not forcing the mind to be empty or still. Thoughts and sensations naturally arise. The focus is on observing thoughts and emotions as they arise and pass, without getting caught up in them or judging. That's the stop creating. Once we attach and keep going with it, we're creating more and more, more.

In the tradition, it's called *papañca*. I love that one—just rolls off your tongue. It means proliferation. We proliferate, we make it go and go, and we create more and more, when it just simply has arisen and we see that and we let it be. Later we can take something up.

And then we embody the body. This mountain posture—so integral to calming the body, to quieting the mind. Because sometimes the body doesn't say anything about us. It's not judgmental. Did you ever hear your body, like, it may do things, but it doesn't talk and say things about us. It's just our body, right? So together, when they start coming together, that can be a big support. Because we realize our mind is going all over, creating all over, but our body is stable. It's okay, it's here, it's in its mountain posture.

So in Zazen, we stop imposing ourself on the world. And this happens with the attachment to our habitual thinking—just going over things again and again, creating again. Stop creating. So I've come to feel this "stop creating," Daido Roshi speaks of, is to leave the mind in its natural state. That's what it does. Brain, if you call it, just in its natural state, don't do anything. When thoughts and sensations arise, just let them arise. And then we just reconnect with our breath. I know that's something there, right? But just find your breath again. Just let it dissolve. And when they fall away, just let it fall away. Try not to manipulate.

At times, we kind of fall through. We fall through these appearances that keep coming. We just fall through it. We fall through ourselves, the usual habitual selves. There's a gap we fall through. We just see it for what it is, how we keep creating.

Buddha invited us to come see beyond this notion of a self. So in the gate of art practice—yeah, we're, this Ango—see, I got all kinds of notes here—yeah, we're working with... Since all things are impermanent, in a constant state of change, as it is, appears as something constantly new and different, moment to moment. So because there's nothing fixed, or there's this great basis of underlying emptiness, things can arise as anything whatsoever. And they have a duration, an amount of time that they'll stay—like this has been around for a while, but it's going. But it seems like it's not—this stand, this floor, this building—everything is changing. And so that can be for a long duration or a very short duration. Sometimes we see impermanence very quickly. Just watch a cloud. It'll just show us impermanence very quickly.

So in our art practice, we're choosing something where we can see its changing nature clearly—like an apple or a leaf or a flower petal or a flower—and that's our teacher. For 90 days, you just stay with that one thing and you make a connection with it and you just express in some medium—painting, drawing, movement, singing—however you want to. And of course, you run into the same things you run into in Zazen. With this one thing, you see everything—you see the whole reality in this one thing, all-inclusive study.

There's an Evelyn Underhill, who's a Christian mystic, speaks of the mystic's way of perceiving. And she says:

"Look for a little time, in a special and undivided manner, at some simple, concrete and external thing. This object of our contemplation may be almost anything we please—a tree, a plant, an apple, a distant hillside, a growing plant, running water, little living things. Look then at this thing you have chosen and willfully yet tranquilly refuse the messages which countless other aspects of the world are sending. And so concentrate your whole attention to this one act of loving sight. And that's the only thing that's sort of in your conscious field. Do not think, but as it were, pour out your personality towards it. Let your soul be in your eyes. Almost at once, this new method of perception will reveal unsuspected qualities in the external world."

So if you can follow that, you're with your apple, but you don't know its name. So you're just there, with this intimate, with this living thing right before we put things on it, and you just let it teach you. And from the outside, everyone's going to... When she says "ignore the messages which countless other aspects of the world are sending," think about that in our life, all the messages that we're sent, that we think we should be, how we should be. An apple's red, sky is blue—no, Giacometti says it's lavender. Don't think, as it were, but just pour out towards it and see what happens.

I love this. Daido gave us—many of you know this assignment—many years ago, and I worked with a potato for 90 days. Did you ever live close to a potato? One potato for 90 days—you can't... So you have to be surprised what's going to happen. You just have to meet it, keep meeting it, just like the person you live with. You know, we can just get into this habituation, but we forget this is a living... this is a living creation we're in, and we're putting this right now together. And that's how it is with our partners, with anyone we meet. We're always putting it together, we're creating it. So how do we get that freshness, that meeting, that thing anew?

As our teacher, she says, an intensified... I don't want to say what she says here because I don't like that she's telling me what I'm supposed to feel, but anyway—it seems as though the barrier between its life and your own, between subject and object, has melted away. You are merged with it in an act of true communion. And you know the secret of its being deeply and unforgettably. Who are we talking about? We're merged. So whose life, secret life, are we learning about, deeply and unforgettably? Don't go further than the tip of your nose. Yeah.

Elizabeth Bishop said, "What one seems to want in art, in experiencing it, is the same thing that is necessary for its creation: a self-forgetful, perfectly useless concentration."

So this interconnectedness, this mutual arising, interdependence... I remembered one time Robert Thurman spoke about this, and the Buddha speaking about this in a very unusual way. And I found it. And it kind of goes along with one of our student's writings, Kay Larson. And so she writes:

"The great chain of interdependence and mutual arising, posited by the Buddha and elaborated in the mystical visions of the Avatamsaka Sutra, which characterize the seamlessness and wholeness of life and art perfectly joined—the art of living perfectly joined, never separate for a millisecond, hierarchies dismantled, their power dispersed, never separate, effortlessly healed action that extends throughout time and space, like the Buddha, as an expression of the mind's inherent freedom," she writes, "the mind ground as the seedbed of creativity, the tree that speaks of truths without endless unboundedness, glimpsed in its absolute aspect."

So the setting for the Avatamsaka Sutra is mind's dawn, and the Buddha's just awakened, as I said before, from his dark night of meditation—a night made dark by his clinging to his fixed views that he held about himself and the limits of his mind. That's why it's dark. And now, through the power of his meditation, he penetrated the veils of the self one by one by one, until he has passed through the seeming solidity of Siddhartha Gautama. As he lets go of the subjective and contingent aspects of his own being, he enters the realm of boundlessness beyond words—a mystic realization of harmonic unity and identity, just like we chanted this morning. And he looks up in the clear light of his Buddha nature, and he sees the morning star. Boom.

Here is Robert Thurman, how he rephrases the Buddha's post-enlightenment dilemma after he realizes himself. Now, you have to understand, Robert Thurman has a lot of sense of humor as he's teaching Buddhism, so I really appreciate this.

Say you are the Buddha and you're free of suffering and you're totally great, as happy as a clam, as happy as a bee, and at one with the universe. And then you see all these miserable people, yet what would you do? What would it do for you to go give them a big grin and a big hug or smother them with joyfulness? They'll just get freaked out and paranoid and say, "What does this person want?" So instead, a Buddha has to develop some strategies, some art, to first of all open the person's imagination to the fact that there is a world where they don't have to be miserable all the time. And then he has to help them with a method of how to move from their paranoid corner of misery into the great ocean of bliss of the universe that you, as a Buddha, perceive.

So the Buddha becomes the world's first performance artist, and he takes on roles intuitively chosen to convey an experience that is more than the sum of words that anyone could say about it. He's got to do something different. He can act freely because he set himself aside. He has pierced through those veils, those illusions—not only of selflessness, but the illusion of that solid, substantial, historically determined "me," concocted from my conditioning, your conditioning. He's seen his essential nature as a mirage of the mind. And he's not entered any unusual or extraordinary or otherworldly state. He has simply let go of his encumbrance. That's what we're practicing—what's in the way. And art practice shows us that. I mean, how many of us have so much around art, you know, and making a mark or a movement, right? We're loaded. So it's a perfect training gate to set ourselves free.

Now the Buddha's free—free to meet others where they stand and adopt whatever tactics are most effective to liberate people. And that's what we try and find with who we're dealing with. As much as we know, we keep trying to find those ways to be liberated. If we feel it, then we can do it for another person.

And here's Thurman again:

"The point is, in terms of art, when we go into the magical aspect of the Buddha, you look at the lifetime of the Buddha and see how every breath that the Buddha draws, every gesture the Buddha makes, every word the Buddha speaks, is an artistic manifestation in the sense that none of it is driven by any sort of selfish impulse on the part of the being that was formerly Siddhartha Gautama. Everything he does is a communication of compassion to other beings, creating doorways to open up their imaginations and then their whole being to enlightenment, to nirvana, to peace, to being at peace. You have to present peace first as a work of art, and that allows people to perceive it, and it opens up the possibility that they can experience for themselves."

So we treat ourselves as a work of art, and we work on this work of art to find peace, to create peace. And people will perceive it, and that opens the possibility that they can experience it directly for themselves. This is something we can create. This is our art.

As a human being, who would want to seek Nirvana if they couldn't imagine that such a state of freedom, that there is such a state of freedom from suffering?

Kay writes: "Do I take the cue from the Buddha and regard my life as a work of performance art that conveys intimately and decisively the state of my awareness and the condition of my compassion? Can I act when need be? And if not, what gets in the way?"

The Buddha is an artist because he has penetrated the veils of self, because he has tapped the enormous creative resources of his Buddha nature and thus is free of mental encumbrances. "No hindrance in the mind, therefore no fear," promises the Heart Sutra.

The Buddha at his awakening saw that all beings have the Buddha nature—perfect and complete, lacking nothing. Doesn't mean we don't need a little work. As Suzuki says: "Perfect and complete, lacking nothing. And we all could use a little work." Thus we are all artists expressing our true nature fully, through the ongoing, minute-by-minute activity of composing our lives out of the flux, out of the floating world. Some of us may realize it and some of us may not, and some of us may create art consciously while others do not. But realization or lack of it doesn't change reality one bit. There's an artist in each of us, and that's Buddhism's great contribution about human creativity.

We are deeply connected and affected by others creating. I listened to Shugen Roshi's talk on Ango opening and he said—I like this comment—he says, "Don't put the handle of creation in someone else's hands. Create the cause and conditions that give rise to good karmic roots. This we can do. We can give rise to creating the good causes that create good karmic roots." And part of Sangha's work is to create that together. And then you take that to your many others—your family, your work, your ride on the subway. We're constantly making art. It's beautiful.

Thank you. Thank you for listening.

To find out more about the Zen Center of New York City's programs, retreats and residency, please visit our website at zmm.org zcnyc.
Speaker: Jody Hojin Kimmel

Talk Location: Zen Center of New York City
Title: Auspicious! Auspicious! Spring 2025 Ango Opening Talk
Extracted Text:
Homage to Buddha, Dharma, Sangha treasures.

How auspicious, the beginning of spring.  
How auspicious, the one house of the ancestral teachings and lineage.  
How auspicious, the Buddha Dharma prevailing widely.  
How auspicious, the temple gate prospers.  
How auspicious, when many disciples assemble to meet themselves and to encounter the moment the world comes and honors our way.  
How auspicious, how auspicious, how auspicious, the beginning of spring.  
How auspicious, how auspicious, the founding of this temple, Karinji Fire Lotus.  
How auspicious.  
I changed that last part. He wasn't predicting we were going to be here. Maybe so.

Welcome to everyone. I wish I could talk to all of you and see what brought you here today, but obviously it's the Dharma on some level. And welcome. This is the beginning of what we call Ango, a 90-day intensive training period. This goes way back to the time of the Buddha, when there were the monsoon seasons and the rains would bring the level of water up. The monastics used to travel—it was primarily a monastic community—and they used to travel from sangha to sangha to learn new things, work with different teachers. So this is part of an ancient history, over 2,500 years ago.

It was a great time to work with the Buddha, because the Buddha and all the disciples would be in one place. That was rare, because nobody could travel anywhere. So we recreate, re-enact, if you will, these Ango training periods in the spring and the fall.

We've gone through this winter, and there's always—I don't know, there's something about this spring one. It's always like coming out of the dark days of winter and just in tune with the earth and what it's doing: this revitalization, this sprouting, this growing, this budding, this greening coming. You can see the small shoots pushing their way through.

When they would gather, they would set up like a university. They would have tents and temporary housing and all stay in one place. The emphasis was on collective practice. I still think that's true, that our Angos are about collective practice.

You know, I was reading this thing about how do you clean potatoes? I love potatoes. I have a real affinity for potatoes. The best way to clean potatoes is to put them in a pot of water and just let the dirt fall off. But you put them all together so they bump around and hit each other, and that's how the dirt falls off. I thought that's kind of like sangha: we all get in a pot, all of us, these potatoes, and just bump around, and that's how we get kind of clean. It just falls off. Just begins to fall off.

When we want to generate these virtues of ours—our ability to be patient, generous, loving and kind, and have a joyful effort in practice—we also have to know the other side. We have to see where we're not generous, where we're unkind, where we're impatient. That's how we learn patience. And what a better way to be in this pot. That's where we really can find out new things.

Maezumi Roshi used to call it a rock tumbler. But I like the potatoes better. If you've ever had a rock tumbler, they all bump together and smooth out their hard edges.

So it was a great time to really develop mindfulness, alertness, concentration, embodiment—all towards being of benefit. To bring more goodwill and a loving heart into the world. That's what the practice was about: to end suffering. End suffering in ourselves and in others. These are all nice words, but the day-to-day doing that and remembering how we act with our speech and our body and our thought, that's the work of each one of us and our intentions and how we might want to live.

I sent out a newsletter, if you got it, with a quote from Thich Nhat Hanh that I really appreciated. He says, "When we say, 'I take refuge in the sangha'—that's community—it's not a statement, it's a practice." I really appreciated that. It's not a statement, it's a practice.

Refuge—the word in Japanese is "ki-e"—to unreservedly throw yourself into something. Almost like when a child is on the stairs and you say, "Jump! Jump!" and there's just that trust—they just go into your arms. It's that kind of "ki-e": unreservedly throwing yourself into the Sangha treasure, the Buddha treasure, the Dharma treasure.

Buddha was constantly offering specific teachings and ways of training and practicing so we could be revitalizing, actualizing who we are, and really making contact with our innate wisdom and compassion. That is who we are. And to keep the pointing towards the wisdom and the compassion.

He would say, "More Dharma is more Dharma." And that's what we say: having more Dharma in your life is more Dharma. Yesterday I said, it's really delicious, the Dharma, but nobody can taste it for you. We each have to engage it on our own. He said, it is the antidote for confusion, overwhelm, anxiety, not creating more harm—this practicing.

The point of this season was to intensify practice. It's not like there's always practice going on, but this is to intensify. I always clarify, because people, when I say "intensify," I feel everyone gets all tense, like, "Wow, I'm already so much," and there's an element of panic. That's not intensifying. It's to deepen. It's to focus our concentration, our contact with the Dharma.

One of the reasons why we need to get the mind into concentration is so our sensitivity to what causes suffering can be seen more clearly, can be made bright. This is needed now and always.

If we're going to practice, step on the path for each of us to know, just have a sense, like, why do this? Why sit down on a cushion for 25 minutes or 30 minutes here in your home and just look, be still? Why? When you get just a sense of that—and it doesn't have to be a sentence or something linear or an idea, but just a feeling for that, why that might be helpful and actually see and experience why—it'll keep strengthening your practice and your wanting to encounter the Dharma, the teachings.

So it is to deepen and also to look at what you're already doing. Where are these places to deepen? Sometimes it's just—I've heard people say, "I'm not very nice. I'm not a kind person. I want to be kinder." And it's just taking that up, looking for those places that we can. That's deepening, that we can just make a little shift, which ripples like crazy when it's for good. That kind of goodwill, it has a tremendous effect, tremendous reverberation. We don't always see it, but we will feel it. And you'll see it felt by others. If that's what you're working towards, it'll be verified by the universe.

So it could be coming in to sit here during the week. Maybe you are close by, or you can get here and you come one morning or evening a month or a week or each day, and you just commit for 90 days. So you were each looking for—and even if you just walked in today and you had beginning instruction, that's enough. Maybe you're just going to try this at home. Set yourself up at home and sit down. That's the intensifying, that's turning towards the Dharma that's so needed.

Find what qualities we each personally need to be developing, and then that comes into the pot. What qualities do we need to abandon? What can we let go of? What is not serving? What habits do we have that we feel like, "Oh, that keeps taking me the other way, a direction I don't want to go in, that's painful." Maybe we can just intensify, learning how to release and go in a different direction.

This is part of what Buddha called the customs of the noble ones: to know what to develop and what to abandon. He calls it the customs of the noble ones, which is each of us. He says that we learn how to delight in abandoning whatever we have to abandon and to delight in developing whatever needs to be developed. Delightful, either way.

When the Buddha was teaching his son Rahula, he said, "Look at your actions before you act. Look at your intentions. If you think that what you're going to do or say or think is harmful, you've got to tell yourself, 'No, don't do that.' If you don't foresee any harm, then you can do it. If while you're doing it you see that some harm is happening that you didn't anticipate, you stop. Otherwise, you keep doing it. Then when you're done, you reflect on the long-term consequences of your actions. If you see that there was any unforeseen harm, then you resolve not to repeat that mistake again. If you don't see that there was any harm, then you can take joy in the fact that you're training your mind well and you haven't harmed anybody at all."

So this is very careful, tender, pointed work that we're doing with ourselves when we take this path of turning around, turning the light backwards. Of course, it's not easy to take a good look at our actions. When we actually can and take responsibility, we feel that delight. Even though it may hurt and it's hard to see, there's a measure of joy. It's like, "Oh, there it is. There it is. I can do something with that." It's a great relief. And we learn how to trust ourselves. It's not our fault, but we're responsible.

Remember, as you'll go along in the Buddhist teachings, that at the basis is emptiness. There's no fixed condition. Nothing is fixed. It's in a constant state of movement. We're in a constant state of change. I think we can see that all the time, how fast we can be in one state and it changes—luckily. Otherwise, why practice? If we're fixed, there's nothing to practice, we're stamped, we're fixed—but we're not. We're not fixed.

So we bring everything that troubles us, holds us back, obscures us, to the path—our pain, our lack of confidence, our, you know, when we do hurt someone, we take responsibility. We bring that to our path and we open it up. It's not to define us. It's how we learn and grow. What a teaching.

I remember going off the path and creating some harm. I wasn't really very conscious. I thought I was, but I did make some mistakes. It took me a while to make sure I could trust myself first before I could open up further. I really had to get that trust back that I wasn't going to repeat, in the way I had, what I'd done. And that I can trust myself more and also draw back blame, because blame never works. You can't blame anyone. It changes. If we really begin to bring it to our path and understand the teachings and karma, then there's a possibility we really gain some wisdom through it. That's the important part.

I didn't kill anyone—just to clarify—it wasn't that egregious, you know, but it was just one of those things we do to each other.

Each Ango, we have a theme, and for this spring, it's mountain training—it's the Eight Gates of Zen. This is my original teacher's recasting of the Eightfold Path of the Buddha: right view, right understanding, right livelihood, right speech, and so on. He created these eight gates, which are:

- Zazen  
- The teacher-student relationship  
- Liturgy  
- Moral and ethical teachings  
- Creative expression and the body, the miracle of aliveness in the body  
- Dharma study, Buddhist studies  
- Work, our right action in the world  

He said, their gates are where we enter. But he said, there are no gates. There's just this life. But we create these gates so we can enter and experience the richness of our life through a particular focus. As we go further into them, hopefully we'll see how they're all interrelated. Buddhist studies is body practice. The highest art practice is our moral and ethical life. That's an art of how to live well. That's the greatest art practice—that it's an art to work with our body, that right action is zazen—all of them interpenetrating.

We'll have what we call a chief disciple, who's a student that has reached a certain level of training. This year it'll be a monastic named Dayo. He's up at the monastery, and you might see him here during Ango. He's been here before, but he's kind of like the lead person, setting example to the sangha in the most humble way they can. It's said the shuso, when it's a monastic, is supposed to be the one that cleans the toilets at night and nobody knows about it. So we'll see if that's what he takes up. But it's kind of like this secret practice, like you don't see what they're doing. They're doing things, but they don't make a big fuss about it.

Then at the end of the Ango, he'll do his first talk and challenge the sangha in what we call Dharma encounter: take up a koan from the tradition, and everyone gets to ask him questions about his understanding. It's called the hot seat.

So there'll be lots of offerings, plentitude of offerings here and at the monastery. You can weave in and out of here. Please, this is your place. You know, this is only here for us. Right? Some residents are here that I'm very grateful for, that are living their own work life and serving the sangha by keeping this place going. Many sangha members and students come. But it only exists for us to practice the Dharma. So it's yours. I hope you can come as much as you can. Like today—it's great if this was always this full.

We have a regular zazen schedule through the week, which you can come to now that you've had beginning instruction. We'll have an introduction to the Buddhist precepts in March, which I'll be doing. What are the moral and ethical teachings of a tradition that doesn't have, say, a God or something external that we look towards? How do we know what's right and wrong? How do we guide our lives? What are the precepts?

We're doing renewal of vows ceremonies, whether you've taken vows or not. It's called Fusatsu. A lot of liturgy—one of the most liturgical ceremonies in our tradition, quite beautiful—where we acknowledge our harmful karma and our good karma that was ever created by me since of old on account of our beginningless greed, anger, and delusion. We can learn how to be at one with it, which means that response-ability to what we create with our body, mouth, and thought. It's not like it goes away, but we can at least get closer and intimate with it and say the yes—like, "Yes, this has happened," whether we've done it or it's happened to us. It's an acknowledgment. Yes. And we can be at one—atonement—with it.

Those will be happening. I'll be showing two films that we created. One is called "Watching the Rock Grow." Have you ever seen that? Watching a rock grow? If you stare at it long enough, you'll see it happen! But this is a film about Daido Roshi and how he formed the monastery in the early years. It's going to be kind of interesting to watch that again with you. You can see, like, this has been so many people and thousands and ancestors. This is our 45th anniversary as a monastery, 25 as a temple here on State Street. Just all the hands and eyes—you—that have contributed to making this place a place of practice. So I thought we'd watch that together and then have a discussion. It's on a Saturday from 2 to 4. A couple of us thought, that's a good time, like it doesn't take up your whole day, you're not eating dinner yet—come watch a film.

The other one will be the Mountains and Rivers Sutra, which combines visual images, natural sounds, music, and Daido merging his artistic expression with a spiritual expression with the Dharma. So it's an opera, so it's sung—the Mountains and Rivers Sutra. This was all based on people that came to the monastery. Someone was an opera singer, someone was a writer of operas, and so they created this opera of the Mountains and Rivers Sutra with Daido's visual things. We'll talk about art practice—whatever you would like to—about this aspect of artistic and spiritual expression coming together.

I will do face-to-face teaching for students and those of you that are formal participants, whether or not you are a student, and whoever else I can see so we can meet. It's a meeting in private on your practice and that includes, of course, your life, but it's brought into the Dharma. As you're sitting and things are coming up or getting clearer, we can check in with one another. Sometimes we don't know, we feel so alone. Sangha helps with that, to be able to see some of the potholes and some of the ways that we move forward. That'll be offered.

We'll be doing a Born as the Earth, Touching the Earth retreat led by some of our Jukai folks. Dogen said, "These mountains and rivers, these buildings, these sidewalks, belong to those who love them." He didn't say about the sidewalks and the buildings, he just said, "These mountains and rivers," which means phenomena, "belongs to those who love them." If we love something, we'll take care of it, he hoped.

So Daido would take us on these wilderness retreats so we can get close to the earth. We like to maintain that in this city, that it's not that there isn't a wildlife here. This trip will be called River to River, meeting the waterways that surround us as New York City dwellers. Actually, our water here comes from the reservoir right by the monastery, right down the pipeline. We'll do work together and body practice sessions, really trying to see how we live one undivided life through these areas, these aspects of ourselves, how that comes together as one undivided life.

The Buddha knew that practicing more intensely gives us greater opportunities. You feel it right away. I'd also like to talk more about liturgy, especially now in the world, and how liturgy can be so helpful with grounding, with overwhelm, with just giving voice to what's coursing through us and opening up to something larger, to the larger wisdom aspect. It's helpful.

Buddha said, more opportunities to recognize the Buddha mind that is steady and continuous, regardless of fluctuations, regardless of conditions, because we don't know, we can't control those, but we can work with ourselves. That's always been so hard. But sometimes it's when those conditions are that way, we find something true in our integrity and we deepen there.

He said, "Peace does not mean to be in a place where there is no noise, trouble, or hard work, but to be in the midst of those things and still be calm in our heart—calm, seeing, contemplating, having responding-ability." We're encouraged not to get lost in the congestion of mind, remembering that we have a path. It's called Marga, having a path. We want to keep exposing the unshakability of the awakened mind. We need each other, and we need to practice that because we forget. I forget. We have to forget. We have to remember, keep remembering what we have, who we are.

It says if we look after and care for our mind really well, then we're not the only one who benefits. The act of generosity and kindness is both to ourself and to others.

The Buddha uses the image of this story he gives of two acrobats. You might know this. There's one acrobat who's the teacher, and then there's an assistant who is a young girl. The teacher says to the assistant, "Okay, if you get up on my shoulders, because they're acrobats, and we'll get on top of that bamboo pole, we should look after each other so that we can both come down safely." And she says, "No, no, no, I disagree. That's not going to work at all. Each person should look after themself so that we can each be safe and come down safely."

It's kind of interesting, right? At first you're like, Oh, that sounds really selfish, you know? And I always thought that on the airplane too—you know, put your own mask on first and then go help people—because we're not... Obviously that's kind of not nice, you know, put it on them. But it's like, we can't be useful if that's going to help us help more. Then we balance ourselves first because we can't balance another person, can we? So we can't look after other people's balance. We have to look after our balance so that we don't knock somebody else off balance, is what he was teaching.

He says, "When we're helping ourselves, we are helping others." Buddha said, "Looking after oneself, one looks after others. Looking after others, one looks after oneself." Yeah. Takes courage. I have to summon courage.

I was at Ayo Yetunde's retreat the week on microaggressions, on just basically being aggressive and how we've handled that in our lives and on this planet, in this particular country. She speaks about Indra's Net, this realization of how we are all interpenetrated and interconnected. Whatever we think, that our actions don't matter, but it does—it affects everyone everywhere. You know, they say when a butterfly flaps its wings in France, we feel the breeze here. I think this is bearing out all over.

I wanted to read this inescapable mutual mutuality that's ever present. It's from Resmaa Menakem. He wrote "My Grandmother's Hands," "Quaking America," and "Monsters in Love." And so she writes—Ayo articulates it so beautifully:

"We are conceived into the net, born into it, and exist within it. We will die in its entanglements. In the meantime, can we enhance the ways we live in this vast and abundant community of kin, near and far? Casting Indra's Nets calls us to live out of and into the best parts of who we are, because we are all kin. She urges us to return to our basic goodness and choose mutuality over brutality, time after time, moment after moment, breath upon breath. If you're ready to be part of this transmutation, please turn to practice."

So that's what we have in store for us, this Ango. I wanted to give us time to enter together. There's a formal entry, but I'm calling forth here just an entry into walking the path of peace, not creating harm, practicing good, and actualizing good for others that we can all do together. Not any kind of formal entry, just by your own yes. You can be able to offer incense today and also sign the scroll. We'll have a few more posted.

I also wanted to bring in briefly just something Martin Luther King said about this net of mutuality, lest we forget. Let's bring him in:

"And don't forget, in doing something for others, that you have what you have because of others. Don't forget this. We are tied together in life and in the world. And you may think you got all you got by yourself, but you know, before you got out here to this temple this morning—you are dependent on more than half the world. You got up in the morning and you go to the bathroom. You reach over for a bar of soap, and that's handed to you by a Frenchman. You reach over for a sponge, and that's given to you by a Turkish person. You reach over for a towel, and that comes to your hands from the hands of a Pacific Islander. And then you go to the kitchen to get your breakfast. You reach over to get a little coffee, and that's poured in your cup by a South American. Maybe you decide that you want a little tea this morning, only to discover that that's poured in your cup by someone who's Chinese. Or maybe you want a little cocoa and that's poured to you by a West African. Then you want a little bread and you reach over to get it and that's given to your hands by an English-speaking farmer, not to mention the baker. Before you get through eating breakfast in the morning, you're dependent on more than half the world. That's the way he says God structured it. So let us be concerned about others because we are dependent on others."

So much wisdom that we can draw from. Let's point ourselves towards getting wisdom.

To close, we'll do this ceremony and we're going to be chanting what's called the Jizo Shingon Dharani. Jizo Bodhisattva is one of the principal bodhisattvas from the tradition—actually, I think you're all Jizo Bodhisattvas. Jizo Bodhisattva is... so they're not external, like they're us, they're qualities that we possess as a protector of those who are traveling, of women, children, all beings. They tend to go into hell realms and help people. So when your friend is in hell and you just are right there with them in presence, that's Jizo, Jizo Bodhisattva. Just these acts of guiding people and stepping in when you need to.

So this is a Dharani, a short calling up of those qualities. It's a repetition: "Um ka ka Kabisa ma e soaka, um ka ka Kabisa ma e soaka..." We'll just go.

I looked at the number of people today and I thought, oh my gosh, if we're all making incense offerings, this is going to be a long service! So I thought students, formal students on behalf of the sangha can make this offering right now. Then we'll leave these haku boxes out and anyone else can make an offering as the service ends and before we go up for refreshments or at any time before you leave. What it is, is there's powdered incense and you just unite with it and you put a little on. The burning charcoal's on the left—so don't pick up the charcoal, that's not the incense. It's pretty clear. I'm saying that because some people have picked up the charcoal—I have!

So pick up the powdered incense and you make an offering there. You hold in mind your intensification, your dedication, your intention. It may not be formed, but just feel it, that'll carry it through.

So we'll get up, we'll hear a drum, and then we'll start the chanting and we'll go from there. Afterwards we'll have a chance to meet upstairs informally. Everyone can come up and have some refreshments, and there are some students you'll see. So feel welcome, if you're new, to meet people and talk to people about what's happening a little further.

Yeah, I'm just really glad you're here and that you came, and that we can form a community like this and support one another and know that this is here for you.

Thank you. Thank you for listening.

To find out more about the Zen Center of New York City's programs, retreats, and residency, please visit our website at zmm.org/zcnyc.
Speaker: Jody Hojin Kimmel

Talk Location: Zen Center of New York City
Title: Thunderous Silence
Extracted Text:
Hello.

When I was at the monastery recently, I started to read Hakuin's book, by Norman Waddell, called Wild Ivy. And Hakuin actually wrote a lot about himself and his practice, to just articulate his process. I've been reading it because, as some of you know, I've been integrating art into teishos, into talks. It's something that Hakuin did, and it's part of the Ebaku line of Rinzai Zen, where they had an art expression within the lineage—shakuhachi and there were many painter priests.

So I thought, let me read about Hakuin and see if I can find anything about his lectures and when he pulled out the brush. I haven't found anything yet, but I did find that he painted a lot, and he wasn't a trained painter either. He had such a wide variety of expression. He could be very kind of realistic, and just be very bold with just splatter, you know, just from the hara, the belly, you know, whatever teaching was needed. He worked a lot with the laity and the illiterate, you know.

So I wanted to reread his Song of Zazen that we chanted, so you can just hear this again. He calls it a song of Zazen, which is kind of nice.

All beings by nature are Buddha
As ice by water, by nature is water
Apart from water, there is no ice
Apart from beings, no Buddha.
How sad that people ignore the nearest and search for truth afar.
Like someone in the midst of water, crying out in thirst.
Like a child of a wealthy home wandering among the poor,
Lost on dark paths of ignorance, we wander through the six worlds.
From dark path to dark path we wander.
When shall we be freed from birth and death?
For this, the zazen of the Mahayana deserves the highest praise,
Offerings, precepts, paramitas, nembutsu, atonement, practice,
The many virtues all rise within Zazen.
Those who try even once, wipe away immeasurable crimes.
Where are all the dark paths then? The pure land itself is near.
Those who hear this truth even once and listen with a grateful heart,
Treasuring it, revering it, gain blessings without end.
Much more if you turn yourself about and confirm your own self-nature.
That self-nature is no nature.
You are far beyond mere argument.
The oneness of cause and effect is clear, not two, not three.
The path is put right with form that is no form.
Going and coming, never astray.
With thought that is no thought.
Singing and dancing are the voice of the law,
Boundless and free in the sky of Samadhi,
Bright, the full moon of wisdom.
Truly, is anything missing now?
Nirvana's here before your eyes. That’s peace.
This very land is the Lotus Land, this very body the Buddha.

That was Robert Aitken’s translation. Hakuin lived from 1685 to 1768—a very dynamic teacher. He was credited with single-handedly revitalizing the Japanese Zen Rinzai School after 300 years of decline. He was so fired up, this guy! And from a very young age, he had a lot of loss.

He heard somebody—I don’t know if it was a teacher, I can’t remember who—but somebody gave this fire-and-brimstone, threatening talk about, like, “If you do something wrong, you’re going to end up in these hell realms.” He couldn’t sleep for weeks as a young kid, and he would ask his mother, like, “Am I going to…? Where am I going to end up?” It bothered him so much. And then she passed away, and he was kind of on his own. So he went into a monastery very young.

He placed special emphasis on brush teachings and koan practice, and he even invented a lot of new koans himself. Some of them we know, and we even see them on tea bags—like, “What is the sound of one hand clapping?” That’s Hakuin’s. And that’s in our koan system. The teacher will say, “Show me, don’t tell me.” And then there’s a whole series of Hakuin questions about this one hand clapping.

So as I said, he was very invested in spreading the teachings to laity and the illiterate. He wasn’t shy about people having kensho—people should have a direct experience of their nature, in a thorough and illustrative way. He wrote:

Never ask your teachers to explain. But when your activity of mind is exhausted and your capacity for feeling comes to a dead end, if something should take place not unlike the cat springing up upon the mouse or the mother hen hatching her eggs, then a great flash of livingness surges up. This is the moment when the phoenix escapes from the golden net and when the crane breaks the bars of its cage.

And he’ll paint this, too. If you can’t understand it by words, he’ll illustrate it for you.

When a person faces the great doubt before them, there is in all directions only a vast empty land without birth and without death, like a large plain of ice extending 10,000 miles, as though seated within a vase of lapis lazuli, surrounded by absolute purity. Within their heart there is nothing, there is not the slightest thought or emotion. It is just as though they were standing in complete emptiness. At this time, when they advance single-mindedly without retrogression, suddenly it will be as though a sheet of ice was broken or a jade tower had fallen. They will experience a great joy, one that never in many years has one seen or heard.

So this is his teaching poem, this Song of Zazen, meditation. It encapsulates the merits of Zazen, and he encourages students to focus on the immediate presence—right here, right now, the immediate presence, just this very moment. He speaks of the many virtues and practices within the Zen tradition and says Zazen contains them all. A form that is no form, as he speaks of in the poem—a form that is no form, where singing and dancing are the voice of the law.

Anyway, this somehow led me to thinking about silence and noble silence. Noble silence is *mouna*—M-O-U-N-A—the Buddha spoke of, which is measurement, which is about measurement and our willingness. He says measurement—Buddha pointed to the measurement of words when practiced leads to more meaningful and powerful speech. So when we’re in silence, in that measuring of words, when we do speak out of this silence, the words are much more powerful.

So what is our willingness to encounter silence? I was just like, what is silence? You know, sometimes it’s got so many different faces because, you know, Audre Lorde on one hand will say, “Your silence will not protect you.” So that’s speaking to a certain kind of silence, where we just don’t say things when maybe we should, and it’s protective. And then Rumi will say, “Let that silence take you to the core of your life.” And Hakuin speaks of this thunderous silence. And I don’t know, it just was something to contemplate.

It’s come up a lot because I have to speak a lot. And I choose sometimes to just remain silent. And so I’m like, what is the silence? What is the silence? When is silence not being silent, actually? And it’s hardly touchable.

In the practice, we could say silence might correspond to having a right view. Seeing impermanence is silence—is seeing the silence of things, that thunderous silence that it’s impermanent, that everything is appearing and disappearing and changing from moment to moment, that kind of silence.

Shunryu Suzuki talks about presence as that which carries us through the difficulty of ups and downs. When you suffer, you should suffer. When you feel good, you should feel good. It’s the willingness to engage with any set of circumstances, to directly encounter the most difficult aspects of our own selves, that gives us the true joy that is part of the meditative practice.

I was thinking about that and how when we enter that silence, that true feeling of feeling, engaging with feeling good or just suffering purely, there’s a measure of joy there, because we’re actually doing that so fully. If you’ve ever felt that, it’s a right view, it’s right understanding. We’re in alignment. Without calling it something, we taste it differently. We taste it differently—appearing and disappearing, changing from known. I could know for myself this feeling, and it was joy that emerged, a kind of joy.

Does it sound like I contradict myself, then? I contradict myself, as Whitman would say. But impermanence is not something we see objectively. It’s something that we taste directly. Impermanence makes me silent—makes me silent, because impermanence is very quiet. But we’re silent, but at the same time we’re many words, many explanations, many representations, many dynamic actions, physical, mental—all this is present. And silence seems to be something very deep, yet very active.

In Japanese, the word for silent is mokurai—mokurai. And moku means silence, and rai means thunder. That’s the word for silence. So silence is quiet, but there’s an enormous voice there, like a thunder. In practice, in zazen, I think we’re sitting into the quiet and hearing that thunder of that silence.

I remember, I told you—many of you know, I was an apprentice to Toshiko Takaezu, my clay teacher. And part of my apprenticeship was a whole life there, you know, was making food and guests, and it wasn’t just clay—working in the garden. We planted tomatoes, and I picked one that was kind of turning red—wasn’t quite red and ripe. And I put it on the windowsill, and we were having breakfast, and I was really excited about this tomato. It was like the first one, and I saw her see it, and thunderous silence.

And I could feel that roar like you would not believe. She was at the sink, and I put it on the windowsill, and she washed her hands and filled the tea kettle. She didn’t say a word to me yet, nothing. And we went about our breakfast. I could hardly chew, and I could hardly swallow. She had this, if you knew her, she had a very straight face, stern at that moment, and she wouldn’t look at me. I was just fidgeting at the breakfast table on my high seat on our bench stool, and we started eating. And she shouted out, “No, you shouldn’t have picked that tomato!”

I was like, finally, yeah. And she went through a whole list of my attributes at that moment—impatience, impetuousness. She just like—this must have been like, on her, like, book—just all these ways that I, in a really loving way, too, I must say. Like, she named them, but she was also not hating me. She was really holding me really beautifully. That was the end of my breakfast.

And then there’s a story of Shakyamuni Buddha where he remained silent to his student, Malunkyaputta. So Malunkyaputta asked the Buddha these questions—whether the Buddha would exist forever, whether the world is eternal, and whether the world is structured by spiritual or by material forces. And the Buddha remained silent. And so this is something people work with—what was this Buddha’s silence, thunderous silence, in response to Malunkyaputta’s metaphysical questions?

And part of that we can understand with this parable of the arrow, where the Buddha was sitting in a park, and this disciple, Malunkyaputta, comes and, recently retired from the world, was concerned with so many things that remained unexplained by the Buddha. And these questions—was the world eternal or not eternal? Was the soul different from the body? Did the enlightened exist after death or not? He thought, if the Buddha doesn’t explain these things to me, I’ll give up training and I’ll return to the worldly life. Have we done that with our teacher? “You don’t explain it to me, I’m out of here.”

So the Buddha replied, “Now, did I ever say to you that if you led a religious life you would understand these things? It is as if a person had been wounded by an arrow thickly smeared with poison. And their friends, companions, and relatives were to get a surgeon to heal them, and they were to say, ‘I will not have this arrow pulled out until I know who wounded me. Of what caste are they? What is their name? Are they tall? Are they short? Are they medium in height? What color is their skin? Where did they come from? What kind of bow was I wounded with? What is it made of? Was the arrow’s feather from a vulture wing, a heron’s, or a hawk’s?’ Surely this person would die before they knew all this.”

The Buddha says, “Whether the view is held that the world is eternal or not, Malunkyaputta, there is still rebirth, old age, death, grief, suffering, sorrow, and despair, and these can be destroyed in this life. I have not explained these other things because they are not useful. They are not conducive to tranquility and Nirvana. What I’ve explained is suffering, the cause of suffering, the destruction of suffering, and the path that leads to the destruction of suffering. This is useful, leading to non-attachment, the absence of passion, perfect knowledge.” Thus the Buddha spoke, and with joy, Malunkyaputta applauded his words.

Buddha keeps pointing us towards wisdom. When we’re suffering, what kind of questions are we asking, and are they relieving us of our suffering? Where are they leading? What are the questions that are helpful?

So Katagiri Roshi, in Returning to Silence, speaks about some of these characteristics of the Buddha’s silence. He says the first characteristic is emptiness. That’s right. Everything is produced by dependent co-origination, which means there’s nothing to hold on to because everything’s interconnected very closely, appearing and disappearing at super speed. So we’re in motion, everything is. There’s nothing but activity. This dynamic, incredible dynamic functioning that we see moment to moment is called emptiness.

Remember, emptiness is exactly form, form is exactly emptiness. It’s dynamic, moving constantly. That’s the first characteristic of Buddha’s silence. So when we chant the Mahaprajna Paramita Sutra—no eye, ear, nose, tongue, no body, no mind—these words “no” and “not” show us nothing has a separate existence; everything’s interconnected, sewn together with a little jewel at each intersection. The koan Mu is “no,” “not,” pointing us in this direction.

The second characteristic of Buddha’s silence is oneness. He said oneness is realizing the wholeness of existence, instead of being content with knowing one small aspect, and is characterized by reflecting upon the self with an open heart that accepts and respects others. So we have another parable of that elephant—Ayo Yetunde spoke of this in our retreat on microaggressions—where there’s an elephant and we’re kind of blind with ignorance. You grab a part, and maybe it’s the tusk, and you say, “Ah, it’s really hard.” Another person feels the tail and it’s like, “Oh, it’s skinny and taut.” So each person has a part, but for wisdom we need to come out from the parts and see a larger web and not just be on these smaller… the wholeness of the existence, not just knowing one small aspect.

He says, to understand, we have our own opinion and then to see our opinion in relation to other people’s opinions. When we see our opinion and others’ opinions are as one whole, it’s pretty hard to fight each other. Wow. Wow. Especially in light of some conversations I’ve heard lately. It’s pretty hard to fight each other. It’s all connected.

So we are quiet. It makes us quiet when we taste the pain and the suffering very deeply. Don’t you find it hard to say anything? We know who we are in that silence together. And this is related to our past, and to our future, and to the present. Right here, now. When we really understand this—not two—we taste silence and we see silence. He says when, where, how depends on our practice. We need to practice being quiet. He says, “I don’t mean shut up, but to feel the great space where you can accept all that’s here. It’s all here. All the characteristics are here. And we’re not apart from any of them.” And yet that dynamic is empty. It’s in movement. It’s not fixed.

The third one he says—Buddha’s silence—he describes as devotion. Silence is full of devotion. Self-centered life is thrown away to wholeness. A whole life is characterized by commitment and love, wisdom and prayer. And prayer in this sense is not something directed from a particular subject to a particular object with the expectation of a result—like you pray for something and then you’re hoping that it’s going to result in something. It’s more open than that.

Simone Weil—I always loved, if I’m saying her name right, am I? What? Simone Weil, Simone Weil—she calls prayer “unmixed attention.” Unmixed attention, like just what that is, that thunderous silence, unmixed attention in prayer. That is the kind of silent devotion the Buddha was offering at that moment.

Ayo also spoke about vulnerability and deeply listening to each other’s vulnerability, and not using that vulnerability as a weapon—not using someone’s or your own vulnerability to attack someone. That kind of devotion, and that prayer, and that unmixed attention, and that devotion, and that silence, that thunderous silence of impermanence, that you hear, that you can listen to, and it’s a gift. It’s a gift to receive and to give that, and it’s not used.

The fourth characteristic of silence is magnanimity. Magnanimity—a kind of generosity or elasticity. I spoke about this morning having an elastic life, a plasticity to us because we’re moving. And when we stop the movement with our thoughts and our rigidity of our mind, that’s the pain, that’s the suffering. We’re stopping something and we’re looking for, how do we release that?

I really felt that when I was laying in my bed, and I have a shagbark hickory outside my window. If you—this week, no, two weeks ago—did you experience those wild winds? Like, there was just these wild, wild winds, unrelenting, like these wind-eaties. I don’t know how many of them there were. They were all there. They were shaking the earth, like wildness.

And I don’t know if you’ve been in an earthquake. My first earthquake experience was in—I mean, there was a few in Pennsylvania that were small. I thought my brother was sneaking up on me and shaking my bed, and I was like, “Barry, stop!” Turned out it was an earthquake—because he would do that. But I remember in New Zealand, I was laying in my—I had a motel room at the time—and my bureau bent in a way that I never saw a bureau do! And I wasn’t on anything, and I didn’t have jet lag. And this shagbark hickory came alive like a person, bending and moving like I’d never seen a tree do before. And nothing broke.

You see that with trees—if they get rigid and stiff, that’s why they’re so soft inside. So it’s kind of like our posture. It’s like we remain soft inside, but we have this architecture that holds us. So it’s kind of getting those two in alignment, where we can remain soft inside, but yet we’re holding ourselves up as well. But we have to be elastic. So that’s what he says—that silence has to have that kind of elasticity, that magnanimity of being movable.

And Buddhist teachings, of course, are vast. They’re vast in characteristic. There’s nothing to pin down. They don’t do that. There’s no dogma in Buddhist teachings. It’s just not like that. It’s very vast. And that’s why this Buddha’s silence is so important to us. It’s just so vast. And he’s pointing to our vastness.

So we sit down to do zazen, and we put ourselves right in the middle of the universe, and we master ourselves there. We taste silence with our whole body and enter the wholeness with everything here—with the doors, with the floor, with the trees, with each other—something we can’t pin down. And the more we practice, the more wonderful flavors and tastes ooze from our study, from our effort, from our life.

It’s tasty, and difficult to tell others how tasty it is, because it’s impermanent. And it’s not something we can pin down, but we can sure share it. Like last night, or one of these nights this week, I leaned against a shoji screen, and it wasn’t a wall. Of course, it fell right over. But right at that moment, it felt like a wall, but it just went badoonk! That’s how words and forms are in impermanence. We lean on them, but they fall. They fall.

And painters and poets—what Hakuin’s doing, he’s trying to express silence using materials. We use words, we use music, we dance. There’s always an experience of lack of complete satisfaction. I was talking about this on the art Zoom, because silence is not something that completely can be expressed in a painting or a poem or in our activity. And that is our life. And that is the key. That is the energy of art. That is the energy of our highest art, of the precepts, is that it can’t be completed. And we have to live with that. We have to live with that. That is our complete, whole, complete, perfect life.

And we can’t do anything but keep trying to express the ungraspable with each other—the impermanence. And sometimes I just make noise. It’s like a suffering that can’t be stopped, just because we’re human and having a body and a mind. And so what do we do? We settle into stillness and silence of this breath, breathing body, and just depend on that sadness to be there and accept it and meet it with patience, with joyful effort, with generosity, with loving kindness.

It keeps us connected. Like, compassion is to suffer with, to suffer with. And then we can understand it in others, know our fear, know their fear, because we are one and the same in that way.

Zen teaching emphasizes right here, right now, because we always have the opportunity to touch silence. It takes a moment. You know, people say, “I’m not practicing.” I always—like, what does that mean? And it turns out they say, “I haven’t sat for a while.” So don’t put those two together. Like, if you started to practice, sorry, you’ve gone too far. You just can’t not practice. You can’t turn—it’s going to be really hard to turn that back, turn that dial back. Not sitting is one thing. And to make contact with why you need to sit down and be still and silent is really upon each of us to make that contact, because that’s going to help you.

I can’t tell you how tasty that is. I can tell you, but you’ve got to taste it. It’s so tasty. But teachers keep telling us and pointing, and for me too. But we only can tell the water is cold if we drink it ourselves. Is this cold? I wonder if this is cold. Ryan, can you tell me, is this cold? No. So, so what’s cold?

So, so you’re the walking temple, is what I’m saying. We’ve come to this temple, but we’re each a walking temple. And you can go in that door. Door’s open. You just turn around in a breath, and you will find stillness, spaciousness, and deep silence. Like, in that moment, just take a breath, you’re in the door, and be there—stillness, spaciousness, and silence. And then you can move. I think that’s the singing and dancing and the voice of the law.

Let it arrest you. Let’s all get arrested. Let’s all get arrested.

Thank you for listening.

To find out more about the Zen Center of New York City’s programs, retreats, and residency, please visit our website at zmm.org/zcnyc.
Speaker: Jody Hojin Kimmel

Title: Dharma Encounter On The Precepts
Extracted Text:
The following Dharma encounter with Ron Hogan Green Sensei took place at Zen Mountain Monastery at the conclusion to a week long meditation session. As you'll hear, Dharma encounters begin with the introduction of a topic related to Zen practice and training. Students then volunteer to present their understanding of the topic or a question for the Dharma Encounter teacher to reflect on. The presence of fellow students means that anyone in attendance can benefit from the exchange. We hope you enjoy.

Good afternoon everybody. So Dharma encounter, it has an ancient history. It goes back to the time of the Buddha, and during the two rainy seasons, the disciples of the Buddha, the Buddha, the Arhats, would assemble for three months, twice a year. We call that Ango. And during that time, teachings would be offered, exchanges would happen, questions, explorations. So that's what's happening today at the end of the first session of Ango and will happen the next session and the third session.

Dayo will lead as part of his training, Shuso, and becoming a senior monastic with more responsibility for leadership and a model of practice. So part of this is training for him, but it's also part of training—an essential part of training—for the Sangha, for students. It's not always easy to come up in public and have an exchange, but I think you'll find if you do, as soon as you kneel down, you'll forget about the self-consciousness and you just—it'll just go.

The Dharma encounter is one of the methods of teaching very similar to—well, it's face-to-face teaching, very similar to dokusan or daisan, which of course is private, so we don't get a chance to see how others interact with their teachers. But here, it's public, so we all can benefit from the exchange that happens. The exchange can be very direct and directly pointing to the great matter. It could be a bit more conceptual; depends on what the student brings forth in response to what I'm about to offer and where they are, where they're coming from, what the opportunity is for something to be revealed.

Well, we've been studying as the central theme of the Sangha, the Eight Gates, which in my mind at least are a, quote, modern day equivalent of the Eightfold Noble Path. And it's the heart of the training matrix here. And these are not the Eight Gates. The Eightfold Dharma Path are not recipes for enlightenment and practice. They're a guide to the path that we can take up as our own practice. But each of us is karmically different. Each of us has to find a way in this practice. Each of us has to take up the teachings in a way that is relevant and meaningful and access it through our own practice.

So although we're united, I would hope, in a desire to awaken and to live a compassionate life that comes out of wisdom, each of us has our own individual life and karma, and that should be respected and understood by each of us as we take up this path and journey along. And it's challenging because so much of what we encounter in life takes us away from the path. There's so many, what I call, shiny objects out there, right? And it's perhaps not possible to avoid being entrapped.

I was just thinking of just going through life, so entering the medical system, or trying to arrange a program on TV through cable, or any of the other myriad ways that we interact with society and how difficult it is, how unhuman it is, and how tempting it is to respond in kind.
