And that's aside from our interactions with each other, both in the Sangha and outside the Sangha, and how easy it is to poison ourselves as we receive this entwining way of relating to our life. The world seems designed to entrap us in that way and to estrange us from ourselves.

And so we practice. We have awareness of that, but it's a challenge. Dharashi spoke earlier in the week about first encountering the precepts and how he saw it one way. But as he practiced, as his practice deepened, he began to understand it in much different ways. I had the same experience. I received jukai, another tradition, another school of Zen, and okay, I got it. I'm not killing anybody, right? I'm not stealing, right? Wrong. There's a lot of ways to kill somebody. There's a lot of ways to steal. And that only became clearer to me. It's a work in progress.

As my practice deepened, as I deepened within my practice, as I practiced with you, with my teachers. And that's an ongoing process. It has no stopping point, no mastery. And so that's really what I want to take up today. And the vehicle for that are three teachings from Maizumi Roshi.

Maizumi Roshi, as you may know, is the great—well, I guess, great-grandfather and the teacher of Daido Roshi, and technically the first abbot here. These teachings seem very simple and obvious, and you can come across them in many other ways, other than outside spiritual practice. But this is Maizumi Roshi. He wasn't offering psychological support for our practice. He wasn't denying that, but that's not what it was about.

So the first thing he said is: don't deceive yourself in this practice. Do not deceive yourself. At one level, it's straightforward, right? You know, like the precepts. Be clear, be honest. Know what you want. Know what you don't want. Seems simple. But where do deceptions arise from? I think we know where they arise from. Greed, even greediness for the Dharma, enlightenment, some gifts that we'll get as a result of our practice, something I'm due. The passions of anger, jealousy. Who has not had some hardcore reaction to what we've encountered? Or just ignorance. We just don't see it, right? We're pretty good at seeing it in others. But how do we deceive ourselves just because we're not aware of the depth of the teaching? We haven't gone there. We haven't looked.

Or in my own experience, when I've encountered teachings I couldn't relate to, I'm just not interested. Has no meaning. Until it did. Until, out of my desperation to address my pain and your pain, I had to investigate it. I had to see what it meant to me personally. And maybe starting with the conceptual. But that's just the beginning. And as we go along in practice, what we previously did not consider self-deception, we now begin to consider self-deception.

The second thing he said—and all three of these blend—is don't make excuses for yourself. That is really interesting. When you enter as a student, really, what that process is about, so far as I understand it, is you are giving permission for the teachings. That's what you're doing. And how does that work? So that's training as opposed to practice. I mean, it's not a sharp line; we're all practicing to one extent or another. But this is a training matrix. And even though you may not live here, you come here and practice. And when you practice, you enter to train. And in training, it's not necessarily what you want or what you want to hear.

So recently somebody asked me about training positions. And he said, every single thing in this monastery is a training position. And the person said, "What? You mean when I wrap a package, that's a training?" Yes, yes, that's training. Well, what's the difference between someone who wraps a package for mailing who's in training, and at FedEx, perhaps probably someone wrapping a package? Is there a difference? What is that difference?

We have an infinite capacity to make excuses for ourselves. And so as practitioners of the Dharma, we're giving permission to receive training, to receive direction, to receive. I may know better in any given situation, I may think, I know better. I've done this a million times. I remember the first time I came here. I was living at 9,000 feet in Colorado and heating with wood. I cut a summer supply of wood for the whole year. I mean, picture that. Me, my chainsaw, the trees, cutting, not getting hurt or killed, and then splitting it and then stacking it. You get many opportunities to lose weight doing that, and the stacking is crucial or it doesn't dry.

And I came here and they said, "Go stack that wood. I'll show you how." I said, okay. And they stacked it. And clearly they didn't know what they were doing. And I didn't say a word. Now, if it had been dangerous, I would have said it. And I knew that stack would fall down, but I didn't say a word. Maybe I should have, but that was the choice I made because I was so eager just to respond to the direction.

And these situations come up all the time. They come up in the kitchen. They come up every place here. And so we're asked to see our own mind. When the person says, "Stack it this way," I see my own mind, "But that's not the way. The person doesn't know what they're talking about." Can I see that? Can I see that I might be angry about that? Can I see that some kid who's 21 is telling me how to stack wood, and I'm 35—I was actually older—and I know how to stack wood? What's my mind at that point? And what's the value in that?

And I'm not saying don't say something if, you know, a person is trying to change a chainsaw chain and doesn't know what they're doing and it's dangerous. Of course you say something. But I'm talking about—and that's training, too—when to step forward and when to step back.

And what does any of this have to do with zazen? Another interesting point of this. So what happens when we're brought up short? When I do something that is not skillful and hurts the other person and someone else, perhaps my teacher or sangha member, points that out—perhaps someone much junior to me points that out—where's my mind? How do I work with that? Do I make an excuse? And there's a lot of subtle ways of making excuses.

We see the obvious ones, right? In politics, "I take full responsibility for this." What does that mean other than the words, "I take full responsibility?" What's behind that? When we take full responsibility or we don't. And this is risky business, right? Because every interaction with somebody is risky business—may not come out the way you would like it to. How do you see that? How do you see your own mind?

My experience and my practice is that in every interaction, every difficult interaction or result of an interaction that I'm in (and I see it in others as well) is that I have contributed to that. Sometimes not obvious, sometimes it would seem to be all the other person's. But karmically speaking, it's worth looking at. How is that? How have I contributed to this? What's my responsibility to this? And then what do I do out of that? What is the skillful means of saying something? Not saying something, just taking it in.

And there's a more fundamental view of taking responsibility, which is the third point. Skipping—sorry. The third point is taking responsibility for yourself. So to take responsibility when you or I deceive, deceive each other, deceive me, when you make excuses for something that happened, that's crucial. How can you turn responsibility into acknowledgement and action? Again, it isn't enough just to acknowledge, "Yes, I'm responsible." What's the action? What should be the action in any given situation? Is there a cookbook for that?

At its most profound level, perhaps, maybe there's more. But from my perspective, at its most profound level, I quote Daido Roshi, who I think was quoting Zorba the Greek, and we heard him say this many times: "You're responsible for the whole catastrophe, you and I." How is that so? How can that be? How can that be? I mean, how can I be responsible for things that I seemingly have no control over, no input into? How can I be responsible for when I get cancer? It happened, happens all the time, without any apparent contribution on the person who's receiving that.

So in these simple instructions—take responsibility for yourself, don't deceive yourself, don't make excuses for yourself—it's all a practice, it's all there. And I'm not going to suggest any questions because it's all there. And I think you can supply the questions or the explorations or the answers. And so that's what I'd like to work with now.

In a moment, the line will be called. Anyone who's on that list in the back, anyone who's signed up for Ango is eligible. I would, as I've already said, like to encourage people who are in training who might hesitate to come up, because it will help you and it'll help me and us. But I also want to encourage more experienced people so that we get a good mix and we get beyond the entertainment of this day—wisdom and compassion.

So let's open up the line. And Dayo will start as part of his training. And he'll do three bows, entering and leaving. And everyone else will do one bow.

Before you start, can I say something? Congratulations on being Shuso. I think it's wonderful, and I wish you the very best. I didn't have a chance to say that. I wanted to say it.

Shoshanji, I'm taking responsibility if I just make it about me and you. Because that's what's alive straight in front of me right now. I've been interested in when I don't take responsibility, when I'm determined to blame you, blame the other, blame you. How hard I have to work that. It seems when I came into training, that I could say, like, "Right, I'm giving you this thing. Right? That's your problem." I've been interested in how many times a second, actually, I have to keep doing that. How exhausting that is. I didn't want to take responsibility.

This morning, I knew this was coming, and I'd done my bit for the week, and I wanted to take a morning off. I wanted to take a morning off. And I just, like, just—just go up there, say something that's okay. And then, you know, you started speaking. I'm quite—and then this.

Now, when we turn our life to the Dharma, the Dharma turns to us. And sometimes, and I'm speaking from my experience, your experience, the Dharma brings us kicking and screaming to clarity and compassion. And that's good. It's the Dharma. One way of understanding is it's a mirror. The Sangha, our teachers, the teaching, show us ourselves. And it's all good.

Do you know why it's all good? What you just described is all good. What makes it all good?

Because this—yeah. Because when I'm—when my eyes meet yours—yeah. When my eyes meet yours.

Are we one body or two bodies?

My eyes meet yours.

That's right. May your life go up.

Don't deceive yourself was one of the instructions. So if I practice well and I understand some, you know, I'm practicing out of self and other and not two. I'm the same as you, and so I shouldn't be deceiving you or me. And there's, like, a relationship there. And I'm working this out as I'm talking. You know, my language is the way it is.

So I guess my question is sometimes in conversation with someone who is not necessarily practicing, doesn't have an understanding of some of the Buddhist teachings. And we all do this. What we say is what we desire, what we wish, what we fear. It's coming out of something great, you know, and the thing for me is like, okay, how do I be with this person, like truthfully, but yet be kind? Because sometimes the two are—it's skill. It's not always available. So I just wondered if you had any advice.

What I do is fumble around. I do the best I can. And that's all you or I can do is the best I can. But I'm careful. And I've said this a number of times before. I have a checking question to myself too: Am I doing the best I can? Do you know what that is?

No, I don't know what that is.

Am I really doing the best I can or am I just using that as an excuse to not look any further?

Okay.

And that guides me because I don't always want to do the best I can. It hurts.

Well, and also, how about asking the person, you know, also like checking with them, "Is this—I'm hearing what you're saying is such and such. Is that how you see it?" I mean, to me that's how, like, I would just reflect something back. Hopefully, you know, I don't know. That's just—

That's a useful technique. It's helpful. It also shows interest in the other person and gives them an opportunity. But what's at the bottom of that?

Being with a person completely. Not separating myself. And for me, that's really a lot of training. It's a lot of training because I'm—I've come from a tradition of opinion, judgment and, you know, and smart alecky, you know, relationships. So this is really a turning around.

Well, you're the only one in the zendo who's like that.

Yeah, so we do. I mean, in this relative world where we're not in control of outcomes and we wish the best, hopefully for everybody. Yeah, we screw up all the time. And that's—thank you for your teaching. May your life go well.

So, Sanji, as I was listening to you give the opening for this, I thought I had so many questions, but when you get up here, things change. But I wanted to touch on "don't make excuses for yourself," but let me frame that slightly differently. What I'm feeling these days is that seamlessness, the seamlessness of activity, of people with people and what we do and how we live our lives. When I come here, and especially this past week—and it's been leading up to this—just feeling that more and more and knowing that I want to explore that more.

And going through the training, there are some things that are becoming very apparent with the koan training, whatever. There seems to be something very common, very wonderful and difficult coming up. But one of the things I wonder, and I have, to be honest—well, this is the funny thing. Let me take full responsibility. And we've spoken about this, about doing some residency here, but I know myself and I think there are others like me. This is a really odd one to say. I know that most likely I know what I do and what I've done for most of my life. And my father used to talk to me about it in not so great terms. You know, in his Jamaican accent, he would say, "Horace, why don't you go along and follow other people?" I say, "Daddy, I can't. I don't know what it is, but I can't." I know, but training here is something. And I see that I'm, you know, that's going to happen.

But what about for people who—people for me, not people, for me—for doing really seamless, connected, honest training? And as I'm saying those words, I can already feel the bullshit coming out of my mouth, but I want to hear it back from you.

Training as a layperson, we don't have the obvious guardrails, right? And being fooled by media, being fooled by other people, and that's a very interesting situation. And you do choose your friends well. You're very careful about that. That's important. But what else? I mean, coming here, being involved, engaged, I just feel like I want to do more. And yet I feel like I'm doing what I can. But am I making excuses?

I can't answer for you. You know, I live at a distance. I can come here when I can come here, and I'm pretty careful about doing that as best I can, even though it creates some difficulty in my life, as it does with everybody. But to answer your question, my perspective of that rests in something underneath. Coming here and not coming here. How do I get training?

So I'll quote Sinclair Lewis, who talked about Aerosmith. "A man is a person of married measurement." A person of married measurement, which is not a compliment. And what's fearful for me personally is if I'm a person of measured practice, am I? In any given instance, it's not a yes or no answer ever. I mean, you can't sit here in sesshin, put your heart on the line and measure that. But there's a larger context, our life, that you're pointing to.

Yeah.

And so we have to weigh what you're weighing. And it's, as you say, it's coming up for you that this is how I live my life. I've set it up that way, or I certainly have responsibility that way. I've made commitments both here and elsewhere, and there's a tension between that. Right. And there's especially a tension—not attention—to what I want and enjoy and what I don't want at the end of my life, which is to look up and say, I don't want that. And I'm desperate for that not to happen. It's not going to happen. And so given that, that weight of that, which is real, I'm going to consider that very carefully. So that takes me to places that I'm not comfortable enough, that hurt to face, to what I cook.

I know you play basketball—to square up in front of someone that you're defending, who's better than you, but you're squaring up anyway, and they're going to score, and you're squaring up, they're not going to score.

Yeah, well, that's the internal dialogue. Sorry if it's non-relational, but that's—there's a determination there, which I hope we can each relate to—that in our own respective way, to wake up, and the clock is ticking, and I have to have the responsibility, face the responsibility of doing what I need to do, to do that, while doing my best to hold these other things. And there's a price. There's a price that you and I have to pay. It's not free. This practice is not free in that sense. And each of us has to determine in any given situation, time, place, what are we willing to do? Will we take a step that we know nothing about? It's a risk, right? Because we're abandoning something. I mean, it's the same risk that when you became a student, you didn't know what being a student meant. I mean, someone who recently became a student said to me, "I had no idea what this was, but I knew I had to do it." So it's yours. It can only be yours. And the karma of that is yours. May your life be well. Thank you for your teaching.

So, Shan Chi, these are questions I try to look into a lot. On the one hand, I tend to see the trees rather than the forest, so I can always find reasons. I tend to see things as complicated, which always helps me find a reason for this and a reason for that. So it's easy to find excuses. And fortunately, I've been in some situations where I saw my mind—I think because of my practice—I could see my mind go there, wanting, wanting, wanting a reason why it wasn't my fault, and I could find them. I mean, in a sense it wasn't. It was more complicated than that. It was true as far as it went and at the same time seeing. But that takes energy to sustain that point of view. And what kind of life do I want to live? Because that's like trying to hold a past together. This is what happened. This. This is what happened, holding that together. And I want to go forward into something better.

And so I'm lucky. There were a couple of situations like that where it was so strong to find a reason why it wasn't my fault. And I just decided not to do that, to take a step forward and say it was. And I discovered that when I did that with people, it built trust with them, which I wasn't expecting. I was thinking, well, they'll blame me or they'll think I'm incompetent, or they won't trust me anymore because I screwed up. But actually it's what builds trust between people to take responsibility, even when it actually is more complicated than it's my fault. Just to say, I don't know, it's like a step forward to make things right or at least better. It's really important for me to discover that.

And at the same time, it's always a very live question for me when that becomes an excuse not to cover the ground I stand on, not to—not to think I'm unworthy, to take the blame because I'm afraid, because I figure no one else will. It's up to me, you know, when does it become a not good thing?

Well, as they say in sports, levels of the game. So there's different perspectives here. One thing that helped me is that when I switched in my mind—and I've said this before—blame, because it's a lot of fun to blame you. You. I'm free of that. To contribution. And as I've mentioned before, I've never seen a difficulty between two people in which they both did not have a contribution. And so from my perspective, instead of blaming, your contribution is your business. It is not my business. Sometimes I have to remind myself of that. But that's how I understand it. But what about my contribution? And that's—this is quite a challenging way of looking at things, because you can imagine easily situations where there's no apparent bad things happen in relationship or whatever, and there's no apparent contribution of one party. The other party committed such a grievous deed. But it's always there in some subtle way.

And then beyond that, in terms of your responsibility, in terms of this practice, what is outside you in this world? What is outside you in a deep sense, not a relative sense?

Well, you could say there's a boundary, but it's always arbitrary where that boundary is.

Yeah, there is no boundary. Fundamentally, there is no boundary. That's what the Buddha awoke to. That's what you're—on a fundamental basis, there's nothing outside you. That's what we're practicing to realize. And then when you step into the relative world, we're full of boundaries. How will you hold that understanding and realization? And you're practicing that. That's what you're practicing in zazen. It's not something—oh, I haven't discovered it yet. You're discovering it breath by breath, by breath, by breath. Moment after moment after moment of shikantaza, you're discovering that. But it's not an idea to hold or a thing. It's much more subtle than that.

So given that, how do you take your practice and see past someone else's or my own insecurities, fears, and understand they're very little. We don't have to focus on them. We can just let them be. We don't have to fix them. We can accept ourselves as we are—sometimes fearful, sometimes not, sometimes this, sometimes that—and allow for that. You have to allow the space for that. That if—when something hurts or feels threatened, if we just run to the place that we've run our whole life, then there's no options, right? There it is. That's it. I'm "safe." Are you safe? You get a life now that's very limited, a life that's very limited, that's bounded by that.

And so we're given the Three Treasures. We're given this practice. We're giving each other to practice that. And it hurts. It hurts. I want to cry. It hurts to face that. It's like your long companion, your dog, has died. You loved your dog, but your dog is gone. So what will you do? And that's the essential question we face time after time. What will you do?

And luckily, what you've done a thousand times and now do a thousand a week. You still have an opportunity to see it, to study it, to work with it. To work with your teacher. To work with the Sangha. To work with your pain and go deeper. May your life go well. Thank you for your teaching.

Shoshanji, some days I don't deceive anyone on earth. Some days I have deceived every single person. Some days I have no regrets. And some days I have hundreds of thousands of regrets. How is it for you?

Have a cup of tea. My heart is breaking. I cry. How is that all good?

Because it's real and it's the Dharma and it's who you and I are. And that's what I care about. How can I be I and you be you and we be together in that. And that is a good day.

Comrade, is that better than no thing?

Beats me. I don't know the difference. Thank you for your teaching.

I think I'm better at recognizing that my default program to receiving feedback for service instructions and whatnot is defense. I actually realized that in October when Gokhan gave me—Alex—October sesshin. At the end of sesshin, Gokhan gave me feedback.

Who gave you feedback?

Gokhan. At the end of sesshin—the sesshin is over. And then he came up and gave me feedback about holding incense. And I just started rambling off the reason why I'm holding it the other way.

He did or you did?

I did. I did, of course.

So why were you holding it the other way?

Because my way is the right way.

Exactly. But I beg to differ, my way's the right way. Now what are we going to do?

Well, I know what I want to do is to hold it the right way, the way that it is designed to be held. So I went back and I realized, wait a minute, there's something that I'm missing. And then I asked Joosan, okay, so how do you hold this again? And then I realized, oh, I've been holding it wrong all these years. So I realized he gave me a gift because it's the end of sesshin. He doesn't have to come up and be sure—he's tired. Or maybe he isn't. But, you know, assuming because people work hard here. And I realized when people are giving main instruction here, especially, they are giving me a gift. And it's so awesome to receive it. So obviously I'm not always happy to, you know, I have a resistance, but I'm learning to work with it.

So what's the gift?

Okay, this might sound a lot—hyperbole. It feels like love.

But suppose it didn't feel like love.

At least I can remember when it feels like love. And I can work with it when it's—when it feels like shit.

So it feels like shit. But what are you receiving? Where is the shit?

It's in my mind.

Well, what makes it shit? Or what makes it love? He's just showing you how to hold incense. He's not thinking love, shit.

Yeah, but I suppose this love is an antidote to my defenses. Maybe they melt, I don't know.

Well, love is a slippery topic. Slippery word. I respect it, though. But you've heard me say, turn everything towards the Dharma. So whether it's shit or love, I mean, you know, there's a koan, which—the answer is "use toilet paper, shit stick as the body of the Buddha," I don't remember exactly the words. How can that be, whatever comes?

Well, how can that be, whatever comes? Is that a question for me?

Yeah.

How could, as Roshi said, really, "It'll all be good. Every day is a good day. Every moment is a good moment." What underlies that?

I feel like when I'm not there, when my self-centeredness is lessened, when I'm not there, it's fine.

Why is it fine? What's there when you're not there?

Everything else.

Exactly. Exactly. In that instance, without any duality, taking my words to mean anything other than that you are awake. And that's a fine day. A fine moment. May your life go well. Thank you for your teaching.

Working in the kitchen, I find it hard a lot of the time to stomach that I have responsibility or that I have influence for the way that other people's practice goes. And that—yeah—that every moment I have a choice to guide that or to kind of look away and pretend like it doesn't matter so much. Or that what I think that people want from me in the moment is more important. And I struggle with that because I feel the weight of it.

You know, the middle way is not only wanting to be free of your fear and suffering and not only wanting others to be free from their suffering, but also deeply respecting that your karma is your karma and theirs is theirs. So their practice is their practice. And that's not, in one sense, a particular sense that we're talking about here. Your direct responsibility—your direct responsibility—is to offer what you're going to offer, what you, this person, can offer. Struggling, not struggling. In other words, offer your practice. And what's theirs is theirs. And that's how it is for all of us.

I mean, how often does somebody—do we do something with the very best of intentions, wanting the best for that person, and it doesn't go well? We're not in control of that. You're not in control of someone else's reaction. You're not in control of outcomes. Right. Can you feel that?

Yeah, we're desperately trying, but it doesn't really work. So what can we do?

I feel like there's times when I know that something is more skillful, but there's like a barrier there that I can't seem to surmount. Or, like, I know that people come in with their tendencies, and I know that they're here because they want to practice. But I don't know. I second guess, I guess, people's insincerity and my own—well, other people's sincerity.

Again, not in your control. And in a particular way, not your business. Right. Everyone comes into the kitchen, so start with yourself. And also, look at situations, ask for advice. This is what happened to Eduna. So only twice this week—just twice—did Shugen Roshi say, "Well, you could have done this instead of said that, and maybe you wouldn't have hurt that person." Only twice. I think I'm doing pretty good.

That was helpful. Oh, next time I'm in that situation, I don't have to—I can be more generous. So ask for help so that the next time—and that's how you learn to be skillful with your practice. And we need help. I need help. We all have a personality. We all have a personality that affects other people and goes into their reference system, right? And sometimes they're not that happy. Sometimes they love it, sometimes this, sometimes that. Doesn't matter. You have to work with it. And you have to be responsible for your job. That too. There's a job going on there, and we have to eat. You have to feed us.

So there's a lot of space there, a lot more space. When it seems that you can ask for help, ask for help. When it seems, "No, I'll learn," do that. When none of that is applicable—sometimes it's not. The water just keeps flowing down the river. Can you live with that without poisoning yourself? You can practice that. May your life go well. Thank you for your teaching.

Shirasanji, do not deceive yourself. Think of the teaching: "Wherever there's a sign, there's deception." I feel like I use a lot of signs. I use a lot of language, and people use that around me, and it creates a lot of activity and pulls me in all different directions. There's all this energy to it, and there's this peace and tranquility in sesshin that I come to. And then going back to normal ways of interacting, all the signs come back. And how is it to be in that? How do we work with that?

Well, I'm cautious with "wherever there's a sign"—what was the word you used? Deception.

Deception.

I don't know about that. I mean, sometimes you hear words that are real, true and honest. Right? Is that a sign?

I guess it's—there can be, like, an energy that is true, but it's still using, like, a finger pointing at the moon in a way. Like, it's just something that's representing something else.

Okay. What else you got other than the finger? It's like I say "orange," and there's no—yeah, there's no—what else you got to say "orange"? Hand me the—yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah. So you have to—yeah, yeah, yeah. So what's the difference between "Hand me the orange" or "Please hand me the orange"? What's the difference between—other than politeness, right?

Yes.

I'm feeling that, like, there's just an energy that we can offer with the ways that we use it. And that's—I feel like that's—

But there's more than that.

Uh-huh.

There's more than—yes, that's true. What's the kind of energy that nurtures, that offers, that truly offers? What is that kind of energy? Where does it come from?

It comes from just that realization that we're in it together. We're creating it together.

Yeah.

Practicing together. Or you're practicing, at least, if you're doing that. And so, yes, the ultimate truth maybe is beyond words and letters. The relative truth is not. And there is a relative truth, and they're not different. And we want to divide them up, right? So this is this, this is that.

Yeah.

But turns out reality is one whole piece. When we divide it, we suffer.

Yeah.

May your life go well. Thank you for your teaching.

So, Sanji, I am practicing just this responsibility for goodness. Palpable. True. Or so it seems to me, like an orchestra at times. True—people hurt people for real. That's all I have.

I cannot really comment, truly comment, honestly comment on what you're saying about your own practice. Because I don't know. I look at my practice and my vows, which almost always are right in front of me, and I think I do my very best to practice them—to do good. To do good for others, to not do evil. But I know there's more in my practice, and so I can't stop there. I can't say that's my vow and I'll live it. And I do live it. Maybe I can't say I do live it, because sometimes I don't. So—and I'm often blind to that. I get the feedback when I suffer. I get the feedback when the sangha, both here and in the world, offers me that. And that is my responsibility. And taking that up and studying that responsibility allows me to go deeper within myself. And it hurts. And I have to face my own ego and my own expectations and desires.

So although I cannot know your practice and how you understand it other than your words, I would just share that with you to see if it offers you anything.

Share what I said.

Yeah.

I love you.

I'm sorry?

I love you.

Yeah.

Yeah. It helps me.

Yes. Yes. I do. I do. We do. Thank you for your practice. Thank you for your teaching.

So, Yanche, at the most fundamental level, at the deepest level, I don't know who I am. And at that level, everything feels like a deception. Any face forward I put is a deception. It's—behind that face is just—I don't know.

Thank you for offering that.

I know I don't want to hurt. I know if I do something, I guess I see reflections of—whatever semblance of a self I'm putting forward comes back. I see that I hurt people. But I also see that people project to me that I'm smart or funny or this or that. But when I'm home alone in a cabin, alone, that all falls away. And I don't know. I think it's just an act.

Can you use that desperation? Can I use it to help you and others?

It's what brought me here.

Yeah.

I use it every day. That's the path.

Thank you for sharing that. Because that's all a path.

Yeah. Every day, you know, you wake up in a simple room with very few things, and you come and you live almost the same day that you lived before. Every day is the same day. So some days are good, some days are bad. You wake up and come down and you practice. Good days, bad days.

That's right.

Yeah. Just keep going. But you use that energy of that desperation. Don't just keep going blindly. Use it. Be smart. I'm cursing you. I would never live up to that. But seriously, we all face this, and what we do then is what matters. And we all face it if we choose to see it, if we choose to look. May your life go well. Thank you very much.

It occurs to me that this is the founding sesshin. Is that right? The founding sesshin. And when I come to the sesshin, sometimes I wear this rakusu, which is Daido's rakusu, and one of his. And that—what he founded and paid a price for—is a gift that we cannot repay. We just can't. But we have to try. And we have to try because our lives are at stake. And the lives of many other people are at stake. And these are getting to be terrible times, maybe much more terrible. We'll see.

Still, from a practice way of practicing, every day is a good day. That's up to us. We have power. And that power is in the Dharma, in this practice. And in our own way that's appropriate to each of us, we can choose to center our life around it. Not even saying you have to change anything, although you may. But certainly it's a change in view. Whether we want that or not. Or are we ready for that? You've seen people come up and have all different perspectives, as do you and I. But there is a karma. And we live that karma. And it extends out way beyond our ken. It goes and it goes.

Just as some guy 2,500 years ago said, "Shit, there's gotta be more than this. There has to be more than this." And here you are. Here I am. And we can offer that. We don't have to be some idea of a deeply enlightened person. I don't know what that means. We just have to practice. We just have to. I mean, in a way, what we talk about is a fundamental integrity, self-deception. What kind of self are we talking about? It's just you. It's just your life.

So let's do this together. Let's practice together. Let's have a life together. Together and apart. Together. It's up to us. This whole life, except us. May our lives go well. Thank you for listening.

To find out more about ZMM's programs, retreats and residency, please visit us online at zmm.org.
Speaker: Ron Hogen Green

Title: 500 Blessed Lives, Part II
Extracted Text:
The following Dharma discourse was given by Jeffrey Shugen Arnold at Zen Mountain Monastery. Shugen Roshi is the Head of the Mountains and Rivers Order and abbot of the monastery. This talk, like all of our talks, is offered free of charge. If you would like to make a donation or find out more about our various programs, visit us online at zmm.org. Thank you for listening.

---

**Bai Zhang and the Fox**

**The Main Case:**

Whenever Master Bai Zhang gave teisho on Zen, an old priest sat with the monks to listen and always withdrew when they did. One day, however, he remained behind. Bai Zhang said, "Who are you standing here before me?" The priest said, "I'm not a human being. In the past, in the time of Kasho Buddha, I was the head of this monastery, and once a monk asked me, 'Does an enlightened person fall into causation or not?' And I replied, 'They do not.' Because of this answer, I was made to live as a fox for 500 lives. Now I beg you, please say a turning word on my behalf and release me from this fox body."

The priest then asked Bai Zhang, "Does an enlightened person fall into causation or not?" Bai Zhang said, "They do not ignore causation." Hearing this, the old priest was at once enlightened, making a bow to Bai Zhang, and said, "I have now been released from the fox body, which will be found behind the mountain. I dare to make a request of the master. Please bury it as you would a deceased monk."

Bai Zhang had the ino strike the gavel and announce to the monks that there would be a funeral for a deceased monk. After the midday meal, the monks wondered aloud, saying, "We're all in good health. There's no sick monk here. What is this all about?" After the meal, the master led the monks to a rock behind the mountain, poked out a dead fox with a staff, and cremated it.

In the evening, the master ascended the rostrum in the hall and told the monks the whole story. Huangbo thereupon said, "This old priest failed to give the correct turning words and was made to live as a fox for 500 lives. You say? If, however, their answer had not been incorrect each time, what would they have become?"

Bai Zhang said, "Come here and I'll tell you." Huangbo then stepped forward to Bai Zhang and slapped him. Bai Zhang laughed out loud, clapping his hands and said, "I thought the foreigner's beard was red, but I see that it's a foreigner with a red beard."

**Wumen's Commentary**

Not falling into causation—why were they turned into a fox? Not ignoring causation—why were they released from the fox body? If you have an eye to see through this, then you'll know that the former head of the monastery did indeed enjoy their 500 happy, blessed lives as a fox.

**Wumen's Poem**

Not falling, not ignoring.  
Odd and even are on one die.  
Not ignoring, not falling.  
Hundreds and thousands of regrets.

---

You know, the nice thing about having the opportunity to give talks on these koans is that they keep opening up, revealing. So this is from the Wumenkan; the other day I took it from the Book of Serenity, and so they're slightly different, same basic story.

And so this question or this matter: causation. The Buddha said it is essential that we study it, examine it, understand it, have faith in it. I read from Dogen, who was very clear, unambiguous, about the importance of having deep faith in causation. And he's—teachers don't really ever say anything new. In a sense, that's the point, right? It's sort of antithetical to our time, where, you know, even if you're just a tube of toothpaste, you have to come out with something new every few months. Really, the responsibility of the teacher is to be true to the Dharma that has come down.

Yes, of course, each person speaks about it in their own way, and there's a newness, a freshness to that. But the Dharma itself does not need improvement, in a sense, or innovation.

Nagarjuna said, "If you deny cause and effect in the worldly realm, as some people outside the Way do, you negate this present life as well as future lives. If you deny cause and effect in the realm of practice, you reject the Three Treasures and the Four Noble Truths." Which means, in a worldly sense, it will be hard to live within Buddha Dharma. It will be very hard to practice.

Cause and effect—one clearly seems to lead to the other. And in that, there's apparent duality. And the teachings speak about: there is cause, there is effect. One of the images or metaphors that's used is of a seed: that when the seed sprouts and begins to send down roots and send up leaves and branches, it's no longer a seed. The causal relationship is there, but the seed is no longer existent. It's now—there is no seed, there's a sprout.

Master Dogen, in the Genjo Koan, said, "Firewood turns to ash and does not turn into firewood again." If you think of this in terms of cause and effect—but do not suppose that the ash is after and the firewood before. We must realize that firewood is in the state of being firewood; the cause is in the state of being cause, and has its own before and after. Yet, having before and after, it is independent of them. It is a complete moment, a complete entity, without any fixedness, without any solidity, without any self.

Ash is in the state of being ash, Dogen says, and has its before and after. Just as firewood does not become firewood again after it is ash, so after one's death, one does not return to life again. So we cannot go back to the cause. We cannot go back to anything.

If you just had the most splendid period of zazen—kiss it goodbye, it's already gone. You cannot keep it. Why would you want to? In a sense, keeping it might presume that this is it, this is what there is, this is as deep, as broad, as insightful, as important as it is. And wanting to get away quickly from what a difficult period of zazen is—also presuming that there is something wrong with that, that that has nothing to offer.

There is no intrinsic good or bad, right or wrong. There is no intrinsic nature to anything. That's what the Buddha realized. Everything—all of us, animate, inanimate, as the Buddha said, within the human realm. Whether we speak of it as a state of becoming—I find that a little problematic, because it's as though it is becoming something, but it is always becoming, so it never arrives. It's sometimes also spoken of as process. I don't know, it sounds a little bit like being on an assembly line, you know. I don't know what the right way of speaking of it is, but the point is, it's alive.

And so the Buddha said, in this moment, you are having an experience. You are experiencing this because of causation, causal actions and results that are bringing you to this experience, this experience to your awareness. In this moment, it doesn't belong to you. You can't keep it. It is not you.

He said, it is only to be experienced—hear only what is heard, see only what is seen. Everything is empty of its own power, its own being, its own origination.

And yet we're deeply affected by things. That's our sentience. It's a good thing, right? What if we were like—I mean, maybe stones are affected. They certainly do change. We don't know what they feel. We feel. Would you want to not, maybe sometimes, but don't wish on that.

So it's: how do we hold this sentience? How do we hold this feeling, sensing, perceiving, body and mind? A word is spoken and you feel love, trust, inspiration. A word is spoken and you get angry, distrustful, or feel helpless. We are affected by actions. That's why actions are important.

The Buddha recognizes how powerful language is. He said, know what you're going to say before you say it, think about its influence. Where is it coming from? Does it need to be said? Is it helping? The effects we experience—that can seem short, that can seem long. People can carry the consequences of actions their entire lives. Maybe you know some who have. And usually there's a point at which there's an investment in not putting that down.

We can carry guilt and remorse. We can carry anger and resentment. That's why forgiveness is so important. Forgiveness is the ability to forsake your right to carry that grudge. You can—it's your right. Nobody can take that away from you. But you forsake that right. For what? For why? And the beauty of that is you can forgive someone who isn't asking for your forgiveness.

We can apologize to somebody meaningfully, deeply, and they not accept it. But no one can prevent us from offering that. We don't have to wait for someone's request to forgive.

A realized being does not fall into cause and effect and was made to live 500 years as a fox. So as I said the other day, seems pretty clear to be punishment. That's an ordinary way of looking at it.

In the moment of firewood, there is only the state of firewood being firewood. In the moment of a cause, there's only that state of a cause. Because nothing is fixed. Everything is not only subject to change, is changing. Habits are either getting stronger or getting weaker. The views that we hold are either becoming more entrenched or not.

I remember years ago, there was somebody in residence—no, they weren't in residence, they'd been in residence, they were living nearby—I was seeing them in dokusan, and they said they were in a corporate job that they hated. I mean, they spoke about it with like, I could feel the hate. And every day she had to go in for this job because she had signed a contract. She had three months left. She had already secured a new position, which she was very excited about, which made the three months still in this job even harder. And she was a practitioner.

And I said, what if you don't make it to the end of these three months? What if you die before that happens? And I said, you made an agreement to give them your best. You've got three months left. Is this helping you, actively hating this? How can you practice this? I said, until those three months are over, this is the rest of your life. If you think of it that way, there is no after, there is no next. This is it.

I remember talking to one of our incarcerated students who had been up for parole countless times, and because of the nature of his crime, he was probably never going to be released. And every time two years would come around, he would get so enthused and do so much work and work so hard and garner so much support to be released, and then it would be denied and he would just be crushed and fall into a depression and then he would rouse again. And I witnessed this over many years. And finally one day I said to him, I said, look, why don't you work hard towards being paroled, but imagine that you are never leaving this place. And he looked at me like—well, you can imagine how he looked at me. He did not hear these as words to be heard, as something to consider. And I understood, I got that.

But it was the clutching, the investment, the attachment to the result that he wanted and many thought rightfully deserved, that was keeping him alive. And I said, but it's also killing you. Is there another way?

There's a koan where a great ox—huge, bulky head, chest, torso—passes through a window, but its tiny little tail won't pass through. Why? And the commentary to that said, if it passes through—the whole ox and the tail—it falls into a ditch. If it doesn't pass through, it's destroyed. But isn't the point to pass through? Aren't we trying to cross over to the other shore? Why, if it passes through, does it fall into a ditch? And if it doesn't, it's destroyed. What now?

Master Sansheng asked Xuefeng, his teacher, "The golden fish that's passed through the net, what does it use for food?" This is the image, metaphor for an enlightened being. A golden fish passes through the net, no longer caught. Now what does it use for food? And Xuefeng said, "I'll tell you when you come out of the net."

I mentioned a koan the other day: "An ascetic who is pure and undefiled will not enter Nirvana. A monastic who breaks the precepts will not fall into hell." This is one of the ways in which the koans in many religious teachings can be so powerful. Because they startle us, right? They do not conform to our idea of how things work. In fact, they seem to often contradict it directly. So are these—is that statement contradicting Nagarjuna? Dogen?

It's so difficult to not assume a self, it's just kind of automatic. And even as we are within the practice of the Dharma, having faith in selflessness, practicing to realize that, bringing those words to our mouth every day—in the midst of that, we continually assume that there is a self. It reveals itself in our language all the time. It's just so strong.

If enlightened beings are not free of causation, then how are they, can they be liberated? How can we be liberated? I spoke about this the other day. Is it just a matter of mitigation, diminishing? That's not what the Buddha was looking for. That's not what he realized.

Is being turned into a fox punishment for the wrong answer? If it's wrong is wrong, then there is no freedom. If he's right, then it seems to contradict all these other teachings.

Having deep faith in causation, Dogen says, do not try and avoid this. Do not try and get away from this. Is there a path beyond right and wrong? Is there a path beyond passing through and not passing through? Not blind to cause and effect, not confused by it, not ignorant of it?

When we realize the self is empty, all the constituent aspects of the self are empty. Everything we give rise to, every action, every gift, everything received—do we stop eating, bathing, practicing, cleaning our room, feeling pain? When an ordinary person realizes it, they become an enlightened being. When an enlightened being realizes, they become an ordinary person.

All of this is pointing to the basic point. All of these teachings have everything to do with not falling, not ignoring, not falling, not ignoring—have everything to do with the basic point. That's why when we practice and we sit, we don't sit and try to, you know, dig up all of our history. Okay, let's deal with it one by one, so every one of our actions, every one of our memories, every one of our—they line up in a queue. You can't even see the end, right? You got to deal with each one of them. We don't do that. I hope you're not doing that.

You just sit. You wait. And if the mind is receptive, if we're practicing alert and relaxed—because even if our mind, even if we think I am open and receptive, the body can be saying, "No way, baby. It's not coming in." That's why it's not just a matter of comfort and ease in meditation, but it's ease—it's opening doors and windows.

And if we just sit, and with a courage, some courage for whatever, for whenever you might need it, then whatever arises, it arises because this is the time. This is the time when that past action has ripened into this moment. That doesn't mean you will think it is the right moment or that you are ready or that you are ripened for this. But that's just our opinion.

What is the middle way that even to say goes beyond all apparent opposites? See, this is where language just—and it's like, ah, that doesn't, that doesn't, that doesn't, that doesn't. The language is—we got to use it, right? It's what we got. But its whole standard is essentially the standard of dualities. It functions in the world of things. It functions to make things clear between a subject and an object. It functions to define, to describe, to limit, to add certainty, to know.

In working in the Bodhisattva path, there is no book. There are lots of books, but there's no essential book. There's no book for you like you're operating a manual, right? So you won't run into a particular kind of jam—just look in the index, it'll be there. Turn to page 24: In the event that this might happen to you, this is what you do. You're the book. It's being written, which means we have to find our way. We have to take refuge.

Years ago, when I was very active in the prison work, I was in the prison at Green Haven, and we were doing zazenkai, and one of the students told me that somebody had recently stolen his radio. I said, "Okay." And he said, "Well, you know, according to prison law, I have to deal with this." I said, "What does that mean?" He said, "I have to go get it, and then I have to teach this person a lesson." I said, "What does that mean?" He said, "You are not going to do this again, and I'm going to make you suffer so that you don't do it again. And I have to do that for that person also to communicate to everybody, don't mess with me." And I said, "Okay. What about that rakusu hanging around your neck?" And he said, "But if I don't do that, then everyone will think I'm weak." I said, "Are you weak?" And I didn't mean physically—I mean, that was clear, he's not weak—but I said, "Are you weak in your heart?" And he said, "No." He said, "I don't really even care about the radio. I just don't want to become prey."

And I said, "Okay, well, I'm not going to try and tell you what to do. I can't do that, right? You're, in a sense, the expert here. You're the one who's taken vows. But understand that in this path, sometimes you have to stand alone. You have to go a different way and find out. Because if you don't do that, you'll never know if there's another way. We'll just keep doing the same old thing, assuming that is the only truth there is."

Some weeks later, when I was back, I saw him again. And I said, "What happened to that radio?" And he said, "Well, I went to the guy, because he knew he had done it, and the guy was prepared for a fight. And this student said, 'Look, I know you took my radio.' He said, 'I make a gift of it to you. I want you to have it.' And then he walked away." And I said, "What happened next?" And he thought for a minute, he goes, "Nothing." I said, "You told me that if you did that, you would become prey." And he goes, "Yeah." I said, "Why do you think this played out the way it did?" He goes, "I don't know." And I said, "When you went to talk to him, were you afraid?" He said, "No." I said, "Think about that. What were you communicating beyond your words?"

Living 500 happy, blessed lives as a fox. In one moment, an enlightened being does not fall into causation. In the next moment, living 500 years as a fox. Three months left at a job you hate—transform that hatred.

I remember also at Green Haven, many years ago, there were two of the main key members of the sangha, very powerful people. I don't mean they were physically strong, but I mean just powerful as people. They could have done anything in the world if they'd grown up a little bit differently. And they were fighting with each other. And it was a long, simmering, festering feud that was affecting the whole sangha.

And I was there with Daido Roshi. He was, I think, doing a zazenkai, something—he was giving a talk, probably something about atonement or the precepts or something like that. And during the middle of this talk, and one of the sort of rules I was told once while I was there was—in prison, you never show your sweat, which means if you're afraid, if you're nervous, you do not show that. Right? It's sort of a hyper, sort of, you know, idea of masculinity.

And in the middle of this talk, one of the two got up, walked across the zendo—he was shaking, I remember that, he was shaking, there's a big man—and he walked across to the directly standing in front of this other person. And I thought, okay, what's happening? Be ready for anything. And he started doing prostrations. Then he turned around, walked and sat down, and Daido Roshi just watched and then continued. It spoke so completely, and that in that place, at that time, to be so vulnerable, willing to make the first move.

If we want the currents in our life to shift, they will. That's their nature. Then why is it that sometimes things seem so intractable? Because they're strong, because they're deep. Because there are things we don't yet understand. Because we can gain more skillfulness, so that we can develop patience and compassion. So that we can understand ourselves.

As I've mentioned, along with Shugen, who's sitting Dungaryo mana today, have been collecting narratives—really he's been collecting them, interviewing some of the sangha members who were here at the very, very beginning—because I wanted to capture... Doesn't have a title yet, this unpublished work, but I think I said something, some title, and then it's an informal, incomplete narrative of Zen Mountain Monastery. Because I wanted to be clear, this is not definitive. This is just a collection of remembrances. So that—because when I first came here, late '84, early '85, I had no idea what had happened before me. I walked in, it was like, oh, it's this. It's just this, you know, I guess it's always been like that. I didn't know who had come before me. I didn't know what had been going through. I didn't know what. I didn't know anything. I just took it at face value, oh, this is a mountain monastery. And so I figured naturally that's probably what people do. There's nothing wrong with that.

But I thought I want to find a way to convey for all of us, particularly new folks coming in or newer, to have a sense of this living organism. I wanted to read just a little bit, give you a little taste. This is from Yushin, Daido Roshi's wife at the time, who came here—and we should do endless bows to her because she was so important in the beginning. When they first arrived, she said, we got out and walked up the driveway. She held Eshin's hand, their child. As we got closer to the building, my seven-year-old boy broke away and ran around to the left side. She was preoccupied with him, so she couldn't really look at the monastery. Then she grabbed his hand and they went to the front door. It was locked or stuck. They couldn't get in. He tried to get in through one of the windows. She said most of the windows were broken. And she said, no, no, no, don't do that. We can't go in.

So then they came around the east side, and Daido was down there. And they saw the Christ figure. And remember that Daido Roshi grew up Catholic, left the church, and he stood there and he said, "Look at this. What is this place?" She said he looked pale, took a few breaths. There were tears in his eyes. He held onto the blue stone. Can you just imagine that?

The first time they went inside, the next visit, she said they pushed open the massive front door with its ornate, sculpted hinges and stepped inside. Scary. The light bulbs were mostly burned out. The place was filthy. The dining room was a mass of broken tables, benches, chairs. There was a terrible odor, a combination of sewage and sweat. I could hardly step into the kitchen. The last people to use it had left a pile of pots and pans and dishes in the sink. Dried out bubble gum was stuck everywhere. That bubble gum was still here when I came. In fact, it was a series of caretaking tasks to scrape it off under tables, on the benches, on the walls—left behind by many of the decades of young campers.

Then they went upstairs and saw what is now the zendo—had 30 pews along the sides, like that one in the back, that's the one remaining. No altar, just some candles on a table. But Daido saw it as our future zendo for sure.

They moved into what we used to call the parsonage, the former Jizo house, which David, his son—one of his sons who came here—said was so unbelievably disgusting, like he couldn't believe what had happened here to make this place look like this. She said, but there was no heat. They had a little wood stove, I think, she said. There wasn't even electricity, she said. Daido drank camp-style coffee, that's for sure, boiled on the wood stove, smoked cigarettes—yeah, that's for sure—as he wrote out our schedule on a pad of paper: the daily schedule, she said, the same one we follow today, almost 45 years later.

She says zazen was paramount to Daido, and we sat every day and held a short service, even when there were only a few of us in the freezing main hall. There were electric heaters, but the electric heat was so unbelievably expensive that they rarely used them. We wore coats and hats and gloves when we sat down and burned everything we could in the fireplace in the dining hall.

David, Daido Roshi's son, who's about my age, said—I remember he came here and spent about a year here. He was a cook, he did whatever needed to be done, he's a beautiful guy—he said, I remember that first winter, we'd be sitting in the zendo, Yushin would sit with us and then take off to make dinner, be with Eshin. It would just be Daido and me sitting, him and his father. It wasn't unusual that first winter that it would just be the first of us sitting in the zendo.

Daido emphasized the schedule, and we followed it. I don't think I realized at the time how important that was, but the schedule, in a sense, held the place together. Daido's attitude was, "I don't care if there's nobody in the zendo but me. We sit." An action, an intention, sincerity, commitment, perseverance, faith. But these need to be grounded, right? They're not just abstract, kind of floaty, let's-feel-good-about-these-things.

What are they grounded in? They're grounded in the Three Treasures. They're grounded in the teachings. Most importantly, they're grounded in you. In your body and mind, in your living experience. And there's nothing flighty about them. It's like food, they're like air. They're the stuff we rely upon. And they grow. That's the thing—no roots, no branches, no place they can be found. But they do grow, these virtues.

So Daido Roshi, in no small way, did all of that for today. Make no mistake, he was thinking about the future beyond him, when we did not, could not even hear his words. We would just go, mama, when he would be talking about the day when he was no longer here. Like, no, I cannot even think about that. But he was. That's love. That's devotion. That's love for the Dharma, love for the sangha here, the sangha to come.

And so that schedule, those people sitting in this zendo, they did what needed to be done at their time. We do what we need to do in our time. That's what we've been given. That's what we give.

What could be better? Thank you for listening.

To find out more about the Monastery's programs, retreats, and residency, please visit us online at zmm.org.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Title: Fusatsu: Wholesome And Unwholesome Actions
Extracted Text:
Common to virtually all the schools of Buddhism are the ten wholesome and unwholesome actions. In our lineage, the Bodhisattva Precepts—the primary practice of the Bodhisattva Path—are the Paramitas. See how the Bodhisattva cultivates the qualities of a Bodhisattva, refines themselves, and gives of themselves.

In the Prajna Paramita Sutra, the Buddha said that the Bodhisattva, this great being, when they course in the Six Perfections—which means to practice, embody these six perfections—whatever gift they might give, they make this common to all beings and then turn it over to the Supreme Enlightenment. They offer up the merit of that action, of that giving, to Supreme Enlightenment, and all of this without taking anything as a basis, without abiding anywhere, holding on to anything, solidifying anything. Whatever morality they guard, when they coerce in this, they cultivate the Six Perfections with this mindful reflection:

If I do not give gifts, then I'll be reborn in a state of woe, and there will be no maturing of beings that I can be a part of. In other words, I won't be able to mature other beings, be of service, nor will I purify the Buddha field, nor will I gain all-knowledge wisdom.

It occurs to the Bodhisattva: If I don't guard my morality, then there will be a rebirth for me in the three states of woe, and I won't be reborn among people or in an advantageous state. Therefore, I won't be able to be of service to mature other beings, nor will I purify the Buddha field or gain wisdom.

It occurs to them that if I do not develop patience, then my faculties will go to pieces, and I will not course on the path of the Bodhisattva, and I cannot help mature other beings.

It occurs to them: When I become lazy and do not develop the path of a Bodhisattva, do not exert vigor, then how can I fulfill the Buddhadharmas? How can I gain wisdom?

It occurs to them that if I become entangled in my distracted thoughts and cannot train in all of the qualities of concentration, I won't be able to mature other beings, help, be of service, alleviate their suffering. How much less, then, can I gain the knowledge of wisdom?

If I am weak in wisdom and skillful means, then I will not fulfill the perfection of giving. If, rather, I fulfill the perfection of giving or practice through meanness, the perfection of morality; if I try to practice a perfection of morality through immorality, or the perfection of patience through ill will, the perfection of vigor through sloth, the perfection of meditation through distraction, the perfection of wisdom through ignorance, then I will not fulfill these Six Perfections. I will not go forth to wisdom. I will not be able to be ultimately of service to all beings.

So it makes it clear, as the teachings do in the Mahayana, in a hundred thousand different ways, that to liberate the self is to liberate others. Our training is to help us develop; it is also to help us be of service. And so an essential part of that is understanding the nature of causation.

A greatly cultivated person does not ignore causation. They are not dark to the workings of karma. They are not confused by actions and their consequences. They do not ignore the conditions of their actions, their intentions, the results, the impacts. A person in practice does not indulge in apathy, complacency, laziness, numbness, particularly in relationship to causation, to live a Dharma life. And it can seem like a very strenuous life because the currents of our habits are strong.

So it takes, for a while, a particular amount of diligence, vigilance, even conscientiousness, resilience, stamina, perseverance, sincerity. And there's much in the teachings that emphasizes our own practice, right? Our own individual, personal effort—those qualities that we're cultivating, those attachments that we have, the struggles that we encounter, how we can practice those, encounter those struggles. Because, of course, that's essential.

But the teachings also acknowledge that there are many ways to be born into this world. There are many ways to move through a lifetime. And those things matter too: the time in which you were born, the place, country, the neighborhood, the family, the government, the wealth or poverty the parents were born to. Is it a time of peace or war? Is it a time of compassion or meanness? Is it a time of freedom or oppression? These things also matter.

Buddhism speaks about this in terms of favorable and unfavorable conditions. It recognizes that it's not just a matter of individual effort and individual practice. So it speaks of how there are unfavorable conditions that we can be born into. We can think of this, in one sense, in terms of rebirth and different realms of existence, which is how it's presented: being born into a hell realm, being born into the realm of a hungry ghost. You can think of that quite literally, but we can also think of it as it is and always has been, in terms of the realms that we create on a day-to-day basis—the tendencies that we have to create certain kinds of worlds within ourselves and around us.

And yet, even though they're considered unfavorable, and some of them are more decisive in terms of their impact, most of them are unfavorable but subject to change. To be born in a hell realm, which is characterized by a life, a world, a time, an inner state of endless conflict, of disruption, of fighting, of anger, of hatred, retribution, pain and suffering. And in this hell realm, it's not just that this comes and goes, but it's sort of the dominant flavor, it's the overarching and underwriting quality of that life. It's the landscape, it's what occupies that person's thoughts, their concerns, their needs. It's the dominant view.

To be born as a hungry ghost, to be born in a lifetime, or in one moment, or in a period of our life, driven by insatiable desire, an unquenchable thirst. This is a place where we can never be satisfied. But there is endless pursuit nonetheless—searching, wanting, plotting, but never being able to satisfy. It could also be a place where desires are easily, endlessly satisfied: the store is always open, shelves are always full, you always have enough to get something, there's always something you want to get. And the belief in an end to this, any ultimate satisfaction, any true happiness, is faded. For the hungry ghost, it's no longer about that. It's just about shopping, searching, seeking, wanting. Here there is only the day to day, moment to moment wanting, hunger, thirst.

To be born as an animal—let's understand this as a metaphor, let's leave the animals alone. In Buddhism, to be born in the animal realm is a world, a life governed by rules, routines, impulses, instinct. In the sense of an instinctual drive, it's a drive that you don't really have much of a choice about. You know, the Canadian goose doesn't think, "I'm not going south this year, I'm done with that." In this world, the demands of those rules and routines leave no room for examination or questioning. They just are to be followed. And so each day is a movement through that world of routines, through that world. In a sense, it's a kind of dogmatic life, a kind of tyrannical life that's really just moving from one fear to another, one forestalling of exposure or failure. The rewards are few; punishments, the threat of punishment, is ever-present.

Remember, these are unfavorable conditions, not conducive, because in each of these realms, the landscape, the life in that realm, is so consuming, it's so demanding, it requires so much of our attention just to live there, to make it, that there's just not really much room for anything else, any other consideration, any other possibility.

To be born among the gods: here you're far removed from the noise and the pain and the hunger. It all seems good all the time. There's no adversity, no real problems, no growth, no need to grow. Everything's good. No need to reflect. What would you reflect on? You get everything you want, everything has been gained, everything is being provided, nothing is lacking. So it's a world of abundant richness that never goes beneath the surface. It's just a world of riches. Here there's no empathy, there's no need for empathy, there's no concern, no need for concern. Everyone around you is in the same situation. You don't need anything, they don't need anything, you don't really need anyone—a rich and superficial life where one takes all they can get and doesn't really need to give anything back.

And then there's being born among those with pervasive false views, in a world where everything runs like normal according to a very particular and pervasive view. Here everything is clear and true and certain. It's a life of convictions, unexamined confidences that are actually laced with anxiety, strong opinions and beliefs. The important matters are already understood. What is not yet understood either doesn't need to be, or will be. Patience is a weakness. Questioning is disloyalty. A world of walls and boundaries where there is a truth that is known, and those who do not know those truths are enemies.

And so, again, in each of these realms, we can imagine, or maybe we've been, visited some of these, and how inclusive it becomes and exclusive at the same time. So these are all subject to change. They can change because there is no absolute, absolute. There is no world that is absolutely defined by any of these qualities. There is no person that is defined by any of these qualities. So they're always subject, open to the possibility of change. Even in the darkest night, the slightest bit of light offers a surprising amount of illumination.

To be born where no Buddha has appeared in the world—this is more problematic. Here your mind stirs, you give rise to a sense of dukkha. You don't know that word, but you know something, you feel it, you're experiencing it, you're wondering about it, you're questioning it. There's a healthy dissatisfaction that is born. There's a seeking mind that begins to come into presence. There must be another path. There is a calling, but no one answers. There is seeking, but there's no path. There's wanting guidance, but there's no teacher.

And then there's also being born without a sufficient mental or physical capacity, we might even say psychological capacity, to hear, to learn, to actually be able to practice the Dharma. The Dharma practice is not about physical prowess or high intelligence, but it is very much a body-mind practice. And so it does require a certain degree of sufficiency, of ability within the body, within the mind, to hear the Dharma, to understand the teachings, to be able to reflect, to take a posture of meditation.

Most of us have encountered these realms—people living in these realms, maybe close up, maybe far away, maybe some of us have been such a person at different times. All of us have, you know, at least driven through these realms, gotten out, had a meal there, bought some clothing, tried them on, tasted a bit. When they're entrenched and ongoing, then the conditions for encountering Buddhadharma become more and more slight. Right? That's what it's basically saying. It's like, I mean, if you could separate the person from the realm—which, of course, you can't, because karmically the person, in one way of understanding, the person has created this realm for themselves. Another way of understanding is sometimes people are born into or thrust into a realm not of their choosing, not because of their actions, but in them. The possibility of practicing becomes harder and harder.

When those realms are occasional, then they can actually be strong, in a sense, negative examples of how not to live. I remember when I was young, I started working when I was young and then worked all the way through the latter part of grade school and then through high school. And, you know, I was a kid, so I had kids' jobs. So if I was in a restaurant, I worked in a laundromat, I was always in the back room, you know, I was never in the front. I mean, who's going to put a kid in the front? So I was in the back, but with adults. And these were adults from all walks of life, all kinds of socioeconomic backgrounds and realities, living in different worlds, worlds different than mine. And it was an incredible education. I met people that I, you know, didn't come across in my neighborhood, didn't go to school with, got to know some of them, heard some of their stories. And it was really the first time where I began thinking about, what is this life like? What is this like? It seems difficult.

But then, of course, there are favorable conditions, right? That's what you've been waiting for, right? To be born as a human being. Being born as a human being is considered most favorable because we live long enough to experience adversity and suffering, right? And to raise bodhicitta. But we don't live so long that we can put it off forever. And so we have this sufficient amount of time, if we're fortunate, right? If we live long enough to have enough life experiences that we realize, okay, this is not going the way I wanted, hoped, thought, can raise bodhicitta, can seek, but we have to. But everything is impermanent. So we have to, like, respond, answer the call.

We need to be born in a place where the Dharma is actually present, it's alive. To have been born at a time when a Buddha was born and taught and those teachings are still available. We need to have sufficient faculties in our body and mind, again, so that we can hear, sit, study, reflect. We need to have lived a sufficiently positive life, healthy life, a sufficiently decent life—decent in the sense of not creating so much trouble—that our karma has been fortuitous enough, fortunate enough, positive enough, that we have found our way to the Dharma.

But again, none of these are absolutes. And I've met people who, by their own admission, had never committed one unselfish act in their life. I'm thinking of particularly people I got to know when I was doing a lot of prison work. I remember one, in dokusan, one student, telling me this. And I knew him, and he was quite a wonderful person, I thought. And he came and he confessed that. I said, "Come on." He said, "No, I'm telling you, I've never done anything in my life that was not about me. It was not putting me first." I've heard from people who said that they were in a hell realm in which there was no escape. And then a shard of light passed through, and they began to think and wonder and question.

But generally speaking, to have lived a good enough life that we are creating positive karma—not only to be able to find a way to the Dharma, but so that when we encounter the Dharma, the burdens that we all carry from our past karma and the lives we've lived are not so heavy, so intractable, that we can't engage a sufficient amount of faith and trust and confidence to be able to trust the teachings when we encounter them. Right? If we don't have a sufficient amount of trust in the teachings, we can't hear them—they're not teachings for us—to be able to trust our teacher, our teachers from whom we hear the Dharma. Again, if we don't trust them, then why would we listen to them? Why would we take to heart what they say?

We need to have enough faith, right? 1% to start. Enough so that when we encounter the Dharma, we don't just turn around and walk away. We stay. We linger. We listen. Maybe we stay a little bit longer. Maybe we take a step forward. So, for the professional cynic or skeptic or doomsdayer, practice is going to be very, very tough. The doors seem to be closed, right?

And so, again, some of these things we can't change. We can't—if we've been born in a time when there's no Buddha, there's not much we can do about that, unless you are that person. We can encounter other things, of course. We can't encounter Bodhidharma. So, no unfavorable condition needs to be completely absent, and no favorable condition needs to be completely present. That's good news, right? So it puts us pretty squarely in a good place. This is a good news talk, if you didn't get that.

Shantideva, in his book, in his teaching on the Bodhisattva, says, "I join my hands and pray to Buddhas who reside in every quarter.
