Kindle now the Dharma's light for those who grow bewildered in the dark of suffering." So there's asking, a beseeching: please, I know you're here, right? Kindle the Dharma light, right? What if the Buddha, after his enlightenment and the reflection after some days over what he had experienced, and then his discernment—should I teach? People are too cherishing of their habits, their attachments, their views. It's just not going to go well. And then the gods or some powerful person or some wandering person, somebody came and appealed to him and said, "No, no, there are people who will hear this. There are people who are waiting to hear this." And what if the Buddha said, "I don't think so," and we never heard. And that was it. We're not here right now.

And so Shantideva is calling to that Buddha: "I beseech the enlightened ones who wish to pass beyond the bonds of suffering—do not leave us in our ignorance, but stay among us for unnumbered ages." Don't leave. Stay.

I was thinking about how in the very early years, when things were tough, finances particularly, and sometimes every once in a while, Daido would—if he felt like, I think we were being too, I don't know, not doing enough to make this place work and generate some income and programs and so on—he would say, quite seriously, "I think maybe I should just go get a job driving a truck and earn some money." And we were like, "Please don't do that."

To live in a time when a Buddha has appeared, to live in a time when a Buddha has taught, to live in a time when the teachings are still present and can be heard, to be able to encounter the practice and do the practice, to find a teacher, a sangha—we can take these things completely for granted. And the teachings are very clear: we should not, but rather actually appreciate how fortunate we are, right? Particularly in our culture, we've sort of had this ingrained presumption, these expectations of everything that we are deserving of, that we should have, and think everything we should not have—we shouldn't have suffering, we shouldn't have adversity, right? Things should be easy. I should be able to get what I want. It shouldn't cost too much. That's a pretty modern delusion.

And the teachings are very clear about this, both in helping us to not fall into that kind of complacency, but also to appreciate our good fortune, how fortunate we are. You know, we can spend, particularly during sesshin, we can spend a lot of time focusing on what is lacking—not enough mindfulness, not enough concentration, not enough energy, not enough whatever. And if we can just pause for a moment and realize, okay, that's just practice, that's not new. There's nothing unique about that. It feels unique to us. It can feel especially special, right? Our distraction, our entanglements, our struggles. And that's not to diminish or belittle the effect that they have on us. They hurt. But to step back a little bit and say, yes, and is there anyone who has not transgressed? Is there anyone who has not struggled? Is there anyone who's meditated and has not experienced this?

The liturgy, the teachings, every service we do, every meal we take is pointing not just to the teachings and to the practice of that particular moment, but our good fortune. The liturgy is constantly pointing to our good fortune, the fact that we can just simply do a service, that we can chant a sutra. "Oh, yeah, the Heart Sutra. Yeah. Have you read it? Yeah, I've read it. What else have you read?" That's why the teaching or the comment that some people, when they read the Heart Sutra, they have a heart attack. Why would they have a heart attack? Because they take it seriously. And they realize, oh my god, is this possible?

You have the good fortune to be sitting on this cushion, as do I, in the posture of a Buddha, to meet your mind. I remember years ago, we did a retreat on ethics in business, medicine or science, and one other thing—I don't remember. And for business, we had a silent partner from Ben & Jerry's, before it got bought out, when they were really about doing social service, social action. And he was talking about some of the plans they'd had. They were going to have an adopt-a-subway thing, you know, like adopt-a-highway, but in New York City. Adopt a subway, but the unions just shut that right down. But one of the thoughts they had was, like, at these G8, G20 meetings with all the world leaders who are going to get together and decide things about us, that before they could start their meetings, they all had to have an ice cream cone. And it had to be in a cone, not a cup. Because when you eat an ice cream cone, what happens? Starts to melt, drips over your fingers. He said, "You become a child. You become a child. You remember what it's like to be a child." Everybody's sitting around the table, licking their fingers. "Okay, now let's talk about what's going on." Even better, after they've had their ice cream—to meet their mind, their mind, their biased mind, their unexamined mind, to meet the minds of others, to begin to examine karma, to take responsibility for past actions and the actions that are happening right now in this zendo, at that table, and to realize we can set those free. We can open our hearts beyond what we can even imagine, towards those that we cannot even imagine opening our hearts to, and that we can be of benefit in the world.

That's what the Buddha was saying in the sutra: When we practice, we make ourselves serviceable—our minds, our bodies, our emotions, our actions. This is how we express our gratitude. That's why it's so important that we have received these practices that have come down to us, that in every generation, in some generation, everybody got together and said, "You know, Fusatsu, we don't really need that anymore." That didn't happen. "Zazen, you know, it's just hard. People don't really like it. We'd get many more people if we didn't do zazen." And that we can do these practices and be changed by them. And what makes that possible to the greatest degree is when you do them with your whole body and mind, all throughout.

That's why it's so important to not become dull or dead to these practices that we do again and again. To continue alive in your mind, to continue, to start again, to continue. And none of us do that every time. None of us do, right? We are creatures of habit. And so these practices become habits. Don't let that run away.

When I'm officiating a service and I realize that I have gotten lost, I feel bad. I do. For that moment. I don't, you know, put a hair shirt on, but I feel bad. Not only did I miss something, but I missed something, right? So I'm not suggesting you feel bad, but that we take it seriously. Shugen talked yesterday about sincerity. That's what makes us work it.

Thanks so much for listening.

For meditation supplies such as cushions, incense, liturgical instruments, Dharma books and more, visit monasterystore.org—support for your spiritual practice at home.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Title: Sincerity In Practice
Extracted Text:
Good morning. Good afternoon. Really, good afternoon.

All right. So what is the work of this moment? We could say it's to look deeply underneath the appearance of things. We could say that what we find comes in glimmers that clarify over time. We could say that our experience, our understanding of the Dharma, happens gradually by virtue of training. We say that the great matter is beyond words, that it's outside the scriptures, and yet it does get talked about in various ways. We have to hush the baby's cry.

So we might say the way is perfect, like vast space. We might say the entire phenomenal world is the magical display of the deity. We might speak of Tathagata, the realm of reality, the Dharma body, Nirvana, the deathless, the unborn mind, the world, Vairocana Buddha.

Master Kazan in Zazen Yojinki, an essay on the practice of Zazen, wrote:
What is this? Its name is unknown. It cannot be called body. It cannot be called mind. Trying to think of it, the thought vanishes. Trying to speak of it, words die. It is like a fool, an idiot. It is as high as a mountain, deep as the ocean, without peak or depths. Its brilliance is unthinkable. It shows itself silently between sky and earth. Only this whole body is seen.

Dogen said to take up a leaf and transform it into the sixteen-foot golden body of the Buddha, to take up the sixteen-foot golden body of the Buddha and turn it into a lettuce leaf.

I have explored now and again a little bit, just a little bit, of Vajrayana meditation practice. And one thing that I've only explored the tiniest bit is this notion of deity practice, where you work with and cultivate an image of the deity and relate to that within your meditation, and bring that deity into your own being, becoming that deity. And I've explored it not as a Vajrayana practitioner would, but as a student of mind and meditation might. And I think it's very interesting from that perspective that there's an approach of starting with the deity and bringing it in, and then seeing the entire phenomenal world as the display of the deity.

And then the Zen approach, which is to start with the phenomenal world—with the lettuce leaf, with the shovel full of gravel, with the shit stick—and to go in that route and discover the entire phenomenal world is no other than the world-honored one. And by "entire phenomenal world," don't mistake who I'm talking about.

In the Pabhassara Sutta, Buddha said:
Luminous, monks, is the mind, and it is defiled by incoming defilements. The uninstructed, run-of-the-mill person doesn't discern that as it actually is present, which is why I tell you that for the uninstructed, run-of-the-mill person, there is no development of the mind. Luminous, monks, is the mind, and it is freed from incoming defilements. The well-instructed disciple of the noble ones discerns that as it actually is present, discerns that as it actually is present, which is why I tell you that for the well-instructed disciple of the noble ones, there is development of the mind.

The well-instructed disciples of the noble ones—how did we get to be so lucky? I don't know. For the well-instructed disciples of the noble ones, there is development of the mind. And as a friend of mine in the Dharma has said on several occasions, we go in the direction we're pointed. So, beyond words and letters, outside the scriptures, and yet there is pointing, and we do turn ourselves and head this development of mind.

We speak about the threefold training of sila, samadhi, and prajna, so commonly thought of as morality (sila), samadhi as meditative concentration, prajna as wisdom. And the Buddha's Eightfold Path can be looked at through this lens of the threefold training. So, with sila, the moral conduct, you have right speech, right action, right livelihood. With samadhi or concentration, that's right effort, right mindfulness, right concentration. And then prajna or wisdom is right view and also right intention or right resolve.

And what I wanted to do is look at the threefold training as some energetic pointers that might be beneficial for us as we continue to deepen into sesshin, more like a flavor or an energy or attitude we could cultivate or call forward, or if we're getting lost or, I don't know, stuck, we might find use for sila.

I was thinking about, what is the energy of sila, the teaching on purification of the mind, ceasing from harm, practicing good, actualizing good for others, the three pure precepts that sort of hold the whole thing. And I thought, you know, sincerity. Sincerity. Caring. The energy of caring. The Latin root of the word sincerity means clean and pure. I was so pleased to look that up and find that—caring, sincerity.

I feel like sincerity and commitment are like two of the beautiful human qualities on which the monastery is built, on which it runs. It's like you kind of have to have sincerity to train. Everybody's sincerity can look different. It doesn't have to show up in a particular way. But I'm guessing that for each of us, it's present—caring, caring, caring about practice, caring about our life, caring about the great matter, the world, living beings. It's the quality in our own heart that wants to know, wants to understand.

I remember once, years ago, in an open sozan, Shoka was the head server—for those of you who know Shoka. And he spoke about how he felt so grateful to have the opportunity to be head server, and that a position like that—and I think he was speaking very personally, but in a sense also more broadly—gives you permission to care. And that really struck me. It stayed with me all these years because sometimes in our culture it seems like, I don't know, the encouragement is to not really give a shit. But isn't caring incredible? Caring about how you do a thing, or caring about a person, caring about a sangha or a monastery? That sincerity.

That sincerity is one way that we can respond to the wounds of the world, isn't it? Like, we can let the wounds of the world, the wounds the world brings to us, or the wounds that we witness in the world—of course, ultimately, where can you draw the line?—we can let them harden, we can let them encourage a strong sort of defense, or we can let them help us care. It's more painful to care. Maybe not, though, right? It seems that way, but there's something else there—the possibility of joy, the reality of love.

What else do you want in your life than love? Aren't you willing to hurt some for the sake of love?

In the precepts retreat that I had the honor and pleasure of co-leading with Shugen Roshi a couple weeks ago, we were talking about, like, when do you know if you are aligned with good? Or like, when do you know that, when your moral alignment is true? Which is a great question to consider. And people had some thoughtful responses. And a common theme that emerged was, like, it's a feeling. It's a feeling. It's kind of one of those things that, like, we can put some words there and we can put some labels there, but what we're talking about is like a heart feeling.

We know when we've done something harmful. God, don't you just feel it when you've hurt somebody? And, you know, we can feel it when we atone, when we repair, when harmony is restored. Isn't this interesting that it's a feeling? Hmm. Does that make you wonder? The livingness of things. We feel it. The livingness of things, the living world, the live world, the phenomenal world as the sixteen-foot golden body of the Buddha.

I've told this story before, but it's a good one, and I know there's some newer folks, so I'm going to tell it again. Many years ago, when I was in my first year of residency and I was in the kitchen, I was the cook with Emmy Stanley—for you old timers who remember Emmy—we were in the kitchen, and one afternoon, one summer afternoon, one of the residents, who was having a rough time and who had a volatile character, just generally speaking, was really upset about something, I don't know what, and he stormed into the kitchen and was speaking loudly, sort of yelling around, and he opened the refrigerator door and slammed it, and then he kicked the refrigerator, and then he stormed out of the kitchen.

And, you know, it's the monastery—like, that does not happen all the time. So Emmy and I were both, like, a little rattled and, like, shaken up. And I don't know that we waited too long before we went to check in with the Tenzo, who at that time was Shugen Roshi in the adjoining office. And we went in and we're, like, trying to sort of, like, report what happened. And Shugen took a breath and he was like, "He shouldn't do that. The refrigerator is a sentient being."

That's not what I expected. That's not what I expected. And I took it in, and I think we probably talked some more. I don't remember anything else of that conversation about what to do and da, da, da, da, da. And anyway, the initial activation felt calmed, discharged. And, like, Emmy and I went back into the kitchen to finish making supper.

And later I was thinking about this, and I had to know, what does this mean? And I went back to Shugen and I asked, "What did you mean by that, that the refrigerator's a sentient being?" And he said, "You know that rock that you and Emmy like to go and sit on in the river?" We used to go during our breaks down to the river. And I said, "Yeah." And he said, "Well, how would you feel if one day you went there and it was covered with graffiti and someone had left trash all over it?" Okay, you with me? That was the answer.

A living world. A living world. And sometimes it does feel like our dominant American culture is behaving like it's a dead world. So that's painful. If you care, that is painful. A little sincerity, a lot of sincerity—practice seems to, I think, nurture sincerity.

There's a story of how a student asked Yasutani Roshi, "You know, Roshi, you speak about how important sincerity is for practice. How much sincerity does a person need? You know, is it like 75%, is that enough sincerity? Or is, like, 85%, 90%—like, how much sincerity is enough?" And Yasutani Roshi said, "I think 1%. 1% sincerity is enough."

At the end of oryoki, we chant, "May we exist in muddy water with purity, like a lotus." So how do we do that?

Samadhi. If sila is the energy of sincerity or caring, samadhi is the energy of steady presence, attention, steady. And this quality of steady attention mixes so potently with sincerity. Things can really happen. I think a lot about the simplicity of the Zen instruction and the simplicity of the form and the emphasis of the form—like, that's a big part of how we train. And people will encounter that, and I think from the beginner's sort of standpoint, it can seem austere, it can seem heavy-handed, it can seem like, wow, there's a really big emphasis on discipline. Like, what about the other important qualities, right? And it can take a while before we start to see, like, what is being offered in all that form. Do it this way, not like this. It's like you have to stick around. You have to stick around.

And so I think it is really good—I feel like over the years we, meaning the training staff, have been learning how to be skillful, more skillful, I hope, in terms of offering the form and holding the discipline. But I guess what I want to say is, like, those instructions—trust them. That's where the sincerity can really help and commingle.

I was thinking again—this is like another memory from long ago, wandering down memory lane—I remember I was like, it was probably sesshin during my first year of residence and my mind was super scattered. And I think that, like, people should appreciate, first of all, just, like, how hard the cooks work and how cooking for sesshin is its own unique practice because you don't really get to sort of finish caretaking, wrap it up and forget about it until tomorrow. There's meal after meal and the cooks are doing things in between. And I remember being in that position and really finding it hard to settle my mind. And again, talking to Shugen and he said—I was, oh, it was oryoki. I guess maybe oryoki was really bringing up my fixations because I'd been, like, part of preparing the meal or something. But I was really, like, going to town in oryoki. I couldn't focus. And he was like, "Well, one thing that could help is to just really pay attention to where your hands are." And at the time I thought, like, that is such a weird instruction. Like, what does that even mean? You know? And, like, he was like, "Because, you know, you're always doing things with your hands in oryoki." And from the vantage point in which I was, I just thought, like, I don't really get it. Like, what does that have to do with, you know, seeing my true nature?

But sincerity—I tried to take it up and I could see, okay, there's a calming effect. I needed to know where to rest my attention, right? Samadhi, that continuity of presence has to have a clarity about what we're being present to. That's part of its skillfulness. So when you have a practice, you know, sometimes the monitors will say, like, "Remember what your practice is." And we might be sitting there and being like, "Oh, yeah, right. Whoops." We have to—our mind needs to know, like, okay, my practice is the breath, or my practice is shikantaza, or my practice is mu. And then that's what we're returning to. And that helps that really active mind, that distracted mind, calm.

And so when we're given the forms of sesshin, where everything is really stripped down and we're given this instruction to, like, be present with what is, that is potent instruction. To the degree that you're able to engage it, I hope that you have discovered just how potent it is.

Master Hongren, who's the fifth ancestor of Zen, Chinese ancestor, says:
There is an indestructible Buddha nature in the bodies of living beings. Like the orb of the sun, its body luminous, round and full, vast and boundless. The pure mind of all living beings is like this, merely covered up by the dark clouds of obsession with objects, arbitrary thoughts, psychological afflictions and views and opinions. If you can just keep the mind still so that errant thought does not arise, the reality of Nirvana will naturally appear. This is how we know the inherent mind is originally pure.

And I would say, you know, having worked a lot over the years with instructions on keeping the mind still and not letting a thought arise, that I have found it to be more beneficial and more skillful to understand that you're just practicing a very, very discerning awareness that gets more and more refined, and thoughts may cease to arise, but it doesn't really matter as long as you're recognizing what the mind is doing and recognizing that brightly. Right? So there's a difference between getting carried away by a thought and having it lead and sort of spin and create a whole world, and recognizing a thought as it arises and seeing that just within that recognition itself, there's the possibility—and in a sense, really, if we're practicing, the inevitability—that then that thought will dissolve. And we can see and feel the mind doesn't necessarily want it to dissolve. The mind will pursue sometimes.

So this is where that steady presence, that quality, that energetic quality of samadhi is so important. You can also think in terms of, like, there's the sense of, like, okay, well, I'm going to take my attention and put it on the breath and, like, keep it there. And there's also, like, I'm going to take my attention and put it on the breath and keep it there, but really my practice is going to be each time that I wander off, seeing that and coming back. It's a slightly different emphasis, but I found it helpful. It's, you know, so that the practice is then like, "Oh, right. Not that—this." You can see if it's helpful for you.

Also, I think helpful to notice that the continuity of attention, that kind of presence, is sensitive. Right? If we're going to be able to see the flickering of thought movement, we need to be sensitive, which means we need to be a certain kind of relaxed, a certain kind of receptive, this luminous mind that's aware and awake. It doesn't have to be treated like a, I don't know, you know, like a sealed container—let's keep everything out. It doesn't have to be like that, as long as you're awake. And that quality of sincerity, again, that can bring forward a nice underlying energy as we're cultivating samadhi. That we care. That we care and that we care deeply enough when the thoughts come and they start going. And we love our thoughts. We love our thoughts, right? It's so interesting. It's not actually, but, like, we think it's so interesting. That's the nature of our sort of karmic mind. It seems so engaging. And so it's helpful, I think, to have that deeper caring to remind us, like, okay, no, this is not the time for that.

So, prajna—wisdom. The energy of prajna: allowing space. This runs so counter to how our mind typically engages with things—very dense and kind of claustrophobic. And if we're looking at our mind, we see, oh, so much activity and so much grasping and so many projections and so many shadows. And I think I came across this teaching by Andy Carr in a book called "Contemplating Reality." And it's a good book. And he has this section where he's talking about how our mind—basically, how projection sort of works. I don't want to get too into it, it's a little dense. Let me see if I can just pull out the juicy bits for the moment.

I mean, basically, he says, like, okay, so he's defining some terms to make a larger point. But he talks about, like, okay, so if you think now about the tall buildings in New York City, an image of those tall buildings will appear in your mind. But this is a generalized—the term he's defining is generally characterized phenomena. So for our purposes, just to note that, like, okay, yeah, we can call, we can sort of call those tall buildings in the city to mind. We do this all the time, right? You can call your mother to mind or your childhood pet, and something will come to mind. Amazing, totally magical. And it's just your thought projection, right? Like, it's not actually those tall buildings. It's not actually your mother, it's not actually your childhood pet. It's your sort of, like, thought, feeling, image, memory, like, gestalt-ish thing. And he calls it—this would be the generally characterized phenomena, which is a referent for the—sorry, specifically characterized phenomena.

But we get confused all the time. And we think that that, like, gestalt-ish, feeling, image, mental formation of a person, a place, or a thing is the thing. It's totally not the thing. And then we spend our lives in this world of all of these generally characterized phenomena, thinking that they're actual. And we are. Andy Carr says, "Here is the basic point: We spend a great deal of time thinking about things, but that thinking is mistaken."

So what happens when it's not the generally characterized phenomena? What happens when we actually encounter a thing as it is?

Master Mazu: The mind can be spoken of in terms of its two: birth and death—ordinary, sort of conventional, I should say—and suchness. Mind as suchness is like a clear mirror which can reflect images. The mirror symbolizes the mind, the images symbolize the dharmas. If the mind grasps at dharmas, then it gets involved in external causes and conditions, which is the meaning of birth and death. If the mind does not grasp at dharmas, that is suchness.

Okay, bringing forth that quality of steady presence and allowing some space, not grasping, then the sacred living world can fully bloom. The Dharma of thusness has been intimately conveyed by Buddhas and ancestors. This is the wisdom teaching.

I've noticed lately that if I am speaking to myself, I can call myself "beloved." And it helps. "Beloved, it's okay. I'm sure you're gonna pull your talk together just fine." You could try that too. "Beloved, hang in there."

Master Hongzhi says: Contact phenomena with total sincerity. Not a single atom of dust outside yourself.

I like that one. It feels like it hits all the notes. Contact phenomena—that's your samadhi presence. Steady contact—with total sincerity, that's your sila. Not a single atom of dust outside yourself, that's your prajna. And on the way to prajna, we have so many glimmers: wonder, curiosity, tenderness, ease. We need all of this so much. It will serve us so well. It will serve the world. We need this connection to the deep truth, the sacred life.

I've been feeling buoyed, grateful, inspired by some words that Van Jones offered—the political analyst, green jobs advisor in the Obama administration. He said, "Then there is this particular kind of theology that is native to the black church, what I call 'Hallelujah Anyhow theology.' Shit's going wrong. Things are crazy. It's bad. Mmm, that blue sky. Oh, those robins." I talked to a friend recently, said, "How are you dealing with all of this?" She said, "I am defiant. They can't have my mind. Hallelujah anyhow."

I'll end with the poem by Joy Harjo:

Praise the rain.
Praise the rain, the seagull dive, the curl of plant, the raven talk.
Praise the hurt, the house slack, the stand of trees, the dignity.
Praise the dark, the moon cradle, the sky fall, the bear asleep.
Praise the mist, the warrior name, the earth eclipse, the fired leap.
Praise the backwards, upward sky, the baby cry, the spirit food.
Praise canoe, the fish rush, the hole for frog, the upside down.
Praise the day, the cloud cup, the mind flat, forget it all.
Praise crazy. Praise sad. Praise the path on which we're led.
Praise the roads on earth and water.
Praise the eater and the eaten.
Praise beginnings. Praise the end.
Praise the song. Praise the singer.
Praise the rain. It brings more rain.
Praise the rain, it brings more rain.

And Rumi:
We are the mirror as well as the face in it.
We are tasting the taste this minute.
We are pain and what cures pain, both.
We are the sweet cold water and the jug that pours.

Let's use this ripe, rich time in sesshin. May it be for the benefit of all beings through space and time.

Thanks so much for listening.

For meditation supplies such as cushions, incense, liturgical instruments, Dharma books and more, visit monasterystore.org—support for your spiritual practice at home.
Speaker: Danica Shoan Ankele

Title: 500 Blessed Lives
Extracted Text:
This transcript was generated by an AI and may contain errors, but I have corrected spelling, names, and Buddhist terms for clarity. The text is broken into paragraphs for readability based on ideas and natural pauses in the discourse.

---

The following Dharma discourse was given by Jeffrey Shugen Arnold at Zen Mountain Monastery. Shugen Roshi is the head of the Mountains and Rivers Order and abbot of the monastery. This talk, like all of our talks, is offered free of charge. If you would like to make a donation or find out more about our various programs, visit us online at zmm.org. Thank you for listening.

This is from the Book of Serenity, Baizhang's Fox Pointer:

If you keep so much as the letter A in your mind, you go to hell. Like an arrow shot—one drop of wild fox slobber, when swallowed, cannot be spit out for 30 years. It's not that the order is strict in India; it's just that the ignoramus' karma is heavy. Has there ever been anyone who mistakenly transgressed?

**Main Case**

When Master Baizhang lectured in the hall, there was always an old priest who listened to the teaching and then dispersed with the crowd. One day, they didn't leave. Baizhang asked them, "Who is this standing here before me?" 

The old priest said, "In ancient times, in the time of the ancient Buddha Kashyapa, I lived on this mountain. As a former abbot, a student once asked, 'Does a greatly cultivated person still fall into cause and effect, or not?' I answered them, 'They do not fall into cause and effect.' And I fell into a wild fox body for 500 lives. Now I ask the teacher to turn a word in my behalf."

Master Baizhang said, "The greatly cultivated person is not blind to cause and effect." At this, the old priest was greatly enlightened.

**The Verse**

A foot of water, a fathom of wave.  
For 500 years, 500 lives couldn't do a thing.  
Not falling, not blind.  
They haggle as before entering a nest of complications. Aha.  
Understand—if you are clear and free, there is no objection to my babble.  
The spirit songs and shrine dances spontaneously form a harmony,  
Clapping in the intervals, singing lila—who doesn't love a good story?

This koan is also in the Mumonkan. The second case, and the way we do it, is that the student, after working with Mu in the miscellaneous koans, goes to the Mumonkan and skips this koan, does all the rest in the collection, and then at the very end comes back to this. Because it's important, and it's not so easy. It's dealt with in the Mumonkan, as is characteristic of the Gateless Gate, kind of bluntly. Here there's a little bit more eloquence.

So, "If you keep so much as the letter A in your mind, you'll go to hell like an arrow shot." So on this path of non-attachment, keep even the letter A. How do we shift? How do we shift? Another way of asking that is: What do each of us preserve? What are the things that we want to let go of, are eager to let go of? What are the things we don't want to—things still cherished, the things we still believe in, that we believe, if only, that they will give, that they will last, they will take away?

I think non-attachment—or attachments—is one of those really key aspects of Buddhism which is so easy to misunderstand, what it actually is. Think of it as denying, of losing, of extinguishing. "It's not that the order is strict in India. It's just that the deluded ones' karma is heavy." Karma is heavy, which means what we carry is heavy. It's binding. It's like a drag, it's like a cloud. It can seem to carry us, to drag us along. It can almost certainly seem to be oneself. 

We can carry it without knowing. We can carry it because we think we deserve to, it's our punishment. We can carry it because we can misunderstand letting go to mean forgetting, or somehow being irresponsible or not caring. And in carrying it for more than a moment—let alone year after year—it is our sense of self. Not in full, but it is something we identify with. And in that way, to not carry it, to shift, is not only unfamiliar, it can be frightening. Like, actually frightening. Not poetically, metaphorically, but actually frightening enough that we go back and pick that burden up again. If we do not carry it, then who am I then?

And so the effects of the karmic actions we carry—what we've created, what we've experienced from others and have integrated, acted upon, created our own karma as a result of—for many of us, is what brings us to the Dharma, right? Nobody comes to practice because you're having too good a time in this life. Everything is going so perfectly, getting everything you want.

Has there ever been anyone who mistakenly transgressed? Has there ever been anyone who has not transgressed? Are there things you regret? I'm going to guess the answer to that is yes.

So what do we do about all that? It's a really essential question if we are trying to not only lighten our burden and not accumulate—because burdens do accumulate, they don't stay neat and tucked. They don't weigh in at one weight and keep that weight through the course of our life. They gain weight. So how do we free ourselves? If you keep so much as the letter A in your mind, it's easy to say, well, just let it go. And that's really good instruction. And it's true, and it's exactly what we need to be doing. But if that's so, then why aren't we all immediately free as soon as we get that instruction?

And so in this koan, there's more to it. In the Mumonkan, after the priest is enlightened, they ask Baizhang to do the favor and say, "There's a fox's body in a cave on the mountain. Would you please bury it with full ceremony?" So Baizhang gets a bunch of the monastics. They go, they find the fox, pull it out of its cave, bring it down, call everyone together for a funeral. And the monks are like, "For who? Nobody's died." And so they have this whole elaborate ceremony for this fox. And then that night, he and Huangbo, his disciple, have an interesting conversation. I'll get to that later in the week.

When Daido Roshi would give this koan, sometimes he would say that he imagined Baizhang had been wandering in the mountains, had come across a dead fox, pushed it back into a cave, and then come down and rolled this whole story out. Haven't you all noticed this old priest who comes? "No, I haven't seen it." "Yeah, every talk, he's back there, then leaves."

And so the priest comes to Baizhang. Baizhang says, "Who are you? You keep coming to the talks and then disappearing." He says, "In former times, I was the former abbot of this monastery. And one day a student asked, as an enlightened being, as a highly cultivated person, fall into causation or not?" And they answered according to the teachings, "No, they do not." And for that, they were made to live as a fox for 500 lives, which is not a good thing.

Does a greatly cultivated person still fall into causation? And the footnote to that says, "Just do good. Don't ask about the road ahead." That is also very good instruction. Just do good. Don't worry about what happens next. Just live in accord with the Dharma, cease from creating harm, live in accordance with your basic nature, and be a benefit. Don't worry about what happens next. I think of Atisha's phrase, "Don't expect applause, just do good."

So the old priest said, "Enlightened being does not fall into causation, has freed himself." The Buddha, upon his enlightenment, said, "I will not return. The house builder will not build this house again." Buddhism teaches that we return because karma is continuing. We are still a result of the forces of karmic actions. And so this enlightened being, the Buddha, does not fall back into causation, does not come back again. So the old man was—the old priest was answering, and it's just that way.

So then why were they made to live as a fox for 500 years? 500 lives? Quite a number of teachers have commented on this koan, which is always an indication that it was of interest. Dogen says students do not understand the principle of causation and mistakenly deny cause and effect. What a pity. Things are deteriorating and the ancestral way has degenerated. Those who say "does not fall into cause and effect" deny causation, thereby falling into the lower realms. Those who say "does not ignore cause and effect" clearly identify with or have deep faith in cause and effect. When people hear about identifying with cause and effect, they are freed from the lower realms. Do not try to get away from this. Do not doubt this.

Without that deep faith—and Dogen is emphatic, and he's just teaching in accord with what began with the Buddha—but without that deep faith, I mean, think about it. We might think that our actions have no consequences. There have been schools of thought that believe that, that everything just happens in some sort of random or not causal way, or that actions don't matter—not having faith in cause and effect, or that we can avoid the consequences, fly below the radar, get away with it.

And so, deep faith in causation, really trusting it in a way, is helping us to see that everything we do has influence. Every action, every intentional action in Buddhism, has an effect, because every action has an effect. But the intentional actions are the ones that Buddhism is really concerned about, because that's where we're creating karma, arising out of whatever we're holding on to, whatever we believe, and how we create and perpetuate dukkha.

And so a faith in Buddhism that is, you know, in the early years, to talk about faith took a lot of qualifying because people—everybody, so many people being new to Buddhism—just assumed that faith was either faith in a higher being like God, or that it was somehow blind faith. You know, the Buddha said so, just believe it, even though that's explicitly not what the Buddha taught. The Buddha was very clear about the importance of having some faith, some trust enough to practice, but then verifying. Having faith in causation helps us to understand that we have influence, and that influence can go in a lot of different directions, right? We can do a lot of good. We can do a whole lot of harm.

I think, in a very real sense, deep faith gives us the confidence to just do good. We don't have to chart our actions on a grid. We don't have to act and then measure its effect. Just do good. Because there's faith in cause and effect. Doing good is good in its own right. And so we don't have to be bodhisattvas on the path that are always looking for rewards or treats or gold stars.

But the question remains: how can we be free? Because we have created karma, we still create karma. I'm imagining that all of us do carry regrets, things that we really, that I really wished I had not done, but I did. Perhaps you did. We cannot go back. And this is the path of going forward. It's a path. So how do we go forward with that? Is freedom just minimizing our negative actions? Just arriving at a place of perfect behavior, perfect speech, perfect thoughts? Is it like a matter of just being hyper alert, right? Sort of staying in the shadows so you never do anything that might go awry?

If realizing the nature of mind, the true nature of reality, is as the Buddha taught, ultimate liberation, then what is it that is realized? Well, it's the nature of the self. It's the nature of phenomena. But how does that free us of cause and effect? Or what do we realize about cause and effect?

So this priest said, "The enlightened being does not fall into causation." The footnote says, "A fitting statement is a stake to tie a donkey to for 10,000 years." In other words, it's fixing something. It's a definitive statement. And being so tethered, you can't move freely.

So what is the priest's mistake? I mean, think about if you did not believe in cause and effect, how would the world look to you? If your actions didn't have consequence, what would the world look like to you?

In Daido Roshi's The Eight Gates, in the chapter on Right Action—which is really the chapter on the precepts—he talks about how at that time, so this is going back, I think it was 1990 when it was published, around then. Because he talks about for 10 years we have been—so for 10 years we were here. And he talks about how in Western Dharma that the idea, particularly in Zen, that Zen is sort of beyond morality, that morality is of the relative world, but Zen realizes the absolute nature and is beyond morality. And so he's very emphatic about that being not true. And that's an issue, you could say, that's been part of Buddhism since the beginning, where there were schools of practitioners who believe that there is no cause and effect, or where people misunderstood selflessness as meaning that there is no consequence to our actions.

Dogen quotes Kumarata, Indian ancestor, who said, "We see both wholesome and unwholesome results occurring in the world throughout time. People acting well, people not acting well. Ordinary folks deny cause and effect when they see kind and fair-minded people suffer and die young, while those who are violent and unjust prosper into old age. Such ordinary folks say neither crime nor beneficial acts bring consequences. Doesn't matter." They do not realize that the consequences of our actions follow us for 100, 1,000, or 10,000 eons.

So this is the teaching of Buddhism—that's the deep faith, is that there is never not cause and effect, and that sometimes that effect appears quickly, sometimes it takes longer, sometimes it takes so long that we don't see it, we don't recognize the effect of this particular action. But what the Buddha taught—and the Buddha was said to have, because of the depth of his enlightenment, was able to see into all of the profound complexities and subtleties of causation and thus was able to say that there is no intentional action that does not bring forth a consequence. There again, just do good, don't worry about, don't get hung up on the road ahead.

And so, but what Kumarata is saying is natural. I mean, probably in every generation of human life and experience, people have wondered this, right? They've lived their lives and they've looked over here and they've seen this person or these people acting like hell beings and reaping lots of rewards, seeming to get all the good stuff, perhaps with impunity. And they see other fair-minded, kind, good people over here who are suffering, and life just seems to keep dealing them bad hands. How to make sense of it? Because of course then that can lead a person to think, well, what difference does it make if I lead a good life or not? If they don't have sort of an inner moral ground, it's like, why bother living well, right? If I'm not going to get some reward, if the consequences of that are not going to benefit me, why don't I just try and get away with everything I can?

What gives weight to our actions? What is that burden? Those burdens that we carry—because we probably have more than one? What gives our burdens their weight, these karmic burdens? Does it come from the original action itself and somehow the life of that action which happens and then is gone, but somehow lives on in us? Is it the action itself? If the action itself has a certain weight inherently, then everybody would suffer the same consequence. If it was something positive, then everyone would equally be uplifted, be joyful, be happy, be inspired. But that's not what we see.

You know, it's like here in the zendo during sesshin, the monitor or teacher can offer encouraging words. For one person, it's inspiring. It wakes them up, it brings them back to their practice, it's invigorating. And the other person may feel annoyed, irritated or insecure, feel left out—"they're not talking to me." Does it come from the one who acts? Is it just from the side of the one who receives? What is the weight? We experience it internally. I talked about this recently in this body-mind. But where exactly? We can't deny that I'm experiencing it. That's how I know that I'm feeling something, carrying something, being bound by something. But where is it exactly? And what is it exactly? Does it have a certain size? A certain shape? Does it live in a certain part of me? Is it in my heart? Is it in my chest? Is it in my gut?

All dharmas are forms of emptiness. But then why was the former abbot turned into a fox? Dogen says, quoting Nagarjuna, "If you deny cause and effect in the worldly realm, as some people outside the Way do, you negate this present life as well as future lives. If you deny cause and effect in the realm of practice, you reject the Three Treasures and the Four Noble Truths." In other words, effectively, you can't practice.

I mean, think about the whole of practice, the whole of sesshin—not the whole of it, but a significant part, and certainly a significant part of what motivates us is the faith that if I understand, develop an understanding that is accurate about this body-mind, about myself, about my actions, about everything that constitutes itself, about the world, about you, each other, about time, about the nature of things, that if I develop a good understanding, and then I practice in accord with that understanding, that I will be moving more and more in a trustworthy way, into accord with everything. Because I'm practicing living in accord with everything. So if I'm doing that, I should experience that, right? There should be signs that that is happening, just as when I'm not doing that, I'm living against—not in harmony, in conflict with—there are certainly signs that that is happening.

And so we rely on that, right? We trust that. And there's a tension there. Because on the one hand, just do good. Don't look for the road ahead. Just sit. Just do. This day, just do sesshin. Don't come in with a truckload of expectations and then be checking yourself. "Okay, what have you gained so far? What have you gained so far? What have you gained so far?" Right? Because that's a cage and you'll know it. Because you'll be crying at some point.

At the same time, to be wholeheartedly practicing and after some reasonable amount of time, say, nothing has happened, there's been no change whatsoever. I have not seen any consequence to my actions. That bears further investigation. So there's a tension.

Dogen says, "Clearly know that those who deny cause and effect are outside the Way, whether they're living a life as a home dweller or renunciant. They say that the present life is unreal, empty, and that their transient body, empty, is in this world, but that their true nature abides in enlightenment—'I'm in the world, but not of it. I see all of you from my lofty place. I'm sorry.' They believe that their true nature is mind, that mind and body are separate. But those who have studied deeply with true teachers should abandon mistaken views which deny causation, have faith in and pay respect to the compassionate teaching of our ancestor Nagarjuna."

So this drumbeat of having faith in causation—not just, you know, it's a good idea, keep that in mind—but like, keep it in mind, examine it, study it, observe it. Now come closer. Look more deeply. What is the nature of cause and effect? How can we free ourselves if we cannot undo what has been done? How can we free ourselves?

And from a more traditional perspective, if what I am carrying is the result of an infinite number of lifetimes in which, in many of those lifetimes, I was not a good person—I was causing all kinds of chaos and riot. Remember a few years ago, I think it was during COVID, when Pema Chödrön did a retreat, I think it was an online retreat, and she was talking about death. And she said, you know, if you find yourself getting really freaked out or worried or obsessed or frightened about death, she said, "Just remember, you have died countless thousands, hundreds of thousands of times, and in some really miserable ways. So keep it in perspective. This is just one." 

How do we free ourselves? What is it that bites us? The old priest said, "An enlightened being does not fall into causation." They have realized something about cause and effect. What is a cause? It's an action, something you do with your body. What is the nature of this body? Something you do with your words. What is the nature of the words—not their meaning, but their self-nature? Something you do with your thoughts. What is the nature of a thought? Well, one thing you already know is that each of those three wheels by which we create karma, change the world, are impermanent, right? Have you ever had a thought that never went away? Have you ever said something that, once you said it, it remained permanently in your mouth or in the ears of the hearer?

We'd like to think that our body is permanent. Maybe. I don't know. I don't know if that would actually be a good deal. Clearly, it's not. The intention that arises that brings forth that action—that comes and goes. The emotion that it might originate—the klesha, if it's a negative: "I'm greedy, I'm acting out of that. I'm angry, I'm acting out of that"—that comes and goes. The consequence—I say something, you have a certain reaction—that comes and goes.

So where is the burden? What is the—because we can't deny. That's what these teachers are saying: Do not deny. Dogen says, "Do not doubt this. Do not try and get away from this." I mean, that's the basis for a kind of a seriously unwell person. And we may have some in high places who do not know the effect or do not care—they know that they have effect, but may not care of the consequences of those actions, which is, in a sense, like virtually denying.

If we didn't have faith in causation, who would practice Buddha Dharma? If there wasn't cause and effect, we wouldn't feel regret or remorse. There'd be no heartache, no worry. We wouldn't carry a burden. If there was no cause and effect, we could put our burden down. Or rather, what you could say about all of those would be: there would be nothing but regrets and no way to affect them. There would be no end to the heartache and no way to diminish them or free ourselves of them. There would be no end to burdens, and they would be permanently attached to us.

What is the true thing about all this? It's important because it's the basis upon which we're practicing. And having deep faith, as I said, is not just about a kind of theoretical faith in something called cause and effect. But if we really trust that and study it, practice it, observe it, examine it, that feeds directly into how we practice.

I mean, think about it. It gives us the ability, the confidence to keep going when your mind is very close to convincing you that you are completely wasting your time. Like, "When are you going to get it?" Or that everybody else here is perfectly suited to be a Buddha, but I'm sorry, you were like in the toilet, right, when they're giving out Buddha nature, right?

What keeps us going when it seems like it's not moving or it's insurmountable, or my attachments seem intractable, or my comparing mind is killing me because I just—I'm digging a hole and I'm digging it deeper and deeper and deeper and just throwing myself into it. Everybody else is fine, but I am going down. So it's quite important.

So is this old priest wrong? There's a miscellaneous koan that's in our tradition that says: In the Maha Prajna Paramita Sutra, expounded by Manjushri, it says, "An ascetic who is pure and undefiled will not enter Nirvana, and a monastic who breaks the precepts will not fall into hell." Now, that seems to directly contradict the teachings.

It's important to understand that that ascetic practices to purify their defilements, and they do not, in their impurity and their defilement, fall—well, they do not, in their purity and undefilement, enter Nirvana, and the monastic practices the precepts, and when they break, they will not fall into hell.

Is that contradicting the Buddha's teaching? That's why this is an important koan, because it's easy to—and one could read, if we didn't read it closely—the commentaries and it seems to be affirming, basically, just do good, don't worry about the rest. The priest answered wrongly, was made to live as a fox, that's pretty clear. Asked for a teaching, Baizhang responded, "Does not ignore causation." Released from the fox body, rewarded. That seems pretty clear. That's not untrue. But it's not enough, and it's not just a matter of not being—the real depth of this koan—but it's not enough for our lives. That alone will not be sufficient to free us.

Daido Roshi said, "We encounter and practice the precepts initially on the basis of faith. They make sense, and we can bring them into our lives." Hallelujah.

It takes years of practice and training—oh, I thought I was quoting him, these are actually my words because I wrote Daido Roshi and I thought, oh, I'm quoting him, then I realized, no, I'm remembering what he used to talk. Remember he told the story once that he was listening, when we started recording talks on audio—the beginning of Dharma communications was in Room 21 in a drawer. Kyōto, who was a head monk, had a tape recorder, and she would record the talks in here, and then she would go in her room. And when somebody said, "Can I get a recording of that tape?" she would go in and put a blank tape in, hit record, and then send it to the person. That was the beginning.

And so he was telling the story once that he was going somewhere and was listening. He had picked up a talk, he thought it was like a senior's talk. And he put it in and he starts listening to it, and there was something about the sound that was a little wonky, but he was listening, and it was good, it was like, good Dharma, but he was listening. He thought, "Those are my words. They're like, completely quoting my words. They're like parroting everything I've said." And then he realized it was him.

So Daido Roshi used to say, talk about how we encounter and practice the precepts on the basis of faith, right? Because they make sense and we can bring them into our lives. And that through our practice and years of training and examination and observing and inquiry and clarification, we begin to understand more and more deeply and broadly the profound nature of these teachings.

So they're one of the most, I think, kind of quintessential examples in Buddhism of a teaching that can seem that anybody can understand, right? A child could understand the precepts and be encouraged to follow them, right? They make that much sense or are that available or that sort of straightforward. And at the same time, they really embody the complete teachings, really the most deepest teachings of Buddhism, to see how they are nondual, arising from and manifesting selflessness, are always good medicine, are always good guides, are always revealing the light, life, and are not fixed, they are not rules, they are not dogmas—they're alive.

And so I'll speak about this a little bit more as the week goes on, but let me just offer this to take a little something back to your seat. In the Mumonkan commentary, or the poem, I think, or the commentary, it says, "If you have an eye to see into this case, then you will know that the former head of the monastery did in fact enjoy their 500 happy, blessed lives as a fox." So what is that pointing to?

Thank you for listening. To find out more about ZMM's programs, retreats and residency, please visit us online at zmm.org.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Title: Realization Of Body-and-Mind
Extracted Text:
This transcript was generated by an AI and may contain errors. Corrections have been made for clarity and spelling, with minimal changes to preserve the original content.

---

This is from the Transmission of Light, Dogen. Dogen studied with Zen Master Ru Jing. Once, during meditation, sitting late at night, Ru Jing said to the assembly, "Zen study is a shedding of mind and body." Hearing this, suddenly, Dogen was greatly enlightened. He went right to the abbot's room and lit incense.

Ru Jing asked him, "What are you burning incense for?"  
Dogen said, "My body and mind have been shed."  
Ru Jing said, "Body and mind shed, shed body and mind."  
Dogen said, "This is a temporary byway. Don't approve me arbitrarily."  
Ru Jing said, "I'm not."  
Dogen said, "What is that which isn't given arbitrary approval?"  
Ru Jing said, "Shedding body and mind."  
Dogen bowed.  
Ru Jing said, "The shedding is shed."

At that time, Ru Jing's attendants said, "This is no small matter, that a foreigner has attained such a state." Ru Jing said, "How many times has he been pummeled here? Liberated, dignified. Thunder roars."

Keizan's verse:  
Clear as pure light. No inside or outside, is there any body or mind to be shed?

The character for shedding here can mean dropping off, forgetting, casting away. So, shedding body and mind—what is it that is shed? We have a physical body, we have mind. Are they the same? Are they different?

Daido Roshi brought body practice as a deliberate and particular aspect of our training here—one of the Eight Gates—and he spoke of it as the miracle of aliveness, which I've always liked a lot. The miracle of aliveness in the Eight Gates. Daido Roshi says, "Body practice is not exercise. It's not martial arts or aerobics, jogging or pumping iron. Body practice is nothing other than washing the face, cleaning the body, urination, elimination, cooking food, eating a meal, healing sickness, actualizing birth, practicing life, realizing death. Only when this is understood can we begin to speak of martial arts, aerobics, pumping iron. Body practice is concerned with self-realization through the body. It is realizing that this body is the body of the Buddha, the body of this entire universe."

One of the things we realize when we come into practice is that practice is a very bodily thing, right? We use it. The first thing that happens is we're taught zazen: to take a posture, to turn inward. In Dogen's fascicle "Body-Mind Study of the Way," he wrote, "To study the Way with the body means to study the Way with your own body." You can't use somebody else's, and you can't use yours until you fully inhabit yours, or to some reasonable degree. It's the study of the Way, using this lump of red flesh. The body comes forth from the study of the Way. So as we practice, the body becomes revealed through the Dharma. The Dharma—our Dharma study—reveals the body: all that it is, all else it is, and also what it isn't.

Everything that comes forth from the study of the Way is the true human body. The entire world of the ten directions is nothing but this true human body. The coming and going of birth and death is the true human body. It can't be known apart from the body. That's why Buddhism, Buddhadharma, is very specifically about the human world, the human realm, the human life, the human body and mind.

To turn the body around, abandon the ten unwholesome actions, keep the eight precepts, take refuge in the three treasures, leave home, and enter the homeless life—this is the true study of the Way, and for this reason, it's called the true human body. Those who follow this must not be like outsiders who hold the view of spontaneous enlightenment.

I was listening to a teacher recently who said that in Tibetan Buddhism, Tibetans tend not to say, "I am a Tibetan Buddhist," but they use a word that says, essentially, "I am an insider." Which doesn't mean an insider as part of an elite group, but rather, "I'm not an outsider. I'm not going out seeking. I'm an insider." As this teacher said, it's an inside job.

This true human body: is that your physical body, your emotional body, psychological, spiritual body? Is it the Skandhas? This is the body of emptiness. Well, what would you leave out?

If we want to be free in this world, that means being free in this life, which means being free in this body and mind. So what would we leave out or deny?

You know, when we're first introduced to zazen—I first learned it from a book, because that's all I knew there was—but to actually be given instruction... In fact, the first time I came here, I was sitting in the zendo on a Sunday morning. Kyodo, the head monk, when they made the announcement for beginning instruction, came up to me, tapped me on the shoulder, and said, "Don't you need beginning instruction?" I said, "No, I'm good." Arrogant. I did not know what I did not know.

But then, when we're receiving this instruction, we shouldn't underestimate the posture: taking the posture of a Buddha, sitting on the seat, the diamond seat. This posture, which is a body of wisdom, taps into our own intelligence, our own sort of perfectness within this body that allows the body to find stability more than we can imagine. Aliveness, more than we can imagine. An openness of pathways, more than we can imagine. A leaping beyond this very body itself, more than we can imagine.

Just these basic elements of sitting upright—that you hold up your own weight. You know, we can think of these things as just, you know, sort of physical manifestations, like do this, do this, do this, without any sense that it's connected, it's part, it's an expression of a basic wisdom and intelligence, a Buddhadharma in this body. And that zazen is a pathway, which means that pathway has to get opened, right? And what we encounter when we zazen is all of the pathways that are not open—those are our struggles. And it is also at the very moment that it is a pathway—the thing itself, the very thing that we're seeking.

Sitting upright, facing forward—it's not a retreat, it's not an escape. Senses are open. It's not a withdrawal. Alert and relaxed. Sounds good. Not so easy. Not so easy because we're not relaxed, we're not alert. Awake.

The body sits zazen, but you don't sit in this body. You don't sit apart from it. The body knows. It's really turning towards the body's intrinsic wisdom. It knows things arise. And we practice: not naming, not denying, not indulging, not distracting, not clinging. We turn our attention to the breath. We follow the breath. Where is it going? We speak of being the breath. Have you ever been apart from it? Turn this body around.

Dogen says, don't be an outsider looking at it objectively. Zazen is very simple. It's not complicated. And if we have the basic physical, mental, emotional ability to do zazen, then that means we have that at the very beginning. So why is it so difficult?

Thoughts arise, emotions come and go. They seem to occur within this body. We experience thoughts in our mind. Energy—we begin to encounter, for lack of a better word, energy. Ki, aliveness, spirit. Something is moving. We can feel it in our eyes, our throat, chest. In large part, in the beginning, it's a tangle. It's almost like a logjam. It's all tangled up. And so we experience it as a tangle. Bound, uncomfortable. It may be strong, it may be weak, it can come and go, it can be tense, it can be relaxed.

It's one of the really important aspects of sitting still and actually experiencing all of those fluctuations, all of those movements. Then, in so many moments, we would just simply rather not, if you don't mind. But there they are.

So we're beginning, introduced to this body-mind, seeing how they arise together. It's interesting, over the years, how many people have come through here who have spent much of their lives in their body doing different forms of yoga practice or martial arts or sports. People in the military who have done really impressive things with their body, right, that required all kinds of abilities, capacities, skill, courage. And yet, something about sitting on this simple mat and going inside—it's not like others. I've seen people who have done genuinely heroic, courageous things in their life become weak-kneed, fearful, reluctant, hesitant, just starting to turn inside to realize the self through the body.

If we identify ourself as anything, it's the body, right? Why do we cling to it so much as it ages? Why does society, or people in society, invest so much in the perfect body—the body that, if you had, everything would be great, you would be happy forever, everyone would love you. And what happens when you get there? You start to age, and that body begins to age, as it must, because that's part of its intelligence, it's part of its wisdom. It follows the natural laws. How do we feel about that?

We feel our emotions, sensations, everything within our body. But where are they? Can you find them?

Daido Roshi says self-realization needs to be with our whole being. Unfortunately, the search for self-knowledge is usually regarded as purely a function of the intellect. Feeling and intuition are largely considered to be subjective and therefore unreliable instruments for realizing truth. Yet by reducing the search for truth to an intellectual activity, we achieve only a distorted understanding of who we really are and of what's possible.

Body and mind have fallen away. Shed body and mind.

I came across an article by a scholar who said that Ru Jing never actually used the term "body-mind." They can't find it in any of his writings or any of his successors' writings. Only Dogen. It's only found in Dogen—in Dogen's teaching—and that the word for "body-mind" is a homophone for the word in Chinese for "dust," and that what is found in the teachings of Ru Jing is that he talked about the dust of the mind, the dust from the mind. And so the scholar speculates that Dogen misheard, and Ru Jing was actually talking about dust. But Dogen heard it as body-mind. So he says Dogen must have misheard this term due to a lack of full comprehension of Chinese, intuitively misrepresenting it or purposefully changing it—which doesn't really matter, right? Because even if he heard it correctly, but then through his own experience—experience: body-mind shed—which is clearly what he experienced and was not based on a correct or incorrect interpretation of a character or word that his teacher had said.

Every person has their own direct experience. And part of training is to, in a sense, test that with the Dharma. I mean, everybody who practices is having experiences all the time, right? Just ordinary experiences, because we're having perceptions, our senses are picking up, we're in a body, things are happening, we're aware of them. So we're having experiences. But in terms of insights, deeper experiences—there are all kinds of experiences that can be had, that are had. But are they in alignment with the Buddhadharma? Which really means, are they helping you to awaken? Because we can have lots of experiences that might be quite wonderful, enlivening, inspiring, but they're not really helping us to awaken. And so part of training is to get clear about that.

One's own body, which is the body of the universe—this body, which is not yours, it's not something... It's your true body, your reality body. It's neither absolute nor relative body. It's not "not this." It's not "not not this" body. This is the body to be realized.

"The entire world of the ten directions," Dogen says, means that all ten directions are the entire world to consider. He says, consider the moment when front and back, vertical and horizontal are thoroughly reached. East, west, south, north, the four midpoints, up and down—the ten directions, front and back, vertical and horizontal. Consider this. He's basically talking about all of space. And then he says, to consider this means to understand and to resolve that this human body, undivided by self and others, is the entire world of the ten directions. This is to hear what has never been heard.

And so think about, in the Metta Sutta, when the Buddha said, "Even as a mother protects with her life her child, her only child, in the same way, with a boundless heart, should we cherish all living beings, radiating kindness over the entire world—upwards to the skies, downwards to the depths, outwards and unbounded." It's exactly what Dogen is saying, and that's a meditation—in this case, a meditation of cultivating metta, loving-kindness, compassion, sympathetic joy, and equanimity.

But it's not just having a feeling, it's bringing forth that within the body, letting it infuse the body all throughout the body, and then letting that body become the body of the universe. So how do we practice that? By extending with our mind that quality, that characteristic in those directions: upwards to the skies, downwards to the depths, outward and unbounded, all four directions. And when the mind enters into that spaciousness, the body has to at the same time be spacious. And so then the body becomes a body of loving-kindness. The universe becomes a universe of loving-kindness. In that moment, it's not you, it's not apart from you. When it is undivided, it's not something that you're doing—it's just loving-kindness cast off.

So when we begin practicing that and it feels wobbly or distracted or tight or diminished—it's not that the loving-kindness itself is diminished, it's not that the body is limited in some way. Is it that symphony of body and mind working as one?

You know, the teachings say that when the body, when the mind—and whenever we think of mind, we have to think of body at the same time. If we talk about body, we have to think of mind at the same time because we have inherited, right, an attitude, a view of the world in which these are separated. So you can be a mind person, you can be a body person. But then when we're practicing this, we're not. I mean, we could think of it as reclaiming or just coming back to experiencing that body, that true human body freed from hatred and ill will, whether standing, walking, seated, lying down, freed from drowsiness, sustain that recollection, sustain that mind. This is the sublime abiding.

The Buddha said, "My body and mind have been shed." Dogen said, "Dropped off, cast away." Which, in a sense, is just the limitation of language, right? If the body and mind was something you could put your fingers on and cast away, we would have all done it. If it was a thing that had a place of its thingness, a location, and we could locate it, we could grab it because it's a thing. That's what you can do with things. And then we put it, put it somewhere, we'd all be enlightened.

And so to even say, "My body and mind have been shed," is really just to say body and mind are liberated. And it's interesting how in this dialogue, Dogen says—when Ru Jing affirms, "This body and mind have been shed," and Dogen says, "Hang on, this is just a temporary byway, don't approve me arbitrarily." He wanted to be sure. He clearly had some surety because he goes into the abbot's room and lights incense, and Ru Jing says, "What are you doing?" But he wants to be sure. He wants his teacher to be sure so that he can be sure.

So he says, "Don't approve me arbitrarily."  
Ru Jing says, "I'm not."  
And of course remember that they had been training together, that Ru Jing gave him—I don't know if it was unprecedented, but it was a very unusual invitation, particularly for somebody who had just come in—and he said, "You can come to my abbot's room anytime." An open invitation. So it wasn't that, you know, Dogen—he was just hearing this from Dogen for the first time and affirming him. He knew Dogen. So he said, "This isn't arbitrary."  
"What is it that you are not giving arbitrarily?"  
"Shedding body and mind."  
And Dogen bowed, and Ru Jing said, "Now the shedding itself is shed."

When we first come into practice, for the most part, I think we know that we have a body, right? That's how we got here. And in a sense, we begin to experience its miracles, if they don't feel quite miraculous yet. We begin to thaw what is frozen, to come into contact with what has been numb, to begin to accept what has been denied, to let go of the idea of the perfect or imperfect body—which means the perfect or imperfect mind, which means the perfect or imperfect self. To let go of what we identify as with body and mind, and then to let go of letting go, freed from hatred and ill will towards others, towards ourself.

Hatred can only occur within a very solid body and mind that is frozen, that is numb in that moment—certainly towards the object of our hatred, but necessarily, because this body is the body and mind of the universe, towards oneself. One's own body has to be frozen, numbed, in order to freeze another, to hate another. But because by that time we have almost certainly adapted to that frozen body-mind—and not just adapted to it, but identified with it, quite possibly turned it into something quite productive, quite successful, rewards—when we free that, then we begin to experience the miracle of dignity, beauty, fragility, resilience, strength, intelligence, suffering. To really experience suffering, right? We don't really expect that that's part of the deal, right? To be free from suffering means that every sequential step to be moving further and further away from it—sorry, it's actually moving closer and closer, because it's an inside thing.

But so, to be able to experience that within this body, freely giving it passage, just like everything else. And really, the miracle of this body, which is not dependent upon size or shape or color or age or ability—but it has to be fully attuned or attuning to those things, which becomes quite important when we're sick, when we've been injured, when we're getting older, when we're getting frail, when we have an illness and the body does not move the way it did yesterday, cannot do what it did yesterday. That might be temporary, it might be ongoing.

This week, in conversations and communication and dokusans, it's like, okay, the sangha is aging. Just had repeated contacts with people who, either they themselves or their partners or somebody in their family is experiencing sickness, old age, and death. And even though we have been practicing for years and years, still, when it really comes home, when we really begin to experience it, it can be a little bit of a surprise. Because there's the idea, right, of sickness, old age, and death. And then there's being sick. There's the idea of aging. I mean, when I was younger, I had all kinds of ideas of aging. I would look at older people and think, "What's with you anyway? Why can't you stand up straight, walk fast?" It seemed like a choice, right? Arrogant.

It becomes real. And so where is the miracle of aliveness now, when it is not and cannot be dependent on those conditions because they're changing?

Dogen said, "To bow all the way to the floor and to bow standing is dignified bearing in motion and stillness. Painting a decayed tree, polishing a brick of dead ash continues without stopping, playing freely with the true body, whether standing or walking, seated or lying down." And so we practice cultivating, coming into contact with, enlivening the miracle of aliveness as we sit, as we walk, as we eat, as we clean, as we work, as we bow. It's a fundamental practice.

And every so often, usually a fairly new student will come in and say, "Okay, now what? I got this. But now what?" Start over, or start for the first time, maybe. Because the thing is, we can't experience the miraculousness until we do. And so until then, what we have to know is our actual experience, which feels some version of limited, confined, not miraculous.

And that's why these teachings are so important, that we keep hearing these teachings, which are reports from inside. And it's like, okay, I hear what you're saying. You're making it very sort of robust and describing this. You're using imagery. It's like, I can visualize it, but I don't know that. That is not my experience. That's the point—to hear that as a calling, an invitation, so that when we enter into these basic fundamental practices for the rest of our lives—sitting, standing, walking, lying down, bowing, eating, urinating, defecating, working—we're on an endless path of endlessly entering in more deeply, because our imagination cannot provide for us the sort of imagined reality of that.

You know, the level of our awareness at any moment reveals to us. It's like I was saying to somebody earlier, we open our eyes and it's like, "I'm seeing everything there is to see in this room." Seems like it. Am I? When we turn our attention inward and I have awareness of what I see, it's like, "I am aware of everything there is to see." No. No, it's like, okay, I hear you saying that, but... And so I can try and imagine. And usually what I'll imagine is some version of, you know, fantastical, magical, supernatural, something. No.

And so that's why hearing these teachings—and then it's like these teachings are intended to make you hungry, hungrier. I don't think I've tasted that yet, but I want to.

Keizan said, "Reaching this point, when you observe closely, even if you use a thousand eyes, you do not find a particle of anything that can be called skin, flesh, bones, marrow. There's nothing to divide into mind, cognition, consciousness. How can you know coolness and warmth, how can you distinguish pain and itch? When the body is the body of the universe, there is no distinguishing. What would you affirm or deny, what like or dislike? This is why it has been said, when you see there's not a single thing."

And so he's speaking about that mind, your natural mind. But isn't he also at the same time telling you how to do zazen? So when you are sitting, don't divide your mind, your body, cognition, consciousness. Don't separate coolness and warmth, don't grab onto one and reject the other. Don't, with everything that arise, choose it or reject it. Let all of those impulses calm.
