And so then Daido Roshi says, as we're practicing this, then we can really begin to understand these forms of body practice: qigong, tai chi, yoga, dance, running, pumping iron—I don't even know if they still call it that. But most importantly, we practice it through the everyday, ordinary movements. Because if we're not doing that, then those other forms—it's not that they can't open that up for us, but they'll be restricted. And so when cooking and sweeping the floor and cleaning a bathroom and driving a car and holding a baby—sounds like caretaking, sounds like work, practice, sounds like a unified life.

I was thinking about—I was talking at breakfast with some folks, and you know, like when the presidential administration was talking about closing down the parks, and I thought, the people who are thinking this way—do you ever go outside? Do your feet ever touch the ground? Do you stand in the presence of a tree? Have you felt the miracle of what is not human but can be known within your human body?

I hear Elon Musk talk about AI and how that's going to save the world and we just need to get to Mars. Then it's like, okay, now it makes sense what you're doing. We don't matter. Doesn't matter. This Earth doesn't matter. Machines matter. What kind of frozenness, what kind of outsider, what kind of mind and body are not one is that? And how, the more pronounced that becomes, the more estranged—not just from others or Earth, but ourselves—in a sense, all things become possible in the worst way possible.

And the sort of—the hard thing about it is if we—we can't know something until we experience something. So even to come into practice and be drawn by the teachings, the reports from within that I have not experienced, but when I hear those, they're touching something in me, the affinity is not over here, it's here. So even if I haven't experienced that directly, if it's not really clear to me, something is being touched, something is alive. And if I don't experience that, at least in that moment, something is not. There is no affinity, there is no contact, there is no calling.

And so that's why the way we sit is so important. You know, we're training in each moment not just to calm our minds, but the whole body. And so to be upright, alert—which means there is a kind of effort which is actually very important. It's not passive, it's not "not me, not now, it's not mine." It's a middle way. It's a middle way which isn't a balance, although balance is good. It's something that has to be discovered and cultivated and loved.

I think of how, as sesshin goes on, even, you know, more beginning students sometimes will say this: everybody becomes more and more beautiful. What's happening there?

So I want to end with this miracle of aliveness with a poem by Walt Whitman:

---

Why, who makes much of a miracle?  
As to me, I know of nothing else but miracles.  
Whether I walk the streets of Manhattan,  
Or dart my sight over the roofs of houses toward the sky,  
Or wade with naked feet along the beach just in the edge of the water,  
Or stand under trees in the woods,  
Or talk by day with anyone I love,  
Or sleep in the bed at night with anyone I love,  
Or sit at table at dinner with the rest,  
Or look at strangers opposite me riding in the car,  
Or watch honeybees busy around the hive of a summer forenoon,  
Or animals feeding in the fields, or watch birds,  
Or the wonderfulness of insects in the air,  
Or the wonderfulness of the sundown,  
Or of stars shining so quiet and bright,  
Or the exquisite delicate thin curve of the new moon in spring.  
These with the rest, one and all, are to me miracles,  
The whole referring, yet each distinct and in its place.  
To me every hour of the light and dark is a miracle.  
Every cubic inch of space is a miracle.  
Every square yard of the surface of the earth is spread with the same,  
Every foot of the interior swarms with the same.  
To me the sea is a continual miracle.  
The fishes that swim—the rocks—the motion of the waves—the ships with men in them.  
What stranger miracles are there?

---

Thank you for listening. To find out more about ZMM's programs, retreats, and residency, please visit us online at zmm.org.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Title: The Transformation Of Karma
Extracted Text:
The following Dharma discourse was given by Jeffrey Shugan Arnold at Zen Mountain Monastery. Shugan Roshi is the Head of the Mountains and Rivers Order and Abbot of the Monastery. This talk, like all of our talks, is offered free of charge. If you would like to make a donation or find out more about our various programs, visit us online at zmm.org. Thank you for listening.

This is from the Blue Cliff Record: The Diamond Cutter Scripture's Scornful Revilement.

A pointer. If you take up one and let two go, you're not yet an adept. Even to understand three corners when one is raised still goes against the fundamental essence. Even if you get heaven and earth to change instantly without rejoinder from the four quarters—thunder, rolling lightning, flying clouds, moving rain, rushing, overturning lakes, toppling cliffs, like a pitcher pouring, like a bowl emptying—you have still not raised up a half. Is there anyone who can turn the polar star? Who can shift the axis of the earth? To test, I cite this old case.

The Diamond Cutter Scripture says: If one is scornfully reviled by others, this person has done wicked acts in previous ages which should bring them into evil ways. But because of the evil and vilification by others in the present age, the wicked action of former ages is thereby extinguished.

The clear jewel is in my palm. Whoever has accomplishment will be rewarded with it. When neither stranger nor friend comes, it has utterly no abilities. Since it has no abilities, the evil one loses their way. Gautama. Gautama, do you know me or not? Pseudo also said: completely exposed.

Good morning. This weekend, Shoen Osho and I were leading a retreat on the Precepts and in the Eight Gates. Daido Roshi says, in essence, the Precepts are a definition of the life of a Buddha, or how Buddha functions in the world—how enlightened beings live their lives, relate to others, make moral and ethical decisions, manifest wisdom and compassion in everyday life.

At the monastery, the Precepts are the basis of the rules and guidelines for all residents. For those practicing away from the monastery, precepts provide a way to see how the moral and ethical teachings in Buddhism can come to life in the marketplace, relationships, government, business, ecology. The Precepts are unique among religious ethical teachings in that they are based on the experience of no self, and that experience makes all the difference in the world.

So we looked at how these teachings are from the very beginning. The Buddha's own original teachings are essential to Buddhist practice, to meditation, to enlightenment, to everything that Buddhism teaches. And as Daido Roshi says, they're based on the experience of no self, selflessness, emptiness of self. And that fact—that realization—makes all the difference in the world.

And so what is that basis? In the pointer, there's this very poetic and rather dramatic list of all these miraculous abilities, and yet, still, that doesn't even reach a half. But can you turn the polar star, shift the axis of the earth? This is not about a magical, supernatural display of powers. In fact, in the Zen tradition, that can be seen as a distraction, should you be so endowed with such powers. What makes all the difference in the world is realizing our self-nature, the unborn, undying body of the Buddha. Here we're freed from self-clinging, from fear, from anxiety, from cruelty.

This koan is interesting, I think, and on different levels. It's kind of startling. It hopefully gets one's attention. It's also a direct quote from the Diamond Sutra, which is one of the essential sutras of the Prajnaparamita body of teachings, which, as one scholar said on the back of one of the translations, is one of the most important bodies of religious teachings ever in human history. It's vast. The Heart Sutra that we chanted this morning is part of that body of teaching, which is even more succinct. The Diamond Sutra has a little bit more pages to it, and then there are successive sutras counted by lines: 8,000 lines, 15,000 lines, 25,000 lines, and so on.

And so this is a direct quote from the Diamond Sutra, and it's speaking about karma. That's why I thought it'd be good to bring it up this morning at the conclusion of this retreat. There are a number of koans that speak, draw directly from a basic Buddhist teaching. So here, quite explicitly from the Diamond Sutra, it's presenting a basic Buddhist teaching about karma, which means that it brings into the koan that basic fundamental understanding of karma in Buddhism.

And that's not actually what the koan is about—or rather, that basic understanding that I'll speak about is a lot of what we talked about yesterday. It's how to understand karma, how can it be spoken about, how can we gain understanding of it so that we can practice well? The Buddha said if we don't understand karma, it's going to be very difficult at best to practice well, because we will continue not understanding the nature of cause and effect. We will continue to play out deeply held habits of mind and emotion and reactivity, which will bring forth the same consequences. And we won't understand why; we won't understand why is that happening?

And so the Buddha said, we need to understand as deeply as we can. He said, the nature of karma is so deep, so profound, that only a fully enlightened being can fully understand all of the web, the strands of karma. But as practitioners, we can understand it deeply enough to help us. And so that basic understanding is brought out. But the koan, as is almost always the case, and interestingly, in these cases where it brings out a basic teaching which could be explained and understood, is looking at it at the fundamental level—not at the level at which it can be explained, not at the level at which basically everyone who understands Buddhism or karma in Buddhism can speak about or understand, but at the basis, because that makes all the difference, as Daido Roshi said.

Otherwise, if that wasn't important or necessary, we wouldn't need to do the meditation that we do, certainly not to the extent that we do it. We wouldn't need to do much of what we do. We would just need to study the teachings, learn them, change our behavior. But even that, you know, that in a sense is telling us that when we try to just change our behavior, even if we change the behavior, other things don't change because there's something at the fundamental that is unchanged.

That's why the Buddha said, developing concentration—samadhi—has a temporary transformative effect. It's calming, it's really important, but it doesn't actually pull up the roots of our false views. It doesn't really liberate us from our clinging.

The Buddha said in an early sutra: "I declare, students of the way, that actions willed—those arising from intention, performed and accumulated—will not become extinct as long as their results have not been experienced, be it in this life, in the next life, or in subsequent lives. And as long as these results of actions willed, performed and accumulated have not been experienced, there will be no making of an end to suffering."

So this is really important, and this is very much a part of this understanding of karma—that intentional action through our thought, words, and actions brings forth a consequence. That is our basic concern in Buddhism, because it's arising from a desire, which means it's arising from my mind, which means it's arising from the way I see things, from my attachments, from my sense of self. It's dependent upon and laden with my own entanglements. And that desire then comes out in my thoughts, words, and actions, and then that becomes part of its consequence.

And so the teaching is that when the consequence to that action manifests, as Shoen Osho talked about yesterday—the teaching of three times—it might happen in the near future, in the immediate moment, it might happen much later, or it might happen, within traditional Buddhism, in a subsequent lifetime. And part of the teaching of that is that karma is not optional. Basically, "I'd rather not participate if you don't mind"—like, that's not an option. In the human world, every intentional action has a consequence, will bear fruit.

So as we talked about, the idea that "can I get away with this? Can I do something that I want that basically goes against the precepts or what is good and suffer no consequence?" And Buddhism says: no, not possible. How and when that consequence comes up, we don't know yet. We'll see when it arises. And so that's a way of helping us to have faith that the idea of getting away with something is a waste of time, basically, right? Much better to clean up our house, to live well, to develop compassion.

And so when that consequence arises, that's the moment—it's like a propitious moment—because the qualities of that action that I have committed continue to exist in me until the consequence, and have force and be influencing me until the consequence of that action, the result, arises within me, within my life. And now is my opportunity, as the Buddha said, to liberate myself. He speaks of extinguishing, of freeing, of dissolving those seeds so they don't continue to manifest.

And so that depends on how do I meet that moment? If I've done something out of anger, and the consequence of that is something that brings anger with it towards me, and I respond again with anger, well, then I'm just taking those seeds and planting them again. But if I respond in a different way, compassionately, with mindfulness, awareness, within a vow, then they begin to dissolve. Those energies are transformed into something that is life-giving rather than taking away.

That's why when we are in the midst of those strong emotions—Shoen Osho talked about the kleshas, these very strong afflictive emotions that are the basis for our actions as they overtake us—that's why it's so important that when those arise, and in a sense, the stronger they are, the more important it is, although sometimes the more difficult it is to practice them well. Because from a Buddhist perspective, that's how the karma of those kleshas begins to transform, and that's always available to us.

The Buddha said, "If one says that whatever way a person performs a karmic action, in that very same way they will experience the result—in other words, in that case, there will be no possibility for Dharma life, and no opportunity would appear for making a complete end to suffering. But if one says that a person who performs a karmic action with a result that is variably experienceable—can be experienced in different ways—then they will reap its result accordingly. In that case, there will be the possibility for them to live a liberated life, and an opportunity would appear for making a complete end to suffering."

So what he's saying is that karma is not determined. It doesn't determine. It's not deterministic. It's not fatalistic. It's ongoing. It's always in process, which means we always have the ability, the opportunity to shift, to turn—no matter how intractable a situation, or we ourselves, or someone else might be. And that's really important, right? That's why the Bodhisattva doesn't suffer defeat. We might have moments where we feel defeated, where it might feel intractable, it might feel hopeless. But really what's happening in that moment is, in a sense, we're indulging. We're sort of getting mired, right, in an emotion, in a thought process, in an imaginary world that doesn't actually exist, in which we are defeating ourselves.

And so the Bodhisattva recognizes that, takes another breath, takes another step, because nothing is fixed. Isn't that good news? Hell, yeah, it's good news.

So think about the variable ways in which we can experience something. So I say something that is hurtful to you, and you respond with injury, with hurt. And I see that, and I don't care, and I walk away. I say something that is hurtful to you, and I see that land on you, and you're hurt. And I'm deeply hurt that I have done that. That isn't what I want. That isn't how I want to be in the world. That isn't what I want my effect to be on you. I am so sorry that I said that. Let me make this right. We know those are two different experiences in the aftermath of something that I said and now I can't take back. But the karma is still moving. The effect is not fixed. It's variable.

And so the moment of action is important, but in a certain sense, from that moment, what's more important is what happens next.

A Chinese master said, "Karma is a residual force of action. Whether actions are good or bad, they depend mainly on the mind. Thus, the presence of strong wisdom or resolution can cause karma to change." And that means the consequence of karma, because karma is the initial action. Karma means what is possible, not what is predetermined. Hence, it can be transformed. Thus, Buddhism stresses past karma, but does not fall into the doctrine of fatalism.

So, obviously, this koan is taking up this question, this reality.

In another early sutra, the Buddha said, "Both formerly and now, what I teach is suffering and the cessation of suffering. If others abuse, revile, scold, or harass the Buddha for this, then the Buddha, on that account, feels no annoyance, bitterness, or dejection of the heart. If another honors, respects, reveres, and venerates the Buddha for that, then the Buddha, on that account, feels no delight, no joy, no elation of the heart."

Now, we might really just immediately appreciate that he isn't crushed by the criticism, but it's like, oh, but we'd like that elation, right? Why not that? And what's important to understand is this is not being cut off, distant. It's just not deflated by one, or made ecstatic by the other, right?

It's a very good practice. When we are being scolded or criticized or hearing difficult words, right? It's so easy to see the self arising, right? It's like a body practice. You feel the energy arising. You might feel a virtual wall of defense arising within you. You might see that your argument is already forming, right? And to just see that as a protection, a threat to the self—what is being threatened—and to just let that relax, breathe, listen, listen, actually hear the words, take them in, right? Even if the person in front of you seems out of their mind, there's probably some truth. As practitioners, my job is to hear that, tease that out, so that I can see that what about this is me? What can I learn? What is being reflected back that I can apply and benefit from? And in doing that, then I often see what remains—maybe that doesn't belong to me, maybe that isn't something I need to take up. And so, not to be deflated.

And at the same time, Daido Roshi used to say often, "Don't believe in your own press notices," right? You read the reviews. Everybody loved you, right? Okay, thank you very much. What's for breakfast? So in other words, the self is not dependent upon—

Last week I talked about Chosen Roshi sending this little clip about, you can be a thermostat or you can be a thermometer. Thermometer is, my energy, my person, my temperature is totally dependent upon you. You love me, I'm doing great. You hate me, I'm doing terrible.

And so if one is scornfully reviled by others, this person has done wicked acts in previous ages, which should bring them down into evil ways. They've done something that was harmful. And when we do something that's harmful, that hurts others and hurts ourselves—because it always goes in both directions—we can mask, numb, distract from the harm that it's causing ourselves. But what happens with practice is we start to feel that more and more. We should be able to feel that more and more. But what's also happening is we're actually—part of why it hurts, I think, is because we're actually going against our fundamental nature. Not just how we want to be in the world, if we want to be in the world in a good way, but at a deeper level, we're actually going against our basic nature.

And so, a person who has done this should, by the laws of karma, fall down into evil ways. In other words, that karma should continue to drag on them, right? And it's important to understand this isn't a cosmic justice system, right? There's no punishment. It isn't a system of punishment. In that sense, the whole idea of karma is it's just the way things work in the human realm. So when we act well and good things happen, it's not that we're being rewarded—by whom? It's not seen that way. It's just the natural results, consequences of affirming positive, generous, loving, compassionate actions coming from wisdom and selflessness. When the opposite is happening, it's not punishment, it's just the consequences of those actions.

And so, a person should be brought down into evil ways. But because of the scorn and vilification by others in the present, now, now the wicked actions of former ages are extinguished. One might wonder, well, why, as the Buddha said in his own sutra, why, if he's teaching, would he be on the receiving end of scorn and revilement? Sometimes we don't want to hear the truth, so shoot the messenger. Another scholar said maybe it's because this sutra, which is a Mahayana sutra, was being criticized by those of the early Buddhist tradition. Whatever the reason is, it's not so important here.

Hakuin, about this passage, said, "This has been misunderstood by many people, past and present. There is something of significance here, you know. No more can be said about it. Everyone should look at it closely someday." Very interesting. There's something of great significance here, you know. I can't say anything more than that, but someday, one day, get around to looking into it. Sometimes when you understate something, it's like a shout.

So again, the teaching is that because of past actions, the scorn or revilement that I'm receiving is a result of earlier actions. It is in that moment—if I respond well—that they will be extinguished. I will free myself of that karma. But what is it that's liberated?

So again, that's a practice way of looking at it. That's an essential way of understanding this. That is how we practice. I mean, every moment when we are practicing and something arises that we could easily respond to out of our habitual patterns that are not helpful, and we do that, if we pay attention, we will see that it's getting harder, it's getting more difficult. The Buddha said, yeah, you might be getting a little bit of pleasure. That's why we do it. But look underneath and see the danger. But it's pointing to something more ultimate.

In the commentary, it says, "The general idea of this sutra is about the efficacy of the sutra itself and its teachings. Someone like this in former times created hellish deeds, but because of the strength of the sutra's good power, they have not yet suffered because they are practicing within the dharma. Because of scorn and vilification by people in the present age, those wicked actions of former ages are extinguished. This sutra, therefore, can extinguish the wicked deeds of innumerable eons, changing the grave to become light, changing the light to becoming inconsequential, and so on."

And there are many Mahayana sutras that talk about how the sutra itself is not just sacred, but has a power. But then he goes on to say, "Some say that the sutra itself has spiritual power. If so, take a volume of it and lay it in an uncluttered place and see if it has any effect on that room." He quotes Fayan, who said, "Realizing buddhahood is called upholding the sutra." That's how we uphold the sutra—by practicing and realizing it.

In the sutra it says, "All the Buddhas and the teachings of complete awakening of all the Buddhas all come forth from the scriptures. But tell me, what is it that you're calling the sutra? If the power is in the text, then all we should do is put the text in the middle of the room and just carry on as always. What is it that you call the sutra?" he asks.

Because of the scorn and revilement in the present age—not the present age, but in this moment. So the student of this koan has to enter into that very moment. It has to become real and alive.

We create mental images and words that have meaning in our mind all the time. We make it up. Our mind is creating—maybe about something that's right in front of us. Often it's about something that is not in front of us. It may not even exist in the world. But in those mental images and words, they have power, right? How do we know that? Because we react to them. So we have certain thoughts, and we start getting aroused. We have other thoughts, we start getting angry. We have other thoughts and mental images, and we become fearful, and so on. That's showing us that they become—they take on a reality in our mind that we actually start reacting to as though they're real.

And that's a lot of what we're trying to free ourselves of, because we can spend—I mean, just examine how much of the thoughts in your mind on an ordinary day are actually helping you. They're constructive. They're helping you gain more understanding about something. They're leading to some action. They're based in mindfulness. And then how many fall outside of those? I would venture to guess most of them; I hope I'm wrong. But most of us are just caught in obsessive, habitual patterns of thought that actually are not only not helpful but are hurting us in multiple ways.

So in a koan like this, and in much of practice—visualization practices, the four immeasurables—when you hold an image of somebody in your mind, we bring forth words and images that have power. We give them power to make something real. The difference is you're doing this deliberately. You're doing it within mindfulness, and you're doing it in such a way that is based in something that is in accord with the Dharma, so that you can realize something that is Dharma. It's not something that's happening to you. You're summoning this very powerful capacity that we have and putting it to good use.

It's kind of extraordinary, right? We might think that we have to—the instruments of our delusion, we have to, like, stop them and then get rid of them and go to Home Depot and get a whole new set, right? Dharma Home Depot. You know, it's probably much smaller. I don't know, maybe not—probably cheaper. But actually, we take—we don't need to do that because we are already endowed with what we need. We just have to put it to good use.

And so here, the student enters into and creates that world: being scornfully reviled by others as a result of my past actions in the present moment—it's happening right now. By virtue of that, the karma of that, the ongoing consequence, the ongoing weight, life of those actions is dissolved. I'm freed from them. What is that? That's what this koan is bringing the student to.

When there's no defense, no wall, no liking or disliking, no pride that arises, no insecurity, no self—if those things are arising, then that becomes the stuff of what that student has to release themselves from, right? The stuff that we would normally easily respond with some of those things. So if those responses arise in the koan, in a way, that's just showing them that they really are making it real. But now they have to go beyond that, so that when no self arises now, what becomes of that scorn? What becomes of the karma of those previous actions? Where do they live now? What is it that we're calling the sutra?

Think about atonement, right? This is a practice—we talked about this yesterday—that is really important and is really based in this fundamental truth: "All evil karma ever created by me on account of my beginningless greed, anger, and ignorance, born of my body, mouth, and thought, now I atone for it." I don't make excuses, I don't blame anyone, I don't defend myself. I abandon everything. I abandon the self. I atone. There is no distance, no separation. There's only this. Now, where—what remains?

There are many practices of living the life of a Buddha, as Daido said, and fortunately, wonderfully, there are many practices that we can take up at the very beginning, because they're just using your voice, they're just using your mind in ways that are familiar to you, right? So we're given language that is based in wisdom before we know what wisdom is. We're given language and practices that arise out of selflessness before we've experienced that. We're given practices and teachings and invited to bring them into our own body, into our own voice, that are the manifestation of compassion—in moments when we're not really feeling very compassionate. How powerful is that? And in a sense, we're taking the sutra—if you think of just all of those as sutras that seem to exist outside—and we're bringing them in, and at some point, we realize what the scripture is, what the sutra is, and then you're never without it. You can't lose it. No one can take it away.

And so, we have these practices that are so, in a way, accessible. And, as I said yesterday, what's so important is that—and how they work hand in glove with our meditation—because when our minds are scattered, we can do any practice, we can say any words. And that scripture is over there somewhere, right? It's in the room, but it may feel like it's on the other, you know, across the way. Can hardly feel it, touch it. But the more stable our mind is, the more focused, the more developed our meditation is, it comes rushing right up, it crawls right under your skin. It starts moving through your blood. That's turning the polar star, shifting the axis of the earth.

And so if we really see the relationship, this sort of beautiful and essential relationship, between—why do we sit in the morning before a teisho, right? Because zazen, in and of itself, is good, that's enough. And because there is going to be a teisho, we sit so that we can hear, right? So that we can hear more deeply. Take it in more deeply.

The clear jewel is in your palm. Whoever has accomplishment will be rewarded with it. When neither stranger nor friend appear, it has utterly no ability. When the coming and going, the liking and disliking, all the many things begin to fall away, we lose our ability in the most wonderful way. The constant self-making, world-making, delusion-making, suffering-making mind—so busy—can we please let it rest and lose those abilities? We don't need them. Since it has no abilities, then the evil one loses their way, right? So when all the students of the Dharma in the Buddha's time were suddenly in the presence of Mara, and Mara was trying to undermine their practice, get them to lose their way, and the student says, "Oh, I know you now," Mara has lost their way. They have no power.

So I'll end with a poem and thank you for this weekend. It was really nice. I felt very engaged and like it mattered—the subject, because it does. But it's such a gift to be in the presence of that. You know, in the early years when things were very much the same and so different in terms of the climate of Buddhism, what Buddhism was, where it was at in the country, what people understood about it, you know, and oftentimes, you know, people would come here and really, you know, were looking, were sincerely exploring and looking, but, you know, were often not in very much—and that has changed so much. And to be able to practice together with you, and even when people are coming and they don't know yet, they don't know if this is their path, but they are looking. And so in the place where they look, there is sincerity, there is engagement, because they want to know, and that makes all the difference.

So thank you. I'll end with a poem:

Dreaming yesterday, dreaming tomorrow,
Today too is a dream.
Dreaming sorrow, dreaming contentment.
Let us dream every living creature awake.
Let us dream ourselves awake.
Dream yourself awake.
That's a good dream.

Thank you for listening. To find out more about ZMM's programs, retreats, and residency, please visit us online at zmm.org.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Title: Eight Gates Of Zen - Zazen: Shikantaz
Extracted Text:
Good evening everybody.

Seeing all these books, you would be right to be worried and doubting about what might be or getting ready to happen. I will try and redeem myself and gain your trust. So we're going to do a series of mondos—myself, Kokon, and Shosan—on some of the gates. As I mentioned, I'll go opening out. I aim to speak on the others in different ways, at different times. So, how fitting that we would start with zazen. I wanted to focus tonight on shikantaza, and then in the next one, focus on koan. As a way of beginning, before we get into it specifically, I want to lay some groundwork.

I think one of the things to keep in mind is that all things—and specific to what we're doing, all aspects of all forms of practice—are not fixed. They're not unclear, and they're not necessarily ambiguous, but they're not fixed. And so we can think of zazen—breath awareness, shikantaza, koan—as a particular practice. Each is a particular practice. We can give instruction, basic instruction. Everyone who takes up a new practice is given some instruction. And then there can be the sense: Well, this is what that is. And that's not not true, but it's not all that it is. Zazen has to be not fixed because you're not fixed. The student is not fixed. Your mind, your practice, your evolving is in a constant state of change.

And so the practice, in a certain sense, has to have a stability, so that every time you go to sit, you have a clear understanding of what you're doing and it meets you. It's not that every time you sit down you're trying to do something different. And at the same time, even with the emphasis we have on teaching within our tradition—face-to-face teaching, a lot of personal guidance in our lineage—most of the time you're guiding yourself, right? Most of the time you're the one who's practicing and responding to whatever you're experiencing.

And so that's why I feel that if we... And what I want to do tonight is start first: What are we doing? What is the aim of zazen? And again, not to nail this down because it can't be. But there is something that we're doing, there is something that we are about, both within Buddha Dharma itself and also in zazen. There are many different ways we could talk about that. As part of what I was trying to get to within myself, I'll sort of begin one way this time, and then when we take up the koan, maybe look at it in a slightly different way.

So, I was looking at this, studying the sutra—an early sutra by the Buddha on dependent origination. It's called the Maha Nidana. Nidana is Sanskrit, maybe Pali, for dependent origination, which is arguably the most important teaching of the Buddha. It encompasses, in a certain way, so much of his teaching, and I would say arguably one of the most important teachings ever brought to humanity. But that's not really what I'm going to talk about. I forgot—I got so swept up. What I wanted to do is draw a little bit from the introduction by Bhikkhu Bodhi, because there he spoke about some things that are familiar to most of us. But again, when things are presented with different language, in a different way, it can be illuminating.

So, he's drawing from the sutra, but he talks about how the Buddha was speaking about, within a particular context, that there is a pathway for what he called designation, for language, and for description. So there's a pathway. Let's think of zazen as a pathway in which we engage in designation, language, and description. So Bhikkhu Bodhi says, first of all, what do we mean? What are we talking about? He says, basically within the commentaries, these words are understood to be synonymous, with minor differences, to mean verbal statements expressive of meaning. So he's talking about language—designating things through language, using language, and describing. And he says the passage can be taken to be talking about the relation between concepts, language, and reality.

So, we are constantly interfacing with, interacting with, responding to, coming to conclusions about our world. And we do that reality—and we do that to a large extent, larger than I think we really know—through language and concepts. That's an important part of what Buddhism is trying to help us to see. But the question is, what relevance is that? Why does that matter?

So, to make it relevant, he says it's necessary to investigate the nature of reference. In other words, in designating, in language, and designation, language, and description—what is being designated? What is being described? Well, something. He's referring to this as a referent—what we're referring to. He says that establishes a connection between ourselves, our experience, and language, words, and things. Designation, language, and description are the tools of reference by which we interpret and evaluate our experience privately to ourselves, and then we communicate those thoughts to others.

So we're having a private experience, but then it's shared through our language with others, and in that way becomes larger. And of course, that private experience becomes more of a common experience as we try to agree on what certain things are and what they mean and so on. He says it's this world of reference—it's the world and all of its many objects—that we are referring to, designating, using language to discuss and describe.

He says, but reference—to refer to something—involves more than simply the indication of something. It's more than just recognizing there's something there. He said it also involves signification, the ascribing of meaning to the referent. While the referent, the object, provides the locus for meaning—what we're focusing on and the meaning we attach to it—the meaning itself is contributed by the mind. The object doesn't have meaning, it's just object. But the mind gives it meaning. It means something to us. What is its significance? When I see it, what does it mean to me? Is it important? Is it not important? Is it worth my attention? Is it not? Do I like it? Do I not?

And this is all a wind-up, right, to get to zazen. Okay, so stay with me here.

So, every morning we chant: "Doing deep prajna paramita, clearly saw emptiness of the five conditions, the aggregates, thus relieving misfortune and pain." I mean, if that line doesn't get anybody's attention—even if you have no idea what the conditions are—something, somebody, this person, this bodhisattva, clearly saw emptiness of these conditions—whatever the hell those are—and relieved misfortune and pain. Don't you want to know what that is?

So the skandhas basically are how Buddhism describes you, the person. In dependent origination, if you're familiar with that, it's name and form. So form is your body. I mean, it can be spoken of in different ways, but let's just take it as your body. You have a physical body in which you experience things physically, which means anything that you can experience tangibly with your senses. And then there's name. Name and form is how it appears in dependent origination. Name are the other skandhas: sensation, conception, discrimination, awareness—what is your mind doing, right?

And so, when it comes into contact, when the mind comes into body, into contact with an object through the body, right—and in a sense, form engages in some other meeting, some other form, an object—what happens? The skandhas are in the way. The Buddha says that's what we are, that's how we create ourselves—it's through the skandhas. It's how we create the world. It's where suffering is born: within the skandhas. That's why that line in the Heart Sutra is so profound, because it's saying, basically, if we understand the nature of the skandhas, we alleviate our pain and suffering.

So here Bhikkhu Bodhi is talking about that. The designation—when we designate, when we add meaning to that—that depends on those aspects of the person or the mental aspect, right? What's happening in our mind, it's the mental body. And remember, don't think of this just as thoughts. It's that aspect of our mind that makes contact through our senses, has perception, recognizes, designates, names, evaluates: like, don't like, neutral, and then responds—begins to create karma.

So he said, it's this in the mental body that designations, linguistic expressions, and descriptions take shape, and from there that they are ascribed—end products of a complex process, drawing upon the contributions of many individual mental factors. So, when we just open our eyes and look—I look at this screen, I see your faces, those of you who are at home—and as far as I can tell, I'm just having an objective, almost a passive experience. Almost passive, except that I'm seeing something of something that's out there that exists by itself. So I'm having an objective experience of an objective reality. Right? I don't see that my mind is in a process, in fact, in a complex process of not only seeing this object, but giving it meaning.

And then he likens it to photographs in a camera. He says, the conceptual and verbal symbols that issue from this mental body can be no more accurate in representing actual reality than the instrument which creates them. Right? So in other words, if you've got a camera that's not working well, it's not reasonable to think that your photographs are going to turn out clear and sharp. Right? If my mind is compromised, is cloudy, is fraught, is consumed, is intoxicated, then that is the instrument through which I'm experiencing the world. It's unreasonable then to think that I'm going to have a clear experience.

And so he goes on to say, when feeling is seized upon as food for desire—feeling here means contact, sensation, when he's going through the skandhas—okay, so form, sensation. When sensation is seized upon as a food, something that feeds my desire. When perception—the next skandha, where I begin to recognize what I'm seeing—becomes a scanning device for finding pleasure and avoiding threats to the ego. So as soon as I begin to perceive something, I want to know: Do I want this or do I not want this? Is this friend or is this foe?

With volition, which we translate as conception—so volition here means intention. It's where we begin to create karma—is driven by greed, anger, and delusion. And our attention, meanwhile, is bouncing around in a very scattered, distracted way, agitated. He says, then one can hardly expect the mental body to mirror the world as it really is—a flawless, precise concept and expression. To the contrary, the system of references that results will be muddled, reflecting our individual biases, our presuppositions, and our wayward emotions, right?

But he goes on to say, the uninstructed worldling—in the early sutras, somebody who's not practicing is often referred to as a worldling or an earthling, which means somebody who's not practicing—the individual, unlearned and untrained, not practicing, does not even suspect the falseness of what we're perceiving, not knowing that their real origins are purely internal. It's not an objective experience one assumes. I assume that I am simply duplicating in thought what exists as concrete fact. So my designation, my description of it, the language that I use, as far as I can tell, is an accurate representation of what I'm experiencing, right? Because that's—I'm just—I haven't examined, right? It's never been brought to my awareness. I've never wondered. So I just take it as a fact.

He says, thus one takes them to possess objectively the meaning we ascribe to them, as standing for a self and its belongings. He says, through the designation "mine," we establish a territory over which I claim control. And that control is me. That's my territory. That's what I need to be in control of, right? Which then, it makes sense that anything that comes into my territory, I want to have some control over, right? And then he says, the objects of these conceptual and verbal manipulations are the aggregates.

And this is important because the aggregates—I think it takes time. It did, is, and has for me to study these, because they can seem very complicated and dense and hard to understand. And sometimes because you encounter them with different translations. So you'll encounter the skandhas, and they'll be translated differently at different times. And sometimes it's hard to keep track of it. And then what is each one? How does that work? How is that the construction of the self? So that's why it bears study.

He says—this is a quote from the Buddha—"there being material form, feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness, these skandhas. It is referring to them, adhering to them, that one considers." It's through that process that one comes to the view or the sort of certainty: this is mine, this is what I am, and this is myself.

He said that's sort of a shorthand way of just talking about the basis of our delusion, because it's with those designations of ourselves—what belongs to me, what I identify as and with, and what I experience as myself—that everything, every bit of trouble and unhappiness and disease and lack of peace arises.

So, he says, correct designation requires that the referent object be designated without overshooting its real nature by attributing to it some significance it does not have. So, kind of a nice way of saying we see something—it's not like we're completely missing the mark—but we overshoot. We project unrealistic, unreal, not actual characteristics, qualities, possibilities, hopes and dreams onto the object. And then, not surprisingly, we are disappointed. We're disappointed because it didn't do what I thought it was going to do, what I saw its potential to do. Dissatisfaction to come.

Okay, so hold that there. Okay, back to the question: What is zazen aiming at?

So, remember that the three trainings are your moral being—not creating harm and bringing about all that is good; samadhi, which does mean to gather the mind—it sort of includes mindfulness, but samadhi actually is more concentration. So it's the development of mindfulness, which is a deeper state of concentration. And the reason samadhi is important is because it has two primary functions. One is it's calming, right? It's settling. Bhikkhu Bodhi says that it puts the kleshas—all these very active and sort of roiling emotions and energies and thoughts and the things that we, you know, that spin us—he says it kind of puts them into a state of suspension. It doesn't eradicate, it doesn't dissolve them. They're still there, but they're just suspended. They're not active. Calming, or letting sort of go quiet. So that's one aspect.

The other is because of that, it then allows the mind to become very concentrated, focused, with a capacity for sort of penetrating insight that isn't available to us when the mind is spinning. It's just not available. Our mind has the capacity for that, but it's not available to us. We can't actually experience things that way because that quality of mind is not present. So that's important. And he makes a point that, you know, in a lot of other forms of meditation, that is the point. That's what meditation in other traditions often are striving towards, because it is powerful, it's good medicine, right? It changes you. It has a transformative effect. But what the Buddha said is, that effect is impermanent. It's dependent upon that particular state of mind. And that ultimately, what frees us is what Avalokiteshvara realized—doing deep prajna paramita within a deep state of concentration, she was able to have a penetrating insight into the emptiness of self.

So those three elements—because the Buddha said, you know, if we're living in accord with our basic nature, which is the precepts, which is also the basic nature of everything in the universe, then we will be living a more joyful life and we won't be generating the need for a lot of remorse and regret, right? Because we're not causing trouble. We're not doing things that then we feel bad about, which is very agitating. And he said that's extremely conducive—not having remorse is extremely conducive to all of the good qualities of mind and emotion and thought that are very conducive to your meditation and your mindfulness, your concentration. And that then is very conducive to your gaining insight. So that's why those three trainings are so tightly and beautifully joined together—because they're all working together.

So, then think about when we begin sitting—I want to get to shikan, but when we begin sitting, what happens? What do you have to deal with? Well, you have to deal with your body, right? And assume some posture and sit in stillness and begin to deliberately bring your mind to attention on the breath, right? And it's not that we have never done those things, but usually unless we've meditated, we haven't done them in this particular way and within a teaching. And so then we encounter our breath, right? We've been breathing every single moment of our life, right? And suddenly it gets very complicated. There's tension. It's taut. We're panting, we can't find the breath. And we're trying to focus our mind. And so we might get very tense in that focus because we're trying to focus and not have our mind wander, so we sort of tighten. And so we experience discomfort. We want to go away from that, right? But we're trying to stay. We experience things that we like. We want to go with them, run away with them, but we're trying not to do that. It's very hard. It's very tempting. We do. But then we come back. But then we run. But then we come back. But then we run, because that's a lot more exciting than what's happening right now.

And then we experience things we don't like. And we have a lifetime of strategies about what to do about that. And we employ them unconsciously. We don't even know it. We avoid, we deny, we blame, we numb, we go to sleep. So we're living on the cushion, and it just keeps happening. But now it happens within a mind that is developing an awareness. I see. I see you. And the "you" is me. And we are deliberately trying to stay focused and let go, right? So now we become more keenly aware of this thing we call attachment, right? And how deeply embedded it is, how habitual it is. How even when I want to let go, oftentimes I don't seem to be able to.

There's a great deal that is happening when we begin sitting. And, you know, of course, we're not aware of all of that at once. If we did, we'd just be overwhelmed. We're aware of, in individual moments, certain aspects. So in one moment we're the breath. The next moment we're aware of something going on in the body. Next moment we realize our mind has wandered and we're back to the breath. So it's like it's manageable, right? Because in a way, we're just dealing with discrete moments that are bringing a discrete sensation, contact, into our attention. And then what do we do? We perceive it, we name it, we recognize it, we like it or we don't like it, we have a strategy around that, we react to it. It's contest. And who is doing all of that? The self. The sense of self is doing it. I am doing that. I don't want this. I want this. I am meditating. I'm letting go.

And what's happening in almost every moment is designation, description, and language. My mind is constantly engaging. I remember thinking early in my training, my practice, when I was here, just the spontaneous way in which my mind would label something when it came, name it. And I remember thinking, I guess that'll always happen. I couldn't imagine that that would not happen, because I couldn't ever remember it not happening. I remember when my mind was starting to get settled down, I remember I was sitting—I was working on this dairy farm upstate. I remember sitting one morning, and I became aware my mind was fairly quiet, but I was aware that there was kind of a background dialogue, just a mumbling, no real content in the background. I wasn't losing my attention, but it was still running. And I remember thinking, I guess that will always be there too. I couldn't imagine that it would ever not be there, right? And all of those things that I just assume—I guess I just have to, you know, meditators just live with this, this is permanent—aren't. Right? They fade.

Okay, so I wanted to start with sort of both a conceptual, if you will, basis to just so that when we're sitting, you're not just following a rule, right? We do need instructions. We do need to have a sense of how to sit. That's really important. But then at the same time—and I think the Zen tradition has a very keen appreciation of this—how quickly we can get attached to just following a rule, right? As though that's all I need to do, and somehow I don't really have to be too actively a part of this and discerning at any given moment—just keep following the rule. And so I think if we understand sort of what zazen is a response to, why are we sitting—the more I practice, the more I think there is no more perfect response than zazen. It's almost like, you know, if you get to a certain point, which maybe only comes through zazen, it's like, how could you—how could I not do this if I want to follow this path?

I wanted to read a little bit—I forgot about this—I wanted to read a little bit from Roshi. He said, this is from the Eight Gates: "Without zazen, there is no Zen. Zazen..." He's speaking from a very particular perspective; he's talking to practitioners of Zen who center their focus in zazen. There are many, many people who are, you know, part of the Zen tradition or believe, you know, sort of identify as Zen Buddhist, but don't meditate. Okay, so this could also be seen as a kind of a biased view—anyway, it is. But it's a good one, right? "Without zazen, there is no Zen. Zazen is the manifestation of the 10,000 dharmas, of the Great Way itself. We can study sutras and liturgy and art, body and mind, but without zazen they remain only the study of sutras, liturgy, art, body and mind. Not yet the study of the Great Way. To study face to face with a great teacher, or even with the Buddha himself, remains only study. It is not yet the eye-to-eye, mind-to-mind intimacy of the Way that is realized through zazen. Zazen itself is the miraculous manifestation of supreme enlightenment. As such, all things sacred and secular, all the so-called dragons and snakes, when encountered through zazen, reveal the marvelous mind of nirvana, the exquisite teaching of formless form, the very body and mind of the Tathagata. Zazen gives life to the Buddha."

So I wanted to start with that ground and then just read a couple of short teachings from within our tradition about what zazen is really about. In the Platform Sutra, Huineng said: "Good friends, when we practice and we don't contemplate the mind, we don't contemplate purity, and we don't talk about dispassion. If someone says to contemplate purity, your nature is already pure. It's because of deluded thoughts that reality is obscured. But once you are free of deluded thoughts, your original nature is already pure. If someone cultivates dispassion—that is detachment, like equanimity, not entanglement—as long as they don't pay attention to the faults of others, their nature is dispassionate. But deluded people act dispassionate, then open their mouths and talk right and wrong and turn their backs on the Way. Meanwhile, contemplating the mind and contemplating purity are actually what separates them from the Way. Some of you will remember this: We should realize clearly, however, this is not meditation, not contemplation, not visualization, not mindfulness. It is not found to be in the mudra, mantra, koan, neither in its stillness nor its functioning, its seated nor its active form, can zazen be said to be meditation. It is not single-pointed mind, which is often used to describe samadhi, no-mind, aware-mind, or trans-mind. It is not revealed in words and letters and is only transmitted one-to-one from Buddha to Buddha."

In the Vimalakirti Sutra, Vimalakirti comes upon Shariputra, who is sitting in meditation. And Vimalakirti says, "Reverend Shariputra, this is not the way to absorb yourself in contemplation." Now, Shariputra is one of the foremost disciples of the Buddha. He knows how to meditate. "You should absorb yourself in contemplation so that neither body nor mind appear anywhere. You should absorb yourself in contemplation in such a way that you can manifest all ordinary behavior without forsaking cessation—that is, without getting entangled in anything. Absorb yourself in contemplation in such a way that you can manifest the nature of an ordinary person without abandoning your cultivated spiritual nature. Sit in such a way that the mind neither settles within nor moves without toward any external form."

In another passage, he's not talking specifically about zazen, but he's talking about the Dharma, which is zazen. And he says, "Shariputra, if you're truly interested in the Dharma, you're truly interested in zazen, you should take no interest in anything." And Robert Thurman, who translated this edition, this copy, has a footnote. And he says, "This concludes Vimalakirti's definition of the religion of Buddhism in its true sense. If you really are interested in the Dharma, in zazen, take no interest in anything." And then he goes on to say, "Any personal interest that is self-centered, self-clinging interest in anything—even Dharma, or Nirvana, or zazen—is nonetheless a selfish, self-clinging interest. And the Dharma obtains only in the absence of self, absence of selfish interest."

A student was asked, "Master Zhaozhou, what is meditation?" And Zhaozhou said, "It's not meditation." And the student says, "What is it?" And Zhaozhou said, "It's alive."

Hongzhi said, "A person of the Way fundamentally does not dwell anywhere, takes no interest in anything." So all of these teachings, all these teachers are really pointing at something.

Okay, you know what Daido Roshi is doing in that passage, which he would, you know, he repeated many times over the years—and it's very similar to what happens in the Heart Sutra—he's saying: "Oh, you think it's this? No, it's not that. You think it's this? No, it's not that. You're going to settle down in this view? No, not that. Well, then it must be that. No, not that. But the teachings say—yeah, but not that." A person of the Way fundamentally does not dwell anywhere.

So, shikantaza we think of as realizing oneself through the manifestation of that which you are practicing to realize. That's what Daido Roshi is pointing to when he says, when you sit in that moment, you are manifesting—but you're manifesting Buddha mind. And in shikantaza, we do that by putting nothing before you. In koan practice, the koan student does it by putting something before you and then realizing that you have not put anything in front of you.

One more and then we'll open this up. He says, "Zazen is not a means to enlightenment; it is the complete action of the Buddha himself. Zazen itself is pure and natural enlightenment. This is the basis of Dogen's teachings: Practice and enlightenment are one. It's very easy for us to take for granted this simple practice we call zazen. It's easy to sit there thinking that counting the breath, following the breath, penetrating koan is what zazen is all about. But zazen is much more than this. Even beginners in their first moments of sitting are manifesting the life of the Buddha in their zazen. Having raised the body-mind to place yourself in the posture of zazen, the mind of enlightenment is in itself the manifestation of the life of Buddha. And with our zazen, we build confidence every day." And he goes on from there.

So what I wanted to do was draw in some teachings of Hongzhi, which, as most of you know, are very poetic, sort of invoking images and imagery. And, you know, it's not didactic. It doesn't say, okay, do this, do this, do this, don't. But as a way of looking at: What does he describe? Why those images? What are those images evoking, and how can those images actually guide us, right? So it can be helpful and necessary at times to receive some degree of instruction, right? And there's also, as I said, a danger, a certain danger in that if we cling too tightly to that, right? Because ultimately, if we want to be a person of the Way, then we should not dwell anywhere.

Okay, so let me just pause first and see if—I know I just laid out a whole bunch of stuff. Let's see if there are any questions or comments.

---

**Question:** So when you said, and you mentioned a couple times, "take no interest in anything," what came to my mind was, is that the same thing as curiosity without words? Because, you know, from the Western point of view, "take no interest in anything" is like the opposite of what we're taught.

**Response:** Well, that's why, you know, it's so important that, you know, who is the spokesperson of the Heart Sutra? Avalokiteshvara, the Bodhisattva of compassion, who is speaking on behalf of the Buddha, but is very much engaged in the world in alleviating suffering. And so if she has realized that in its deepest state, that clearly is not leading her to a state of being passive or complacent or uncaring, right? So "curiosity without words"... I don't know. I mean, I want to talk a little bit about the role of inquiry because in zazen—in the breath practice, for the most part, certainly in beginning years—there's no real... Usually there's—the focus is on developing our seat, right? It's on developing our mindfulness, settling the body, learning how to work with our karma, the consequences of our karma in terms of things that we don't like and we find difficult, working with emotions. And by working with, I don't mean engaging in a thoughtful, analytic way in the sense of we might do in other times, but working with through Dharma practice, you know, as an object that is arising in our meditation in a way that's described in the teachings.

So we're developing our capacity to be fully present and aware to all of the things that we would normally react to and get entangled in, because they keep coming, without getting entangled—which is not a small thing, right? At all. And that, as I said earlier, is, you know, goes hand-in-hand, is happening while and at the same time that things are calming. That's what allows us to be less reactive, right? To not get so entangled. We don't get so reactive and entangled because those things that are arising are not as strong as they were. And even as they do come back strongly, we're developing more of a ground, a basis of stability, of mindfulness, so that we're not so easily tipped over and get lost and lose our awareness, which means we can't—in those moments of being overwhelmed with it, we can't actually practice it. But we're sort of under the sway of it until our awareness returns.

So in the breath practice, that's what we're doing. That really all-important essential work that goes on, in a certain way, forever, you know, except in those increasing moments where the self isn't arising and the kleshas aren't manifesting and you're not entangled and there is nothing to react to. And so in the breath practice, it's mostly developing that. This can also depend on how a person's working with, how they're being guided, how long they sit with it. It can bring in inquiry. In koan study, koan study is a very explicit way of engaging in investigation right through the koan. The koan presents you with a question or something that needs to be resolved and resolved in a direct, experiential, non-conceptual way—in other words, to be realized. And that has its own strengths and possibilities and its own dangers. So there are very particular ways in which a student can get caught and trapped in koan work.

Shikantaza basically takes all that away. There is no object. And so there are different ways in which a person can get trapped and caught within shikantaza, okay? Because these practices are not something that's happening to us; we're bringing ourselves to them. And so to the degree that we are still dwelling somewhere, that we are entangled, we are still reacting, we will do all of those things in that particular form of zazen. That's all.

---

**Question:** Mike asks, "If the realization of emptiness entails the cessation of meaning-making, I-making, mind-making, etc., how is this realization distinct—and I'm hoping it is—from an experience of vast meaninglessness? It certainly feels like the opposite of that."

**Response:** Go back, I missed a word. How is it—what? How is this realization distinct from an experience of vast meaninglessness? Because meaninglessness is dwelling somewhere resolutely. It's really taking the position in the mind that nothing has any meaning. That's a very particular view, right? It's a perspective. It's a position that one can hold on to. It's a misunderstanding in a sense, and not clear even if there is some experience. Usually, it's more of a conceptual response to the teachings of emptiness, that if I experience emptiness, I imagine that to be something. And I imagine in that state the world to appear in a certain way, which results in "nothing has any meaning anymore." But that has nothing to do with the experience of emptiness. That's a whole lot of dwelling somewhere, right?

But it's an important question because that question has been raised since the time of the Buddha. That concern or that assumption that that's what emptiness will bring you. And so since the time of the Buddha, there have been an ongoing generation after generation response to that concern, that critic, or that doubt. And so if a person—and I encounter students and people who are sort of a little caught in that, you know, as they're practicing and letting go, sometimes they start to feel like, you know, where they're headed is "nothing has any meaning, there's no purpose," right? But in those moments, they're really wandering away from actually practicing and they're getting more and more caught in thoughts about things, projections.

The Buddha said, "Great is the gain of concentration when it is based in virtuous conduct. Great is the gain of wisdom when it is based in concentration." Right? Again, how these three aspects of training work together. And then remember that when we're practicing, we're just—we're talking about zazen tonight. But we should never separate that from the Eightfold Path in our training, from the Eight Gates, from living a life within the Precepts, cultivating compassion, living with other people, being wholehearted, raising aspiration, working with difficulty. In other words, we're engaged in all of the affirming and life-giving aspects of Buddhadharma. And we're also engaging, when they arise, with all those sort of life-destroying or life-denying aspects of our self. And we're diminishing those and we're strengthening all the life-affirming aspects. And the stream that runs through all of that is zazen.

So zazen is not happening in isolation. It's happening within all of these different forms of practice and experiences and ways that we're being influenced and stimulated and reminded and brought back and motivated. Okay, so all of this is helping to both strengthen all of this and also keep things, in a certain way, in their proper place and keep them in a proper relationship with each other. Right? So it's whole. It's a whole path. It's a whole complete endeavor. And I think that helps to... That when we get into—and we sort of go down dark alleys in our practice, that's not happening in some way. That's not happening. Okay. We've kind of gotten caught up in a gully somewhere. Okay. So we need to find our way back.

---

**Question:** Thank you. Yeah. You spoke about not dwelling in a place—that's part of our zazen practice. And yet—and so I want to know something about the relationship between that sensibility of allowing things to flow and developing focus and concentration on a seemingly, like, an object such as the breath, for instance. Because in the beginning we look at it as an object, for sure. And then—so what is, like, a focus like that with—and not an object, but merging, maybe, or...?

**Response:** Yeah, yeah, that's a really good question. It's—and I think part of what is so beautiful about the Dharma and the teachings in practice is that, you know, when we come in and begin practicing, we just—we bring everything we are and have been to it. So we're going to keep doing the same thing within the practice of zazen. So we're going to bring our attention to the breath, and that is going to be an object to us, right? The practice that we're doing, we're going to keep assigning meaning to. "This is good zazen. This is not good zazen. I'm a good practitioner. I'm not. This is a good thought. This is not a good thought." I mean, is any of this unfamiliar to you? Right? That's why I wanted to start with that first part, you know, in which we designate something, we recognize something, we use language to describe it. And then, very importantly, as Bhikkhu Bodhi said, extremely important, we add meaning. You know, the teaching about not judging—that's the meaning. That's like pulling up to the meaning, you know, and filling it up. And that's where it gets complicated. Because once it means something, meaning is not something that just floats around out there in the void. It's meaning in relationship to me, myself. What does this mean about me? So when I'm having a gnarly or a nasty thought, or I'm angry as hell and I don't want to be, that that's threatening my sense of who I think I am, who I want to be. So we've got a problem, right? All that's happening is I am experiencing a certain kind of energy that's arising within me in a certain kind of way that I have learned and recognize and call anger. And once I name it, to me, it's filled—what that means to me is all there. And that's what I get entangled in. I'm not getting entangled in just the sensation. I'm getting caught in what it means to me, right? That's what I want to deny and push away, or that's what I want to hold on to. Because what this means to me is, "I'm good. This is good. We are good."

And so, coming back to your question, in every moment when we are calming, slowing down, suspending that response, when we do that, we're definitely—subject and object duality is very much present. But in every moment when I begin to not react that way, let go of that, soften that hard sense of boundary and sense, subject is beginning to soften. It's not so strong, right? I mean, when people begin to have an experience, like, you know, at the beginning of sesshin, you hate everybody. At the end of sesshin, you love everybody, right? They're the same people, right, as they were at the beginning. But some kind of boundary, right, hard boundary, is beginning to dissolve. And so that non—that sense of nonduality, which is a concept, is beginning to actually be experienced before we might even recognize it.

**Follow-up:** So does that come from the... I'm going to use the word, not the calming, but I'm sure that's part of it, like the actual focus and merging with the object so that it's no longer an object?

**Response:** Yeah. Okay, so again, remember, the samadhi has that aspect of calming, you know, the roiling energies, but also strengthens the natural capacity we have for a very strong, focused, penetrating concentration. Which means it's not dwelling. It's not—when you're using the word "dwelling," to me, it feels more like making a world, you know, making a nest.

**Follow-up:** Well, but more simply, there's just me and the breath and we're there. You know, I am observing the breath. There's me and there's my breath, and sometimes it's there, sometimes it's not. I bring it back. So there's a sense of subject and object. But the stronger, the more the mind calms and the stronger that concentration develops, that concentration, in a sense, seems to be bringing me into a more intimate experience of the breath, where that sense, that constant awareness of me, me, me and it, it, is beginning to drop away, as will time. You know, sounds, other experience through the senses will just sort of pass through. We don't open on them. And all of that that's softening are the ways in which that sort of strengthens and continually affirms the sense of me. And that...

Okay, let's do this. We'll take a break.

---

**(after break)**

This is from Hosui: "It's my understanding that to expose our seeking mind, we need to look at the meaning beneath the words, not the words themselves or the objects they point to. And don't we have to use words and language to dismantle them? Is this correct understanding?"

**Response:** Well, I'm using a few tonight. Right. I'm not sure what you mean by "dismantle," because that could be understood as, you know, through a kind of logical languaging process. I'm going to kind of deconstruct... Does she say anything more specific about the...?

**Follow-up:** No, I would say—and this gets more... Hosui? Is this Hosui? The first sentence, the first bit that I didn't read out: "I would like to go back to the nature of words and language, which are how thoughts are expressed." That's the bit that I like.

**Response:** So there's a different way—I mean, that can be helpful—but there's a different way of, you might say, analyzing or seeing into the nature of words and language, which is the more inquiry aspect of zazen, of meditation.

Okay, so let's take a little break, let's say about five minutes or so, and then we'll come back. And I want to bring up some of these passages from Hongzhi and relate them more specifically to shikantaza.

---

**(after break)**

This aspect in... I'm sorry, one of the distinctive aspects of Buddhist meditation is those three trainings: the sila, the samadhi, and prajna. So there's wisdom, but it's not just—it's inquiry. And so in the Theravada tradition, there's samadhi and there's vipassana, right? Which is usually translated as insight or clearly seeing and knowing. And so then the question becomes, well, how does that come about? So if a strong, focused concentration helps to bring forth a more penetrating mind, how does that bring about insight, given that that insight by its definition has to be nondual? In other words, there has to be the dropping away of not just concepts and meaning, but a sense of self, a sense of object, a sense of doing, striving, of accomplishing.

And so again, in the koan, that's part of the struggle: you're given an object and then the challenge is, now resolve that—you know, directly experience what that question is pointing to without holding on and turning it into something, much less cogitating on it.

Shikantaza doesn't give you anything. So normally when we speak of shikantaza, it's just awareness, just sitting, with a sort of emphatic "just." And so it's not constructing or discriminating. So it's, in a sense, the supreme practice of not doing, which is not passive, because passivity is just another form of doing. It is dwelling somewhere. At the same time, it's not exerting. So it's not passive. There is effort, but it's not exerting.

So when Huineng says don't contemplate the mind or purity, when Vimalakirti says take no interest... FYI, last I heard was "take no interest."

There you go. Take no interest. That's where they lost...

Oh, okay.

So, Dogen says, "Be it known that for studying the way, the established means of investigation is a pursuit of the way. In seated meditation, the essential point..." So he says that there is a practice of investigation. So we are investigating something, inquiring into something. And the essential point that distinguishes that particular kind of investigation is understanding that there is a practice of a Buddha that does not seek to make a Buddha. Since the practice of a Buddha is not to make a Buddha, this is the realization of the koan that in and of itself a seated Buddha does not interfere with making a Buddha.

So let me think of the images I often think of and have been helped by—the images that are often used in relating to shikantaza. A boundless sky, right? It's boundless because it is just sky. It's just empty space. It doesn't expand or contract. It is not something. And so it doesn't interfere with anything. It has no opinion. It doesn't get larger or smaller. Sometimes it seems to be—appears to be—filled with clouds, sometimes it seems to be bright and blue, but it's never not the sky. It doesn't discriminate. And so in a very real sense, we're returning or bringing the whole of one's being into that perfect state which we call Buddha, right? But it's not just a matter—it's not just enough to be in that state. There has to be—we have to realize it. So there has to be a shift, a subtle shift in the mind, where, as Dogen says, we make intimate contact with the unseen. And this is where words just—you know, we have to leave them. This is where the instruction, what we know, we have to leave behind, right? You have to go in alone.

That passage I think I spoke of last week—Dogen says, "We should not value what is far away. Do not despise it, just become completely familiar with it. Do not despise what is near at hand and do not value it. Become completely familiar with it. Don't take the eyes lightly—and eyes here mean all, every sense—and don't give them weight. Don't overreach, don't add meaning, don't have an opinion. It's just become completely familiar with it. Make the eyes and ears sharp and clear." That's basically it.

So now what? So let's look at a few passages from Hongzhi. I was reading an article recently of Zuise that she—I don't remember, it was in publication—and she quoted Yasutani Roshi on shikantaza, who said, "Shikantaza is like sitting in the center of a clearing in the forest, knowing that ultimate danger is about to strike, but not knowing what form it will take or from what direction it will come." If you look at his photograph on the Ancestors Hall, it's a little bit like this, I just imagine.

So, okay, but before the—the sentiment—just imagine yourself in that position. What state of mind are you in?

**Comment:** I mean, I understand that the response is that I'm awake and alert. But I feel like it's also true to say I would be, like, fearful and anxious. I don't know. I don't know how skillful I find that metaphor, that's all.

**Response:** Yeah, yeah, I acknowledge that. So I felt the same way. And I thought it was—it was just so evocative, stark. But that sense of, you know, imagining yourself in a place where you're not in danger, right? But that you're—there's a level of alertness that is not focused on any one place or one thing because it's spacious, right? So you're not looking here or there, right? Okay, so we'll just forget about that if it didn't work for you.
