Yet, one of the strengths of the Zen teachings has been its unique ability to metamorphose and adapt in accord with the imperative of time and place, circumstance, degree. On the other hand, at the core of this ancient tradition remains a critical, immutable truth that does not change—the heart of the Buddhist teachings, which has been conveyed for the past 2,500 years plus in Zen's journey across the face of the earth.

And then he said, "It's my sincere wish that the readers of this book will discover for themselves that the spirit and authenticity of these teachings are still alive and intact in these pages." And really, he means in these forms of training.

Let us show him that that is so. That would be a nice thing to give to Daido Roshi, because of whom we are here this morning.

Thanks so much for listening.

For meditation supplies such as cushions, incense, liturgical instruments, Dharma books, and more, visit monasterystore.org—support for your spiritual practice at home.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Title: Cold And Heat
Extracted Text:
The following Dharma discourse was given by Jeffrey Shugan Arnold at Zen Mountain Monastery. Shugan Roshi is the Head of the Mountains and Rivers Order and Abbot of the Monastery. This talk, like all of our talks, is offered free of charge. If you would like to make a donation or find out more about our various programs, visit us online at zmm.org. Thank you for listening.

This is from the Blue Cliff Record, Tungshan’s No Cold or Heat.

Pointer: 10,000 ages abide by the phrase that determines heaven and earth. Even the thousand sages cannot judge the ability to capture tigers and rhinos without any further traces of obstruction. The whole being appears everywhere equally. If you want to understand the hammer and tongs of transcendence, you need the forge and bellows of an adept. But say, since ancient times, has there ever been such a family style or not? To test, I’m citing this old case. Look.

A student asked Master Dongshan, “When cold and heat come, how can we avoid them?” Dongshan said, “Why don’t you go to the place where there is no cold or heat?” The student said, “What is the place where there is no cold or heat?” Tungshan said, “When it’s cold, the cold kills you. When it’s hot, the heat kills you.”

The verse: He lets down his hand, but still it’s the same as a 10,000 fathom cliff. Why must correct and biased be in an arrangement? The ancient Crystal Palace reflects the bright moon. The sly hound of Han vainly runs up the stairs.

So maybe there were one or two things you came into this sesshin that you would be happy to avoid or ignore, or would be delighted if they would go away. That’s not a new thing. It’s been around a long time. The Buddha said over and over again that the path is about the cause of suffering, the cessation of suffering. It’s about the cause of that which we’d like to avoid, and it’s about the cessation of that which we would like to avoid.

Abiding by the phrase that determines heaven and earth, Haukin says there’s no particular phrase that settles the universe. There’s only one phrase. The whole place, in its entirety, is the phrase that settles the universe. The whole place, the whole mind, the whole body.

The world just seems like it’s all cut up and divided, and we too just become part of the same formula—cut up and divided. The Buddha said it’s inevitable then that there will be conflict, and that conflict will be hard to avoid.

And so, if we want to understand the hammer and tongs of transcendence, we have to use the forge and bellows. That’s what we call practice. In the monastic tradition, there’s a sense or idea of formation. The monastic enters and begins a process of formation. I think that’s a wonderful and true description. We can also talk about the formation of a bodhisattva, the formation of an enlightened being. Having Buddha nature from the beginning, still there needs to be formation.

And so, we can talk about holding on and letting go, and stopping and seeing. Have faith that we’re like a priceless jewel that is covered with a little bit of dust and dirt obscures it. But this basic matter of wanting to avoid—when cold comes, how can I avoid it? It’s an honest question.

The footnote says, cold and heat are right in your face, all over, all throughout. Can’t really avoid it. Although, my goodness, we try. Think about how strong is the desire, the impulse, and the belief in avoiding what we dislike. From a place of distinct and separate, it makes sense. If you’re trying to cross the street and the street’s filled with traffic, you don’t just run out into it. There is something there.

I remember years ago when I was living in a temple, I took a long bike ride all the way up the West Side Greenway, up into the northern part of the island. No, I went up the east side because then I wanted to come back the west side. But I was way up, way up, way up. And I knew that the Greenway was down there, over there, but there were a bunch of woods. So I thought, well, I’ll just cut down through the woods and cross over and get on it so I don’t have to go back and go the long way. So I came down and there was about a four-foot wall and then there was the West Side Highway. It was extremely busy and I thought, I am not going back through those woods, I’m going across. So with my bicycle, I had to jump down, run across and not die. And I remember telling Dai An about this when I got back. She said, “Do not tell me these things.”

So avoiding sometimes is just plain common sense. When you touch a hot pan, your hand responds with wisdom, with intelligence. It knows what to do. It doesn’t need to think, it doesn’t discriminate, it doesn’t hate the pan, it just responds. It’s not avoiding anything. It’s immediate, spontaneous. So there’s the wisdom of not doing what is harmful. I mean, that’s what practice is about. That’s what the precepts are about. Sitting zazen is recognizing what is helpful and what is not. Understanding the nature of causation is understanding what actions lead to what consequences.

“All things everywhere equally” doesn’t mean that fire won’t burn your skin or extreme cold won’t cause frostbite, or that being burned is the same as getting frostbite. You and I are different, but we have the same nature. What is that? So how do we free ourselves?

This is really important to understand: that alleviating suffering doesn’t mean that an enlightened being becomes invulnerable to the elements, or that their body no longer has nerve endings that will send a message of pain to the brain. In the Mahaparinirvana Sutra, the Buddha talks about, very close to the end of his life, getting extremely sick and being in extreme pain. And that because it was not time yet for him to die, he bent it back, but there it was.

So think of just in an ordinary day like today, for example, how many moments has something arisen that you didn’t really like? It’s very simple, very ordinary, very common, very familiar. How many moments were there where you would have liked something else? Maybe in a small way, maybe in a big way. How often did that lead to judging and comparing? Or did it arise from judging or comparing? Did it end up blaming somebody or something for something? Was there frustration or resentment?

The Buddha taught that there is freedom through non-avoidance. How is this?

And so this student asks this question: “When cold and heat come, how can we avoid them?” Dongshan says, “Why don’t you go to a place where there is no cold or heat?” The footnote says the world’s people cannot find it. The world’s people cannot find it. Because we need a path, we need some wisdom. We need to know what we’re dealing with. But even Buddhas cannot find it. But that’s not the same. It’s not a place.

Faith Mind says, “Neither love nor hate, and you will clearly understand. When there is neither cold nor heat, then you know.”

Tenkei Denson said, “The twin roads of life and death are what students suffer over. This question here refers to them—life and death as cold or heat.” And you could just pick any duality, the duality of your choice du jour or of the moment, because it’ll change and then there’ll be a new one. Something that I don’t want means there’s something that I do want. Something that’s not good means something that there is good. Something that’s hurting means there’s something that’s not hurting—the twin roads.

The footnote also says, as soon as Dongshan lets down his hook, the student climbs onto it, like fishing. And actually, Tungshan wants that. Dongshan wants his student to climb on. He wants the student to respond. He welcomes the question. But really, he wants the student to climb on their own hook. He wants the student to, as they must, come to understand themselves.

I remember in the early years, for a while—probably longer than it needed be—there were so many times when things would arise in my mind, questions. And I would think about taking them to Dokusan and ask to understand it. And I would think, but I have to be the one to ultimately understand this, so what’s the point in asking? And then after a while, I realized—and in many brief Dokusans I realized—I’m not even giving him a chance to teach me. Yes, ultimately I have to know, I have to be the one. But how? Right? I’m not even giving him a chance. I’m not asking questions so he can throw out a hook that I can climb onto.

So Dongshan says, well, what is the place where there is no cold or heat? The student asks that: what is the place where there is no cold or heat? There’s got to be a place. Tell me and I will go there. Because I would very much like to avoid this.

The footnote says, the real does not conceal the false. The crooked does not hide the straight. So much seems hidden in practice. Things begin to be revealed. We begin to see things about ourselves, about our mind. We begin to have experiences—simple experiences, natural experiences within our meditation—that are affirming what the teachings are pointing to. We begin to realize nothing was actually hidden. I just didn’t see it. And the true does not conceal the false. Crooked doesn’t conceal the bent. It’s another way of saying, don’t waste anything. Don’t decide in advance something isn’t useful.

Haukin, speaking about this, said, when the monk asks the question, “What is this place?” Haukin says the student conceives an interpretation following the words and is trying to figure this out. The student doesn’t realize yet that they’ve been given a method of changing their bones. So often we just want to rearrange things a little bit on the surface. Just move the furniture a bit, make it more comfortable, make it work a little bit better. But the teacher wants us to change our bones, like a complete realignment from the inside.

An old master picked out this koan and said, “Dongshan puts the collar on the sleeve and cuts off the shirt front, under the armpits.” In other words, he’s just turning himself inside out for this student. But what could he do? The student didn’t like it.

And then another student, hearing this, came up and says, “Well, how then should they be dealt with?” And after a long silence, the master said, “Peaceful meditation does not require mountains and rivers. When you have extinguished the mind, fire itself is cool.”

Peaceful meditation does not require a certain time and place, a tranquil setting, a sesshin, silence, the right conditions for a long time. It can greatly benefit from those things. That’s why we create them. The Buddha said, go to a quiet and secluded place. Vimalakirti is revered as going into the busiest place possible to practice, recognizing that that would be a very advanced practice.

But this teacher is saying, we should know, though, that mountains, rivers—the perfect setting—is not required. Just extinguish the mind. Just let the mind come to an absolute rest. Then the fire itself is cool.

And so where is this place where there’s no cold or heat? Tungshan said, go to the place where the cold kills you. Go to the place where the heat kills you. Another translation says, where the cold destroys you. Stark. But what is being killed? It’s language to get our attention. To say let the mind rest is true, but it can sound a little bit too nice. We might miss it. But to say let the cold kill you makes you sit straight up. What it’s like if you meet the Buddha—kill the Buddha. What? What kind of killing is this? What is it that’s being killed? What is the distress?

If the Buddha’s enlightenment and the alleviation of his suffering was a result of him having transformed the world into a place where there was no longer greed, anger and delusion, pride and jealousy, no more conflict, no more division, no more hatred, then we wouldn’t need to be here, right? He would have done it. He would have said, no, you don’t need to change your bones, just change everything else. But that’s not it.

We change our bones because we can’t control the world. We can do stuff in the world. No one is without influence, and much needs changing. But to alleviate at a deep level ultimately means, just as peaceful meditation doesn’t require mountains and rivers, nor does liberating ourselves.

Another master asked a student, “When it’s so hot, where will you go to avoid it?” The student said, “I’ll avoid it inside a boiling cauldron, within the coals of a furnace.” The master said, “How can it be avoided in a boiling cauldron?” The student said, “The multitude of sufferings cannot reach here.”

There’s a koan in the miscellaneous early collection of koans that says, “How do you stop the suffering?” It’s directly this.

There’s another koan that says that there was a student who was studying with a master and came to take their leave. The teacher said, “I don’t have anything to give you, so I’ll give you this.” And he turned towards the charcoal burner and with tongs picked up a red hot piece of charcoal and gave it to the student. And the student did not know how to receive it. And so they stamped off and went back to their room and sat for some days. And then the koan says, then they came back to take their leave. The teacher handed them this red hot coal. And now the student knew how to receive it. And the question, of course, is, how did they receive it?

Think about just the very beginning of zazen. You begin sitting and pretty soon, very often, you experience a little bit of discomfort. Maybe your legs are tight, maybe they go to sleep, maybe there’s a little bit of pain. Maybe you have some difficult memories, maybe some emotion comes up. Maybe the person next to you is breathing too loud. How do you avoid that?

Well, you probably know how not to avoid it in the sense of dislike it, hate it, wish it wasn’t happening, want it to go away, getting angry, and then it gets—what?—stronger. It gets stronger. And so in the very beginning of beginning instruction, when there’s pain, you feel pain. Now can you dissolve that distance? Because there can be no—the multitude of sufferings cannot reach there—when you’re not there.

And so to enter fully into your breath, enter fully into the pain, which really means to extinguish your mind into the pain, into the breath, have no idea, no thought, no plan, not be trying to get away. That’s not a bargain you’re making. You’re just releasing, relinquishing, building no wall. Let the pain destroy you, dissolve the sense of you and pain, and it’s yours. And you don’t want to.

You know, those little—I mean, relatively speaking, they’re little—little pains, little discomforts. They can seem mightily big when they’re happening, but in the whole spectrum of possibility, you’re okay sitting here on this cushion experiencing some kind of discomfort. And that, that’s the training ground.

I remember the first time I entered into—because I was in a lot of pain. And the period was a long way off, the end of the period was a long way off. And I thought, gotta do something. And so I did what I had been taught. I turned my attention into that pain, and it wasn’t the same. And I remember thinking, I didn’t move, trying to figure it out, like, what was that? And it was important that I understood that I wasn’t just using, like, mind control, you know, to somehow suppress the pain or suppress my senses or something like that. Because I realized that isn’t actually what I was doing. It was more sort of the opposite, giving up control. And I realized, you know, as simple and slight as that was, that that was showing me something important, more important than I could even know at that time.

So he says in the verse, he lets down his hand, but still it’s the same as a 10,000 fathom cliff. Tungshan’s trying to help. He wants the student to resolve this. He knows how important it is. He knows how it will change a student’s life. But still, it’s as though the student is at the bottom of a 10,000 fathom cliff. Even with a helping hand, we still have to climb.

Why must correct and bias be in an arrangement? If you arrange them, the footnote says, where will you have today? How will you not become involved in dualism?

You know, one of the difficult things or tricky things about this essential teaching, you know, that by turning towards the very thing that we want to avoid—why we sit in stillness, why we practice with a discipline, right? Why we don’t just keep wiggling away, but actually hold ourselves, but hold ourselves well, right? Not just enduring, but actually the opposite. Relinquishing, surrendering, letting go, softening.

One of the tricky aspects about that is that sometimes in living, we’re in difficult situations or with difficult people or in a difficult time. We’re dealing with something very difficult within ourselves. And it can be hard to know. Like, the teaching seems to say, just keep turning in, keep turning in, keep going in with it, stay with it, don’t turn away.

Compassion is the embodiment of wisdom. And wisdom has an aspect of intelligence, right? It’s not one-dimensional, it’s street smart. There’s a common sense to it, you might say. And so how do you know when you’re in a difficult situation or difficult relationship and you have choices? Sometimes you don’t. You have to stay. But if you have choices, how do you know when to stay or when to leave? And in leaving, is that turning away, is that trying to escape, is that avoiding? Is that not good practice? How do we know when a situation is just not healthy, not helpful, not conducive? Sometimes maybe it’s fulfilled its purpose, or maybe there is a potential in that situation for it to be something different or for us to be at it in a different way. We sense that, but sometimes we may need to acknowledge there is the potential. But I don’t have that capacity right now.

And as a practitioner, that can be a tough discernment because it can feel like a failure. It can feel like not doing what the teachings are encouraging us to do. There may be a way to find peace in here, but I can’t find it right now. And I have tried. So how to know when to shift and when to keep turning towards? Is there a way of shifting, stepping back, turning away without turning away, without creating more dualism? There needs to be. We need to find that.

Practice is not a fixed rule. In a very real sense, in time, with lots of practice, experience—actually experience and practicing and engaging—we’re learning, we’re developing, we’re having all kinds of experiences in different situations, and we’re seeing how different situations, different ways of engaging, lead to different consequences, different results. That’s developing knowledge, you could say, so that we’re getting wiser, smarter, hopefully.

Sometimes we can shift from within and enter more fully, and sometimes we need to shift in a new direction and enter more fully. And of course, the thing is, we have to make that decision. It’s good to seek counsel, it’s good to get advice, good to get some help. But ultimately, each of us in those moments is the one who makes the decision. And it must be like that, because in that action, in that choice, we are creating karma, right? And it’s important that we take ownership of that. You know, if you’re in a tough spot and you ask somebody what to do and they tell you and you do it and it doesn’t work out, who’s going to get the blame? You told me to do this. If you do it and it does work out, what have you learned?

Why must correct and bias be in an arrangement? The world is filled with differences—of everything. That’s not changing. We’re not trying to change that through practice. We’re trying to understand it at its deepest level and free ourselves of the discriminating mind which sees the differences and then divides and separates and ranks and elevates and subjugates, so then we can move within those differences without being fooled—fooling ourselves.

I did an interview just this week with somebody who has a podcast, can’t remember the name—Shrinking Trump, that’s the name. And a psychologist. And he was here like 25, 30 years ago, I think. Came for an introductory retreat and told a story about being here in the zendo and sitting zazen for the first time. Mind was a mess. Went into Dokusan to Daido Roshi, talked about his messy mind. And Daido Roshi lied and said, “Just keep letting go. Keep, keep letting go.”

So he said, the next day—I’m not sure what he was here for, maybe it was an introductory J—but the next day, he had an opportunity to have another dokusan. And he’d had some more sitting, and he’d had a moment where everything fell away and he was just in bliss. It’s perfect. So he was very eager to share this with Daido Roshi. So he goes running in and shares his wonderful moment. And Daido Roshi listened to him and said, “Okay, just let that go.” I said, yeah, that’s pretty much it.

It’s not because one is good and one’s bad. It’s just keep doing that, whatever it is—going to the place that we would like to avoid. Let the heat kill you, the cold kill you, kill the idea, the belief, the view, the attachment. Because there’s actually nothing there. There’s nothing you can touch, nothing you can put in a box, nothing you could bury, nothing you could even extinguish. And yet the sense of that something which has no substance is so strong.

That’s why the analogy of a magician—the magician creates an illusion, and everybody sees it, and it’s real. It is there. Something’s there. Everybody’s seeing it. But it’s not as it appears. We cannot know that when we’re standing over here looking at the illusion. As long as we’re in the audience, we cannot know that. That’s why we sit on this cushion.

In the early days, sometimes when people would come and say, they would say, “I’m not really interested in practicing, but can I just sit in the back while you guys are meditating and watch zazen or sitting?” No tourists. We have no audience. No one’s performing. It’s all in. And that takes some faith, particularly when it’s difficult.

And you can imagine that with different kinds of challenges, different kinds of hot and cold, and when heat and cold is simple pain, in a way, it hurts, but it’s simple. It’s immediate, it’s physical. It’s right there. It’s not that complicated. That’s why it’s so important to practice those moments. Because the principle or the Dharma of what’s being experienced in that moment where it kills you is the same as when it’s something that seems much more complicated, because the thing that we want to avoid ultimately is not what’s going on out there, but it’s the mind.

The ancient crystal palace reflects the bright moon. The footnote says round and full. Just don’t grasp the reflection, so try and take it home. Don’t try and hold on to it. The sly hound of Han vainly runs up the stairs. Story about a dog who saw the moon through the window at the top of the stairs and ran up trying to get it.

These teachings, this practice in a way, is more profound, more thoroughgoing than we can imagine, and also more simple, more immediate, more accessible than we might think. It’s because it’s so close that it can be hard to see.

Thank you for listening. To find out more about ZMM’s programs, retreats and residency, please visit us online at zmm.org.

Title: Mountains And Rivers Sutra - 1984 - 6 Of 6
Caption or Other Speaker: â€œThe blue mountains are constantly walking. The Stone Woman gives birth to a child in the night. The mountains lack nothing. Hence, they are constantly at rest and constantly walking. We must devote ourselves to a detailed study of this virtue of walking. The walking of the mountains is like that of people. So not doubt that mountains walk simply because they may not appear to walk like humans. . . â€
Speaker: John Daido Loori

Title: Mountains And Rivers Sutra - 1984 - 5 Of 6
Caption or Other Speaker: â€œâ€™The Stone Woman gives birth to a child in the nightâ€™ means that the time when the Stone Woman gives birth to a child is the night. Among stones there are male stones, female stones and stones neither male nor femaleâ€.
Speaker: John Daido Loori

Caption or Other Speaker: â€œWe do not realize that the Blue Mountains must be understood in terms of immeasurable Dharma realmsâ€. So we must carefully investigate this walking of the Blue Mountains.â€

Title: Emergent Trends In Western Dharma
Caption or Other Speaker:
Presenter: Lama Surya Das

Lama Surya Das (Jeffery Miller 1950 - ) is a Western Buddhist meditation teacher and scholar, one of the main interpreters of Tibetan Buddhism in the West, and a leading spokesperson for the emerging American Buddhism. The Dalai Lama affectionately calls him â€œThe Western Lama.â€
Surya has spent over forty five years studying Zen, Vipassana, Yoga, and Tibetan Buddhism with the great masters of Asia, including the Dalai Lamaâ€™s own teachers, and has twice completed the traditional three year meditation cloistered retreat at his teacherâ€™s Tibetan monastery. He is an authorized lama and lineage holder in the Nyingmapa School of Tibetan Buddhism, and a close personal disciple of the leading grand lamas of that tradition. He is the founder of the Dzogchen Center and Foundation in Cambridge, Massachusetts, and its branch centers around the country. 
He has brought many Tibetan lamas to this country to teach and start centers and retreats. As founder of the Western Buddhist Teachers Network with the Dalai Lama, he regularly helps organize its international Buddhist Teachers Conferences. He is also active in interfaith dialogue and charitable projects in the Third World. In recent years, Lama Surya has turned his efforts and focus towards youth and contemplative education initiatives, what he calls â€œTrue higher education and wisdom for life training.â€
Lama Surya Das is a sought after speaker and lecturer, a published author, translator, and contributor to major newspapers.

He is the author of thirteen books:
The Snow Lionâ€™s Turquoise Mane: Wisdom Tales from Tibet (1992)
Awakening the Buddha Within: Tibetan Wisdom for the Western World (1998)
Awakening to the Sacred: Creating a Spiritual Life from Scratch (1999)
Awakening the Buddhist Heart: Integrating Love, Meaning and Connection into Every Part of Your Life (2000)
Letting Go of the Person You Used to Be: Lessons on Change, Loss and Spiritual Transformation (2003)
Natural Radiance: Dzogchen Pith Instructions (including seven guided meditations on CD) (2005)
The Big Questions: How to Find Your Own Answers to Lifeâ€™s Essential Mysteries (2007)
Buddha Is as Buddha Does: The Ten Transformative Practices of Enlightened Living (2007)
Words of Wisdom (2008)
The Mind is Mightier than the Sword: Enlightening the Mind, Opening the Heart (2009)
Natural Great Perfection: Dzogchen Teachings and Vajra Songs (with Nyoshul Khenpo) (2009)
Buddha Standard Time: Awakening to the Infinite Possibilities of Now (2011)
Make Me One With Everything: Buddhist Meditations to Awaken from the Illusion of Separation (May 2015)

Title: The Seeds Of Heaven And Hell
Caption or Other Speaker:
Senior's talk by Ron Hogen Green

From Master Daowi:
â€œPeople are backwards. Ignorant of the True Self, they pursue things, willing to suffer immeasurable pains in greed for a little bit of pleasure. In the mornings, before they open their eyes and have gotten out of bed when theyâ€™re still only half awake, their minds are already flying about in confusion flowing along with random thoughts. Although good and bad deeds have not yet appeared, heaven and hell are already formed in their hearts before they even get out of bed. By the time they go into action, the seeds of heaven and hell are already implanted planted in their mindsâ€.
Speaker: Ron Hogen Green

Title: The Coming Of Age Of American Zen
Caption or Other Speaker:
Presenter: Peter M. Matthiessen

Peter M. Matthiessen (Isshin Muryo Roshi, 1927 â€“ 2014) was an author, naturalist, activist, and Zen teacher. Muryo Roshi began his Zen practice in 1970, with Soen Nakagawa Roshi. In 1976, he met Bernard Tetsugen Glassman (aka " Bernie Roshi") and began studying with him shortly after that. He was Bernie's first Dharma successor and became a Roshi himself in 1997. Bernie's practice and teachings as the founder of the Zen Peacemaker Order (https://zenpeacemakers.org) had a profound effect on Muryo Roshi's life as a Zen Master. He was deeply drawn to the practice of bearing witness, going to Auschwitz three times, and doing street retreats.

He deeply embraced the guidance of the Three Tenets of the Zen Peacemakers:
â€¢ Not-knowing- giving up fixed ideas about ourselves and the universe
â€¢ Bearing witness to the joy and suffering of the world
â€¢ Taking Actions that arise from Not-Knowing and Bearing Witness

He is author of over 30 books and won the National Book Award three times, the third for his novel Shadow Country (2008), making him the only writer to receive the award for both fiction and nonfiction.
Speaker: Other

Title: Toward American Buddhism
Caption or Other Speaker:
Presenter: Robert Thurman

Robert Alexander Farrar Thurman (born August 3, 1941) is an American Buddhist author and academic who has written, edited, and translated several books on Tibetan Buddhism. He is the father of actress Uma Thurman. He is the Je Tsongkhapa Professor of Indo- Tibetan Buddhist Studies at Columbia University, holding the first endowed chair in this field of study in the United States. He also is the co-founder and president of the Tibet House New York. He translated the Vimalakirti Sutra from the Tibetan Kanjur into English.

He is the author of the following works:

The Holy Teaching of Vimalakirti: A Mahayana Scripture, Pennsylvania State University Press, 2000, ISBN 9780271012094
The Central Philosophy of Tibet: A Study and Translation of Jey Tsong Khapa's Essence of True Eloquence, Princeton University Press, 1991 ISBN 9780691020679
The Tibetan Book of the Dead: The Natural Liberation Through Understanding in the Between Bantam Doubleday Dell, 1994 (translations in Spanish, French, German, Italian, Korean, Japanese, Chinese, Russian) ISBN 9780553370904
Essential Tibetan Buddhism, Castle Books, 1995 ISBN 9780062510518
Wisdom and Compassion: The Sacred Art of Tibet, Abrams, 1996 ISBN 9780810939851
Mandala: The Architecture of Enlightenment, Shambhala Publications, 1997 ISBN 9780500280188
World of Transformation: Masterpieces of Tibetan Sacred Art in the Donald Rubin Collection (with Marilyn Rhie), Tibet House/Abrams, 1999 ISBN 978-0810963870
Inner Revolution: Life, Liberty, and the Pursuit of Real Happiness, Penguin, 1999 ISBN 9781573227193
Circling the Sacred Mountain: A Spiritual Adventure Through the Himalayas with Tad Wise, Bantam Doubleday Dell, 1999 ISBN 9780553103465
Infinite Life: Seven Virtues for Living Well, Riverhead Books, 2004, ISBN 9781594480690
The Universal Vehicle Discourse Literature (with Lozang Jamspal, et al.), Columbia University Press, 2005 ISBN 9780975373408
The Jewel Tree of Tibet: The Enlightenment Engine of Tibetan Buddhism, Free Press/Simon & Schuster, 2005 ISBN 9780743257633
Anger: of the Seven Deadly Sins, Oxford University Press, 2005, ISBN 9780195169751
Life and Teachings of Tsongkhapa, Library of Tibetan Works and Archives, 2006, ISBN 9788186470442
Why the Dalai Lama Matters: His Act of Truth as the Solution for China, Tibet and the World, Atria Books/Beyond Words, 2008, ISBN 9781582702209
A Shrine for Tibet: The Alice Kandell Collection with Marylin Rhie, Overlook, 2010 ISBN 9780967011578
Brilliant Illumination of the Lamp of the Five Stages, Columbia University Press, 2011, ISBN 9781935011002
Love Your Enemies: How To Break the Anger Habit & Be a Whole Lot Happier with Sharon Salzberg, Hay House, 2013 ISBN 9781401928148
Speaker: Other

Title: Mainstream Dharma
Caption or Other Speaker:
Presenter: Jon Kabat-Zinn

Jon Kabat-Zinn (born Jon Kabat, June 5, 1944) is an American professor emeritus of medicine and the creator of the Stress Reduction Clinic and the Center for Mindfulness in Medicine, Health Care, and Society at the University of Massachusetts Medical School. Kabat-Zinn was a student of Zen Buddhist teachers such as Philip Kapleau, Thich Nhat Hanh and Seung Sahn and a founding member of Cambridge Zen Center. His practice of yoga and studies with Buddhist teachers led him to integrate their teachings with scientific findings. He teaches mindfulness, which he says can help people cope with stress, anxiety, pain, and illness. The stress reduction program created by Kabat-Zinn, mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR), is offered by medical centers, hospitals, and health maintenance organizations.

Works:
    Full catastrophe living: using the wisdom of your body and mind to face stress, pain, and illness, by Jon Kabat-Zinn. Delta Trade Paperbacks, 1991. ISBN 0-385-30312-2.
    Mindfulness Meditation for Everyday Life. Piatkus, 1994. ISBN 0-7499-1422-X.
    Wherever You Go, There You Are: Mindfulness Meditation in Everyday Life. Hyperion Books, 1994. ISBN 1-4013-0778-7.
    Full catastrophe living: how to cope with stress, pain and illness using mindfulness meditation. Piatkus, 1996. ISBN 0-7499-1585-4.
    The Power of Meditation and Prayer, with Sogyal Rinpoche, Larry Dossey, Michael Toms. Hay House, 1997. ISBN 1-56170-423-7.
    Everyday Blessings: The Inner Work of Mindful Parenting, with Myla Kabat-Zinn. Hyperion, 1997. ISBN 978-0-7868-8314-1.
    Coming to Our Senses: Healing Ourselves and the World Through Mindfulness. Hyperion, 2006. ISBN 0-7868-8654-4.
    The mindful way through depression: freeing yourself from chronic unhappiness, by J. Mark G. Williams, John D. Teasdale, Zindel V. Segal, Jon Kabat-Zinn. Guilford Press, 2007. ISBN 1593851286.
    Arriving at Your Own Door. Piatkus Books, 2008. ISBN 0-7499-2861-1.
    Letting Everything Become Your Teacher: 100 Lessons in Mindfulness. Dell Publishing Company, 2009. ISBN 0-385-34323-X.

Title: How Buddhism Came To America (How The Swans Came To The Lake)
Caption or Other Speaker:
Presenter: Rick Fields

Rick Fields (1942-1999), born Frederick Douglas Fields in New York City, was a respected journalist, a leading authority on American Buddhism, and a student of ChÃ¶gyam Trungpa Rinpoche. He was the author of several books, most notably "How the Swans Came to the Lake: A Narrative History of Buddhism in America." He served as an editor and regular contributor to many magazines, including Yoga Journal, New Age Journal, and Tricycle The Buddhist Review. 

Mr. Fields was an early instructor at the Naropa Institute's Jack Kerouac School of Disembodied Poetics, where he was an associate and friend of the school's co-founder, Allen Ginsberg.

Title: Dharma Encounter - Dharma Transmission:  â€œWhat is it that Happened?
Caption or Other Speaker:
Dharma Transmission: â€œWhat is it that Happened?

Dogen said,
â€œWhen the Seal of Enlightenment (Shisho â€“ the document of transmission) is received, there is self-enlightenment with no master. And self-enlightenment with no self. That is why we say Buddhas transmit enlightenment and ancestors mutually pledge enlightenment. If you are not a Buddha, you cannot clarify the essence of this principle. Even those people who are on the highest level or have the status of a Buddha cannot easily grasp this. So how is it possible for scholars of the Sutra or Abhidharma to conjecture about it? They may pretend to explain it, but they have no real understanding.

Buddhas transmit to Buddhas, and only Buddhas can master the Buddha way. There is no place Buddhas are not. For example, stones transmit stones. Jade transmits jade. Chrysanthemums and pine trees transmit and hand down the Seal of Enlightenment. Each generation of chrysanthemums or pine trees passes its life to the next generationâ€.

So how do you understand dharma transmission?
Speaker: John Daido Loori

Title: Relationship And Intimacy As A Path
Caption or Other Speaker:
Presenter: Tsultrim Allione

This is a talk given at the Buddhism in America Retreat, held on January 17, 18, and 19, 1997 in Boston, Massachusetts.

Lama Tsultrim Allione is an author and teacher who has studied in Tibetan Buddhismâ€™s Karma Kagyu lineage. She was born in 1947 in Maine under the name Joan RousmaniÃ¨re Ewing. She first travelled to India and Nepal in 1967, returned in 1969 and January 1970 she became one of the first American women to be ordained as a Tibetan nun. She was given her vows by the Karmapa, from the Karma Kagyu school of Tibetan Buddhism, who gave her the name Karma Tsultrim Chodron. Allione gave back her monastic vows four years later and married. She has given birth to four children, one of whom died from sudden infant death syndrome. Tsultrim Allione continued her studies and Buddhist practice, which led to the 1984 publication of her book Women of Wisdom, a collection of the namtar of six Tibetan Buddhist yogini such as Machig LabdrÃ¶n (founder of the ChÃ¶d practice), Ayu Khandro Dorje Paldron (1839â€“1953), Nangsa Obum, Jomo Menmo (1248â€“1283), Machig Ongjo and Drenchen Rema. This is the work for which she is most well known, and it has since been translated from English into several foreign languages and expanded in a revised 2nd edition. In 1993, with her husband, David Petit, Tsultrim Allione founded Tara Mandala, a retreat center in southern Colorado, in the United States. As well as offering retreats at Tara Mandala, Allione regularly teaches in the United States and Europe.

In 2008 Lama Tsultrim Allioneâ€™s book Feeding Your Demons was published, an approach based on the ChÃ¶d lineage of Machig LabdrÃ¶n that Allione has practiced since 1973. Allione opens chapter five of the book by quoting Carl Jung as saying, â€œOne does not become enlightened by imagining figures of light but by making the darkness conscious.â€ Mark Epstein has described her work as â€œa book that Carl Jung could only have dreamed of writing.â€ Allione claims that the â€œprocess of feeding our demons is a method for bringing our shadow into consciousness and accessing the treasures it holds rather than repressing it.â€

In 2009, Lama Tsultrim Allione was selected by an esteemed committee of scholars and practitioners to receive the international â€œOutstanding Woman in Buddhismâ€ Award given in Bangkok, Thailand. 
Lama Tsultrim is enjoying being the grandmother of six and has completed her new book, Wisdom Rising: Journey into the Mandala of the Empowered Feminine, published by Simon and Schuster in May 2018. At the same time, Lama Tsultrim continues to guide Tara Mandala and thousands of students around the world. Her writings and teachings come from her sublime Tibetan lamas as well as her experience as a Western woman and mother. She is known for her ability to translate the wisdom of the ancient Tibetan Buddhist tradition into clear teachings that are relatable and relevant to Western audiences.

Title: Buddhist Ethics 3 Of 4
Caption or Other Speaker:
Presenter: Robert Thurman

Robert Alexander Farrar Thurman (born August 3, 1941) is an American Buddhist author and academic who has written, edited, and translated several books on Tibetan Buddhism. He is the father of actress Uma Thurman. He is the Je Tsongkhapa Professor of Indo- Tibetan Buddhist Studies at Columbia University, holding the first endowed chair in this field of study in the United States. He also is the co-founder and president of the Tibet House New York. He translated the Vimalakirti Sutra from the Tibetan Kanjur into English.

He is the author of the following works:

The Holy Teaching of Vimalakirti: A Mahayana Scripture, Pennsylvania State University Press, 2000, ISBN 9780271012094
The Central Philosophy of Tibet: A Study and Translation of Jey Tsong Khapa's Essence of True Eloquence, Princeton University Press, 1991 ISBN 9780691020679
The Tibetan Book of the Dead: The Natural Liberation Through Understanding in the Between Bantam Doubleday Dell, 1994 (translations in Spanish, French, German, Italian, Korean, Japanese, Chinese, Russian) ISBN 9780553370904
Essential Tibetan Buddhism, Castle Books, 1995 ISBN 9780062510518
Wisdom and Compassion: The Sacred Art of Tibet, Abrams, 1996 ISBN 9780810939851
Mandala: The Architecture of Enlightenment, Shambhala Publications, 1997 ISBN 9780500280188
World of Transformation: Masterpieces of Tibetan Sacred Art in the Donald Rubin Collection (with Marilyn Rhie), Tibet House/Abrams, 1999 ISBN 978-0810963870
Inner Revolution: Life, Liberty, and the Pursuit of Real Happiness, Penguin, 1999 ISBN 9781573227193
Circling the Sacred Mountain: A Spiritual Adventure Through the Himalayas with Tad Wise, Bantam Doubleday Dell, 1999 ISBN 9780553103465
Infinite Life: Seven Virtues for Living Well, Riverhead Books, 2004, ISBN 9781594480690
The Universal Vehicle Discourse Literature (with Lozang Jamspal, et al.), Columbia University Press, 2005 ISBN 9780975373408
The Jewel Tree of Tibet: The Enlightenment Engine of Tibetan Buddhism, Free Press/Simon & Schuster, 2005 ISBN 9780743257633
Anger: of the Seven Deadly Sins, Oxford University Press, 2005, ISBN 9780195169751
Life and Teachings of Tsongkhapa, Library of Tibetan Works and Archives, 2006, ISBN 9788186470442
Why the Dalai Lama Matters: His Act of Truth as the Solution for China, Tibet and the World, Atria Books/Beyond Words, 2008, ISBN 9781582702209
A Shrine for Tibet: The Alice Kandell Collection with Marylin Rhie, Overlook, 2010 ISBN 9780967011578
Brilliant Illumination of the Lamp of the Five Stages, Columbia University Press, 2011, ISBN 9781935011002
Love Your Enemies: How To Break the Anger Habit & Be a Whole Lot Happier with Sharon Salzberg, Hay House, 2013 ISBN 9781401928148

Presenter: Robert Thurman

Robert Alexander Farrar Thurman (born August 3, 1941) is an American Buddhist author and academic who has written, edited, and translated several books on Tibetan Buddhism. He is the father of actress Uma Thurman. He is the Je Tsongkhapa Professor of Indo- Tibetan Buddhist Studies at Columbia University, holding the first endowed chair in this field of study in the United States. He also is the co-founder and president of the Tibet House New York. He translated the Vimalakirti Sutra from the Tibetan Kanjur into English.

He is the author of the following works:

The Holy Teaching of Vimalakirti: A Mahayana Scripture, Pennsylvania State University Press, 2000, ISBN 9780271012094
The Central Philosophy of Tibet: A Study and Translation of Jey Tsong Khapa's Essence of True Eloquence, Princeton University Press, 1991 ISBN 9780691020679
The Tibetan Book of the Dead: The Natural Liberation Through Understanding in the Between Bantam Doubleday Dell, 1994 (translations in Spanish, French, German, Italian, Korean, Japanese, Chinese, Russian) ISBN 9780553370904
Essential Tibetan Buddhism, Castle Books, 1995 ISBN 9780062510518
Wisdom and Compassion: The Sacred Art of Tibet, Abrams, 1996 ISBN 9780810939851
Mandala: The Architecture of Enlightenment, Shambhala Publications, 1997 ISBN 9780500280188
World of Transformation: Masterpieces of Tibetan Sacred Art in the Donald Rubin Collection (with Marilyn Rhie), Tibet House/Abrams, 1999 ISBN 978-0810963870
Inner Revolution: Life, Liberty, and the Pursuit of Real Happiness, Penguin, 1999 ISBN 9781573227193
Circling the Sacred Mountain: A Spiritual Adventure Through the Himalayas with Tad Wise, Bantam Doubleday Dell, 1999 ISBN 9780553103465
Infinite Life: Seven Virtues for Living Well, Riverhead Books, 2004, ISBN 9781594480690
The Universal Vehicle Discourse Literature (with Lozang Jamspal, et al.), Columbia University Press, 2005 ISBN 9780975373408
The Jewel Tree of Tibet: The Enlightenment Engine of Tibetan Buddhism, Free Press/Simon & Schuster, 2005 ISBN 9780743257633
Anger: of the Seven Deadly Sins, Oxford University Press, 2005, ISBN 9780195169751
Life and Teachings of Tsongkhapa, Library of Tibetan Works and Archives, 2006, ISBN 9788186470442
Why the Dalai Lama Matters: His Act of Truth as the Solution for China, Tibet and the World, Atria Books/Beyond Words, 2008, ISBN 9781582702209
A Shrine for Tibet: The Alice Kandell Collection with Marylin Rhie, Overlook, 2010 ISBN 9780967011578
Brilliant Illumination of the Lamp of the Five Stages, Columbia University Press, 2011, ISBN 9781935011002
Love Your Enemies: How To Break the Anger Habit & Be a Whole Lot Happier with Sharon Salzberg, Hay House, 2013 ISBN 9781401928148

Title: Seeking The Transcendent: Unitarian Universalism And Zen Buddhism 2 Of 2
Caption or Other Speaker:
Presenter: James Ishmael Ford (Zeno Myoun, Roshi)

James Ishmael Ford (Zeno Myoun, Roshi) is an American Zen Buddhist priest and a retired Unitarian Universalist minister. He was born in Oakland, California on July 17, 1948. He earned a BA in psychology from Sonoma State University, as well as an MDiv and an MA in the Philosophy of Religion, both from the Pacific School of Religion.
Ford began his Zen studies in 1968 at the Berkeley Zen Center under the direction of Mel Weitsman, later Weitsman, Roshi. He was ordained unsui and received Dharma transmission from the late Jiyu Kennett Roshi. After leaving Kennett Roshi's Shasta Abbey and for a brief time exploring other religious traditions including the Episcopal Church, the western Gnostic tradition and Inayat Khan Sufism, Ford pursued Zen koan introspection for nearly twenty years in the Sanbo Kyodan tradition with John Tarrant Roshi, with whom he completed formal training and from whom he received Inka Shomei (formal recognition as an authorized Zen teacher) in 2005.

Ford began to be seriously involved in Unitarian Universalism at about the same time he began his work with Tarrant Roshi. After completing theological studies he became a Unitarian Universalist minister, serving Unitarian Universalist congregations in Wisconsin and Arizona before becoming senior minister of the First Unitarian Society in Newton, MA in 2000. In May 2008 First Unitarian Church of Providence, RI called him to its pulpit; he began his ministry there in the summer of that year.
Roshi Ford also maintained his relationships within the Soto community, and in 2004 Ford participated in the first Dharma Heritage ceremony of the forming North American Soto Zen Buddhist Association. This event, designed to be the equivalent of the Japanese Soto Zuisse ceremony, was a public acknowledgment of Ford (among others) as a senior member of the North American Zen community. Ford, a past president of the Unitarian Universalist Buddhist Fellowship, was the first Unitarian Universalist minister to be named a Zen master.

Roshi Ford is a significant figure in the establishment of Zen in North America. He is the co-founder and first abbot of Boundless Way Zen, a network of meditation groups mostly in eastern Massachusetts. He was also influential in the development of the Nebraska Zen Center in Omaha and the Great Heartland Buddhist Temple in Toledo, Ohio.

In 2015, Ford retired from his ministry at the First Unitarian Church of Providence, left Boundless Way, and moved to Long Beach, California. He then established the Empty Moon Zen Network, a network of Zen Centers in California, Washington state, and Pennsylvania.

Starting in April 2019, he has served as a minister at the Unitarian Universalist Church in Anaheim.
Ford is co-editor of The Transient and Permanent in Liberal Religion, and is the author of This Very Moment: A Brief Introduction to Buddhism and Zen for Unitarian Universalists, both published by Skinner House Books. He is also the author of a study of Zen teachers and communities in North America, Zen Master Who? A Guide to the People and Stories of Zen, the co-editor of The Book of Mu: Essential Writings on Zenâ€™s Most Important Koan, and the author of If You're Lucky, Your Heart Will Break: Field Notes from a Zen Life from Wisdom Publications. His most recent book is Introduction to Zen Koans: Learning the Language of Dragons also released by Wisdom.

Ford is a member of the American Zen Teachers Associated and served on its membership committee for a decade. he is also a member of the Soto Zen Buddhist Association, in which he served on the board of directors. He maintains connections with the Unitarian Universalist community through his work with their Society for Community Ministries and Spiritual Directorâ€™s Network.

Roshi Ford has nine Dharma heirs including Josh Jiun Bartok Roshi of the Greater Boston Zen Center, Melissa Myozen Blacker Roshi of Boundless Way Temple, Dosho Port Roshi of the Nebraska Zen Center, and Jay Rinsen Weik Sensei of the Buddhist Temple of Toledo, Ohio.


Bibliography
â€¢ James Ishmael Ford; Dan O'Neal; Alice Blair Wesley (1995). The Transient and Permanent in Liberal Religion: Reflections from the Uuma Convocation on Ministry. Skinner House Books. ISBN 978-1-55896-330-6.
â€¢ James Ishmael Ford (1996). This Very Moment : A Brief Introduction to Buddhism and Zen for Unitarian Universalists. Skinner House Books. ISBN 1-55896-347-2.
â€¢ James Ishmael Ford (2006). Zen Master Who?: A Guide to the People and Stories of Zen. Wisdom Publications. ISBN 0-86171-509-8.
â€¢ James Ishmael Ford; Melissa Myozen Blacker (2011). The Book of Mu: Essential Writings on Zen's Most Important Koan. Wisdom Publications. ISBN 0-86171-643-4.
â€¢ James Ishmael Ford (2012). If You're Lucky, Your Heart Will Break: Field Notes from a Zen Life. Wisdom Publications. ISBN 1-61429-039-3.
â€¢ James Ishmael Ford (2018). Introduction to Zen Koans: Learning the Language of Dragons. Wisdom Publications. ISBN 978-1-61429-295-1.

Title: Poetry Reading
Caption or Other Speaker:
Presenter: Ed Sanders

Ed Sanders was born in Kansas City, Missouri. He dropped out of the University of Missouri in 1958 and hitchhiked to New York City's Greenwich Village to attend New York University. He graduated in 1964, with a degree in Greek.

Sanders wrote his first notable poem, "Poem from Jail", on toilet paper in his cell after being jailed for protesting the launch of nuclear submarines armed with nuclear missiles in 1961. In 1962, he founded the avant-garde journal Fuck You/A Magazine of the Arts. Sanders opened the Peace Eye Bookstore at 383 East Tenth Street in what was then the Lower East Side; the store became a gathering place for Bohemians, writers and radicals. On January 1, 1966, police raided Peace Eye Bookstore and charged Sanders with obscenity, charges he fended off with the aid of the ACLU. Notoriety generated by the case led to his appearance on the February 17, 1967 cover of Life Magazine, which proclaimed him "a leader of New York's Other Culture."

In late 1964, Sanders founded the Fugs with Tuli Kupferberg. The band broke up in 1969 and reformed in 1984. On October 21, 1967, on the National Mobilization Committee to End the War in Vietnam's March on the Pentagon, Sanders helped The Fugs and the San Francisco Diggers in an attempt to "exorcise" The Pentagon. In 1968, he signed the "Writers and Editors War Tax Protest" pledge, vowing to refuse tax payments in protest against the Vietnam War.

In 1969, Sanders recorded and released his first solo album for Reprise Records, Sanders' Truck Stop. Reviewing in Christgau's Record Guide: Rock Albums of the Seventies (1981), Robert Christgau wrote: "This is literally a country-rock takeoffâ€”not a parody but a departure. But though I hesitate to criticize a man who is not only a saint and a genius but who says hello to me at the post office, I must point out that the yodeling country twang Sanders developed with the Fugs has never known the difference between parody and departure, which makes some of these songs seem crueller than they're intended to be. Of course, sometimes they're cruel on purposeâ€”like 'The Iliad,' a saga of good old queer-bashing with a Greek-to-me intro. And sometimes, like 'Jimmy Joe, the Hippybilly Boy,' they'reâ€”snurfleâ€”lyrical and sad.â€

In 1971, Sanders wrote The Family, a profile of the events leading up to the Tate-LaBianca murders. He attended the Manson group's murder trial, and spent time at their residence at the Spahn Movie Ranch. There have been two updated editions of The Family, the most recent in 2002. The Process Church of the Final Judgement sued Sanders's U.S. publisher for defamation over a chapter linking them with Manson's activities. The case was settled by the publisher, who removed the disputed chapter from future editions. The Process Church then sued Sanders's British publisher, but lost the suit and were forced to pay the defendant's legal fees.

Sanders is the founder of the Investigative Poetry movement. His 1976 manifesto Investigative Poetry, published by Lawrence Ferlinghettiâ€™s City Lights Books, influenced investigative writing and poetry during the ensuing decades. In the 1990s, Sanders began utilizing the principles of Investigative Poetry to create a series of book-length poems on literary figures and American History. Among these works are Chekhov, 1968: A History in Verse, and The Poetry and Life of Allen Ginsberg. In 1998, Sanders began work on a 9-volume America, A History in Verse. The first five volumes, tracing the history of the 20th century, were published in a CD format with over 2,000 pages in length.

Sanders received a Guggenheim Fellowship in poetry in 1983, and a National Endowment for the Arts Fellowship in poetry in 1987. His Thirsting for Peace in a Raging Century, Selected Poems 1961â€“1985 won an American Book Award in 1988. He was chosen to deliver the Charles Olson Memorial Lectures at SUNY Buffalo in 1983. In 1997, he received a Writers Community residency sponsored by the YMCA National Writer's Voice through the Lila Wallace Readers Digest Fund.

In 1997 he was awarded a grant from the Foundation for Contemporary Arts Grants to Artists Award. In 2000 and 2003 he was Writer-in-Residence at the New York State Writers Institute in Albany, New York.

Sanders lives in Woodstock, New York, where he publishes the online Woodstock Journal with his wife of over 47 years, writer and painter Miriam R. Sanders. He also invents musical instruments, including the Talking Tie, the microtonal Microlyre, and the Lisa Lyre, a musical contraption involving light-activated switches and a reproduction of Da Vinci's Mona Lisa.

Title: Haiku And Shakuhachi Performance
Caption or Other Speaker:
Performers: Ronnie Nyogetsu Reishin Seldin and Clark Strand

Ronnie Nyogetsu Reishin Seldin (1947 â€“ 2017) 
Founder of the Ki-Sui-An Shakuhachi Dojo in New York City with several branches on the East Coast, Ronnie studied shakuhachi in Kyoto, Japan with Kurahashi Yodo Sensei, who was a disciple of Jin Nyodo. There, in 1975, he received the name Nyogetsu and a teaching certificate at the level of Jun Shi-han in the Kinko school of shakuhachi. After his return to New York, Nyogetsu was awarded the rank of Shi-han (Master) in 1978, as a result of his efforts to spread the teaching of this instrument in America. In 1980, he received his Dai Shi-han, or Grand Master's license. In 2001 he received Koku-An Dai-Shihan (Grand Master's license at the level of Kyu-Dan, or 9th level) from Japan's Living National Treasure in shakuhachi, Aoki Reibo. Ronnie was also given the name Reishin (Heart/Mind of the Bell) at that time.

Clark Strand
Author of "Seeds From a Birch Tree: Writing Haiku and the Spiritual Journey", Clark Strand is an American author and lecturer on spirituality and religion. A former Zen Buddhist monk, he was the first Senior Editor of Tricycle: The Buddhist Review. He left that position in 1996 and moved to Woodstock, NY, US to write and teach full-time.

Title: Informal Remarks - July 1995 Sesshin
Caption or Other Speaker:
Remarks given by Zenkei Blanche Hartman with an introduction by John Daido Loori.

Zenkei Blanche Hartman (1926â€“May 13, 2016) was a Soto Zen teacher practicing in the lineage of Shunryu Suzuki. From 1996 to 2002 she served two terms as co-abbess of the San Francisco Zen Center. She was the first woman to assume such a leadership position at the center. A member of the American Zen Teachers Association, Blanche was especially known for her expertise in the ancient ritual of sewing a kesa. Hartman became known for her attention to issues women face; she and her late husband Lou Hartman had four children, eight grandchildren, and a number of great-grandchildren.

Blanche Hartman was born in Birmingham, Alabama to non-practicing Jewish parents in 1926. Educated in the Catholic school system in the early 1930sâ€”and impressed with the religiosity and faith of one teacherâ€”in 1943 she moved to California, where her father served in the military.

After taking up biochemistry and chemistry at the University of California she married Lou Hartman in 1947, giving birth to four children. In the late 1950s she found work as a chemist, though by 1968 she began questioning the direction of her life. She and her husband began sitting zazen regularly at the Berkeley Zen Center in Berkeley, California in 1969, and in 1972 the two entered Tassajara Zen Mountain Center. The couple lived at all of the other San Francisco Zen Center sites, including City Center and Green Gulch Farm. (Lou died in 2011 and Blanche later lived at AgeSong.)

During the 1970s, Blanche received training in Nyoho-e â€“ a traditional method for sewing Buddha's robeâ€”in the lineage of Sawaki Kodo Roshi from Kasai Joshin Sensei, formerly of Antaiji. Blanche was fundamental to the spread of devotional sewing practice throughout North America. She and Lou were both ordained as priests by Zentatsu Richard Baker in 1977, and Blanche was given the Buddhist name Zenkei (meaning inconceivable joy).

In 1988 she received shiho from Sojun Mel Weitsman, and in 1996 she became installed as co-abbess of the San Francisco Zen Center. This was the first female abbess of the City Center, having served just after Tenshin Reb Anderson and Sojun Mel Weitsman. One reason Blanche accepted the position of co-abbess, serving two terms from 1996 to 2002, is that she understood the need for women to have a role model.

Title: Shuso Hossen - June 1995
Caption or Other Speaker:
Shuso Hossen with Mark Sando Miniberg

Mark Mininberg, Sensei, received dharma transmission and teaching authority from Roshi Bernie Glassman, head of the Zen Peacemaker Order, in 2011. He previously trained for more than twenty years under Abbot John Daido Loori at the Zen Mountain Monastery in Mt. Tremper, NY. Mark is a member of the White Plum Asanga organization of Zen teachers.

Mark completed facilitator training at the New England Institute of Systemic Constellations under the supervision of Ed Lynch, Bill Mannle, Don Paglia and Eve-Marie Elkin. He has also studied a number of other healing modalities, including energy medicine and positive psychology.

Mark is a graduate of Wesleyan University and holds a law degree from the University of Connecticut.

Mark served for many years as a healthcare administrator and since 1995, is the president of Hospital Energy, a national consulting firm. He is frequent lecturer on energy, healthcare, and environmental matters, including invitations from the U.S. White House, the United Nations, the World Bank, the Oxford University Law Colloquium, Yale University Center for International Studies, Harvard Law School Negotiation Project, and the Columbia University School of Public Health.

He has also served as an adviser to the Society for Neuroscience in organizing its summit meeting with His Holiness the Dalai Lama concerning the Science of the Mind.

Title: Business World- Spiritual Practice Workshop 3 Of 3
Caption or Other Speaker:
Presenter: Gerry Shishin Wick, Roshi

Gerry Shishin Wick is a Soto Zen roshi, author, oceanographer and abbot of Great Mountain Zen Center in Berthoud, Colorado, which he founded in 1996. He is one of the twelve Dharma Successors of the late Taizan Maezumi, receiving Dharma transmission and a Denkai (precept transmission) from him in 1990. Prior to it, for 24 years he underwent Zen training with Maezumi, Shunryu Suzuki Roshi and Sochu Suzuki Roshi. He remained the president of White Plum Asanga, a Zen school in the Hakuyu Taizan Maezumi lineage, from 2007 to 2014.

He has a Ph.D. in physics from the University of California, Berkeley, and has held a variety of jobs in the scientific community as well as an adjunct teaching position at Naropa University in Boulder, Colorado. He also administered the Zen Center of Los Angeles and the Kuroda Institute for the Study of Buddhism and Human Values from 1978 to 1986. In 2006, Wick received inka from Bernard Glassman. He was acknowledged as a Roshi in 2000 at White Plum Asanga, where he remained the president from 2007 to 2014, when he retired as an elder.

Title: Power Of Mind Retreat 3 Of 3
Caption or Other Speaker:
Presenter: Mark Epstein

Mark Epstein, M.D. is a psychiatrist in private practice in New York City and the author of a number of books about the interface of Buddhism and psychotherapy, including:

- Thoughts Without A Thinker
- Going To Pieces Without Falling Apart
- Going On Being
- Open To Desire
- Psychotherapy Without The Self
- The Trauma Of Everyday Life

He received his undergraduate and medical degrees from Harvard University and is currently Clinical Assistant Professor in the Postdoctoral Program in Psychotherapy and Psychoanalysis at New York University.
Speaker: Other

Title: Tibetan Book Of The Dead 4 Of 4
Caption or Other Speaker:
Presenter: Robert Thurman

Robert Alexander Farrar Thurman (born August 3, 1941) is an American Buddhist author and academic who has written, edited, and translated several books on Tibetan Buddhism. He is the father of actress Uma Thurman. He is the Je Tsongkhapa Professor of Indo- Tibetan Buddhist Studies at Columbia University, holding the first endowed chair in this field of study in the United States. He also is the co-founder and president of the Tibet House New York. He translated the Vimalakirti Sutra from the Tibetan Kanjur into English. 

He is the author of the following works:

    The Holy Teaching of Vimalakirti: A Mahayana Scripture, Pennsylvania State University Press, 2000, ISBN 9780271012094
    The Central Philosophy of Tibet: A Study and Translation of Jey Tsong Khapa's Essence of True Eloquence, Princeton University Press, 1991 ISBN 9780691020679
    The Tibetan Book of the Dead: The Natural Liberation Through Understanding in the Between Bantam Doubleday Dell, 1994 (translations in Spanish, French, German, Italian, Korean, Japanese, Chinese, Russian) ISBN 9780553370904
    Essential Tibetan Buddhism, Castle Books, 1995 ISBN 9780062510518
    Wisdom and Compassion: The Sacred Art of Tibet, Abrams, 1996 ISBN 9780810939851
    Mandala: The Architecture of Enlightenment, Shambhala Publications, 1997 ISBN 9780500280188
    World of Transformation: Masterpieces of Tibetan Sacred Art in the Donald Rubin Collection (with Marilyn Rhie), Tibet House/Abrams, 1999 ISBN 978-0810963870
    Inner Revolution: Life, Liberty, and the Pursuit of Real Happiness, Penguin, 1999 ISBN 9781573227193
    Circling the Sacred Mountain: A Spiritual Adventure Through the Himalayas with Tad Wise, Bantam Doubleday Dell, 1999 ISBN 9780553103465
    Infinite Life: Seven Virtues for Living Well, Riverhead Books, 2004, ISBN 9781594480690
    The Universal Vehicle Discourse Literature (with Lozang Jamspal, et al.), Columbia University Press, 2005 ISBN 9780975373408
    The Jewel Tree of Tibet: The Enlightenment Engine of Tibetan Buddhism, Free Press/Simon & Schuster, 2005 ISBN 9780743257633
    Anger: of the Seven Deadly Sins, Oxford University Press, 2005, ISBN 9780195169751
    Life and Teachings of Tsongkhapa, Library of Tibetan Works and Archives, 2006, ISBN 9788186470442
    Why the Dalai Lama Matters: His Act of Truth as the Solution for China, Tibet and the World, Atria Books/Beyond Words, 2008, ISBN 9781582702209
    A Shrine for Tibet: The Alice Kandell Collection with Marylin Rhie, Overlook, 2010 ISBN 9780967011578
    Brilliant Illumination of the Lamp of the Five Stages, Columbia University Press, 2011, ISBN 9781935011002
    Love Your Enemies: How To Break the Anger Habit & Be a Whole Lot Happier with Sharon Salzberg, Hay House, 2013 ISBN 9781401928148
Speaker: Other

Title: Platform Sutra Retreat - 3 Of 3
Caption or Other Speaker:
Retreat presented by John R. McRae.

John R. McRae (1947â€“2011) was a renowned expert on Chinese Chan who also possessed an extensive knowledge of the field of Buddhism in general. After getting a PhD at Yale University, he taught at Cornell and Indiana Universities before moving to Japan and teaching part-time at Komazawa University. As a specialist in East Asian Buddhism, he was especially interested in ideologies of spiritual cultivation and how they interact with their intellectual and cultural environments. His seminal work on Chinese Chan was The Northern School and the Formation of Early Chan Buddhism (University of Hawai`i Press, 1986). This was later followed by Seeing through Zen: Encounter, Transformation, and Genealogy in Chinese Chan Buddhism (University of California Press, 2003). He spent much of his career studying the life of the important Chan figure Shenhui (684â€“758), and was expecting to complete a manuscript on the topic before his passing in October of 2011 from pancreatic cancer. John also completed a number of translations of Chinese Buddhist scriptural texts for the BukkyÅ DendÅ KyÅkai's English translation series, and served as Chair of the Publication Committee for the series until his passing.
Speaker: Other

Title: Victim/Victimizer - Seeing Both Sides Retreat (1994) 3 Of 3
Caption or Other Speaker: Presenters: Jan Chozen Bays Roshi and Laren Hogen Bays Roshi
Speaker: Other

Title: Victim/Victimizer - Seeing Both Sides Retreat (1994) 2 Of 3
Caption or Other Speaker:
Presenters: Jan Chozen Bays Roshi and Laren Hogen Bays Roshi

Jan Chozen Bays Roshi is a pediatrician and nationally recognized expert on child abuse. In the 1980s and 1990s, she conducted the medical examinations of thousands of infants and children who had been abused or killed and regularly appeared in court as an expert witness. In 1987, she helped to found Child Abuse Response and Evaluation Services (CARES) Northwest, now one of the oldest and largest child abuse assessment centers in the United States.

Since 1985 Chozen, Roshi has been the teacher for Zen Community of Oregon. In 2002 she helped to found Great Vow Zen Monastery and is the co-abbot. In 2011 she also helped found Heart of Wisdom Zen Temple in Portland, Oregon.

Laren Hogen Bays Roshi holds a Naturopathic Doctor (ND) and Masterâ€™s Degree (MS) in Psychology and worked as a consultant for the Oregon Department of Corrections for fifteen years, assessing and treating men who were incarcerated for violent physical and sexual crimes. 

He has been a leader of Zen Community of Oregon since 1985 and worked full-time for the sangha since 1997. He is co-abbot of Great Vow Zen Monastery.
Speaker: Other

Title: Liberating Sexuality Retreat Part 5 Of 5
Caption or Other Speaker:
Presenters: Jeffrey Hopkins and Barbara Rhodes

Jeffrey Hopkins (born 1940) is an American Tibetologist. He is Emeritus of Tibetan and Buddhist Studies at the University of Virginia, where he taught for more than three decades since 1973. He has authored more than twenty-five books about Tibetan Buddhism, among them the highly influential Meditation on Emptiness, which appeared in 1983, offering a pioneering exposition of Prasangika-Madyamika thought in the Geluk tradition. From 1979 to 1989 he was the Dalai Lama's chief interpreter into English and he played a significant role in the development of the Free Tibet Movement. In 2006 he published his English translation of a major work by the Jonangpa lama, Dolpopa, on the Buddha Nature and Emptiness called Mountain Doctrine.

Zen Master Soeng Hyang, Barbara Rhodes, or Bobby, as she is known to many people, was one of Zen Master Seung Sahnâ€™s first American students and began studying with him in 1972. She was given inka, or permission to teach, in 1977 and received dharma transmission from Zen Master Seung Sahn in 1992. For many years Bobby worked as a hospice nurse and her practice and teaching was profoundly impacted by sitting with her patients as they transitioned from this body. Today, Zen Master Soeng Hyang is the guiding Zen Master of the Kwan Um School of Zen, a Korean lineage, which includes over a hundred centers and temples worldwide.
Speaker: Other

Title: Haiku Series - 6 Of 6
Caption or Other Speaker:
Presenter: Clark Strand

Author of "Seeds From a Birch Tree: Writing Haiku and the Spiritual Journey", Clark Strand is an American author and lecturer on spirituality and religion. A former Zen Buddhist monk, he was the first Senior Editor of Tricycle: The Buddhist Review. He left that position in 1996 and moved to Woodstock, NY, US to write and teach full-time.

The six-part series, presented over the course of the 1994 Spring Ango, includes the following topics: The formal arrangement, Shasei (å†™ç”Ÿ, "sketching from life"), Seventeen sounds (5-7-5), Seasonal feeling, Wabi, Karumi, Zen.

The presenter, Dharmachari Subhuti, originally Alex Kennedy, is a senior associate of Sangharakshita, founder of the Triratna Buddhist Community (formerly the Friends of the Western Buddhist Order (FWBO)), and President of the London Buddhist Center. He has held various positions of leadership and has been instrumental in many developments in the community.

Subhuti was influential in the building of the London Buddhist Centre, which opened in 1978, and he helped to raise funds from the Greater London Council for its completion. He developed training for men preparing to be ordained into the Triratna Buddhist Order at Padmaloka retreat center, near Norwich in England. He also helped to found Guhyaloka, a retreat center in Spain, where men make final preparations to become members of the order.

He was introducted by Mandravadra, founder of the Aryaloka Buddhist Center in Newmarket, New Hampshire.

Friends of Western Buddhism Order (Triratna Buddhist Community) was founded in 1968 by Sangharakshita. Sangharakshita (born Dennis Philip Edward Lingwood, (1925-2018) was a British Buddhist teacher and writer. His approach was to take what he perceived as the best from various Buddhist traditions and meld them together. Sangharakshita was not a formally recognized teacher in any Buddhist tradition.

Title: Guishanâ€™s â€œI Have Already Exhausted Myself For Youâ€
Caption or Other Speaker: The strength of the teachings of Zen lies in their universality. True teaching is able to reach people in all sorts of circumstances because it is grounded in reality. It is immediately applicable to our everyday lives, because it is revealed as the natural world. It is not obscure or esoteric, but concrete, practical and relevant. That is why much of Zen training is what is called â€œbody teaching.â€ It is not intellectual, but a complete embodiment of the understanding that arises out of the rigorous practice of zazen.
Speaker: John Daido Loori

Title: Haiku Series - 1 Of 6

Presenter: Clark Strand

Author of "Seeds From a Birch Tree: Writing Haiku and the Spiritual Journey", Clark Strand is an American author and lecturer on spirituality and religion. A former Zen Buddhist monk, he was the first Senior Editor of Tricycle: The Buddhist Review. He left that position in 1996 and moved to Woodstock, NY, US to write and teach full-time.

The six-part series, presented over the course of the 1994 Spring Ango, includes the following topics: The formal arrangement, Shasei (å†™ç”Ÿ, "sketching from life"), Seventeen sounds (5-7-5), Seasonal feeling, Wabi, Karumi, Zen.

Title: Haiku Mind - 2 Of 2
Caption or Other Speaker:
Presenter: Clark Strand

Clark Strand was raised as a Southern Presbyterian and studied philosophy and religion at Sewanee: The University of the South.

Strand's early explorations into Zen Buddhism enabled him to become a leader in this sect while residing at a Rinzai Zen Buddhist monastery. But he left this monastic order, and engaged in self-discovery through psychoanalysis, while working as the editor of Tricycle. In this position, he fortuitously learned about many schools of Buddhism in Asia and the West. He also explored the activities of various religious communities, including Buddhist temples, Hasidic synagogues, Christian monasteries and Hindu cults, in order to understand religionâ€™s compatibility with the realities of modern life.

In January, 2000, Strand founded the Koans of the Bible Study Group (since renamed Woodstock Buddhist Bible Study), a weekly inter-religious discussion group devoted to finding a new paradigm for religious belief and practice.

In the early 2,000s, he began exploring the Soka Gakkai International originated from Soka Gakkai Japan, a humanistic religion based on the teachings of the 13th century Japanese monk, Nichiren who lived in Kamakura period. Strand's studies of this religion led him to write Waking the Buddha. Selection from this book: "One of the most striking things about the Soka Gakkai from a Buddhist point of view is its emphasis on attaining victory in ordinary life--sometimes under extraordinary circumstances...members chant the mantra-like title of the Lotus Sutra, Nam-myoho-renge-kyo, as a way of harnessing the universal life force inherent in their own bodies and minds...That principle of interconnectedness corresponds with what we know today about particle physics and planetary ecology, both of which support the view that all things are intimately interrelated and dependent upon one another-- that nothing exists as separate and alone."

Strand has written five other books, as well as articles on a variety of religious, spiritual and ecological themes. He writes for The Washington Post, The Huffington Post, The New York Times, Newsweekâ€™s On Faith Blog, Tricycle, Body & Soul, Spirituality & Health and several other publications.
Speaker: Other

Title: Revealing The Mysteries - 2 Of 2
Caption or Other Speaker:
Presenter: Father Robert Edward Kennedy, S.J.

Father Robert Edward Kennedy, S.J. (born June 20, 1933) is an American Jesuit priest, professor of theology, psychoanalyst and Zen rÅshi in the White Plum lineage â€“ dharma successor to Bernie Glassman RÅshi.

Kennedy joined the Jesuits on August 8, 1951. At the end of a long spiritual and academic training he was ordained a priest in Japan in 1965. He studied with Yamada Koun in Japan in the 1970s. He was installed as a Zen teacher of the White Plum Asanga lineage in 1991 and was given the title RÅshi in 1997. Kennedy studied Zen with Yamada RÅshi in Kamakura, Japan, Maezumi RÅshi in Los Angeles and Bernard Glassman RÅshi in New York City. Glassman RÅshi installed Kennedy as sensei in 1991 and conferred Inka (his final seal of approval) in 1997, making him a rÅshi (master). Kennedy is currently an elder in the Zen Peacemaker Order founded by Glassman in 1996.

Kennedy was for a time chairperson of the theology department of Saint Peter's College in Jersey City, New Jersey. Currently, he teaches theology and used to teach Japanese. In addition to his work at the college, he is a practicing psychoanalyst in New York City, a representative at the United Nations of the Institute for Spiritual Consciousness in Politics and the author of two books, Zen Spirit, Christian Spirit and Zen Gifts to Christians. He sits with his Zen students daily at the Morning Star Zendo in Jersey City, NJ and with students in other zendos located throughout the tri-state area. He conducts weekend and weeklong sesshins (Zen retreats) at various centers in the United States, Mexico, Poland, England, Ireland, and Northern Ireland.

To date, Kennedy has installed 14 dharma successors: Janet Richardson RÅshi, Charles Birx RÅshi, Ellen Birx RÅshi, Janet Abels RÅshi, Ray Cicetti Sensei, Gregory Abels Sensei, Paul Schubert Sensei, Inge von Wobeser-Hopfner Sensei, Patrick Eastman RÅshi, Michael Holleran Sensei, Carl Bachmann Sensei, Carl Viggiani Sensei, Miriam Healy Sensei, Kevin Hunt Sensei (a Trappist monk from St. Joseph's Abbey at Spencer, Mass.), Cuca Montacel Sensei and Tim Butler Sensei.
Speaker: Other

Title: "The Tuning Meditation" (From The Deep Listening Retreat)
Caption or Other Speaker:
Presenter: Pauline Oliveros

This is a brief excerpt from the retreat. In it the participants sing in the â€œThe Tuning Meditationâ€, which she introduces before the piece begins.

Pauline Oliveros (May 30, 1932 â€“ November 24, 2016) was an American composer, accordionist and a central figure in the development of experimental and post-war electronic art music.

She was a founding member of the San Francisco Tape Music Center in the 1960s, and served as its director. She taught music at Mills College, the University of California San Diego (UCSD), Oberlin Conservatory of Music, and Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. Oliveros authored books, formulated new music theories, and investigated new ways to focus attention on music including her concepts of "deep listening" and "sonic awareness".

In 1988, as a result of descending 14 feet into an underground cistern to make a recording, Oliveros coined the term "deep listening", a pun that has blossomed into "an aesthetic based upon principles of improvisation, electronic music, ritual, teaching and meditation. This aesthetic is designed to inspire both trained and untrained performers to practice the art of listening and responding to environmental conditions in solo and ensemble situations".
