Title: Zen Monasticism 5 Of 5
Caption or Other Speaker:
Presenter: Robert Buswell

Robert Evans Buswell Jr. is an American academic, author and scholar of Korean Buddhism and Chinese Buddhism as well as Korean religions in general. He is Professor of Buddhist Studies at the University of California, Los Angeles and founding director of the Academy of Buddhist Studies (ë¶ˆêµ í•™ìˆ ì›) at Dongguk University, Korea's main Buddhist university.

He studied Asian Studies at University of California Santa Barbara. He then left the United States and became a Buddhist monk in Thailand, then Taiwan, and finally The Republic of Korea where he spent five years at Songgwangsa. This experience was related in his book The Zen Monastic Experience: Buddhist Practice in Contemporary Korea.
He is the Distinguished Professor of Korean and Chinese Buddhist Studies, and director of the Center for Buddhist Studies, at UCLA. He simultaneously serves as founding director of the Academy of Buddhist Studies (Pulgyo HaksurwÅn) at Dongguk University, the major Buddhist University in Korea. He has served as the chair of the Asian Languages and Cultures Department (7/1995 to 6/2004), and was the founding director of the Center for Buddhist Studies and the Center for Korean Studies at UCLA. He served as the founding director of the UCLA Center for Korean Studies (5/1993 to 6/2001) and is the current Director of the UCLA Center for Buddhist Studies. He was interim vice-provost and dean of the International Institute (2000-2001) and was elected president of the Association for Asian Studies (2008â€“09)

He has published fifteen books and roughly forty articles on aspects of the Korean, Chinese and Indian traditions of Buddhism and Korean religions.
Speaker: Other

Title: In Search Of The Self Retreat
Caption or Other Speaker:
Presenter: Gerry Shishin Wick, Roshi

Gerry Shishin Wick is a Soto Zen roshi, author, oceanographer and abbot of Great Mountain Zen Center in Berthoud, Colorado, which he founded in 1996. He is one of the twelve Dharma Successors of the late Taizan Maezumi, receiving Dharma transmission and a Denkai (precept transmission) from him in 1990. Prior to it, for 24 years he underwent Zen training with Maezumi, Shunryu Suzuki Roshi and Sochu Suzuki Roshi. He remained the president of White Plum Asanga, a Zen school in the Hakuyu Taizan Maezumi lineage, from 2007 to 2014.

He has a Ph.D. in physics from the University of California, Berkeley, and has held a variety of jobs in the scientific community as well as an adjunct teaching position at Naropa University in Boulder, Colorado. He also administered the Zen Center of Los Angeles and the Kuroda Institute for the Study of Buddhism and Human Values from 1978 to 1986. In 2006, Wick received inka from Bernard Glassman. He was acknowledged as a Roshi in 2000 at White Plum Asanga, where he remained the president from 2007 to 2014, when he retired as an elder.

Title: Mother Of The Buddhas: Meditations On The Prajnaparamita Sutra
Caption or Other Speaker:
Presenter: Lex Hixon with an introduction by John Daido Loori.

Lex Hixon (1941â€“1995) (born Alexander Paul Hixon Junior, also known as Nur al-Anwar al-Jerrahi in the Sufi community) was an American Sufi author, poet, and spiritual teacher. He practiced and held membership in several of the world's major great religious traditions, and documented his spiritual explorations in nine books and many articles and teachings given to various groups. His passionate conviction that all of the great religions are true was sparked by his study of the life and teachings of Sri Ramakrishna, and he made his life a witness to this belief by fully immersing himself in multiple religious practices and studies, not as a research project but as an act of faith.

His book, Mother of the Buddhas: Meditations on the Prajnaparamita Sutra is discussed in this talk.
Speaker: Other

Title: Buddhism After Patriarchy - Session 2 Of 2
Caption or Other Speaker:
Presenter: Rita M. Gross
Rita M. Gross (July 6, 1943 â€“ November 11, 2015) was an American Buddhist feminist scholar of religions and author. Before retiring, she was Professor of Comparative Studies in Religion at the University of Wisconsinâ€“Eau Claire.
In 1974 Gross was named the head of Women and Religion, a newly created section of the American Academy of Religion. She earned her PhD in 1975 from the University of Chicago in History of Religions, with the dissertation "Exclusion and Participation: The Role of Women in Aboriginal Australian Religion.â€ This was the first dissertation ever on women's studies in religion.  In 1976 she published the article "Female God Language in a Jewish Context" (Davka Magazine 17), which Jewish scholar and feminist Judith Plaskow considers "probably the first article to deal theoretically with the issue of female God-language in a Jewish context". Gross was herself born Lutheran before converting to Judaism in her twenties.
In 1977 Gross took refuge with ChÃ¶gyam Trungpa Rinpoche, becoming a Tibetan Buddhist. In 2005 she was made a lopÃ¶n (Tibetan (Wylie): slob dpon; Sanskrit (IAST): ÄcÄrya, "senior teacher") by JetsÃ¼n Khandro Rinpoche, and taught at Jetsun Khandro Rinpoche's Lotus Garden Center, located in the United States.
Gross grew up on a dairy farm in the Rhinelander, Wisconsin area. Gross died, of a stroke, on November 11, 2015, at her home in Eau Claire, Wisconsin.

Title: Vimalakirti Retreat - Session 3 Of 3
Caption or Other Speaker:
Presenter: Robert Thurman

Robert Alexander Farrar Thurman (born August 3, 1941) is an American Buddhist author and academic who has written, edited, and translated several books on Tibetan Buddhism. He is the father of actress Uma Thurman. He is the Je Tsongkhapa Professor of Indo- Tibetan Buddhist Studies at Columbia University, holding the first endowed chair in this field of study in the United States. He also is the co-founder and president of the Tibet House New York. He translated the Vimalakirti Sutra from the Tibetan Kanjur into English. 

He is the author of the following works:

    The Holy Teaching of Vimalakirti: A Mahayana Scripture, Pennsylvania State University Press, 2000, ISBN 9780271012094
    The Central Philosophy of Tibet: A Study and Translation of Jey Tsong Khapa's Essence of True Eloquence, Princeton University Press, 1991 ISBN 9780691020679
    The Tibetan Book of the Dead: The Natural Liberation Through Understanding in the Between Bantam Doubleday Dell, 1994 (translations in Spanish, French, German, Italian, Korean, Japanese, Chinese, Russian) ISBN 9780553370904
    Essential Tibetan Buddhism, Castle Books, 1995 ISBN 9780062510518
    Wisdom and Compassion: The Sacred Art of Tibet, Abrams, 1996 ISBN 9780810939851
    Mandala: The Architecture of Enlightenment, Shambhala Publications, 1997 ISBN 9780500280188
    World of Transformation: Masterpieces of Tibetan Sacred Art in the Donald Rubin Collection (with Marilyn Rhie), Tibet House/Abrams, 1999 ISBN 978-0810963870
    Inner Revolution: Life, Liberty, and the Pursuit of Real Happiness, Penguin, 1999 ISBN 9781573227193
    Circling the Sacred Mountain: A Spiritual Adventure Through the Himalayas with Tad Wise, Bantam Doubleday Dell, 1999 ISBN 9780553103465
    Infinite Life: Seven Virtues for Living Well, Riverhead Books, 2004, ISBN 9781594480690
    The Universal Vehicle Discourse Literature (with Lozang Jamspal, et al.), Columbia University Press, 2005 ISBN 9780975373408
    The Jewel Tree of Tibet: The Enlightenment Engine of Tibetan Buddhism, Free Press/Simon & Schuster, 2005 ISBN 9780743257633
    Anger: of the Seven Deadly Sins, Oxford University Press, 2005, ISBN 9780195169751
    Life and Teachings of Tsongkhapa, Library of Tibetan Works and Archives, 2006, ISBN 9788186470442
    Why the Dalai Lama Matters: His Act of Truth as the Solution for China, Tibet and the World, Atria Books/Beyond Words, 2008, ISBN 9781582702209
    A Shrine for Tibet: The Alice Kandell Collection with Marylin Rhie, Overlook, 2010 ISBN 9780967011578
    Brilliant Illumination of the Lamp of the Five Stages, Columbia University Press, 2011, ISBN 9781935011002
    Love Your Enemies: How To Break the Anger Habit & Be a Whole Lot Happier with Sharon Salzberg, Hay House, 2013 ISBN 9781401928148

Title: Gay & Lesbian Practice Retreat - Session 3 Of 3
Caption or Other Speaker:
Presenter: Jeffrey Hopkins

Jeffrey Hopkins (born 1940) is an American Tibetologist. He is Emeritus of Tibetan and Buddhist Studies at the University of Virginia, where he taught since 1973. He has authored more than twenty-five books about Tibetan Buddhism, among them the highly influential Meditation on Emptiness, which appeared in 1983, offering a pioneering exposition of Prasangika-Madyamika thought in the Geluk tradition. From 1979 to 1989 he was the Dalai Lama's chief interpreter into English and he played a significant role in the development of the Free Tibet Movement.In 2006 he published his English translation of a major work by the Jonangpa lama, Dolpopa, on the Buddha Nature and Emptiness called Mountain Doctrine.

Title: Ango "Syndromes" And Other Topics - Mondo
Caption or Other Speaker:
Daido quotes from â€œOn Ango - the Training Periodâ€ by Dogen Zenji
â€œ . . . If we experience the inner essence of the training period, we can push on. And, all our actions: taking meals, stretching out our feet and sleeping will be forms of training throughout our lives.
If we grasp this, we will be diligent and not relaxed for even a moment. Such action is the ninety day training period. This is the key point, an original face of the Buddhas and Ancestors. It is here that we touch their skin, flesh, bones and marrow. The days and months of a ninety-day spring training period carry the enlightened vision and essence of the Buddhas and Ancestors. Even in just one term of spring training, people become Buddhas and Ancestors. Both the beginning and end of the training period are the Buddhas and Ancestors. Outside of this, there is nothing, neither large nor small. . .â€
Speaker: John Daido Loori

In addition, he holds a formal mondo to address questions raised by the Sangha.
Speaker: John Daido Loori

Title: Vimalakirtiâ€™s Gate Of Non-Duality
Caption or Other Speaker:
We have everything we need to be free--we simply have to put aside wanting to be comfortable. In this heartfelt and inspiring discourse, Daido Roshi explores how every moment presents an opportunity. We can understand the teachings and adopt the forms. This is easy. But to truly challenge ourselves--to practice the edge we've been avoiding--is to find true freedom.

To understand the Buddhist teachings and adopt the Zen forms is the easy part. But to truly challenge ourselves and turn toward the places we've been avoiding is the path to true freedom. Every moment presents us with this opportunity.
Speaker: John Daido Loori

Title: Bodhidharma Retreat - Session 3 Of 3
Caption or Other Speaker:
Retreat given by John R McRae.

John R. McRae (1947â€“2011) was a renowned expert on Chinese Chan who also possessed an extensive knowledge of the field of Buddhism in general. After getting a PhD at Yale University, he taught at Cornell and Indiana Universities before moving to Japan and teaching part-time at Komazawa University. As a specialist in East Asian Buddhism, he was especially interested in ideologies of spiritual cultivation and how they interact with their intellectual and cultural environments. His seminal work on Chinese Chan was The Northern School and the Formation of Early Chan Buddhism (University of Hawai`i Press, 1986). This was later followed by Seeing through Zen: Encounter, Transformation, and Genealogy in Chinese Chan Buddhism (University of California Press, 2003). He spent much of his career studying the life of the important Chan figure Shenhui (684â€“758), and was expecting to complete a manuscript on the topic before his passing in October of 2011 from pancreatic cancer. John also completed a number of translations of Chinese Buddhist scriptural texts for the BukkyÅ DendÅ KyÅkai's English translation series, and served as Chair of the Publication Committee for the series until his passing.
Speaker: Other

Title: Great Faith, Great Courage, Great Question
Caption or Other Speaker:
Dharma Talk given by Zen Master Soeng Hyang (Barbara Rhodes)

"Three essential elements of Zen: having great faith, great courage, and a question - a great question."

About the presenter: Zen Master Soeng Hyang, Barbara Rhodes, or Bobby, as she is known to many people, was one of Zen Master Seung Sahnâ€™s first American students and began studying with him in 1972. She was given inka, or permission to teach, in 1977 and received dharma transmission from Zen Master Seung Sahn in 1992. For many years Bobby worked as a hospice nurse and her practice and teaching was profoundly impacted by sitting with her patients as they transitioned from this body. Today Zen Master Soeng Hyang is the guiding Zen Master of the Kwan Um School of Zen, a Korean lineage, which includes over a hundred centers and temples worldwide.
Speaker: Other

Title: Ease And Disease - Part 3 Of 3
Caption or Other Speaker:
Presenter: Zen Master Soeng Hyang (Barbara Rhodes)

About the presenter: Zen Master Soeng Hyang, Barbara Rhodes, or Bobby, as she is known to many people, was one of Zen Master Seung Sahnâ€™s first American students and began studying with him in 1972. She was given inka, or permission to teach, in 1977 and received dharma transmission from Zen Master Seung Sahn in 1992. For many years Bobby worked as a hospice nurse and her practice and teaching was profoundly impacted by sitting with her patients as they transitioned from this body. Today, Zen Master Soeng Hyang is the guiding Zen Master of the Kwan Um School of Zen, a Korean lineage, which includes over a hundred centers and temples worldwide.

When you are born, where do you come from?
When you die, where do you go?
Life is like a floating cloud that appears.
Death is like a floating cloud that disappears
Life and death, coming and going,
Are also like that.
There is one thing that always remains clear.
Itâ€™s pure. Itâ€™s clear. 
It is not dependent on anything else.
And what is the one pure and clear thing?

Title: To Be Cultivated and Not To Be Cultivated
Caption or Other Speaker:
Bear Gokan Bonebakker, Senior Monastic

Drawing on the teachings of Thich Nhat Hanh, Chan Master Sheng-Yen, and IMS Teacher Joseph Goldstein, Gokan offers insight into how we stop creating evil, practice good, and actualize good for others. How does zazen help us to do that, to stay in our own experience? And how do zazen and the precepts give each other life?
Speaker: Bear Gokan Bonebakker

Title: Guishan's Gift
Caption or Other Speaker: Particularly during the holiday season, the virtue of generosity is frequently and casually invoked. But how do we actually practice true giving and true receiving? Shugen Roshi describes giving in harmony with receiving, not looking for something in return â€“ a generosity which is deeply authentic even when only great effort can bring it forth.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Title: Nanyue's "It's Not Like Something"
Caption or Other Speaker: In this talk, Shugen Roshi takes up the lines central to our Ango study of Buddha ancestors: â€œI am like this. You are like this. All the ancestors in India were like this.â€ Through the lens of Master Dongshanâ€™s Five Ranks, he speaks of the importance of practicing, actualizing and transmitting that which is always present and cannot be taught.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Title: Ever Intimate With Thinking
Caption or Other Speaker: â€œWe bow in deep respect to Prajna Paramita, mother of all Buddhas. She illuminates our delusion and dispels all fear.â€ Hojin Sensei uses this line from the daily liturgy to urge us to â€œentertain our delusions as guests,â€ learning to regard what may seem like a hindrance as the very means of our awakening.
Speaker: Jody Hojin Kimmel

Title: Calling In The Ancestors
Caption or Other Speaker:
Danica Shoan Ankele, Senior Monastic

In this talk, Shoan evokes the pervasive presence of the ancestors in our practice of zazen, oryoki, and liturgy. She cites the writings of women ancestors across space and time, speaking to the mystical truth-seeking heart of every religious tradition.
Speaker: Danica Shoan Ankele

Title: Virtue, Concentration, Discernment
Caption or Other Speaker: â€œConcentration nurtured with virtue is of great fruit, great reward. Discernment nurtured with concentration is of great fruit, great reward. The mind nurtured with discernment is rightly released.â€ In this talk from Novemberâ€™s Shuso Hossen Sesshin, Shugen Roshi delves into this simple yet profound teaching from the Pali Canon. Ethical action, meditation and insight rely on and support each other, he notes, forming a unified path which can address the many aspects of our humanity.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Title: Jukai Ceremony
Caption or Other Speaker: Shugen Roshi officiates a ceremony in which Nancy Meyer-Emerick (Eisho, â€œeternal bloomâ€), Constanza Ontaneda (Sokyo, â€œeveryday sutraâ€), Steve Miron (Seigan, â€œsacred eyeâ€), Achong Chen (Jusan, â€œpearl mountainâ€), Jonathan Rosenthal (Seiko, â€œboundless peaceâ€), and Polly Horn (Kiho, â€œradiant dharmaâ€) receive the sixteen Buddhist precepts and are given their new dharma names.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Talk Location: Zen Center of New York City
Title: Mondo on the Jataka Tales: Hairy Kassapa
Caption or Other Speaker: Hogen Sensei leads the last of three group study sessions on the Jataka Tales, legends about the previous lives of the Buddha found in the Pali Canon. Here he takes up the story of Kassapa, an ascetic whose almost abandons his commitment to non-harming in order to marry the kingâ€™s beautiful daughter, Candavati. The discussion focuses on gender, desire, objectification, and what it means to study texts from cultural contexts different than our own.
Speaker: Ron Hogen Green

Talk Location: Zen Center of New York City
Title: Mondo on the Jataka Tales: Buddha as Robber, Teacher as Thief
Caption or Other Speaker: In the second of three sessions looking at the Jataka Tales, Hogen Sensei leads a group study of one of the Buddhaâ€™s past lives in which, oddly enough, he was the leader of a gang. What can learn from this tale about our own choices in life? What can we learn about the long road of karma?
Speaker: Ron Hogen Green

Title: Images And Dream Phenomena Retreat
Caption or Other Speaker:
Harry A. Wilmer was born in 1917 and earned his BA, MB and PhD. at the University of Minnesota, and later trained in psychiatry at the Mayo clinic. Wilmer began his career as a Freudian analyst but adopted a Jungian approach after receiving Jungian analyst training in Zurich.

In 1955 Wilmer was drafted into the U.S. Navy and served at the Oak Knoll Naval Hospital in Oakland, California where he oversaw the care of Naval and Marine Corps patients with a variety of mental disorders. While serving at Oak Knoll, Wilmer developed his approach to group therapy, and integrated video technology into his practice. His observations about group interaction eventually led to his book Social Psychiatry in Action, later developed into the 1961 docudrama People Need People, hosted by Fred Astaire.

Dr. Wilmer continued his group therapy work in the late 1960's through the University of California at San Francisco, eventually establishing the Youth Drug Ward at the Langely Porter Neuropsychiatric Institute. The Youth drug ward served young hippies from the Haight-Ashbury district who had experienced adverse affects from drug use. The therapy included "creativity seminars" which featured such artists as Joan Baez and Rod Steiger. Also during the 1960s, Wilmer worked extensively with inmates from the San Quentin prison and their families.

In 1969 Dr. Wilmer moved to Texas and became professor of Psychiatry at the University of Texas Health Sciences Center at San Antonio. While there he provided therapy at a Veterans Hospital for Vietnam War veterans who were suffering from PTSD. He later expanded his practice to those affected by AIDS.

Dr. Wilmer retired from psychiatry in 1980 and the same year established the Institute for the Humanities at Salado, where he hosted artists, scholars and other speakers to conduct workshops and give lectures. Dr. Wilmer was a prolific writer with such titles to his name as Practical Jung: Nuts and Bolts of Jungian Psychotherapy, Closeness in Personal and Professional Relationships, How Dreams Help and many more.
Speaker: Other

Title: The Sutra Of Complete Awakening
Caption or Other Speaker:
Book of Equanimity = Book of Serenity

Presenter: Gerry Shishin Wick, Roshi

Gerry Shishin Wick is a Soto Zen roshi, author, oceanographer and abbot of Great Mountain Zen Center in Berthoud, Colorado, which he founded in 1996. He is one of the twelve Dharma Successors of the late Taizan Maezumi, receiving Dharma transmission and a Denkai (precept transmission) from him in 1990. Prior to it, for 24 years he underwent Zen training with Maezumi, Shunryu Suzuki Roshi and Sochu Suzuki Roshi. He remained the president of White Plum Asanga, a Zen school in the Hakuyu Taizan Maezumi lineage, from 2007 to 2014.

He has a Ph.D. in physics from the University of California, Berkeley, and has held a variety of jobs in the scientific community as well as an adjunct teaching position at Naropa University in Boulder, Colorado. He also administered the Zen Center of Los Angeles and the Kuroda Institute for the Study of Buddhism and Human Values from 1978 to 1986. In 2006, Wick received inka from Bernard Glassman. He was acknowledged as a Roshi in 2000 at White Plum Asanga, where he remained the president from 2007 to 2014, when he retired as an elder.
Speaker: Other

Title: Victim/Victimizer- Seeing Both Sides Retreat (1992) - Part 4 Of 4 - Dharma Talk
Caption or Other Speaker:
Dharma talk given by Jan Chozen Bays Roshi and Laren Hogen Bays Roshi, who gave this weekend's retreat, "Victim/Victimizer- Seeing Both Sides".

Jan Chozen Bays Roshi is a pediatrician and nationally recognized expert on child abuse. In the 1980s and 1990s, she conducted the medical examinations of thousands of infants and children who had been abused or killed and regularly appeared in court as an expert witness. In 1987, she helped to found Child Abuse Response and Evaluation Services (CARES) Northwest, now one of the oldest and largest child abuse assessment centers in the United States.

Since 1985 Chozen, Roshi has been the teacher for Zen Community of Oregon. In 2002 she helped to found Great Vow Zen Monastery and is the co-abbot. In 2011 she also helped found Heart of Wisdom Zen Temple in Portland, Oregon.
Speaker: Other

In 1987, she helped to found Child Abuse Response and Evaluation Services (CARES) Northwest, now one of the oldest and largest child abuse assessment centers in the United States.

Since 1985 Chozen, Roshi has been the teacher for Zen Community of Oregon. In 2002 she helped to found Great Vow Zen Monastery and is the co-abbot. In 2011 she also helped found Heart of Wisdom Zen Temple in Portland, Oregon.

Laren Hogen Bays Roshi holds a Naturopathic Doctor (ND) and Masterâ€™s Degree (MS) in Psychology and worked as a consultant for the Oregon Department of Corrections for fifteen years, assessing and treating men who were incarcerated for violent physical and sexual crimes. 

He has been a leader of Zen Community of Oregon since 1985 and worked full-time for the sangha since 1997. He is co-abbot of Great Vow Zen Monastery.

Title: Zhaozhou's "Mu"- Meeting The Gatekeeper
Caption or Other Speaker: Encountering the barrier is a unique and critical aspect of Zen training. But what is the barrier? In this talk on the first koan of a student's formal training, Ryushin Sensei explores what causes our suffering and brings us to practice, how to work with a barrier in the context of Zen training, and the teacher's unique role as "gatekeeper" of what is often referred to as the "gateless gate."
Speaker: Konrad Ryushin Marchaj

Title: Spring 2009 Ango Art Presentations, Part 2
Caption or Other Speaker: Various speakers.
Speaker: Other

Title: Zhaozhou's "Mu" - Realize Complete Freedom
Caption or Other Speaker: Our practice rests on our question--the depth and sincerity of our inquiry into the nature of suffering, the self, of life and death. To embody our question, we must practice with our whole heart, casting away all the obstacles we put in our path. This requires great trust in ourselves and unflagging perseverance. In this talk on the introductory koan of Zen Buddhist training, Shugen Sensei explores what kind of effort is required to realize complete freedom.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Title: Bodhidharma's Skin, Flesh, Bones, And Marrow
Extracted Text:
The Deepest Realization

What are the attributes of a person with great spiritual realization?  This eye-opening dharma discourse by Geoffrey Shugen Arnold,  Sensei explores a koan in which the Zen master Bodhidharma asks his students to express their realization and then transmits his role as teacher to one of the students.  Shugen Sensei warns us not to make the typical assumption that the recipient's realization was higher than his peers.  He demonstrates that this tendency to compare leads to many of the world's problems and inequalities, and specifically discusses the greed involved in the privatization of American prisons.  Indeed, spiritual realization entails ceasing to compare others, and instead, seeing the perfection in everyone.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Title: Ma Tsu's Permutations Of Assertion And Denial
Extracted Text:
Sudden or Gradual?

Does enlightenment come suddenly or gradually?  Is it helpful or necessary to use concepts to guide our spiritual practice?  Or do we need to let go of preconceptions to be open to reality as it is unfolding now?  In this dharma discourse, Konrad Ryushin Marchaj, Sensei addresses this quandary from citing approaches as gradual as understanding the twelve links in the chain of interdependent coordination and as sudden as the teacher striking the student in numerous Zen discourses.  We are urged to find our practice and ourselves within the dynamic tension of this question.
Speaker: Konrad Ryushin Marchaj

Title: Kuei Shan Attends On Pai Chang
Extracted Text: Ryushin Sensei talks about the nature of language and the nature of how we hear each other in regards to the question of expressing the Self with your lips and throat shut.

Title: Lingzhao's "bright And Clear"
Extracted Text:
Clarity in the Midst of Chaos

We take the genuine spiritual path of renunciation when we realize that our habits, fixations, and craving cause suffering for ourselves and others.  In order to see the roots our our neurosis and become free, we must cultivate deep silence and stillness. This can cause the insanity and suffering within the world to be much more apparent to us. However, Geoffrey Shugen Arnold, Sensei warns us that we cannot allow the calm of spiritual practice to become a hiding place.  Instead, we must see the clarity that is always present, even in the midst of chaos of the world.  By trusting this inherent clarity, we can work within the world with wisdom and compassion.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Title: Tan Hsia's Have You Eaten Yet?
Extracted Text:
The Seeing That Comes Before Looking

n zen practice, we are often admonished to cease looking outside of ourselves.  What does this really mean?  In the beginning, it can be interpreted as letting go of the illusion that if only we had the right conditions we would be content.  However, we often enter spiritual life with the same attitude: that if only our practice was more ideal, then we would realize ourselves.  According to Konrad Ryushin Marchaj, Sensei, the novice practitioner looks in order to see.  To deepen our practice, we must recognize the seeing that comes before looking, as if we are becoming aware of the source of a light rather than the object that is illuminated.  Only then will our inherent clarity and freedom become available to us.
---
What does it mean to look deeply within? To plumb the depths of our being, we need to recognize the "seeing that comes before looking," becoming aware of the source of the light, rather than the object it illuminates.  

No view; error of practice; casting off into the ocean; you are the only hope to correct this error; error of zen; error of practice
Speaker: Konrad Ryushin Marchaj

Title: Neither The Wind Nor The Flag
Extracted Text:
Tell Me I'm Right

How many arguments could be avoided if we simply recognized our underlying desire to be affirmed? How often are we more concerned about getting our point across than the feelings of those with whom we are communicating? By letting go of our attachments we discover that being right isn't what we really  care about. 

Seventy percent of flies take the edge off when there is an edge. Fifty percent take the edge off when there isn't an edge. Thirty percent practice and enter the edge.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Title: Wu Chiu's Unjust Beating
Extracted Text:
The Person Of No Rank

If we really want freedom for ourselves and others, we must let go of seeking status. Indeed, we must let go of the desire to rely on any fixed identity and be open to assuming whatever role is appropriate in each situation that we encounter. Only then will we experience true freedom and fellowship with others.
Speaker: Konrad Ryushin Marchaj

Title: Chin Niu's Rice Pail
Extracted Text:
Happiness Without Conditions

How many times have we searched for happiness and ended up disappointed or even worse, regretful? We are conditioned to search for temporary happiness in things that eventually leave us feeling wanting. Once we stop searching outside of ourselves, we can find the true joy that exists in every moment. 


WZEN: "Giving Up the Happiness Game" How many times have we searched for happiness and ended up disappointed or, even worse, regretful?  In our delusion, we continually search for temporary happiness in the fleeting, shifting things of this world. Yet to truly resolve our suffering,  we need to stop looking outside and discover the true joy of fully experiencing our life as it is.
Speaker: Konrad Ryushin Marchaj

Title: Dharma Encounter on Earth Day
Extracted Text: We look at the world and see the distress it is in yet in Buddhism it is said that everything is inherently perfect. On this Earth Day Shugen Sensei takes up the questions our current "situation," a word too small to describe what is actually taking place. How can we as dharmic practioners, as inhabitants of this Earth help? Is is a spritual matter, is it an economic matter, is there a difference? It seems that no matter what we do, love should be the driving force behind it. We must develop wisdom and compassion and fuel our efforts and our protests with love. How do we apply Mayu's fanning himself to the state of affairs we are in now?
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Title: Ta Lung' Hard And Fast Body Of Reality
Extracted Text:
Flowing with the Current of Reality

Ryushin Sensei takes the Buddha's well-known metaphor of practice as "going against the current" and looks at practice from a slightly different vantage point: although this journey goes against the flow of conventional living, a life of selfless activity actually goes with the flow of reality.
Speaker: Konrad Ryushin Marchaj

Title: Jiufeng's "Head and Tail"
Extracted Text:
On The Ground

It is not enough to have insight; we must be able to put it into action in our lives. That's why it's said that wisdom without compassion is not true wisdom. We have the ability to act for the benefit of all beings, but we must be willing to let go of all abstract notions about practice, so we can truly bring it to life. 

WZEN:
The Banner of Truth 

When we feel too busy to practice, too distracted to focus, too fearful to face our own mind, we turn away from the truth of our life. In this helpful and inspiring talk, Shugen Sensei encourages us to move beyond tension and conflict and harmonize our body and mind with reality.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Title: Hsuan Sha's Guiding And Aiding Living Beings
Extracted Text:
WZEN:

Nowhere Else

If you're seeking the direct teaching, realize that all the teachings are pointing to you, here, now. We have to trust and be willing to give ourselves completely, to let go into the complete simplicity of this moment.
Speaker: Konrad Ryushin Marchaj

Title: Fayan's Substance And Name
Extracted Text:
The Root Of Suffering

All of our suffering is born out of our seemingly intractable attachments. Yet zazen is the practice of non-abiding. That's why it has the power to show us that we are already free. Knowing this truth won't help us, but realizing it will transform our lives.  

WZEN: "Everywhere is Maitreya" -- 
Where does it all come from? The Buddhadharma teaches that all things are established from a non-abiding basis, but what does that mean, particularly for our day-to-day practice? Shugen Sensei draws on the teachings of Dogen Zenji and the Vimalakirti Sutra as he guides us in exploring the nature of mind and reality, the arising of wisdom and compassion.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Title: Yen Kuan's Rhinoceros
Extracted Text:
The Perfect Note

In this powerful talk, Ryushin Sensei hones in on the painful truth of our fascination with our attachments and the need for letting  them go completely. This process requires bravery and the willingness to be completely honest, so we may find the perfect note that expresses the unity and wholeness of our lives.
Speaker: Konrad Ryushin Marchaj

Title: Chih Men's Body Of Wisdom
Extracted Text:
The Single Thread

In this dharma discourse Ryushin Sensei challenges us to recognize the body of wisdom which is our very life. How do we engage in activity in the world without falling into one side or the other of our habitual, dualistic ways of thinking? We need to understand that without stillness, without that commitment to look at oneself persistently and honestly, there’s no chance we can offer the deep wisdom that this world so desperately needs.
Speaker: Konrad Ryushin Marchaj

Title: Chao Chou's Three Turning Words

The Other Shore Arrives

We are so used to our linear thinking that we do not question our assumptions about time, about beginnings and endings, or completion. But these landmarks are illusions that we use to keep ourselves safe, and when we are able to let go, we see there is no passing, nothing to complete, no place we need to go.

Title: Buddhadharma at the Beginning of the New Year
Caption or Other Speaker:
The Advantage of New Years ( part 2 )
A monk asked Jinqing Daofu,"Is there Buddha Dharma at the beginning of the year or not?
Jingqing said, "There is."
The monk asked, "What is the Buddha Dharma at the beginning of the new year?"
Jingqing said, :" New year is auspicious. The myriad things are new.
etc...

Shugen focused on the first and the last parts of the koan. Master Jingqing's answer and Master Dogen's comments on the answers.

He talked:
- about the newness of things... how in a sense being creatures of habit
even if we want to experience the freshness of the moment and get rid of the burden of the past, we can be afraid of the unknown and step back.
What is new has not existed before, never occurred before, but the Buddha said: "everything is completely the same and completely different simultaneously, without conflict."

- about the vows of the teachers to alleviate the students's sufferings; the student has to die to his personal self, to what he calls himself.

- about the inner journey being the greatest and the most difficult journey.

- about the great generosity of Master Dogen stating that everyone's life is blessed ( sentient and insentient) expressing the great love of the Bodhisattva, helping to realize that this very life is the place of liberation.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Talk Location: Zen Center of New York City
Title: Buddhadharma at the Beginning of the New Year
Caption or Other Speaker:
from Master Dogen's  Eihei Koroku
Is there Buddha Dharma in new year's day?
The teacher answers: " Yes. This is an auspicious time. The myriad things are all new". The student thanks the teacher for his answer. The teacher says: today, I have lost some virtue.
Another student asks the same question to another teacher, who answers: " No. No Buddha Dharma in new year's day".
Same question and apparently different answers.

During the Zazenkai discourse, Shugen focused on the second part of the koan.

Importance of beginnings and the level of preparedness required for each beginning.
He talked about the delight and the rejoicing in virtue necessary for true practice and how dedicating merits are essential, how heart/mind have to be unified.
While marking a beginning could be seen as artificial, we can sense in it the opportunity it offers even if it is part of a continuum.
Buddha dharma is the ultimate truth and the teachers answered from this truth, from this free place. It is not fixed and cannot be compared; it is the nature of everything, true all the time.
The buddha taught to look closer than what the senses inform us, look beyond the names. If we allow the mind to rest, we can experience that the qualities we thought were solid and fixed are not so.
For this relaxation to occur we need to have profound trusting in what is, not to create conflict in our mind; we have to get rid of plans and agenda to fit our purposes and move in accord with our true nature.
Teachers are dedicated to help their student see this ultimate truth and to trust the bare simplicity of their own mind.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Title: Baofu's Blocking of the Eyes, Ears, and Mind
Caption or Other Speaker: When we look at the world around us, we rarely perceive reality as it is. Our preconceived notions and biases are hidden to us, inseparable from what we see as the real world. In this poignant talk, Shugen Sensei relates this Buddhist teaching to current events, including the Trayvon Martin murder. He reminds us why we practice--to see reality clearly so we can put an end to suffering.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Talk Location: Zen Center of New York City
Title:
Daitsu Chisho


Who Is It That's Binding You?



Acting From A Perceived Sense Of Self-existence Creates A Gap Between 'me' And What I Perceive. Although It Is An Illusion, This Gap Is The Cause Of All Suffering So We Try To Fill The Gap With Objects Such As Cars, Relationships, And So Forth. Once We Begin To See More Clearly, We Realize That We Are Responsible For For Our Own Mind And That We Don't Need To Be Saved Or Made Whole. We Can Discover Our Own Natural Completeness.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Title: Zhongyi's Monkey
Extracted Text: Every aspect of our experience -- everything we see, feel, think -- is Buddha nature.  There is nothing beyond the universe of our senses. Yet, as the Identity of Relative and Absolute says, each and all subjective spheres are identical yet independent.  How is it, then, that our subjective universes fit together?  In fact, this interrelationship is what this path is all about.
Speaker: Konrad Ryushin Marchaj

Title: Proliferation-Free Zone
Caption or Other Speaker: On Sunday, June 22nd, Hojin Osho offered a talk on papanka, the Pali term for mental proliferation. As Hojin explains, papanka is the mental world we create with our thoughts, concretizing our mental experiences and calling them real, rather than practicing mindfulness and seeing reality itself. She discusses how papanka is a cause of suffering in our lives and how mindfulness frees us from its unwholesome influence. She sums up her talk with the advice of the Buddha: "The best friend is a well-trained mind; the worst enemy is a poorly-trained mind."
Speaker: Jody Hojin Kimmel

Title: The Beautiful-Awful
Caption or Other Speaker:
Hojin Osho offered this talk during Fall 2016 Wild Grasses Sesshin:

“I wanted to talk today about story, and how the stories of women have helped me. And in particular two women I’ll take up today: Rengetsu who wrote this [poem, “Field of Wild Grasses”], who I have a real affinity for—I’ll tell you about her haughty life—and Patachara. Because, over these years, I’ve been looking for stores about loss and grief and how my ancestors practiced[….]

“[Rengetsu] found out what mattered most through these ruptures:

‘The evanescence of
This floating world
 I feel over and over:
It is hardest
To be the one left behind.
I can only sob
and sob.’

“She recognized impermanence was for real, not just on an intellectual level. And I remember how long that took, to really feel this is not going to last. […] The rupture is nature. It makes adjustments to what’s needed and what to trust in being it. She trusts in her not knowing the depths of wisdom and love that can open in a human heart—if we enter the journey into our darkness, back into the light, into our darkness, into the light. I like to call it ‘the beautiful-awful’.”
Speaker: Jody Hojin Kimmel

Title: To Be Enlightened By The World: 2016 Fall Ango Intensive, Part 3
Caption or Other Speaker: Continuing the retreat-weekend's thematic progression·activating awareness in zazen and then bringing it into liturgy, from stillness into activity·Shugen Sensei leads the sangha in examining how we can bring bring our attention into the activity of Right Livelihood. In particular, he asks, "How do you remember?"  He explains, "What we translate as 'Mindfulness' means 'to remember, to remember, to remember'·this very deliberate, very conscious part of practicing the living Way. [.] [I]f we think of the elements of an offering, of a prostration, of zazen, then those are the elements that we can bring forward into our work, into our relationships. And in that way, those become reminders·living reminders·and not just reminders but practice, because we're not just remembering. Within remembering, we're practicing." Sangha members respond and ask questions.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Title: To Be Enlightened by the World: Fall 2016 Ango Intensive, Part .5 Bonus – Chanting the First Half of "Genjokoan"
Caption or Other Speaker: The assembled ZMM sangha begins the ango intensive by chanting the first half of Master Dogen's "Genjokoan". (Shoan is the liturgist.)

Title: To Be Enlightened by the World: 2016 Fall Ango Intensive – Part 1
Caption or Other Speaker:
Friday Morning Retreat-Session

Shugen Sensei and the sangha explore the role of faith in Zen practice and reflect on personal experiences of the practice of zazen, examining Master Dogen’s Fukan Zazengi (“Universally Recommended Instructions for Zazen”) and the core text of the ango, Genjokoan.
Speaker: Geoffrey Shugen Arnold

Title: Emperor Ko's Hat
Caption or Other Speaker:
Book of Equanimity = Book of Serenity

. . . Weâ€™ve got a responsibility in this country. Nobody will chop your head off if you practice your religion. Youâ€™re not going to get thrown into jail â€“ not yet anyway - if you practice moral and ethical values. (Or, maybe you will go to jail. It depends on the kind of action you take. Sometimes thatâ€™s the price).

But, we have a responsibility. Itâ€™s called practice. And, practice means more than just sitting crosslegged on the pillow - more than just clarifying ourselves. The question is, â€œHow do you bring out the Dharma Jewel in your time, in your season? How do you follow the example of the Buddha, Nagarjuna, Asoka, the National Teachersâ€? Each time and season was different. Each Upaya was of a different form.

[Your] question is, â€œWhat is the form for you? Now? What is the form for your life? My life? How will you do it?â€

And most importantly, â€œWhen will you do it?â€ Keep in mind that you only have now to work with. Thereâ€™s nothing else.


John Daido Loori
Dharma Talk: Emperor Koâ€™s Hat
